div.p: ASTREA. A ROMANCE, WRITTEN IN FRENCH, BY Meire Honorè D'Vrfe; AND TRANSLATED BY A Peron of Quality.
The econd Volume.
LONDON, Printed by W. W. for H. Moely, Y. Dring, and H. Herringman: And are to be old at their Shops in St Pauls Church-yard, Fleettreet, and in the Lower walke in the New Exchange, 1657.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p: HAving in the Epitle to the precedent Volume inited on the generall advantages accrewing to Mankind by Romances, and particularly by this of Atrea above any other, ome would haply imagine there were no more to be done in this, than to tell the Reader that this is a econd Volume of the ame excellent ASTREA, when he hath the Book already in his hands. This were an imagination flat enough, even though, out of an exces of foreight, they hould further upect it were the Stationer's deigne to commend both, by telling him, that, As good entertainment begets confidence; o the world's kind reception of the former, had contributed much to the publihing of this Second Volum. No, thee are Cajolleries, and Artifices may haply be excuable before uch Books, as, like pittifull Shewes, mut needs have a Trumpet or a Jack. pudding at the Doore, that is, uch as would urprie people into a credulity, not a little prejudiciall to their Ey • s, their memorie, their Undertanding, and their Pures.

Know therefore, that this proceeds not from private Interet, but publique atisfaction; and is not o much the deigne of the Stationer, in point of advantage, as (o welcome is this Piece abroad) an effect of the Buyer's expectation and importunity; and thence he peremptorily affirmes, that the better his Bookes ell, the greater obligation he puts on the world. This ome may thinke a Paradox; but to hew it is demontrable, I need onely ay, that the more a Booke is bought up, the more are people inform'd, the more intructed, the more edifi'd; which who looks not on as of much greater conequence than the price, is
a peron certainly of no great correpondence with Letters. If o, how then are we oblig'd to thoe who pend their endeavours and Etates to atisfie our Curioity, to harpen our imaginations, to rectifie our judgements, to purifie our language, to perfect our morality, to regulate our deportments, and to heighten and inflame our more generous inclinations, nay to acquaint us with all that is pleaant, all that is excellent, all that is extraordinary in human Actions? And thee are the true deigns and ends of Works of this nature; Thee are Academies for the Lover, Schools of War for the Souldier, and Cabinets for the Statesman; they are the Correctives of paion, the retoratives of converation; they are the entertainments of the ound, and the divertiements of the ick; in a word, the mot delightful accommodations of civill life.

div.head: Book I.
div.p: AFter it was determined amongt the hepheardees of Lignon, to go all together within three dayes upon a viit unto the diguied Alexis; Love, whoe cutome is to torment thoe mot, who are mot devoted unto it, began to make the hepheardee Atrea enible of uch odd panges of trange impatiencies, that he could not give any good account of reaon for them. She found in her elfe uch a violent deire of eeing Alexis, becaue every one reported her o reemblant unto Celadon; that the prejudicated mind of this age hepheardee, was fully reolved to love her before yet he ever aw her; or rather, this foretalled reolution was a forerunner of a mot great and impatient love: o as it may be aid, that this new love was implanted in her very Nature, ince it produced in her, all the conequences and effects which love ueth in the oul of a zealous lover: o as three dayes which were to be expired before they went this long deired viit, eemed unto her three long and tedious yeares: And he would with all her heart have been contented to abate o many yeares of her life, upon condition thee three dayes were done, that he might injoy her hop't for contentment: But when Alexis undertood by her Brother, that Atrea was to come to ee her very hortly, oh how this diguied Dru de tarted at the newes? he reented two different Paions at once; he was highly joyed, to thinke that he was to be bleed with a ight, of her dearly loved hepheardee, and to talke with her in that diguie: Alo he was damped with a pale feare, when he conidered that her Mitree had reaon to accue her of diobedience, & inning againt her poitive commands; a Crime which was death it elfe unto her to commit; for having untill that time preerved her affections pure and free from all manner of blame, he would much rather chue death, then uffer it to be tained with the leat blur of infidelity or want of repect: but, as all true Lovers ue, her thoughts harped more upon the pleaing tring of her hopes, then upon that which her feares uggeted; o as he begun to thinke this terme of three dayes a long while too, and to be angry with thoe that took o long a term.

Leonide who knew all the ecrets of her heart, and who eemed to be detined never to enjoy what he deired, but to contribute all her endeavours and indutry towards the contentment of another; had not he, I ay, weetned thee tedious dayes by her affability and complaiance, doubtlee the time had been mot irkome unto her. But ee what a bad mater love is, and how ill does he recompene the paines of thoe that erve him; He
did injoyn thee two Lovers with abundance of mutuall affection unto one another, but as if he were unwilling they hould arrive at the um of contentment, he kept them ignorant of their happinee, and by this ignorance blated their contentment. For Celadon being condemned unto perpetuall banihment, he laid the fault upon the change in his hepheardees affection: And Atrea having een Celadon throw himelfe into the River of Lignon, he thought, that this hepheards love not being able to endure the cruelty of her command he had choen death before the inupportable entence of her anger; and this conideration cot her abundance of bitter repentance, many a ad igh, and a very deluge of Teares. This impatiently expected day drawing nigh, and being earnetly deired both by this new Druide, and by the new love of Atrea, both of them not being able to tay o long as till the Sunne was up, they quitted their beds upon the firt bluh of Aurora. Celadon, as mot vigilant, called the Sun luggard, and conjured Aurora to open the windowes of Heaven quickly, that thereby this happy and long'd for day might receive a beginning. Whilt this retlee hepheard was in this longing expectation, and condemning the Suns low motion, day did by degrees enlighten his Chamber; o as auming Druids habit, he left the Name of Celadon, and in lieu of it aumed the Notion of Daughter unto Adamas; happy had he been, could he have left off his Paion as he did his habit; but Celadons heart was till the ame in any diguie, and nothing could work a change in it but death.

Being thus clad in the habit of Alexis, as oon as the doores of the houe were open, he walked alone into a little Grove which had the view of the Plaine; and from whence he could ee the whole Coure of the delightfull River of Lignon: As oon as ever he cat his eye that way, it preently topped at the place where Atrea dwelt, and thinking upon the happy dayes which he had pent in that place, when in his own habit he was freely allowed to be with his beloved hepheardee; Oh what abundance of ighs did this thought force from him? He began to recollect into his memory, all the weet and kind anwers which ever he had given him, when being forced by the violence of his love, he begged ome aurances of affection from her: Here he reveived the memory of all the traveres and thwartings which Alcipes and Hipolite ued; he did not forget the avernee of Alces, nor the anger of their Parents, nor his long travels, nor any ubtiltie which love had taught him: Alo he punctually remembred Atreas contancy in all difficulties, nor did he forget any circumtance, which might be any argument of her love once unto him. Then preently after conidering how the cae tood now, and how he had banihed him her preence, alo looking upon that fatal place where he received that dimall entence, Yonder (aid he, and pointed to the place with his finger) yonder's the place detined to Ravih from me all my joyes, and to be the beginning of all my mieries. But (aid he after a melancholly paue) is it poible o great affection hould ever become uch extreame hatred? Can uch firm Contancy admit of any Change! And can uch perfect happinee be ever turned into uch unlook't for diaters. Then tanding in a mute poture, admiring the trange difference between his life pat, and this preent: Nay, nay, (aid he) never tand wondering at the trangenee of the alteration; but rather wonder, that uch a change hould be, and yet Celadon hould live, ince he hath lot all that can make life weet.

Atrea in the mean time, who had not cloed an eye all the night, no ooner pied the firt bluh of Aurora, but he quitted her Bad, dreed her elfe with all poible hate, and went with all diligence to find out her Companions, who being lee paionate upon the journey then he, had pat away the night with lee inquietude and more ret; And though in her way thither he epied Silvander in the field of Mercury, lying down under the Pillar, yet leat he hould loe time, he would not peak unto him, but hated away towards her Companions, whom he imagined to find leeping, and whom he intended to haten. And indeed he did find them all aleep, he awaked them, called them luggards, and to prompt them unto more hat, pulled the clothes off their beds, and made them wonder at her forwardnee, but the vehemency of her paion might plead her excue: Oh Silvander, how much beholding hadt thou been unto this hepheardee, had he brought thee along with her to be witnee of this Act, in pulling off the Clothes from them? Judge what effects uch a ight would have caued in thee, ince Atrea eeing thoe beauties in that poture, was ravihed with admiration at them, and with a igh, aid, Ah Diana, had you been the third in the Temple, certainly Celadon would have betowed the Apple upon you. Atrea (aid he unto her) You are this morning in uch a mood,
as I mut needs upect your judgement: And as for matter of beauty, I cannot pretend unto it: As I was comming hither (aid Atrea) I aw one who I am ure is of another opinion; and had you een him as I did in the field of Mercury, with folded armes, and eyes lifted up to heaven, you would have better believed what I ay. I know (aid Diana) that you peak of Silvander: but iter, I know again that what he does, is but fained, and upon a wager; Fictions, replyed Atrea, doe never caue reall paions; and call me the mot ignorant peron that lives, if Silvander doe not mot paionately love you, and if his affection, treat him as you will, doe not accompany him to his Grave; for melancholly perons who are low and long before they do love, when once the flame is kindled, it will never be extinguiht in them. I mut confee iter (aid Diana) that when this wager firt began, I had the ame apprehenions. And but becaue you would needs have it o, I hould not have conented unto it, knowing very well how dangerous thee fictions are: but ince the dieae of this hepheard proceeds from the permiion which you have obtained for him from me, I am reolved that this hall be the lat day he hall have leave to continue his Courthip; for I will give judgement betweene Phillis and him in the preence of Alexis and Leonide; the three moneths are determined, and I have deferred it only out of deire that the Nymphs might ee the concluion of the buinee, as he hath the beginning. Atrea being unwilling to dipleae her, was ilent; but Phillis began, Good iter, aid he, doe you think that when your judgement is given, if he doe love you, he will then ceae? I believe (anwered Diana) that he will not then talke to me as he hath done; and if he doe love me, the trouble of it will be his own. Oh Diana, replied Phillis; you are mitaken: for now you may put it off by aying, that what he does is onely to make good his wager; but when this excue is taken away, you will be then obliged to receive his language as in good earnet. What you ay, replied Diana, is very true; but let me tell you, that if he give me any language but what is fitting, I hall give him anwers as hall keep him from any replies. Upon this Phillis began to laugh; My deare Companion, aid he, we have een ome put on uch reolutions, who have been forced to alteration: for tell me, I beeech you, uppoe he hould continue in his addrees after your charge to the contrary, what then? would you kill him for his diobedience? I would not kill him, anwered Diana, but I will give him uch language as if he did love me, he would feare offending me; and if he did not love me, let him doe what he will, he will be weary of it quickly. Nay on the contrary, replied Phillis, If he doe not love you, he will not care how much he dipleaeth you; and if he love you, his affection will not let him obey you in any thing which hall croe his love: for, iter, be aured, that a violent affection may perhaps be thwarted, but never entirely eradicated. Perhaps he will for a time obey your evere commands, but ere long he will cat off all coniderations, and like a Torrent which is topped in its coure, will at lat overflow its own banks, and all the fields about it: So I ay, your forbiddance may for a time be a toppage unto the tream of his violencies; but his affection will at lat break down all before it, and overflow all your commands that obtruct it, and perhaps with uch violence as every one hall ee it. If it hould o fall out, as you may very well expect it will, what can you doe more, but till renew your firt forbiddances? Perhaps your language will be more harp, but alas, words are but words, and too weak to give a check unto one that really loves, as I believe Silvander does. Siter (aid Diana faintly) I never yet met with any uch obtinate Lovers which you peak of; and when I doe, I hall find out a way to be rid from them: Heaven has not made us o mierable, but though they have denyed us trength, yet have they given us prudence enough to preerve our elves.

Thus thee faire hepheardees dicoured while they were dreing themelves; and when they were ready, they went towards the field of Mercury, where they were all to rendezvous; then to go unto the Temple of the good Goddee, and from thence to Alexis. Silvander was before all the ret, finding no contentment, but when he aw Diana. When they came there, this hepheard was inging, and was o rapt up in his own imagination, as though they were very near him, yet he perceived them not. Diana eeing him in this condition; he knew very well that Atrea and Phillis had poken truth, and that he prepared himelf for a great Combat with her; who ince the death of Philander, had never any park of good will unto any man but this hepheard but not enduring that Silvander hould erve her, being a peron altogether unknown he reolved upon extream rigor againt the affection of this hepheard; and perhaps, omething againt her own inclination. Whilt he was in thee thoughts, Phillis who loved Silvander for cauing
the jealouie of Lycidas to vanih. She pittied him, and turning towards Diana, whipered thus in her eare; I doe ingeniouly confee, Mitris, that this hepheard does love you better then I doe, and I am affraid that if you be judge the caue will go againt me. Dianas mind being directed another way, he did not reply, but as oon as Silvander had done inging; How now hepheard, aid Phillis unto him, doe you value this company o little, that you will not daign them a look? Silvander being roued out of his deep thoughts, by this voice, as out of a profound leep, he tarted up, and aluted the hepherdees. I mut confee (aid he) that Phillis hath obliged me, though perhaps contrary to her intention. Your ingratitude, anwered Phillis, is uch towards me, as I hall never advie any to oblige you, ince you doe o ill acknowledge it; doe you thanke me thus for advertiing you of your duty, and for bringing her unto you whom you ay you love? methinkes common civility hould prompt you unto a more handome acknowledgement then this. Phillis, anwered Silvander, you put me in mind of thoe Cowes, who when they have filled the Paile with milk, doe throw it downe with their foot; for when you had in ome ort obliged me, you cancell the obligation by upbraiding me with it. I mut confee that what you have done does merit acknowledgement, but what acknowledgement is due? the very ame that Diana ueth unto her little Dogge Driope, when he hath done any thing which pleaeth her; and if you aske her, what recompence he gives him, he will tell you, that he onely chocks him under the chin, and trokes him half a dozen times upon the back; and ince you have done no more for me, methinkes you hould be content with the ame paiment. Atrea and Diana could not chue but laugh at his merry anwer. Upon which Silvander tepped towards her, and offered to troke her as Diana did her Dogge; but he puhed him away, and with a frowning look, aid unto him. If you ue to pay your debts with uch money, I believe all your Creditors will cat you off as I doe, ince your payment is o bad but, ungrateful peron, you cannot deny your Obligation unto me to be great, for changing your melancholly thoughts into a ight of the fair Diana. This Obligation, aid he, I mut needs confee to be very great, if it was done intentionally; but it was done with a quite contrary deigne, becaue all that proceeds from an enemy may well be upected. What ill deigne could I have in it, replyed Phillis? Perhaps you thought, aid he, that the everity of my Mitres would more perplex me then my melancholly thoughts; or becaue you know that the more one ees the peron loved, the more is love augmented; you thought there was no peedier way to kill me, then by the ight of this faire hephearde. But Phillis, doe not think that I will ever hrink from uch a death, ince I am ure I cannot avoid it, and ince no life can be more deireable then uch a death is.

This dipute had lated longer between this hepheard and hepheardees, had they not een a company coming towards them, and very neare; all with intentions of going together as viitants of Alexis. One of the company, to make the time eem lee tedious, did ing, and the ubtance of his ong was againt an uncontant hepheardee: Silvander and Diana litned with ilent attention unto the words of the Song: the finger was preently known to be Corilas, who being tung with the perfidious tricks of Stella, he could not hide thoe reentments of hatred which he had conceived againt her. That hepheardee alo, after addrees in hopes of regaining him, finding all her endeavours to be in vaine, he alo turned her amity into hatred, which was o publiquely known unto every one, as they were commonly called. The Friends Enemies. The hepheardee did not at that time returne any anwer, becaue Hylas as he began, did ilence her with inging out thee lines.

lg.l: JF love be good, then it mut be confet
That God communicable is the bet;
What crabbed Timon then can me reprove,
Or check me for communicating love?
If love be bad, then certainly none will
Condemn me for avoiding what is ill:
But be it good or bad, to me all's one,
I'le either many love, or ele love none.
The Univere doth change, and all that's in't,
The life is dull tha'ts tasked to a tint.
Natures delight is in variety,
If all ublunaries doe change; faith, why not I?

div.p: At thee lat words this Company was o neare Atrea and her Companions, that they all aluted each other, and left inging to enquire of each others welfare: Hylas, he applied himelfe unto Silvander; Oh, my good friend, aid he unto him, I ee that here is not one in all the company that knows how to love but I for if there was you would not thus trifle away your time, but go preently to the faire Alexis. I believe, anwered Phillis, that we hall be there time enough to imploy all your Contancy: No, no, replied Silvander, he has all the reaon in the world to make hate, otherwie there would be ome danger, let the end of his love hould be before the beginning of our journey. Perhaps you think (aid Hylas) that you have given me a notable check, in aying, that I doe never love any long, but I take it as one of the greatet commendations you can give me. For good Silvander tell me, Is not he that goes as much ground in an hour, as another does in a whole day, is not he, I ay, the bet Footman? and a Maon that builds a Houe in a moneth, which another will not undertake under a whole yeare, is not he the bet Workman? If you will make your love a Lackey (aid Silvander) I hall think the fater it goes, the better it is; But as for your Maon, let me tell you Hylas, that he who makes mot hate is not the bet workman, but he who does his work the bet, does bet deerve that name: for mot hate makes wore work, and often poils all. Hylas would have replied, when all the Company began to et forward towards the Temple of the good Goddee, where Chryante expected them at Dinner: for that venerable Druid undertanding their determination, and being deirous to viit the faire Alexis, he invited them all unto her houe, that he might make one of their company: this requet, which was honourable unto them, was not denyed, and therefore Silvander left the incontant Hylas to wait upon Diana, being exceedingly glad of this opportunity of being with her when Paris was not. Had the diguied Alexis looked the right way, he might eaily have een them come from the field of Mercury; for the Grove where he was, urveyed the place; but her eyes were o fixed upon the place where Atrea dwelt, that he tood like a tatue expreing no ignes that he was alive, but onely breathing or rather ighing.

She had longer tood in this muing poture, if Leonide had not diverted her: this Nymph not being able to extinguih her flames of affection towards Celadon, he was o much delighted in the company of Alexis, that he was abent from him as little as poible he could. The wie Adamas having the words of Silvia till freh in his memory, though he knew well enough what ardent affection that hepheard had unto the faire Atrea, yet did he live in much perplexity, knowing very well that his Neece was not o disfurnihed of natures gifts, but that he might in time worke upon a young heart, and make it forget all repects of loyalty and duty.

This conideration was o trong in him, that he would never have permitted this young hepheard to enter his houe, under the habit name and motion of his Daughter Alexis, had not the Oracle made a promie unto him, that when Celadon did enjoy his contentment, his age hould then be happy; o as being intereted in point of happinee, he choe rather to take o much paines to watch the actions of them both, then to loe that happinee which the Heavens had promied. Now becaue he could not have his eye alwayes upon them, in repect his dometique and publique affaires invited him another way; he charged Paris to be preent with them as much as he could.

This morning when he heard they were both gone out of the houe, and that Paris was not with them, he went immediately after them, and followed his Neece o cloe, as he was in the Grove almot as oone as hee, where Alexis had beene along while entertaining her thoughts: the noie which the Nimphs made as he came caued Celadon to looke that way, and as he turned he pyed the Druide comming, unto whom he bore o much repective reverence, that though he had rather have beene alone entertaining his thoughts of Atrea: yet eeming otherwie, he went to meet him, and bid him good morrow with a countenance of joy more then accutomed; of which Adamas taking
notice, after his morning alute, he told her that her countenance of jollity did preage but a bad concluion of the day. If it pleae, good Father, anwered Alexis, you hall receive contentment by it; for as for me, I have no hopes but in death; and if you did oberve me with a merrier countenance then ordinary, it is becaue I thinke my elfe every day neerer the end of that torment which Fortune hath ordained for mee; imitating in this, thoe who are in a long and tedious journey, who when they come to their Inn at night, are pleaed to thinke that o much of their paines is leened; the Druide returned this cold anwer; My dear Child, thoe who do live without hope of comfort in their mieries, doe not only offend againt the Providence of great Tautates, but alo againt the prudence of them who have the Guardianhip of them. In this occaion therefore I have a double caue of Complaint againt you: you have offended both the Gods and Mee, as Druide of the Country, into whoe hands the Oracle hath committed you. Father, anwered Alexis, I hould be extreamly orry, hould I offend either the great Tautates or you; and for an explanation of my words, give me leave to tell you that my intention was not to doubt either in the Providence of our great Gods, or in your Prudence; but I doe beleeve it is not the will of the Gods to give me any contentment as long as I live, and that my misfortune is o great as it is beyond all humane Prudence to helpe it. You mut know, replyed Adamas; that the lighting of a benefit received, does often withdraw the hand of the Benefactor, and makes it more lacke in conferring then it was before; take heed you provoke not the Heavens unto the like for you doe o ill accept of what they have begun to doe for you, as you have reaon to feare, that in lieu of happinee, they will inflict new punihments. Doe you not conider that when you had mured up your elfe in a Salvage Rocke, the Gods ent Silvander with conolation unto you? Then, to make their goodnee more apparent unto you; did not he caue Atrea her elfe to come unto you? Did you not ee her; nay, almot hear her, and the Lamentations he made for you? what better beginnings of happinee could you poibly hope for then thee: I will not intance the viits of Leonide and my elfe, for perhaps they were troubleome unto you; but I may well mention the goodnee of the Gods to you, in inpiring mee to bring you unto my houe, under the notion and habit of my Daughter Alexis, for doubtlee it is her whom Atrea comes to ee: What more aupitious beginning can you have then this? Can you imagine, that without the particular aide and aitance of the Gods, this habit and diguie could delude the eyes of o many perons? All the people of your owne Towne, your friends, your familiars, have een you, and been deceived; your owne Brother himelfe is mitaken; but the favours of Tautates ret not here: for hee inpired Atrea to come and ee you: what can you deire more for a properous beginning? Yet I ee, uch is your ingratitude that till you complain, or at leat receive not thee benefits with a thankefull heart. Take heed Child, you provoke not a Diety too arre, leat they hould withdraw thee favours, and give you a jut caue of condolement. Father, anwered Alexis, I doe mot gratefully acknowledge the goodnee of Tautates, and your indulgent care over mee; but till I cannot chue but complaine; for I am yet like unto a poore afflicted man, who hath a thouand torments at once upon him; though one or two of thoe torments be taken away, yet the ret which remaine are enough to move complaint. The Druide was ready to anwer when he aw Paris coming towards them, who being clad in his hepherds habit, made it manifet that Love prompted unto the dree. Leonide alo flattering her elfe in an opinion that her beauty needed not to ubmit unto the beauty of Atrea, he ued all her art, and trimmed up her elfe to the bet advantage that Alexis eeing her in that dree, and comparing Atrea with her, the artificiall lutre of the one, might dimme the naturall implicity of the others beauty. Alexis in her uuall habit eemed to care leat for this viit, though he had the mot interet, and becaue he deired not to be knowne by any, hee added nothing to her ordinary dree; beides, he knew that her happinee was to be expected from fortune and not beauty: but however, he appeared o fair in that imple habit without any artifice, that Leonide could not keep her eyes off her.

After ome common dicoure, Paris who was paionately in love with Diana, to make himelfe more pleaing in her eye, he aumed the habit of a hepherd; and not being furnihed with o much patience as to tay till their coming, he told Adamas, that if it pleaed him, he would goe and meet thoe fair hepherdees, who were to viit his Siter, and conduct them to the bet and neeret way. The Druide knowing what affection
he had unto Diana, and not diallowing it for ome reaons, which hereafter hall be declared, did commend his deigne, hinting unto him that courteie and civility, of all the vertues did mot attract the hearts of people, and that it was the naturall quality of perons well borne. Paris upon this leave went preently towards Lignon, and going down the Hill unto the bridge of Boteree, he followed the River, taking into a little path upon his right hand, which led him into the Wood, where the empty tombe of Celadon was erected; and paing on he came unto the Meadow which is before the Temple of Atrea. He had no ooner et foot in it, but he pyed on the other ide of it two Horemen, the one of which was armed; he had on his right hand a Gantlet, and on the other a Buckler, a Plume of black and white, which waved over the Crupper of his Hore, his Corlet was et with Lions, his Sword Falchion like, which turned up at the end like to a demicircle, hung by his ide in a rich carfe.

As oon as Paris perceived him, he remembred what hapned unto Diana when Filidas and Filander were laine, and therefore retreated into the Wood, yet being very deirous to know more of them, he till kept his eye upon them through the thick Wood. He aw that as oone as they were entred into the Meadow and pyed the pleaant Fountaine, which is at the entrance into the Temple; the Cavelier lighted from his Hore, and the other whom he judged to be his Servant, ran to him, held his tirrop, tooke his Hore, unbridled him, and without any repect unto the place, let him eat upon the acred Grae: Meane while the Cavelier went to the Fountaine; dranke of the water, and wahed his hands and face. Paris by his deportment did imagine that his intention was not to offer harme unto any, and this opinion made him o bold as to go neerer him, yet till concealing himelfe in the thicke Wood; o as he uneen came o neere them, that he could both heare and ee all that they aid and did: He aw that the Cavalier was both young and faire, though extreame orrow appeared in his face; then looking upon his Armes, he thought him to be a Gaule, and that he was in love: for he bore upon his ilver Sheild a Tyger feeding upon a Hart, with this Motto. Thou gav't me death, and I maintaine thy life.

Perhaps he had oberved every thing both longer and better, had he not beene prevented by the ighs of this Caveller, who looking fixedly upon the Fountaine, rowed himelfe as out of a deepe lumber, and lifting up his eyes towards Heaven, he taxed his courage with Puillanimity, for upporting o many misfortunes; his words were econded with many a igh, and ighs econded with howers of teares, which trickled downe his cheekes into the Fountaine: Preently after, lying along upon the ground, and letting his arms hang looe, he grew pale, and his complexion changed, o as his ervant who kept an eye upon him, eeing him in this condition, he was affraid leat he hould woone; he ran therefore unto him, cat a little water in his face, and recovered him before he lot his knowledge or trength But hee, opening his eyes, and lifting them faintly up to heaven, made uch ad Lamentation, that his ervant could not chue but igh: which he oberving; what Halladine (aid he) dot thou igh? Sir, aid the Servant, I igh more to ee uchan alteration in you, then for the ditater of which you complain: for to be deceived by a woman, to be betrayed by a Rivall, that virtue hould procure envy, and that fortune hould favour the deignes of enemies, is not at all trange, becaue it is ordinary: But I mut needs wonder to ee the courage of Damon, which hitherto I believed invincible, and which hath made him eteemed and feared both of friends and enemies, hould now hrink at a common accident, which inferiour courages are wont to reit. A thought of revenge, if nothing ele, methinkes ir, hould move you to preerve your elfe untill you have found out Madonthe, that you might in herpreence call them to an account, who are the caues of your dipleaure. For Gods ake ir, conider that a Calumny which is not diproved may well pae for a truth; and conequently Madonthe had reaon to treat you as he did. Paris oberved, that at the name of Madonthe, the Cavelier aumed a little vigour, and that looking upon him, he anwered with a faint voice; Ah Halladin, didt thou but know what torments are upon me, thou wouldt ay that I doe want courage, ince I doe endure them any longer and live. Oh ye Gods, who both ee and heare my unjut orrowes, and my jut complaints, either betow a welcome death upon me, or ele take away the memory of o many dipleaures
from mee. The Gods, aid the Servant, doe ue to favour thoe who by their courage and Prudence endeavour to helpe themelves in their misfortunes, and to decline thoe who loing their heart and courage, have recoure only to prayers and weake tears; why doe you thinke, did they betow upon you a oule of a higher generoity then upon others? doe you thinke it was to make ue of it only in properity, and not to encounter the guts of adverity? Certainely Sir, you ought to hew the effects of it upon all occaions, epecially in adverity, to the end that thoe who • ee that vertue in you, may praie the Gods for imparting o much perfection unto man, and conidering it in you, they may come to the knowledge of the great Giver. Will you offer to abue the favours and the hopes which every one hath in you? I have heard ome ay who knew you in your infancy, that you promied a noble courage even from the very Cradle, and hewed o much generoity of oule, as every one conceived that you would prove an example unto the world of an invincible pirit: will you not Sir anwer all their hopes and expectations? There are ome women who thinke it a hame to hrinke at the blowes of Fortune, though their natures be puillanimous and timerous; yet being dipoed unto vertuous ends they often change their Natures: you Sir are a man: that very word commands you to be couragious: you who are a Cavelier, brought up in Martiall wayes and hath looked grim death in the face; you who have acquired great reputation in the greatet dangers: you I ay, who are Damon, who never tarted at any difficulty, now faint at uch an accident as this? Will you offer to die before you doe an act worthy not only of a Cavelier, but of a common man? Halladine, Halladine, anwered the Cavelier, thee coniderations are good in another eaon, or in any other man but my elfe: alas, what act can I doe, which will doe me any good, only dying excepted; for all others are dipleaing unto her for whom only I deire to live. Thou knowet that Madonthe is the only aime of all my deires and ince all my hopes of her is lot, what can I deire but death? But Sir, aid Halladine, how doe you know that all your hopes of Madonthe are lot? Thou thy elfe aid the Cavelier dot know as much: give me leave to tell you Sir, (replyed Halladine) that I doe know how the cae tands better then you doe: for Sir when you commanded me to carry your letter and Theranders Ring unto her, and the Handkerchief full of your blood unto the hellih Leriana, by chance I met with them both together; and though that divellih wretch who was the caue of all your miery did tand immovable at your meage, which I declared from you unto them: yet I oberved Madonthe firt to grow pale, afterwards to tremble, and latly when hee heard of your death, and aw the blood, he was urpried with o much orrow, that had he not beene held, he had unke downe, o as had I thought you alive, doubtlee I had brought you very good newes from her. Oh my friend Halladine (aid the Cavelier) what a weake concluion dot thou make? Didt thou but know the nature of women thou wouldt confee with me, that uch alterations in them doe proceed rather from Compaion then Paion: for certainly all women are naturally pittifull, and compaion is an ordinary effect of their weake oules; o as what thou obervet in Madonthe proceeded from the pittifulnee of her Nature: But, Halladine, it is not pitty or compaion, but paion and love that I doe deire from her, and this thou didt not dicover in her oule. Alas Sir, aid Halladi • e, unto what a mierable condition are you reduced ince you your elfe are the very wort enemy that you have? I wonder uch an accident hould worke uch an alteration in your judgement. Admit the wort, that Madonthe does not love you; yet if you deire to overcome her and obtaine her favour, why doe you not goe where he is, but hun all community with mankind, or habitable places? Since hatred is the higher, (aid the Cavelier) for eeing the peron hated, have I not good reaon to hun the ight of Madenthe, becaue he hates me? and o being deprived of her whom onely I deire; all things ele that I ee are dipleaing unto mee, why then houldet thou thinke it trange, that I hould direllih all others, ince I cannot ee Madonthe? Good Sir, aid Halladine, what comfort can you expect to finde in Wildernees, and uncoth avage places? Death, (aid the Cavelier) for that is all the comfort I hope for ince it is o, aid Hallad • ne, is it not better to go and die before Madonthes face, that he may ee you die for her, then to languih away your life amongt Rockes and Caves and olitary Woods, where none knowes what you do: Thou ayet well Halladine anwered the Cavelier, but thou knowet that Madonthe is fled away with her darling Therander; and to enjoy him with more ecurity, keepes cloe from any finding them: Dot thou thinke that I would not have had recoure unto
ome deperat act, if I had not had uch an intention as thou peaket of? Upon thee words, teares hindered his peech, and pitty moved Halladine unto the ame, o as for a while they both tood peechlee. Paris who litned attentively, hearing Madonthe named, could not at the firt imagine it to be her, whom he had een diguied in the habit of a hepheardee with Atrea and Diana: But when he heard Therander named, he made no doubt but that it was he, and therefore he hearkned more attentively, when Halladine began to peak thus; For my part, ir, aid Halladine, were your cae mine, I would never die for one who changes me for another, but if the dipleaure of it did o far tranport me as to reolve upon death, I would firt end death to the man, who is the caue of my loe before me, and he hould die by no hand but my owne. For beide the weet of revenge, I would let her who changed me for him, ee what a bad choice he had made: I would never uffer him to inherit my happinee after my death. Therefore I advie you ir, if you be reolved upon death, that firt you give Therander his death, who is the obtacle of your happinee, and caue of your death. I mut confee (aid the Cava • er) that in this thou peaket reaon; but Halladine, thou knowet he conceales himelfe, he is afraid of uch a deigne; and to prevent it, He, Madonthe, and her Nure, keep o cloe, as none knowes where they are. Whilet he was aying o, and whilt Paris was litning with an inquiitive eare, the poore ditracted hepheard Adrates came inging ome mad freakes in dicompoed meeter, without any order or ene: this mierable lover, ince the judgement of the Nimph Leonide given againt him in favour of Palemon, did o reent his eparation from Doris, that being out of all hopes, his minde was ditracted. 'Tis true, he had ome intervalls in which he would talke pertinently enough, but then preently he would change, and rove a hundred miles from the matter, o as he moved all that knew him unto pitty, and others to laughter; love being the caue of his ditraction, all his follies harped upon that tring; and when his good intervalls were upon him, his complaint was all upon the obduracy of Doris, the injutice of Leonide, the good fortune of Palemon, and his owne miery. Thee trangers litned unto him, but could hardly undertand what he aid, ince not one word was pertinent unto another: yet he, ravihed in his owne fancy, not eeing them, came inging cloe to them; and had not the Hores neighed, perhaps he had paed on without a ight of them. The Cavelier hearing him very often intermixe with his roving language, the words Love, Beauty, and Paion, did know what his dieae was, he deired to know a little more, and riing up, he poke thus unto him Good friend, tell us in what Country we are? and what is the miery which makes you thus complaine? Arates eeing the Cavelier, and his minde running all upon love, did anwer him: Sir, he is o infinitely faire, that no mortal can equall her, and Palemon hath ravihed her from me. The Cavelier replyed, who is that Palemon? Palemon, anwered the hepheard, is Palemon; yes, yes, aid the tranger, I know that is his name: but what is he, of what quality? At this quetion, Adrates was a little troubled, and looking wildly upon the Cavelier, he anwered, Palemon is one whom Adrates does not love. And Adrates, aid the Cavelier, who is he Then the hepheard growing more frantique, broke out into extreame laughter, and in concluion, began to cry, aying, the Nimph has wronged me; Doris at the beginning cryed, then went away; and though I called her back, yet he would not o much as look back upon me, was ever any thus ued? The Cavelier was at firt amazed at his language, and plainly aw that he was ditracted, and thinking love to be the caue, he pittied him; then turning towards his ervant, ee, aid he, what will be my fortune, if I doe not die: for certainly this hepheard is run mad for love. Love, replyed Adrates, is as mad as either. For Palemon if he were not, Doris would either have been here, or I where he is. Thus he roved into uch odd impertinencies, that Halladine could not forbeare laughing, which the Knight perceiving, Thou dost laugh at this poore hepheard, aid he unto Halladine, but does not conider that perhaps thou wilt have the ame occaion to laugh at me. At me aid the hepheard, why, I am Adrates, and I would know whether Palemon will live a long time or no. The Cavelier was o troubled with his impertinent peeches, and o unwilling to be diverted from his thoughts, that he commanded his ervant to bridle their Hores, and getting up, they went into the wood where Paris was, who was in two or three mindes whether or no he hould hew himelf, and as a tranger, offer him all poible aitance, as by the Lawes of Hopitality he was obliged: but conidering that if he engaged himelfe with this Cavelier, he hould loe an
occaion of erving Diana: alo thinking it better to advertie Madonthe and Therander of him, he till concealed himelfe upon thee coniderations.

Paris was no ooner out of the wood, but looking towards the great Meadow, he epied the Company which he came to meet: amongt the ret, there was Atrea, Diana, Phillis, Stella, Doris, Aminthe, Celidea, Floris, Circene, Palanice, and Laonice; all thee rallied together with curioity, to ee the beauty of Alexis, and the rarities in the houe of Adamas: There was alo many hepheards, amongt the ret, Lycidas, Silvander, Hylas, Ti •• is, Thamares, Calidon, Pal • mon, and Corrilas, all who, to beguile time and length of way, either ung, or held out ome pleaant dicoure. Paris was now o neare that Silvander knew him, and becaue he led Diana by the arme, he thought it would dipleae his Mitree, if he did not yield his place unto Paris out of repect, though not unto any out of love: And to oblige her by the Act, he aid unto her in a low voice, I beeech you mitres command me to let your arme go, that I may doe it out of obedience unto your command, ince I cannot doe it by my good will. Shepheard, aid he, and miled, ince you think my command will doe you ervice in the Act, I do command it you. Oh Heavens (aid the hepheard) who would not wholly devote himelfe to your ervice, ince you are o obliging even in your diobligings. He durt not ay any more let Paris hould heare, for he was very neare, o as Diana advanced to alute him, as all the company did. Silvander had no ooner quitted his place, but his Rivall poeed it with as much contentment, as the other left it with dipleaure. After ome dicoure, Paris oberved that neither Madonthe nor Therander were in the company, and therefore he asked Diana of them: unto whom Laonice anwered, that Madonthe was this morning very ill dipoed, and that Therander kept her company. I hould have been glad (aid Paris) to have met them here, that I might have acquainted them how ome enemy of their's is come into the Country; and that it is bet both for Madonthe and Therander, to look well unto themelves. Silvander who had alwaies an eye upon Diana, he heard what Paris aid; and becaue he was a great eteemer of Madonthes virtues, he took upon him to acquaint them at his return, Laonice who watched for an occaion to be revenged upon this hepheard, he oberved how ready he was to take upon him this office, to the end he might make ue of it in time and place. Diana alo, who began to have ome parkes of good will towards this hepheard, did take notice of it, as hereafter hall be declared, which Leonice did very well perceive. But in the meane time, let the reverent Chryante hould tay too long, all the Company et forward. Diana entreated Phillis to be alwaies near her, let being alone, Paris hould fall into dicoure of his affections: therefore he kept her elfe on the other ide of that hepheardee, and took her by the arme. Calidon waited upon Atrea, and Tircis and Silvander kept together; as for Hylas, he undertook no body, but was ometimes the firt, and ometimes the lat of the company, without fixing himelfe unto any of the hepheardees; he took no more regard of Phillis, then if he had never een her in his life; at which Tireis admired, and after a little conideration of it, he could not chue but ay aloud unto him; Is it poible Hylas, that you hould be o near Phillis, and take no notice of her? Hylas eeming as if he had not een her, turned about as if he looked for her: at lat, looking upon her, I aure you, my time-pat Mitres (aid he unto her) that my heart was o much in another place, that my eyes never informed me that you were here; and perhaps the ame occaion has brought us both together; very likely, anwered Phillis; you came with a deire to ee the faire Alexis, and I came with orrowes that I have lot you, epecially at the game of the Fairet, as you ay it was. Faith Phillis, anwered Hylas, the heavens would have it o: How Hylas, aid Thircis; doe you thinke that the heavens are the caue of your incontant humour? as well (anwered Hylas) as of thoe vaine teares which you hed upon the cold ahes of Cleon. Things which doe not depend upon our elves (aid Tircis) and whoe caues are unknown unto us, we doe ordinarily acribe unto the puiance and will of the Gods. But uch things as the caues whereof are known, we never ue to acribe them unto the Gods as the Authors, epecially uch things as are ill, as incontancy is, for that were flat blaphemy; whether incontancy be good or bad, anwered Hylas, is a quetion which will admit of dipute; but it mut needs be confeed, that it proceeds from the Gods; for is not beauty the work of great Tautates? and what makes me change but beauty? were not Alexis fairer then Phillis, I had never changed.

Beauty then is the caue, and if o, why may we not impute it unto the Gods without
any blaphemy, epecially ince wee ee by the effects that the change is good and reaonable, being according to the laws of Nature which obliges every one to look for wha •
is bet. That beauty is the worke of great Tautates (anwered Tircis) I doe confee and more, that it is the greatet of all which fall within the compae of our enes: but to affirme that it hould be the caue of incontancy, is an errour, as if one hould accue Light, with the fault of thoe who goe out of the way, becaue it hewes them everall Pathes. And as to your aertion, that incontancy is according to the Laws of nature, which commands every one to aime at the bet: take heed Hylas that it be not of a depraved nature, and quite contrary to the Command you mention: For how doe you know, that your change is for the bet; for my part I ee no advantage you get by it: but the loe of that time which you imploy about it; you take much unprofitable paines to no end, and make every one corne your friendhip as too light to be entertained: if you thinke thee to be advantages, I confee you have ome reaon to court them; but if you will credit Judgements which are not infected with your owne dieae, you will find them to be the greatet evils that you can meet withall.

Diana who oberved that Tircis poke in good earnet, and that Hylas perhaps would grow angry, he would needs interrupt them, o as this dicoure might pae no farther; which to effect he put Phillis upon it, who began thus: Heretofore, my late Servant (aid hee unto him) you were wont to complaine, that of all the company Silvander was your only enemy; but now methinkes Tircis hath upplyed his place. It is no wonder, my late Mitree (anwered Hylas) for it is very ordinary to ee ill opinions take hold upon ignorant perons: Tircis would have replyed, had he not beene prevented by poore Adrates, who being come into the Wood, they aw talking unto Trees and Flowers, as if they had beene people of his acquaintance: ometimes he fancied that he aw Doris, and then kneeling downe upon the ground he adored her, and as if he were begging for the favour of a kie of her hand, he made a long peech: ometimes againe he fancied that he aw Leonide, and then he rayled and wihed her all manner of bad Fortune: but when he fancied Palemon, the expreions of his jealouie was very pleaant; for though it was very confued, yet it gave good evidence of the grandure of his affection. The company paed cloe by him, and though the very ight of him moved every one to pitty, yet much more when he pyed Doris, becaue then he tood immoveable like a Pillar; his eyes fixed upon her, and his armes a croe his bret, without a word, as if he were ravihed. Afterwards pointing at her with his finger, when he paed by him, he aid with a deep igh; ee, ee where he is; then fixing his eyes upon her, hee never moved them as long as he could ee her: but when he began to loe the ight of her, he began to run untill he was before her; then he looked upon none in the Company but her, and o ilently looking upon her, he accompanied her unto the outgoing of the Wood, for farther he durt not pae: when he lot the ight of her, he began to cry out: Adieu Palemon, make much of Doris, and upon this he ruhed into the Wood, where he almot alwayes was, becaue that was the place where Leonide gave judgement againt him. Every one pittyed him except Hylas, who preently began to laugh, and turning towards Silvander; This Shepherd, aid he unto him, is an effect of that contancy which you commend o much; which of us two doe you thinke is in mot danger to reemble him? Complexions mot perfect (anwered Silvander) are mot eaily altered, but to chue I had rather be like Adrates, then like Hylas. The choice of the one, aid Hylas, is in your power; but not of the other: How doe you meane it, aid Silvander? The meaning aid Hylas is nothing difficult: my meaning is, that if you will you may become a foole like Adrates, your humour is inclinable to it, but you cannot reemble Hylas. In this, you are mot deceived, replyed Silvander; For things that depend upon the will may be in choice, but things that depend upon the will of another are more difficult; and therefore every one that will, may be either vertuous or vitious but they cannot be well or icke when they will: now the condition wherein poore Adrates is, it is not voluntary, but forced, as proceeding from a malady, the remedies againt which is not in his hands, but your malady depends wholly upon your will; o as it is demontrative by reaon, that it is an eaier matter to reemble you, then that mierable Shepherd. Admit it o, (aid Hylas) yet is it not better to reemble me, ince if I will, I can deliver my elfe from my malady as you call it, then to reemble Adrates who cannot free himelfe from his? Tis true, anwered Silvander, but if you doe leave off your incontancy, then you doe not reemble your elfe: I did ay that I had rather
reemble Adrates then Hylas; that is, Adrates the mad, than Hylas the incontant. Truly, (aid Phillis, and interrupted them) you pree too hard upon my late Servant; I mut needs take his part and ay, that incontancy is better then madnee, ince it does not take away the ue of reaon, which doth onely ditinguih men from beats: you are mitaken Shepherdee (aid Silvander) for the dieae of Hylas and that of Adrates are both of them reall maladies; but that of Hylas is the wore, becaue all maladies of oule, are wore than thoe of the body. As for the reaon which you urge, it is not coniderable, for if the caue of a malady doe proceed from ome defect in the body, yet that body may till be reaonable as we ee thoe who are intoxicated with Wine; now the malady of Adrates doeth doubtlee proceed from the weaknee of his braine which is not able to endure the entence which Leonide gave againt him; but that of Hylas proceeds from an imperfect judgement, which hinders him from dicerning good from bad, but uffers vices to become habituall. And becaue it is the reaonable oule which gives being unto men, and makes them differ from beats, it is better according to your own Argu •• t to be unound in body than in oule; 'tis better to be a hanome Hore or a Dog, then to be the bare outide of a man; without a ound oule, becaue a Hore is a perfect Animall; but he who hath a rotten oule and unound intellectuals is infinitely imperfect; and therefore I conclude it is better to be dieaed as Adrates is, then as Hylas.

All the Company did laugh at this concluion, and the noie was o high, that it was long before Hylas could be heard; And when he began, they aw the age Chryante, who pying them afarre off, came to meet them with a great Company of her Virgins •
therefore putting an end to all diputes, they advanced forward to falute her, and to doe her all the honour and reverence which was due unto her vertue and profeion.

The Temple of the good Goddee, where the venerable Chryante reided, was at the bottome of a delightful Hill, which was wahed by the cleere wave • of delightfull Lignon; and on the other ide tood the acred Grove of the great Tautates. In this umptuous Temple which the Romans dedicated unto Veta, and to the good Goddee did the vetall Virgins officiate, according to the cutome of the Romans: The venerable Chryante was the chiefe Governee, though he was a Gallian, and of the Druid • s order.

When the Romans under pretence of helping the Heduois whom they termed their friends and confederates, did eize upon Gaule, and ubjected them unto their Republique; one principall marke of their victory was to caue their Gods to be adored in all places of their uurpation; not thinking themelves intire poeors, if they did not interet their Gods, and oblige them to their preervation; and yet let they hould hew themelves inupportable at the firt, they permitted the Gaules, who adored but one God, under the names of Tautates, Heius, Tharames and Bellinus, to ue their ancient cutomes, and live in their old Religion; knowing very well that nothing is more intolerable to men, then tyrannically to force their beliefe. And therefore when they entred into the Dominions of the Seguians, they would not alter any of their Cutomes, Manners, Government or Religion. But when they found in this acred Grove an Altar dedicated unto a Virgin who hould have a Child, and that Divinity erved by the Daughters of Druids, they had much more repect unto it, thinking that place was conecrated under another name, either unto the good Goddee, (in whoe ervice men could not officiate) or unto the Goddee Veta, in whoe Temple they were wont to place a tatute of a Virgin, holding a Child in her Arms: Having this opinion, not to leen the honour and ervice which they rendred unto thee two Goddees, whom they held in great reverence; they built a Temple unto them both, with two Altars alike, and to the honour of the good Goddee, they called it Bonleia, and to the honour of Veta, they are called Vetals; and becaue the People were infinitely Religious towards the Gods whom they adored, not knowing whether thee Goddees would be worhipped after the manner of the Romans or the Gaules, and alo to content the Inhabitants of the Country, they left the Virgin Druids to their ancient Cutomes and Ceremonies unto whom they gave all authority concerning manners and oeconomique matters: And thus was the venerable Chryante abolute Mitree of the Virgin Druids and Vetals.

This Temple was larger and more pacious then eemed to the eye, being built in an orbicular ome; it was covered with lead: in the middet and highet part of it, was
erected a Statute of a Virgin holding a Childe in her Armes; in the midt of this Temple was placed two Altars, at uch equall ditance, that the one was no further from the middle then the other; by the ide of either of them there tood an Arke of white Marble, upported by three Columnes in which was put all the Fruites which were offered; at the doore tood a Baon of water which they called Lutrale, in which the Torch which was at the Altar when divine Service was celebrated, was firt wahed, and afterwards extinguihed.

When all this Company met the venerable Chryante, it was o early as the morning acrifice was not then begun; and therefore he invited all the faire hepheardees unto it, telling the hepheards that he was orry to rob them of their good company: but he was contrained unto it, by the inviolable Ordinance of the Goddee, who commanded that all men hould be banihed thoe Altars.

Paris, Calidon, and Silvander who were mot concerned, made anwer, That they were orry for the hallow merits of men, ince that was the caue which moved the Goddee to thinke them unworthy of that honour, and beeeched her and them all, that they would not entertaine in their hearts the like hatred againt men. To which, the venerable Chryante anwered, That the wie Goddee had not excluded men their Altars, out of any hatred unto them but upon other repects; and perhaps to make the Vetalls more attentive in their devotions, and their minds not drawn another way by the ight of mens perfections. Hylas who had no devotion unto the Gods of his own Country, and much lee unto thoe who were trangers unto him, made anwer; That if thoe Goddees did forbid him to love faire ones, Hylas would be none of their Votaries: Shepheard, aid the venerable Chryante, I advie you not to provoke the Gods: Upon this word he retired into the Temple, becaue one of the Vetals, according to their cutome, came and cryed three times, Hence, all prophane ones.

Hylas therefore could not have time to reply as he intended: for as oon h • he was entred, the doors were hut; o as Paris, and all the hepheards, were forced to goe and wait in the acred Grove, where the Druide was to acrifice, when the Vetalls had done

Thee vetall Virgins were habited in white Robes, and o long behinde, that they could vaile their heads therewith, when they went into the Temple to acrifice. This day was dedicated unto Veta, for not to be urcharged with too many acrifices; their dayes were to be divided, one day they acrificed unto Veta, and another unto the good Goddee. This day then being the Vetals, as oon as the doores of the Temple were hut, and all the vetall Virgins, Druids and Shepheardees had taken their places, they all bowed to the ground; as oon as the chiefe Vetall tood up, who taking in her hand a branch of Laurell which a young Vetall preented unto her, and which was dipped in ther water, which was called Lutrale, which he brought with her in a ilver Baon; he prinkled her elfe therewith, and afterwards did the ame unto all the Congregation, who being all protrate upon the ground, received this water with great devotion. Afterwards, being rien up, and he returned to her eat, another young Virgin preented unto her a basket full of flowers; he put one Pofie of them upon her head, and did the like unto ix others, who kneeled down at her feet, and who were to ait her in the acrifice; one of them went preently, and tooke the Napkin and Baon with which they were wont to acrifice. Another took the box of perfumes, which was called Acerta: Another carried the water which was to be ued in the acrifice, for the Vetals never ued any Wine: And thoe alo of the good Goddees, never ued wine but milk: The fifth carried the bundle of Vervine; and the ixth, a basket of Flowers and Fruits.

Being all thus before her, cloe to the Altar of Veta, before which he did protrate her elfe upon her knees; he began an Antheme in praie of that Goddee, and all the Vetals joyned with her: and having ung the firt vere, they all roe up, having each of them a Taper in their hands, and walked two and two. The younget went firt, the elder next, and afterwards the ix which carried the Chaplets of Flowers: lat of all, the chiefe Vetall with her Patorall taffe, and all the ret went about the Altar: Then every one went to their places againe, except the chiefe Vetall, and thoe that carried things neceary for the acrifice: Then he who carried the bundle of Vervine, laid it down on the left hand of the Altar, where the fire was kept in day and night by two Vetals, becaue if it went out
they thought ome great diater would befall them. If ever the fire did extinguih, the Vetal that kept it was everely punihed: then they kindled it againe with the rayes of the Sun, which fire they eteemed Sacred. The other Vetal, who carried the Flowers and the fruits, did put them into the white Marble Ark, of which we poke before; and the other four tayed with the chiefe Vetal, who then protrating her elfe before the Altar, did with a loud voice confee her innes; then acknowledged that he durt not approach the acred Altar of that Goddee, being o defiled with innes; and that he was very unworthy to offer any thing that was pleaing unto her, unlee it was by her commandment. Afterwards approaching nearer, he trewed the Altar all over with perfumes and incene, which cat a fragrant mell all over the Temple. Then turning her elfe towards the Eat, he uttered in a ditinct voice, ome words which a Vetal repeated unto her word by word, reading them out of a Book, for fear of miing, or bad pronunciation; for hould any mitake fall out in them, they believe that the acrifices are not pleaing unto the Goddes.

The words are thee, O Mot renowned Goddes, Daughter of Great Rhea, and puiant Saturn, Veta, whom the Thirrians do call Labith Horchia; Receive we beeech thee this devout Sacrifice which we offer unto unto thee for the people and Senate of Rome, for the preervation of the Gaules, and for the Grandure and properity of Amais our Soveraign Lady. Let the Sacred Fire which thou hat committed unto our keeping, never extinguih: And let thy requet which after the victory obtained over the Titans, thou madet unto Jupiter, to be till a Virgin, be alo obtained for us, and that we being all thine, we may be eteemed part of thy elfe.

At the lat words of this upplication, all the Virgins anwered, Amen. Afterwards every one threw into the fire ome Incene and Aromatique drugs; then the chief Vetall taking ome of the acred water, he prinkled the flowers, the fruits, and the fire with it: All thee things being done, he went a little from the Altar, and began a Hymn in praie of the Goddee, and all the Vetals, as a Chorus joyned with her. Latly, one, who tood oppoite to the chiefe Vetal, pronounced in a loud voice, That it was permitted them to depart; and o the acrifice ended.

Then the venerable Chryante, who medled not with the Sacrifices, but onely as an aitant; he went out of the Temple, and all the ret, except the Vetals; and went into the acred Grove, where the Prophets and the Shepheards waited for them: the one ort, to acrifice; but the other, as much out of devotion to the hepheardees, as unto their great Tautates.

Hylas more impatient then any ele, out of his zealous deire to ee the faire Alexis, he was contrained to be preent at the acrifice of the Prophets; but his prayer was, that Tautates would be pleaed this once, to be contented with hort Ceremonies, that he might be going his deired viit: and indeed as oon as the lat word of the acrifice was pronounced, he roe up, and forced all the company to doe the like. He was as haty alo when dinner was done; for eeing the venerable Chryante fall into dicoure. Madam, aid he, and interrupted her, If you do not give order for our departure, ome of the company intends to leave you, and go unto the fair Alexis. Phillis anwering for the venerable Chryante; what a curvie humour are you in Hylas (aid he) to be weary with being in this place? where do you think to find better company? My late Mitree, anwered he, Did I love you as I do Alexis, and you not here, I hould tell you in anwer to your quetion, that the bet company was where you were: but ince the cae is altered, I mut tell you upon the ame reaon, that where Alexis is, there is the bet company for me. And to make my words good by my actions, if you do not go jut now, you hall have no more of the company of Hylas, Upon this, making a low reverence, he prepared himelfe to be gone, when all the company flocked about him, and would have tayed him by force. Whilet he was triving to ecape their hands, a Meenger came unto Chryante from Amais, who ent word, that he would come and lie at her houe the ame night, that he might the next morning acrifice unto the Gods, by reaon of a trange Dreame which he had. This meage caued Hylas to be hotter upon his departure, then before: and eeing that the venerable Chryante could not go, his importunity was uch, that the fair hepheardees were forced to go away ooner then otherwie they would: Atrea indeed
was very deirous of hate in going, though her dicretion did hanomely diemble it, which Hylas and his free humour could not. Having therefore taken their leave, they et forward, accompanied with the kind hepheards; and becaue the Paths were in ome places very narrow, every one did undertake the conduct of her who was mot agreeable to his fancy, except Silvander, who out of repect was forced to quit Diana unto Paris; and Diana had deired Phillis not to be farre from her, let Paris hould fall into dicoure of his affection: Phillis therefore took Diana by the other arm, and mixed dicoure amongt them, eeming as if without deign.

It happened, that being come out of the Wood, and having paed over Lignon, at the bridge of Botereux, the way was o broad that many might goe abret: Phillis therefore called Lycidas unto her; and eeing that Silvander was contrained to entertaine Hylas; Silvander, aid he, (purpoely to interrupt Paris) pray give me your opinion: which of us two hath the better place? I think anwered the Shepherd, that this which I have long had is the bet; you mut have very good reaons (aid Phillis) if you can make me beleeve it; and your affection is very cold, if you thinke o: yet it is true (aid Silvander) though not beleeved, o as, whatoever you thinke of my place or affection to Diana, I would not change with you; for as ure as you are Phillis, my place is better then yours: I have heard aid Philis, that the neerer one is to the party loved, the more is the Lover contented; you have heard the truth, replyed Silvander; You ee, aid Phillis, that I am neere Diana, and you are at a great ditance: For all that, anwered hee, I am neerer to her then you are; for you are only by her ide, and I am in her heart. I hall no longer be orry for the paines you take in walking (aid Hylas) for now I ee it is Diana that gives you trength to make long journeys without wearying your thighs. Silvander miled at the anwer, and replyed: I know Hylas that you doe not undertand what I ay; nor indeed is it to you that I peake, but unto Phillis, who, the truth is, I find to be ignorant enough in the myteries of love; but yet he is willing to learne, o as he doth better deerve to heare me than you doe. If Phillis deire to be a Schollar in the Schoole of love (aid Hylas) and will follow my documents, I hall make her an excellent Artit. Every one laughed at Hylas, and becaue Silvander oberved that Atrea and Diana looked downe with their eyes, he would change dicoure, therefore aid unto him: I perceive Hylas, that you are very liberall of your Doctrine, but to returne unto what I poke unto Phillis; I ay againe that I am neerer Diana then he is, though he tand cloe by her ide, becaue Diana is in my heart: you aid, replyed Phillis preently, that you were in her heart. I ay it againe, anwered Silvander; beleeve it, aid Phillis, there is a great deal of difference; for if you doe love Diana, it may be aid that he is in your heart; and if Diana love you, then it may be aid that you are in hers. After the common and vulgarpeech, aid Silvander, it may be o undertood; but amongt perons of undertanding, the one may be taken for the other: for to be in any place, is to be undertood two wayes: The one, when the body is in a place, and then the outide is in onely there; the other is, when the oul which is all pirit, doth hover in any place, as mine doth in the heart of Diana; for a oule lives more where it loves, then where it breaths,: To live, is an immediate act of the oule; it followes therefore, that if I love Diana, I am really in her: it is alo a common phrae to ay, My heart is there, though my body be here: This, anwered Phillis is a little too obcure for me: but by all this you onely prove that your oule is there, and not Silvander, and therefore my place is the better: for one part of me at the let, and that which is mot apt for paion, the body is neerer her then you are. I confee, anwered he, that in body you are neerer then I am, but you cannot conclude by it that your place is better, becaue the oule is o much uperiour to the body, as there is no comparion betwixt them. I wih withall my heart Shepheard (aid Hylas) that we two were both in love with one Shepheardee: for ince you contemne the body, I would willingly take it for my hare, and leave the oule freely to you, though it were the mot learned oule among all our Druids: As for example, leave the body of Alexis to me, and I will leave the oule of Adamas unto you, who is a very knowing man. Every one did laugh at this propoition, unto which Silvander anwered thus: If all things be taken according to their true merit, certainly your choie is not the bet: For the body which you only love, is an object unworthy of the oules love, becaue love hould alwayes adde ome perfection unto the Lover; for it is confeed by all, that love is a deire of omething which is wanting. Alas the body is unworthy of the oul's love, becaue
it is vile and bae, and much below it; uch Hylas, as love onely the body, are Pigmalion-like, who fell in love with a peece of Marble: Nature it elfe is very repugnant to it, and you will confe • it, Hylas, when I aske you this Quetion. If Alexis were dead, would you then love her body? To which Hylas making no anwer; I ee you are mute truth hath ilenced you, or ele you are ahamed of a bad opinion. Neither the one, nor the other (aid Hylas) but what hould I anwer? Doe you thinke I can divine? I can give you an accompt of things pat if I can remember them, and of things preent when I know them; but as for things future, good Friend, who doe you take me for: Doe you thinke I had one of the Sibils to my Tutor, or that I was brought up at the choole of Prediction? Good Silvander, if you dicoure with me, talke of things within compae of mans capacity, and let the ecrets of the Gods alone: leave things future unto them, they have reerved them unto themelves. If you aske whether I doe love the body of Alexis: I anwer you, that I do; but if you aske me what I would doe if the body had not a oule, I mut end you to uch as can foretell things; you may take them along with you, if you will upon an errand to the Detinies, and when you returne, I hall enquire of you what I hall doe then: but in the meane time I will love the body of the faire Alexis, not as he will be a hundred yeares hence, but as he is now at this preent, the mot perfect workmanhip of the gods.

Thus talked Hylas, and Silvander would have replyed, when all the Company came to a narrow planke, where every hepheard was officiouly carefull to helpe his hepheardee over; and when they were all on the other ide, Silvander offered to fall into dicoure againe, but Diana hindred him, becaue hearing a hepheard and a hepheardee inging, he deired him to liten. All the Company turned their eyes to the place from whence the voice came, and drawing a little neerer, they aw a hepheardee itting under a hady Tree, and a hepheard upon his knees before her, courting her, and he returning him very didainfull anwers. Enough, enough Alcidon (aid he) if you will have me to tay any longer here, either be ilent, or talke of omething ele; and beleeve it, that whatoever you ay upon this ubject, will onely increae my diaffection to you. If I had not more hope (anwered hee) in the jutice of love, then in yours, I hould long ince, not onely have ceaed talking, but ceaed living. What can your hopes be, aid Daphnide? for if the God of whom you peake were jut, he would long ince have made you an example unto all uch as are o bold as to offer wrong? Doe not offend him (aid Alcidon) who hath power to order things according to his will, and of whoe power you cannot be o ignorant, as to thinke that you ought to corne me as you doe: The hepheardee would have replyed, had not the company been o neer, as caued her to be ilent.

Atrea, and the ret of the Company, who heard thee trangers, being invited by the beauty of the hepheardee, and the hanome deportment of the Shepheard, as well to atifi their curioity, as their duty, unto which the lawes of hopitality did oblige them, which were mot religiouly oberved in that Country; they addreed themelves unto the hepheardee, and after alutation, offered her and all her company, all manner of aitance; for at the ame time there came unto her two other hepheardees and a hepheard, who had trayed from them, and tayed under a hade untill the heat of the day was a little over. Daphnide, eeing this faire Company accoat her with uch courteous expreions, he anwered with all poible civility, and told them all in generall that the Heavens had beene mot gracious unto the Country, being inhabited by perons o accomplihed with all manner of merits. Atrea made anwer thus; There is not any here who is not very much devoted unto your ervice, as well in obedience to our Lawes which command us to be hopitable unto Strangers, as out of deire to have the honour of doing ervice unto perons of o much merit as you and your companions. Since my firt encounter is o good (aid the Stranger) I begin to hope for a happy concluion in my voyage: And ince your courteous offers doe imbolden me to enquire of what is neceary to be known; I beeech you fair hepheardee tell me, if there be not a Fountaine in this Country, which is called the Fountaine of Loves verity, and where it is? Atrea looked upon Paris and Silvander, and returned no anwer, which caned Silvander to anwer for her. Faire hepheardee (aid he) the Fountaine of which you enquire is in this Country; bnt love hath o ordered it that upon the matter it is not here, being guarded by uch inchanted Animals, as there is no accee unto it: And where is it, replyed Atrea? How, aid the Stranger, are you of
this Country, and ignorant of a thing o rare? It is almot incredible: Thoe who ee your face which is o faire, cannot chue but love you, and by conequence you cannot but be o curious as to know the truth of their affections who love you, which as I have heard ay; may be een in this fountain. I know, aid Atrea, and bluht a little, that it is your Complement which makes you peake o advantagiouly of my face, and nothing ele, therefore I will not anwer unto that. But as for that curioity which you thinke is in me; firt, I have no occaion for it, becaue I was never o happy as to be loved in that manner: and econdly, we never ue to have recoure unto the Fountaine you peake of, to know the mindes of thoe who erve us, becaue we have a better, and more ure way. What is that, I beeech you, (aid the tranger). It is, aid Atrea, Time, and the effects of it. I do conceive, aid Daphnide, that this way is very uncertaine; and I my elfe can ay, that I have been often deceived by it.

If that do faile us (replyed Diana) then we doe ue another remedy: What is that, aid the tranger? It is, anwered Diana, not to love at all. That remedy, aid Alcidon, is mot unjut, for thereby the innocent will be punihed, and not the culpable. For he who deceives any hepheardee, in faigning to love her, cares not whether he love him or no, and o receives no punihment for his fault: and he who does really love her, bears all the blame and punihment. You ee, generous hepheard (aid Hylas) that our hepheardees are as unjut as faire; and yet for all that, we can't chue but love them; what then hould we do, if their minds were as weet as their faces?

One of the hepheardees hearing Hylas peak thus, began to fix her eyes upon him, thinking that he hould know him. And doubtlee, but for his habit which did a little diguie him, he had not tood o long in doubt; but after he had a little better conidered with her elfe, he addreed her elfe unto Thameres, and asked him in a low voice, whether that hepheard who poke, was not Hylas, and he anwering, yes; he whipered Daphnide in the eare, and aid unto her, Madam, he whom you pake unto, is Hylas, and you know him not: The tranger bluhed; and holding her hand before her face, as being ahamed to be een in that habit, went back a pace or two, crying out, Oh heavens Hylas, how your habit alters you, and perhaps mine alters me as much: Then Hylas coming nearer her, he looked eriouly upon her, o as though he had not een her of a long time; and though her habit had much changed her, yet he knew her to be Daphnide, eteemed the fairet Lady in all Arles, or the Roman Provinces; but he was o much amazed at the ight of her, that he knew not whether he dreamed or waked. At the lat, after a long paue, he went back, looked upon her, and was not able to peake one word: which the tranger perceiving. Certainly, aid he, This is a Country of wonders; for I find in it hepheardees more civilized, than any perons in Cities: Naturall beauties, without any artifice; and the greatet wonder of all is, to ee Hylas ilent. Hylas turned towards her, and knew her that poke unto him, to be Carlis, the other Stiliana, and Hermanthe, with them: this ight did o amaze him, that not able to peake a word, he ran to embrace his deare friend Hermanthe; and after a long embracement, he parted, and imbraced againe; have I met with my dear Hermanthe? (aid he) Is it poible I hould find here the greatet beauties in all the Province of the Romans? I might have aid the whole world, if this Country in which we are were excepted. What? The o much admired Daphnide; the proud Stiliana, and Carlis, who firt taught me to love? The Gods have been abundantly favorable to me, in conducting you hither: Madam (aid he unto Daphnide) you, and your company, are come to be witnees of my Glory and Felicity.
