Hylas, anwered the tranger, you enjoy no contentment, but I do participate in it as your friend: but if you wonder to ee me in this equipage, I do no lee, to ee you thus diguied, and in a place where I had no thoughts of finding you: however, I doe thinke the encounter mot happy, if it will make me any harer in the Glory and Felicity which you enjoy. Madam, aid Carlis, he nevers offers any igne of joy for meeting with me, or with Stiliana. Oh my firt Mitree (aid he) why do you think o? you know that ones firt love is never forgotten. But you hew the contrary (aid he) for love cannot be, when the party loved is forgotten; and you cannot deny, but that you had forgotten us all. I am compounded of another mettal (aid he) then other lovers are; for I never ue to forget thoe whom I ever loved; nor is my affection to them extinguihed. 'Tis true, my memory will ometimes tumble, and be covered over with oblivion, as fire will be in the embers, and my affections will lacken as a bow that hath been too long bent; but my memory will get up againe: blow but the ashes from the embers, and
the fire will be in; and the bow after a little unbending, will aume its firt trength; even o will my memory, and my affection, when the ahes of oblivion are blown away, by the fight or preence of the party loved. I perceive, aid Stiliana, that Hylas is till Hylas I hope (aid Daphnide) that we hall have leiure to know further of your welfare; but in the meane time, let we hould commit ome errors amongt thee fair hepheardees, I pray Hylas tell us who they are, and whether Atrea and Diana be in the company. Madam, anwered Hylas, they are both there; and then he hewed them unto her; then Daphnide aluted them againe; and after he had well looked upon them, Fame I perceive (aid he) has undervalued the truth; for I ee your beauty goes beyond all reports. Madam, anwered Atrea, and bluht, thoe that live as we do, may ay, that they are hardly in the world; for living onely in woods and fields, fame can take no notice of us, and we think our elves very happy in her ilence. You may ay what you pleae, replyed Daphnide; but now I have een you, I am able to ay, and truly, that though fame hould peak highly in your advantage, yet he both is, and would be arre hort of the truth, and do you wrong. Madam, aid Diana, it is onely your weet civility which is pleaed to betow thee attributes upon us: And though we are, as my companion aith, almot out of the world: yet would we gladly be uch as you are pleaed to ay we are; for perfection is deireable in all. You cannot deire more then you have; replyed the tranger; for if you hould, your deires would be above the power of Nature: and I cannot believe it poible, he hould make two different beauties more perfect, How, Madam, aid Hylas, though they be uch as you ay they are, yet I was never in love with them, or o little, as it may be termed nothing. All birds, anwered Daphnide, are not pleaed with the pure light of the Sun, nor by conequence, your bad ight with thee great beauties. Nay, nay, Madam, replyed he, It is rather becaue there are greater beauties in this Country then they are, and you know Hylas was ever a lover of the fairet. I can very hardly believe what you ay, anwered the tranger. I hall make you confee it, aid he, if you will goe whether all this company are going: Dicreet hepheardees (continued he, and turned towards Atrea and Diana) know that you ee here in the habit of a hepheardee and hepheard, the fairet Lady, and mot generous Cavalier in all the Province of Galloligures; and I believe your Country never received a greater favour from heaven, then in receiving them therefore Noble Paris, I beeech you let them not depart from this company, until Adamas have een them at his houe. Paris and the hepheardees addreing themelves unto Daphnide, did excue themelves for not rendring them that honour which was their due; and beeeched them to favour the great Druid o far, as to viit his houe; which they conented unto, as well to atisfie the requet of Paris and the hepheardees, as out of their deire to peak with age Adamas, about ome affairs which brought them unto that place, having heard very much of his widom.

Hylas was very glad when they conented; and becaue Daphnide knew him in the Ile of Cama • g • es, and in Arles, and was well acquainted with his honour, he propoed many quetions unto him by the way, unto which the hepheardees would ometimes anwer for him, and ometimes Silvander: And though he was in a little kind of contraint before Daphnide, Stiliana, and Carlis: yet he could not chue but break out often in his anwers, epecially when Silvander pake: at which thee trangers did o laugh, that addreing himelfe unto Daphnide: Madam, aid he unto her, I think, that in taking upon you the habit of thee hepheardees, you have alo taken their humour, ince this hepheard's talk does pleae you o very well: for he never opens his mouth to contradict me, but preently all fall a laughing. But my good friend Silvander (aid he, and turned towards him) you mut know, that it is at you whom this Lady laughs, and not at me; for thy education being onely Rurall, thou peaket accordingly: therefore I think thy bet dicretion is, to talk no longer. Courteous hepheard, aid Daphnide, do not believe Hylas, you do not know him o well as I do; but I hould be very orry you hould have any uch opinion of me. Madam, anwered Silvander, Hylas and I have often uch contets as thee, and never believe each other. But Hylas, aid he, and turned towards him, do not mitake your elfe, for I do know before whom I peak, and know this Lady.

I had pent my time very ill amongt the Mailians, and had been both deafe and blind, if I had not heard of her merit, and een her beauty: I know, Hylas, and perhaps better then you do, who the faire Daphnide is, who Alcidon, and who is the great and renowned King E • rick: perhaps I can give a more particular relation of the City of
the Mailians and of Arles, then many others; and therefore though I am a hepheard doe not think to daunt me with your big words. Daphnide then interpoed; truly, aid he, I doe beleeve this hepheard knowes me, and I beleeve what he ayes, and alo I beleeve he knowes more then you thinke he doth. But kind hepheard (aid he unto Silvander) if it will not be too much trouble unto you, tell us how you came to know all thee things? Madam, anwered Silvander, I was along time in the Mailian chools where your Name was o cryed up by the Bardi, that every one did hear of it. How came you now to be in the habit of a hepheard (aid he) and what caue doth retaine you in it? Fortune, aid he, brought me into this Country, and Love tayes me in it. And aid Hylas, Love brought me into this Country, and Alexis tayes me in it. Who is that happy Alexis, aid he, (and miled) She is one, aid Hylas, who will make you bluh for hame, and grow pale with envie: he is o faire, that he hath no equall. Aylas, anwered he, you ay o much that I mut needs beleeve you in part, and too much to be beleeved in all; your owne eyes (aid he) will be witnees preently againt your elfe, and will enforce you to jutifie all my words; for I have not poke one yllable too much in her Commendations. Alcidon hearing this, thought himelfe concerned: Hylas (aid he) I will acknowledge your Mitree to be faire, but that he is fairer then Daphnide, if words will not maintaine the contrary, my blood and life hall. Hylas hearing this, aumed a very erious looke; as farre as words will goe, aid he, I will maintaine what I ay; but if you come to matter of blood and life, I will not onely quit her unto you, but unto any that hall maintaine the contrary; for my profeion is talking not killing: every one began o to laugh at this anwer, that Alcidon could not reply of a long time after.

Doubtlee their dicoure had continued longer, if they had not been very neer the houe of Adamas. In the meane time Alexis in contemplation of that contentment which he promied unto her elfe in the ight of Atrea, did tand leaning againt a window which looked towards the Plaine, and talked with Leonide. When he perceived the company comming, and aured her elfe that Atrea was amongt them, he tarted: ometimes he looked upon one, and ometimes upon another hepheardee; but when he pyed Atrea, oh, into what an extaie he was tranported! he fixed her eye upon her, and poke not a word, as if he would take her fill of that pleaing Object: At lat fetching a deepe igh, he hewed her unto Leonide with her finger; ee, ee, aid he, the fairet ight in the whole world, being as bad almot in that rapture, as Adrates was. Then keeping ilence a while, he went a pace or two backe from the window, and folding her armes upon her bret: Oh heavens (aid he) how dare I preent my elf before her, when he hath commanded me the contrary? What, aid Leonide will you relaps into your old errour? Were not thee coniderations ufficiently debated with Adamas before you came hither? have you o oone forgotten his prudent reaons? Doe not thinke (aid Alexis) that I have forgotten them, but I am ure Atrea will ee me, and I hall ee her, he will peake unto me, and I unto her, and is not this diobedience to her Command? Goe, goe, (aid hee unto me, I hall never forget thoe cruell words) goe diloyall man, and never come in my ight unlee I commmand thee. The Nymph thinking that if this dicoure went on, it would much diquiet Alexis, he would not anwer unto her; only thus, thee thoughts Alexis mut not now come into your mind; it is already reolved upon, the time is now come wherein you mut hew your elfe a man, Sonne to Alcippes, whoe courage was o highly eteemed by every one; you mut I ay change your Countenance and Garbe; you mut receive Atrea without any wonder, and at the firt accoat of her, have o much power over your elfe, that none may dicover you you know that the firt impreions take deepet roote, and upon them the mot ure judgement is built; therefore reolve with your elfe o to diguie the matter, that thoe whom your habit deludes may not be undeceived by your actions. Ah Madam (aid Alexis) how eaie a matter it is for thoe that are well to give counell unto the icke? here is a fault committed already replyed Leonide; why doe you call me Madam, and not Siter; you know Adamas will needs have me call Paris Brother, and o he commands me to call you Siter, and if you doe not the like you will be upected, you know that your face does extreamly reemble Celadon, and therefore you mut ue abundance of Art to deceive people. Siter, anwered Alexis, ince you are pleaed I hould call you o, I hall endeavour to carry my elfe as well as I can; but I aure you never was any, more put to it
then your mierable Siter is upon this occaion, and unle • e ome helpe me out I know not how I hall delude the eyes of Atrea with whom I never ued any diimulation or diguiement. Upon uch occaions as thee, aid the Nymph we mut make our wit and courage appeare, and as they ay make a vertue of neceity. Aure your elfe, the Authority of Adamas is o great, and every one hath uch an opinion of his Wiedome, that with a little helpe of your own, none will quetion but that you are his daughter.

As they were thus talking, Adamas being advertied of the coming of Atrea, he came to hearten Alexis, which was no mall Prudence; for he was o much out of her elfe, that good preparatives were but neceary, leat he being urpried he might give too much knowledge who he was. When they were in the midt of their dicoure, newes was brought them that all the Company was come in, to the firt Court of the Catle. Alexis bluht, and her legs trembled o, that he was contrained to fit downe. Leonide who perceived it, the better to hide all faults, told Adamas that it was good to draw the Curtains of the windowes, and to let in as little light as might be, that the alterations in the face of Alexis might not be dicerned, and that the pretence for it might be to hinder the Sunne from keeping the roome too hot. The Druide liking the Counell, commanded all the Curtaines to be drawne: But as they were buie in preparing all things on the one ide, Atrea was as much perplexed on the other: her heart did beat extreamly, and coming unto Phillis aid to her in her eare: Good Siter find ome excue or other out, which may caue us to tay a little; for I mut confee that my hopes to ee the face of Celadon in Alexis, does o much put mee out of my elfe, as I feare, that if I h • ve not a little time to recollect my elfe, I hall give too much knowledge of what I deire to conceale, epecially unto thee Strangers. Upon this, Phillis went unto Daphnide, and aid unto her: Are you not weary Madam with walking up the Hill? If it be your pleaure, I am ure all the company would be very glad to take a little breath before they goe up into the Hall. For my part (aid Daphnide) I like the motion very well, but would not propound it leat I hould dipleae. Hylas who could not indure to be retarded from his contentment in eeing his deare Alexis; Madam, aid he, if you were not in very good company I hould not offer to leave you; but ince you are, I beeech you take it not ill, if I goe before, and tell them that you are coming; for I had rather take breath with Alexis, than here. Then not taying for any, nor for the anwer of Daohnide, he went up the taires, at the top of which, and at the entrance into the Hall, he met Adamas, Leonide and Alexis: and becaue all three of them did thinke that the love of Hylas would be an excellent umbrage of what they deired to conceale, they made him as welcome as they could: The Druid himelfe, after he had aluted him, milingly aid, that it was eaie to ee who of all the Company was mot their friend: Sir, aid Hylas, if the hate which I have made in coming firt, move you to thinke o well of me, my taying the lat will be as good a tetimony of my good will, and I wih my company were as welcome unto you, and your company as it is deired by me. No quetion but it is, aid Leonide, is it not, Siter? For my part, aid Alexis, I am very much contented in it: Hylas then going neerer her: Fair Alexis, aid he, in a low voice, o my company yeeld you any contentment, it is enough: Why, (aid Leonide, eeming to be angry) doe you o little eteeme the ret of the company? I aure you proud Shepheard, I will be revenged of you, and before the day be done, you hall repent of your didaining me thus: he uttered thee words with an angry looke, and did very well feign a dicontented peron. But Hylas, who naturally did not care for any woman living, unlee her he loved I hall be very orry, aid he, when the faire Alexis repents of what he hath aid unto me: and till then, you will but loe your labour, if you eek for any revenge upon me: And when he doth repent of it, you need not eeke for any greater revenge, for my orrowes will be o great, that nothing can make them greater. Servant, anwered Alexis, as long as you doe love mee, you need not feare any revenge, for your good will is very deare unto mee.

He was ready to reply, when Adamas interrupted and asked him, who were thoe hepheards and hepheardees which were coming. There is, Father, aid he, Atrea, Diana, Phillis, and everall others of that neighbourhood: There are alo ome trangers, as Florice, Cyrcenea, and their Company; but that which invited me to <> me before, was to tell you, that we met by the way with faire Daphnide, a Lady of the
highet eteem of any in the Roman Province, and with the generous Alcidon, who diguied in the habit of hepheards, are come into this Country to eek for the Fountaine of loves verity: Alcidon is the mot beloved Cavalier in all the Province, epecially by the great Eurick: And thus you ee I am not the onely tranger, who diguieth my elf in the habit of a hepherd, to live happily in your Country. Adamas anwered him; Is it poible it hould be the faire Daphnide, with whom the great Euricke, King of the Viigots was in love? and Hylas anwering him, that he was the ame, he continued; though I never aw her, yet I hall know her, for I have a Picture which they aure me, does very much reemble her, except her habit do caue an alteration: yet I will eem to know nothing, and will bid all our hepherdees as welcome as I can.

Their dicoure had continued longer, had they not been prevented by the coming of the Company: for Atrea, although he was the caue of their tay, yet he was not able any longer to tay from the ight of that o much loved face; therefore he made ign unto Phillis, who undertanding her meaning, addreed her elfe unto Daphnide and Paris, and aid unto them aloud: Now if it pleae you, it is full time to follow Hylas; for what will Adamas think, when he heares by him that we are here? 'Tis true, aid Daphnide; and taking Atrea and Diana by each hand, they led the way, and the taires being very large, they went up all three a bret, and the ret of the company confuedly followed after. Adamas waited for them in the entry of the great Chamber, where he received them as kindly as poibly he could: and eeming not to know Daphnide nor Alcidon, he addreed his peech unto the hepheards of his acquaintance, and aid unto them with a miling countenance: Faire hepheardees, you give me ome caue to think that you are proud, becaue you eem to leight your Neighbours: has my Daughter been thus long here, and you not daign one courteous viit? Atrea, who oberved, that though he poke to all in generall, yet he addreed his peech particularly unto her, he made anwer for all. Revere • d Father (aid he) things that dod epend upon the will of many, are oftentimes retarded, though every particular deires to make hate: This excue, aid Adamas, will hardly hold; for methinkes every one of you in particular, does owe me as much friendhip, as I doe owe you all in generall. Then Diana undertook the matter; Father, aid he, and miled, many had rather give that which they do not owe, then pay their due debts: but as we have committed this fault, o are we punihed for it, in depriving our elves o long, from that which is o great a happinee unto us: Upon this, Daphnide addreed her elfe to alute Leonide, and Atrea the like unto the diguied Alexis: but oh how he was atonihed, when he cat her eye upon his face? and how amazed was Alexis, when he aw Atrea coming to kis her? Oh love? into what a condition didt thou put them both, when they kied each other? The hepheardee was as red, as if her face were all fire; and Alexis trembled as if a great fit of an ague had been upon her: Hylas, who oberved how zealouly his Mitree aluted this hepherdee, he grew o jealous, that he could not endure he hould hold her any longer in her armes; and this jealouie was a caue of their parting, o as Diana aluted her the next; after her, Phillis; and then all the ret of the company.

Adamas, who deired to hadow as much as poibly he could, the alteration in the face and pirit of his Daughter; after all alutations were done, and that all the company entred confuedly into the great Chamber, he et Alexis in the mot obcure place; and when they were all ready to it down, he eemed to take notice of Daphnide and her company, therefore asked Thameres in a loud voice, who thoe fair trangers were? Sir, aid he unto him, Hylas can better informe you of them, then I can, if it pleae you to aske him; for I can tell you no more, but that we met them as we came hither, and he told us that they were Ladies of as high eteem, as any in all the Province of the Gallogures. Then Paris coming nearer unto Adamas, told him, that it was the fair Daphnide, and the famous Alcidon, well known for beauty and merit in the Court of the great Eurick. The Druid eeming as if he knew nothing of them before, eemed alo to be very angry with Paris for telling him no ooner. Then addreing himelfe unto her; Madam, (aid he) I beeech you pardon my ignorance, and lay the fault upon your habit, that I have not rendred that honour which is your due Reverend Father (anwered Daphnide) when I diguied my elfe in this manner, my intention was not to be known in this Country where I am come, not in the rank of Daphnide, but onely to find that tranquility which the Gods have promied unto me: and I do believe, that but for Hylas, I had gone through my voyage, as unknown as I deired. But ince I am prevented, I beeech you
Father, let all thoe circumtances of honour and repect, which you mention, alone; and help me to find out thoe wholome remedies which the Gods have made me hope to receive in this Country. Adamas with much honour and ubmiion, anwered her; that he would erve her in all things, within the compae of his capacity; and that he would not be dipenced with, for doing her that honour which was her due: then preenting a Chair unto her; another unto Alcidon, and unto all the ret of the company, every one taking their places, Atrea at next Alexis, and Leonide on the other ide, which prevented Hylas from being next his new Mitree: And becaue he thought her too much taken with Atrea, he often interrupted her, and contraried her in her peech, o forced her to anwer him: Phillis perceived by Atrea's looks, that he was troubleome to her, and therefore to give her more opportunity of talking with that Druid, who had uch a reemblance of her beloved hepherd, he entred into dicoure with him; My late ervant, aid he unto him, is there not one park of that ancient affection towards me alive? This new Mitres whom you adore o much, makes no great account of you: Come, come, return again to me that loves you, and eteems you as you deerve. Hylas who was paionatly in love with Alexis; Late Mitres, aid he unto Phillis, you conider not unto whom you peak, when you mention any parks of old affection; the very word old, is enough to make me hate it. If therefore you would have me return again to you, talk no more of any old parks: for this is my Motto
An hour is too long to love?
A Minut's fair; and not above.

Do not think that the eteem which you ay you have of me, will any thing attract me; for one never ueth to care for the eteem of thoe whoe friendhip he hath quitted, and who are meerly indifferent to him; Silvander then began to anwer for Phillis. Reputation, aid he, which every one does o much deire, what is it ele but this eteem which you o much contemne? if it be to be eteemed, even amongt enemies; why, Hylas, hould it not be eteemed from one whom you have o much loved? I perceive, anwered Hylas, that Silvander is not in the place which he deires, no more then I am; and to vent his choller upon ome body, he tells me uch tales, as Nures ue to lull their children aleep withall: But my good friend Silvander, have a good heart, and take patiently thee rubs of fortune: conider that we live in a very bad age, wherein favours are not dipened according to merit; let us be patient man, fortune will one day ceae from perecuting us.

p.U:
aid this unto Silvander, becaue Leonide in favour of Paris, had placed Diana in the midt, o that Silvander could not come near her, but was forced to it betwixt Celadon and Florice; which being known unto every one, was the reaon why every one laughed at the anwer, epecially Phillis, who aid; It mut be confeed, Silvander, that now it happens unto you, as unto one who will undertake to part two who are fighting, and betwixt them is wounded, though he had no quarrel. If you had not often tryed (anwered Silvander) that the weapons of Hylas have neither point nor edge, I hould not wonder you hou'd ay o. But, hepherdee, having had o much experience of them, I wonder you hould have that opinion: Never wonder (aid the hepherdees) for he hath changed his weapons, he does not now fight with his own; thoe wherewith he hath now wounded you, are borrowed of one whoe cutome is to vanquih. After that rate, anwered he, I hall partly confee as much. To tell you truly (aid Hylas) neither of you can wound me, either with your own Armes, or any other you can borrow; for be they as good as they will, they have no force againt me: If they were in my hands, aid Florice, what would you ay unto them? I would ay, anwered he, That I do not remember you ever had any I hope, aid Cyrenea, that you will not ay o by me. I mut confee (aid Hylas) that when I aw you but eldome, I loved you much; and when I aw you much, I loved you but little. Her ight then, aid Palinice, did as the Scorpion does, which heales the wound it makes; but I am confident you will not ay o of me. Of you (aid he, as if he were atonihed) for God ake tell me how they call you, that I may know whether your Name can wound me more then your Fade? I perceive, aid Stiliana, that it is onely I who had the power to Captivate you. The hort pittance of time that I was your Prioner, anwered Hylas, does plainly hew how victorious you were. The truth is, replyed he, you did go out of Prion, but it was not without paying
your ranome. If I did pay it (replied he) then I owe you nothing, and if you thinke to make me your Prioner againe as eaily as you did, you are very much mitaken: I am now a better Souldier then I was, and therefore I would advie you not to put it to the hazard; your teares I aure you will not doe it. Come, come, aid Carlis, Hylas is only mine, for as I was the firt that ever he loved, o he ought to be the lat, is not this true, Hylas? Conider Carlis, aid he unto her, that every thing wil mot certainly return to its firt beginning; and as the firt time that ever I did ee you, I did not love you; o hall I not love you, the lat time I ee you.

div.p:
None could forbeare laughi • g at the anwers of Hylas, which continued o long that Alexis and Atrea had time enough to talke; but though Alexis might have imployed that time very well, yet he was o long before he could begin, being hindred by everall coniderations, that perhaps the opportunity had been lot, if Atrea had not begun to peake firt. For this diguied Druid eeing her before her eyes who had commanded her never to ee her, fearing to be known by her voice, or ome other of her getures, was o mute, that he durt not open her mouth, which Atrea attributed unto the little acquaintance that was betwixt them, or ele conidering that he had beene alwayes converant with the Virgin Druids, he knew not how to talke of Country affaires. But the hepherdee was much mitaken, for the reaon was, becaue he knew too much, and becaue that face which did repreent that of Celadon, as well in her memory as before her eyes, it made her extreamly deirous to gaine the favour of Alexis, which was already but too much gotten, and therefore hee was the firt that broke ilence thus. When I doe conider the beauty of your face, and the Graces wherewith the heavens have adorned you above all the Beauties of our age, I am almot ready to tax them with injutice in depriving this Country o long of that which it produceth mot rare, and in hiding you amongt the Druid Virgins o farre from us: But when I call to mind that the whole Univere is not too good to erve that great God who made it, I mut confee that the choice of you was mot jut, being the mot perfect peece in the World. I wih (aid Alexis) that thoe perfections which your civility puts upon me were as truly mine, as yours are in you, that I might in ome ort be worthy to erve the great Tautates: Idoe not bluh faire hepheardee to heare you ue this language, which rather puts me in mind of my imperfections, then repreents unto me what I am. I am orry, replied Atrea that you hould have o ill an opinion of mee, as to thinke that I uppoe any imperfections in you: For though the heavens have made me a hepheardee, and have given me no more wit then uits with a rurall life, yet as the Sunne is eene by all upon whom it hines, by ome more, ome lee according to their Capacities, o may I ee your Perfections, and know them, o farre as to admire them, though I mut confee that many others unto whom Tautates hath given better judgement, may dicerne them better, but cannot admire them more then I doe. I hall not contradict a judgement o favourable, replied Alexis: only I pray God that when you know me better, you doe not revoke it: For though neither my intention nor profeion will let me be long in this place, yet I hall alwayes thinke my elfe exceedingly happy in the favour of all thoe who reemble you, particularly your elfe, whoe acquaintance I have o long deired; and I aure you that this deire will make me leave my Companions with lee griefe, when I know that I hall ee Atrea: Madam, anwered Atrea, this favour is trancendent: For if you have a will to be with us, our happinee is immeaurable; or if it be out Complement onely to oblige us, yet we are happy in that you entertaine uch thoughts in you. But I may mot truly ay, that the newes of your coming filled the Country both with joy and orrow; orrow in hearing of your icknee, and joy to hear we hould be o happy as to ee you. It is o long before you came hither (aid Alexis) that if any other but you, fair hepherdee had told me o, I hould not have beleeved it; but to let this dicoure alone, I beeech you tell me, how you ue ordinarily to pend your time: for I am told that the hepherds and hepherdees of Forrets doe live the happiet of any people in the World. It is certainly (aid Atrea) very happy unto uch whom Fortune hath not foraken: and you know Madam, that thoe who were once happy, when they loe part of what they injoyed, are more mierable then thoe who alwayes were mierable. Tis true, aid Alexis, but I doe not thinke your rurall and olitary life doth meet with any rubs of Fortune. Not o much aid Atrea, as thoe who live in Court, and in the tranactions of the World; but as Lakes though lee then the Sea, have
their tormes and tempets; o it is with us, we alo have our misfortunes and mieries; and for my part I may well ay, that having within the pace of one month lot a Father and a mother, my affliction is o great, that I am not yet recovered of it: Is it long, aid Alexis, ince you had this loe? About foure or five months ince, (aid Atrea) and upon this he fetched a deep igh: It is a very ad affliction (aid Alexis) to loe uch friends, but nothing is more naturall, then for Parents to dye before Children; and this may be your comfort, that they left you at an age wherein you are able to governe your elfe. One thing, aid Atrea, doth mot exceedingly trouble me, which is, that I am partly a caue of their death: Truly, aid Alexis, you bring it into my memorie, that I have heard omething concerning it, and I thinke they told me that they were drown'd, in endeavouring to helpe you out of a water into which you were falne. Pardon me Madam, aid Atrea, it is true, that I fell into that fatall River of Lignon, as I endeavoured to helpe a hepherd who was drowned there: and the newes being carried to Hippolita my Mother, that I was drowned, he was urpried with uch a fright, that he did never recover it, but dyed preently after: and my Father for griefe of her followed her: Thus was I at once deprived both of father and mother. Atrea could not relate thee accidents without much griefe, and Alexis alo; eeming as if it were out of compaion: I pray aid he, who was that poore hepherd which was drowned? I know not, aid Atrea, adly, whether you heard of him, but his name was Celadon, brother unto Lycidas whom you ee there: Was it Celadon (aid Alexis) who was onne unto Alcippes and Amarillis? The ame, aid Atrea; I have often heard talke of him, aid Alexis, truly it was a very ad accident. I aure you Madam, aid Atrea, that all manner of delights hath been ever ince banihed out Coats,; For when he was alive, there was nothing but mirth and jollity amongt us, and now uch a dulnee reignes, as if it were not the ame Country: And for my part having lot a Father and a Mother, who loved me mot tenderly, and falne into the hands of an Uncle, my orrowes are double. But Madam I beeech you pardon me for troubling you with uch ad dicoure. Oh, aid Alexis, you doe infinitely ingage me in it, and you will doe me an extreame pleaure if you will give me a relation of every particular which concernes you; for beides your merit and vertue, which obligeth every one to eteem you, I have a mot particular deire to be intereted in your love; and therefore I beeech you continue on Madam, aid Atrea, it is an infinite honour to me, and I protet unto you, that from the very firt minute I aw you, there is omething which o devotes me unto you, that nothing can divert me from your ervice, but death Alexis would have replied, and perhaps have entred farther into dicoure if the jealouie of Hylas had not hindred her; but he not being able to endure this long dicoure betweene thee two Lovers, he did impudently fall upon his knees before Alexis, and taking her hand, kied it before he was aware, which he perceiving pulled backe, and aid unto him: how now Servant, does the faire hepherdees of Lignon permit uch familiarities? The Virgin Druids, from whence I came, I aure you would thinke this very trange. Mitree, aid Hylas, even as I doe not ue to regulate my elfe according to the civility of thee hepherdees, o you ought not to follow the everity of thoe Druids: for if you doe, neither you nor I hall receive much contentment by it. I know not what you meane, aid Alexis, but I am ure you mut have very trong arguments to divert me from following the example of thoe holy Virgins, amongt whom I have beene o long converant. I do beleeve what you ay, replied Hylas, but you mut know, you need no wore Rhethorique to make me change my Nature. I hould be orry, anwered Alexis, to force you unto any change, for I would have you be as you are; onely let the law be equall between us; and this, as your Mitree, you may very well allow. Tis true, aid Hylas, but how doe you meane? I meane aid Alexis, that as I allow you to be as you are, o you mut allow me to be as I am; and without any changing of humours, either in you or me, we may love each other, as we did at firt. I doe allow of part of what you ay, replied Hylas; but the ret is not according to my mind: and I feare you have beene o cloytered up amongt the Camutes, that you are halfe poiled: Every one began to laugh at the dicoure of Hylas. In the meane time, Adamas entertained Daphnide and Alcidon, after this manner.

Madam (aid he unto her) I make no quetion but that it was upon a good occaion you came into this Country: for otherwie you would never have left the lutre
and delicacies of the Court, I hould not have preumed to aske the caue, had not your elfe emboldned me; and knowing thereby that you expect ome ervice from me, my readines to do it, prompts me to ask what it is, to the end I may erve you according to your merit, and my duty. Father, anwered Daphnide your widom, and my need of your aitance, makes me trut you both with this ecret, and the greatet I hall ever have. I hall think my condition very happy, aid the Druid, if I meet with any occaions to employ my elfe in your ervice: and to make it appeare how much I eteem your merit, I beeeth you take o much paines to ee a Gallery which is in this houe, and there you hall find your own Picture ranked as it deerves. I did never think, aid Daphnide, that • a thing o little worthy, of either eeing or preerving, hould be in the poeion of the Great Adamas. Yet ince you have done o, I hall think the Gods intend good unto me, by infuing this curioity unto you, which argues a willingnee to helpe me in this buinee, from whence my whole happinee mut proceed. I hall acquaint you Father, before we part, with the occaion which brought me hither; in the meane time, I beeech you till me, in what part of this Country is the fountaine of loves verity? and how I may ee it? I can verily tell you, Madam, aid the Druid, where this Fountaine is, for it is not farre from hence: but I thinke it to be a thing impoible for you to ee it, becaue it is trangely inchanted, and guarded by Lyons and other fierce Animals, o as no humane force can quell them. If the hazard of a life, aid Alcidon, will conduce unto the contentment of my Lady, he hall quickly receive what he deires. I doe believe aid the Druid, that if courage and valour could doe any thing againt inchantments, the faire Daphnide would have what he deires, by the meanes of the valiant Alcidon.

But you mut know, that the trength of all men in the world united together, will do no good; for pirits which are uperior unto the nature of men, are o puiant, that even one of them is able to ruine the whole Vnivere, unlee the great Tautates for the preervation of mankind, did retrain them: o as the afer way is to have recoure unto Prayers and Supplications, or ele tay untill the time prefixed be expired, and the conditions of the inchantment performed. What are the conditions? aid Alcidon: They are, aid Adamas, very trange: For the enchantment mut not end but in blood, and by the death of the mot faithfull lover, and loved, that ever was in this Country. This, aid Daphnide, is a mot trange Fate, and mut needs be mierable My elfe (aid Alcidon) can furnih out the mot faithfull lover: yes, aid Daphnide, and miled, if to love in everall places at once, be fidelity. If you, replyed Alcidon, could but manifet your fidelity, as I can, Alcidon would preently hazard his life. I aure you, aid Daphnide, I am not o deperate as to die, to make inchantments ceae. But Madam, aid Alcidon, It hould eem the will of the Gods o to doe, ince they commanded us to come hither. I hall obey the will of the Gods, aid Daphnide, as far as poibly I can; but before I take this coure, mut have a more cleare and abolute command for it. This, replyed Alcidon, argues but a very faint affection: I do confee it, aid he; for I cannot undertake to be a acrifice for the publique: beides, I am not now in love with any; and therefore why hould I hazard my life for any: and if I were, I would not do it. I hould think them out of their wits that would; for it is not likely any that loves well, would deprive themelves of the ight and preence of them they love, to put an end to an inchantment.

But Father, aid he, and turned towards Adamas, I ee that Alcidon contraines me to dicover unto you, the caue of my coming hither: If you pleae therefore we will retire, and I hall willingly doe it, upon condition you will give me the bet advice you can Madam, aid the Druid, I would I were as able to give you good counell, as my affection promps me to do you all manner of ervice: If you pleae therefore to leave all this good company together, you may retire into a Gallery which is cloe by, and call whom you pleae to accompany you. Upon this, riing up, Adamas addreed himelfe unto Leonide, Paris, and Alexis, and commanded them to tay with thoe faire hepherdees, and curteous hepheards, whilet he waited upon Daphnide into the Gallery: and you, Hylas, aid he, laying his hand upon his houlder, I entreat you to entertaine this good company, and as one of our bet friends do my houe honour: Faith, aid Hylas faintly, I ue more to dihonour, then honor the houes where I am; yet to obey you, I will do my bet, provided my Mitres will do as I bid her: every one did laugh at the anwer of Hylas, epecially Alexis, who holding her hand before her face, aid unto him very handomly; Perhaps Hylas, you will he too evere; No, no, aid Hylas, I require but word for word, if o, aid Alexis, and if Adamas permit me, I am contented
Then, fairet Mitres, aid he unto her, entreat all this company, epecially Hylas, to keep you company all this day, and a little longer if you will. For why hould o many good friends part o oon? Adamas who was very glad of this requet, anwered before Alexis.

I aure you Hylas, aid he, that I do deire it with all my heart, and thoe who will not condecend unto that deire, doe extreamly dioblige me. I will tell you, Father, for them all, aid Hylas; that we will all obey you with as good a will as you can deire it: and though all hould goe away, yet I would tay alone, to give a tetimony what power you have over me. Believe me, Hylas, aid Daphnide, you have very well improved your elfe in this Country, and have learned o much civility, that when you come againe into Camargue, you may keep a Schoole, Madam, aid Hylas, If all my Schollars would prove like unto my Mitres, I hall take ome delight in it: otherwie, believe me, I would not impart my knowledge, unlee unto ome uch a one as your elfe. You doe oblige me, aid he, in equalling me unto Alexis. Pardon me, replyed Hylas preently, I did not well conider with my elfe when I committed this error; for uch is my affection unto my Mitree, that I cannot judge of any thing but to her advantage. Daphnide had anwered,, if he had heard thee words, but he was gone away too far off, and carried with her Alcidon, Stiliana, Carlis, and Hermantes, the ret tayed in the Great Chamber, where a Collation was brought in.

The Gallery into which the wie Adamas conducted Daphnide and Alcidon, was more coniderable for the curioities which were in it, then for the magnificence of the Structure; though the Doors, Windowes, and Chimneyes, were all of perfectly polihed Marble, very rich and beautifull, though the lights were at jut ditances; a regular proportion in the height and widenee, exactly oberved according to the length and rules of Architecture; and Fretworkes and Gilding was not pared; yet uch had been the care of the wie Druid, to inrich it with all manner of rarities and curioities, which either Europe, Aia, or Africa produced; not onely of his owne time, but of all ages pat, whoe memory was not lot, that thee did much exceed the richnee of the buildings; and as the one did take the eye with beauty, the other did trike the mind with admiration beyond all thought.

The Arch which was upported by a large Frice, was painted with the mot ancient Hitory of the Gaules, ever ince the great Dis-Samothes unto Francus, who being abent, and taken up with his other Conquets, let the Government of the Dominions unto the Druids and Gaulih Knights. There was not forgotten the Great Dryus, who by the intitution of the Druids, left Religion, and the Laws of his Fathers, unto his ucceive Nephews. There alo was the portracture of the Great Hercules, who married the Princes Galathea, who by his eloquence and Arms, did draw the Gaules unto Civility, and unto Generoity by his example. There alo was Sigoveus, and Belloneus; the one of which went over the Alpes, conquered, and Callidot, Gaul Cialpine; and the other paing into the Forret of Hircinia, did found the Kingdom of the B • yens. To be briefe, there one might ee the Gaules under Brennus, triump in Rome over thoe great Citizens, there loading themelves with Gold: And paing from thence into Greece, rifled the Gold and Treaures of the Temple of Apollo, and o returned into their Country.

Above this, was a econd Frice, wrought with everall orts of Fretwork gilded, which was a great ornament to the Edifice. Betwixt them both, was placed the tatues of the Roman Emperours, from Caear unto the third Valentinian. But the greatet curioity of the place was, that every pace betwixt the Windows, was filled with Maps of all the Provinces of Gaule, o exactly drawne, that as one walked, one might not only know the ditances of places, but alo the cituation of places, Townes, their Climates, the coures of the Rivers, and the propriety of every Province in this little world. No obervable battle, or important iege, but was et in its right place; o as the great iege of Alexia, and the ignal expeditions of Caear, might be een in the plates where they were acted.

About thee Maps, might be eene the Pictures of thoe Princes, who ruled thoe Provinces from time to time, o as there might be een Pharamond, Clodion, and Merovius; and after him, without any Crown, Childerick his Son, for he was not yet King, becaue his Father was alive. In the Map of the Sequaners and Hednois, one might ee Athanarick, and his wife Bliinde, who though he never paed the Rhine, was yet et there as
Father unto the valiant Gaud elles the firt King of the Burgundians, who planted upon the bankes of Arar and Rone. Next unto this King was his wife the wie and pious Theudelinda; after them, their onne Gunditch, who did firt ettle the Crown in Gaul; after that, Gondebert with his three Brothers, Chilperio, Godamar, and Godegeiles. To be briefe, the Druide was o curious, that nothing could be deired, which was not to be een there; o as Daphnide, Alcidon, and their company admired at thee rarities, and eteemed them the mot excellent peeces that ever eye beheld, and cating her eye by chance upon the map of Aquitane, the faire Daphnide aw there all the valiant Viigots who there reigned; As oone as he perceived them, he could not take off her eye, becaue he knew there the names and faces of many: Amongt the ret, of Thorimond of Thierry his Brother, and of the valiant Eurioke, next whom he aw her owne Picture, as when he was about the age of eighteen or twenty yeares, he kept her eye long upon it; and afterwards cating them upon the Portraiture of Euricke, he could not chue but igh and ay: Oh great Euricke, how fatall was the expedition which ravihed thy Scepter from thee, and what great caue have I to grieve, ince it is not permitted me to follow thee? Madam, replied Alcidon, it mut needs be confeed, that the loe of Euricke was a generall loe, but it would have beene much greater, if yours had followed; and doe you not thinke that the Gods in preerving you had a great care of me? Such is their goodnee Madam, that they never reject the prayers of the jut. I doe wonder at that the more, aid Daphnide, becaue mine are not received which were made with o much jutice and reaon: For, is it not mot jut and reaonable to accompany in death, thoe whom they loved in life? Adamas hearing his dicoure was very deirous to heare more, o as beeeching Daphnide to ubmit her will to the great Tautates, he deired her to it downe, and to beleeve that all things are o wiely dipoed by him, that all humane widome was contrained to confee it elfe ignorant and blind, in comparion of his omnicient Providence. Then Daphnide itting next unto Adamas, and all the ret of the company taking their places, he began thus.

div.head: The Hitory of Daphnide, Euricke, and Alcidon.
div.p:
I know very well, reverend Father, that the great Tautates does all things for the bet: For loving us, as the workmanhip of his owne hands; it is not likely he will withdraw his love from us. But let me tell you, that as Phiique though for our good is yet very bitter and loathome; o thoe afflictions which wee receive from the hands of the Gods, though they be very good for us, yet are they very heavy upon thoe that receive them. Thoe who murmur againt his will are indeed much too blame; but if when they feele the mart they hrinke and bewaile it, they doe but pay the Tribute •
of their weaknee and humanity. I doe confee, that the goods which I have received from his hands are innumerable, and his favours are above his punihments; but we being all of a nature more enible of the bad, than the good, I am forced to ay, that the afflictions which I have received have almot blotted out the memory of the bleings. And being reolved to retire my elfe from the tormes of the World, there is nothing which hinders me but the puruit of this Cavalier, whom I call troubleome: This being the occaion which brought me into this Country; I beeech you Father give me leave to let you undertand how the cae tands betwixt us; that ince the Fountaine of loves Verity is hut, we may by your wie Counell and advice, finde ome eae in our troubles.

Know therefore that Thierry the great King of the Viigots dying honourably in the battle ought in the Cathalaunique fields, he left many children behind him, ucceors, not only in his Crowne, but alo in his courage and valour. He who firt ucceeded him was Thorimond his eldet Sonne, he being received King and crowned in Tholoue, he made it his principall tudy, not only to enlarge the limits of his Kingdome: but alo to replenih it with Cavaliers and Ladies: Heaven was at that time favourable unto his will; for neither Ataulfes nor Vulalia his Predeceors, nor the great Thierry his Father had neere o many accomplihed Gallants nor o many faire and wie Ladies as this great and generous King had. It was my Fortune at that time to be brought unto the Court by my mother, when I was about fifteene or ixteen yeares of age. I mut confee
that I did not yeild unto any of my age, in the good opinion which I had of my elfe, either by reaon of the confidence I had in my own beauty, which the flatteries of men infued into me, or by reaon of that love which every one is apt to have of themelvs, which made me thinke all things more perfect in me than in others: But o it was, that me thought I did attract the hearts as well as the eyes of all in the Court. The King himelfe who was one of the mot accomplihed Princes that ever the Viigots had, da • gned to cat a favourable eye upon me, and to carrae me; but there being a diparity in our ages, he did withdraw himelfe conceiving and conidering that uch a love was more fit for one that was younger than himelfe.

At the ame time Alcidon was with the King, and I may without flattery ay before his face, that then he was the very Sun of the Court, the beauty of his face, his tature, his hanome proportion, his garbe, his becomingnee in every thing: his weet dipoition, his courteie, valour, vivacity of pirit and wit, his generoity, and his other perfections did get him the onely eteeme of the time. The King who was infinitely deirous that his Court hould flourih in the bravery of Cavaliers, above all other Courts of Europe; he oberving the merit of Alcidon in his youth, did take a particular care of him, auring himelfe that if this hopeful Plant wat carefully pruned, he would prove the glory of his Court.

Never bluh Alcidon to heare me peake o advantagiouly of you in your preence: I would have you know that my jut hatred of you, hall not hinder me from peaking the truth, and becaue he paued a little, as if he expected he hould anwer; I do admire, aid he, that you hould ee in me uch ecret qualities, which perhaps all that know me would contradict, and yet that you hould neither ee nor beleeve my extreame affection, it being o great, as all that know me cannot be ignorant of it. I have long debated this in my oule, and can find no other reaon for it, unlee that perhaps you reemble thoe that make their eteem to appeare highet when they would be hut of the peron whom they eem to eteem; We hall debate that, aid he, another time, then returning to her dicoure, he thus cotinued.

Thorimond intending to furnih Alcidon with all poible accomplihments and knowing that the bravet actions and noble deignes doe pring from love, to ow the eeds in his oule, he commanded him to love and court me. Alcidon, who was not o young, (though not above eighteen yeares of age) but he was apprehenive of the favour which the King did him, and knowing alo that his advancement depended upon his obedience he undertooke his Commands, and applied himelfe unto me, as much as any one of hils age poibly could; and to traine up his Youth in all compleat exercies, the King caued Bals to be kept very often, alo Riding at the Ring and Tilting: It chanced, that preently after Alcidon had received this command, the Ball was kept in the preence of Thorimond and the Queene: it was the cutome at thoe Bals, to dree themelves with their bet art: It hapned that day day, as if it were done upon deign, that both he and I were in white. And becaue he would let the King ee how willing he was to obey his commands, when the Ball began, he tooke me out; which the King perceiving, and oberving that the youngnee of both was uch as we had not confidence enough to peak unto each other, he began to laugh, and ay unto thoe about him. I cannot tell who put that couple together; but if it was Fortune, it appears in this that he is not blind; for I thinke they could not poibly be better ma • cht. They are both as innocent as their habits peakes them, and I beleeve they have not o much boldnee as to peak one word: And it hapned as the King aid; for young Alcidon (whether out of bahfulnee, or becaue ome parke of love began to kindle in his oule which kept him in that repect off me) did pas away all that night and poke not one word unto me. And I, having no deignes at that time, did tudy to pleae the eyes of all in generall, and had no particular aimes.

Ever ince this day affection increaed, and to that height, that as his heart was inflamed, o his tongue told his dieae: And I mut confee that his merits and ervices gave uch eloquence unto his language, that I was perwaded he did love me, and ere long that he did deerve to be loved. In the meane time, he advanced himelfe o high in the favour of his Mater, that there was no office about him o great, unto which he might not apire; and indeed after he had given him free accee unto his Peron, and in all privacies how great oever, he betowed upon him the greatet office belonging to his Crown, though perhaps his minority of age was not o fit for it, as ome other. The
truth is, o many amiable qualities, and noble perfections, did o much <> his youth, that envy it elfe did not blame the Kings choice. But oh wie Alamas, them is nothing in this world durable; Fortune may well be painted with two face, one for properity, another for adverity: For this great King, in the midt of his owne Kingdome and Forces, was mot unfortunately killed by a Chyrurgion. This wicked <> being to let the King blood, whether by chance or villany, he o cut the vein, that he could not tay the bleeding: The King perceiving this accident, he took a <> in his left hand, and in anger killed the Chyrurgion; but that did not help him, for he dyed preently after to the great griefe of all his ubjects.

Judge, Father, whether this uddain death was not terrible unto my Mother and me; It caued us to retire as oon as we could, into the Province of the Romans, where our etate lay, fearing ome <> in this Kingdome, which was deprived of o great a King. As for Alcidon, his griefe was uch, as it was believed he would not live: He knowes how I reented his orrowes, and grieved for his loe, as our amity commanded me; yet he had o forgotten both me, and all his promies, as I never heard of him all that time. Unto Thorimond, ucceeded his brother Thierry, who took upon him the Crown of the Vi •
gots, with a deire to augment it. And to that end, hearing that the King of Swedes would needs extend their limits unto Spain: he ent him word, (though he had married his iter) that if he would not deit from this enterprie, he would oppoe him: of which Richard making no account, (for o was the King of Swedes called); Thierry paed over the Pirenian hills, fought him, and was victorious. Thierry, dying preently after. Eurick his brother ucceeded him; who by his valour, quelled all the <> or the people; and afterwards eeing that the Romans, who called us their ancient friends and confederates, would ubmit unto us as the ret of the Gaules, he turned his Armes againt us, I mean in the Province of the Romans.

I hall not init upon particular decription of thee Victories, ince they are not pertinent to our dicoure. But I mut tell you, that after he had taken the City of the Mailians, he beieged Arles, becaue until that time I never heard of Alcidon: and he had no more memory of me, then if he had never een me. But then, as if he was newly waked out of a deep leep, he bethought himelfe, and writ unto me. You may imagine Father, how a young pirit, that had a very good opinion of herelfe, could reent this long ilence, which I could not call • om, becaue I valued my elfe at uch a rate, as I thought I could not be corned. Now thinking very often with my elfe, that he cared not for me, I vowed a hundred times not to care for him; and that though he hould return unto me with all imaginable ubmiion, yet would I look upon him onely with an indifferent eye: I will not deny, but this loe was a very great griefe unto my oule; and I mut confee; I love him; o as when I received this Letter from him, the memory of his former merit, made me break open the eals and I found thee words.

div.head: Alcidons Letter unto Daphnide
div.p: I Cannot tell, Madam, whether you will know my hand, or have yet in memory the Name of Alcidon, o long has my misfortune eparated me from you, and hindred me from keeping my elfe in your memory by any good ervice. If you have yet any memory of me, and if the loe of two uch dear Maters, and if the long imployments in a continuall warre, will be admitted as good excues, I beeech you, Madam, to pardon my long ilence, until I may with your permiion, let you know by word of mouth the unfortunate occaions which have all this while deprived me of my chiefet happinee. If your goodnes can urmount my hopes, and grant me o much favour, I beeech you appoint ome place which you hall thinke mot convenient, where I may receive that happinee, and you hall find that Alcidon never was more yours, then till he is; and that he has yet till preerved himelfe mot faithfully for you; and you will now find him more able to doe you ervice, then in his green yeares, when you did him the honour, to admit him your mot humble ervant:

Thee are the flatteries, wie Adamas, by which love ueth to abue youth: I had no ooner read his Letter, but though I did very well know the hand, yet I could not preently conent to the eeing of him: for mitruting the ayrie leightnee of men, epecially young
men, and mot particularly of Alcidon, whoe unettlednee was yet freh in my memory; I would not, at the firt entreat, hew my elfe o very pliable to his requet, but reolved to let him champ a little upon the bit, purpoely to harpen his deire; knowing very well, that love apires alwaies mot at that which he thinks is forbidden. And in this reolution, I took pen and paper, intending to write a didaining anwer, as his two years ilence deerved; but ome Daemon or other, I know not whether good or bad, prevented me, repreenting unto me the merits of Alcidon, that his youth might plead his excue; the divers trange accidents which happened in that time: o as altering my firt deign, I reolved to ee him, with an intention to make him pay deare for his fault, if I found him imbarqued to love me: In this humour, I writ unto him thee words.

div.head: Daphnides anwer unto Alcidon.
div.p: IT is not Love, but Curioity onely, which makes me give you leave to ee me: doe not therefore take this leave which I give you, as any advantage to you; but be a better husband of thoe favours you receive, then you have been of thoe which your infancy obtained from me:

The Army was then about Arles, and the Great Eurick having taken the City of the Mailians; intended to force this, to make himelfe Mater of all the Province of the Romans; and to Ruine and Ravage all uch as would not ubmit unto him. In this reolution, he re-inforced his Army, and wated all places where he had no hopes that his Armes could retaine: upon this account, the Venetians, the Regnois, the Tricatins, Araue, Valence, and many other places, felt the fury of his word, whilet he till continued the iege of this trong City, which as the chiefe of that Province, gave greatet reitance, as well by reaon of it naturall trength, as the great number of Souldiers within it.

As for my Father, when my Mother and I left the Court, after the death of Thorimond, he retired himelfe unto a trong place which he had in Aquitaine. My Mother, who was much affraid of War, thinking to hun it, came unto the Province of the Romans, and it was there where it proved mot hot; But when he heard that the Army of Great Eurick was coming, he retired unto the farthet part of the Venetians, along the River of Sorgues, where he had a good houe, and a iter married, not above four or five leagues from thence, unto a principal Cavalier of the Country.

When I received this Letter from Alcidon, the indipoition of my mother, gave me liberty to dipoe of my elfe freely; for her dieae being onely age, and no other violent dieae, unto which Phyick was remedy; he gave me the freedom of diverting my elfe, ometime in walking along the River ide, and ometimes in viiting my Neighbours, mot of whom were my kindred and allies. I ent therefore by word of mouth unto Alcidon, by him who brought the Letter, That if he hould be at Lers, which is a Catle cituated upon the Rone, the fourth day of the following moneth. I would ee him, and that I pitched upon this place, becaue I knew the Mater of it was his friend, and a ervant unto the King Eurick: but that he hould come as privately as he could, becaue if it was known he was there, he would run a great hazard, by being in an enemies Country, and I hould be talked of as the occaion.

Here Daphnide paued a while, and rubbed her hand upon her forehead, as if he were conidering what he hould ay: at lat turning towards Alcidon, I would willingly go on, (aid he unto him) but methinks it better, that as I have told what concernes me, o you hould tell what concernes you, to the end Adamas hearing us both peak, he may be more aured of the truth, Alcidon anwered, you may command me any thing, Madam, and I hall mot readily obey: but methinks you much wound the widome of this great Druid, by aying he will ooner believe my words, then yours; for certainly you know better what I did, then I my elfe; for my life hath been no better then a death, and I would not live a moment longer, then in obedience to you. Adamas then began to peak: Sir, aid he, Were I as much in love with this Lady as you are, this belief might well be in me; but ince I am not, what you doe ay of your elfe, does more aure me of the truth: and ince he gives you authority, you need not make any difficulty of it.
Authority? aid Daphnide: Nay more, I command him; and, if he be as good as his word, he will not diobey, unlee he love me more in word then deed. Alcidon then making an humble reverence; this tetimony, aid he, is but weake, to hew my deires of obeying you; yet becaue I mut obey in all, I will in this: Then he began thus,

I will not repeat what this fair Lady hath poken, nor will I offer to excue my elfe of what he doth blame me, at this time: for I believe it will come in more pertinently in ome other place, before this dicoure be ended, in which I hall hew her my reaons, and let her know the incerity of my affection; or ele I hope, that when I have ended this relation, he will give me leave to defend my elfe; not againt her, but onely againt thoe bad impreions which calumny hath imprinted in her, in prejudice of my innocence. And o taking the tory where he left it, I hall onely ay, that when her anwer was brought me, never did man think himelfe more happy, more contented, nor better atisfied with this Fortune than I. I read and kied the Letter a thouand times, and as often imbraced the welcome Meenger; and becaue he was a man in whom I had great confidence, and who had often given good tetimonies of his fidelity, therefore I imployed him in this buinee, which o neerly concerned me; and I asked him a thouand quetions, as whether he was as faire as when I lat aw her? whether he expreed any ignes of loving mee, and above all, whether he heard he loved any other? And when he anwered according to my minde, I did imbrace him with uch raptures of joy, as he wore he would tell me no more, ince I was ready to choake him with hugging him in my armes.

When Thierry dyed, he left his Crowne, as the faire Daphnide told you, unto his brother Euricke, a Prince, who by his great and vertuous actions, did with general applaue get the title of Great. This Prince did not onely ucceed his brothers in the Crowne, but alo in their Deignes, o as he hewed the ame favours unto me, that Thorimond did, an event which happens very rarely in the change of Princes; the Succeor eldome affects thoe whom the Predeceor loved; yet more by my good fortune than merit, I had this honour, o as I was raied by Thorimond and maintained by Thierry, I was alo favoured by the great Euricke, not now as a child, but a man able to doe him ervice, as I was obliged. The favour of this Prince had brought me into uch familiarity with him, as he concealed but few things from me, and his love le • then any thing ele. And this Prince, though in all things great, yet he excelled all in his age in courteie and love. I neither could, nor ought at this preent, be abent from his Army, without his leave, and therefore I tooke a time when he was alone in his Cloet, where after a mile? Sir, aid I unto him, I have a deigne in my thoughts, and I beeech you give me leave to put it in execution. Alcidon, anwered he, your courage hath often prompted you unto things mot dangerous, and I wih you would have more care of your elfe, then hitherto you have had: for Fortune is full of incontancy; though he mile at one time, he will frowne at another, and no prudent man will tempt or trut her too farre; yet tell me what your enterprie is? And having more experience then you, I hall know whether it be eaable or no. Sir, replyed I, and miled, were it a buinee that depended upon Mars, I hould expect from you very good intructions; but needing no other guide but Love, who is blind, and a Boy, I thinke that I hall not need either your prudence or experience. The King then imbraced me and aid; Alvidon, my advice in that alo will not be unprofitable: for you know that I am a Souldier as well under the banner of Love, as of Mars; o taking me by the hand, he would not let me ret, until he got out of me, the name of Daphnide, and the place where I was to goe unto her: He had heard often of her name, but had never een her, yet by reports knew that he was very faire: Upon this, he was o farre from obtructing my deigne, that he did not only offer me all manner of aitance, but to accompany me himelfe; and when he aw I would not give conent unto that, he advied me to goe with very few perons, but upon good Hores, and with men who feared no dangers. That above all, I hould not tay in any Towne or Houe, but onely to get Victuall, and then to eat it, and lye in ome Wood. If this Lady, aid he, have promied you any good will loe not the opportunity; for there is a criticall houre in which women will grant any thing one will aske, if one can but hit upon it; and on the contrary, if one let that houre lip, without erving her, he will never, or very rarely be recovered: after thee advices of Love, and many others, which would be too tedious to reheare, he gave me leave to depart.

The Catle of Lers which Daphnide made choice of to be the place of our meeting was ituated upon the bankes of the great River Rone; and truly, the Lady had made this choice with much judgement, becaue the Mater of it was a Servant and an Officer unto King Euricke, who had erved him in his Army in matters which concerned Engines of War, having the command of Cathapaltes, Rumes, Slinges, and uch like Intruments of Artillery, and moreover he was my very particular friend. The wife of this Cavalier was in ome ort a kin unto Daphnide, o as it was almot impoible to make choice of a fitter place, having only this inconvenience, that from our Army one mut pae ten or twelve long leagues, all through the enemies Country; and though the danger was great, yet it was nothing when Love commanded, who cloed my eyes againt all dangers, rather than diobey.

I tooke with me, him who brought me the anwer from this faire Lady, as well for the confidence I had in him, as for a guide, becaue he was very well acquainted with all the wayes of that Country: And in obedience to the Kings command, I tooke onely two other Cavaliers with me. Thus we foure taking hore, we et forward an houre after dinner, unknowne to any, for we tooke other habits, and began our journey under the favour of Love, which was uch, as after we had travelled all that day, and all the night following, we arrived at Lers about Sun riing, where the Mitree of the houe received me o kindly, that I thought at firt, he was advertied of the deigne which brought me thither: but preently after, I perceived he knew nothing, and that all her courteie proceeded only from the friendhip which he knew was betwixt her husband and me, and he was extreamly inquiitive to dicover the caue of my voyage; And therefore to colour it the better, I told her I came upon buinee of great importance, which concerned the Kings ervice, and came by night for feare of being dicovered I beeeched her to conceale my name, and to keep the gates of the Catle cloe hut, and that when night came I would depart, if poibly I could: Shee being dicreet and very affectionate to the Kings ervice, with whom her husband was, he ordered it o as very few in her houe knew that I was Alcidon, and the more eaily becaue at my firt entrance, I changed my Name.

Halfe of the day was pent, and I heard no newes of the faire Daphnide, or at leat if it was not, it eemed o unto me: After much impatient expectance, I went up into a high Tower, eeming as if I deired to view the Country, though it was only in hopes to ee her coming. There was not a Houe, nor a Wood, nor a Hill, of which I did not aske the name, the better to cover my impaciency: but nothing could divert me, though the Lady of the houe did all that poibly he could to make the time eeme lee tedious unto mee.

At lat, after many a long look, and when I began to be cut of all hope, I aw a Coach coming that way which I knew he was to come, and hewing it unto the Lady, he looked a while upon it: At lat, it being come a little neerer, he turned towards me. If I be not much mitaken, aid he unto me, the Coch comes hither, and if it be, as I think it is, you hall ee one of the greatet beauties in all this Country: Who is it? (aid I unto her very coldly) I know not, aid he; whether you have een her in the Court of King Thorimond with her Mother; but if you have, I am confident you know her name: For, though he be my Coen, yet I mut needs, and truly ay, that he is very faire, though he was then but a child: It is, aid he, the young Daphnide. At the firt I eemed to have but a little memory of her; but preently after, as if I had better recollected my elfe: Yes, yes, aid I, I doe very well remember her, he had then a Father and a Mother, with whom he dwelt; for he was none of the Queenes women: She was not, anwered he, and perhaps the reaon of it was unknowne unto you, becaue you were then very young; but indeed it was becaue the Queene was jealous that Thorimond did looke upon her with an over-kind eye, and yet I aure you, he was then but a very childe, as you will judge when you ee her, for he eemes to be very young yet. How? Madam, aid I unto her, I ee her? I beeech you, No; let I hould be dicovered, uand my deigne poyled. For if it hould, beides my owne ruine, the Kings ervice would be poyled. She anwered, that I needed not to feare it: for Daphnide would at her requet be very ecret, and her Father was a faithfull devoted Servant of the Kings: I, whoe deire was to ee her, yet eemed to be perwaded unto it by her. I am, aid I to her o much devoted unto the ervice of Ladies, as I cannot beleeve any of them will doe me harme. Upon this, wee aw the Coach take into the way
which conducted to the houe, which aured us, that it was he: And the Mitree of the houe, very glad of uch guets, taking me by the hand, aid unto me: Will it pleae you, wee hould goe and receive them? I will put my elfe into their hands, aid I unto her, and miled: perhaps I hall be afer that way, than by reitance, for ubmiion workes mot with generous oules.

Whilt we were thus talking, the Ladies were come into the bae Court of the Catle, where the Lady of the houe went to receive them, and told them in their eare, what Guet he had in her houe, and how he thought fit they hould know it as well as her elfe. The faire Daphnide had with her two Siters, both very fair, but both hort of her: As for me, I was retired into a low Parlour, where I eemed unwilling to come out, for feare of being knowne and it was well I did o; for had I not beene alone at their firt coming, my actions would have dicovered my paion: For when I aw them firt come out of the Coach, he who came out firt was o faire, as I tooke her for Daphnide, and eeing the econd fairer then he I recanted my firt thought, aying to my elfe, this was he; but I reted not long in this error, for preently after I aw this faire one come forth, who did o ravih me, that I knew not what I did; but their complements and alutations, gave me time to recollect my elfe a litle: o as when they came into the houe, I became o confident, that when I aluted them, I was able to hid my tranport: afterwards, addreing my elfe unto her, who had the ole dominion of my oule, I aid unto her; Madam, ince fortune will have it o, I mut confee my elf your Prioner: ir, aid he unto me in a loud voice, we will not refue the advantange which we have over you; but we rather wih our merits had gotten it, then our fortune. Your merits, replyed I, may pretend unto far greater; and fortune gave you this as being much too little for your merits. You have given me the ame aurances heretofore (aid he in a lower tone) but in a language which poke more incerity, then that which you now ue. At that time, anwered I, I might peak as a childe, but now I have more knowledge of my elfe, I am ure I peak with more truth; yet if you will have it o, let be attributed unto fortune: but I pray, aid he, and miled, how doe you think to pay the ranome for getting out of our hands? for you mut never hope for liberty but by that meanes. My ranome, replyed I, be it never o great, will not be halfe o hard to be found, as to get my heart conent, that I hall come out of your hands. I perceive (replied he, and miled) you remember yet what leons King Thorimond taught you, and can talk to Ladies as you were then wont. So I ought to doe with you, anwered I, ince you have the ame eyes, and ame beauties, wherewith you were wont to conquer all thoe that durt look upon you: I thought, anwered he, that men of arms and blood, uch as follow the King Eurick, had onely talked of killing and murdering; but I perceive Alcidon, whereoever he is, is till the ame Alcidon; that is, all courteie and civility; upon this he went into the great Chamber with all the company.

The firt Complements being paed, our kind Land-lady cauing eats to be brought, he placed me more out of civility, then deign next unto Daphnide, at a little ditance from the ret of the company; o as eeing my elfe in a place where I might peak more freely, my affection and my duty, both invited me to give her thanks for the favour of this meeting: but when I began, he interrupted me with an angry look, and laying her hand upon my mouth, he aid unto me; You mut not think Alcidon, that you are any thing obliged unto me for this viit, becaue I would never have conented unto it, but onely out of a deign to punih you, knowing that ince you did love me, when I was a meer childe, you will now be ready to die for the love of me, eeing me more improved. This is the true caue which moved me unto this meeting, I meane to chatie you, and not to gratifie you; for having rendred your elfe o unworthy of thoe favours which I conferred upon, I will try whether chatiements will make you better know your duty both unto me and your elfe. Can you think, forgetful lover, that after o many expreions of favour and love, that my beauty deerves to be forgotten; and that in two long years, no park of any memory hould appeare? Doe you thinke perfidious man, that o long a ilence can be excued by the mieries of the time? Wars, and all impediments whatoever, cannot perwade me but that it is ome defect in affection, and not any reall excue. I know that if I would permit it, you will flow with excues; but I forbid you to peak; not that I feare your language can perwade me, but becaue I am reolved not to believe you; and becaue I will not let you have o much content, as to peak any thing
before me which hall pleae you: By this you may know, that this meeting for which you think your elfe obliged unto me, reembles weet poyon, which by weetnee gives death. I offered to anwer, but I no ooner opened my mouth, but he checked me, aying; what Alcidon, doe you care as little for diobliging me in my preence, as in my abence? No, no, Alcidon, that is not the way to win upon Daphnide What then, aid I unto her, is it your pleaure I hould do? To uffer, aid he, and be ilent. For it is fit you hould expiate your inne of ilence, by ilence Upon this, I was mute; yet hewing by my lookes that my heart was troubled, that I might not peak in my own defence. She on the contrary, looking with a little more favourable eye, after a while of ilence, began thus:

This Daphnide whom you ee before your face, forgetful Alcidon, is the very ame hee was, when you firt made o many oathes of fidelity unto her; the very ame who believed you; the very ame whoe hands you o oft wahed in your then innocent teares. But to your hame, he is able to ay, that he has kept her faith without the leat tain, though he hath ince had o many occaions to hate you he has till continued her love to you, and entertaines in her oul thoe aurances which you gave unto her: and though he has had many inducements to cat you quite off, yet her heart would never conent unto it, being reolved rather to part from her life, then thoe pledges which you gave her of your fidelity. Thee eyes which have been o often idolized by the young Alcidon, have been witnees of many a teare hed for your long abence, when I remembred your young promies, which now I find to be o fale: for you never had the leat parke of memory, or thought of her, unto whom you promied eternal memory. Oh Alcidon; you hall heare how I have lived ince the death of the great King, unto whom both you and I were o much, obliged; and you will confee, if you be not the mot unjut man that ever breathed, that your ilence hath made you unworthy of love, but that my affection is till greater then your offence:

Then he began to repeat all paages, ince the beginning of our eparation unto this meeting, not omitting any circumtance that argued my oblivion, wherewith he accued me: and on the other ide, to tetifie the memory he had of me, he related all the remarkable actions that I had done: and after a long repetition of them, at which I was amazed, that he hould know o many particulars: I perceive, aid he, that you are amazed I hould relate your own life unto you; but had you beene as you ought, I hould have come to the knowledge of them from your elfe, and not from others, which argues a defect in your affection, and your ilence is a igne of your hameful forgetfulnee.

She had continued thus upbraiding me, and in relating both her own life and mine, very near two hours, and would not uffer me to open my mouth in my own defence, nor to anwer her. At lat, this offended beauty finding ome proofe of the power which he had over me, he began to change her countenance and language. Now Alcidon, aid he, I permit you to peak, being contented with two hours ilence in my preence, in exchange of two yeares voluntary ilence in my abence. It argues your abundant goodnee, aid I unto her, and miled, that you will thus change years into hours. Your crime is uch, replyed he, that no punihment can equall it: but I will hew my elfe as merciful, as I am able to punih you if I will.

Madam, aid I unto her, I hould kie your faire hands, by way of thankes for uch extraordinary favours, were I not afraid I hould be perceived, but I lay my heart at your feet, in tetimony of my gratitude; I doe mot ingenuouly confee, Madam, the fault wherewith you charge me. But if your goodnee would be pleaed to let me tell you the occaion and reaon why I was o long ilent, perhaps you would thinke me as worthy of commendations, as of blame.
