Since I have pardoned you, (aid he) and given you leave to peake, you may ay what you pleae; and I wih you may hew uch reaons as may perwade me, that you are in no fault. Let me ay then, (continued I) that you may well conceive, I grieved extreamly at the death of a Mater, who loved me o exceedingly, and raied me by his favours above the reach of all Court Envy. Now I hould have extreamly offended againt his memory and the offence would have been thought high ingratitude, if I hould have entertained the leat kind of contentment in my oule: Times of mourning injoynes us unto ad habits, and forbids any thing of joy or content. Now the poor and diconolate Alcidon, was forbidden all manner of happinee, and deprived
himelfe of all that came from you Madam, who was and is his only joy and felicity. To atisfie then, both my duty and my affection, I made choice of o bidding my elfe the honour of hearing from you, to the end nothing hould divert me from my adnee, which was then eaonable. But Loves knowes, and that mierable heart which loves and adores you, knowes, that in the midt of my bitter orrowes, none grieved me o much as that I was ditanced from your preence and memory. Two things principally may argue the truth of this unto you. Firt, if I had not truly loved you, my age would not have permitted me to live o long amongt o many faire Ladies without love. Secondly, as oone as I had in ome ort forgotten my orrowes for my great loe, my continuall thoughts of you, would never let me be in quietnee untill I had the honour of eeing you: The danger of the journey, nor the ditance from the great Euricke, whoe favours hine upon me as fat as thoe did from Thorimond, could not hinder me. Now Madam, I protrate my elfe at your feet, reigning unto you all my affections, all my thoughts, my heart and oule, beeeching you to receive them, not as any new offering or freh acquiition, but as yours from my infancy; my Detiny, my Mater and my heart, did give me unto you. I hall receive your excue aid he unto me, as they ue to receive a debt from a bad pay-mater, though the money be a little too light: and I will beleeve what you ay, upon condition that none of your future actions give me any caue of doubt.

When I would have anwered, I was hindred by the Lady of the houe, who came to tell us it was Supper time; therefore we referred the ret of our dicoure till after it was done. And it was no ooner ended, but I out of civility falling into dicoure with one of her Siters, he came unto us, and having eparated me a little from the ret, we fell into talke where we left, with o much contentment unto me, that I mut needs confee my joyes were never greater. Thus we pent part of the night; at lat, bed time forcing us to part, we advied upon a more afe place of meeting; and being contrained to depart in the morning, it was now long before we could reolve upon the place: At the lat, he aid unto me, but in a very doubtfull manner: I am loath, Alcidon, to put you into any danger, but ince you are o urgent upon it, I will tell you, that I have a Siter married within five or ix Leagues of this place, where we might very well meet, were it not that my brother in law is an Enemy unto King Euricke, yet were there no other difficulty but that, we might find a remedy; but as ill lucke is, he hath invited a great Company to the marriage of one of his Siters, o as all things eeme contrary unto us: I do not think there is one of any quality in all the Province, which is not an enemy unto the King your Mater. I mut confee Father, I found much danger this way, but when I conidered that there was no other way to enjoy the company of my Mitree, danger was the leat of my thoughts, and therefore I anwered her: That no hazard hould make me loe the happinee, o he would but command it; onely beeeched her to take uch order, that when I was in the houe, none hould ee me; for I was confident that under her command I hould receive no harme.

In this reolution we parted, and the next morning leaving one of her Servants with me, who was very truty; he departed, and I had not the honour to ee her purpoely to take away all upition from the Lady of the houe. As for me, I departed with my guide, ome three hours within night: after many thankes unto my Hotee for her kind uage, I hall not here relate the various encounters I had by the way: The place unto which I was conducted was one of the mot olitary eats in all the Country, and the fittet for any interpries of love.

Upon the bankes of that great River of Rone, do tand many faire Townes, which take delight in her waves; one of the bet and mot peopled is Avignion, ome five or ix Leagues from whence towards the eat is a Valley, which being incloed on three ides by high Hils and great Rockes, was at the firt called Vale cloe, and afterwards by corruption of language, of which the vulgar is alwayes Mater, it was called Vauclue; at the end of this Valley, under huge Rockes, and by a wonderfull Fountaine which gives a beginning to the River of Sorgues, which a little below parts it elfe into two Arms, like a little Iland, where this houe unto which I was to goe did tand, and which tanding betweene two Rivers, has the name of an Iland. The place from whence this Fountain prings, is truly for its olitude, in ome ort venerable; but omething terrible by reaon of the Rockes which inviron it, and therefore very little frequented
by people. It was here where my guide brought me to alight from my hore, and to leave thoe who came with me, which by my command, though with orrow, they did. From this ource unto the Ile is about a quarter of a League, which I was to walke on foot, and in the night, which I did in uch doubts and incertainties, that love made it appeare in me, how not onely himelfe is blind, but he takes ight alo from all thoe who are his ubjects. At the lat, about the eighth or ninth hour of the night, we came unto the Garden doore which belonged unto the houe, which though it was promied me hould be left open, yet it was hut; judge Adamas, what I thought of the matter then, and whether I had not reaon to expect Mars in lieu of Venus. But after a long doubtfull expectance, I heard the doore open, and the firt thing that preented it elfe unto my eyes, was a fair Lady, decked as Painters ue to doe the Goddee Diana. her haire looe, her bret and houlders naked, her leeves turned up as high as the elboe; gilded buskins upon her legs; her, Quiver by her ide and a Bow of Ivory in her left hand. I was ravihed at o fair a ight, and admired her habit; but I undertood ince that he was o diguied like Diana, for Name ake becaue he was called Delia, which is one of Dianas names, purpoely to daunce that night with her Siters, and other young Ladies there, in honour of the great Aembly. As oone as ever he aw me come in, aid he unto me, and tooke my hand; Come in and attempt this dangerous adventure under the conduct of Diana, Under the banner of uch a Goddee, anwered I, there is nothing which I will not attempt. Some interpries, aid he, do eeme eaie at the firt, which afterwards are ound full of difficulty, and take heed let this be of that quality: If this were not of great importance, replyed I, I would never have come o farre to attempt it. I am very glad, aid he, to finde you in that reolution; and know that both Love and Fortune will ait a couragious oule; and to hew how deirous I am you hould bring your enterprie to pae, I will give you afe conduct from all that are in this enchanted houe, unlee from the eyes of your Mitree, and from this Diana who peakes unto you. I doe accept of this aurance, aid I unto her: Well, (aid he) before you have done with this adventure, we hall ee what your Fortune will be, and what your courage: In the meane time, valiant Cavalier, enter, but till enter upon uch conditions as thoe who enter, ue. I beeech you, aid I unto her, what are thoe conditions? You hall know, anwered he, when you are entred. Why, aid I, are you afraid to tell them, leat they hould affright me? If o, faire Diana, you are mitaken: For I will undertake any conditions, o they doe not contrary that affection which I have vowed unto my Mitree. Upon this, I entred in alone, he lockt the doore, and my Guide returned through the Rockes of Vauclue. Now was I alone with Delia in the Garden; and I mut confee, that he was o advantaged by this odde fantaticall dree, as he might very well be termed faire, and one that was not prepoeed might well have found a heart to love her: She eeing me tand o mute, looking upon her, and thinking it was my impatience becaue he carried me no ooner unto the faire Daphnide, he miled, and aid unto me. What Sir, were you bold at your entrance, and now how o little courage to accomplih your adventure? What fault faire Diana, aid I unto her, doe you finde in my courage, what mut I doe? and againt whom mut I hew my valour? How, aid he, and et her Arms upon her ides, have you not before your eyes an enemy fierce enough to make you put your hand to your Armes? I mut confee faire Goddee, aid I, that you are a very dangerous Enemy unto one that has a heart, but certainly againt me your Arms have no edge, ince the faire Daphnide has long ince deprived me of my heart. How, aid he, is there no hopes of gaining any thing from you? You may hope, replyed I, to gaine any thing that I have, you meane, aid he, any thing but your heart. Well, well Alcidon, you are not yet in a good faith; but before you ecape my hands, I will make you ue other language: I have met with ome, who at the firt have aid as you doe, and yet before all was done did ubmit themelves as conquered: uch as thoe, anwered I, either did but lend their, heart, or if they did give it, did teale it back againe to give it unto you, but I cannot doe o, who have not only given away my heart, but my will, my oule, and my life alo. Had you any courage, as you tax me for having none, you would not imploy your valour and your trength againt one that is without defence, as I am: What honour will it be to vanquih one that is already vanquihed? one that has no heart; this were to trike one that is dying by the wounds of another. Come, come
my heartlee enemy, aid he unto me, I know you would have me carry you preently unto Daphnide; but doe not thinke Alcidon, that our emnity is o great, but I woud have done it before now, if it had been time; doe you ee yonder window which tand out further then the ret? there is Daphnides Chamber; when it is time for you to goe there will be a Candle et in it to advertie us but aure your elfe, that as you think the time long here, your Mitres thinks it longer where he is, having abundance of troubleome perons, who warme about her like o many flies, epecially her brother in law, who thinking to doe her a pleaure, never tirs from her: Come, come, you that are a very finely accomplihed Cavalier, methinks you hould not be weary of my company, many have told me that I am pretty hanome, and I am in an humour to treat you o, that what you will not doe by faire meanes, I will make you doe by force: I meane, I will in pite of you, keep you from being weary. I mut confee once again (aid I unto her) that it is impoible for any one that has a heart, not to love you. For, faire Delia, there are o many admirable perfections in you, as look which way one will, one hall be ure to find abundance of invitements to love.

You think till (aid he unto me) to ecape my hands with this excue, but before we part, I will make you find another and therefore what will you ay next Alcidon? I will ay, replyed I, that you can do miracles, which need not be thought trange; for your beauty equalling the power of the great Gods, you may doe them as well as they: but will you give me leave to peak freely? with all my heart, anwered he, for you ee I do the like: Then fair Diana, aid I, let me tell you, the Moon is the mot glorious lamp that now hines in the heaven (the moon then hining) and if there was no Sun, none could deny, but that it would be alwaies o: I confee it, aid Delia, what doe you infer by that? I infer, replyed I, That the fair Diana unto whom now I peak, would be the fairet in the world, had he not a iter, and there is none but he which hinders her from the title of the fairet. Could I as eaily believe that, aid he, as I am ambitious of that title whereof you peak, I vow Cavalier by thee Arrowes and Bow, that if I could not kill her with my own hands, I would poyon that iter who eclipeth my beauty; but I am afraid, that if he were taken away, it would happen unto me, as unto the Moon, in abence of her brother the Sun, become obcure and pale. I hould have anwered, when the o much deired light appeared in the window, and my affection carrying my eyes almot alwaies that way, would not let me loe o much time as to anwer her when I aw it. Shewing it therefore unto Delia, I beeeched her to accomplih the favour which he had begun. I will, aid he unto me, and took my hand you know it is the office of the Moon, whoe Name I bear, to clear the Night, and to be a guide unto thoe who wander. My life, aid I unto her, is obliged unto your ervice, though I am afraid that obligation is little worth, ince you are carrying me unto one whoe beauty kills all thoe that looke upon her: and being accutomed to ee men languih and die, it is not likely he will have any compaion of my paine. Thoe, aid he, whom I take unto my protection, are never ill treated; for if they were, I hould not have opened the doore unto you: and beleeve it, I never carry any to their punihment: And whereas you feare that her beauty will kill you, never feare that fortune good Cavalier, your Arms are very good, and tryed: for uch as will die at ight of beauty, will die at the ight of me; o as you having pat that danger, never fear any beauty living will kill you.

Thus we went talking in a low voice, until we came to the houe, which was the happy habitation of my Mitree; and finding a door open, we went up a paire of narrow taires, unto the Chamber door, with as little noie as poibly we could: Then Delia caued me to tay, and went in alone to ee who was there, but he found onely the faire Daphnide by her elfe, who faigning to be troubled with the head-ake, was laid downs upon her bed, purpoely to be rid of the company; and pretending that the light was offenive to her, he caued the Candle to be et in the window; Delia came preently unto me, and taking my hand, carried me to her iters bed ide, and aid unto her; ee Daphnide, what Diana has taken in her lat chae: I mut confee, aid I unto her, and miled, that I am yours, if a heart could be divided into two: but ince mine is in the dipoition of my fairet Mitres onely, I am come to render it unto her, vowing never to take it out of o weet a prion. In this, aid Delia, you hew the weaknee of your judgement, ince you had rather give your elfe unto a Nimph as Daphnide is, than unto a Goddee as I am, nay Diana, who is the Mitres of all the Nymphs, Jupiter, Apollo,
and almot all the Gods, aid I unto her, have lighted Goddees, and courted Nymphs. But never was any o faire as this, into whoe hands I do ubmit my oul & my life: upon this, kneeling down, I took her hand and kied it often, whilt he was o tranported that he gave no anwer; which Delia perceiving, iter, aid he, will you let this Cavalier adore you indeed and kneel till his knees ake, before you give him any anwer? Then rowing her elfe as out of a deep lumber, he aluted me, and afterwards anwered her iter. I hope Delia, this Cavalier will pardon the fault, and not thinke it proceeded from any incivility, but from my feares of that danger which he is in for my caue. I admire, (aid Delia) that you being my iter, hould be uch a coward, whereas I am o tout as to take prioner the bravet Cavalier in all the Army of the great Eurick; how can you want courage, having (as he ayes) the heart of the valiant Alcidon? Ah Delia, anwered I, and ighed, it is a bad igne for me, to ee my Mitres o aint, for it hewes he has not my heart; for if he had, he would rather pitty my miery which he has caued, then feare any dangers wherein I am. Could I Alcidon, anwered my faire Mitres, remedy the one, as well as I can the other, you had reaon to thinke o: but conider, that if I did not love this Cavalier, who complaines thus of me, I hould neither be in thee feares wherein I am, nor he in the danger wherein he is. I anwered her, If you peak from your heart, Madam, then cure me of the malady which proceeds from your elfe; and never doubt that I can receive any harme, as long as I am in the honour of your favour: Delia then miled, and aid; I perceive that when you have been together a little, the pain of the one will be changed into contentment, and the feares into confidence. But let fortune hould hinder your deignes, peak as low as you can, and I will go and it by the Candle, eeming to read, that I may put it out, if any chance to come; or ele I will fall in talk with them; and tell them how you doe, without bidding enter. But Cavalier, aid he, and addreed her elfe unto me, Remember the promie which you made when I opened the door unto you, and admitted you unto this adventure, which was, to performe the conditions then propoed, and if you be worthy of the name of a Cavalier, you will keep your word. You have kept your promie o well with me, anwered I, that I were a mot unworthy recreant, if I did not the ame with you. Then, aid he unto me, you are obliged according to the conditions etablihed, not to attempt any thing, upon any occaion, nor for any repect or reward whatoever, againt the honour of the Ladies who are here; but on the contrary, you ought to be contented with thoe favours which they confer upon you, not eeking or deiring any greater. I will ooner heathe my word in my heart, anwered I, then entertain a thought againt this ordinance Every Cavalier of honour, is obliged unto it by his very Name: for that repect is due, as unto one of the principal tatutes of love. I ever thought, anwered Delia, of Alcidons dicretion; and I doe exceedingly rejoyce, you doe thus econd my thoughts, ince the law had not been etablihed but for you. How? aid I, not etablihed but for me? was it made onely to retrain my indicretion? Is it thought that I am more impudent than any of the Knight errantry? That is not the reaon, aid he unto me; but is it not reaon this contraint hould be etablihed for you onely in this adventure, which you terme the adventure of perfect love, ince you onely are permitted to attempt it? But ince, before you have done, you are to deal with a fiercer Champion then I am, I will leave you together with your enemy, let you hould complain of diadvantage.

Upon this, not taying for my anwer, he went away, and at down with a book in her hand, and left my fairet mitree and me together, as he aid he would. At which I being tranported with abundance of contentment, after I was et down upon the bed by her, I tooke her hand, and kiing it many times, I aid unto her: Madam I am mot enible of my extreame obligations, and my life is too little a price to be paid for uch a happinee. Did you kno • what paines I have taken, aid he, to give you this tetimony of my good will, doubtlee you would et a good value of eteem upon it. For though my iter does now hew her elfe o tout in the matter; yet believe me, Alcidon, he is not alwaies o, and it was not weak perwaions which could make her conent unto it. Oh what artifice and tricks have I ued to deceive, not onely my brother in law, but all his kindred and friends, or indeed all the whole Province. Conider, Alcidon, what a trange reolution I had in putting my honour and your life into o great a danger: For to permit your coming into this place is no lee. Madam, aid I, and kied her hand, if you conider my extream affection unto you, Love, and You were unjut, if you did not anwer
it by extraordinary proofes of your good acceptance, and I doe confee, that this is above my merit, though it doe not equall my affection. For it is uch, that mot certaine death cannot make me tart from your ervice. Alcidon, anwered he, if your affection be uch as you ay, I wih it may continue as long as I live. But I doe much feare the love of a young heart. Madam, aid I unto her, doubts ue to enter into the oules of thoe who are not well grounded in their Faith; and thee in you give me more caue to fear weaknee of affection on your ide; for the principal effect of true love is, to remove out of the Lover all manner of mitrut of the peron loved, and it is impoible to love one whom they mitrut.

By this, replyed he, you may know the grandure of my affection, ince having o many occaions to doubt you, yet is it till tronger then all thoe doubtfull occaions, and makes me till give you uch tetimonies of my good will. Yet Madam, aid I unto her, give me leave to ay in mine owne defence, that you doe wrong my love, in taxing it with youngnee, for I am twice ten years of age. Ah Alcidon, aid he, before any good aurance can be, you had need be twice twelve. At this I laughed and aid: that Madam were indeed requiite in thoe who love common beauties; but for you and I, time is not o much to be inited upon; for our ties and obligations are as trong now, as they will be foure yeares hence. She would have replyed, when Delia began to cough, as an advertiement, that he heard ome coming: preently after, her brother in law came to the doore, unto whom he made a igne with her finger, and went as oftly to him as he could, as if he were afraid to wake her iter; her brother in law asked her how Daphnide did. She complained a long while, aid he unto him, and now he is fallen aleep. What, aid he, will you not come downe and dance? to what end did you ele dree your elfe in that habit? I hope brother, anwered he, that my iter will be well after he has lept a while, and if he be, I will come and finih our deigne with the ret but if he continue ill, we mut deferre it until another time, and if you will come up againe about halfe an hour hence, I hall tell you more: upon this her brother in law went away, and he came unto us to tell us what he had aid, and when I deired her to defer it until to morrow; he anwered me, I perceive Alcidon that you are all for your elfe, and care not for the interets of another, o you can enjoy your opportunities as long as you tay, you care not what becomes of us when you are gone. You doe not well, aid Daphnide to make this contruction of what this Cavalier aid; for I am mot confident he has more care of us then o; but if he love us, as I beleeve he does, he will not take it ill, if we leave him a little without company; I conceive it therefore bet, that when my brother in law comes againe, you tell him that I am better then I was, and that if he will come, and dance here, I hall be very glad of it, o he bring with him as few company, and as little Muique as he can; in the mean time, we will put Alcidon into this Cloet which is cloe by my bed.

This Counell was approved of as good, and to hew me this Cloet he tooke the Key, and not tirring from off her bed, he opened the doore, and cauing a Candle to be brought, hewed it unto me, where I found roome onely for two Chaires and a Table. The place was fretted and gilded, and very handomely furnihed; in this place, aid he unto me, you may be with afety, and if you will leave the doore a little open, you may ee us dance: though you mut not expect to find the magnificence of the great Eurick, yet I am confident this Ball will not be dipleaing unto you, by reaon of the various habits and new inventions. To which I anwered, that nothing would be dipleaing unto me, that pleaed her.

Whilt we were thus talking, the Brother in law returned, and o oftly leat he hould wake Daphnide, that he had almot urpried us: But Delia, who firt heard him, did put out the candle, leat he hould ee, and peaking a little louder, Brother, aid he, have but a little patience, and my iter will dance with us, he is awake, and o well as he will come and ee us, will you not, Siter, aid he, and addreed her elfe to my Mitree. Yes Siter, anwered he, but Brother I beeech you, come hither to dance, and bring as few people, and little Muicke as you can; for I am afraid leat the noie hould caue my head to ake againe. The brother was very glad of this newes, and went in all hate to tell the company: in the meane time I had le • ure to take up my little habitation, and he to draw the Curtaines, and order all things o as none could ee me and yet I could ee almot all that was done in the Chamber.

We had no ooner put all things into order, but a great number of Cavaliers came into
to the Chamber, with many faire Ladies, and amongt the ret Stiliana and Carlis, who have accompanied my Mitree hither. After ome paages of civility (for it mut be confeed that the Cavaliers of the Roman Province are the mot courteous of all Gaule) every one began to talke as the humour tooke them: At lat they fell into talke of the King Euricke, and his Wars; which they being all exceedingly enible of, there was not one in all the company, who had not ome paionate invective againt that great King. The bet language any had for him, was to call him Barbarous, Cruell, the Ruiner of Gaule, and all Europe; and then fell to wihes: One wihed that he were his Prioner; another to ee him dead; a third, that all his Armie were routed; and the bet wih was, that he had never beene. All this dicoure I heard, and judge what would have beene my entertainment had they found me. I beleeve they had not o oon left talking of this great King, and their paions had not been o oon layed, had they not heard the Muicke, which let them know that Delia and her Companions were ready to dance. Then every one tooke their places, and preently after, thoe faire ones entred in uch an admirable trim, and with uch a delicate new Aire, as I mut needs confee I never aw any thing more full of taking delight. I cannot now init upon any particulars, more than concernes the tory in hand onely let me tell you that though all was well performed, and full of various delights, yet I could not chue but thinke the time long, and wihed for an end of this Maske, becaue I thought it tole that time from me, which might be better imployed, At lat, the Ball ended, and the God of leepe commanded all the company to retire. Delia onely tayed in the Chamber with her Siter; and then the Prioner of Love came out of his Prion, chiding Delia for being o long in her dances. Oh what bad company is this Cavaliere (aid he) I am confident not one in the Company is weary but yourelfe. But iter, ince he is o dumpih. I advice you to packe him hence, for how can you hope to content him alone, ince all this company had much adoe to afford it him? Siter, aid Daphnide faintly, all things upon earth cannot afford us contentment, if it doe not come of our elves: As all the drugs in the Univere, cannot cure a body, if that body by its owne dipoition be not apt and conducing to it: And o Alcidon, if he will have contentment, mut content himelfe and not thinke that a great number of people can doe it. Madam, anwered I, If I had my will in my owne power, as others have, I hould doe as you doe ay; but ince I have put my will into your hands, my contentment mut depend only upon you: Siter, aid Delia, and miled, doe not repent of the time you have kept this Cavaliere caged up by your bed ide, for methinkes he hath learned to peake very well.

After ome other dicoure, they concluded to put me into the Cloet againe; untill they were undret, and their maids in the Chamber were gone; but when they opened the doore unto me, I found Delia in bed with her iter, and he taking notice that I was not well pleaed at it: What Cavaliere, aid he unto me, why doe you frowne upon me? It is your elfe that is the caue of my being here. I doe perceive, anwered I, that I am the caue, and I cannot be orry for it, ince my fairet Mitree will have it o. The truth is, I hould have been very glad, if I could have poke unto her without a witnee: Doe you not know, aid he, that there hould be Witnees unto all good Contracts. Love, replyed I, never needs any witnees, and love will erve us for witnee, if you need any: Love, aid he, cannot be a Witnee, for he is Judge. If Love, replyed I, cannot be a Witnee in matters of Love; much lee Diana, who is alwayes a declared enemy. Though I cannot be a witnee, aid he, yet I may be the Executioner of the punihment. If you deign that, anwered I, have I not a good occaion to deire you not here? Daphnide, who had not poken all this while, interrupted us, and addreing her elfe unto me; It was I Alcidon, aid he, that appointed her to be there, and my reaon for it, is o much to your advantage, as when you know it, you will not be angry; for it is not to witnee againt you, nor accue you: I am fully aured of Alcidons dieretion, and of the power which he hath given me over him: but being more in doubt of my elfe, then of you, I deired her preence to keep me from doing more than I was reolved, and let my good will to you, hould make me goe beyond the limits of duty and fittingnee. I mut confee Madam, aid I unto her, that thee feares in you, are a great honour unto me, but the remedy which you apply is very cruell and vexatio • s. Alcidon, anwered he, you mut love me, as I love you, and know that he who deerves your love, ought not only to be without blame, but alo without upition of any blame.

We talked o long, and with o much delight upon this ubject, as I took no notice how day began to break: and then, the conultation was, whether I hould depart or tay. The faire Daphnide, who was till apprehenive of my being in any danger, he was at the firt, of an opinion with Delia, that I hould be gone before it was any lighter: but when I hinted unto her that perhaps, it would be long before uch another opportunity of eeing her would be found; he conented unto my tay, though Delia was of a contrary mind. But love being above all reaons, it was reolved that I hould tay that day in this place, and that when night came I might depart with more afety: And to the end I hould not tay alone in my little prion, the faire Daphnide reolved to keep her bed all day, and eem as if he were not well: for this Cloet was o near her beds head, as we could talke together without being heard by any in the Chamber. This being reolved upon, Delia undertook to acquaint my guide with all neceary intructions what to doe, and to appoint thoe Cavaliers to keep themelves cloe till night.

Having often heard our Druids dicoure of the Great Tautates, and of the immortal oules of men, who after this life do it within heaven, where they remaine for ever: I wondered, but could not comprehend that uch a life hould be delightfull, ince they ay, that they never eat nor drinke, or leep, or any thing ele, but perpetually thinke and contemplate, thinking that time hould eem very tedious unto them, ince it is o long even pat all imagination. But I mut confee, that now I know the contrary, when I conider how quickly and pleaingly hours paed away, when I was o near this faire one; for I was atonihed when I aw it was day, thinking the night not an hour long, o quickly had the time flown away.

Every one of the houe being up, Delia was contrained to the like, and I mut be cloitered up in my cloet: for he would not uffer me to ee when he dreed her elfe, becaue of her maids who waited upon her. I would gladly have done the office of her maid, and helped her, but he would not permit it: Delia alo was againt it, and bad me get into my Cage I pray Love, aid I, be revenged upon you for it: Love, aid he, has nothing to doe with Diana. No? aid I; yet Diana quitted heaven for a kie of Endimion; and he was not o coy, but for a fleece of Wool he was very kind unto Pan, though he had a cloven foot and hornes on his head. Let that Diana of whom you peak, replied he, anwer the Calumny as he pleae; but let me tell you, that unlee my minde alter very much, I will never kis him that is aleep; and as for the hornes of Pan, certainly if ever I love any, I had rather he hould have them then I; yet, aid I unto her, the Moon, whoe name you have, does weare them very hanomly. That is, anwered he, becaue he is not married, and what he does, is onely to advertie lovers whom he lights in the night, that the hornes which they are going to give another, hall at ome time or other be given unto them againe. But, aid he, you prolong the time, get into your Cloet; o he puhed me in, and locked the door upon me: Then calling in the maids which were in the next room waiting he ilently dreed her elfe, pretending that Daphnide was not well: afterwards drawing the curtaines of the Windows, he went to give uch orders as were reolved upon; in the meane time, although there was ome in the Chamber, yet for all that, we talked together, without opening the doore; and though it was in very low voice, yet one of the maids paing by the bed, did hear us, not what we aid, but onely confued whipers. By fortune, Delia being careful of us, came back into the Chamber at the ame time: The maid then addreed unto her, and told, that he feared her iter was icker, then he imagined; why? aid Delia, becaue, anwered the maid, he talkes to her elfe, as if he were ditracted; what did he ay? replied Delia; I did not heare the words ditinctly, anwered he, but I am ure he talked. Alas, alas, aid Delia, doe you not know it is her cutome every morning, as oon as he wakes, to ay her prayers. The wench believed Delia, who a little after came to us, and told the tory, advertiing us to peak lower. I hall, aid I; but, faire Delia, is it not better to end them all out, that the door may be opened. Ah, ah, aid he, and laughed, I am now faire Delia, and not long ince nothing but homed Diana, who loved clubfooted Pan for a fleece of wool; pray tay there where you are, until you have learned to peak a little better of Diana, otherwie he will be angry, and punih both you, and us alo. Upon this, he went to end out the maids and commanded one of them to bring up ome meat for her iter, and to bring more then ordinary, becaue he did not up the lat night. The maid returned preently as he was commanded; Then Delia hut the door: Now aid he, the
Cavalier hall ee how I will be revenged of him; then opening his door, Come Cavalier, continued he, before you receive the punihment which I intend you, I have brought you ome victuals, to trengthen you a little, for I hould be very orry you hould die, before you have felt my revenge. She poke this with uch a pleaant aire, as it was impoible to forbear laughing: and after her iter had taken a little broath, But Delia, aid he, where did you get this? will it not be perceived? yes, anwered he, if I had no more invention then you. Come, come, no more quetions, here it is, eat and be thankful, and the reffue will erve a hungry Cavalier, whom I wih o ill unto. It is better, aid he, to let him have it all; for having fated o long, I am ure he has more need of it then I have. Upon this, he forced her iter to take a little, and offered me ome alo, which I refued: Nay, nay, take it, aid he, it will down with the help of a willing mind. In uch talk as this, we paed away all the morning, and dinner time being come, I mut be hut up againe, leat I hould be een by thoe who brought up meat: The wort was, that dinner was no ooner done, but the Chamber was full of Gallants, whereof ome perhaps had the ting of love upon them; and by fortune; the brother in law itting on the beds ide, he caued a Chair to be et for the principal of them, o near me, that I could carce breath but be heard. Conider Adamas, in what a cae I had been in, if I had been forced to cough or neeze. The mot of their talke was of King Eurick, and the preparations which were making in divers places againt him; of which I was very glad to be informed, that I might acquaint the King therewith, which afterwards did him good ervice: But the wort of all was, they tayed talking until night, though in the Chamber of a ick peron, and never from about her bed: At lat, having a mind to walk, they left her all alone; and then the doores being hut, I came out of the Cloet which Delia opened unto me. Well, aid he, How doe you like the adventure? pray what will you call it? Shall the name of it be Perfect love, or Extream patience? It is, aid I unto her, the mot pleaing adventure that ever I had. But, aid Daphnide, what doe you think of your being o long in that Cell? I think, Madam, anwered I, that I am infinitely happy in being near you. You may ay what you pleae, replied Delia, but I am confident you think liberty better then a cloe prion. If Diana knew what it was to love, anwered I, and what contentment it is to be neare the peron loved; he would not be o incredulous as he is, but on the contrary that I have found the Proverb to be fale, which aith, No Prion weet; for I never found half the delight and contentment in the Palace of Great Eurick, which I have done in this Prion.

We continued in this dicoure a long while, and it was o weet unto me, that hours eemed but minuts: and upper time being come, I mut be againe hut up, but it was for a hort time; for Daphnide being as I think, orry to leave me alone o long, he made uch hate, that her iter complained he had not time enough to eat: yet he had me in memory; which done, I beeeched the faire Daphnide, that ince I was to depart o oone, he would be pleaed to put off all viits for that night, to the end that the time which remained might be imployed with her, which he might wel do by feigning her elf not wel, and by pretending that their being o long about her bed that afternoon, was the caue of it. With much a doe, he conented, and Delia went preently from her to bid all the company good night, and to deire excue, that he went to take her ret o oon.

In the mean time, I was all alone with my faire Mitres: For Delia, let any hould urprie us, had locked the door, and carried the key with her. Love then, and this opportunity, gave me a great alarm: for loving this fair Lady mot paionately, and eeing my elfe alone with her, it was enough to invite me unto the highet train of Courthip: two other great Coniderations preented themelves unto me: one was, the aurances which he gave me of her good will, which ought not to make me the more bold: The other was, The precepts which I received from Great Eurick, not to let opportunity lip; yet judge, Madam, how my affection was tempered: you know, Madam, that all I did, was, I kneeled down at your beds ide, and taking your hand, I kied it with a zealous kie, and a igh: thus was my love accompanied with mot humble and devout repect.

The truth is, wie Adamas, that after I had been thus with her a long while, I aid unto her: I beeech you, Madam, How do you command me to live? I would not have you live, anwered he, as you have done for the time pat; for if you hould, I would never pardon you, after thee tetimonies of my good will which you have received from
me. This, Madam, aid I unto her, is a trange command, and I vow that I will never obey it. How Alcidon, aid he and tarted up out of her bed; Do you vow to diobey me? Conider well what you ay. By fortune Delia put the Key into the doore at the ame time, and we h • rd her opening the door, upon which, fearing letome hould come with her, I retired my elf into the Cloet without giving any anwer; but when he was come into the room, & I aw her alone, I came out, & would have taken the hand of my fair Mitris, but he pulled it away in an angry manner, aying unto me o loud that Delia heard; ince you are in that mind Alcidon, you would doe me a pleaure, if you would trouble me no longer. Delia hearing her give me this language, had an opinion that I had courted her iter in ome way that was dipleaing unto her: This opinion moved her to mile and ay; I ee that much may be done in a little time, ince uch a change is hapned in this little while I have been away I dare lay a wager Cavalier, that you have not oberved the cutomes and conditions which I told you off when you firt undertooke this adventure. Nay, nay, anwered her iter, but perhaps he hath done much wore; for had he done as you ay, he had been onely a perjured Lover, whereas by this which he hath done, he hath declared himelfe perfidious and a Traytor. Oberve age Delia, aid I unto her, two great injuries, and yet you ee me indure them patiently, untill that you have heard us both, and I will make you my Judge, hoping that you will appoint what atisfaction he hall make me.

The Cavalier, aid Daphnide, is infinitely impudent; for he demands atisfaction, where he deerves punihment: but Delja ince he hath made choice of you for his judge, I will alo chue you for mine, that you may appoint a punihment utable to his crime, if you can find one equall unto it; and becaue he hall not ay, that I am too bitter in my relation, I am contented you have it from his owne mouth. Then I began to anwer very calmly, Oberve I beeech you oh my Judge, how my affection urmounts the rigour of this Lady, he requires that you hould cruelly punih me, and if I have committed a fault, I make the ame requet; but if he have done (I will not ay a fault, for I do not think he can) but if he have done any injury againt my love I do not require that he hould be punihed; for if he mart, I hall die of the paine; all I deire is, that he may not offend againt that affection which I beare her. I deire, anwered Delia, that if you will have me your Judge, I may heare your difference. Heare it I beeech you aid I unto her, from her owne mouth; for beides that, I know he can peake nothing but truth; it is reaon you hould know it from her, ince he accueth me, and would have me punihed. Tis true, aid Delia, it is your part to peake firt: I hall let you undertand it in few words, replyed he, for our dicoure was not long; he pake thee words unto me. How Madam, doe you command me to live? I anwered him, I would not have you live as you have done for the time pat; for if you doe I hall never pardon you, after I have given you uch tetimonies of my good will. He anwered; this is a mot trange command, and I doe vow that I will never obey it, and when I charged him with his diobedience you entred, and hindred me from knowing what he would anwer. Then Delia turning towards me: Has Daphnide told the truth, aid he? Yes my Judg, anwered I, and upon thee words, I require jutice; as for the injury he offered in calling me perfidious and Traytor, I ay nothing, becaue you heard them, and beides that, they are but conequents of the firt offence. But aid Delia, which way hath he offended you? For Cavaler, anwer unto thee quetions; doe you not proee your elfe a lover of this Lady? Yes, anwered I, o, that when I ceae to love, I ceae to live. Then replyed Delia, do you not know, that it is one of the principallet laws of Love, for a Lover to obey the peron loved? Yes, anwered I, and o, the commands be not contradictory to his affection; as if he hould command him not to love her, he is not to be obeyed. Tis true, replyed Daphnide, for every thing doth naturally fly that which would detroy it: but how can you excue your elfe as not offending againt this Precept, in this occaion, where you have not onely thought the command which he made that you hould love her, to be trange and hard, but alo has vowed to diobey her. My Judge, anwered I, I did protet it, and I vow and protet it till; and with this reolution, that if I could die and die againe, a • many times as I have lived houres, ince my firt birth, I would rather chue all thoe deaths, then not vow and protet it. You hear (aid Daphnide, being extreamly angry) how he peaks, and judge whether he does not deerve punihment. My Judge, (aid I and miled) let my Mitree command me to fight againt a whole Army of men; let
her appoint me to cat my elfe into the fire, nay, if he pleae let her preently put a dagger through my heart, I will immediately obey her: And to let her ee what dominion he has over me, let her put me to what tet he pleaes; for I am ure he cannot command me any thing, be it never o dangerous or full of difficulty, but my love will prompt me immediately to obedience. Doe you not remember that when you firt admitted me entrance, and enjoyned conditions upon me, how I promied to performe them all, provided they did not contradict my love? I doe remember it, anwered Delia: Then my Judge, replyed I, methinkes you hould not take it ill, that I hould make this vow and protetation of diobedience unto my Mitree, for had I done otherwie I had been perfidious and a Traytor, both to her and Love. I asked her how it was her pleaure I hould live; I would not have you live, anwered he, as you have done for the time pat. Now if I did love her for the time pat as much as a heart could love, in commanding me not to love her as I did for the time pat, is not this to command me not to love her; and hould I not be diloyall and perfidious if I hould obey uch a command? No, no Madam I cannot doe it; I loved you when I was a Child; I have continued it when I was a man, and hall love you till death; nothing can divert me from this reolution; it is o rivitted in my heart that it will never out as long as I live, nay, it will be found in my heart after my death. Delia then began to mile, and aid, I ee that Love is a Child, and a little thing will et him a crying: my entence is this, I doe ordaine firt that all differences hall ceae; then, that Alcidon, as a punihment for his fault in anwering Daphnide o peremptorily, that he would diobey her, that preently he doe kie the hand of his Mitree; and that Daphnide as a punihment for commanding him a thing which he would not have done, had he rightly undertood it, that he hall kie Alcidon, as a tetimony of her repentance. This judgement was executed to my great contentment, and we pent all the ret of the night in uch pleaant dicoure, as when I heard a clocke trike, me thought that it did not make quarters of hours.

I hould never make an end, hould I relate all the dicoure we had amongt us: I will therefore onely tell you, that being ready to depart, after I had deferred it as long as poibly I could; I took the hand of my fairet Mitree and kneeling downe I aid thus unto her; I am now Madam upon the lat minute of my happinee; for Delia and the time forceth me to depart; I perceive that neither of them are enible of my paion, and for ought I perceive, you, who are the caue of it, are as inenible as they. Alcidon, anwered he, doe not complaine of me; but conider, that if I did not love you, I hould never run the hazard of my honour, and your life, which is dearer to me then my owne, and you thinke that the paion which blinds my eyes unto all thee coniderations mut needs be very great. Madam, aid I unto her, this is it which mot amazeth me, that ince you have already done o much for me, you hould now doe o little. Then her Siter being at a little ditance, doing omething in the Chamber, Daphnide anwered me. Remember Cavalier, that the conditions betwixt Delia and you, at your firt entrance into this adventure were, that you hould not be too importunate in your demands, but to be patient and perevere. At this word he held her hand unto me, which with a igh I devoutly kied. Then, aid I unto her, all that I have to doe, is to pray unto the great God Saturne, who is the Governour of time, that he will make it pae away quickly, o as I may arrive at my happinee before my death: otherwie, that if I mut never arrive at it, then that my life may quickly pae, o as I may not live and languih too long in paine. Live Cavalie •• , aid he unto me, and live contentedly, and conider that I doe love you. Thee were the lat words he then poke unto me; for the clocke trucke twelve, which was the hour of my departure, by appointment. And Delia, let he who tayed for me at the doore hould be perceived, would not let me tay any longer: Beides, I was o extreamly grieved that the time was o expired as I could not open my mouth to bid her adieu, at the let, I doe not remember what I aid. Thus I parted o confuedly melancholly, that I was in the midt of the Garden before I poke or anwered Delia one word, at which he being halfe angry: What Cavalier, aid he unto me, and pulled me by the arme, have you let both your tongue and your heart behind you? I doe not know faire Delia, aid I unto her what I have left, nor what I have brought; but this adventure has given me the greatet hopes, and the leat effects that is imaginable Why? ungratefull Cavalier, aid Delia, could you ever
imagine to obtaine more then you have from my iter? Much lee in regard of my merit aid I unto her, but much more in regard of my affection: If you had a ound judgement, aid he unto me, I believe you would have thought quite contrary; for you might expect to obtain much, ince you are Alcidon, o much eteemed by all that know you; o as your merits might jutly plead highly in your behalfe; but your love cannot yet pretend unto much, being o young, as I cannot tell whether your affection can be called by the name of Love; for the name of man, mut not be attributed unto one which is but newly crawled out of his Cradle. How aire iter of my fairet Mitree, aid I unto her; doe you call my love young, when it took root in me as oon as I had any knowledge of good or evill? and can you call it little, which in grandure urpaeth the greatet Gyant that ever breathed upon earth? I think it young (aid he) becaue it never took beginning, till the day before you began this adventure: and I eteem it little, in comparion of what it will be, and in reaon ought to be. But, aid he, and haked me by the hand, let us leave off this dicoure, and tell me when you think to ee us againe, and what you have reolved upon with my iter? You heard all our dicoure, anwered I, and I am o much grieved to part from her, that I doe not remember any thing. Since o, aid he, and miled, your Mitres did very well to favour you no more, for your grief would have made you forget all: Doe not think o, replyed I; for as I have not forgotten, that I did not receive thoe favours which I hoped for, o hould I never forget, if I had received thoe favours which I deire.

Doe not imagine o, anwered he, for men doe much longer remember injuries then benefits; and bitternee has a longer relih in their mouthes then weetnee; but ince you have not reolved upon any thing with my iter, let me advie you to ee her againe, as oon and as often as you can: for you mut conider, that nothing but eyes will atisfie love, nothing will make it take root ooner then eeing her; and nothing will make it grow better then often talking with her. I deire Alcidon, to tetifie, that I doe love you; and ince you have undertaken this adventure, and ince it was I who opened the door unto you, I will give you uch advice, as quetionlee, if you doe follow it, you will bring your enterprie to pae; I am a little elder then my iter, and conequently have a little more experience then he, and perhaps then you either; therefore doe not • ight thoe intructions which I hall give you, unlee you meane to repent it. My iter loves you, he has told me as much, and you may believe it, by her thus hazarding her honour for a ight of you: but he is very young, and by conequence naturally ubject unto the imbecilities of youth. Youth is apt to take any kind of impreion, and as apt to loe it aagain; their moit memories are like oft wax, you may imprint what you will, and it will as eaily loe the impreions, if any new print be offered: therefore to avoid this danger, and if you will till be loved, and well loved, you mut by your preence often renew thee firt impreions, if you cannot doe it as much as is requiite by preence, let it be by Letters, and meages: for when uch unhop't for, and unexpected Complements doe come, they work very great effects: for in love, thoe contentments which are expected, eem to be due, and it is an injury if they be retarded or refued; whereas others that come unlook't for, work great effect upon that oul which receives them. Fair Delia, aid I unto her, If I could requite thee favours which I receive from you, with the hazard of my life, I hould think my elfe much beholding unto fortune: But not daring to hope for o much happinee, I beeech you believe, that in tetimony of the eteem which I have of your judgement and good advice, I will mot religiouly oberve it, and preerve my obligations unto you in my memory as long as I live; and in requital, though I have not a heart of mine own to preent unto you, I will engage my elfe to end you one, which you will eteem much above that which was mine, and is now Daphnides. Alcidon (aid he, and miled) I perceive by your dicoure, that every thing turnes to its beginning: for when you came firt into the Garden, you talked thus of loing your heart, and doe the ame at your going out: I wih that he who has it, may long injoy it: and in the meane time, I hall ee what effects your promies will produce, as well in oberving my advice, as in ending me this heart which you have promied.

Being now come to the Garden door, I took my leave of her; and having found my guide, we walked a gentle pace towards our rocks, but as if the heavens frowned at our eparation: they were upon a uddain overpread with Clouds, o as we did not onely loe the light of the Moon, but were o wet with Rain, as we were forced to helter our elves
under a thick tree, until the fury of it was over. My guide had o lot his aime of the way, as when we went unto thoe who tayed for us, he wandered, and led me unto the head of that Fountaine, which gives both the name and beginning unto the River of Sorgues. This Fountaine is o beet with great Rocks, that it eemes as if it were incloed with high walles every way, but that by which we came. When this Spring is calm, it eems to be a great well, whoe water being too full, runs over: But ometimes, as my guide told me, it is mot horrid to behold: For, aid he, do you ee that high Rock upon your left hand, I aure you, that it will often belch out his water as high as it, with uch a fury and noie, that no Tempet at Sea does equal it. Doe they not know the caue aid I unto him? No, anwered he; for ometimes it begins to be in this fury, when the weather is very faire, and as now you ee, when it raines, it will be as calme as other waters. The caue, replyed I, mut needs be from wind incloed, which forceth the waters thus.

Whilt we were talking thus, the Rain till continued, and I, having found a hollow Rock, under which I could helter my elfe, I advied the Guide to go unto them who tayed for me, in the mean time I would ret my elf, and when the raine was pat, the Moon would hine, and help us in the way.

Now, Reverend Father, I hall here relate unto you a mot trange adventure, not as pertinent to our dicoure, but for the trangenee of it. When my Guide was gone, as I commanded him, and I alone under this wild Rock, Love, out of pitty would not let me be long without him, for I fell into the weet thoughts of Daphnide; and after I had pleaed my elfe a while in thoe raptures, me thought the weather cleared up, and the Moon breaking through the thick Clouds, hined as bright as ever I aw it: This invited me out of my hollow Rock, and whilt I was looking about me that way which I uppoed my company would come, I heard the Fountaine make a noie. I went preently to the ide of it, thinking it would rie up, according to reports: and having a deire to ee this wonder, I et my elfe down upon a tone near unto this Fountaine; then did I ee a thing which indeed is beyond beliefe, without a ight: I aw the water rie above its bank, up to the height of four feet, and then it appeared to be like an old man from the middle upward, with long haire dangling about his houlders, and a beard hanging down to his breat, which being wet as well as his hair of his head, eemed to be o many everal treams about him, with another that flowed out of a pot which he held under his left arm. This old man was Crowned with Rock-fern, and Ruhes, and for a Scepter, held a great Reed in his right hand. Whilt I tood wondring at this Viion, I aw the water to divide it elfe into everal treames, and as oon as he touched them, I aw o many Naiades, or water-Nymphs about him, as there was treames in the Fountaine. All out of reverence, bowed unto him, and he raiing himelfe above them, as upon a Throne which the water made for him, they came to kie his hand, and to preent him with ome Gifts: one preented unto him a Chaire, made and covered with Mos; another, a Garland of Ruhes and Ivie; another, a Girdle of Fern; another, a basket of Chenuts; one offered Poites of water flowers; another, a Net full of everall Fihes: To be brief, every one gave him omething, as tetimonies of their good will, which he received with many thanks. After this, with a loud hril voyce, he aid, Oh Divine Naiades, whom the Detinies have ordained to live in waters, and who complain that you are confined unto my little Spring, whereas your iters wim with full pred armes in the Rone, and Durance. Ceae your complaints, and with me rejoyce at the advantageous choice which they have made for you. For though the limits of our Dominion is not equal unto others in largenee: yet we doe excell them in o many priviledges, that we have no reaon to envy any of our Neighbours: For our life is weet and quiet, none comes to break our leep, nor interrupt our patimes; our banks are never meered with Homicides, nor are our waters ruffled with the welling weight of ayling Ships. But that which ought mot to content us, nay which makes us glorious, above all the Rivers of Europe, is, my divine iters, the infallible promie which we have from Detiny, and which was confirmed with thee words.

Happy Daemon of Sorgues, Hearken (aid he unto me) to the promie which I make unto thee, Nine and twenty ages hall be no ooner pat, but upon thy bankes hall come the Florentine Swan, which hall ing o weetly under the hade of a Laurel tree, that ravihing thereby both Gods and Men, he hall for ever make thy Name famous through all
the world, and hall make thee excell in honour, all the Rivers which like thy elfe doe empty themelves into the Sea.

He would have continued on, when hearing ome noie, and as I beleeve, epying my Companions as they were coming to me, I was atonihed that he and his troope dahing the water with their hands, they made it rie o high that I lot my ight, and I lay as if I were aleepe, as thoe who came unto me told me, not o neere the Fountain as I thought my elfe, but in the ame place where the Guide left me when he went unto them.

This aid Adamas, was a mot miraculous viion, which truly for my part I beleeve to be a dream, but not an ordinary one; for doubtlee this doth ignifie that ome great and remarkable peron hall inhabit in thoe olitary Rockes, and make thoe bankes famous, by the renowne he hall get; which is to be uppoed will be very great, ince the promie of it is made by the Detinies, with uch advantagious words. I cannot tell, aid Alcidon, whether it was a Dreame or no; but I am ure, that I thought my elfe to be awake: and afterwards he continued thus:

I tooke Hore, and to omit all the particulars of my returne, after many dangers, I arrived at the place where I left King Eurick, who received me with many a Carrae; and as it pleaed him to honour me o farre as to love me o would he often aske me how I did thrive in my love; o now taking me by my hand, he carried me into a private roome where none could heare. Come, Lov's Souldier, aid he unto me, Does all goe well in your enterprie, and have you had a good journey or no? Sir, aid I, when it hall pleae you, I hall give a true relation of it, and then your elfe may judge. Let it be now, aid he unto me, for I much long to know whether you are as properous in Love, as I have been in Warre: Then in obedience to his command, I related the whole Adventure; but I have ince heartily repented that I poke o advantagiouly of Daphnides beauty and pirit; for I perceived that it pleaed him exceedingly to heare that all I obtained was good words, and a few kies: then would I have applyed a remedy to my errour, but it was too late: yet to turne the matter, I began to extoll Delia, and o, that at firt I did beleeve I hould imbarque him there. The King, who was more ubtill then to beleeve it, to put me out of my upition, did et o good a face upon the matter, that perhaps any other might have beene deceived as well as I. Oh what groe folly it is for any Lover to acquaint his Mater with his affection! For it did kindle in him uch thoughts as were not in him before, and put him into hopes of being, if not a Poeor of my happinee, yet at let a pretender unto it; yet God knowes what force ambition has upon the pirit of a woman, epecially upon a woman of a generous oule. Whilt we were thus dicouring upon the buinee, newes was brought the King, that they of Arles were reolved to ubmit themelves into his hands, upon thoe conditions he offered unto them; to wit, the conervation of their Franchies and priviledges, without which the Inhabitans of the Town were o couragious, as they would never have conented to acknowledge him. This is the reaon, aid the King, and tooke me aide, why I aske you whether you are as properous in Love, as I am in Warre: For this City is the chiefe of all the Province, and it rendring it elfe unto me, it is to be thought that all the ret after its example, will doe the like. Sir, aid I unto him, it is a very happy Omen unto me, and if I doe bring about my deigne, I will not change my prize for yours. The King imbraced me with a mile, and aid afterward aloud, we hall heare the ret of your buinee another time; Meane while, I will goe and take orders to content thoe of this Towne o, as may invite others to doe as they have done; that Sir, aid I unto him is the bet coure you can take; for a great King, as you are, hould force people unto ubmiion, more by weetnee, then violence.

Whilt the King was buie on his ide, I was no lee on mine; for at the ame time I dipatched Alvian, which was the name of him whom Daphnide gave me for a guide; and becaue he had a great trut and confidence in him, and that his fidelity and affection was already known unto me, I deired him to contrive it o, that by his prudence I might ometimes ee that fair Lady; I told him that I would never forget my obligations unto him, which I would repay any way he would deire: o he departed with a promie, that he would tudy my contentment, and upon every occaion would tetifie his deire of doing me ervice. Thus I left him, and was in uch raptures of Love, as I had no other thought but of Daphnide; I found by experience, that Lovers doe not meaure
their time, like other men, but according to the impatiency of the paion which poeeth them; for dayes eemed unto me whole months, o long did I thinke them, hearing no newes from this faire Lady; my weetet entertainment was my owne thoughts, which when I could get my elfe out of all company, ran continually upon the paages of my voyage.

The great Eurick, having nothing to doe after the rendition of this Towne, would refreh his Army for ome dayes; for it had been much tyred out in that occaion, and dividing them into everall Quarters, he kept no more about him, then were requiite for the afety of his peron. And becaue it was his cutome when he tooke Truce with Mars, to begin warre with Venus, and with his port in hunting, he devoted himelfe unto them two, there being nothing more odious unto his courage, then idlenee; and it was his ordinary Apothegme, that to live and do nothing, was to bury himelfe before he was dead.

My office called me to be continually about his peron, but my affection to him much more; and therefore I was never from his elbow. The truth is, this new love, or rather this renewing of my old love to Daphnide, had made me o melancholly that I could hardly peake unto any: Which the King perceiving one day when he was hunting, whether it was to mocke at my paion, or whether it pleaed him to heare talke of her, who tyed my heart and my tongue, I know not; but he called me unto him, and with a mile, aid; May one not interrupt your thoughts o farre Alcidon, as to tell you, that they are o much taken up with abent perons, that they care not for us that are preent. Sir, aid I unto him, there is a neceity of it upon me, which I hope wil erve for an excue. For ought I ee Alcidon, replyed he, none but I am a loer in this Adventure. Why Sir, aid I unto him? Becaue, aid he, Daphnide hath gotten a Servant, and you, in lieu of a Mater, have gotten both a Mater and a Mitree: But I have lot; for whereas, I alone did poee you, now I have a Companion who has a hare with me, and perhaps a greater then I have. Did I thinke Sir, replyed I pr • ently, that my affection would any manner of way divert me from that ervice which I owe unto you; doubtlee Sir, in lieu of Love, I would chue Death, and hould thinke my elfe unworthy to live, if I did not to my lat breath continue in this deigue. But then, if without prejudice to your ervice I may obtaine that happinee which Love doth promie me, and which my heart does o paionately deire, I cannot thinke it any loe to you; for a good Mater, as you are does alwayes deire to ee his Servants thrive in contentment. I mut confee, aid he unto me, and laughed, that this affection, o it do you no harm, it will not doe me any; but I much feare, that as dieae cannot continue long, but it mut needs either increae or diminih; o if yours do not quickly diminih, it will o increae, that we hall be both loers: And therefore you mut either be diverted from it, or ele ue ome remedies. Sir, aid I unto him, the care which you are pleaed to have of me, will guard me from all danger: But to cure or diminih my affection, is to attempt a thing which is beyond the reach of all poibility.

This, aid the King, is a mot trong and violent paion, Sir, aid I unto him, did you but ee her who is the caue of it, you would ay, all is too little to equall her: But is it credible, aid he, that he hould be o fair, as you peake her? Sir, anwered I, did I not feare that I my elfe hould be the caue of my owne ruine, I would tell you (and truly) much more; but I am afraid that in o doing I hould harpen the weapon which will kill me. How doe you meane? aid he unto me, and becaue I did not anwer: Speak freely Alcidon, aid he, tell me what your fear is; and he commanding me two or three times, at lat I continued; I feare Sir, and not without reaon, let Daphnide being o infinitely faire, hould have as great an influence upon your oule, as he hath upon mine; if that hould happen, there is no way for me but death, and a death o deperate, that my mot mortall enemies would pitty me.

I knew by everall circumtances, aid he then unto me, that you were in this doubt, and I had a mind to put you out of it: No, no, I would not offer uch wrong unto any of my ervants, much lee unto you, upon whom I have conferred o many ignall tetimonies of my particular good will: live happily, and never fear it, for I wear by my Crowne, that no humane beauty upon Earth can make me commit uch a fault. Sir, aid I unto him, I mut humbly protrate my elfe at your feet, by way of gratitude: for I eteeme this favour no lee than a new life, and am ure that if uch a misfortune had beene, I had been but a dead man.

Our dicoure had not o oon ended, unlee the Chae coming towards us, had not forced us away; as for me, I was the mot contented man alive, putting full aurance in his words, and therefore ever ince, when he pake unto me, I told him freely all paages concerning my paion. Some dayes thus paed on, and I heard no newes from Alvian, which was no mall trouble unto me: But at the ame time, the Kings affaires invited him to receive ome place which would ubmit into his hands; and therefore he drew out part of his Army towards that quarter where Daphnide dwelt. When the King told me his reolution, I was ravihed with joy, and aid unto him; Now ir, I hope you will grace me o farre, as to ee my Mitree, for we hall pae cloe by her houe; with all my heart, anwered he: then we hall ee whether he be o faire as you ame her to be; and if I talke with her, I hall quickly know whether you will peed in your hopes.

The King ets forward, and to omit all matters which are not pertinent to my tory, though in themelves worthy of Chronicle; and being within a mile of Daphnides houe, he told me that he would ee her, and that in rrpect of the good ervice which her Father had done him, he could doe no lee being o near her and her Mother, but ee them. I am till afraid Sir, aid I unto him, that this honour which you intend to doe them, is mixed with Love. What? aid he, and miled, you old fits of folly againe? will you not believe what I have promied with an oath; had I onely promied, I hould be onely a deceiver in o doing, but having worn, I hould be perfidious: Come, come, cat away thee foolih thoughts, unlee you are reolved to offend me; and on the contrary, be confident that I will do all the good offices I can, and as you can expect from the bet of your freinds.

Upon this, I preently dipatched a meenger unto Daphnide, to let her know of the Kings coming; and when we were in ight of the houe, I would have gone before, but he commanded me to tay with him, becaue (aid he to me, and miled) I hall be more welcome if I bring you with me, than if I come by my elfe. Sir, aid I unto him, I believe that Lady has o much judgement, as rightly to value the honour which you doe her; but Sir, take heed let you loe the title of invincible; for I aure you, there are trange Captivaters in that houe; it is the habitation of the Graces; Daphnide is accompanied with two iters, who yield not unto any but her elfe; and had I not been already engaged, there is one Delia who doubtlee had abolutely captivated me. Is that he, aid the King, of whom you poke to me before? Yes ir, anwerd I, and doubtlee the mot accomplihed beauty that ever I aw, if as I told you before, he had not a iter. To her then, aid the King, will I addree my elfe. By this time we were come o neare the Catle, that the Ladies being upon the bridge, the King lighted from his hore to alute them; and taking the Mother by the hand, he went into the great Chamber, where they talked a while; and the King enquired of her and her husbands health, and whether Wars were not offenive to her. In the meane time, I talked to the fair Daphnide, who though at all times fair, yet, that day, it might be aid, he urpaed her elfe, having added unto her natural beauty, o many Graces by her artificial dres, as I never aw any o fit to conquer hearts. Delia tood next to her, and my eyes and heart being fixed in contemplation of their beloved object, I tood gazing a long time before I poke. You went away, aid Delia, without a heart, and return without a tongue; if you loe as much every voyage, you will become very ill company: Delia, aid I unto her, you are very pleaant; but if he who hinders you from being the fairet in the world, doe ue uch Arts, I know not what will become of me. Who doe you peak of? aid Daphnide; of you Madam, anwered I, who adds o much art unto your Naturall beauty, that no eye can look, and hope to ecape imprionment. I hould in favour of Alcidon, anwered he, believe that this might be, if every one did look upon me with Alcidons eyes. But let us leave this dicoure, and tell us which way do you take. I am ure, aid I unto her, that the way hither, is the way of my felicity, and my way from you, is the way of my hell: Nay, nay, aid Daphnide; I mean, which way does the King go, and whither does your Army intend to march? I would have anwered her, but the King called me away. Alcidon, aid he unto me, come hither, and be a witnee; is not the trong Towne of Arles reduced into our hands? Yes certainly, ir, aid I unto him; and you mut look for other Kingdomes, and indeed other Worlds, to exercie your Armes in, for there is no more to Conquer which I know of. They will not believe me, replyed the King; and
therefore I pray relate unto this incredulous Lady, how not onely Arles, but almot all the Province which is called the Romans, is in our hands. Oh, ir, aid the good old Lady, not but that I did believe what you did ay; but it is becaue till now, we thought the Towne of Arles impregnable. Nay, nay, replyed the King, I will have you undertand the whole eries of the tory, to the end that hereafter you may not doubt of what I ay: Upon this, riing up, he et me in his place, and went to the place from whence I came; and becaue Delia when he came, would have retired, he pulled her back, and talked awhile unto them both. I could not poibly heare what they aid, as well becaue it was but a little too far off, as becaue I was engaged to talke unto this old Lady. But preently after, when the King took Daphnide by the hand, and carried her the Window, I mut confee, then I began to doubt, and my words did o die in my mouth, as if I were oul-lee: I could not chue but oberve their faces and actions; and whatoever I aw, made me upect that which I feared mot; o as I wihed withall my heart, for ome hot alarm to call away the King from the place where he was. I cannot tell how long his Courthip lated, but I am ure it lated o long, that I thought every minute a day. At the lat, the King took his leave, and went on his journey. Daphnide eeing me following, did beckon unto me, as deirous to peak with me; whereupon I commanded one of my men to hide my hore, to the end I might have ome colour to tay behind; o as though the King called me twice or thrice, yet tay I did, eeming to be very angry with my ervants, for the little care they had of my Hore. The King, and almot all the Train departed; and I going into the houe, eeming onely becaue I would not have the Ladies tay o long in the Sun, I took Daphnide aide: Well Madam, aid I unto her, what doe you thinke of the Great Eurick? Nay, aid he, what dicoure doe you thinke we had? I cannot tell, replyed I: Then, aid he, I will tell you, and you hall judge which of us two loves you bet: when he took me to the window, to the end Della might not hear, though at the firt he tayed her with me out of civility: he aid unto me; I doe not now wonder, that Alcidon hould run uch hazard to ee you, for I protet you are the fairet in the world; and now I have een you, I cannot think any in the whole Univere worthy of eteem.

At the firt, this dicoure made me bluh, epecially hearing him mention you, and of a buinee which I did not thinke he knew of: yet eeming as if I did not undertand him, I anwered thus: I know not ir, why you hould tell me of Alcidon, nor what hazards he has run; but I am ure, that there is nothing in me worthy of your eye, nor of the language of o great a King. Why, fair one, aid he unto me, did you thinke Alcidon could leave our Army without my leave, and without telling me whither he went? The Law of War is very evere and trickt: moreover, aure your elfe, that he is too young to enjoy o much good fortune. I am o little vered in the way of War, anwered I, and the age of Alcidon does o little concerne me, as I never learned the one, nor cared for the other. Why, aid he, doe you thinke I know not, how he hath eene you twice; the firt time at a Cavaliers houe, who has the charge of my Artilery; and the next time, at your iters, where you kept him in a Cloet: No, no, Fair one, he has told me all, and o particularly, as you your elf do not know them better: Certainly, aid I, Alcidon has a great confidence in you; and in aying o, I was contrained to cover my bluhes with my hand, being ahamed the King hould know all thee particulars. But he miling; This, aid he, is the common vanity of all young people; they cannot be ilent, but mut be blabbing of their own happinee; but be not angry I hould know this, ince loving and honouring you o much as I do, I hall take no notice of it; but if you will follow my advice, and preerve your reputation, cat off this youth, and reject his addrees; for you may be certaine, that he who would tell me thee things, will in an humour tell them to any other, and perhaps to ome that are not o dicreet as I am.

Judge, Alcidon, aid he to me, into what a condition you have brought me, by acquainting him with thee things, which above all you hould have concealed. How can I chue but be extreamly angry with you, when I reflect upon the wrong you have done me? Madam, aid I unto her, I mut needs confee my elfe in a great fault, but I am confident you will excue it, if you will but pleae to remember the manner how we lived in the dayes of his Predeceor King Thorimond, who being the firt caue of our love; I thought this King, being as gracious unto me as the other, would alo favour the accomplihment
of it: but I perceive their deignes are farre different; for the one aimed at my happinee in giving me that which he had a mind unto himelfe: and the other intends to make me mot mierable by ravihing from me, her whom he knowes is mine, and without whom he knowes I value not my life: For I doe foreee, by the knowledge which I have of his humour, that he will love you; his deigne I perceive is to put you out of conceit with me; o as your mind then not being ingaged, he hopes the more eaily to win upon you, and bring about his own ends. But Madam, if you doe think him able to compae his deires, and that I hall ever ee this change in you, I conjure you by the memory of great Thorimond, who loved us both o well, never to let me ee it, but to tell me betimes, that my death may anticipate uch a dire accident. Daphnide then miled, and aid, I am very glad to ee you o much perplexed as you are, as well to prevent you from relaping into your crime of being o liberall in your tongue, as to know by your fears which you have of the King and of his good will unto me, that you doe really love me. But Alcidon, I love you too well to let you be long in this perplexity; Live therefore contentedly, and be confident, that as long as Alcidon loves me, Daphnide will never love any other, and that neither the grandure, nor authority of a King hall ever be able to alter me in this reolution.

We had talked longer, if the King who had already ent twice for me, had not ent the third time, fearing, as I beleeve, let Daphnide hould impart unto me, what he had aid unto her: Therefore after I had kied the hand of my fairet Mitree, and after he had given me aurance, that if the King continued, he would impart all unto me, I departed, and galloped after the King, whom I found gone but a little way; for he tayed purpoely to dipatch away an expree to colour thereby his taying for me, and to the end, that if I came not quickly, he might end another meenger for me. When I was come unto him; Alcidon, aid he, I ent for you, becaue there is danger in coming after an army with few men; for I have intelligence that the Enemy is not farre off, and if they have any deigne of doing any thing, they will watch uch occaions by their pies. I gave him mot humble thankes for the care he had of me, and though I made no hew of it, yet I knew very well, that when he aid the enemy was not farre off, he aid truly, ince he himelfe was neer me, and no enemy could be more dangerous nor cruell then himelfe. Oberve, wie Adamas, the follies of love; I reented the injury o deepely, that had I not feared to incur the danger of being taxed for a perfidious Cavalier, I know not unto what fury my reentments might have prompted me unto againt him; but upon good conideration of the matter, I reolved to mother my wrongs, and eeme to take no notice that I knew any thing; conidering, that when the deires of people are thwarted, they are mot violent, and when the deires of perons in power are once knowne, they are prompted to ue violence.
