But the great contraint in which I lived, did o perplex me that I fell icke: By this, reverend Father, you may judge how great my affection was, ince it had power to bring me into uch a condition. The King did not thinke my icknee o great as it was; but it increaing every day, and his affaires contraining him not to abide long in one place, he left me in the City of Avignion, upon the report of the Phyitians, who told him how great my dieae was.

Thus I tarried in this Towne o ill, that but for the contentment which I received from ome Letters which Daphnide ent me by Alvian, I know not what would have become of me. However, it was more then eight dayes that I kept my bed, before I heard any newes from Daphnide, becaue he not knowing of my icknee, but uppoing me to be in the Army, he ent Alvian thither. In the meane time I who thought that he knew of my icknee, I pined away with orrow and griefe, having an opinion that her ilence proceeded from a defect in her affection, and then I blamed the incontancy and ambition of women, uppoing that the Kings affection to her was certainly the caue of it. At lat, my impatiency not being able to indure this incertainty: I ent unto her my Servant, who carried my Letters; the firt time unto her, and in the extremity of my icknee, I writ thee few words unto her.

div.head: Alcidons Letter unto Daphnide,
div.p: I Have all the reaon in the world at this time to complaine againt my Fortune, being at once left both by my Mater and my Mitree. (I know not Madam whether it be permitted me to phrae you o) But in this I mut needs commend her, who eeing the injuries, which both of them doe me, he would not let me live any longer, leat I hould any longer indure this unjut punihment.

See, age Adamas, how Love will ometimes both wound and cure his Subjects, almot at the very ame time. Alvian, who was ent to eeke me in the Army, and hearing that I lay icke in Avignion, he returned in all hate to his Mitree, who preently dipatched him unto me; and by fortune, the ame day that her Letter came to me, mine came to her: The Letter which Alvian brought, imported thee words.

div.head: Daphnides Letter unto Alcidon.
div.p: THe Bearer hereof, hath been a great ditance off to eeke you, and to my great griefe will find you neerer; If my Health be any thing deer unto you, let me heare of yours.

When I received this meage, and undertood by word of mouth the reaon why he writ o hort, was becaue he thought me o icke, as I was not able to read more. Oh, age Adamas, I cannot expree my joyes! I was indeed very icke, and the Phyitians, who applyed onely corporall remedies, were farre beides the marke, ince my malady was only of the mind. The truth is, that from the firt houre of Alvians arrival, I recovered trength; and not to diobey the command which I received from Daphnide; I ent him back the next morning with this anwer.

div.head: Alcidons Anwer unto Daphnide.
div.p: IT is from Daphnide you mut inquire of Alcidons health, ince it wholly depends upon her: If you continue upon him the honour of your favours, he is well: otherwie he is not onely dead, but orry that ever he lived.

On the other ide, Daphnide eeing my thoughts, or rather my jealouie, he was very deirous that Alvian might remove it from me; for he knew very well, that I had a great confidence in him. And further to make her good will appeare, he ent my Servant backe, with o many good words, and aurance he would never alter, as I was contrained to beleeve it: Her anwer was this.

div.head: Daphnides Anwer unto Alcidon.
div.p: IF it be o, that one may judge of another by themelves, I have great reaon to doubt of that fidelity which you have promied me, for you have done o of mine. If you were in my roome, hould ambition tranport you above love? Oh no, I will not harbour uch an opinion of you: For I mut confee, Alcidon, if I did, I would not love you o well as I doe; wrong me therefore no more in this kind, unlee you would have me beleeve, that you would have that affection diminih, which you have worne unto me.

Thus we continued many dayes writing unto one another, with o much contentment unto me, that my dieae was forced to leave me: and when I had got o much trength as I hoped every day to ride abroad, Alvian came to bring me two Letters which the King had writ unto her from the Army: And in tetimony of her free way he lived with me, he ent them yet ealed, as when he firt received them.

div.head: Daphnides Letter unto Alcidon.
div.p: NOw the Wars are begun, I have ent you two Prioners; none yet ever poke with them, treat them as you pleae, I freely give them unto you, as I will doe all the ret that fall into my hands.

In this, I received at once a great pleaure, and a great dipleaure; I cannot expree my contentment, to ee that Daphnide did o well performe her promie to me; but it wounded me to the very oule, to ee that the King hould attempt that, which he had worn unto me the contrary. To withdraw my elfe from Daphnide, I thought a thing impoible; and I knew that if the minde of this faire one proved trong enough to reit him, he would in a tranport of paion banih me the Court: Alo if he yielded or was overcome, then there was no hopes of any life for me. I remained long in this doubtfull incertainty; at lat, love having the predominancy in my heart, I reolved to advie her, not to receive any uch meages from him, if it were poible: yet my curioity prompted me to ee what the King had writ, having an opinion, that though I did not, yet he would read them, and I hould never know; o I returned her this Anwer.

div.head: Alcidons Anwer unto Daphnide.
div.p: THee two Prioners, Madam, are not of that quality to be kept long in my prion: I have therefore ent them both back: But take heed let in hearkning unto any more, the Fort which Parleyes doe render it elfe.

I hould be too tedious, hould I relate all the Letters which we writ unto each other at that time; for ince it was not above ix or even leagues betwixt us, we ent unto each other almot every day: But o it was, that the King being reolved to be as victorious in Love, as in War; he perited o cloe in the Courthip of this faire one, as what excue oever he can find, he mut confee, that if it was not Love, yet it was Ambition at the leat, which invited her to hearken unto him, and to entertaine his Courthip: Oh Heavens? what groe folly it is in any, to look for any certainty under the Moon? I mean for any thing which is not alterable? Whilt thus we continued writing unto each other, the King continued his enterprie; and I who thought that I had a good occaion to laugh at him, did find my elfe in the concluion, the party laughed at. Pardon me, Fairet Mitres, I beeech you, if this truth offend you. Well, well, Alcidon, aid Daphnide, and interrupted him, I will not now anwer you, go on with your dicoure as you pleae. Upon this, Alcidon continued.

The King having effected his enterprie againt his enemies, he returned the ame way he came, purpoely to ee his new Mitree: and to the end I hould know nothing of it, he came the night before his Army, almot all alone, and lodged in her houe. He had made choice of uch to wait upon him, as I knew nothing of it a long time after; but at lat, I came to know it by an accident, which hereafter I hall tell you. In the meanetime, the King came to Avignion, where he honoured me o far, as to enquire of me: and becaue I was extreamly vexed at the puruit which I aw he made of this faire Lady, I could not perfectly hake off my icknee; but being neither well nor ill, I languihed away uch a melancholly life, as I became carce knowable: The King hearing of it, ent everall times to viit me, and he himelfe condecended to come and ee me, but poke not a word of Daphnide, nor made any hew of eeing her, or had her o much as in memory. I for my part, kept not uch a cloe Guard upon my lips, but told him, that it grieved me o much, that againt his promie he hould ue me thus, as the very ight of him aggravated my griefe, and augmented my icknee.

Since the lat time that the King was with Daphnide, he writ unto me onely as an umbrage for her intentions, and to keep me as long as he could from the knowledge of all paages, though he knew they would out at lat: for the Courthip of Great Princes
cannot be long concealed. As for the Letters which he received from him, he ent them not unto me, as he was wont to doe, unlee it were ome out of which no great matter could be collected, and thoe very rarely. Thus did I fret away my time with uch heartbreaking thoughts, as when I think upon them, I cannot chue but wonder they did not bring me to my Grave. Sometimes in the evening when the weather was fair, and the Sun in decline of heat, I hould walke upon the bankes of the River Rone, towards the houe of this fair one, and there all alone contemplate upon my own thoughts, until the Suns light had left our Hemiphere; and then I hould returne to my own lodging, and pend the whole night in the ame melancholly imaginations.

How often have I taken conjectures of my misfortune for certainties, and then wihed my elfe out of this life, as thinking that I lived onely to reent my own orrowes and her treachery? How oft have I with didaine, thought my elfe a fond fool for loving uch a weathercock beauty? how many times have I reolved to break off all thoe perfidious bonds that tyed me to her ervice? perfidious may I well call them, for all her oathes and promies, which together with her beauty, tyed me to her ervice, are all vanity and deluders.

But alas, how oft have I alo conidered, that not being my elfe, I was not able either to doe or reolve upon any thing, but according to her will and by as that drew me unto her? Till now, age Adamas, my miery was onely dubious, and hanged onely upon upition: but now, ee how the whole truth came to be dicovered unto me.

I was walking, as I told you, upon the bankes of Rone, not with any intention to divert my elfe, but onely to entertaine my mortal thoughts one evening, as I was returning to my lodging, I aw a young Cavalier, who was one of my friends, whoe Father erved the King in his Courthip of this faire one; and he rid by me, and did not know me, not imagining that he whom he aw could be alone o late, whom he knew never ued to walke o lenderly attended but riding on a little further, and knowing and ervant that waited upon me at a ditance, he asked him what he did in that place: and my ervant anwering, that he waited there until I had done walking; the Cavalier preently alighted from his hore, and having aluted me, beeeched me to pardon him, for paing by and not knowing me. After ome common dicoure which we had together upon that ubject, I asked him from whence he came, and whither he was going? He who was altogether ignorant of my love unto this fair one, and knew nothing neither of the Kings but by his father, he anwered me with all freedom and plainnee. I come ir, aid he, from a place, where you are had in memory, and I have brought you a letter which will tetifie as much; then putting his hand into his pocket, he took it out, and withall another, the upercription whereof I knew; and having a upition, that it was directed unto the King; alo eeing how free this young Cavalier was in his language, as I tooke my owne letter, I asked him, for whom the other was: For whom (aid he) why? it is to the King my Father is faln ick, and he gave it unto me to carry unto the King: He pake thus unto me, as thinking that I knew of the Kings love, as I did all other the Kings buinee before. Though this made a deep impreion upon my heart, yet I miled at his implicity, and aid unto him: I doe believe, dear friend, that both you and your Father, are put to very much trouble in the buinee. Oh Sir, aid he very freely, I wear unto you, that all the voyages of War which the King has taken has not been o troubleome to us, as this cured love hath been, epecially ince the King in his return, went to ee that faire Lady; and you may imagine this a truth, by the icknee which my Father hath gotten. My dear friend, replyed I, and embraced him uch as great Princes doe imploy upon uch occaions, are uch whom they bet love; and therefore you are not a little obliged unto that fair Lady who is the caue; beides your own merit, of the Kings love and favour unto you. Sir, aid he unto me, I cannot tell what may happen; but I am affraid that this Lady of whom you peake, will o bewitch him, as none can have any hare in the Kings favour and love but herelf.

Thee words went o to my heart, as they contrained me to dimie him ooner then otherwie I would: and having no curioity to know any more, I told him purpoely to make him go away, that the King impatiently expected his coming, and that I would not deprive him of his contentment by taying him any longer.

Thus I remained all alone, unlee accompanied with o many dimal and mortal thoughts, as it was above an hour before I would return: but at lat, night contraining
me to retire into the Towne: I went unto my lodging with a defigne to depart all alone the next morning, and o hun all manner of humane Company, as none hould ever deceive me againe. And to begin, I went unto my Chamber by a backe taires, and having none but my Page with me, I went preently to bed, and commanded him to tell all the Company that expected me, how I was not well, and that I ent him to bid them all good night. I cloed not an eye all the night long, and Aurora began to bluh before any mind of leep came upon me: And being in a full reolution of departure a Feaver eized upon me o violently, as I was contrained to deferre untill my recovery. I had not yet looked into the Letter which Daphnide ent me, having neither o much courage as to ee what was in it, nor hate enough to cat it into the fire; but not knowing which of thee two I hould reolve upon, I held it in my hand, and kept it two dayes before I brought it to light: At lat, being tranported with choller one night when I was alone, I mut, aid I to my elfe, I mut needs ee the treachery of this perfidious woman, and afterwards o exclude her out of all memory, that nothing may remaine of her in me but eternall corne. Upon this, raiing my elfe up in my bed, I opened it, and by the helpe of a wax Candle which tood by my bed ide, I read what he had written unto me.

But, wie Adamas, unto what purpoe hould I repeat here thoe words which were writ onely with an intention to delude me the longer: And againe, why hould I not repeat them, ince it is requiite the Phiitian hould know the wound, before he can apply right remedy? I will therefore reheare them, not any thing to my conolation, but onely to let you ee how I was ued.

div.head: Daphnides Letter unto Alcidon.
div.p: SHall I never heare anybetter newes, but that Alcidon is till icke? Shall I never ee him as he was when he undertooke the adventure of Perfect Love? Have all my Prayers no efficacy in them? will the Gods be eternally deafe unto all the upplications that I make unto them for your health? Oh ye Gods; if o, then either abridge my griefe, or ele change my heart, that it may not be o enible of his ufferings: and you Alcidon, either reolve upon a recovery, or ele to kill me with griefe.
See reverend Father, what a cruel Letter I received, after I had dicovered her treachery to me; unto which in a tranport of anger I returned this anwer.

div.head: Alcidons Letter unto Daphnide.
div.p: THere is nothing can cure Alcidon but death, ince he findes no fidelity either in his Mater or his Mitree; and therefore to what purpoe hould I live any longer amongt a Company of perfidious people? Never complaine that the Gods are deafe; for they have heard your prayers, and in not giving health unto him whoe life could do nothing but grieve for the breach of o many oathes, they have made your heart inenible of me, but too enible of another, who perhaps will one day revenge o many per • idious oaths; for the Gods are more jut then not to revenge me, and punih you.

I gave this Letter unto my ervant, who carried my firt, and did command him to returne preently, and not tay for any anwer. The mart of this dipleaure was uch, that my dieae increaed very much; of which the great Eurick hearing, although he was ahamed of his filching away this faire one from me; contrary to all his promies made unto mee, yet after dinner he condecended to come and viit me. I was indeed very icke, and yet my greatet paine was the remembrance of his theft; o as when I was told the King was coming to ee me I trembled, as if a new fit of an Ague had eized upon me; and when I aw him, there appeared not a drop of blood in my face; but perhaps thoe who oberved, did thinke my palenee was onely an effect of my icknee.

He came to my bed ide, where after he had asked me all circumtances, concerning my dieae, and I anwered as civility and honour commanded; he at downe, then turning
his backe upon all the Company, he began to peake in a lower tone, and eeing that I carcely poke one word, he thought to waken me by talking of Daphnide, little thinking that I knew how quares went betwixt them. He asked me how that fair one did, and how long it was ince I heard from her. I anwered him very faintly, that I thought he was well, and that I never heard from her ince the day that he writ unto him, by uch a man, and then I named the man who brought me the lat Letter. The King bluht and at firt would have denied that he received any from her; but I beeeched him to pardon me, for I knew he did, and that the ame man who brought him his Letter, brought one to me alo. How? aid he then unto me, did he then end one unto you? Yes Sir, anwered I, and moreover I know of the honour which you did her, in eeing her at her houe At this, he was a little confued, when he aw I knew what he thought me ignorant of: and after a long paue: Alcidon, aid he unto me, I mut needs confee my fault, though to my hame: Tis true, I did ee that Lady of whom you peake and have received Letters from her: and more then all this, I mut confee that I doe love her above my own life.

I cannot deny but that in this I am a very bad Mater, and a wore friend to treat you thus after o many promies to the contrary; but in my confeion of this perfidie, I can ay no more in my owne defence, but that I was deceived my elfe, before I deceived you: I was perwaded, that as I never met with any man living who could overcome me, o much lee that a woman could be able to doe it; and in this opinion I promied you that which ince I find my elfe not able to performe. The confidence which I had in my owne trength againt men, did drive me into the errour of depiing all women in general, and of this Lady in particular; and my orrow is o much the greater, in that it reflects upon Alcidon, to his prejudice; Alcidon I ay, whom I loved o well; and it is to be beleeved, that ince I have been o perfidious unto him, it is a thing abolutely impoible for me to doe otherwie: Alcidon my dear friend, I freely make confeion of the wrong which in pight of myelfe, I have done you; proteting that if I could any way in the world pay that debt unto which I am obliged, I would preently doe it, with as good a heart, as ever I received any favour from heaven.

The King uttered thee words in uch a dicompoed manner, and with uch a countenance, as tetified that his expreions did not come from his heart: And becaue I aw him tand ilent, I anwered him; Sir, aid I, all that is in the world were created to erve your greatnee, epecially Alcidon who is ready to acrifice himelfe upon the Altar of your contentment: And the Heavens foreeeing it impoible I hould be deprived of Daphnide and live, will take away my life, let it hould be any obtacle unto you: And therefore welcome death, ince my life cannot conduce to your contentment. Upon this, I could not retraine my teares, and the King being moved at them, after a while of ilence, aid unto me: You cannot Acidon, wih me o ill, as the injury I have done you does merit, I doe mot ingeniouly acknowledge it, and wih that my blood could remedy it; perhaps I hall doe it in time, but for the preent there is no thought of it. And yet for your atisfaction, I am reolved upon any thing you would have me, onely take heart and recover of your icknee; and beleeve to your contentment, that I will doe all I can to procure it. After this, the King went out of my Chamber, leaving me in uch a ad condition as it is incredible any other than my elfe hould live under uch a load of orrowes and depaires.

Alcidon turmoiled with the memory of thee painfull paages, and the wrong which he received both from his Mater and his Mitree, he lot his peech, o as after a while of ilence, when he offered to peake, he could not; and therefore he was forced for a long time to be ilent; at lat triving with himelfe he broke out with much adoe, and aid: You ee Madam, how in obedience to your commands, I make my old wounds bleed afreh, but when I conider all is by your command I doe patiently indure all; but if your Rigor be not greater than my Patience, I beeech you helpe me to beare the burthen which you have impoed upon me, I meane in the continuance of this relation of my mifortunes, of which you may peake with more aurance than I can; for in all that is hereafter to be told, I am only the ufferer of what you were pleaed I hould endure. Methinks my requet is not unreaonable, that the wie Adamas may undertand from your mouth the truth of thoe things, whereof you only are the Author. Adamas not taying for the anwer of Daphnide, turned towards her, and aid; Methinkes Madam the motion
of this Cavalier is reaonable, and that by your owne ordinance impoed upon him, you are obliged unto it.

Reverend Father, anwered he, the law is not equall betwixt him and me yet ince you thinke it fit, I hall doe as you pleae; and I mut tell you, that though Alcidon hath poken the truth, yet as good Orators ue, he hath inerted ome words to the great advantage of his caue: Then after he had paued a while, he continued the dicoure thus.

div.head: The Sequel of the Hitory of Daphnide and Alcidon.
div.p: IT is a Proverbe full of reaon, that Parties intereted or prepoeed with any Paion, can never be good judges, becaue their judgements being offended, they can never performe their perfect Functions, no more than a leg or an arme can which has any great wound. Alcidon has made good the Proverb by the conequences which he hath o often drawne to my diadvantage being byaed thereunto more by paion then by reaon: And becaue my dicoure would be very long if I hould anwer all his particular rovings into Paion, I will omit them, and truly relate the remainder of our Fortune, and leave you to cenure of his paions. And to begin where he left, I will tell you Reverend Father, that having received the Letter which he ent unto me, unto which I returntd no anwer, becaue the Meenger according to his command went preently away without bidding any adieu. I became the mot deolate peron in the world, being taxed with a crime (and with ome colour of reaon) which I could not helpe. I undertood preently after by the Kings Letters, all the dicoure which they two had together, and afterwards by Alvian, whom I ent purpoely to ee how he did, though I did not write, who told me how ill he was.

I dicoured long with my elfe what I hould doe in the buinee; for on the one ide, his affection to me invited me to goe unto him, and tell him how he was mitaken: on the other ide, I durt not doe it for fear of being blamed. I was long wavering in the ballance between thee two coniderations, before the Scale would turne to either ide; but at lat, the returne of Alvian contrained be to goe unto him; for bringing me uch very bad newes of his icknee, I cat off all other coniderations, and reolved to ee him: In this determination I ought out for ome excue to colour my Voyage: And preently after, a very good one preented it elfe: For Peace being made, my Brother-in-law was contrained to goe to Avignon about getting of a Cozen of his, who was a Prioner in the Towne which was rendred unto the great Eurick; and who becaue he would needs contradict the generall reolution, thoe of the place eized upon him; and though Peace was afterwards publihed, yet they would not et him at liberty, leat if the warre hould breake out againe, he hould interprie omething againt them: And eeing there was ome difficulty about his inlargement, and that the buinee by conequence would take up a long time, he would carry his wife with him, and he had a great deire of my Company, that I might be een with him, if he was forced to make any addrees unto the King. As oone as the husband made the motion unto me, I conented with a condition of my Mothers conent: The good old woman gave her conent as oone as ever he undertood the caue; o as within two dayes after, we et forward, and as fortune was, our lodging hapned to be directly over againt the lodging of Alcidon.

His icknee was much poken of, and the King went oft to ee him, for he loved him very well: but when he was advertied of my arrivall, he hewed himelfe more deirous of his health than before: For whereas he was wont to ee him but once or twice in a weeke, ince I came, he went to him every day, and as he went or came backe he commonly came to my lodging. As for me, the ame day I came I ent to Alcidon, and told him by Alvian, that if he was pleaed, I would willingly come and ee him and as oone as I received his anwer, I went thither I found him very ill, and his Chamber full of Phiitians and Chyrurgians, o as at that time. our talke was onely of his malady; unto which, he anwered very little, and ighed much. The day after, I tooke my time o conveniently as I found him almot all alone; and then after I asked him how he did, he anwered me with tears in his eyes, and in a feeble and languihing tone: Why
Madam, aid he, doe you aske me any quetions concerning that dieae which you your elfe have caued? you mut needs know it better then I, or all my Phyicians. Alcidon, anwered I, I doe indeed know part of your dieae, which is that of your minde; but I am altogether ignorant of your corporal dieae, and it is that which I am mot affraid of: for, as for the other, I am confident you will quickly recover. Ah Daphnide (aid he unto me, with a deep igh) I ee by this, that you have mot care of that part which leat does merit it: for, if there be any thing in me which is commendable, it is this oul, with which I have not onely loved you, but even adored you, with uch a pure and entire affection, as I believe none but your elfe could leight it as you do. This anwer, replyed I, argues your dieae; but have all the care you can for the cure of your body, and you will finde that the dieae of your oule is not mortal; at leat, if there be any parke of •• aon yet remaining in you. I doe know, anwered he, that the dieae of my oule is not mortal; for our Druids tell us, that the oul never dies, but is immortall: but ince the dieae of my body, will not cure the dieae of my oule, I will further it with my own hands ere long, that I may no longer look upon a peron with the eyes of love, who has o little in her oule. I perceive, replyed I, that you are deeply wounded, and your greatet paine is in your opinion: you thinke that the addrees of the Great Eurick have uch an influence upon me, that they will extinguih that affection which I have promied unto you. Is not this your dieae Alcidon? Doe you not think you have reaon to complaine againt me, and your fortune, which was to love a peron o wavering and incontant? To this he anwered very faintly; Did you as well know how to cure, as to find out my dieae, I hould confee you to be an excellent good Phyitian. It is as eaie to cure it, replyed I, as to know it. And to begin; tell me Alcidon, how came you to know, that I doe not love you? is it not by thoe anwers which I have given unto the King, and by uffering my elfe to be een and courted by him? But lay aide your Paion a little, and conider who King Eurick is; who I am; and in what times we live in: You ee Eurick is a great Prince, who is able to doe what he will: againt whom, Cities, Provinces, nay whole Kingdomes are not able to reit, when he is pleaed to turne his Arms againt them.

Doe you think that love is not as trong a paion in him, as his ambition? Can you believe that I am able to reit his force, more then o many millions of perons? you know that I am his ubject; that I dwell in the Country which he hath conquered, and in a time when he thinks all forfeited unto him: Can you thinke me well advied, if I hould didaine and reject him. Doe you think he would uffer me to live quietly in his Dominions, if I hould treat him o, epecially knowing from your own mouth my love unto you? He would alo accue You of all the harh treatment that he received from Me. Is it poible your paion hould o blind your eyes, as not to ee that the onely remedy is this which I have ued? Into what a trange fury would his didained love turn, if it hould beleighted? the name of hatred is too low; ome new phrae which ignifies hatred, mut be invented, before it can be rightly expreed: hatred, anger, rage, fury, deire of revenge, nay tyranny, and cruelty, will not ignifie his Digut. Then Alcidon, conider, into what a condition I hould have brought you & my elf alo, if I had taken that coure; the leat you could have expected, is banihment out of all his Dominions; and the leat that I could look for, is a thouand wrongs and affronts, which neither you nor I could ever have endured without death or revenge: ee into what extremities we hould have brought ourelves, and what contentments we may well hope for by living thus; confes my counel to be the bet, ince it ecures us from all danger, and makes a way for us to live happily together, and with more contentment than ever we did. Alas, Madam, anwered he, how eaie a thing it is to know, that all thee reaons are but meer excues, for did you intend as you ay, why did you conceal the matter from me? why did you not dicover it at the firt, but made ue of o many hifts and deluions, as may well be called treachery, of which I had never known, unlee I had made the dicovery by a meer accident? I hall in this confee the very truth, anwered I, I thought you to be o farre from this opinion, that I thought it to no purpoe to tell you, but to ue you as children are ued who are ick, they weeten the edges of the Cup which holds the bitter medicine, and o tempt them to take it the more eaily, and by this meanes preerve their lives; auring my elfe, that you would not take it ill when you knew my intention, but would relih both the benefit, and the medicine. Alas, aid he unto me, with a deep igh, a medicine
more bitter and difficult to take and endure, than the dieae is of which you would cure me. All ick people, anwered I, when Medicines are preented unto them, do ay as much as you, but when they find the good effects, and recover health, then they commend both the medicine and Phyician, and reward them with a thankful Fee: and I hope that ere long you will do the like.

He would have anwered, but was prevented by a great company of Cavaliers, who came to viit him; and preently after, I left him with them, not fully atisfied in his mind, but o dipoed, that my arguments began to worke with him and becaue I deired his recovery above all things, I aw him againe two or three dayes after, and ued uch arguments, that he conidering the tate of things, and that there was no remedy, he conented I hould continue o with Eurick: upon which, I made a promie unto him, that as he was the firt I ever loved, o hould he be the lat, and that I would love him until I was in my Grave: That the affection which I bare unto Eurick, might be called Reaon of tate, and that which I bare unto him, might be called Love of heart.

Thee, Reverend Father, were the remedies which I ued to cure this ick man, and they had uch an operation upon him, that he began to recover, and rie out of his bed; o as before I went from Avignion he was perfectly well, and o contented that I hould mile upon the King, that he himelfe would often come with him, when he came to viit me. The truth is, I was put to ue all my art in carrying my elfe o wimingly, as to perwade the King that I was quite off the hinges with Alcidon; and Alcidon had much a doe to perwade him that he had no deigne upon me; for the King knowing what good will had been betwixt us, he could not believe that he could out of repect unto him, extinguih his flames unto me: Alo conidering, that Alcidon was young and hanome, and at a right age for love, he thought him o fit a ubject for my love, as he could not thinke I could quit Alcidon for him. Thus did he live long in jealous upition; but the dicreet carriage of Alcidon, and my coldnee towards him, did make him loe that opinion; and therefore thinking himelf ole poeor of my affection, he openly hewed his love unto me; o as after my brother in law by my mediation had obtained his deires, he ent for my Father and Mother to come unto him, purpoely as an excue for his deires of having me near him. Although they were both very old, yet ambition which alwaies takes more root in the oules of old people, then in young, did in obedience to his commands, move them to leave their homes in hopes of preferment unto greater favours.

Now are both become Courtiers, and the King did not deceive their hopes, for he loaded them with wealth and honours, which yet they did not long enjoy; for whether it was that their age was arrived at that term, beyond which none can pae: or whether it was that the Turmoiles and noie of the Court did abridge their lives; yet o it was, that they both dyed preently after, as if they came to the Court onely to leave me in poeion of it, for otherwie, I durt not have come: but being there, I tayed there under excue of taking order about ome dometique buinee which was left upon me, and afterwards when the Kings affection to me was publihed in hopes to be his wife, as he himelf divulged.

During all this time, few dayes paed without giving Alcidon an opportunity of eeing me in private, and in which I did not pend two hours at the leat with him, which alwaies eemed hort unto me when we parted: He knowes very well that all this is true, and that many times in tetimony of my good affection to him, I have put both him and my elfe in very great danger of life and honour. The truth is, I mut needs commend both him and his dicretion in this, that what opportunities oever I gave him, and what favours oever I hewed unto him, he never offered to go beyond the limits of honety: and though I believe, he thought that I would not uffer him, yet I am much obliged unto him, in that he never gave me any caue to repent of my kindnes to him.

Living thus in the flow of contentment, though I was in continuall feare let the King hould come to know of this good will: and let that hould give him occaion to change, as he had already done to the diadvantage of others; I oberved that there was many great Ladies, who to enjoy the favour and poeion of this Prince, whether it was out of a deire of the Glory to command him, whom o many millions obeyed; or out of a piring hopes to obtain a Crown, I cannot tell; but they were very aiduous in prucing themelves up in hopes to be pleaing in the Kings eye. Amongt the ret, I oberved
two; the one was called Clarinta, and the other Adelonda: As for Clarinta, I mut needs confee I never aw a fairer, nor more meritorious of love, having all the amiable qualities that are deirable. In the firt place, Envy it elfe could not find the leat tittle of a defect in her face; he had a hand, no eye ere aw a fairer nor better proportioned; her tature was tall, traight and lender, and the Majety of her mind was uch, as if he were borne purpoely to weare a Crowne, as many of her Ancetors formerly had done: And to make her Charmes the more inevitable, the Univere had not a finer wit, the rayes of which hined in all her actions: but epecially her peech was o infinitely charming, that not to be taken with her, there was no other remedy, but not to ee and heare her. To be briefe; I mut confee, that were I a man, I had devoted my elfe her adorer, what treatment oever had I found; and woman as I was, I was never atisfied but when I aw her, and was with her, although o many perfections and merits gave me ufficient caue to hate her, becaue of the deigne which I had, and the pretenion which I know he had.

As for Adelonda, truth is, he was faire, but not comparable to Clarinta; neither in beauty nor merit; and moreover, being married, he could not have the apiring pretenions of the other o as though I was not troubled much to ee Eurick carrae her, yet the other gave great guts of upition; and therefore I reolved to divert the mind of the King firt from her, and afterwards at more leiure from Adelonda; epecially when I aw that he went ometimes unto her. And though at the firt he feigned that he did viit her, not out of love, but only honour; yet afterwards his viits were ofter than uuall, and he hid them from me, as much as he could. I quickly oberved this my elfe beides thoe pies which I had continually about the Prince, did preently advertie me of it. After I had well conulted with my elfe upon the bet remedy againt this torm; at lat, I bethought me of Alcidon, thinking that if he would econd me in it, my deigne might happily proper. And becaue the matter required preent expedition, the firt time I had an opportunity of talking with him alone, I ued this language.

Alcidon, I am unreolved whether or no I hould impart a buinee unto you, which troubles me more than I am able to expree, fearing leat the affection which you beare unto me, hould make you take my words otherwie then I deire: and yet if you doe but conider how I have lived with you for the time pat, and what evident tetimonies I have given you of my good will, I am confident you will thinke that it is onely the neceity of our affaires which contraines me to deire a thing of you, which I have hitherto delayed. You know, how as my fortune is, all that looke upon me, are enviers of my happines; o as I mut tand upon my guard againt all perons who would if they could tep into my roome. The affection which you have promied unto me, and that which I bear unto you, does trongly invite you to have an epeciall care of me, but more of your owne conervation: For though none knowes of the great league that is betwixt us; yet few perons but know that you have beene ever well affected to me. Now Maxims of tate doe ay, that the fortune of the head ought to be communicated to the Members; o as your ruine is mot evident if mine befall me. I lay thee intances before your eyes, to the end you may not think that trange which I am contrained to propound for our preervation. You ee how Clarinta, whether relying upon the grandure of her parents, or building her deigne upon the foundation of her beauty, I cannot tell, but you ee how he endeavours to get the good will of Eurick, and which is wore, her labour, is not lot, for methinks that Prince begins to thinke her more amiable than I wih he did; you know how fleeting and alterable his mind is, and how hitherto none could make him fix.

If Clarinta hould compae her deigne, conider how he would banih us from Court, leat he her elfe hould fall into like confuion, wherein he has brought us. Therefore before things proceed any further we mut by way of prevention ue all the arts we can imagine for a helter againt this torm. To thinke of uing violence, and to force the wounded pirit of this Prince, would hew ignorance in thoe effects which love ueth at the beginning to produce, for nothing makes it greater than oppoition, like unto a coale which the wind makes blaze by blowing upon it. To thinke that diimulation will mend the matter, and in eeming not to know it, that time may produce ome good remedy, is very bad, and dangerous counell: For although Love which findes no oppoition may by little and little loe it elfe, and become nothing, yet as this cae tands, the danger will be inevitable; for love does never leen till after fruition: Clarinta cannot
be enjoyed till after the marriage; and after marriage though Eurick hould alter his affections, yet notwithtanding, he would be Queen of the Viigots, and we by conequence ubject unto her will, and liable to all her violences. So that upon erious conideration, I can finde no better remedy againt this menacing danger, than this which I hall propoe unto you, which once more I conjure you to take in a right ene, and not upon any other urmies than as I intend it. You cannot be ignorant how liberall the heavens has beene unto you in the gifts of Nature, and in accomplihing you every way above other men: you have had ufficient proofes of it in all your attempts: I make no doubt but if you would cat your flaming eye a little upon Clarinta he would preently melt at the charms of it, and unlee her heart be made of tone, he cannot avoid the amiable glances thereof; If you would put this my requet in execution, mot certainly he would love you, and preently reject Eurick and all his ambition; he would wholly devote her elfe unto you, or ele Eurick eeing his addree, and her entertainment of it, he will didaine her and retire: Thus hall we avoid a misfortune which does much threaten us; if you can tell me any better expedient, I beeech you propoe it, that we may make choice of the bet: I have long deferred the making of this over-ture, fearing leat you hould have an opinion, that I propoed it as a way to rid my elfe of you, though my intention onely is, that we may live together for the future in more contentment and afety.

This was the language I ued unto Alcidon, o plainly demontrating my intention unto him, as I could not imagine that he hould be dicontented at it, or upect that I had any other aime then what I told him: yet for all my aurances of the contrary, and mauger all my reaons and arguments, he was perwaded that my deigne in this motion was, to et him further from me, and then to comply more freely with great Eurick. After a long muing ilence, and fixing his eyes upon the ground, he looked up, and with a mile which poke his dicontent, he anwered me; I wih, Madam, that I could erve you in this according as you deire: and indeed I will, for your deire is to me a mot full command: but my heart tells me, that a great misfortune will take original from this command; yet obey it I will, not out of any hopes I have in thoe favours which you ay the heavens have o liberally indowed me withal, but onely to let you ee that I will obey you in all things as long as I live. Oh Heavens! cannot the King be contented in the happinee of your love, but he mut needes make me entirely mierable? Oh Alcidon, hat thou a heart that can upport thee injuries of fortune? But why hould I not endure them, ince the faire Daphnide commands it o: then turning towards me with abundance of reverence, Yes, yes, Madam, aid he unto me, I will doe as you command me, though it cot me a life, and all manner of contentment.

Upon this, he would have gone away, but I held him by the arme, and after a econd urging of my Arguments, and adding the bet motives I had, I deired him, that though our ruines would be inevitable if not prevented; yet if it went o much againt his minde, that he would not attempt it, for no misfortune whatoever would be more grievous unto me then his dipleaure: but till if he would allow of reaon, he would plainly ee that he was erronious, in having any uch opinions, and that he did exceedingly offend me in entertaining them. Madam, aid he, If I doe offend you in it, I will preently doe my penance in obeying your command; and o as I am confident you will pitty me for it, but I pray heaven your pitty come not too late: yet I am o entirely ubmiive unto whatoever is your will, as I protet obedience unto whatoever you hall command; and doe not believe that I will faile in it, further then my power fails me: and though you doe ee me make a little doe at your command, yet I beeech you thinke that it proceeds from no other caue, then from my abundance of affection, which cannot endure to heare of the leat thought of any eparation from you; or that I am able to make any addrees of love unto any whomoever but your elfe, unlee it be under a guie of diimulation, and that too with inufferable paine unto me. Alcidon, aid I then unto him, I am not now to begin the knowledge of your affection to me, nor of your merits, to have my reciprocall love: but I pray you believe, that unlee death doe very uddenly urprie me, I hall in ome ort come out of your debt, and pay my mot due acknowledgements, for any thing I either have or hall receive from you. And that you may more clearly ee the end I aime at, I doe promie you, Alcidon, and wear by the great God who puniheth all fale Oathes, that all the paines you hall imploy in the Courthip of Clarinta, hall be put upon my core and account, and that it hall be my
elfe who will pay you your wages. Methinkes that if Alcidon did love me, thee expreions would content him; and yet I perceive this enterprie goes againt his heart, and he will attempt it, onely becaue he will not diobey me But o it was, that in obervance of his promie to me, he reolved upon it and according to his bet dicretion, he began this addree, in which truly he found more difficulty then we imagined, and much more had met with, if fortune had not removed ome great impediments, by an encounter which I hall relate unto you.

div.head: The Hitory of the Artifice of Alcires.
div.p: IT is eaie to be imagined, that Clarinta being uch a captivating beauty, and brought up in a Court full of generous young Gallants, was not long without many ervants: Amongt the ret, there was two who under an umbrage of Conanguinity, had ininuated themelves highly into her favour: The one was called Amintor, and the other Alcires, both of them indeed very valiant and amiable Cavaliers. And who, if I be not mitaken, did imbarque themelves at firt into the affection of this beauty, under the notion of friendhip; a ubtilty very ordinary and often ued by love, the better to urprie thoe who are of harder tempers to give it entertainment, Beides the kindred which was between thee two Gallants, their long education together, the conformity of exercies unto which they addicted themelves, and their concurrency in age did unite them in a trong league of friendhip, and adopted them brothers in matter of Armes, and to weare amity and aitance of each other: But love which never admits of any companion, did make a fraction in this league of friendhip, as hereafter I hall relate unto you. Fire cannot be o hid, but ome moak will appeare, but I believe it is a matter more hard to cover love long, epecially from thoe who have any interet in it. And therefore Alcires finding that Amintor did thrive in his addrees better then himelfe, and eeing all jut wayes would not avail him, he reolved to have recoure unto ubtilty, thinking that, o he could overcome, all wayes are allowable in Love.

It is uuall amongt perons of any quality, to make choice of one amongt their ervants, whom they make a confident, and trut uch a one more then any other: Clarinta made choice of one amongt her maids, whom he loved very well, and truted with her mot intimate ecrets. Alcires, who knew what prevalence uch ervants ue to have with their Mitrees, had long before hand courted the good will of this wench; and being a brave Gallant, and very liberal, he got himelfe o farre in her favour, as he could mould her into a model: o as when Amintor and he met together at the faire Clarinta's, he would alwaies yield place unto him, and entertaine this wench who tood a ditance from them: And when he aw Amintor look upon him, he would alwaies have ome ecret to whiper in her eare and mile, doing all he could to make Amintor enter into ome upition.

Amintor oberving this, as the nature of lovers is, he preently upected that this familiarity betwixt them proceeded from ome greater caue then from that wench, and perhaps from ome deign which Alcires had upon the Mitree. Amintor being a man of a free open heart, and one that could not long mother his thoughts from a friend, one day meeting with a fit opportunity, he aid thus unto him: Good Alcires, what buinee of importance could you have with Clarinta's maid, which made you o earnet with her as you eemed? Alcires eeing his plot began to take, did at firt anwer him onely with a mile and afterwards, would you have me tell you? aid he, you doe o wholly take up the Mitree when you are with her, as I being all alone, am forced to take up with what you leave me, the maid: But heretofore, aid Amintor, you were not wont to doe thus, and I am no more a taker up of the Mitree, then I was wont to be; what new mood has of late poeed you? Alcires paued a while before he anwered, and then looked upon him with a ubtile mile; at which Amintor was more troubled then before, and eeing that he poke not a word; Why, aid he, doe you not give me an anwer: have I any interet in your familiarity with her? if I have, I pray let me know it, that I may hare in your mirth. Alcires then, etting a more erious face upon the matter: Amintor, aid he unto him, Although there was no ligaments of Conanguinitie us, yet as I am your friend, you may eaily believe, that I will impart any thing
unto you; and the very truth is, I had long ince acquainted you with what you deire to know at this time, had I not feared your digut of it; and this conideration will till top my mouth, unlee you aure me of the contrary. I will not give you that aurance, aid he, if you tell it with an intention of dipleaing me; but if you tell it with an intention that I may prevent any inconveniency, I hall think it a very great obligation. If you will promie me, aid Alcires, to ue it with dicretion, and to take well the advertiement which I hall give you, onely with intention to bring you forth of a great error, I am very ready to tell it you, as your kinman, and as your friend: but otherwie I hall not; for unlee you make good ue of it, it may doe you much hurt. Then Amintor making that promie unto him, Alcires went thus on: Know Amintor, that after a long Courthip of the faire Clarinta, I propered o well, that he is intirely mine, aad I have enjoyed her. Oh Heavens! aid Amintor, doe you know what you ay? have you enjoyed Clarinta? Yes, yes, aid Alcires, I have enjoyed her, and therefore et your heart at ret; for he is o much mine, as very few nights pae, but I am with her, and therefore you ee I hun her company as much as I can, purpoely to deceive inquiitive eyes, as he deired me. Oh ye Gods, aid Amintor, and lifted up his hands; Oh heavens! will you not punih her? I aure you, aid Alcires, that I had a longing deire to acquaint you, becaue I was extreamly orry to ee you o deceived: but as I told you before, I much feared that it would vex and dipleae you. Amintor upon this folded his Arms, and tood ilent a long time; at lat aid thus, I hould be extreamly angry with you Alcires, for ravihing Clarinta from me, did I not know that when we both courted Clarinta, we had no deigne of deceiving one another: for as thoe who run for a prie, though many run, yet onely one can win it: o I have no reaon to be angry with you for winning Clarinta from me; but rather, I have reaon to thanke you for telling me, that I may run on no longer in an error: only one thing wants, which would um up my obligation, and which I conjure you unto; which is, that you will atisfie my eyes in the truth of this, as well as you have done my eares. I hall give you as good atisfaction as I can, anwered Alcires, but I am afraid it will onely feter your wound the more, and be a greater dipleaure unto you. No, no, replyed Amintor, it cannot more dipleae me, but will rather encourage my reolution to doe as I ought: Alcires eemed to be a little puzled at this quetion, but he foreaw it, and therefore prepared himelfe for it from the firt: Truly Amintor, aid he, I know not well how to atisfie the nice curioity of your eye; for I have a good deire to give full contentment, yet I am afraid it will be abinee of difficulty to get you into her Chamber, becaue it is not every night I go unto her, but onely when the opportunity falls hanomly out for it, which he cannot let me know of, until every one be in bed: beides, I know how to get in, but you will be een. Nay, nay, aid Amintor, I deire not to go o farre, I had the ame conideration with my elfe; It will atisfie me, if I can but be with you, and ee when your elf go into her Chamber. If that be enough, anwered Alcires preently, you hall be fully atisfied, and perhaps this very night if you tay in my Chamber: then Amintor promiing he would, they parted in this reolution.

See, age Adamas, unto what impotures we women are ubject unto, by the example of this wie and faire Lady, who though he was clearly innocent, yet by the calumny of Alcires, was deemed as culpable by Amintor. He went and waited with a longing impatiency, untill the crafty Alcires came and called him: Alcires in the interim hoping to compleat his plot, which he had thought was well begun, and having long before reolved upon this way; the time being come when every one went to bed, he came to Amintor, and told him he would conduct him to the promied place. The King who tooke great delight in bring amongt Ladies, had lodged Clarinta, Adelonda, and me, in his Palace, pretending it as a great honour unto us: Clarintas quarter was a ground Chamber near the Court, and had onely three or four teps unto it: from oft the halfe part of thee little taires, one might go into her Chamber everall wayes; through one doore, one came into a great Dining room, and a drawing room, out of which was a paage through a little dark Gallery, which conducted into her Cloet by a back door; and here it was where Clarinta commonly lay; and if one would go further without going into her Cloet, they needed onely to open a door cloe by, through which they came into a great Chamber that conducted out of the Palace, by a Gate very eldom frequented.

Alcires having long before hand oberved thee things, he conducted Amintor into
his little dark Gallery, where taying without any light when all were in bed, he aid uno him; you hall ee Amintor, that as oon as I knock at the Cloet door, it will be opened unto me but I beeech you according to your promie, return as oon as ever you ee me entred in: then leaving him ome five or ix paces from the door, he eemed to goe unto it, but went unto the other which paed into the great Chamber, and which being o neare Clarintas Cloet, Amintor could not ee the great difference; then after Alcires had tayed a little while, he returned unto Amintor, and whipering him in his eare, told him that they were come a little to late, for all were aleep, but yet he heard them riing: but I beeech you o • ce more, aid he, that when I am entred, you may goe away as oftly us you can, and in the mean time tand a little further off let when the door opens and a Candle come, you hould be een. Amintor did o, little dreaming of his ubtilty, which was onely to get him further off the Cloet door, let he hould ee the difference of the Doores: Alcires then going as gently as he could unto this door, he opened that which paed into the great Chamber, and preently hut it after him; for the pring lock was made after uch a fahion, as it would hut of it elfe, and Alcires having oberving it, he came a little before, and had left it half open. Amintor hearing it open, and hut preently againe, did verily believe that it was Clarinta's Cloet doore; and probably any other, beides him, might have been deceived, the doores being o neare each other, and the place o darke but for better aurance, he went and laid his eare to the doore, and hearkned if he could heare any talke, or any noie; but whether it was that the noie which Alcires made, had wakned ome in Clarinta' •
Chamber, or whether it was his owne imagination which made him thinke o; yet o it was, that he had an opinion he heard a noie, which tranported him into uch a fury, as he was ready to breake the doore open with his foot; but thinking upon the promie he had paed unto Alcires, and the kindred between them: alo conidering into what a confuion he hould put all the houe into, he had o much power over himelf as to forbeare, and go away, but o vexed as he could not ret all the night. On the other ide, Alcires having play'd his part o well thus far, and fearing let Amintor hould look for him at his Chamber, he would not go unto it, nor unto any other place where any one might ay the next day that they aw him, and there paed all the night away in a grotto of the Garden, whereof he had got the key: judge you into what a perplexity he put Amintor, and how prudently warie a Lover ought to be in avoiding the artifices of a Rivall. The dipleaure of this Cavalier was uch, as not being willing to declare it unto any, he was contrained to keepe his bed, and murmur away the time againt a malady, without looking for any remedy; of which Clarinta being advertied by common reports, and being ignorant of his dieae, her love to him forced her unto a viit; and he found him o full of orrowes, that he could hardly look upon her, which he attributed unto the greatnee of his malady: but going another time to viit him, and till finding him more melancholly and cold then at the firt time, he could not chue but ay thus unto him; Is your icknee Amintor, o extream, that it does not onely make a change in your face, but in your humour alo, which is o much different from what it was wont to be, that indeed you are not knowable? Ah Clarinta, anwered he and ighed, how happy had it been for me, if this alteration had come ooner? he tood atonihed at this anwer; and when he would have continued dicoure, his Phyitians came unto him, o as he durt not make any further replies; but after a little longer tay, he went away, the wort atisfied peron in the world: in the meane time, Alcires to loe no time in the econding o good a beginning, and to comply with all occaions that preented themelves, he grew more kinde and familiar with Amintor then before, and kept himelfe o contantly near him, as it was impoible for any to peak with him, and he not heare. For knowing very well that his dieae proceeded from depaire principally, he was loath any hould undeceive him, or let him know the truth. But becaue he had not yet accomplihed his chiefe worke, but thought it neceary that as he had deceived Amintor, o to deceive Clarinta alo, purpoely to make her fly from him, as he fled from her: one day therefore when he was with his companion alone in his Chamber, he made a hew as if he would write omething which was of ome importance; but as if his fancy was not pleaed with what he writ, he raced out ometimes a word, and ometimes a whole line; and at lat, as if he were angry at the dulnee of his genius, he tore the paper in pieces, and flung away the Pen; at which Amintor miling, and wondering at it, he asked him, why he did o?
I aure you, anwered he, that my wits are off the hinges this day; This morning the King commanded me to write a Letter of thankes unto a Lady, for ome favour which he had done him, and to carry it to him when I had done, that he might trancribe it; but my genius is o dull to day, that I am not able to write one ignificant yllable to the purpoe. Amintor loving Alcires, and knowing that Eurick ued to imploy his friends ometimes in uch Commiions, whom he thought had a happy faculty in penning; he would try whether his malady would permit him to write this Letter for his friend, and taking his cribled Paper out of his hand, the better to hint him upon the ubject, he writ thee Lines.

div.head: Amintors Letter in the name of King Eurick.
div.p: IT is, Madam, by the grandure of my affection, that you have meaured the favour which I have received from you: but by what rule can I quare and equall the thanks which I owe unto you for it? it mut needs be by ome rule that is infinite, for uch is my will to doe you ervice, which I beeech you to receive, as from a peron who loves you above all the world, and thinkes himelfe the mot obliged peron in it.

Alcires did deire no more, but that Amintor hould write uch a Letter upon this ubject, not with intention to give it unto the King, as he pretended; but to effect another deigne which he had plotted in himelfe; he much commended therefore the acutenee of his fancy, and his facility of expreion; then thanked him for it, and put it in his pocket: after this he went away, pretending to trancribe it in his Cloet, where he was to doe uch things. By fortune, the rude Copy which he firt writ, remained upon the Table, which the poore ick Amintor laid up in a little drawer where he was wont to put uch Papers, without any other deigne but that it might not be een. Alcires in the mean time, ealed the Letter, but gave it no upercription, and went to Clarinta, taking a time when he thought to find her alone. Two dayes were already expired, ince the lat time Clarinta did viit Amintor, and ince he returned o ill atisfied; and though he was very deirous to know why Amintor hould peake in that manner unto her; yet he durt not goe againe o oon, let he hould thereby give occaion of candal: And now eeing Alcires, alo knowing what familiarity there was betwixt them, and not being ignorant that Alcires loved her as well as Amintor; yet he could not chue but aske him how he did? Alcires, eeming as if he did not know that his friend loved her, did anwer her very coldly: I believe, Madam, he is very well; for he is of late o jocond and merry, as it is not likely he will long keep his Chamber, ince all the Phyitians ay that the caue of his malady was exceive orrow: I believe, aid Clarinta, that the Phyitians aid truly; but if he be o jocond as you ay, he is much changed ince I aw him; for the lat time I was with him, he could carcely open his mouth to give me a word. I know not, aid Alcires, when it was you aw him, but I am ure that never man looked with a more contented face, then he did yeterday morning; and it was not without good reaon, if he who obtaines his deires has any reaon to be contented, I beeech you Alcires, aid he preently, let me know what it is which caueth him o much contentment, that as his Couen and friend, I may participate in his joyes. Madam, replyed he, I hould willingly obey your command, but that I know very few women who can be ecret; and hould he ever come to know it, I hould quite loe his friendhip, which I value at a very high and deare rate. I mut confee, aid he, that I am a woman but none of thoe who you ay cannot keep a ecret, having ever made a contant profeion not to peak of any thing which I promie to conceal, as at this time I weare and protet I will: Upon this promie, aid he, I will tell it you, but upon a condition that you hall not by your overaigne power over me, urge me to tell more then I am willing to impart: I aure you (aid he) that I will not: Know then, replyed Alcires, mot craftily, that poor Amintor is ecretly become deperately in love with one of the prime and fairet Ladies in all the Court; and loving her extreame paionately, he reolved to try how her pule did beat in good will towards him: but finding himelfe not not o happy as in his hopes, he reented it o adly, that he fell ick, and fell into uch trange fits of melancholly, as there are very few perons but that ghee her to be the onely
caue of it. Of which this faire one being advertied, was moved unto o much compaion as to viit him: and ince finding the grandure of his affection, he gave him o much caue of contentment, as before he did of depaire Do not expect, Madam, that I hould tell you who it is, unlee you can gues at her by the effects which I hall relate: but o it is, that this very morning he hath a writ a Letter unto her, and made me his confident to carry it. Clarinta hearing this, and being infinitely urpried at it, he could not chue but bluh extreamly; and becaue he would not have Alcires ee her, he held her Hankercher before her face, and asked him who that kind Lady was, till keeping her Hankercher cloe to her face: This is it Madam, aid Alcires which you promied not to urge me to reveale; but to give you full aurance of what I ay, though the Letter be ealed, yete will break it open and hew it unto you, then he opened it, and preented it unto her She who knew it very well to be Amintors hand, as oone as ever he cat her eye upon it, and therefore beleeved all that Alcires aid: he read it with a trange perturbation of pirit, which till made her more and more deirous to know unto whom thee thankes was directed. Will you not tell me Alcires (aid he unto him) unto whom this good language was written? Madam, aid he, I hould have named her unto you at the firt, had I not taken o deepe an oath to the contrary, as it is horror unto me to thinke of breaking it: but let it uffice you that he is one of the fairet Ladies in all the Court I beleeve it, aid Clarinta, ince you ay it: but for all her beauty, let me tell you that he is very kind: And ince you will not tell me her name, for want of other revenge he hall never have the contentment of reading this Letter: Then out of pite, he tore it in everall peeces. Alcires eemed to be hugely angry at this and would have hindred her, although it was the leat of his cares: at lat, eeing there was no remedy, he was pacified: I will tell him, aid he, that as I pulled my Handkercher out of my pocket it fell into the Fire and was burned before I ever tooke notice of it, but if he will write it, I will carry another.

Could he poibly ue more ubtilty to break of friendhip and love on both ides than he did? And it had uch operation in them both, that Clarinta being deceived by this Letter, and Amintor by his owne eyes, they were both o ill atisfied with each other, as they longed for an opportunity of meeting to upbrald themelves mutually with infidelity: But upon better thoughts Clarinta he reolved to ee Amintor no more, and Amintor, he would not as he ued, end any more to viit her; and all this did but the more confirme them in thoe opinions which Alcires had infued into them.

Now Reverend Father, be pleaed to oberve how eaily Fortune can when he will, facilitate the way unto her Favorites to bring about their deignes. I have inited omething long upon the ubtilties of Alcires, and dicontents of Clarinta, that you may thereby the better undertand, how Alcidon to effect my requet unto him, came to be in favour with Clarinta: for it is mot certain, that without this diention he had very hardly compaed his deigne; but as he was ever happy in all his attempts, o he was no lee in this encounter.

Alcidon would very faine have palliated his infidelity with words; and though I was ilent when he poke, and eemed the firt time he came unto me to take no notice of any thing; yet I know very well that he had other affections in him than unto me; and without going any further, I was fully informed that Thorimond being dead, and when Thierry his Brother aumed the Crowne, then did he ee Clarinta in one of the Aquitane Cities, and loved her; and if I would, perhaps I could tell him both the time and the place; but it will uffice that his owne oule knowes this to be true. And becaue Alcidon eemed to deny what he aid; Nay, nay, Alcidon, aid he, never deny the truth; you know that what I ay is true; And that a little after the accident of Damon and Madonthe, Thorimond dying and Thierry ucceding him, you followed him in his Voyages, and at the eige of a City, you aw that Lady, in whoe ervice you had continued longer, if Thierry had not dyed almot as oone as he was King, and being ince much imployed by the great Eurick in everall enterpries, you forgot Clarinta, as you did me. Come, come Alcidon be content • d; if I would, I could relate, not onely the beginning and progree of this affection; but perhaps alo o many particulars of your life, as will make you amazed.

I peake this, wie Adamas, not to upbraid his incontancy; for I know that his age would not then permit him to be more contant; but my drift is onely to let you undertand
that it was much lee paines to him to make his affection knowne unto that Lady. I do not deny, aid Alcidon, and interrupted her, but that at the time you mention, I did ee Clarinta, and that her beauty did at the firt bluh ravih me, by an unexpected encounter: For at the eige of a Towne, there being an intermiion of Armes, I went up to the wals to fetch off ome Souldiers who lay a little too neere: There I epyed this Lady upon the battlements, peaking unto one of our Army whom he knew: I mut needs ay, that as oone as I aw her, I admired her, and that he had then like to cot me my life, For the Truce being ended whilt I was gazing upon her, I took no notice how Arrows flew about as thicke as hailetones, which thoe of the Towne did hoot at me I remember her dree was an embleme of death, for he was then in mourning for her Father, o as the ight of her was almot mortall to me in that kind: but I will never confee that this did ever make me falle in my duty to you, and you doe me mot manifet injury if you ay otherwie. We will beleeve what you pleae, aid Daphnide, but Alcidon, this time in which I commanded you to peake unto her of Love was not the firt time you aw her, and therefore accee was more eaie unto you. Yet at the firt, he knowing of the paages betwixt us, becaue the King himelfe had told her, he did much reject his addree: For you mut know, Reverend Father, that the great Eurick deiring to ininuate himelf into her favour, did let her undertand, that all the addrees which he made unto me, were onely in the behalfe of Alcidon, whom he told her was paionately in love with me.

This Cavalier being very deirous to overcome this fair one he would not be repuled upon the firt denial. But one day, when Eurick was walking upon the banks of Rone, and the better to pae away his time, had invited many Ladies, amongt which Clarinta and I were; I oberved how Alcidon accoated her, and how after he had talked a while with her, he gave a paper unto her, which he tooke, and tore in peeces, and without reading it threw it into the water. I could not then heare what he aid unto her, or what he anwered, becaue they poke very low, and I was very farre off. But Alcidon told me ince, that he aid thus unto her.

Doe not thinke it trange Madam, I hould in this place try whether I can obtaine that which I could not in another; I meane the honour and happinee of your favour: For being alwayes unfortunate, when I begged it upon the Land, I will try whether the element of Water will prove more favourable unto me: And becaue when I looked upon you, my oule was o wholly in my eyes, as my tongue forgot its function, and I could not peake, therefore I preent my hearts humble deires unto you in this paper, which I would, but cannot peake: Upon this, he preented it unto her, and he fearing that if he did refue it, many might take notice of it, he tooke it, and aid thus unto him: You have reaon Alcidon to thinke that this element will be more favourable unto you than the other, if it be true that every thing favours its like; for your incontant humour does not at all reemble the Earth, but the Water very much, which ebbs and flowes, and is never till. And to hew you that I am of the ame judgement, I will betow upon it this paper, in which you ay you have writ your deires, to the end it may grant your requets, auring my elfe that you being as incontant as it, it will favour you, as much as poible it can: Upon this he tore the paper all in peeces, and without reading it, threw it into the Water. Oh Madam (aid Alcidon to her, triving to tay her arm) can you thus depie the mot pure affection that ever was offered unto you? Are you not contented, unjut beauty that you are, to burne my heart by the flames of your eyes, but you mut alo drownd all my deires in this Water before you ee them? You doe me wrong replyed he, in accuing me of injutice, ince I make my elfe appeare to be mot equitable in detaining nothing of anothers, and in rendring unto this element, which is o incontant, the thoughts and conceptions of the mot incontant heart in the whole Univere.

Whilt this Cavalier and Clarinta were thus talking, the King was dicouring with me; yet I was not o attentive to his talke, but till I had an eye upon Alcidon, auring my elfe that Clarinta by ome action or other would give me ome light of what he aid; and to the end that the King hould take notice of them, I fixed my eyes upon them, and would not anwer him: And he pulling me by my arme, as if he would wake me out of a leepe: I am awake Sir, aid I unto him, pray ee what I am oberving; then I hewed
<>
Clarinta and Alcidon, and as fortune was, jut at the ame time when the Cavalier
gave her the Letter, o as he aw how he tore it, and threw it into the water, of which I was very glad, to the end he might take notice of this new Love; knowing very well, that in uch matters as thee, you need onely make them ee a little, and let jealouie alone to make up the ret.

Since this day, Alcidon followed his enterprie o cloe, that the faire Clarinta thinking this would be a fit meanes to gaine Eurick, and to make Amintor lament the loe he had of her, he eemed to incline unto him; I ay eemed, for indeed he was then fuller of Ambition then Love; and therefore he aimed at Eurickes love, and was vexed at Amintor, thinking he had left her for ome other; againt which, he thought her Carrae of Alcidon, might be very profitable unto her: For he knew very well, that to reduce an Apotate Lover, there was no better way then to make him jealous; and to get the affection of a King, no better artifice, then firt to get the favour of his favorites, as he knew this Cavalier to be one, to the end that they by their good words in the cure of their mater, might induce him unto love: beides which, he had as he thought, an example of this in me, whom he knew Alcidon favoured; and he thought that I was advanced unto the Kings favour by this meanes. Upon thee coniderations therefore, he began to hearken unto this Cavalier, and to conferre ome kind of triviall favours upon him, of which I was very glad, thinking that when the King aw it, he would according to his humour, be extreamly offended at it: and when I could talke unto Alcidon in private, I till olicited him to engraciate himelfe further into her favour, and to court her as much as he could in the ight of King Eurick, which he did o effectually, that not onely the King, and Amintor, but almot all the Court took notice of it, though neither Clarinta nor Alcidon, had at the firt any aimes of making themelves loved in good earnet, but onely as conducing to their everall deignes, which could not be accomplihed had they kept their amities in ecret; becaue all the effects which they hoped for, was to proceed from the knowledge which others were to have of it.

They continued thus a long while, during which, Amintor till inveighed againt the affection which he bore unto Clarinta; his generous oule not being able to conent, that his heart hould ever love one, who as he thought had o baely betrayed him. On the other ide, he who thought that he had more reaon to hate him, for o unworthily cating her off, although he eemed not to care a ruh for it, yet her oule was o extreamly nettled with pite at it, as though he was not able to find revenge o oon as he deired, yet he could not defend her elfe from extreame adnee, which in her face did dicover that dicontent, which her heart would have concealed: And as a now-ball growes bigger for being rowled in the now, o this her dipleaure being joyned unto other vexations, whereof the life of man is very fertile, together with ome indipoition of her body, he was brought into uch a condition, as he was contrained to keep her bed, where all her patime was to igh and lament.

Amintor was preently advertied of it; for by reaon of their affinity, both their dometiques had much familiarity together. But this was not enough to appeae the offended pirit of that Cavalier. It happened, that this faire one growing every day wore and wore, he was told one night that he was o very ill, as it was feared he would not live until the morning. Thus farre he had held out; but hearing talke of death, he thought it time to render himelfe, and therefore without more delay, he dreed himelfe by force, and though ick, yet crawling as well as he could to the lodging of Clarinta, he found her in bed, yet not in uch extremity as was reported. She who expected any viit ooner then his, and who was much offended at him, could not indure his preence without paine, thinking that he came to ee her onely to delude her more; and therefore he rowed up her elfe with a reolution to anger him as much as he could: And in order to this, after ome common dicoure, he asked him, what newes at Court: For, aid he, I keeping my bed as you ee me, I know nothing, but what out of pitty is told me. Madam, aid Amintor faintly, It is o long ince I was at Court, or in any place but my bed, as you mut not aske me for any newes: I came hither onely to ee you, and am very glad to find you in a better condition then I heard you were. Perhaps Amintor, anwered he, you were in hopes to finde me dead: No, no, Sir, I will not yet put you to the expences of mourning for me: And to hew that I am not, thankes be to God, in uch a bad condition, I will manifet to you, that my thoughts are quite another way; then putting her hand under her Pillow, he pulled out a Paper which he gave him; Here Amintor, reade
thee Lines which were writ upon thoe Flowers which you ee at my Beds head; & if you cannot gues at the Author, I will tell you who it is: Before I ever reade them, aid he, I am mot confident that I can name him; then opening the Paper, he began to read it.

When Amintor had read two or three lines, he paued a while: Well Sir, aid Clarinta unto him, what doe you thinke upon them? Hitherto, anwered he, I find nothing which makes me alter my opinion, except the hand, which indeed is not the ame I thought it; but perhaps it was writ purpoely to delude thoe that read it. I am ure, aid Clarinta, that you are mitaken; but read on, and perhaps you will know better, and your opinion will be quite confued. Then Amintor began to read again; and when he had read a line or two further; I cannot tell, aid he, whether that which followes may alter my opinion; but thus far I am till in the ame minde, and then he began to read out the ret. When he had done, he mued, and was much gravelled to imagine who hould be the Author: for at firt he thought upon Alcires, but the concluion put him quite out of that conceit: Clarinta eeing he could not hit upon it, and eeming to make great eteem of the Paper, he laid it in the place where it lay, and then turning towards him; I perceive Amintor, aid he, that you cannot find out the Author; but, I aure you, he is a peron who merits as good fortune as any about the Court, I mut confee, Madam, anwered he, that thee lat lines doe put me out of my knowledge, unlee to diguie himelfe the more, he faigns to be lee favoured then he is. Why Amintor, replyed Clarinta preently, doe you thinke me o liberall of my favours, as to conferre them upon any one? this might erve uch a one unto whom you gave o many fine thanks; but if you have not forgotten the way of my living with you, when you made addrees to me, you may know that I am not a peron from whom any favours are to be expected. Oh Madam, anwered he, and ighed, I have but too good a memory of what you mention; But alas, my own eyes are uch certaine witnees, that I cannot give them the lye.
