Clarinta was very ill; but when he heard him ay o, he turned in a fury towards him; what can your eyes witnee, aid he, to my diadvantage? and becaue out of his repect unto her, he did not anwer, he continued; Nay, nay, Amintor, Never offer by your ilence, to cover your ill will unto me under a vaile of repect, content your elfe with your pat treaons, and doe o • excue them, by accuing me of your fault. Neither your eyes, nor the eyes of all men living, can tetifie any thing to my diadvantage; if they doe, they are unjut, and I hall look upon Amintor as the mot perfidious and ungrateful man alive. If ever I failed, Madam, aid he, in my honourr of fidelity which I owe unto her who accueth me of perfidy and ingratitude, I pray heavens this minute may be the lat of my life. But if you pleae, Madam, to give me leave, I will anwer to the quetion you asked me. Yes, yes, aid he in an angry manner, tell all you know; but be ure there be more truth in your words, then in your oathes. Madam, anwered he, your command is needlee, and this is truth it elfe, that I would not deire life, but to have the honour of doing you that faithful ervice which I have vowed: I doe impatiently deire to heare the end of your dicoure, aid Clarinta, that afterwards I may make you confee your elfe to be the mot ungrateful peron in the whole Univere; I hall prove it by your owne hand, unlee you have the impudence to deny it: Amintor, after a while of ilence, anwered thus; If you will pleae, Madam, to tell me what moves you to ue uch bitter termes and injuries againt me, I will atisfie your deire with a Protetation, that if I doe lye in any thing I ay, I will pray unto the Gods mot everely to punih me, before I tir from this place: but I mot humbly beeech you, to let your minde be at ret, until I have poke a little in my owne defence. When you hewed me the Paper, I believed the happy Alcires to be the Author of it; but when I found in the lat lines how he complained againt thoe Flowers, for enjoying the happinee he deired, and of which he was deprived; I preently altered my opinion, unlee it was o expreed purpoely to diguie the matter; for I have een him enter into your Chamber o eaily, that he could have no caue to wih for more permiion than he had. Oh ye Gods, Cryed out Clarinta, did you ever ee Alcires come into my Chamber in the night? Madam, anwered he, I have een him go in, and in the night; may the Gods never proper me, if thee eyes of mine have not een him do o: would any have thought, replyed he, that Amintors oule hould ever have been o wicked, as to jutifie a thing o fale, and to call the Gods for a witnee of it? I am orry, Madam, replyed he, that in my obervance of
your Commands, I hould be forced to a dicoure, which troubles you o much; but mot auredly I have een him goe in, and o ure I am of it, that unlee I had entred in with him, I could not be more ure. This, replyed Clarinta, is the mot impudent villany that ever was invented: And oh ye • ods that ue to protect the innocent, take my caue into your hands; make my innocence appeare, and punih thee impotors; afterwards addreing her elfe to the Cavalier: it is not a time, aid he, to diemble any longer; I will have this villany earched to the bottome, and the maske of it taken quite off: Life is not dearer to me than my honour, and death hall be evermore welcome to me than this Calamny and therefore Amintor peake cleerly, and tell me when, and how you aw Alcires come into my Chamber, otherwie I hall beleeve that all you ay is onely your own invention Madam, anwered he, Alcires is the man who unhoodwinkt thee eyes of mine, who when I would not beleeve what he aid, did let me ee the extraordinary favours you did him, and brought me to your very Chamber door to ee him enter, and upon this, he related unto her the whole tory of the buinee, both what he had eene, and what had paed between Alcires and him.

This poore Lady was o atonihed at this cunning Calumny, as he tood along time like a Statue, and was not able to open her mouth, at lat recollecting her elfe, and rouing up her pirits; is it poible (aid he) that any humane wit hould be o wicked, as you tell me Alcires is againt me, who never gave him any caue? Can the clemency of the gods be o great towards men, as not to chatie uch a damned villany? In the firt place, Amintor, I doe weare and protet unto you, that there is nothing in the world more fale than this impoture, and may the gods poure out the highet of their indignation upon me, if there be any part of this calumny true: in the econd place, I conjure you by our former friendhip, and by all thoe promies of good will unto me which you have vowed unto me, alo by the obligation of conanguinity betwixt us, that you earch out this wickednee to the very bottome, o as there may not remain in you or any that heares of it, the leat doubt of the truth: And upon this condition and no other, I will pardon the offence you have done me in beleeving uch fale and wicked things of me; And though I could clear the matter before you goe from hence; yet I deire for my atisfaction, that as Alcires and your owne eyes have deceived you, o I would have it them that hould undeceive you, you ay that he ued to come very often unto me: Looke, but looke well into the matter, and I am confident you will find he went ome whither ele. And yet, not to leave you long in o bad an opinion of me, I will let you ee that Alcires does not manage his villany with judgement; You told me that when he brought you to my Chamber doore, was the ame day that Eurick condecended unto Daphnides petition concerning a Prioner; I doe very well remember by a remarkable accident, that it was the fifteenth day of the Month of Mars: Now I would gladly have you heare the tetimony of all the ervants in my houe, before I peake with them, to the end you may know that God may permit innocency to be landered, but not oppreed; And it mut be confeed, that in this God hath hewed a particular protection, ince for more than eight dayes before, and more then eight dayes after the fifteenth day of the month of Mars, I did not lye in my Chamber, but in my Mothers, unto whom I went every night, by reaon of ome indipoition which he had.

If it be o, aid Amintor, than the villany is cleerly dicovered: You hall immediatly ee (aid he) that o it is: upon this, he called for all her maids, and in the preence of the Cavalier asked them, how long it was ince the lat time he lay in her Mothers Chamber, and how many nights he lay there; all of them tetified the very ame he had told, and did make the impoture of Alcires o plaine that Amintor was put out of all doubt.

This Cavalier hearing the concurrent Tetimonies of o many, he was o convinced of the truth, as he thought it abolutely impoible to be otherwie. And when all the women were retired, he aid thus unto Clarinta; I mut needs confee Madam, that the impoture of Alcires is very great, and containes two grand offences; the one againt you, & the other againt me; and becaue I am enible as well of my own error as his wickednes; I mot humbly beg a pardon for retaining uch an ill opinion of you, beeeching you to conider how cunningly this villany hath been carried, and how true love is alwayes apt to be jealous: When I have the happinee to obtaine this pardon, I hall then call Alcires to a trickt accompt for taining the reputation of Clarinta and for mot perfidiouly
betraying his friend Amintor by his ubtle impotures. Clarinta who till preerved ome parkes of good will unto this Cavalier, eeing him o ubmiively upon his knees before her, he kindly tooke him up, and cauing him to fit by her, with teares in her eyes aid thus unto him. Although Amintor, the ubtle villany of Alcires be very great and much beyond your crime; yet let me tell you that you are farre from being blamelee in beleeving uch things of me, having long before received o many tetimonies from me of the contrary: But when I conider your affection to me, I will lay the whole load upon jealouie, which is ordinary with thoe that love, and o pardon the fault upon two conditions; the one is, that ince Alcires ueth to come o often unto me in the night, you to follow him, o as you may know whither he goes, for certainly he comes not hither; in thus doing, perhaps you will dicover ome other haunts, which I hall be glad to know, that I may pay him in his owne Coyne, and doe him the dipleaure he intended to doe me: The other condition is, that you promie me not to reent this offence too deeply againt him; I know your courage is apt to call him unto atisfaction, and this I mut not uffer, becaue if you doe you will offend me more than he has; it would reflect much upon me, you would thereby make all the Court know that which is now onely knowne to your elfe; you know that a Calumny will blat a womans reputation and candals will pread themelves like aire into all eares. Madam (aid Amintor) this lat command goes omething hardly downe; and I beeech you conider, that though it be not in revenge of you, yet I am obliged to let this impotor know, that I am not a peron that can put up uch injuries: for reputation is o chairy and cautelous, as though none know any thing, yet if we our elves can uffer any indignity without reentment, we are not worthy to be called perons of honour; for a concience is as good as a thouand Witnees. Amintor, aid he unto him, I would have you doe this for my ake, and to conider with your elfes, that every Cavalier is obliged at much unto the honour of Ladies as their own; you know Amintor that you ought to have a care of mine, and ought not to doe any thing which may give it the leat taine. I will not intance by way of obligation upon you, the affection which heretofore you have promied unto me; for I now ee, that the power I have over you is but very little. Madam, aid Amintor, and interrupted her, to hew you that you never had more power over me than now you have, I will do as you command me, but till upon condition that you tell me, what the perfidie is whereof you accue me, and whether it arie from uch another originall as that of Alcires. I do beleeve, aid he, that it is poible to be o, yet your owne hand writing which I know very well, will hardly let me thinke you innocent. Then cauing a box to be brought unto her, he tooke out the torne paper which Alcires gave unto her, and giving one piece unto him, can you deny, aid he, that this is your writing? Amintor having looked well upon it; I mut confee, Madam, aid he, that this is my hand: Then aid Clarinta, when all the peeces are put together, they will hew you the perfidie whereof I accue you; for I confee the Letter was brought whole unto my hands; but when I aw my elfe o baely betrayed by a peron from whom I leat expected it, very pite and anger made me tear it thus in pieces. Amintor was o much amazed as he could not anwer; but he raiing her elfe up in her bed, and preading the pieces of paper upon it, he joyned them o together as he read unto him, that thankes which he gave for the extraordinary favour which he had received. Amintor calling to memory the time when he writ this Letter, and by what cunning he was induced to write it: I mut needs confee Madam aid he, that Alcires is the mot ubtle, crafty and pernitious man that ever breathed; tis true I writ this Letter, and gave it unto him onely as a Copy, and without any eale; and o he told the whole tory and truth of the buinee: but, aid he, I doe remember one thing which remains in my hands, and which confirmes, as you aid, that God never fails the innocent, for that will hew you the truth of what I tell you and therefore by your permiion, I will end for a little box, in which I put the paper that Alcires writ, when he intreated me to indite that Letter for him, according as he aid, the King had commanded him. By which you may plainly ee, that what I did was only at his intance, and without any concernment of my owne. Clarinta had a great deire to ift out the matter, and therefore deired him to end for this paper which being preently brought did cleerly tetifie the truth of what Amintor aid, which gave uch full atisfaction unto Clarinta (for he knew the hand of Alcires very well) as giving her hand unto Amintor, I aske your pardon wronged Amintor, aid he, for the ill opinion which I entertained of
you proteting for the future, that no Artifice whatoever, hall make me mitrut your affection. Madam, anwered Amintor, and kied her hand, I hall place this day in my Calender, as the happiet I ever lived, ince it has dicovered two things which would never have come to light by any other meanes: The one is, That it hath let me know how my own eyes have betrayed me: And the other is, That it hath let you ee, how I am till your mot faithfull ervant. Thee two happy encounter • doe o much t • nport me beyond my elfe, as I mut confee I have not words to expree my thankes unto you, and my good fortune; He would have continued, but he was prevented by the Kings coming in, who hearing how ill this Lady was, he came to viit her, almot all alone, let too much company hould diquiet her: and he came in upon uch a uddaine, as he urpried the pieces of the Letter which were upon the bed: As for Amintor, he had preently put his up; but Clarinta was o urpried at the Kings uddaine coming, and finding that Cavalier with her, as he forgot to put hers up: And the King pying them, laid his hand upon them o quickly, as he could not hinder him, and all her prayers were fruitlee to make him render it back again. But on the contrary, lapping it up very carefully in his Hankercher; and after he had talked with her a while, he retired himelfe to his Cloet, where putting the pieces of Paper into order, and aw the thankes which Amintor gave her, (for he knew it to be his hand) imagine you in what a cae he was. All Lovers are commonly jealous, but epecially this King; whether it was that he loved with great violence, or whether his generous courage could not brooke a Rivall; yet o it was, that this jealouie moved him to uch a hatred of this fair & wie Lady, as he did not content himelfe with telling this unto me, and hewing the Letter unto Amintor; but he blazed it abroad, and made uch a publique matter of it, as all the Court had talke enough upon that ubject.

Oberve, age Father, how this pettih god, whom they call Love, is pleaed to make himelfe merry with uch as erve him, I deired to break off the amity betwixt Eurick and Clarinta; and in order thereunto, I made ue of Alcidons love by way of gratification; and to the end I hould not be beholding to my own prudence, did raie up Alcires, who with a Letter which fell into the hands of the King, did doe the work for me. The drift of Alcires, was to take off a ervant from Clarinta, and by his ubtilty make her hate his Rivall, and quite contrary, the diatisfaction of Clarinta was the caue of her receiving Alcidon into her favour: And o Alcires, in lieu of one Rivall, found two. Alcidon on the other ide, who gave that Paper of Veres unto Clarinta, in hopes to obtaine her favour, he gave occaion to Amintor to be reconciled unto her, and to find out the knavery of Alcires. Alcires he got Amintor to write a Letter, with intention to make the faire Clarinta hate him by it; and this Letter quite contrary to his aime, did make himelfe out of favour: But the wort of all is, and which is the caue of my coming into this Country: I who aiming to make Clarinta loe a ervant, I gave her one, and deprived my elfe of him, to reigne him unto her; for Alcidon ince that time, has o wholly devoted himelfe unto her, that he is mine onely in his tongue, and hers in his heart. Oh the giddy and uncontant humours of men! There is nothing in the world will make them and their fleeting minds firm and table.

But this Cavalier, having begun a Courthip of this Lady, by my commands, he continued it according to his will; o as he may very well boat, that as I took one ervant from her, he has alo ravihed another from me, and with this advantage, that he loved Eurick onely out of ambition: but I did love Alcidon really and cordially: At the firt, I did not reent the loe, becaue I received extream contentment in being, delivered from that inquietude which Clarinta kept me in, till of late. But I did not long enjoy this ret, for it eems the heaven is pleaed I hould tread alwaies upon thornes; for I had no ooner enjoyed this happy victory, but I was forced to take up Armes againt a new enemy.

For Eurick being extreamly offended at Clarinta, but for ome great and prudent coniderations, durt not make hew of his reentments, he reolved to make her repent it, and through envy would chatife her, by conferring thoe favours on another, which might have been hers, could he have been contented to be onely his. And in order to this reolution, whereas before time his affection was divided amongt three; now his intention was, to place it all, at leat all his favours, upon one onely Mitres.

I told you before, that when I deired Alcidon to make addrees unto Clarinta, there
was another Lady whoe name was Adelonde, unto whom the King had made ome igns of goodwill. And now, in revenge upon Clarinta, he devotes himelfe, and all his favorable addrees unto her; he is now become his, and the Courts onely Idol; o as though her extraction was much inferiour unto Clarinta's or mine, yet uch was his deigne to preferre her before us both; o as I mut confee I was two or three times in a mind to break off quite with him: But Alcidon, by his wie advice, till diwaded me, and in this made me overcome both my elfe, the King, and her: o as I may well ay, that I doe owe all the contentments which I have ince received, unto him, and his patience.

Adelonde being now raied above all her hopes, he till raied her pretenions unto a higher pitch and though all the world did thinke the favours which this great Prince conferred upon her, to be very high, yet till her deires were higher. Thee inatible deires prompted her to make ue of all wayes, jut or unjut, eaie or hard, to accomplih them. And therefore, when ome of her friends advied her to ue ome charmes, thereby to retaine the wavering minde of this Prince, he hearkened unto them; Whereupon, he gave unto the Great Eurick, a bracelet of her haire, the lockets whereof were Lions, et with tones: Thee Lions had uch a quality, as whooever wore them about their arms, they could love none but her. Perhaps it may not be trange, that two uch puiant paions, as Love and Ambition, hould tempt her unto this Crime, had he reted here, and not add • d a econd, which indeed proceeded meerly for want of judgement: But he thinking that he would preerve them as precious Gemmes, and would weare them continually; or at leat, to make him do o, and not give them unto another: he told him, that a very learned Druid, who had a very particular care of him and his Crown, knowing what wicked attempts would be againt his life and tate, had made thoe Lions under uch Contellations, and with uch Art, that as long as he wore them about his Arme, no enterprie of his enemies hould have any effect againt him; but as often as any enterprie was attempted to his prejudice, thee Lions would advertie him, by cratching his Arm gently with their Clawes.

But ee, age Father, how the Heavens doe mock at thoe, who would compae their deignes by unlawful meanes. That which this Lady had taken o much paines about, to augment and preerve the affection of this great Prince unto her, was it which made her entirely loe it: For as oon as ever he perceived that he made ue of Charmes and Magick, he believed that all the inclinations he had unto her, proceeded from ome Divels, and not from her beauty, or any merit in her: and from that time did o extreamly abominate her, as he would never come neere her; and when he pake of her, he called her his Medea, and his Witch.

I have related this paage, Father, not as any way relating unto Alcidon, or me; but onely that you may better know the humour and pirit of the Great Eurick, and by that to judge whether I had not great reaon to preerve his good will unto me, by all manner of prudent ubtilty that poibly I could; and whether I had not as good reaon to impoe this task upon Alcidor.

Now, whatoever I hall relate unto you more concerning this great Prince, will not at all concerne the difference betwixt us; for ince that time, we lived together as we did before. The King he returned unto me with all manner of ubmiion and orrow, for offending a peron whom formerly he had loved. Alcidon, he • loved and courted Clarinta before my face, never rendring unto me thoe offices which the affection I had unto him merited, and which by the law of Fidelity he was bound to pay, had there beene any park of that virtue in him. As for me, I bore it out as well as I could, and preerved the Kings favours to me with all poible olicitations: o as I could with truth ay, that amongt all my cares, none was o great, as to ee this fickle Alcidon was not ahamed to erve that Lady in my very preence, after o many promies of affection and fidelity to me.

But, Father, why hould I talke any more upon this ubject, ince I now mut tell you of this great Princes death; and tell it I mut, ince, I owe it unto the memory of the greatet and mot generous Prince that ever raigned in Gaule. Now therefore, age Adamas, that the great Eurick finding the affection of Clarinta fickle, and that of Adelonda, full of foul practices, he thought mine onely worthy of himelfe; for he aw me keep uch a retired decorum in all my wayes, as he could not upect I loved any but himelfe, unlee it was Alcidon, of whom he could not entertaine the leat park of jealouie.
But calling all my actions into his memory, and how modetly I had tolerated his various affections and departures, and alo how weetly I received him at his returne, he came at length to that reolution which I deired, and declared that he would marry me, and make me Queen, as well of his Dominions, as of his heart and affections. Judge, Reverend Father, whether I and all my relations had not good reaon to deem our elves fully happy: But alas, I find too well, that the heavens are not pleaed to let a high happinee lat long: For when I was arrived at the very top of all my hopes, happinee and deires; when I had made all preparations of joy for the marriage, a cured Aainate being inpired with a hellih pirit, did ravih him from me by a fatall blow which he trayterouly gave him to the heart.

Oh Heavens! Can you uffer uch a horrid villany to pae unpunihed? mut not uch a Monter as this be made an eternall example of horrour to affright all men, if there be any o unnaturally wicked from uch a cured act? You may imagine in what a ad condition I was, when this fatall newes was brought unto me by the outcryes of the People: For my part I am not able to tell you how I tooke it; for I did not onely loe the ue of my reaon, but alo of my enes for a long time; for every one tooke me for dead. Oh happy had I been if it had been to; then hould I have buried all my orrows, & all my contentments would have followed him to his Grave. Upon thee words uch a flood of teares flowed in her eyes, as he was not able to peake of a long time; which gave a ufficient tetimony how deepely he reented her loe; but at lat, the wind of everall ighes drying up the raine of her eyes, he aumed her pirit, and continued thus.

Pardon I beeech you Father, the weaknee of a woman, for uch an occaion might perhaps excue a pirit of a higher temper than mine, did any reent them o neer the heart as I doe. But to pae over uch ad remembrances which cannot chue but be tedious unto you, and to fall into the dicoure where I digreed, give me leave to tell you, that whilt I was in the midt of laments, and could not find any ret or conolation to my ad oule; this cruell Alcidon, to loaden me with more miery, did preently quit Clarinta and comes impudently upon me, as if he had never let any other have a hare in his affection. I mut confee I was much amazed to ee him without bluh talke to me with as much confidence as formerly; but I was more offended at him for coming upon me o impudently, and never offering to aske pardon for the injury he had done me, and to talke to me of love and affection: For nothing under the Sun offends a woman more than after profeion of Love to quit her and love another. I permitted his dicoure a long while and gave no anwer: I beleeve he attributed my ilence unto the reentments of my loe; but eeing he continued on, my patience could hold out no longer, and therefore I was contrained to ay thus unto him. Alcidon let me intreat you to hold your peace, uch talke as this, is not now eaonable betwixt us; though heretofore it was permitted, yet now, ince both you and I are much changed from what we were, it is not allowable. He would have anwered, but I gave him the top, and aid unto him; Yes, yes, Alcidon, both you and I are very much altered: I in this, becaue heretofore I thought you had loved only Daphaide, and am now aured of the contrary: And you in this, that heretofore you devoted your elfe wholly unto me, and now the faire Clarinta onely poeeth you, and may he long and peacably enjoy her Conquet: I promie you Alcidon that I am o farre from envying her happinee, as I will pray the Heavens it may many ages continue: Alcidon was mightily amazed at this, and would gladly have jutified himelfe; but I was o certaine of the truth, as all his talke did rather move anger than love. Afterwards (for at that time he aw me o angry, as he could not put in a word) I left him in as angry a mood as I my elfe was: But the next morning he urpried me before I was dret; and by chance Carlis and Stiliana were then both in my Chamber, and they being very familiar with us, neither he nor I concealed any thing from them: He fell downe upon his knees, proteted that he would never rie, unlee I would promie him to heare his Jutification patiently, and then he would let me dipoe of his life and happinee as I pleaed. I, who was ufficiently loaded with misfortunes already, had no mind to adde unto them thoe dipleaures which I foreaw, but perited in my reolution not to hear him, knowing very well, that good wits never want good words to perwade what they will, epecially Alcidon, whoe eloquence I was not ignorant of, but was affraid he would incline me to imbrace that ervice, which had o baely quitted me for another.

At lat Carlis and Stiliana hearing our contet, they told me, that uch a Judge was unjut as would condemne a Party before he heard him. Mot true, my dear friends, aid I unto them; but did you know as well as I, what charmes his words have whom you would have me hear, you would advie me to top my eares, rather than lend them unto the inchantments of uch a Charmer as Serpents doe: But ince you will have it o, let me oblige you to ait me; which both promiing they would, he roe up, and knew o well how to plead his Caue, as they were both abolutely for him. And becaue I knew very well that all his eloquence was but oyled words and gilded language to gloze over his excues, without any reality of truth, I o farre reited him, as it was reolved upon by both ides to have recoure unto the Oracle, which returned us this anwer.
Upon a day, you'l ee
A Fountaine, in Forret
Called Loves Veritie
Will et your hearts at ret.

This Anwer, o obcure and full of ambiguity, none of us knowing the Country, nor ever o much as heard of the Fountaine of Loves Verity, it did much perplex us: And Alcidon to hew what a great deire he had that the truth of his affection might appeare, he made uch enquiry of this Fountaine, as hearing of it, he could not ret untill a Voyage unto it was reolved upon. I mut needs confee, Father, his importunity did much move me unto it; but one of the cheife reaons which induced me thereunto was my deire of being for a while abent from the place where I had o many ad Memorandums of my loe, hoping that being farre off them, my orrowes would by degrees leen: And unto this may be added my curioity of eeing whether that Country, and thoe who dwelt in it were o happy as reports went; for wonders were told me of the places beauty, of the weetnee of the Aire, the abundance of Rivers, full of Fih, and the pleaantnee of the Fields. But when I heard of the delectable lives of the Shepherds and Shepherdees of Loire, of Furant, of Argent, of Serane, but epecially of Lignon, I was ravihed, and wondered that all Europe did not go and inhabit in Forrets. To know therefore whether all this fame was true, I coneuted unto this journey: and becaue we heard that all thoe who are there were habited in the garbs of hepherds and hepherdees, alo deiring not to be knowne, we diguied our elves in this habit, as well for the reaons aforeaid, as becaue we needed not any great train of Servants to attend us.

Thus reverend Father, you have heard, not onely a relation of our lives pat, and of our difference, but alo the caue of our Voyage, and of our diguie; we want nothing now but your prudent direction, how we may ee and have addrees unto this Fountain, and your apient Counell unto uch as tand in uch need of it as we doe.

Thus ended the faire Daphnide, leaving Adamas in a great opinion of her Prudence and Wit; and becaue he perceived he expected his anwer, he replyed thus. Who is it Madam, that hath heard of great Euricke, and amongt the wonders of his Hitory does not admire the puiance that the beauty of Daphnide had over his oule? I beleeve that Ganges and Thyle have heard o much dicoure of it, as that your names are as well knowne here as in Gaule.

But I mut confee that preence which uually does diminih the opinion which fame gives of abent perons, does make it appeare that the opinion which I had of Daphnides beauty and merit was much below what I find to be true: I thanke the Gods for honouring my houe o much as to ee you in it, and hould be much more thankfull if I can be any way erviceable unto you For, and it is without any flattery, I was never more affected unto the ervice of Amais or Galathea, then I am unto yours, and I hall eteem ery day happy that gives me any opportunity to hew the truth of this: Let alo this my devotion extend it elfe very farre unto Alcidon: And as to the Quetion which you aske me concerning the Oracle, I can at preent ay no more but this; that it is impoible you hould receive that benefit which the Oracle promieth from the Fountaine, unlee ome trange and even miraculous things do come to pae: For Madam, this Fountaine as I told you before is indeed in this Country, and not farre from this houe, but Clideman and Gug • man procured a learned Druide to inchant it, and et uch guards upon it, as it is a thing impoible to attempt the eeing it by force: For it is perpetually watched
by mot fierce Animals; and uch Charms cannot be uncharmed, but by the death of the mot faithfull Male and Female Lovers in the world. What kind of Animals are they? (aid Alcidon): for to tetifie that I doe, and ever did love this fairet Lady, I am very willing to venture one.

If you can but finde, aid the Druid, and miled, the mot faithfull female, as it eemes you have the male, perhaps you may with the loe of your life, let the faire Daphnide ee this Fountaine: but I believe you will hardly finde a companion; and ince it is o, I advie you to leave off your deigne, and take my word that no humane wit or power can bring it to pae, but this way I have told you: It is guarded by two of the greatet and mot fierce Lions that ever any eye beheld, and two of the keenet Unicorns, which guard the entrance into this Fountaine, whilt the Lions go about to looke for their prey: As for the Unicornes they fed like Hores and Deer, upon Gras and Leaves. But it is mot trange, that thee Lions, though of a fierce and keen nature, yet never offer any harme, but unto uch as offer to enter into this Fountaine; in o much as the little Children feare them no more then they doe little Dogges; but if any doe approach neare a hedge which growes about the Fountaine, you hall ee the Lions grin with their teeth, and their eyes parkle; and alo the Unicornes prepare themelves in uch a fearful poture, as is mot terrible to behold: There is no thoughts therefore of any force; but in as much as I know that the Great Tautates is no lyer, and that by his Oracle he anwers you, that one day you hall ee the Fountaine of Loves Verity; It is very fit methinks, that we dicoure a little upon this ubject; for Oracles are never fale, but the interpretation of them does very often deceive us, becaue ometimes they mut be undertood according to the naturall word, and ometimes Allegorically: To come therefore to the interpretation of this: If one hould take it literally, and according to the word, it might be thought that the Inchantment of this Fountaine will quickly end, were it not for one word, which is, One day, which methinkes intimates as much, as if it were a thing farre off: for o we ue to ay, when we wih for any thing which we long for: And upon this conideration I ground, that the Oracle is perhaps to be undertood in another manner, which I thus interpret.

The proper quality of the Fountaine of Loves Verity, is to ee whether or no one doe truly love. Then any thing that can let us ee the ame thing, may upon the ame reaon be aid in that particular, to be the Fountaine of Loves Verity; that is, working the ame effects which this Fountaine doth; Now Time, Pereverance and Services, may doe the ame. It followes therefore, that Time, Services, and Pereverance, is this Fountaine of which we peak. And that which induceth me unto this opinion is this word, One day; For that denotes length of time, which gives occaions of doing ervice, and gives leaure to hew pereverance. To tell you why the Oracle did Allegorically peak rather of Forret in particular, then of the Roman Province, ince time may worke the ame effects there, as well as here, is a thing which I cannot doe: and yet ince there cannot be any thing uperfluous or defective in the Oracles which are the words of the Gods; I thinke this Country was made choice of for two repects: The one, becaue you hould be farre from your own Country, where your quality, your buinee, your kindred, friends and acquaintance, may o diturbe you, that the leat part of this time which hould be imployed to bring you unto this knowledge, is imployed as the Oracle commands; whereas being here free and without any contraint, the whole time is your own. The other repect is, and I believe the greater; that heaven would have you ojourne a while in this Country, to the end that by oberving the daily converation of thee incere hepheards and hepheardees, you may the better come to know the incerity of that affection which Alcidon profeeth to you, or ele his fality and diimulation: For whitenee will bet appeare, when black is oppoed to it. I conclude therefore, by one way or other, that the Oracle is to be undertood thus: That you ought to tay for a time in this Country, as well to ee whether the inchantment will ceae, as to try the truth of Alcidons affection; of which in the interim, I am in very great hopes; for it is to be thought, that the Gods like good Phyitians, would never apply remedies to dieaes that are incurable; I meane, that had they known the anger of Daphnide would be perpetuall they would never have propounded this remedy.

Thus the age Druid ended his dicoure, and becaue Daphnide offered to be going away, Adamas did the like; but Alcidon tayed him, beeeching him to make Daphnide
it downe againe, that he might in his preence import a buinee of ome importance. Then the Druid taying her almot by force, Alcidon began thus.

He, Revernd Father, who aid he was cut with the harpet word, and being asked what word, anwered, that it was the word of Calumny, does thereby intimate unto our undertandings, that there is nothing which deeper pierceth the heart and the oule then it, and which I have very often found to be mot true in my elfe, ince it o pleaed my fortune and this faire one to have it o; and the wounds mart now wore then ever, ince he continues her ill opinion of me, and blames me in the preence of o reverend a peron as the wie Adamas. And becaue I know that a charge untrue may pae for truth, and becaue I had rather die any way then in her ill opinion, I mut humbly beeech you, Madam, give me leave to peake the truth in my own defence. Then becaue the Druid aid it was but reaon, he continued thus:

THis faire one, age Father, has taken the paines to relate unto you the whole eries of my mierable fortune, and I mut needs ay, he has done it truly, unlee in her two dogmaticall opinions: I mut needs ay, he is like unto thoe who look through coloured Glae, whoe eyes ee all things to be of the Iame colour: for her minde being poeed either with Love or Ambition, he judges of all things according to thoe Glaes; o as every thing which he ees in me, eems unto her to be as he ees them in her elf: Alas fairet Daphnide, it grieves me to upbraid you thus, and I wih I could make it fale with the loe of my blood and life: but you have tetified that it is but, too true, both by effects and by words: when you commanded me with o many protetations of affection, to court Clarinta, what promies did you then make me? you have heard them, grave Father; for he has rightly related them, and the reaons alo why he thought it requiite, I hould addree my elfe unto Clarinta: I hall onely hint at them, to bring them into your memory; If I be ruined in the opinion of Eurick, aid he, then are you the ame, becaue our two fortunes are conjunct and ineparable. But what kind of ruine was it he menaced and meant? onely forooth, to be banihed with her from the Court: If Clarinta, aid he, doe proper in her deignes, he will banih us both the Court. Why, Daphnide? Is it uch an intollerable torment, and an utter ruine, to pend the ret of your dayes with one that loves you beyond all expreion? Oh that your language had been as full of truth as cunning, and that Love had as much power over you as Ambition? then would you never have enjoyed me to court her, who would have ruined nothing in us but this idol Ambition. Nay on the contrary, he would with abundance of thankes, have been glad of the occaion of our living together. But I beeech you reverend Sir, oberve what a fine gilded Pill he gave me to wallow, and what a delicate cover he had to excue her etting me away from her. You cannot be ignorant, aid he, how liberall both Heaven and Nature hath been unto you in all excellent endowments; If you doe court Clarinta, he will be taken with them, which Eurick eeing, he will corn her; and he will give her Selfe, and all her Ambition unto you.

Oh Love, wilt thou not revenge uch poyoning flattery? She would perwade me, that Clarinta would quit that ame Ambition, which caueth Daphnide to reject me, and give me unto another: but why hould any imagine, he hould deire my eparation from her? Is it out of any ecret hatred he beares unto me? or becaue he thinkes me troubleome? No, no, none of thee; but for the ame reaon he her elfe alleadged. Eurick, aid he, eeing you Court her, and he entertaining you, he will leight her and retire. This, this, Father, was the maine end all her candid eloquence did aime at: Thus would he have hifted me off unto Clarinta. Well, he commanded it, and I was all obedience; but have I not great reaon to complaine, ince he is not atisfied with thus deceiving me; but he mut alo at my returne, accue me of her own fault? I weare unto you, aid he, that all the paines you take in Courting her, hall be put upon my accompt, and I will be your paymater. Is it poible Daphnide, you hould peake this, and now blame me for Courting Clarinta? Nay have I not rather reaon to require my wages for doing your commands as near as I could? But perhaps you ay, that when Eurick was once out of fancy, I hould have deited, and as the occaion varies, o ought the enterprie. I mut confee, Madam, that when the caue ceaeth, the effects mut ceae alo: but ince the
King was diverted from his affection unto Clarinta, by reaon of my addree, o had preently deited, why might it not well be imagined, that then his affection would have returned: would not this lat fault have beene wore then the firt? But fairet Daphnide, if you had a mind that I hould have deited, why did not you command me. Could you imagine that you had not an abolute power over me, having had formerly o many ignall tetimonies of it. But here comes in a very fine accuation; As oone as ever Eurick was dead (ayes he) he preently leaves his Clarinta, and never o much as asking any pardon, comes to me as impudently, as if he had never devoted himelfe unto another. What is it thou ever cant doe, unfortunate Alcidon, to give a tetimony of thy fidelity, ince that which in all reaon is the greatet evidence of it, is taken for the contrary? I courted Clarinta by command and againt my will: onely as Daphnide aid, through reaon of tate, and to the end Eurick hould digut her: Now can it be thought trange that when Euricke is dead during this counterfeit Courthip, I hould deit from it? had I not done o, it might be thought I had ome other deigne: But aid he, you ought to have asked me pardon before you returned to your wonted way of converation with me; Good God, mut I in lieu of payment and recompence aske pardon? And why Madam I beeech you, hould I aske it? Perhaps you will anwer, becaue you have courted Clarinta; but I beeech you, did not you command it, and command it with a promie of recompence? but perhaps you will ay again, that I continued longer in the ervice than I hould have done; but why Madam, hould I not have continued longer ince I expected your commands for it.

May not this ame Quetion be as well asked a Gally-lave, whoe will depends upon anothers? If one hould aske him why he is o long in that Captivity? Has he not more reaon to aske, why doe they keep me in it o long? You tell me, you are ure I loved Clarinta, and endeavoured for particular favours: But uppoe I did, and that this affection did dipleae you, can you blame any but your elfe for it; why did you command me to erve her? Is it not an evident demontration, that ambition is more predominate in you than love, and mut you not needs confee, that ince I obeyed your command o willingly, Love was more trong in me than your Ambition? For all thoe reaons which you alledged unto me to hift me off from you, was only in favour of this cured ambition: And if the love which you ay I bore unto Clarinta was o potent in me, why did I reject her ervice as oone as poibly I could? Why ele hould I quit her as oone as ever Euricke was dead? Had Clarinta treated me wore than uuall, had he made any new choice, or had there beene any bad undertanding betwixt her and me, then there had beene ome caue to upect my returne unto you; but ince he never gave me the leat hadow of any caue, what can you thinke could make me leave her, but onely the inviolable affection which I till preerved for you? But Father, perhaps you may aske why the faire Daphnide, who had formerly made o much affection unto me appeare both before, and during Euricks love, even to the hazard of our Fortune and reputation, hould after the death of this Prince, thus change her mind
• nto me, and give me no entertainment: For it is not likely, that a Lady o admirably accomplihed every way, and o full of judgment, hould alter her humour without ome occaion. No Sir, but will you ee her reaon for it out of her owne words: Tis true, that at firt he loved that Prince onely out of ambition, and as he cals it Reaon of State; but is it trange a finger hould be burned if It be held in the flame; nay it were rather a miracle if it hould not, for that were againt Nature.

The great Eurick was doubtelee a Prince o fully adorned with all accomplihed blandihments that allure Love, as the faire one was by degrees caught before he was aware, and in lieu of loving him, as he aid, he loved him as he deerved: And to make this truth evident, doe but oberve how adly he has reented his loe even unto this day; who can doubt but that thee are effects and certain conequents of a mot reall and ardent affection? I cannot relate the everall ad reentments he has expreed of his death, for they will but open my wounds the wider: But I am ure, age Adamas, that you would judge them full of extreame affection, and the bad entertainment which I have received from her proceeds from no other caue, but from her love unto this Prince; and as an umbrage of it he would et that fault upon my core, which he hould doe upon the great Euricks and my misfortunes. But fairet Daphnide, though you have loved him, not as you ay, in reaon of State, but in good earnet, yet againt whom doe you thinke you have offended? Not againt one who has not love enough to pardon, to forget, my even
to quite erae the offence; but it againt Alcidon, who you know adores you; he is ready to give you his life, and his oule, and not to upbraid you with the injury. Why doe you not put forth your hand unto him, and by that action of kindnee ignifie, that none but the great Eurick could ever interpoe betwixt you and him. It is no meane glory unto me, that he whom I love hould have beene adored by the greatet Prince in the whole Univere; nor will it be a little atisfaction unto the Ghot of that great Prince, you horld love Alcidon, who indeed did yeild unto him in Fortune, but excelled him in love.

If I ay any thing which your owne oule knowes not to be mot true, tax me with a lie; but if you cannot deny this truth, why will you toment me any longer, and make me doe penance for a fault which you your elfe have committed? Upon this, Alcidon riing from his eat, and falling downe upon his knees before the faire Daphnide, and taking her hand: I doe vow and weare, aid he, by this faire hand which is onely able to ravih away my heart, that I did never in my life render any homage, but unto her that owes it, and that it is he alone who has and ever hall have the ole power over me. Dipoe of me and of my fortune as you pleae, and let Daphnide be as cruell as he can, yet till hall Alcidon love her for ever. And you reverend Father, aid he, and addreed himelfe to the Druid; The great Tautates hath etablihed you a Judge in this Country, why doe you not condemne this Faire one to give me that heart which he hath o often given me, and taken away againe? If he doe accue me for loving any ele, is it poible he hould know better than I my elfe? She affirmes I love Clarinta, I weare and protet the contrary, why hould he thinke to be beleeved more than I? She ees onely my outward actions, but I know the intentions of my heart; perhaps he will ay that I would deceive her, and that he would not deceive me; but why hould I deceive her; for if I did not love her, I would not care for her affection; and if I doe love her, can he thinke that he who loves one will deceive her.

Thus poke Alcidon, adding much other dicoure, and many arguments which Daphnide could not handomely anwer. At lat, the Druide poke; Methinkes Madam, aid he, that the Oracle is cleared, and that now is the time to compoe this difference. I would to God, aid he, that it could be o compoed, as that quietnee of mind might be retored unto Alcidon and me, which we have taken from each other; Are you pleaed Madam, aid Adamas, that I hould be your Judge: If Alcidon will conent unto it, anwered he, and if he will tand unto what you hall doome, I will never be againt any thing which you hall deeme fit. I doe protet by all that is acred, aid Alcidon, that there is nothing in the World which can keepe me from loving and adoring you; and I weare that I will o farre tand unto the doome of wie Adamas, that if he doe entence the contrary, I will o farre obey it, as that you hall never be troubled with me; and if I faile in this Oath, may all the Elements he my confuion. Then Adamas, with the gravity of a reverend old Judge, began in a Majeticall manner to peak thus: Tell me, Madam, aid he, did you ever love Alcidon well. Above my life, anwered he; and doe you now hate him, replyed he: I hate his levity and incontancy, aid he, but not him: But ay he be not incontant replyed he, nor ever loved any but you, would you then love him till, and be orry for charging him wrongfully? Doubtlee I hould, aid he: Can you charge him with any other incontancy, continued the Druid, but in this buinee of Clarinta? Is not that enough, anwered Daphnide? But when he firt went about to erve Clarinta, aid Adamas, was it not by your command, and did he not undertake it againt his will? I mut needs confee, aid he, that in this I was unwie, and he adiembler; But had he made a retreate, aid Adamas, and Eurick cloed with Clarinta againe, would you not then have blamed Alcidon for diobeying your Commandement? I thinke I hould, anwered he. Hear then your dooms oh Daphnide and Alcidon, aid the Druid; The great Tautates who made the whole world by Love, and by Love preerves it, would not onely have things inenible, hould be united and linked together by the bonds of Love, but things alo enible and rationall.

From hence it is that he hath given unto the inenible Elements, qualities which linke them together by ympathy: Unto Animals he hath given love and deire to perpetuate their kind, and unto men reaon, which teacheth them to love God in his Creatures, and the Creatures in God. Now this Reaon tels us that whatoever is amiable ought to be loved, according to the degrees of its goodnee; and o, whatoever is mot amiable,
and has mot goodnee, ought to be mot loved. Yet in as much, as we are not obliged unto this love, untill this goodnee be known unto us; it followes by conequence, that themore any good is known, the more it ought to be loved: But ince God hath made every thing by love, and that the end of every thing is alwayes mot perfect, we may eaily judge, that ince all good things have Love for their end, Love is the bet of all things. Now knowing this goodnee of love, we are obliged by the Lawes of Reaon to eteem it above all things; and the more it is known, the more we ought to eteem it. The Oracle which was given you, for compoing your difference, makes good what I ay: For it is this,
Upon a day, you'l ee
A Fountaine, in Forret
Called Loves Veritie
Will et your hearts at ret.

That is, In Forret you hall come to know, that you doe really love each other, and then your hearts will be et at ret: for the Great Tautates, who gave this Oracle unto you, knowing how religiouly you payed what was due both unto Him and Reaon, did alo know that as oon as you were aured of each others affection, you would preently thinke it mot reaonable, to love according to your merits: And therefore Daphnide, ince you ee, that Alcidon does love you, (for why hould he o paionately deire your love, if he did not truly love you?) And you Alcidon, ince you ee the love of Daphnide towards you (for why hould he be je • lous of you and Clarinta, unlee her love were the Mother of her jealouie?) I doe Ordaine, or rather, the Great Tautates commands you, that forgetting all pat paages, and without any tay to ee any other Fountaine of Loves Verity, you doe preently unite your affections, and revive your ancient loves of each other; make it appeare that none loves better then you two, for none have more caue, ince heaven hath infued it into both.

Upon this, Adamas took both their hands, and joyning them together, aid, May this union be happy, and eternall. It is a thing impoible to expree the joyes of Alcidon, or the thanks he gave unto the great Druid, but epecially unto Daphnide: Stiliana, and Carlis, and Hermantes, rejoyed for Alcidons ake; for where ever he came, he had the happinee to get all mens love.

Thus was the dipute betwixt Daphnide and Alcidon, compoed by the prudence of the age Adamas. Although he conceived the meaning of the Oracle to be, That their jealouies of each other hould vanih by a ight of this Fountaine; yet like a peron of deep apprehenion, judging by their dicoure, that he hould doe them a better office, and more utable to their will in reconciling them, he thought it fit to expound the Oracle in this manner, and alo to advie them, to tay in this Country a while, to the end that if any upitions yet remained in them, and that if it pleaed the Heavens to uncharme the Fountaine, they might there be perfectly cured of their malady.

Whilt thee things paed thus in the preence of Adamas, the hepheards and hepheardees, who were in the Great Chamber with Leonide and Alexis, as oone as the Collation was ended, did fall into their everall dicoures where they left. But Alexis and Atrea, for feare of being interrupted, did take each other by the arm, and walked to the other end of the Chamber, which made well for Alexis, for by moving, he might the better hide the alterations in her face and better excue her diorderd language. Atrea who was no lee tranported, to ee uch a lively reemblance of Celadon, and not able to hide her contentment, was very glad of this convenience to talke with Alexis walking, as well becaue none could heare them, as becaue he might with more freedom expree the affection which he bore unto her. After therefore they had walked two or three turns, neither of them knowing well how to begin dicoure; Atrea broke ilence thus,

I hall as long as I live, Madam, oberve this day as a Holiday, in memory of the high favour which I have received on it in making me o happy as to know you, and to expree my mot zealous deires of doing you ervice. The acred Misletoe which it hath pleaed the Great Tautates to make grow in our Hamlet this yeare, was an Omen of the happinee which we were to receive by your coming into this place; hewing thereby,
that the liberall hand of the great God, where it betowes one favour, does accompany it with many others. The happinee and good fortune of it, aid Alexis, is all on my ide, in coming hither at uch a eaon, when this acred Misletoe is to be gathered; for that is the caue of my happinee in eeing you, it being one of my greatet deires. How, Madam? aid Atrea, doe you thinke it your happinee in wronging us all, and me in particular, by thinking we came hither onely becaue of this acred Misletoe? I will thinke, aid Alexis, as you pleae; but give me leave to ay, that it is at this time the caue of my happinee in eeing you; and though I had not been here, yet you would have come to invite Adamas unto the acrifice of Thanks. I doe mot eriouly protet, Madam, aid Atrea, that it is your elfe onely which invited me to come hither; for I never in my life had a more earnet deire of any thing, than of eeing of you; beeeching you to believe, that it is not my humour to meddle with any publique matters, but I leave them unto our wier Pators, who takes the cure of them according to their cutome, and according as they thinke mot advantagious for this Country. I hould be very proud of my elfe, aid Alexis, if I could be perwaded of it; for it is a thing which I mot wih, and prie above any happinee that ever happened unto me. But pray tell me, fair hepheardee, in what place is this Misletoe found? If the Sun would permit you to looke out of the window, anwered Atrea, I hould let you ee it from hence. I believe, aid Alexis, that the Mountain does interpoe, if it be on that ide; but if it do not, I believe the heat of the day being over, we may enjoy the pleaant propect of all that plaine: upon this, opening the Window, and both looking out; after they had looked about every way, Atrea began thus.

Doe you ee, Madam, the coue of that River which runs by the walles of Boen, as if it did cut that plain almot in the middle, and empties it elfe into the lap of Loire; that is the fatall and defamed River Lignon, upon which you may perceive our Hamlet to be eated, oppoite unto mount Verdan, which is a little Mountaine in forme of a pointed Diamond, in the middle of the plaine, and which lookes like a Rock in the Sea. If you pleae to cat your eye a little upon the left hand, you may ee the Temple of the good Goddee, a little round Temple under which runs an arme of that detetable Lignon, and a little beyond that, following till that • ravinous River, you may epie a little wood, and it is there where the happy Oak grows which this year bears the acred Misletoe. And truly it is worthy obervance, That, there, is the form of a Temple made out of little Trees, pleached together mot artificially. None knowes who made it, nor the time when it was o contrived; and yet it is o well ordered and contrived, as whooever coniders it, mut needs confee him that did it a mot admirable Artit. We almot all think, it was the worke either of Pan, or Egipan, or ome other Rurall God; for uch exquiite inventions when the Author is unknown, are commonly attributed unto ome Deity. Alexis feemed to wonder at all this, and the better to colour her diimulation, eemed as if he could not ee this place which was hewed unto her, though none knew it better then her elfe but Atrea pulling her a little nearer, and holding out her hand to direct Alexis unto the place where this Temple was: Doe you ee, Madam (aid he unto her) that wood which growes almot cloe upon the banke of the River? Cat your eye a little upon the left hand and you may ee a little Meadow greener then all the ret; the reaon of it is, becaue the gras of it is not oyled, nor any Cattel driven into it, becaue it hath been long ince dedicated unto ome Deity, as well as that little tuft of Trees which joynes upon it. Now this little acred Meadow, eems as if it had been conecrated as the Court belonging unto that artificiall Temple, which tands amongt thoe Trees I think, aid Alexis, that I doe ee the place you meane, and I doe oberve one tree much higher then all the ret: Right, right, aid Atrea, that is the Tree which upports the Temple, and to its fame, has this yeare the happinee to beare the acred Misletoe, for which we ought to offer a acrifice of Thanks. Had I o much wit as to relate all the rarities there, and the Art wherewith it is made, I am ure you would admire them: Amongt the ret, I oberved the Picture of the Goodee Atrea (for the Temple is dedicated unto her) much different from thoe by which they ue to repreent her unto us: She is pourtrayed in the habit of a hepheardee, with a heep-hook in her hand, and her flock about her: and which is mot admirable, all that ee it, ay, that he reembles me. Alexis could not chue but bluh at this, and it was happy for her none tood by; for it had been an eaie matter to ee what alterations were in her face, and fearing let if Atrea hould accidently
looke towards her, he hould perceive it, he leaned upon her elbow in the window, and covered her face with her hand, and to give her no leiure to looke upon her I beleeve faire Shepherdee, aid he, that he who drew the picture of that Goddee in that manner, did it with much reaon: For Atrea, who is the goddee of Jutice, cannot be better repreented, than by a hepherdee with her heephooke and her flocke; both to hew that in places mot retired and rurall, the innocent and weake are by her kept in afety, and to hew that by the meanes of Jutice, peaee and abundance is maintained amongt men, which are two things which cannot be better repreented, than by hepherdees and their flocks. But I doe thinke him much more judicious in giving your, fair face unto that goddee: For how could he poibly make choice of a better being to repreent a Diety, than in taking for his patterne, the mot perfect that ever Nature hewed unto us? And uch is your beauty, that I beleeve if that goddee Atrea would looke upon this picture he will be prouder of your features, than of her owne and had rather be uch a one as you are on the Earth than as her elfe is in Heaven.

Thee Praies, aid Atrea and bluht, are much too high for one o full of misfortunes as my elfe; epecially coming from you Madam, unto whom they are much more due; but uch as I am. I am mot devoutly yours, o as you may dipoe of me as you pleae, and peake of me likewie: For I profee, that I have no higher ambition than to merit the title of your mot devoted ervant. Faire hepherdee (aid Alexis) would you have me beleeve what you ay? Madam (aid Atrea preently, I doe mot earnetly beg it, and conjure you unto it by what you love mot; This conjuration, aid Alexis, beides your owne merit, has a great prevalence and mut needs be granted; and therefore according to your conjuration, I doe promie henceforward to beleeve all your expreions of good will unto me, upon a condition you will never repent of it I and in exchange, I doe oblige my elfe by my fidelity never to deny any thing which you hall aske in the name of her whom I love bet. Madam, replyed Atrea, may I never live a minute longer than I devote my elfe, my ervices, and my life unto your ervice. Faire Shepherdee, aid Alexis, I doe oblige my elfe in the tronget tyes of fidelity to entertaine your amity with all my heart, and will never whilt I live faile in any duty of a perfect friend.

Who is able to expree the contentments both of Atrea and Alexis? ince both loved each other better than themelves, but that Atrea feared her friends would never conent unto her following this dear Druide unto all places whereoever he went, and but that Alexis had an opinion he hould loe all thee pretious favours if he were knowne, it had beene impoible for them to hide the excee of their atisfactions.

On the other ide, Paris who kept himelfe alwayes next Diana, and who could not ufficieetly expree his high affection to her, being vexed to ee o many people about him who harkned unto what he aid, and deiring to entertaine them with omething ele, he deired Hylas to take a Lute and ing. Hylas all complacence, did take the Lute, and conented unto the deires of Paris, upon condition every one would doe the ame, particularly Silvander. This hepherd, who had an eye alwayes upon Diana, knowing that he loved very well to hear him ing, he tooke the Lute from Hylas, and ung a ong, the ubject of which was, that though he loved extreamly, yet he thought he loved not enough.

When Silvander had done, he kied the Lute and preented it unto Corilas, who willingly accepted of it, and fixing his eye upon Stella, he began to ing upon this ubject, that Now his Love was extinguihed, it could never kindle againe. Stella hearing how Corilas twitted her, he offered to take the Lute, intending to pay him backe the money which he lent, but the hepherd doubting it he would not let her have it: aying it was unreaonable that Hylas who firt had it, hould be o long without it: Be not offended hepherdee, aid Corilas unto Stella, if I doe give it unto Hylas, ince if your deigne was to expree any thing of your humour, I aure my elfe he will atisfie you, if he ing according to the dictates of his heart: You are very kind Corilas, aid Hylas unto him, to pay your debts with anothers money; at the leat, Stella and I have this advantage, that being both of one opinion, we have met with one that will allow of our humours, but yours is o bad, that you are ingular in your Sect, then taking the Lute, and not taying for the anwer of Corilas, he ung in commendation of incontancy.

Phillis, who could not indure that Hylas hould pae without an anwer, Methinks Silvander, aid he, that both you and I are obliged to anwer this incontant hepherd, ince he is o imp •• as to peake thus in the preence of our Mitree; for every right Lover when he heares any thing in diadvantage of fidelity is obliged to defend that vertue. Mot true, my Enemy, anwered Silvander, and I hould have done it ere now, but that I was affraid my indicretion would have beene blamed for interrupting, yet if Hylas will repeat the ame Veres he ung, I will try whether I can anwer them Vere by Vere;
•• haps aid Hylas, it will not pleae the Company to repeat what I have ung already; but, Silvander, that you may be without excue, I pray anwer thee: I am ready, aid Silvander; for being ure I have reaon on my ide, I am very couragious to undertake the Combate. As the generous Lyon, aid Hylas, contemnes all creatures that are his inferiours in trength; o doe I you, Silvander, being o much my inferiour both in wit, and goodnee of caue; thus they began to ing, one for, and the other againt incontancy.

Whilt thee two hepherds were thus inging, and the ret of the Company attentively hearing, Paris cloed with this opportunity, and got neerer Diana; was there ever uch a pleaant humour (aid he unto her in a low voice) as this of Hylas? I thinke (anwered the hepherdee) that he is like all other men, onely he is a little more free and open in uttering his thoughts than others are. Oh Madam, replyed Paris, have you uch a bad opinion of men, and thinke them all as incontant as he is? I have no bad opinion of men, (anwered Diana, and miled) for I cannot thinke it an errour in them to doe as Hylas doth, ince it is a thing very naturall, to love where we like bet: And ince mot hepherds doe love onely to pleae themelves, have I not good caue to thinke that where they find mot pleaure, there they will without any difficulty love, imitating in this our heep, who ue not to eat alwayes of the ame grae, nor feed only in one Pature, but loving variety, graze ometimes in the Meadowes, other times upon Hils, and ometimes again under Shades: The hepherdee as he poke this, miled, to hew he poke againt her concience, and Paris taking notice of it, anwered thus: Hylas would be well confirmed in his opinion, fairet hepherdee, if he heard you; but I beleeve if you were condemned to follow this opinion, it would be omewhat difficult to make you conent unto it. I mut confee, anwered he, that what you ay is true, for hepherdees are not ubject unto the ame Laws which hepherds are; for they doe not only fly incontancy, but contancy alo. This is too enigmaticall for me to undertand, replyed Paris, unlee Fairet you be pleaed to make a cleerer interpretation. My meaning is, anwered he, that the Virgins of this Country, doe not only fly incontancy, becaue they are not of a wavering temper; but they fly contancy alo, becaue they will not be obliged unto any kind of amity, loving and eteeming all that deerve it, not with love and paion, but according to duty and reaon.

I doe beleeve it, anwered Paris faintly: but for ome interet which I may have I wih that one amongt them were of another humor. Generous Paris, replyed Diana, you mut needs pardon their dull capacities: for being brought up, in rurall and halfe alvage places, you cannot expect they hould differ much from uch as they mot convere with: you ee what an influence education hath upon people, and above reaon: for I beleeve there is very few in all this company, who would not more contentedly chue to live with their flockes upon the bankes of Lignon, and under their homely roofes, than in princely Pallaces, and civilized Cities. I beeech you fairet hepherdee aid Paris, what opinion are you off, what doe you thinke of this houe? and how uits it with your liking? I hould hew my elfe of a very weake judgment, anwered Diana, if I did not thinke it very noble, and very pleaant. Much more noble and pleaant would it be, aid Paris, if what is now in it, would be alwayes in it. Tis true, replyed Diana, for o many faire hepherdees and hanome hepherds, doe not onely make the company very great, but alo the place very pleaant. It is not the quantity, replyed Paris, but the quality of perons which makes me eteem it: I am of your beliefe, aid he; for mot company does commonly mot of all make one weary of it; but they mut be of a very bad humour that doe dilike the company which is here. I perceive, replyed Paris, that you will not undertand my meaning; for it is not of all the company which I peake, but it is, fairet hepherdee of one only, without which one, all the ret of the company would be weariome unto me. Diana faigning not to undertand him: That one (aid he very
coldly) is much obliged to you; though all the ret are but very little beholding; there is none in the company, anwered Paris, ought to thinke much at me for it, ince without that one my life it elfe is unpleaing to me; after this, both tandin •
<> and Paris eeing Diana, did not reply, I did never in my life (aid he, and miled) ee a hepherdee lee inquiitive than Diana; Why doe you not aske me who this one is? becaue aid he, it would be indicretion in me; for I am ure that if you had a mind to name her, you would, and if you deired to conceale her, I were very indicreet if I did importune you She, added Paris, unto whom I have given my heart, may very well know all th •
ecrets of it, nor ought I to conceale them, Men in giving uch gifts anwered Diana d •
often give and take againe: If you meane by me, replyed Paris, pardon me fairet Diana, if I tell you, that you wrong me; ince from the firt day that I gave my elfe unto you, the gift was with o full a conent of my heart, as I hall never enjoy any contentment untill you have taken full poeion of it; and it was of you I poke when I mention'd one, from whom I mut receive my full contentment. I hould be very unworthy (anwered the hepherdee, and bluht) if I did not receive this honour you are pleaed to doe unto me, with much obligation unto your civility: Nay, nay, aid Paris, never tell me of any civility or repect, but in lieu of thoe words, put in that word of Love. That word, aid he, fals not handomely from the tongue of a woman; If it will not come off your tongue, replyed he, then let it be in your heart: That would be too great a crime, replyed Diana, and would render me unworthy of this honour you are pleaed to doe me.

Silvander and Hylas had now done inging, and there was not a word amongt all the company, as if they were in hopes of their beginning to ing againe, which was a caue that many perceived not onely the affection wherewith Paris poke unto Diana; but alo the paion in which Silvander was to ee their long dicoure; which Hylas conidering, and thinking to get ome advantage over him: Come, come Silvander (aid he) we have ung enough; let us now be a little erious and rationall if we can Tell me upon your faith whether you perit till in the ame opinion which you were wont to be: I am not much addicted unto changing (aid Silvander) but of what opinion doe you meane? Are you till in the heart of Diana, replyed Hylas, and is he till in yours? why doe you aske me this quetion, aid Silvander? Becaue (aid Hylas) I will at this time make you confee the contrary. Methinkes Hylas, anwered Silvander, you had better have lept on then wake to no purpoe: Whilt every one laughed at this quetion and this anwer, Phillis tooke an occaion to interrupt the dicoure of Paris and Diana, and to call her companion to heare this fine dipute: In the meane time Hylas anwered; hepherd, hepherd, I doe not wake to o little purpoe as you thinke, ince to put one out of an errour, is a worke never out of eaon, but anwer me; Are you till in the heart of Diana, and is Diana in yours. Diana hearing this quetion; Hearken (aid he unto Paris) what Hylas ayes: For I am confident it will be ome mad piece of dicoure or other: Then they heard Silvander anwer thus; Doe you thinke Hylas that becaue you are continually changing, others are the like: Diana and I are in the very ame places we were wont to be; Why then, aid Hylas, he is in your heart, and you in hers. It is as you ay, anwered Silvander: Then, prethee good Silvander tell me, aid Hylas, ince you are in the heart of Diana, whether the dicoure which Paris had now with her did pleae her or no? And Diana, ince you are in Silvanders heart, tell us whether Silvander was pleaed at the Dicoure.

There was none in all the company, except Silvander, who did not laugh o loud, as they caued Atrea and Alexis to turne about and ee what the matter was; which Hylas oberving, he tayed not for Silvanders anwer (for Atreas long dicoure was as vexatious unto him, as that of Paris was unto Silvander) but ran preently to her; Mitree, aid he unto Alexis, Thee hepherdees of Lignon are uch bewitching flatterers, that unlee one take very good heed, it is almot impoible to reit their charms. I beleeve Servant (aid Alexis) that you peake like a very knowing man. Tis true (aid he) I have not been o long Apprentice, but I have learned my Trade; For before I loved Phillis, I thought Laonice faire, and before her, Madonthe, and before them both, Criide: Here is three trangers, aid he, pointing at Florice, Palanice, and Circenea, can witnee I am no Novit, when I was Servant unto them; and if Carlis, who is in the Gallery with Daphnide were here, he could tell you how he was the firt who taught me my Primer. But Servant, aid Alexis, I doe not thinke that Carlis can boat that
you hold her for your lat Mitree, as you did for your firt: for I have heard you ay, that you have loved but as many as you have met. Mitree, aid he, you hould have added as many faire ones, as I have met: for I doe confee, that whereoever my eye oberved beauty, I was a lover and ervant of it; and methinks you hould like my humour very well, ince it hath made me yours; and without which, ill-favoured Carlis had till poeed me.

I like your humour extreamly well, anwered Alexis, did I not feare that as it is now the caue of your being mine, o it will hereafter make me grieve for the loe of you. Oh fairet Mitree, aid Hylas, I beeech you not to thinke any uch thing; for beides your offence unto my love, it is mot impoible any uch thing hould ever be; for I never loved any thing but beauty, and out of you it is mot impoible to find it. I hould be very glad, anwered Alexis, to have you continue long in this opinion of me, that I may not loe as others have; but I had rather that all your perwaions could make me believe all you ay of me to be true. I need no perwaions, anwered he, where every eye is able to tetifie. If all did ee me with your eyes, anwered Alexis, their tetimonies might perhaps be favourable unto me. I am certaine, replyed Hylas, that there is none here, will give my eyes the lie. Your eyes indeed may ee things as they are, anwered Alexis, but your mouth may perhaps be given a little to Hyperbolize, and your tongue which is o glib in attributing unto me, more then is my due, does tetifie that you have learned in more Schools then one. I doe confee it, replyed Hylas, but withall I am able, and without vanity to peak it, that the Schollar, urpaed the Mater. You never told me (aid Florice) that when you were my Schollar, you learned your leon of Circenea, and Palinice alo. And had we all three united our learning together, we might have kept you longer at School. How ervant, replyed Alexis, what? erve three at one time? You may judge by that Mitree (aid he) the greatnee of my courage, and whether I doe not erve you mot devoutly, ince I attempt none but you alone.

Whilt he was talking thus, Adamas, Daphnide, and Alcidon came out of the Gallery, becaue it was near upper time; and when they had talked awhile upon everall ubjects, the table was furnihed, and with uch and o many delicacies, as Daphnide admired that a country houe could find out uch varieties of curioities as this wie Druid had provided. Supper being ended, and after much and various dicoure which lated long, Adamas oberved by the eyes of mot in the company, that it was bed-time; and therefore he invited Daphnide and Alcidon unto their ret, waiting upon them to their Chambers, and leaving Leonide and Paris to carry the ret of the hepheardees and hepheards into theirs: but though the night was farre pent, yet Alexis having carried Atrea, Phillis, and Diana into their Chambers, he could not o oon part from them; but, after a hundred good nights, till he had omething to ay: At lat, Leonide having lodged all the ret, came into the Chamber, and hearing the clock trike midnight, he contrained her to retire. The three hepheardees being now alone, although there was everall beds in the Chamber, yet would they needs lie all together.

Whilt they were addreing themelves, Atrea could not for her life talke of any thing ele but Alexis. Siter, aid he unto Phillis, was ever two faces o full of reemblance, as this of the faire Alexis, and that of poor Celadon? For my part, aid Phillis, I never in my life aw two more like. Nay more, aid Diana, did you ever ee any Glas repreent a nearer imilitude, betwixt the ubtance and the reflection? Nay iter, aid Atrea, what would you ay if you had poken with her in particular as I did? her voyce, her pronunciation, her aire, her actions, her miles, nay every little feature are o reemblant, as if Celadon were by her, I could finde no difference; and the more I conider it, the more I am ravihed with admiration. I wih with all my heart, replyed Phillis, we could perwade Adamas to let her tay amongt us for a time; and if we could, iter, I believe you would be well contented. Doubtlee I hould, anwered Atrea, for I can truly ay, that ince the death of poor Celadon, I never enjoyed any pleaure but in the ight of Alexis. But alas, there is no hopes that Adamas will ever uffer her to come unto us, for he is o dear unto him, as he cannot uffer her to be out of his ight, nor would it be pleaing unto her, being accutomed unto another kind of life: And fortune is alwaies o little my friend, as I cannot thinke he will ever doe me o great a kindnee. Siter, replyed Diana, If you deire that this faire one hould come into our Hamlet, we mut ue a little cunning; ometimes one hall bring that to pae by ubtilty, which
would be denyed; if it were openly asked; and uch kind of policy is not blameable when it will not hurt any one. Should we aske this favour of the Druid, perhaps his civility would be o great as not to deny it; and perhaps alo, he would alleadge uch coniderations, as we hould not peed: but let us goe another way to worke; let us entreat him, and let all the company do the like, that he would be pleaed not to retard the acrifice of thanks for the acred Misletoe: he hath already promied as much unto other hepheards, who came with the ame Petition: If we bring him to that pae, as to come preently with us, I am confident he will bring Alexis with him, as well becaue Leonide will come, as to accompany Daphnide, whom we mut entreat to ait us in the buinee: Beides, the acrifice being a buinee of great and religious olemnity; and Alexis being a Druid, it is not likely he hould be left at home. Yet to be every way prepared; if it happen o that Adamas do make any difficulty in it, we mut intreat both her and Leonides good will unto it; for I do percieve that he is not dipleaed to be in our company; and yet truly conidering the difference in education, perhaps he does onely contrain her elf out of civility to be o complaiant unto us in her Fathers houe. But for all that, I am fully perwaded, if we could once get her into our Hamlet, we three hould keep her in it, by endeavouring to pleae her in uch things as he takes mot delight in; and perhaps when he ees the honet innocency of our lives, he will not thinke it much diagreeable to her humour Truly, aid Phillis, and hook her head, he is of a trange temper if we did dipleae her; but I lay my life, that we hall all cry when he is contrained to leave us, and therefore we had as good let it alone Atrea hearing this, aid unto her; Siter, if you take any delight in my company, let us procure her to be amongt us, for otherwie I am but a meer lot woman. But will you know what I foreee? (aid Phillis) I make no quetion but we hall get her amongt us, by the meanes which Diana hath propoed; nor doe I feare but Alexis will be well pleaed with us, if I doe but take the paines to humour her; but I plainly ee that when he comes, Atrea will quite leave us, and make no more reckoning of us then as meer trangers.
