And therefore I will tell you what we will doe if that happen: This Alexis will not tay alwayes with us, but will one day return either to Dreux or to Carnutes, and then we will make no more reckoning of her, then he does of us. Fie, fie, Siter replyed Atrea, I cannot abide you hould bring this ad eparation into memory; for Gods ake, let us not bring on a miery by the thought of it, which will come but too oon of it elfe. No, no, replyed Diana, let us lay aide all uch Cogitations, and doe what our amity commands us: ince Atrea has no contentment but in this, let us doe all we can to continue it to her: And though he hould doe as you ay, yet if we doe love her, we hould be orry for her, ince all things are common amongt thoe that love one another and loving her as we do, why hould we not hare with her in the contenment which he receives?

With uch dicoure as this, thee hepheardees got to bed, and after good nights unto one another, they fell aleep in this reolution which they had fixed upon. But on the other ide, Alexis being retired into her Chamber, and Leonide with her, Adamas entred preently after them, who having brought Alcidon and the old Pators into their Chambers, leaving the care of the ret unto Paris; He came unto Celadon, to know what had paed betwixt him and Atrea. After he had hut the door, let any hould heare, Well Alexis (aid he and miled) how does Celadon? As for Celadon, anwered Alexis, I cannot tell how he does; but as for Alexis, let me protet unto you, he ayes that he never in her life had more contentment ince he was your Daughter. I am glad on • , ayes Adamas, o it continue. But tell me truly, Celadon, Doe you now repent of your believing me? It is a thing impoible, anwered the hepheard, that any hould repent following your counell. For all you give is good, But let me tell you Father, that this which I have received from you upon this occaion, is full of danger unto me; for if Atrea hould come to know me. I protet there is nothing under the Sun could keep me alive; for beides the jut occaion which I hould give her to blame me, for diobeying her command, I hould grieve o exceively for failing in my duty, as it would uffice to take away my life; or if it did not, I would court all inventions in the world to give me a uddaine and cruell death. Well, well, aid Adamas, I perceive your condition is not yet in a fit temper to take thoe remedies which I would give you, we mut tay till time has a little more prepared your contitution; in the mean time, be ure you put on a trong reolution, not to diobey any thing I hall command, for otherwie you will give me occaion
to tax you with ingratitude. Father, aid Celadon, I will never faile in my obedience to you, provided your commands do not contradict thoe which I have already received, which is mot impoible I hould not oberve: I will never advie you (aid the Druid) againt what you ay: But let me tell you, that the patient mut not think, he knows what Phyick is better againt his dieae, then the Phyitian doth.

To morrow, I will go in the company of thee hepheards and hepheardees, to offer the acrifice of thankes for the alubrious Misletoe which is found in their Hamlet; and as it fortunes, under the very ame Oak where you made the Temple of Atrea, which let me tell you, is an Onch of very good fortune to you. And becaue I mut according to cutome, carry Paris and Leonide with me, it is requiite I hould carry you alo. Oh Father, (aid Alcidon) what do you mean? into how much danger would you bring both me, and your elfe alo? Since it hath pleaed good Tharamis to give me the contentment of eeing this hepheardee, of talking with her, and yet not to be known by any in the company; doe not put me and yourelfe unto any further hazard: what a wound would it be unto your untained reputation, if it hould come to be dicovered? and to me it would be mot certaine death. Let us thank the God for the favour he hath done us; and let me rather retire into ome deart, where I may end my mierable dayes. I ee, replyed Adamas, that you are to begin again your firt leon: That God whom you name, hath commanded me to have a particular care of you, and I mut be obedient. For, Child, you mut know, that he never commands any thing, but what is jut and laudable: and though humane ignorance does ometimes thinke the contrary, yet in the end we ee, that he who keeps cloe unto his Ordinances, does urmount all difficulties, and clear all thoe triviall doubts which may obcure the glory of his actions. Therefore, never trouble your elfe with any thing that relates unto me, no nor what returnes unto your elfe; for Thamires never undertakes a thing, which he does not bring unto a perfect end: It is he, who by me does that which you ee me doe for your good, having commanded me by his Oracle. Doubt not therefore, but that both You and I hall receive contentment.

Celadon would have replyed: bnt Leonide interrupted him, aying, You may ee, hepheard, that oftentimes one will do thoe things for another, which he would not doe for himelfe: If Adamas hould leave you at home, and carry with him Paris and me, what would be thought of you? what trange opinions would there be, if you who goes under the notion of Druid, hould not come unto a acrifice of uch olemnitie; ince you have gone o far, you mut go farther; and ince Tautates hath committed you unto the tuitiod of Adamas, and you your elfe confented to it, you cannot make a retreat without offence both againt that God, and Adamas alo. You mut hut your eyes againt all coniderations whatoever, and ubmit your elfe wholly unto his prudence and conduct.

p.U: haked his head at this: Father, aid he, ince the Gods have commanded it, and ince you are pleaed to take it upon you, I refer my elfe, my life, and all my contentments unto you. Upon this, the Druid embraced him, and taking Leonide by the hand, left him to his ret. But his thoughts would not permit him to take any, for all the night long his minde ran upon the weet dicoure which Atrea and he had, and upon every circumtance, not forgetting a yllable, or the leat action which gave him any tetimony that till he loved the memory of Celadou. And when he had long entertained thee thoughts, he would gladly have driven them out of his mind, as thinking them contrary to his preent condition.

div.p: Fie, fie, mierable hepheard (aid he) why dot thou uffer thy elfe to be flattered up with the miles of fortune? hat thou not often found, that he never Caraes, but with a deigne of deceiving? nor raieth thee up, but that thy fall may be the greater? Conider to what a height of happinee thou wert once elevated; remember that never any hepheard could call himelfe o bleed as thy elfe: Then turne but thine eye upon the preent condition, and tell me if it was poible to fall from a teeper Precipice. And now at this time, when under a hadow thou art taken for another, and under a borrowed Name much off: Cant thou take thee favours as thine owne? thou dot not conider that thou tealet them under the umbrage of anothers Name, and that they would be denyed unto thine.

This conideration did make all his firt thoughts o bitter unto him, as he was almot
ready to fall into the ame depaire as when he lived in his Cave, and he wanted but a little of reolving to returne into his firt deign of eparating himelfe from the World, ince he aw no hopes of any cure for his mieries. And probably this reolution had prompted him to put his deigne in execution, had not ome good Angell brought into his memory the apient advice of age Adamas, apprehending that if God had not deigned him ome olace in his miery, he would never have put him into the hands of uch a reverend Peron, who was eteemed highly good and wie amongt all that knew him. After he had toed away mot of the night in thee turbulent thoughts, this comfortable conideration laid him aleepe; and it being breake of day before he began, it was long before he awaked. Atrea, Diana and Phillis did not the like; for Atrea paionately deiring to get Alexis unto her Hamlet, he waked betimes: And Diana fearing leat Paris hould find her in bed, although he carried himelfe at a repective ditance, yet he would not put it to the hazard, but as oone as he aw Atrea wake, he awaked Phillis, and began to upbraid her; what Servant, aid he, are you not ahamed to be aleep and your Mitree awake? Mitree, aid Phillis, I did not know you to be awake, but methinkes you hould leepe as well as I doe unlee Silvander were in my room. Oh Servant, aid Diana, let Silvander be where he is, he does not thinke upon us, and let us thinke no more of him. As well as I love you, replyed Phillis, I would not be tyed to thinke upon you o much as he does.

This is a bad opinion which you have of him, replyed Diana, but you hall ee that when I have given my judgement, which will be within this two or three dayes, he will preently turne to his old byas. Siter, aid Atrea, doe you really, and upon your faith, thinke as you ay? When you aske me upon my faith, aid he, I mut conider a little better before I anwer; but if you will know what I would have him doe, I will tell you, and truly; that I doe love him o well and my elfe alo, as for both our quiers I w • h as I ay. Upon my faith (aid Phillis and miled) you doe lye; and pardon me Mitree if this offend you, for there was never any woman yet that was angry for being loved and erved by a peron of merit; but on the contrary, I have een many very angry with thoe that did love them, and afterwards did fall off from loving, though they had no deigne upon them. Nay, I will goe a little further; I never in my life aw any who were not inwardly angry at uch changes: I my elfe who never did love Hylas, yet mut needs confee that when he quitted me, I was angry at him though I carried it as well as I could: and the reaon of all this is, becaue as the addr • es of thoe who love us are arguments of our beauty and merit; o their departures from us are arguments of the contrary. You may thinke of me as you pleae, aid Diana, but I protet that if it were in my choice whether he hould continue, or give over his addree unto me, I doe foreee that they would both be o troubleome unto us both, as I know not which I hould chue: For if he doe continue it what deigne can I have in uffering it? For it is not probable my Parents would ever uffer me to marry a peron who is unknowne, and I my elfe hould be ahamed that Diana hould ever commit uch a fault. Then againe, if we hould breake off all amity, I aure you that I hould long lament it, becaue I thinke his merits make him worthy of Love: It is the greatet folly in the World (aid Phillis) that Parents hould make marriages, and we are very fooles to let them. Has not this brought Atrea into the condition wherein he is; had her Parents left her to the free dipoition of her elfe, he had married Celadon; he had been alive, and he for ever contented; whereas, on the contrary, Parents croing them has killed the one, and the other is little better. And now, the old foole Phocion would betow her upon Calidon, and is o perwaded to bring it about that he never rets. Ah that I had the hampering of him I hould quickly reolve what to doe. What would you doe (aid Atrea) if you were in my roome; I would tell him in few words (aid he) that I could not abide him: What would be thought of a woman aid Diana, that hould peake o, and what would they ay of her? Mitree, aid Phillis, words are but words, and opinion is but opinion, and both but wind; but to marry a peevih Husband is a thing that would be felt all ones life: And therefore I hall thinke you very inconiderate in aying that you will not marry Silvander, whom you confee to be a man of much merit, and every way compleat, onely becaue you know not from whence he came. Ah Mitree, will you not eat fine fruit unlee you know the Tree whereon they grow? Oh the groet folly of all others, to purue appearances with all eagernee, and never care for things that are recall and truly good. God has infinitely blet me
in giving me Parents of another mind; for I aure you, had they beene of uch a temper, I hould have found them worke enough. Diana miled at this, and aid, Your counell Siter is very good, but not to be followed alwayes. For I beeech you tell me; this opinion which you leight o much, and thee appearances which you condemne, are they any thing ele but reputation, which is a thing as deare as life is? is there any thing upon earth more mierable than a woman without this reputation, is there any condition
<> pittifull, as that of a peron who hath lot it? I mut confee, that conider it rightly, and it will be found a folly; but is there any thing amongt us which is not folly, if it be earched to the bottome? No, no Servant, all the world is nothing but a gloe, a vaine hadow of good; though you and I doe know this to be true, yet by the common conent of all, it is judged otherwie, and you or I mut not be the firt, to breake the Ice. This makes me thinke upon the counell that was given amongt the Rats, who reolved for their afety to have a Bell tyed about the neck of the Cat, to the end they might hear her when he came, but upon the uphot of the reult, there was none amongt all the company that durt attempt the doing it.

Dicouring thus, thee faire hepherdees dret themelves: and Atrea, not well knowing upon what deigne, did trim up her elf with more care and curioity than he did ince the loe of Celadon; which Phillis taking notice of, he could not chue but mile, and hinting it unto Diana, Mitree, aid he, the hepherdees of Lignon are of a very odde humour: Why? aid Diana, becaue I ee, aid Phillis, that Atrea takes abundance of paines to dree her elfe better than ordinary For my part I know no reaon he has for it, unlee it be her affection to this faire Druid, whoe acquaintance was but of yeterday. I pray tell me, is it the humour of the hepherdees of Lignon to aect o oone, and rather hepherdees than hepherds? To which Atrea anwered; Tis true, I have a greater humour to make my elfe amiable, than ever I had, and there is good reaon for it, becaue when I was courted by hepherds, I thought my elfe of merit enough to make my elfe loved amongt them, never putting my elfe to any further trouble than to be eene: But now if I will obtain the favour of this faire Druid, I mut be as carefull of my elfe as any Servant is in getting the favour of his Mitree. But Siter, replyed Diana, Phillis and I are either much mitaken in our judgements, or ele there is great defects in uch as ee you and doe not love you, though for nothing but for your merit. Upon this, they had all dreed themelves, and as they were going out of the Chamber, they aw Paris walking with Leonide in the next room, and the hepherdees were neere them before the other perceived, they eemed to talke very affectionately; of which Paris was much ahamad, and when he aw them, after morning alutes, he asked Diana pardon, who anwered him that he had committed no offence whith concerned her: For he being the meanet of the three, they had more reaon to complaine than he, if there was any caue at all; and not taying for his anwer, he addreed her elfe unto Leonide, and asked her whether he had a good night? I have more reaon to aske the ame quetion of you (aid Leonide) who are up o early; was there not omething in your Chamber, or your bed which was the caue of it? Both in the Chamber, aid Diana, and in the bed, but it was this faire hepherdee, aid he, and pointed at Atrea, who waked us ooner than we would, out of her deire to imploy the time h • is to tay here, as well as he can, I meane as near the faire Alexis as he can get; for he is o zealouly devoted her Servant, as I know not how we hall part them, when ye goe from he • ce. Come, aid Leonide, let us go to h • r, if he be awake; but as we goe, let me impart one ecret which I have thought upon, which will be a meanes they hall not part o oone: You mut intreat Adamas that without any more delay, he goe and offer the acrifice of thankes for the Misleto, and that h • carry us all with him.

I know he will not deny you, for I know he mut performe this duty once, and he will be for one night contented with the houe of Atrea, by reaon of Phocian whom he loves and eteems very much-and o hall we be all together, all the day to morrow but fair hepherdees, be ure you conceal me in the buinee; for if Adamas hould know that this advice comes from me, perhaps he would be angry, and make ome difficulty in it. Nor is it neceary that Alexis hould know, becaue he is of a very retired humour, and never o well contented as when alone. I matter not if Paris be of the plot, becaue I know that he takes much delight in your company, and will not croe it. I hall never deny the opinion you have of me, aid Paris. Then Atrea after he had miled upon Diana
and Phillis: Do you think, Madam, aid he, that Adamas will not deny us, and will let Alexis go alo? for the truth is, if all the world go, and Alexis tay behind, I hall be but in a very bad mood, and perhaps hall hide my elfe from the trouble of all the ret of the company.

You ee, Madam, aid Phillis, that the hepherdees of Lignon are no diemblers: both he, and all the ret, aid Leonide, are more worthy and etimable for it; but I beeech you, from whence proceeds this great amity? by ympathy, aid Atrea, and I am not my elfe unlee I be by her: ince o, aid the Nymph, I hall render you all the contentment that I am able, and I cannot chue but admire, for Alexis, the lat night did peak the ame of you, that you do now of her: I have a very intimate familiarity with her, and know her uual humour; but now he is quite out of all her Naturalls, and the alteration mut needs proceed from ome upernatural power. Madam, aid Phillis, you will make her o proud, that we hall not be able to live with her: upon this they came to the Chamber of Alexis, where they found her yet in bed; for being omething early, and it being morning before her thoughts would give her leave to leepe, he was hardly awake when all this good company came into her Chamber.

The truth is, he was much urprized at this unexpected viit, but not o much as to forget hiding the Ring which he took from Atrea, when he threw her elfe into Lignon, and which he wore ever ince about her arme in the ame Ribband in which it was tyed: alo he neglected not to cloe her mock before her breat, let a difference of Sex hould thereby be dicovered, and let the faire Atrea hould ee the Picture which he ued to wear about her neck, and which that hepherdee knew very well; he held one hand before her face, and with the other took the heet and almot covered her elfe, as if he were ahamed to be een in that poture. Leonide to make her elfe merry, aid thus unto her; What do you think, Siter, of thee faire ones whom I have brought to helpe you up? Siter, aid Alexis, and raied her elfe a little up, you have done me a great hame, in doing me a great favour; for what will all thee faire ones ay, finding me thus long in bed? The wort they can ay, replyed the Nimph, is that you are a luggard, and that the Druids of Carnutes are not uch early riers as the hepheardees of Forrets? Upon this, all the hepheardees gave her the good morrow; and he after a general thankes for their Complement, turned towards Atrea in particular; and you faire hepheardee, aid he, how have you paed away the night? Siter, aid Leonide, hall I tell you for her? I protet he hath lain with you all the night. With me, replyed Alexis preently? Yes with you, aid Leon • Ede, if not in body, yet at the leat in minde. That way indeed he may, anwered Alexis; and I believe it, for I aure you faire hepheardee, (aid he, and took her hand) that the dicoure we had the lat night, has o taken up my whole mind, that I never lept until it was day.

Leonide, to give her dear iter the opportunity of talking more privately with Atrea, took Diana unto the window, and Phill • s alo: There he kept them in dicoure, whilt Alexis cauing Atrea to it down upon her bed, and till holding her hand, he was almot tranported with an extream deire to kie her. At the lat, fearing to dicover what he deired to hide, he contented her elfe with preing her hand betwixt hers: and after a while of ilence. I protet, fair hepheardee (aid he unto her) I have thought upon you, and the dicoure we had all the night long. But tell me, I beeech you; Is it poible that Phocion (as Leonide aured me the lat night) hould force you to marry againt your minde? Madam, anwered Atrea, 'tis very true, that it is his d • igne; but it is as true alo, that he hall never bring it to pae Not that I have o much courage as to contradict him openly, but I hall treat Calidon in uch a ort, as I hall drive him out of any uch fancy: Not but that I know the hepheard is a man of more merit then I deerve; but for all that, my genius is not agreeable, nor can uit it elfe to his. How is it poible, Madam, I hould ever believe Calidon loves me, when I know he loved Cel • dea above his own life, and this with excee of diobedience to an Uncle, who was unto him in lieu of a Father, and from whom he hoped for his etate. But I have heard ay, replyed Alexis, that now he is out of this humour, and does not love her. I believe it true, anwered Atrea, but it was when he had lot her beauty, and then his flame extinguihed; o that as oon as my face changeth, his affection to me will change alo. What a ad diater would it be to me, if I hould live to ee uch a change, nay the leat diminution of good will to me? But Madam, continued he with a deep igh, that is
not the principal difficulty; for perhaps I hould hope to keep his mind in due amity, having not o low an opinion of my elf, but that with a little tudy, I hould hold him within compae of duty to me. But there is another obtacle in the way which hinders me, from ever marrying, far greater then all thee. Yet, Madam, I dare not trouble you with any uch ralations, and what would you think of me, for being o familiar as to talke unto you of uch trivial matters? Alexis then haked her hand, and aid, Did you but know how infinitely I love you, certainly you would never peake thus unto me, who am infinitely deirous to know your buinee and intentions, that I may the better erve you in them; whether it be by my own endeavours, and by the meanes of Adamas, or any other way you hall pleae to imploy me. Madam, replyed Atrea, I am very enible of the great honour which you are pleaed to confer upon me in your love, and thinke it to be o high a happinee unto me, as I value it infinitely above my life: but as for the offer you are pleaed out of your abundant goodnee to make unto me concerning Adamas, I humbly beeech you never to peake unto him in it, becaue I would not have him imployed in a buinee of o mall a conequence, and which I can well enough bring to pae my elfe, auring my elfe that I can deal well enough with Calidon. I wih you may, aid Alexis, but I am affraid you will find it a difficulty: when I looke upon the beauty of your faire face; for beauty, faire Atrea, is Glue, or Bird-lime, which will never let go thoe wings which are touched with it. Madam, replyed Atrea, I am not owner of o much beauty; or if I were, I hope my reolution is tronger then all the violencies and wilfulnee of Love.

And be pleaed to know, that I will die a thouand death, rather then I will ever marry, ince it is the will of heaven, or rather my bad fortune o to have it. At this word he topped, and pulled out her Hankercher to wipe her eyes, for he was not able to withhold her Teares. And when he was beginning her dicoure againe, the coming in of Adamas prevented her; who coming into the Chamber by chance, and finding this good company there, he was orry that he had interrupted them: for there was nothing he deired more, then to ee Alexis and Atrea together, in hopes that this way would remit Alexis into his former condition, and conequently that his old age hould be very happy and contented, according to the Oracle. Yet eeming as if his coming in was of purpoe; and after he had aluted all the hepheardees, he aid thus unto Alexis: What Daughter, in bed yet? What will all thee faire hepheardees ay, eeing you uch a luggard! Sir, anwered Alexis, the fault is in my iter, who brought them hither without giving me any notice. The fault, replyed Adamas, is in your elfe, who are yet in bed; and if they erved you aright, they would pull all the clothes off, and teach you to rie ooner in the morning.

Then Atrea, who was rien off the bed, in reverence of Adamas: Reverend Father, aid he, There is reaon why we hould rie early, becaue we have flocks to look unto: Moreover, it is fit, Alexis hould preerve her beauty without taking any paines. You may ay what you pleae, replyed Adamas; But my opinion is, that if he will be fair, he mut doe as you doe; for your beauty may tell her, that your Receipt is a very good one. Atrea bluht a little, and would have replyed, if one had not come to acquaint Adamas, that Daphnide and Alcidon tayed for him in the great Chamber; And therefore, he taking the hepheardees by their hands, they all left Alexis to dree her elfe, whilt he went to hew unto this good company the rarities of his houe, which indeed were curioities of much admiration.

After all the Company was aembled together, and that to the great contentment of Hylas, Alexis was come unto them, Adamas thought it bet, before dinner, to hew them the Walkes, and the rather becaue the Sun was masked with many Clouds: Every one applyed themelves unto thoe that bet pleaed them, except Silvander, Hylas, and Calidon: For Paris tooke Diana whom Silvander out of repect was contrained to quit: Alexis till was with Atrea, which kept Hylas and Calidon from the happinee of talking unto this feigned Druid and faire Shepherdee. As for Calidon and Silvander they durt not hew the leat dicontent: But Hylas who was not accutomed unto any contraint M • tree, aid he, as oone as they were out of the houe, I beeech you let Calidon wait upon Atrea: Who then, aid Atrea, hall keepe the faire Alexis company? Pray good Shepherdee, aid Hylas, never take you any care; he that cares for the birds of the Aire, will not let her be without helpe; and for want of a better, I will tender my
ervice unto her, and at the ame time he took Alexis by the other arme. Truly (aid Atrea halfe angry that he could not be alone with Alexis) it is eaie to know Hylas, that you are none of the Shepherds of Lignon, for they doe never ue to be o impudently bold: I doe beleeve it, aid Hylas, and it is very likely, that they being Shepherds are not o couragious as I am: Methinkes, replyed Atrea, that ince you aume the ame habit, you hould alo aume the ame courage. No, no Shepherdee (anwered he) a Hero is not lee hardy for having a ruty Sword; but on the contrary, if examples of vertue have any influence upon Shepherds, Calidon whom I ee there looking upon you, as if he would began Alms; would doe as I doe. Atrea looked downe with her eyes upon the ground, fearing leat if this dicoure continued, that young Shepherd hould imitate Hylas, and o of one fault he hould make two, he was ilent, and aid not a word more: But Hylas oberving this, and having an opinion that if any would divert Atrea, he might the more eaily talke with Alexis, he made a igne unto Calidon, which made him more confident than uuall, and therefore after an humble reverence unto the Shepherdee, he tooke her arme, pretending he would helpe her to walke. The Shepherdee eeing there was no remedy, turned her head towards Alexis, and aid thus; I ee that bad examples are ooner followed than the good and I mut now recall that advantage which I gave unto the Shepherds of Lignon: Alas, aid Alexis, and hooke her head if our lives had none of thee bitter wormwoods, we hould be but too happy, he poke this in o low a voice, that neither Hylas nor Calidon heard her; yet the cold entertainment which this hepherd received from this hepherdee did make him thinke that he had much rather be alone with the Druide; but eeming to take no notice of it, he continued on his deigne, o as now there was none without a Companion but Silvander. But Laonice who till nourihed a pirit of revenge againt him, and ought for an occaion of doing him ome ignall dipleaure ever ince the day that by his judgement he lot Tircis; eeing him thus alone, he thought now that he had met with a fit opportunity; he knew already what affection he had unto Diana, and what affection Diana had unto him: For their loves being great, it was impoible to hide it from her who kept a very obervant eye over all their actions. Therefore eeing him alone, and very penive, he went unto him, and put on a face far different from her heart: Shepherd, aid he, I ee o many ignes of orrow painted in your face, as I cannot chue but thinke, that perhaps you are in love: Shepherdee, anwered Silvander, I have o many everall occaions of orrow, as you need not aske me whether Love be a caue: I thinke, aid he, you have no new occaions, for of late dayes you are more contented than uuall; but will you give me leave to tell you what I thinke? The caue of your melancholly proceeds either from a dieae preent, or from a dieae abent: You mut explane the Riddle, anwered the hepherd, before I can returne an anwer; I meane replyed Laonice, ince you would have me peake cleerly, that either griefe preent torments you, eeing another in your roome with your Mitree: or ele the good which is abent; for I know that you doe love Madonthe: Sage hepherdee, aid Silvander, I ee you are a great Propheree: For it is one of thee two that does torment me but perhaps (aid he and miled) not o much as you imagine. Sometimes in uch dieaes (aid Laonice) one is apt not to think themelves o ill as they are, but in good earnet Silvander, which of thee two is it that mot troubles you? Which doe you thinke, aid Silvander? If I hould tel you my opinion, aid Laonice, perhaps you would not confes it. Were it a crime to love, aid Silvander, I mut confee I had no reaon to confee; but ince it is rather a vertue, or at the leat an action which in it elfe is neither good nor bad, why hould you thinke I will not confee it; ince in denying a truth I hould commit a greater inne: Mot true, hepherd, replyed Laonice, for every one who would be eteemed good, ought above all things to be very carefull they never injure the truth: and therefore Silvander tell me upon your reputation; does not the abent good trouble you more than the preent evill? Silvander had no mind of making his affections knowne unto this tranger, if poibly he could avoid it, and therefore with a mile anwered her: I cannot chue but admire at the quicknee of your ight, dicreet Laonice; for I durt have worne that none had taken notice of thee things; but I beeech you, how came you to this knowledge? Silvander, aid he, content your elfe with this that all thee diimulations which you ue to Diana may perhaps amuze Therander, but not uch as have with my eyes oberved your actions: All thoe that live about the delectable River of Lignon,
have their hearts o poeed with their owne paions, as they never oberve anothers? have no eyes for any but for them they love. But I who have nothing ele to doe, but to oberve the actions of all, I doe plainly ee that Madonthe does pleae you more than Diana; but be not orry that I know it, for perhaps it will not be unerviceable to you: Madonthe loves me, and I think he will be eaily induced unto any thing I hall perwade; I know what it is to love, and which way to compae the contentments of it, and I promie you to aide and erve you in all I am able. Silvander could not chue but laugh to heare her talke thus, and to confirme her in the opinion which he had conceived, he beeeched her to be ilent, and above all, not to acquaint Madonthe, leat it hould offend her, and o ruine his whole deigne; he thanked her for her kind offers, which he would not refue, but would not make ue of at that time, for everall reaons which hereafter hould be made knowne unto her.

Silvander thought himelf very ubtle in this, but Laonice who eemed to beleeve him, began to contrive the michiefe which he intended him, upon it, and which ince he made him pay o dear for. In the mean time Paris and Diana were entred deepe into dicoure; for this young man was o inflamed with a violent affection unto this hepherdee, as he could never ret, but when he was with her. Certainly, if he had intended to love any, he would have pitched here; but ince the death of Filander, he would never uffer love to take any hold of her affections, thinking none worthy to be Succeor unto uch a hepherd as Filander. If he did afterwards love Silvander, it was not out of deigne, but upon a urprize which the merits and addrees of that hepherd made upon her; o as the good will which he had unto Paris was no more than as a iter unto a brother, and o farre he thought her elfe obliged by the affection he had unto her; and he was hindred from any farther, by the affection he bare unto the memory of the courteous Filander; yet he whoe affection had no limits, to render unto her all poible tetimonies of his love, he reolved to try his fortune, and thinking this opportunity to be good, he would not let it lip: leading her therefore by the arm, he drew her a little from the ret, and whilt every one was buied in their owne various conceptions, he poke thus unto her. I cannot chue but wonder, fairet Diana, that all my endeavours to doe you all ervice, hould not let you ee the great affection which I have unto you; or if you do ee it, I wonder more that it hould have no greater operation, nor produce any more reciprocall good will in your oule: Though my ervices cannot merit o high as love, for that were too much happinee, yet Methinkes they might at the leat produce ome parkes of good will, and be in ome degree pleaing unto you; I have tryed all wayes, and in this cannot but accue the meanee of my merit, and the greatnee of my misfortune; I have tryed, I ay, and doe find all wayes that are advantagious unto others who are in love, but find them all unprofitable unto me; you injure my extreame affection; my ervices dipleae you; my patience makes me depicable: my contancy tedious unto you, and the very age I pend in loving, erving and adoring you, is o terile, as you hardly take notice, I am any thing yours Oh Heavens, can uch cruelty, if not ingratitude, accompany uch a noble oule? will you never uffer my tears to mollifie your heart of Ad • man ••

At this word Paris was ilent, as well becaue he feared that his eyes could not retraine thoe teares which thee words would bring from his heart if he continued his dicoure, as becaue he would give Diana time to peake ome words of conolation to him. She, who did love him, as I told you before, not thinking him o deeply engaged in the Fetters of love, and deiring if it were poible not to let him depart dipleaed, after a weet glance of her eye towards him, aid thus unto him; I did not thinke generous Paris to have heard uch language from you, which is as farre from my expectation, as the Heavens are from the Earth; you blame me for being inenible, and that I doe not acknowledge the affection which you have unto me, and I beeech you, what would you thinke of me, if not loving you, yet I hould behave my elfe towards you as I doe: Have I not hewed you as much plauibility and favour as I am capable off? Did I not alwayes anwer you with all courteie and civility that was hanome for me doe; What can you deire more of me? do you ee me Garae any more then your elfe? do I not apply my elfe more unto you, then any other? and at this very time, do I offer to talk or glance any eye upon any but your elfe? Oh fairet hepheardes (aid Paris, and ighed) I do confes all you ay, and that you do more for me, than for any other: but
what am I the better, as long as you do nothing for any ele, nor me neither? If my affection were not as it is I mean, extream, perhaps I hould not with o much importunity beg tetimonies of your good will. And as much as you ay, you have done for me: what I beeech you have you done, but onely as to the on of Adamas the firt time you aw him, and before he gave tetimony of any affection? All your actions towards me, I mut confee are full of civility and weetnee, But are you not obliged to the ame towards all of my qualitie? Can you thinke thee duties that belong to my Name and Quality, can atisfie for thoe that are due unto a violent affection? No, no, fair one, Civility and Courteie will erve the on of Adamas, but nothing ele but Love can atisfie Paris: There mut be a reciprocall compliance, before I can leave complaining; and I mut blame you of inenibility, and my elfe of ill fortune, in loving o great a beauty with a hard heart. Then Diana after a little paue, returned him this anwer: I thought until now, Paris, that there had been nothing in my actions but what would have pleaed you, thinking that I had regulated them according to the Rules which Virgins ought to oberve, even when they have a deigne to pleae and oblige; but I perceive I was mitaken, but to hew my repentance, and how free I am with you, I will very incerely tell you my thoughts: I honour you Paris, as much as I do any man in the world; and I do love you as much as I do my brother; if this will not content you, I cannot tell what you can deire more.

Fair Diana, aid Paris, This Declaration is indeed very pleaing unto me, and as the Son of Adamas, I am fully atisfied; but, as Paris, not at all: becaue my affection requires nothing more; not Courteie for Courteie, but Love for Love. If you be not contented and atisfied with this I have told you Paris, replyed the hepheardee, you mut look for more from your elfe, ince you uffer your deires to go beyond due limits; and I have a jut caue of complaint againt you, if I would take it, for pretending more from me, then I ought to give 'Tis very true, replyed Paris, that you would have mot jut caue of complaint, if faire hepherdee, I hould deire any thing from you which was not fit for you to grant: But all my deires being grounded upon honour and virtue, methinks you hould not complaine againt them; And to open my heart mot freely unto her that owes it, know fair hepherdee, that I am o wholly devoted unto you, that I hall never enjoy any ret or contentment, untill you be alo mine, upon condition of marriage. You do me much honour, replyed Diana, in having uch thoughts: but you mut know, that I have Parents, unto whoe widome I refer all uch matters: and yet if you will have me hew you my very heart, I do weare, Paris, that neither you nor they, nor any alive, are able to move me unto any uch mind of marriage. I do love you as my Brother, but cannot as a Husband; and do not think this trange, for my minde is the ame towards all men living. Oh ye Gods, aid Paris then, mut I never receive any perfect contentment? You ay that you do love me as your Brother, but you ordain that this Love mut all my life long be a barren, teril, and fruitlee love, Paris, aid he, what would you have me ay? have you a mind I hould deceive you? or with ome mooth diembling language, give you ome deluding hopes? methinks I have obliged you in dicovering my reolution o freely and genuinely unto you. Oh hepherdes, aid Paris, with a profound igh, what a mot diobliging obligation is this? how many ad ighs and orrowful tears mut I pay unto your cruelty, to acquit my elfe of his fatal obligation.

They would have continued longer, when coming to a cros-walk, they were hindred by the ret of the company, who were returning to the houe; for Adamas was told it was dinner time, and Alexis tired with the talke of Hylas, and to be o long eparated from Atrea, he took all occaions of being with her againe; and as oon as he aw Diana, I beeech you fair hepherdee (aid Alexis unto her) help me to defend my elfe againt the fine dicoure of Hylas for I aure you, I know not how to anwer him: Mitree (aid Hylas) thoe that cannot defend themelves, they mut yield unto the courteie of their enemies. I had rather die (aid Alexis and miled) then render my elfe unto the mercy of uch a conqueror. Rather then you hould die, aid Hylas, I would render the victory, and yeeld my elfe the conquered. Truly, aid Alexis, you are very courteous: but, Hylas, I am of o proud a temper, and o little deirous to be obliged, as I know not whether I hould receive your offer. Why hould you make a quetion of it, aid Hylas? is it perhaps you corn it? No anwered Alexis; but rather becaue
I feare let being victorious in that manner, I hould be overcome. Oh heavens, aid Hylas, and cryed out, I ever thought it a dangerous buinee to love a learned woman, and one that is brought up amongt the Druids of Carnutes: I do vow and weare by the love I have to you, that when I began firt to love you, I was afraid of nothing more then that you were not imple enough. Why good Hylas (aid Diana, who was very glad to mingle dicoure, purpoely to be rid of Paris) would you love one that was imple? Truly, aid Hylas, I would not have her a fool, nor would I have her overwie; o he have as much wit as to believe all I tell her, I would not have her able to expound the deep ciences of our learned Druids. But if he hould have no more wit then to believe you, replyed Diana, you would be put to a great deale of paine, by reaon of the cure you would have in the carriage of her elfe. You are much deceived hepherdee (aid Hylas) for what is pleaure to one, is never painful. Some ay o indeed, aid Diana, but I do not think o; for I believe the pleaure onely keepes them from thinking of the paine: but that they have none is an error, ince if they be put to any violent exercie, they will blow and paint as if they wanted breath. See Diana, aid Hylas, you are one of thoe two, whom I would not love; you have too much wit, and put me to pain in tudying how to anwer you, which is a thing I cannot abide: but on the contrary, I hould be extreamly contented, if he admire all I do, and all I ay: from admiration proceeds from a good opinion, and from this good opinion will proceed the love that I deire.

Silvander who was neare, and watched for an occaion of econding Diana in her dicoure: Admiration, aid he, will work the contrary effect which you deire. Why o? aid Hylas; for if he admire me, he will believe me full of great and high parts; and when I peak, I am an Oracle unto her, my deires will be Lawes, and my will Commands: Admiration will produce quite contrary effects, replyed Silvander; For the learned ay, that Admiration is the mother of Verity, in as much as admiring any thing the minde of man is naturally apt to earch for the knowledge of it, and this earch makes him find out the truth: and o Hylas, in aying that he will admire you, you doe as much as ay, that he will know you; and knowing you, he will finde that if hee eteemed any thing in you, he is mitaken; and then in corning you, he will admire that he hould admire you: I perceive hepheard, anwered Hylas, that you are one of thoe wits, which, were I a woman, I hould never love: But though you can talk well, yet talke as long as you will, I am till in the ame opinion; for he who does admire whilt he is in that admiration, does he not infinitely eteem the party that caueth it? 'Tis true; aid Silvander; but then preently after that, he will change when he comes to the knowledge of the Truth. This, replyed Hylas, does give me atisfaction: for in aying he will change preently, let me tell you, my good friend Silvander, aid he, and clapt him upon the houlder, he may chance to doe as I may do; but let her make as much hate as he can, I will pardon her if he change ooner then my elfe: and if he do chance to be before me, faith ile over take her preently. This anwer caued every one to laugh, and this dicoure entertained them till they came into the houe, where the Table was furnihed with many delicacies, and every one at down as the night before.

All dinner while, nothing was almot talked on, but the merry humour of Hylas; and to put him upon dicoure, there was alwayes ome or other who took his part. Amongt the ret, Stella, who though he did it in hew to pleae the company, yet was it not at all againt her humour, he having all her life long followed the rules of this Doctrine. And Corilas who had heretofore reented the effects of it, hearing how he took part with Hylas: Shepherd, aid he unto Silvander, I beeech you tell me; is it true that love does grow from ympathy? All thoe who ever poke of it, anwered Silvander, ay Yes, Then, aid Corilas, am I the onely one that believes the contrary, and have had full experience of it: For can two humours be more like, than thoe of Hylas and Stella? and yet I do not ee there is any love betwixt them. There was not one at all the Table, who did not laugh when they heard this dicoure of Corilas. And when Silvander would have anwered, Stella interrupted him, in aying; I do not bluh, hepherd, at a thing which hath given me all the contentment I enjoy; for had I not changed when I loved you, I had lot it; and you mut accue the reaon which Silvander gave, for my changing which is, that Admiration is the mother of Truth: for at the firt not knowing you, I did admire you; and when I did know you, corned you; o as you may very
well give this Motto; Farre off, omething; neer nothing. But, aid he, and miled; as you ay, that I am Incontant for loving you once, and not loving you; o you may better ay that I am Contant, in changing once only and continuing in a reolution of never loving you, as long as I live. The quetion which I asked, replyed Corilas, is not whether you be a wavering Weather-cocke or no: But whether (Hylas and you being alike, and impathy being a caue of love) whether you doe love one another? Unto this he preently aid, I will tell you Corilas, that impathy may worke its effects, when there is no greater force to oppoe it; And that impathy which may be betwixt Hylas and me, might have o much force as to make us love, if it were not that knowing thee o little worthy of love, thou hat made me have uch an ill opinion of all other hepherds, as I know not whether ever I hall love any. You have taught me a leon, aid Corilas: For having had o much experience of you, I cannot conceive that thoe who are under the ame habit you are, doe not hide under thoe habits the ame imperfections: Fie, fie, aid all the hepherds, this, Corilas, is too much, to blame all the ret: No, aid Corilas, my intention is not to blame them: I onely ay, that I cannot conceive they have not ame imperfections; I doe not ay, they have them, and in this I blame onely my elfe, as not having the judgment to know the truth: But of all this, I accue this deceiver, who yet cannot glory in her victory, for he has paid deer for it.

Daphnid •
and Alcidon did hearken with much delight unto the dipute of thee hepherds and hepherdees, and admired that thee Rurall wits brought up amongt Woods and in Fields, hould be o polite and civilized. But Daphnide having a very curious pirit, and deiring to know every thing, he addreed her elfe unto the age Adamas: Methinkes Father, aid he unto him, that to part thee two friendly Enemies (for he knew they were o called) and to atisfie a curioity wherein I have long lived, you would doe very well to tell us what this Simpathy is, of which they peake, and whether it will caue love; and in o doing, you will feat us double, both in our bodies, and in our minds. Madam, anwered Adamas, your curioity is commendable, and did I not give it atisfaction I were much to blame, as well in not obeying what you pleae to command, as in not informing uch as deire it, as my charge obliges me; and the ooner, becaue I am able to doe it in few words: Be pleaed to know, Madam, that Tautates the upream Creator of all things, did make Heaven, which is his chiefet Manion, and the place where he created all oules, and becaue it is nothing likely that any thing hould come out of the hand of uch an excellent Workeman which is not in its full perfection, he formed the oule by intellectuall participation. Now this participation is taken from the pure intelligence of that Planet which is predominate when it is created, and this perfection which it receives, is o agreeable to it, as it is inflamed with love of that intelligence which did impart it unto it. And even as a Lover doth forme an Idea of the thing loved in his fancy, as perfectly as poibly he can, to the end it may fill the eyes of his oule, and pleae himelfe in this contemplation when he is deprived of the ight of that beloved face; o likewie this oule being in love with the upream beauty of this Intelligence, and of this Planet when it entred into the body unto which it gave the forme, it did imprint not onely the ene and the airy body, in which the learned ay it is wrapped but alo the fancy with this Character, with the beauty of which it was ardently inflamed in heaven, o as it can apprehend a figure and perfect reemblance of it: and pleaing it elfe in this contemplation it conceives a certaine naturall dipoition to eteeme all that reembles it good and beautifull, and to dilike generally all that is unlike unto it, accutoming its judgement in uch ort unto this will as it becomes habituall, from which we cannot refraine without very great force upon our elves: From hence it is, that as oone as we cat our eyes upon any one; if they doe report unto our oules, as faithfull Mirrrors, that there is in this peron omething which doth reemble that Image of Intelligence immediately we doe love, without any farther dicoure in our elves, or other earch for the occaion of this good will, being drawne unto it by an intinct which may be termed blind: On the contrary we doe hate, if we doe find them different; and this is it they call impathy, which is that conformity which we find betwixt one another; and which indeed is the ource of love and not beauty altogether, as many believe: For if beauty were the ource of love, it would follow that all faire ones would be loved of all: But we ee on the contrary, that not the mot faire and the mot worthy, but thoe onely who come neeret to our humour, and with whom we have mot conformity, are thoe whom we doe love bet.

Here the Druide topt, and Daphnide began thus; I mut confee with thankes, reverend Father, that you have at once cleered everall doubts unto me, yet one remaines in which I much deire atisfaction. If it be o that love proceeds from that reemblance that I meet with all in the party that I doe love: How comes it to pae, that the ame reemblance does not make him love me? For, if I do love by this impathy, and if this impathy doe come as you doe ay, Methinkes it is impoible but that he mut have the ame inclination unto me, that I have unto him; My meaning is, that the ame Planet mut have the ame influence upon us both; yet for all that we ee many who doe not at all affect thoe who are even ready to dye for the love of them. Your doubt, Madam, replyed Adamas, deerves a cleering; it is very ingeniouly moved, and hewes the excellency of that pirit from whence it comes.

Be pleaed therefore to know, Madam, that as I told you, the oule fancies unto it elfe an Idea, and the mot perfect image that it can of this Planet, and of that Intelligence or apprehenion which it loves; but in as much as, to repreent o faire and o perfect an Image, the matter is of uch an inferiour ort, as it is able to doe it but very imperfectly: It mut enue that this repreentation is not equally perfect in every one, becaue the matter of the body is better dipoed in ome than in others, and accordingly as the oul does find it, o does it worke more or lee perfectly; As in painting, if the pencill, and the colours be naught, the Painter mut needs make bad work, and but little reemblant unto the thing he would repreent, o the oule finding the body indipoed to receive the figure and lineaments, that he would give of this beauty which it loves, the reemblance remaines o imperfect, as the features are hardly knowable: And when this happens thus, doubtlee he that hath the mot perfect repreentation of this Intelligence, and of the Planet, hall be loved by impathy of the other who hath it, though ill done: For his oule, though it hath not the repreentation of this face which it loves, in this body, to the life; yet does love the Portraiture when he ees it well done in what place oever it be; but on the contrary, that oule which hall meet with a matter: well dipoed, and which by conequence hath the Idea and patterne well repreented; it daigns not to turne its eyes upon the other, either becaue it cornes it, eeing it o ill made, or becaue it knowes it not, having o little reemblance; and from hence proceeds that love which is not mutuall.

But (aid Hylas and interrupted) good Father give me leave to aske you one quetion: If thee loves proceed from impathy how comes it to pae, that after one hath loved another, he ometimes ceaeth that love; nay, ometimes to corne, and often to hate. This quetion, anwered the Druid, and miled, is a quetion fit for Hylas, and you may ee that this impathy is a blind intinct, ince Hylas loving and ceaing to love one and the ame ubject, yet he does not know why he does o: But Hylas, I will tell you, to the end that hereafter you may know the reaon of thoe things which you doe o well practie.

Imagine, Hylas, that thoe impreions which the oule makes in her body, by which he repreents this uperiour beauty of her undertanding, and of her Planet, be indeed corporeall: For he drawes the lineaments in the fancy, as a Lover does the features of thoe he loves in his imagination, and repreents them in uch ort in his enes, and in his complexion, as he makes his humour melancholy, if he have any influence from Saturne; and merry, if from Jupiter; and o of the ret. And afterwards, as we have already aid, he takes o great a cutome in contemplating and approving thee things, as he has made it habituall, which though it be very difficult to change or loe, yet it may be changed and lot. As we ee commonly come to pae, in wax and a eale: Though the wax have an impreion and figure, yet if one will make a new impreion, the ame wax loes the firt figure, and takes the new; o the oule having imprinted this Coeletiall Character in the enes, if they through careleenee be not pleaed with it, or ele any new objects make the will rove after them; it is certaine, thee will marke his fancy with another figure, and it will o loe the firt reemblance, as that it will retaine no hadow of it; and then the party who was loved by him, or who loved him by impathy loing this reemblance which he had, he loeth alo the love which it caued. For even as Habitudes, o impathy, may be lot, and gotten; but Hylas, if every time you have changed, you have imprinted a new Idea in your elfe, there is none in the world whoe impreions are not in you; o as my daughter may hope that you will be more contant
unto her, than you have been to all the world; not that he merits more then her world of Predeceors, but becaue he is the lat. Every one laughed at the concluion; and Hylas had anwered, if Atrea had not interpoed.

I beeech you, Father, aid he, if it be o that love doth proceed from this ympathy, how comes it to pae, one hould be long acquainted with another without any love, and yet love at lat? The anwer which I gave unto Hylas, replyed Adamas, may erve unto this quetion: At the firt, that peron had not the Character of the beauty of this intelligence; and ince by a new mark, as with a new eale, he might have it imprinted: but to demontrate it a little clearer.

The oul being wrapped in thee bodies of ours, as long as it is there hut up as in a Prion, he does not undertand, nor comprehend any thing but onely by the enes by which, as by o many windowes, he come to the knowledge of all that is in the Univere: And he does not onely not undertand nor comprehend, but by them; but alo he can neither undertand nor comprehend, but by corporeal repreentations, although he does tudy and contemplate the incorporeal ubtances. Hence it comes to pae, that he cannot have a knowledge of things more perfectly, then as the enes preent them unto her: and if they be fale and deluders, they deceive her, and caue her to be of a fale judgement; as we ee in uch as are ick, who think meats though never o good, yet to be ill tated, becaue their gut is depraved. So likewie, uch as have ill eyes, they oftentimes ee things double, or of another colour: or yet, though the eyes be good and ound, yet ome interpoitions betwixt the eye and the object may delude; as if they look through a blew or red Glas, all they ee eems to be of the ame colours: A traight taff put into the water, will eem crooked; and all things greater or leer, according to the qualities of the Spectacles through which they are looked upon. Now thee falities, being repreented by the enes, for truths, the oule which gives credit unto them, is preently corrupted in her judgement, becaue the things preuppoed, and from whence he drawes conequences, are uch: The Judgement being made, the Will immediately conents unto it: The Will, I ay, which has that which is good for her object, and that which is judged o, or which on the contrary, does fly that which he thinks to be evill.

And from hence you may undertand, fair hepherdee, that the reaon why ometimes we ee one whom we doe not love, yet afterwards do love; is, either becaue our eyes and our enes, whoe office is to preent thee things unto the oule, are not faithful in the functions; or ele the Mediums by which they act, have ome imperfection which hinders them from doing their duties faithfully; which imperfections being removed, they come to dicover the truth, and relate it unto the oule, which then finding this reemblance, brings ardently to love that which before he aw and did not care for.

Diana, who hearkened very attentively unto Adamas: Reverend Father, aid he, and miled, I would gladly propound one quetion unto you, did I not thinke I hould be too troubleome in it: No, aid Adamas, whatoever o weet a hepherdee hall ask, I hall anwer if I be able: Surely, aid he, the wie Adamas is able to anwer many more, then uch a filly ignorant hepherdee as I am can aske. Tell me, I beeech you, ince love proceeds from ympathy, which is an image repreented in us, of that Intelligence and Planet under which we were born; how comes it to pae, that faire ones are commonly loved by every one? For it hould eem that all thoe who love, are born under one and the ame planet, which we know they are not, being borne at everall times.

I ever expected, anwered Adamas that this ubtil hepherdee would aske ome quetion which was not common; but I will try if I can anwer it. All fair things, although they be differing, yet have ome conformity amongt themelves, as all good things have; and therefore ome have aid, That there is but one good, and one faire, after the imilitude of which all things good and faire are judged to be uch. Now thee Planets, and thee Intelligences which govern them, are neither good nor faire, but onely as they reemble mot the upream good and faire. And though they are amongt themelves eparate and differing; yet they are not amiable nor etimable, but as they are good and fair: And this Goodnee and Fairnee having alwaies conformitie, though they be in divers ubjects; it need not be thought trange, if many doe love thoe perons who are faire, though they be not born under the ame Planet, ince every one oberves in their
beauty omething which is conformable unto their owne.

I am now, replyed Hylas, the mot contented man in the world, for I have learned one thing which will be highly advantagious unto me. And you Silvander, aid he, and turned towards him, you have reaon to be mute at this dicoure, for it nothing concernes you. I do not know, anwered Silvander, wherein it will much advantage you. O ignorant hepheard, replyed Hylas, didt thou not hear the wie Adamas ay, that the reaon why faire ones are loved by o many, was, becaue their beauty had a conformity with all the Planets and Intelligencies? I heard it very well, anwered Silvander; but what does that advantage you? In this, replyed Hylas, ince I do love o many everal beauties, it argues that I have conformity with them all; o conequently am fairer then you are, who never looks but upon one. I think, replyed Silvander, and miled, that if your argument be good, you are not onely fairer then I am, but then any in the Country, nay then all, put them all together; but you mut not undertand the dicoure of the age Adamas in that ort; but on the contrary, if you remember what he anwered Daphnide, you will finde that it is a igne of a great defect in you, who has the portraiture of your Intelligence and Planet o ill made, as there is not one of thee faire ones who does not didaine to ee in thee o great imperfection of a thing o perfect.

This moved all to laughter, and Hylas had replyed omething in his own defence, had they not rien from the Table, it being very late, and becaue Atrea did very well remember the counell which Leonide gave her, to entreat Adamas that he would be pleaed to come unto their Town, and offer the acrifice of Thanks for the fortunate Misletoe; he took Diana, Phillis, Celidea, Stella, and the ret of the hepherdees a part, and propounded to them, that ince the hepherds had already hewed their forwardnes in requeting Adamas to offer this acrifice; it was fit they joyned with them in the ame deires, and to try if they could carry him with them when they returned. Every one approved of the motion; and after a conultation, who amongt them hould be their peaker, it was agreed, that Diana hould be the mouth of the Company, which he accepted of, though at the firt he made ome difficulty. So then addreing themelves unto Alexis, they intimated unto her their deires of peaking unto the age Adamas, they deired that it might be by her meanes. Alexis never asking what the buinee was, went preently unto Adamas, letting him know the deires of thee dicreet hepherdees. Then Diana in the Name of all her Companions, delivered their Petition in very elegant terms. And added thereunto, that they would eteem it as a high favour, if he would be pleaed without any longer delay, to go now along with them; alo did humbly beeech him, to let the fair Druid his Daughter, and the Nimph Leonide, honour the acrifice with their preence.

Unto which upplication, they received this Anwer from the Druid: Fair and dicreet hepheardees, your requet is o jut, and I am obliged o much to ee the honour of the great Tautates performed, that upon one condition, I am ready to do as you deire, I am mot confident anwered Diana, that there is none here, who are not pleaed with any thing you hall be pleaed to command. I deire then, replyed Adamas, that you will tay with me all this day, that I may take order for all things neceary for the acrifice, and I promie you that to morrow I will conduct you to your Town: And I hall mot humbly deire, that this Lady (aid he, and addreed himelfe unto Daphniae) will do us o far honour, as to be an aitant at this acrifice of Thanks, as well to render this honour unto our great Tautates, as to oblige us all, in not parting o much good Company. The condition upon which our Petition depends, replyed Diana, is o much unto our advantage, as we cannot deire a more noble favour.

Thus the voyage of Adamas was concluded upon, and he at the ame time in order to his promie, beeech' • the fair Daphnide he would be pleaed to be an aitant, which he freely conented unto, as well out of her complacency, as out of her great deires to ee the manner how thee hepherds and hepheardees do live, of whom he heard o much. Alexis was a little tartled at her returning unto her Town, being till in extream feares of being known: Yet eeing it was a thing reolved upon, he diembled her feares as well as he could. Atrea, after thankes returned unto the Druid for this great favour, he came to rejoyce with Alexis, becaue they hould enjoy her company a long time. 'Tis I, fair hepherdee, replyed Alexis, who ought to rejoyce the mot, and, who can mot truly ay, that I was never better pleaed at any thing, ince I came from the place where
I had my education, than I am in my contentments of eeing you. Madam, aid Atrea, heaven forbid I hould ever doubt of any thing you ay: but I mut needs confee that if I could, it is of this, becaue I can hardly perwade my elfe that I, inconiderable I, who am o very unfortunate, hould have any thing in me, which can merit, or which is capable of receiving o high a favour.

Faire hepherdee, anwered Alexis, you may very well beleeve what I aid, for I never ue to lie, and beleeve it alo, that I had rather dye than either lye or diemble unto you whom I love o well. Does it pleae you then Madam, replyed Atrea, that I hould beleeve it o? Not onely pleae me, aid Alexis, but I doe infinitely deire it with all my heart. Then Madam, aid Atrea, I would with all my heart alo, it would pleae you to let me live with you as long as I live, which if you doe, you will make me the happiet and mot contented woman in the whole Univere.

p.U: aid Alexis, and tooke her hand, I am affraid you will quickly repent of this reolution: Did you Madam but know Atreas humour, replyed the hepherdee, you would never thinke o, for he is of uch a Nature that never alters a reolution once taken. Alexis upon this tood till and poke not, and going a pace or two backe, did looke upon her with the ame eye he did, when he commanded her never to ee her again, and this thought did o frehly bring into her mind all former paages, as it was impoible for her not to give ome knowledge of her elfe, by the teares which trickled from her eyes, which yet he had o much power over her elfe as to retraine after a few drops.

eeing uch a udden alteration in her, was much atonihed, as not being able to imagine the caue, nor conceive that any thing he had aid could poibly dipleae her: And in this perplexity they both tood a long while peechlee; at lat the hepherdee was the firt who began to peake: Madam, aid he unto her, I ee that you are changed upon a udden, and I cannot poibly chue but be exceedingly troubled at it; if I be the caue, either by my dicoure, or otherwie, I doe vow by that oule which loves you above all the World, that I will preently be revenged upon my elfe for it; if I be not, then tell me I beeech you, if my life can doe you any ervice, and you hall ee there is nothing o deare unto me, which I would not acrifice unto it. Alexis, knowing her fault, and checking her elfe; did endeavour to excue and hide it as well as he could, and therefore with a deepe igh, he anwered thus; Tis true, faire hepherdee, that the alteration which you oberved in my face, did proceed from you, and yet you are not to be blamed, but onely my owne oule, which is too enible of a thing which your words did bring into my memory: And to give atisfaction unto your perplexity, you mut know, that I being brought up amongt the Virgin Druids of Carnutes, amongt the multitude that was there, I made choice of one, whom above all the ret eemed unto me mot amiable, and thought my elfe not mitaken in my choice, he being eteemed o amongt all our Companions, and having all deirable qualities which ue to create love: She was faire, hanome, and as well extracted as any in all the Country, her wit was utable to the perfections of her body, everyway accomplihed, and all her actions were weetned with affability and civility; her weetnee flowed o upon me, that I loved her, and becaue I thought he loved me, I loved her extreamly, and this love came to that height betwixt us, that I could not live without her, nor he without me: Thus we paed over many yeares with abundance of content and atisfaction from each other; but whilt I thought my elfe more happy in this condition of friendhip, than the greatet Monarch can be of his Dominions, this faire one quitted me, and o eperated her elfe from all termes of friendhip with me, as he would never ee me againe, and without ever telling any caue fell into uch hatred of me as he would never come neere me

div.p:
My perplexity at this alteration was o great, and the blow o enible, as I becoming all orrow, I fell icke, and o dangerouly, as I beleeve you have heard, that I thought I hould never recover it. Now when you fell into expreion of your contant and unalterable humour, I remembred the like expreions which this faire and wie Virgin ued unto me, and which were o ill oberved, and this caued the alteration which you oberved in my countenance. Madam, aid Atrea, I am orry that I hould be any way the caue of your perplexity; but I hope you will thinke me innocent, for had I knowne it, I would never have committed this fault: But who would ever have thought, that you who are o faire and full of all perfections, enough to invite and keep the whole world in love with you, hould ever find a woman o imple and inconiderate, as to let a happinee
voluntarily ecape her hands, which every one ought to deire and covet? Oh God! Oh Heavens! Oh all thats acred! how carefull hould I be in keeping o great a happinee, if Heaven beyond my merit hould ever raie me to o high a fortune? And with how much carefull aiduity hould I court it, if by my care, paines, and travell I had any hopes to obtaine it? But Heaven, which has looked upon me with a frowning eye ever ince I was borne, will I feare never be o favourable to me as long as I live. Faire hepherdee, aid Alexis then, let me intreat you, that unlee you will exceedingly dioblige me, accue not this faire and wie Virgin of any crime in treating me after this manner: For I cannot endure without much dipleaure he hould ever receive any blame, for that which is only my fault, and the ill influence of that planet under which I was born. And as to your deire of my ucceeding in her place, beleeve it Atrea, it is I that would covet it with any Art, but for one thing which gives me a checke. And mot auredly were it not for that conideration, my deires of it hould exceed yours But, faire hepherdee I fear, that though now at the firt, you judge me worthy of your amity, yet when you do particularly know me, your judgement will find it elfe mitaken, and looke aquint at me as this faire and wie one did, whoe loe I doe o adly reent; and if uch a fatall chance hould befall me I know not what would become of poore Alexis, being able to ay, and truly, that I doe find my elfe o weake againt uch fatall blowes, as I know not whether my life will lat after I have received them. And ince it hath pleaed the great Tautates to recover me from the danger of the lat. I mut confee that my feares of falling into the like, makes me tremble, and turnes my blood to ice. It does not plea • you Madam, replyed Atrea, I hould ay that this faire one was to blame in treating you thus, and therefore becaue I will not upon any conideration whatoever dipleae you, I will not ay it; but by your permiion I will ay, that he will never find uch a jewell as he has lot; and that if Tautates as a mot particular bleing would preferre me unto her roome, I would not part from it for a thouand worlds. Ah faire hepherdee, aid Alexis, and ighed, if uch a happinee hould befall me, I hould vaule your amity at as a high rate, as you can mine: But beleeve me faire one, you know not what you deire, when you deire my amity. I confee Madam, what you ay, anwered Atrea; for the happinee which I deire is o high, as the weaknee of my undertanding is not of capacity to comprehend it: But Madam, ince it is not the meanee of my merit, what is it which hinders you from doing me this high favour, ince I doe call Tautates to witnee, that if I be o happy as to obtaine it, I will preerve it deerer than my life; nay, even that life which would be an infinite happinee, if you thinke me worthy of it. Alexis upon this, welling with contentment, he tooke her hand, and graping it a little, aid unto her; faire hepherdee, remember where we leave this dicoure, and we will finih it to morrow, as we goe unto your Towne; in the mean time, be aured that I have a greater inclination and will to love you and erve you, than you can tell how to deire.

The reaon why Alexis referred this dicoure untill another time was, leat lookers on hould have any upition, had it continued longer; beides, he could not there hide her bluhes and alterations in her face, as he hoped to doe by the way, when every one would imploy their eyes in looking at their feet, and chuing the way: And beides that, he intended to advie with Adamas and Leonide what to doe upon this occaion: And by fortune, Hylas, as if he had been ome expree Envoy, came to interrupt their dicoure. Mitree, aid he, if you continue talking thus long with this hepherdee, I hall beleeve you thinke the hepherdees of this Country more amiable than the hepherds. Never doubt that, aid Alexis, and lay the blame only upon Nature which inclines every thing to love its like; but Servant be not angry nor troubled at it, for I have love enough for you yet. I thought, replyed Hylas, that being brought up amongt the Druids and learned Virgins, you had knowne the Lawes of Nature better than you doe; but ince you come from amongt them o ignorant, I will intruct you Mitree a little better than they have done. Perhaps Servant, anwered he, and miled, you will loe both your time and your paines as well as they; and therefore I advie you to let it alone: Yet I cannot endure the wrong you have done me, replyed Hylas, without complaint, ince you will not be told of your faults and intructed in your errours. I hould be orry, aid Alexis, that Hylas hould complain of me in earnet, but I hope he is onely in jet. How can you thinke I hould chue but be angry? replyed Hylas, when I heare you ay that you have love enough yet left for me, after you have loved thee hepherdees? It eemes
I mut be contented with the refue of others, and take what they leave: I do expect, Mitree, that they hould have what I leave, and all reaon requires it o. If that be it which angers you, replyed Alexis, and miled, we hall make all traight. I will divide my amity into two, one half hall be to love hepherdees, and the other hepherds; and amongt all the hepherds you hall be in the firt place. But of thee two parts, aid Hylas, Which hall be the prime and the greater? There is no quetion, anwered Alexis, but it mut be that which is to be imployed amongt hepherdees; and with reaon, becaue of hepherds, you are the onely one whom I will love: and of hepherdees, there is not one whom I will not love and erve. Then (aid Hylas) I mut confee you are in the right, and that I am too blame for accuing you of ignorance, ince I ee you are more knowing then even Silvander is.

Whilt they were talking thus, the ret of the company were dicouring upon everall ubjects in the Great Chamber; and Phillis who had her eye continually upon Atrea, eeing Calidon going towards her, and knowing he had a deigne of particular dicoure with her, he advanced to interrupt them, and left Silvander alone with Diana; for as fortune was, Paris deiring to conult with Leonide, he was gone with her to her Chamber, o as Silvander had the opportunity of coming nearer this hepheardee, with whom Phillis alwayes tayed, until Calidon caued her to go away: And becaue there was continual contets between them, Mitres (aid he as he went away) I would not have you think me jealous, o as I dare not leave this hepherd with you; for I am o confident of my good fortune, and of his hallow merit, as I do not at all fear him: And to hew the truth of my words, I will leave you both together, whilt I go and helpe Atrea in a great Combate which I ee he is preparing for, againt an approaching enemy; o without tay for any anwer, he went towards Atrea, who imagining the occaion of her coming, took her by the hand, and pulled her o near, as Calion could not well accot her. But that young hepherd who was really wounded with the beauty of Atrea, could not forbeare from coming to her: and becaue his addrees unto her were known unto Phocion, who liked very well of it, and was advied unto it by Thamires, he thought it no matter, though he poke unto this hepherdee in the preence of any other; and that Phillis perhaps would help him out in the declaration of his minde, becaue he might think it a match advantagious to her companion. Phocion had already declared himelfe to be of the ame judgement, who was held to be one of the wiet Pators of his time, and Uncle unto the hepherdee, and who ince the death of her Father and Mother, had ever as much care of her, as if he had been his Daughter.

Approaching therefore with this aurance unto this faire hepherdee; Shall I not be too troubleome (aid he unto her after a alute) if uncall'd, I make a third in your Councell? Never Calidon, anwered Atrea, for he cannot be troubleome in what place o ere he comes, epecially unto us who highly eteem him: I could wih, anwered the hepherd, that this Epithete of Eteem, had been changed into Love. Sometimes we doe wih (aid the hepherdee) things that are prejudicial unto others, and not advantagious to our elves. I do believe (aid Calidon) that what you are pleaed to ay, may fall out in any other occaion ooner than in this which preents it elfe. For, fair hepherdes, give me leave to tell you, that you may believe, my deires are not diadvantageous to you, ince the aid Phocion is of another judgement: Phocion, who in prudence and widome, is reputed for the Oracle amongt all the hepherds of this Country, and who did me the honour to grant my requet which I made unto him by Thamires. Alo, to ay it is any prejudice unto my elfe, it cannot be, for on the contrary I hall never enjoy contentment until it be brought to pae. I cannot tell (replyed Atrea, with a little anger in her eye) what the requet whereof you peak may be; But if it be any thing that concerns me, there is none who either ought or can promie any thing for me againt my will and conent, ince my Father and my Mother, to my ad misfortune, are both taken away. And as to what you ay concerning Phocion, you cannot tell me any thing of his prudence and widome, more then I do know; but this does not conclude him and I to be both of the ame judgement: and though that his may be the better, yet it mut be ome time before I can conent unto it Alo to tell you truly, I do believe that if this wie Pator did know my mind, he would quickly change his opinion; and that is it, which makes me entreat you to change yours; for if you do continue in it, beides the doing of your elf no good, it will draw much dicontent both upon your elfe, and me.
Fair ones, replyed Calidon, are like unto Gods, they will be overcome by upplications. I cannot tell what fair ones you meane, replyed Atrea; but I am mot ure, that neither your words, nor your prayers, will ever obtaine any thing from me that will pleae you. Perhaps, aid he, that when you ee me even ready to die before your faire face, you will not be o extreamly cruel as to let no pitty be found amongt o much beauty. If you continue, anwered Atrea, you will make me believe, that you think you are till talking to the fair Celidea. But Calidon, to be free and plain with you; ince death hath taken from me, him whom I deired, I will never give death o much advantage as to deire any more; do not think but that I do eteem and honour your merit, as much as I do any hepherd in the Country: I do acknowledge my elfe obliged unto you for this addree, but never thinke that thee coniderations, or any other whatoever, can ever make me alter my will: And take this as a Doom written by immutable detiny. Since Atrea hath lot her firt Love, he hall not love any other but Tautates, unto whoe ervice he hall devote all the ret of her life.
