Conider this Calidon, and believe this Prophecy, which if you doe not, time will tell you how true it is, and make you repent of your incredulity.

This Anwer was o reolute, that Atrea amazed the hepherd, o as he troke him dum, and could not reply; and the hepherdee eeing him in uch a confuion, he roe up and left Phillis in her room: Then he went towards Alexis, who eeing her coming, and knowing by her looks that he was troubled, he left Hylas to aske her what the matter was. Madam, aid Atrea unto her, with a mile mixed with didaine, you may think that it is eaie for me to upport my burthen, but I was never more weary of it in all my life; for the importunities of thee Lovers are abominably troubleome. Calidon knows how to chue his time, and he knowes how well dicoures of Love does pleae me: I advied him to continue, if he did intend to loe his labour and his time, and that perhaps he thought he was peaking unto Celidea. Then he related unto the Druid all the dicoure, and the anwer he had given him, with o much paion, as Alexis aw that there was no feare of this Rival.

In the mean time, Silvander was with Diana, he at, and he kneeled, and o over-joyed to ee himelfe with her, in the abence of Paris and Phillis, as he could not be thankful enough to Love for o great a favour. Mitree, aid he unto her, How hall I begin to thank you for this high favour, in taying here with me, whereas you might pend the time in talk with thee kind hepherds, and fair hepherdees? Silvander, aid he, though I would oblige you, yet in this I do not do it o much as you ay; for I am confident there is none in all the company, who would not be glad to change places with me: and I weare hepherd, that I think my elfe o well, as I would not with them. Did I think, replyed Silvander, that your heart is conentant to the harmony of your tongue, I hould think my elfe the happiet hepherd in the Univere. If that be all thats wanting to make you happy, replyed he, be confident Silvander, that then you are as happy as you can wih. What aurance, aid Silvander, can I have of it? You are a peron of o much judgement, anwered the hepherdee, as you will quickly find the truth of it, if you will but be pleaed to look for it; or if you could not, what ele, do you think could tay me here? I could find excues in abundance to go away; But I rather fear, Silvander, that I am wearyome to you, and that it is onely civility which keeps you here with me: Fairet Mitree, aid Silvander preently, This exces of kindnee which you are pleaed to hew me, does but offend me, ince if you have that opinion of me, or think me a man of o weak a judgement, you doe a manifet wrong unto your and my affection; for certainly I were a man without common ene, if I did not ee the perfections of the faire Diana, which every one that ees, confees, and admires. Is it poible that Silvander hould be the onely man that is blind? Can he not ee the Sun when it hines? But the truth is, I am o dazled with o great a light when I am with you, as I have no eyes but onely to ee, nor pirit, but onely to adore divine Diana upon earth, whom I hold trancendent to her in the heavens, ince the one is urmounted in Glory by the Sun her brother; but the other urpaeth all that is in the Univere. Silvander, aid the hepherdee and miled, I permit you to ay what you will of me, who knows well enough what I am: but who would ever have thought, that the wager which you undertook, could inpire you with uch fained expreions. But as to your wager with Phillis; how long hepherd, mut I be your Mitree? when mut I change that Name to that of your Judge? Thoe expreions wherewith I am inpired, replyed Silvander, are o full of
reallity, as they have no dependance upon the wager: And as for the name of Mitree, whereof you peake: beleeve it faire Diana, that you may take the name of Judge when you pleae, but never can hake off the name of Mitree, which not the wager, nor fiction, but your perfections and my affection have o jutly gotten upon my oule. I have formerly told you, replyed the hepherdee, that I allow you to peake thus untill the wager be decided; but pray tell me, when hall we all three be dicharged of this buinee? For it has continued o long that the term of three Months is almot doubled. For my part aid Silvander, I hall neither prolong nor retard the time, being aured that come when it will, I hal not alter my condition. Do not talk of the future, aid Diana, but with doubt, ince none but the gods can tell what it will produce, but tell me Silvander, hall we imploy the afternoon in ending the difference? I conceive it a convenient opportunity, and we hall have as good aitance, as we can deire.

Silvander knowing that he could not hope to live with her in uch freedome, when this fiction was taken away, he made a top, and did not returne an anwer to the hepherdee, which he perceiving how he was perplexed, it did the more aure her of his affection; but feigning, as before accutomed; why do you not give me an anwer, hepherd, aid he, would you have us take this convenient opportunity, or would you have it deferred untill to morrow when we are at our owne Town? See what a tractable Judge I am, I refer it unto your will. My Judge, aid Silvander, and miled, before I give an anwer I beeech you let ome Articles pae betwixt us; promie me that your judgement hall pae to my advantage, and that the thing which is mot pleaing to me, may not be forbidden me, and then if you pleae I will receive your doome before I depart from this place. My judgement, aid Diana, hall be jut; and as for the forbidding which you o much feare, let me undertand what you meane, and I will anwer you. Silvander then auming a more erious looke: I never had the leat doubt, aid he, but that you would be mot jut; but give me leave to tell you, that extream jutice, is extreame injury; and becaue you deire an expoition upon my econd requet, I conceive Mitree, continued he, and miled, that it is bet to defer the buinee untill another time, to the end, I may have the more time to informe my Judge: Upon this, they were interrupted by Adamas, who invited Daphnide and the ret of the company to goe and walke; for the heat of the day being over, it was more pleaant abroad than in the houe. And mot of the company being deirous to take the Aire, the delightomenee of the place inviting them, they all et forward, ome inging, and others dicouring upon uch ubjects as bet pleaed them.

The Cavalier who was cloe by the Temple of Atrea, taking the ame way that Paris went, he came preent to the bridge of Botereux, and a little after to the height of the Plaine which dicovered the Catle, and great Cittie of Marcellies. The Country eemed very delectable unto him: For on the one ide he aw the fertile Hils of Couant, which from the tops to the bottomes were enricht with many Vineyards, and upon the tops of all, great Woods, which Nature had placed there to fence them from blutering winds; The Plaine extended it elfe as farre as Mont Brion, and following thoe delightfull Hils enlarged it elfe towards Surida, Mount Round and Feurs, with o many little Rivolets and Lakes, that the variety made the propect beyond imagination pleaant: And becaue the way in which he was, conducted to Marcellies, and his face being that way, it was the firt place his eye fell upon. The Catle, cituated upon the point of a Rock, which made it obvious to the eye, and een farre, did preently bring into his memory, the place where he firt aw Madonthe: For its grandure, its Towers and magnificence of tructure had a great reemblance of the place where he dwelt. This Memorandum brought into his fancy the many pleaing paages which formerly he had een with her, and the extream perplexities and orrows he had utained ince his digrace: And becaue this comparion could not chue but much trouble his mind, this poor Cavalier was contrained to lite from his hore, and ret himelf under the firt hade he found, where leaving his Hore with his Servant, he went under a hady tree, he lifted his eyes up to heaven, & tood o ravihed in contemplation, as he could neither hear, nor ee anything about him

The Servant, who did exceedingly love his Mater, and was orry in his oule to ee what a mierable life he lived, did heartily cure love, and her that was the caue of it. By fortune at the ame time, hearing a voice, he began to liten, and tepping a little neerer aw a Cavalier complaining againt the ingratitude and incontancy of a Lady. And becaue he thought this would be a good excue to make him retire from his ad thoughts. Sir, aid he unto him, hearken I beeech you unto the Cavalier is inging who
is neer you. Away, away, aid he, I care not for medling with the matters of another: Dot thou not thinke I have enough to doe with my owne? The buinee of another, Sir, replyed the Servant, may doe good if good ue be made of them: Upon this they hearkned, and heard the Cavalier inging a very invective ong againt his owne Lady, and againt all others.

The one Cavalier hearing the other blame all women againt reaon for the fault of one was much offended againt him for it, taxing him with indicretion and injutice: And thinking that if he hould uffer it without revenge, and let uch blaphemies pae unpunihed, he hould commit a great fault againt the faire Madonthe: And therefore he would preently make him eat his words, and cry mercy for the injurious language he had uttered; but upon better conideration he thought it more expedient to give him occaion of eeking Combate; for, aid he, if he be couragious, he will reent the offence I hall give, and require atisfaction, and if he be a Coward, he is not worthy my fighting with him. In this reolution, the Cavalier roe up, and turning towards the other Cavalier, after he had a little conidered what he hould ay, he ung in as loud, and ditinct a voice as he could, a ong which intimated, That ince he aw how incontant his Lady was, it was his part either to die, or ele cure himelfe with didaine of her.

This being ditinctly heard by the other Cavalier, he could not chue but thinke that thee words were intended againt him. And being one of the mot couragious Cavaliers in all that Country, he tooke it for uch an affront, that without more adoe, he pulled downe his Helmet (for he was armed Capape) and went through the Wood to the place from whence the voice came.

The other, who expected to ee what effects his anwer would produce as oone as he aw him coming, and being reolved that if he did not reent his words, he would adde uch as hould provoke him to fight But the arrogance of him with whom he had to do was uch, as he needed mall provocations, as well becaue he was confident of his own trength & skill, as becaue he was Nephew unto Polemas, whoe authority was o heighted ince the departure of Clidemant and Lindamor, as he was neere the capacity of making himelfe abolute Lord of the Seguians. The name of this Cavalier was Argenteus; he was taller than the common height, and o well proportioned every way, as it was eaie to judge him a man of great trength and courage. He had long courted one of Galatheas Nimphs, and whether it was true or no, I know not, but o it was, that he thought he loved him: her name was Silere, one that was very faire and highly hanome; but when he was urgent with her for ome tetimony of her good will, and when he denied him, he according to his arrogant humour would needs ue a kind of authority over her; which he taking very ill, he choe rather to break quite off with him, than any longer to endure his arrogancy. He eeing himelfe deceived in his hopes, fell into uch a paion of anger againt her as he conceived an extreame hatred againt all women whatoever for her ake, and ever ince, did vent the mot bitter invectives againt them, that he could invent.

Argenteus then, according to his cutome, arrogantly approaching the other Cavalier without any alute or action of civility, was it to me Cavalier (aid he) that you intented your ong. The Stranger who naturally could not put up any incivility, and being already ill atisfied with him; Take it as you will, aid he unto him, I perceive by your armes and your language, (aid Argenteus) that you are a Stranger: For did you know me, you would give me another anwer; but ince it is o, either get upon your Hore, or ele be as you are on foot, and I will make you know your folly and rahnee. Then loe no time (aid the Stranger) but on foot let us end the difference: Upon this he tept into the high way, he drew his word, and tood in uch a bold poture that Argenteus judged him to be a brave Cavalier.

When they were ready to begin fight, they heard a great noie of Hores and Coaches, which came from Marcelleis traight towards them. This moved Damon to ay, that he thought it better to goe into the Wood, and let the Company pae, leat they hould be interrupted: But Argenteus who did imagine that it was Galathea or Amais, and was very deirous to hew his valour: No, no, Cavalier, aid he, never let us hide our elves but when we do ill, and therefore as you ay, let us loe no time, unlee your heart faile you to maintaine your quarrell My quarrell, aid he is o jut, that though in other occaions I had no courage, yet I hould in this, not only againt you, but againt all men
living. But if as you ay, ill actions ought to be hid, I know not a place dark enough to hide yours, who maintaines a thing o unjut, and o unworthy the name of a Cavalier, in blaming Ladies whom every Cavalier is obliged to maintain, erve, and defend. Alas my good friend, aid Arganteus, and mocked him, how long have you been a high-way Orator: It is with this, aid he, and hewed him his word; that I ue to peak; and if you have courage, you hall find that I can doe better then you can peak.

Upon this, they fell on very furiouly, and as tout a Combate it was, as could be een betwixt two valiant Cavaliers: They were no ooner warmed in the fight, but all the company, whom they aw coming, arrived at the place: And becaue the Combat was in the high way, and every one knew Arganteus, they topped to ee what would be the iue. Galathea, who was in the Coach with the Nymphs, did hate the arrogance of Arganteus, and they all wihed he might be punihed for it by this tranger. But knowing his great valour, trength and skill, they were much afraid he would be too hard for this unknown Gavalier, though his hanome preence and good beginning got him a good opinion amongt them. Galathea eeing Polemas near her Coach, called unto him, and asked who it was which was fighting with Arganteus, and what was the caue of the quarrel, and whether it were not bet to part them? To which he anwered, That it was injurious to hinder them from ending their difference, ince they fought upon equall terms, and without treachery: And as to the Cavalier and their Quarrel, he could meet with none that could inform him, but the ervant unto the tranger. Polemas anwered thus, becaue he was very confident in the valour of Arganteus, and that the tranger would not be able to reit him: and he was very deirous that Galathea might ee the valour and courage of thoe that had relation unto him. But he according to the curioity of all Ladies, being deirous to know who this tranger was, caued his ervant to be called unto her, whom he asked who that trange Cavalier was, and how the quarrell began. The caue of their quarrel, Madam, anwered he, is very jut on my Maters ide; For he hearing that other Cavalier peaking very ill of all women, he could not endure it, as thinking it againt the honour of a Cavalier: But as for telling you who he is, I am orry it is forbidden me; yet I aure my elfe, that as oon as the Combat is ended, he is o civil as to atisfie your demands. Polemas laughed to hear him peak thus, and in mockery aid unto him; well aid my good friend, thou art in the right, when thou aidt, my Lady hould know, when the Combate is ended; for his Epitaph upon his Tomb will tell her. Sir, aid the ervant to him, if my Mater had not come off a more dangerous enterprie then this, he would never have been able to come o farre as he hath done upon this he retired to the place where he tood before.

During this dicoure, the two Cavaliers continued the fight mot furiouly; and Damon had uch a deire to come off with honour, as there was not a by-tander, who did not eteem him a very brave Cavalier, epecially Galathea, and her Nymphs, in whoe eyes might their contentments be een, when Damon got any advantage, which they would not diemble though Polemas tood by, becaue it was their caue in which he fought.

It was now near half an hour ince they firt began blows, theirs Arms were broken and hattered in everal places, when Argantens felt himelfe omething faint, and was not o nimble, nor laid on uch vigorous blows. On the contrary, Damon did not onely eem hearty and freh, but did rather increae in vigour and agility, which did exceedingly trouble Polemas, but more Arganteus, who did now begin to eteem his enemy very highly; but preenly after, the trangers word did reach his body almot at every blow, o as Arganteus fainted down right, either by reaon of the loe of blood, or greatnee of his wounds. Now Polemas did heartily repent that he did not part them at the beginning of the Combate, and wihed that ome good genius would move Galathea to interrupt them: he who perceived how Polemas was troubled, although he did not love him, yet would give him this atisfaction in repect of the ervice he did her Mother; and knowing no better way to part thee Cavaliers, then by entreating them her elfe, he came out of her Coach, and withal her Nymphs came to the Combatants; At the very ame time Arganteus not being able to utaine himelfe, fell on his knee, and eemed as if at the ight of thee Ladies, he had done it purpoely to ask them pardon for the injury he had done unto women. But becaue Polemas thought Galathea too low, and that his Nephew who drooped already, would be quite dihonoured if he tayed
any longer; he made a ign unto ome of his ervants, who preently gallopped, and fell upon Damon, who never upecting uch treachery, nor had o much as looked back but for the cry of Galathea and the Nimphs, towards whom turning his head, he aw even or eight Cavaliers coming towards him with words in their hands, and menacing him. All he could do, was to recoil unto his ervant; but his courage was mot high and admirable ince coming out of this Combate, after which he tood in need of ret; as oon as his ervant brought him his Hore, he vaulted into the addle without any tirrup; and he tood in need of all his agilitie to ave himelfe from the hurt they would have done him; for he was no ooner in his addle, and the bridle in his hand, but he had them all upon him, do what Galethea could, who was much terrified with all her Nimphs amongt all the hores. As for Polemas, he faigned that he never aw the confuion, being with Arg • nteus, and taking order concerning him.

In the mean time, thee Cavaliers did o aault this tranger, as though at two blowes he ent two of them out of the Combat, yet could he not prevent a wound in his houlder, and his hore from being killed under him, with everal blowes which they gave him in his flank. The tranger perceiving him to faint under him let go his tirrops, and jumped nimbly upon the ground, which helped him very well, for the Hores of his enemies would not come near unto his being dead; yet it was impoible to ave himelf long, without ome unexpected helpe.

The Nimph who aw uch bae injury done unto this Cavalier, and not being able to endure it, he cryed, and threatned the men of Polemas; but one amongt their who commanded the ret, and to whom he had made a igne, knowing his maters will, and eeming as if he did not heare Galathea, did till command them to kill the Cavalier; when, as fortune was, one of the Lions of the Fountain of Loves Verity, eeking for his prey came amongt the hores.

This Lion was o great and terrible, that all the Hores when they aw him come amongt them, took uch a fright, as there was neither Cavaliere nor Servant that could be mater of his own, but all ran away. That of Polemas and the trangers ervant, getting the bridle in their teeths, they ran as far as the Town of Boen, no Bridge, no Gate, no Hedge, nothing could top them; thoe that tayed with the Coaches, took uch a flight, that they never tayed till they were above a league from the place, where they were overturned, and all the Coaches and Harnees torne in pieces; o as it was a thing impoible to bring them back that day: as for Arganteus, they had et him on hore-back, but he was not able to hold himelfe on, o as being foraken by all thoe who held him, at the firt tart of the hore he fell down, and o unluckily, as he broke his neck: Thus ended the proudet, and mot arrogant Cavalier in all the Country, and his hore by fortune running away for fear, and almot over the tranger, he ran him through the body with his word, and he fell down dead by his Mater. The Nimph thanked God for this encounter, for he knew that the Lion would not doe any harme, being o inchanted as he could not offend any, but thoe who would try the adventure. And yet preently after he was driven into feare; for the Lion who came onely to eek for his prey of food, eeing the trangers hore dead, he began to eat upon him: But the Cavaliere having received o much good fortune from him, thought it a kind of ingratitude to een him torn in pieces without defending him; he went towards him with his word drawn, which the Nimph eeing, and fearing let the Lion being provoked hould hurt him, he cryed out, and entreated him not to go any further: But he could not endure this indignity, he went traight to the Lion, but becaue his back was towards him he would not trike him behind, and made him turne the other way: The furious beat, eeing himelfe threatned with a word, he leapt aide, as if he would have run towards the Nimphs, which the Cavalier fearing, he was much more exaperated to interpoe betwixt them, o as the Lion who was till before him, began to roar out extreamly, beating his taile againt the ground, grinning with his teeth and parkling eyes, he eemed as if he would preently fall upon him, and but for the inthantment, doubtlee, he had; But that force being above his, he was contrained to turne aboue, and went to feed upon the hore of Arganteus, of which after he was atisfied, he carried part of the ret, according to his cutome, unto the other Lion which guarded the Fountaine. The Cavaliere eeing the Lion going towards Arganteus, and fearing let he hould devour his body, he tood by it, and guarded it, not being willing the Corps of o crave a Cavalier hould be abued
But when he aw him gone, then he went to the Nymphs, who having beene Spectators of all his generous actions did highly eteem him. He addreed himelf firt unto Galathea imagining it to be her, as well by her Majetical deportment, as by the honour which all did doe unto her; and after civill alutation, he beeeched her to pardon the inconveniency which upon his occaion he had received.

I am very orry Sir for yours, anwered he, and extreamly angry againt the indicretion of thoe who have o unworthily and inconiderately aaulted you in my preence; but I promie you, Sir, that beides the correction which you have given them, I hall caue them to be punihed according to their merits. Madam, anwered the Cavalier, I hould be very orry that any who are in your ervice hould receive any dipleaure by reaon of me: I deire rather to erve them all, and beg your favour upon them, Madam, and beeech you not to refue it at my requet Sir, aid he, it mut be you that mut forgive them, ince it is you whom they have offended; It is not the part of thee Ladies and my elfe to deny you any thing you hall pleae to aske, ince you have o well defended us againt this dicourteous Cavalier; and would have defended us from the Lyon; but we will peake of this another time. In the interim I thinke you have received a wound in your houlder, it is requiite the blood hould be topped, untill we come to a place where the wound may be dreed. The wound whereof you peake Madam, replyed he, is but a cratch; and all that you pleae to ay I have done for you, is farre hort of what low, and which I would mot willingly pay in your ervice: But ince all your company is cattered I beeech you give me leave to conduct you unto ome place of afty, for I perceive this Country is not without very dangerous Beats, o as it is not afe to go without good guard. Galathea miled, and aid: I perceive Sir that you are a Stranger ince you doe not know this Lyon to be inchanted, o as he will doe no harm unto any unlee unto uch who will try the adventure of the Fountaine which he guards, and had you not provoked him, he would not o much as have looked towards us. I could not endure, aid he, that he hould tear my Hore in pieces before my face, much more that Cavalier, who though indicreet, yet was very valiant and couragious.

Silvia, who paed behind this Cavalier to looke upon his wound, tooke notice that it bled till which caued her to ay unto Galathea; Madam, you talke too much unto this Cavalier, for he bleeds very fat: Then they went all unto him, and almot by force bound up his wound with their Handkerchers and made him a Scarfe to hold up his arm. Then Galathea conceived, that ince their Coaches came not, that it was the bet coure to walke gently unto Mount Verdan, where they might conveniently tay, doubting that the Coaches were overturned and broken: And becaue the way was but hort and very faire, all the Nymphs approved of the motion; and therefore the Cavalier tooke Galathea by one arme, and Silvia tooke her by the other; and all the ret followed, dicouring upon nothing ele but the valour and merit of this Stranger: ome extolled his combate; others blamed the wrong that had beene done him; Some admired his boldnee, and others could not highly enough eteeme him for defending his dead Hore, and his intention to defend the Corps of Arganteus? But all deired mot paionately to know who he was, uch extraordinary favour had his valour purchaed him amongt the Ladies.

He had not yet pulled up his Helmet, and walked on as if he did not intend it; when Silvia oberving the curioity of all her companions: Is it not trange Madam, aid he, that we hould be o much obliged to this brave Cavalier, and neither know his Name nor his face: If you pleae, we will make tryall of his courteie as we have already of his valour: for he walkes on with his Helmet downe as if he were yet in hand with Arganteus. The Cavalier not taying for Galatheas anwer, anwered: For my face, Madam, it hall not be concealed from you if it pleae you; but as for my name, I beeech you let it be concealed till, becaue I am ure you know it not. To which Galathea anwered; You may, noble Cavalier content us in both, if you pleae, and indeed you ought not to make any difficulty of it: For ince you ay we doe not know it, you may hew it and atisfie us, and yet it is no more known than before. I ee Madam, replyed he, that it is an eaier thing to vanguih Cavaliers, be they never o valiant, than to defend ones elfe againt faire Ladies. I will therefore addree my elfe unto upplications; and of two things which you aske I will atisfie you in one preently, and beeech you to d •• er the other untill we come to Mount Verdan. It hall be then, replyed Galathea, upon condition of granting one thing which I will aske you.

There is nothing Madam, which you can command, replyed the Cavalier which I will not obey, and atisfie withall my power. Upon this, lifting up his Helme, he appeared to be very faire, he was young, and his paines in the combate had put uch a freh colour in his cheekes, as none could by his face ee the adnee of his oule; and this was the reaon, that all eeing him o very faire, they were the more impatient to know who he was: And had they not eene the aged Cleontine coming with a great number of Virgin Druids, with ome of the Vaci and Eubagi mot certainely they had gotten him, not onely to tell his Name, but alo what fortune brought him thither: But he anwered, how one ought never to depaire of aitance from heaven, epecially when one has right on their ide.

Whilt they were talking thus, the age Cleontine was come o neer, as Galathea tepping a little before, received her in her armes, and held her o whilt he aid; What doe you thinke Mother of the Equipage in which we come? I doe not thinke you expected us in this manner I did not expect Madam, aid Cleontine, that you hould take o much paines as to come o farre to ee me, for when you have any ervice for me, you may command me to come unto you; but you doe honour our great Tautates in condecending unto o much humility, as coming unto this acred place, where it pleaeth him to render Oracles. I mut confee, aid Galathea, that my deign was to come hither, but not o oon. Upon this Galathea aluted the Virgin Druids; and afterwards, continuing her way towards Mount Verdan, and not eeing Celidea amongt the ret, he asked where he was: Madam, aid he unto her, never was a more happy marriage, than that between Thamires and her; and I doe not thinke that any who ees them but doe deire to marry: And what's become of Calidon, aid the Nymph: Oh Madam, anwered Cleontine, he is perfectly cured of the dieae which he caued in him, he has now no other thoughts but of marrying Atrea. How, replyed the Nymph, will Calidon marry Atrea, and is he conenting? who is it that makes this match? It is, aid he, Phocion, Uncle to Atrea and Thamires, who is very olicitous in it, but I am affraid it will hardly be a match: For Atrea is o avere unto it, as they will have much adoe to get her conent. And why, aid Galathea does he love any other Shepherd? We do not heare, replyed Cleontine, that he loves any yet, for he is too buie in lamenting her loe of Celadon, and erecting him a Tombe. What is become of that hepherd, aid the Nymph: I thinke Madam, aid Cleontine, that about even or eight Months ince, he was drowned: And why, aid the Nymph, doe they make him an empty Tombe? Becaue Madam (aid Cleontine) that the learned Sarronides and Druids tell us the pirit of him who dies, will wander and walke many ages if thoe who urvive doe not pay the office of Sepulture: And becaue the body of Celadon was not found, they erected him this empty Tombe of which I told you: How, replyed Galathea, when he was drowned, and his body lot, was it never ince found? Never Madam, aid Cleontine, that we could hear of, and it is to be beleeved that all the hepherds about ued all endeavours poible; for never was any hepherd in this Country more beloved, nor any truly more deerved it: And Madam had he been o happy as to be known unto you. I am confident you would have thought him o. And as I hear, this hepherd had a long time beene a devoted ervant unto Atrea, but carried the matter o cloe and dicreetly as none could perceive it; and the lee becaue it was unlikely ever any love hould be betwixt them by reaon of an inveterate enmity that had long been betwixt their Fathers: And becaue cloe and mothered love is alwayes mot violent, probably o was theirs, both in that repect, and in repect of both their merits: For I dare ay Madam, and with abundance of truth that I never in all my life aw a fairer nor more accomplihed hepherdee. Now Phocion, who is her Uncle, and who, as next of kin, has the care of her, would gladly marry her unto Calidon, who indeed is a very fine hepherd; but there is o much difference betwixt him and Celadon, as it is very unlikely, that hepherdee will ever conent epecially having yet Celadon o freh in her memory; yet Calidon till hopes, and keepes as cloe to her as poibly he can As for Thamires, he lives the mot happily and bet contented of any man in the world, and ayes that the cars of Celideas face being tetimonies of her vertue, doe make her so faire and amiable, as he cannot deire her otherwie; and in this contentment, he is o well atisfied, as he cannot be an inch from her: I am very orry he is not here, that he might have the honour of kiing your hand, as much disfigured and ill favoured as he is. But Atrea, Diana, Phillis, and other hepherdees of the
neighbouring Towns, are the caues of her miing this honour, having yeterday invited her to viit the Daughter of Adamas, who is returned from the virgin Druids of Carnutes, and reputed one of the fairet Ladies, and the mot dicreet in all the Country. Perhaps, aid Galathea, Celidea will return at night, then we may ee her. I wih it, Madam, anwered Cleontine; but I am afraid that Thamires who accompanies her, is the caue of her tay; for it being late, he will not let her travell, becaue he is extreamly careful of her health; beides, I know the venerable Chriante will not let her part from Bonlieu.

Thus Galathea, without eeming to take any great notice of things, gleaned from the dicoure of Cleontine, all the tate of Celadon, and of his love; yet much wondring that none hould know what was become of him. Then conidering with her elfe that this hepherd not being in this Country, he was to blame in accuing Leonide, he intended to call her unto her again, and in order thereunto reolved to pae by the houe of Adamas, as well to bring her away with her, as in hopes to meet Atrea there, of whom he had heard o much, to the end he might judge, whether her beauty was uch as might invite Celadon o much to light hers. In thee thoughts he could not refraine from ighing very loud, which Cleontine oberving; Oh Madam, aid he, why do you igh? Is there any thing which troubles you? Galathea having no mind he hould be the ecretary of her thoughts, anwered her; I igh Mother, to think of Clidemant, you know where he is, and there are many occaions of danger to caue feare of his being well. It is many dayes ince either Amais or I heard from him; and of late the Vaci tell us, that when they look into the intrals of the Victims, they find the mot noble parts defective: Moreover, I have had ome very horrid Dreams, and believe it, thee things much trouble me. My Mother alo, who is fuller of apprehenions then I am, hath thought it fit we hould offer ome acrifices, and that I hould come to conult with this Oracle, whether I intend to come at my return from Bon-lieu, where I am going to offer ome acrifices unto the Gods in lieu of her, who this morning deigned it her elfe, but being prevented by ome intervenient and important buinee, he commanded me to go in her room. Madam, anwered the age Cleontine, our Great
• autates, is o trancendently good, that when our ins doe call for chatiements, he gives us advertiement of it, to the end that the feare of future evill may make us turn to him, and that with acrifices, upplications, and amendment, we do appeae his anger, and divert the punihments from us. And therefore, Madam, thee advertiements are not to be depied; for if they hould, it would make his hand more havy upon us, for having o little care of his advice: Let Amais and you, lay thee things to your hearts, ince it is to be believed they are not without great reaon. Examine well all your actions, and if upon a trict urvey you finde any that is not good, reprove them your elves, and not tarry till Tautates make you more enible of them: Afterwards make a trict inquiition what is done in your houe, and if you find any offences in it, reform them o as they may be no more committed: Then let your eye be over all the Country, and diligently inform your elves what abues are predominant and ued there; chatife thoe that are the Authors of them; for that tate where vice goes unpunihed, and vertue unrewarded, is very near deolation. Know Madam, that the Prince and the State are but one body, whereof the Prince is the head And as all the paine which the body reents does come from the head, o all the paine which the head endures, does proceed from the body: My meaning is, that as Tautates does chatie the people for the fault which the Prince commits, o he does punih the Prince for thoe which the people commit. This Madam is the counell which I give unto you, and which my profeion would not uffer me to be ilent in

Galathea thanked the age Cleontine for her prudent and religious admonitions, promiing her, not onely to oberve them her elfe, but to acquaint Amais with them, that he alo might follow them: Afterwards, he related unto her the accident which had hapned, and how much it troubled her; for beides the death of Argenteus, the inolency of Polemas in her preence was very ditateful to her, o as it wounded her to the very oul. Madam, anwered Cleontine, uddain paions are often to be excued, becaue they are often not in our own power; and if we do not bear with one another in the infirmities of our humanity, how hould we thinke Tautates will bear with us. But aid Galathea, for Polemas to doe thus unto a tranger, one that had right on his ight, and in my preence; let me tell you Mother, that it is a boldnee which proceeds from omething
ele then courage, and induceth me to thinke, that he who dares do thee things does think he may do omething which is wore. Indeed, aid Cleontine, when a ubject does faile in that repect which he owes unto his overaigne, he does it either out of defect in his judgement, or ele becaue he thinkes himelfe o powerfull, that he feares not not any dipleaure, and therefore it concerns him to take good heed.

With uch dicoure as this, they came to the houe of the age Cleontine, into which Galathea entred, as well to ret elfe as to get the trangers wounds dreed, unto whom all the Nymphs could not do too much honour, nor hew too much demontration of good will: epecially Silere, who when the time was, would have been orry for his victory, before Arganteus trangreed the limits of his dicretion; but ince his love was turned into didaine, he fell into o great a hatred of him, as he had courage to look on him when he was dead, without betowing upon him one ingle tear; o much did the preent injury deface the memory of all his pat ervices.

The Cavalier was preently diarmed, and earched by the Chyrurgions, who found onely one wound in his houlder, which was o light that they made no matter of it, onely advled him to keep his bed that day, by reaon of the loe of blood. Galathea deiring to offer the acrifice which he reolved upon before he went from the place, he ent to provide bulls and other things neceary againt the next morning: Alo he reolved to enquire of the Oracle, and the Cavalier beeeched her, that he might conult with the Oracle alo, and joyn their acrifices together: She was pleaed to gratifie him o far, as to permit him, although it was not altogether the cutome: In the mean time, they ent out every way to enquire of their Coaches, and the ervant of the unknowne Cavalier.

After they had dined, and every one expected to heare ome newes of thoe that were thus cattered, Galathea itting on the Cavaliers bed-ide, and eeing all ilent in the Chamber, he aid unto him; Although, ir, we are much obliged to you for the Combate you undertook againt the inolent Arganteus, yet you are in one thing obliged unto us; for when we entreated you to pull up your Helmet, and tell us your Name, and what fortune brought you into this Country; you were pleaed to atisfie us in letting us ee your face, but the coming of the age Cleontine hindred you from anwering the other part of our deires; but ince we have een your face, it does the more inflame our deires of knowing unto whom we are o much obliged; and what was the caue of your coming hither: And all this, that we may the better erve you in any way we are able. Now is the time convenient; there is no feare of any prejudice to your wound, and therefore we hope that you will atisfie our deires. Madam, anwered the Cavalier and miled, Does the demanding of a thing make it a debt? Sir, replyed the Nymph, It is the peculiar priviledge of Ladies in this Country; and you know that every one is obliged to the obervation of the Lawes belonging unto that Country wherein he is. 'Tis true, Madam, aid he, but my greatet difficulty is, not without reaon; That I cannot imagine you hould take any delight in hearing the diaterous fortune of the mot mierable Cavalier that lives, if it be living, to conume his life amongt all the mifortunes and mieries that a man can poibly meet wi • hal. Let not this be any difficulty, aid Galathea to him, ince in acquainting us with your misfortunes, we are deirous to erve you, and may help you. Madam, aid he, If my misfortunes be contageous, we had abundance of reaon to fear them. No, no, Sir, replyed he; let every one beare their owne burthen, and I am ure there is none in all the company but thinkes their own the greatet: open therefore your wound unto us, ometimes one may meet with another, who is able to give unexpected remedy. It is not the hopes of any Remedy, replyed he, which will move me to hew mine, for I know there is none but death: But it is onely, Madam, to obey you, and atisfie the curioity of thee Ladies: Then raiing himelf up a a little in his bed, he began thus:

div.head: The Sequell of the Hitory of Damon and Madonthe.
div.p: I Should thinke that I had great reaon to complain againt my ad fate, which hath o inceantly purued me ever ince I was bome, at least ever lince I knew my elfe, if I did not conider, that thoe who complaine and murmur are inners againt the great Tautates, as if we were not all his, and would not uffer him to have the free dipoition of his owne, and all that is in the Univere: This conideration has often tyed my tongue, when extremity of orrowes would have moved me to murmu • againt my Fortune; yet if in the violence of my paine it be permitted to let go ome ad ighes, wonder not Madam I beeech you if in the equell of this dicoure you oberve me ending forth ome ad ighes at the memory of o many misfortunes And beleeve, that if it were not your expree command, I hould not relate my mierable life, the memory whereof cannot chue but make my wounds bleed afreh.

Be pleaed to know then, Madam, that my Country is Aquitane; I was educated by King Thorimond, one of the greatet Princes that ever reigned over the Viigots: A Prince o good and jut, that he got the peoples love as much as if they were Viigots. This King raied his Court unto a higher pitch of glory than any other neighbouring Kings, both by his arms, and the civility of thoe that were about his Peron: We were a jolly company of young boyes brought up under him with as much care and indulgency, as if we had beene his owne: Of this Volley was Alcidon, Cleomer, Cel • das, and many others who all became very brave and gallant Cavaliers; it was my fate to be brought up amongt them, and I may ay, that this education was the onely peece of good fortune that ever I had. My Father, whoe name was Beliantes, and who by his vertue was raied unto great Authority about Thierry, he left me an Orphan in my cradle, there begining the fortune which ever ince hath purued me: For, not being willing I hould ever arrive unto that credit which my Father had gotten, he deprived me of it when I was ucking my Mothers bret, and preently after tooke away my mother alo, and made me mourn in my cradle.

At my coming out of my infancy, I cat my eyes upon a faire Lady, whoe name I deire to conceale, as well as my owne, becaue I would not dicover all my miery. Nay, nay, aid Galathea, we mut needs know both her name, and yours alo; for there is nothing you can tell us which we more deire. Then, aid he my name is Damon, and hers Madonthe. How, replyed the Nymph preently; Damon who erved Madonthe, Daughter unto the great Captaine of Aquitane, whoe name was Amorant, and killed in the Battle of Attila upon the body of the valiant King Thyerry, and whom Leontidas would have married to his Nephew? Are you that Damon, who out of jealouie fought with Therander a little before the death of Thorimond? I am the very ame Damon of whom you peake, replyed he, that is the mot unfortunate Cavalier that lives, or ever did live: You doe infinitely atonih me, aid he, for every one beleeves you to be long ince dead, and that you ent your ervant with a Hankercher full of your blood, unto your Mitree, or rather unto the wicked Leriana, as a tetimony of your death. Tis true, replyed the Cavalier with a deep igh, but fortune intending to perecute me more yet, would not let me go o good a way: Truly, aid the Nymph, many are deceived; for the opinion of your death is pread all the Country over, and nothing is thought more certaine.

I do remember, that when the newes of your death came hither, and relation was made of your Love, of your Jealouie, and of your death, many did pitty you, not only becaue you were dead by o ill a way, but becaue you did not live to ee the revenge which was upon the wicked Leriana, every one thinking that your fidelity and your affection did merit o much atisfaction before you dyed, as to know the innocency of the poore Madonthe. But how was it poible you hould be aved from that mot deperate danger? Madam, anwered the Cavalier, ince I perceive you are informed of all paages as well as my elfe, I will only relate unto you what hath chanced unto me ince my combate with Therander, and o abridge a great part of my dyatrous life.

The truth is, I received in the combate which I had with Therander very many wounds, and amongt the ret two very great ones, which put me into good hopes of
dying, having no deire to live, ince he for whoe ake onely my life was deer unto me had o cruelly betrayed me. In that deigne, I took the blindet way I could chue, thinking that when my blood failed me, I hould end this mierable life; and in this reolution, when I found my elfe begin to faint, I commanded Hall • dine my ervant to carry unto Madonthe the Ring which I tooke from Therander, and unto Leriana my Hankercher full of my blood: The one, to hew unto her whom I loved, that he was to blame in preferring one before me, who did lee deerve it, and the other to glut the cruelty of Leriana. I perceived by the anwer which Halladine gave me, that if I had followed his directions he would have gotten me unto ome place where wholeome remedies might have hindred me from what I deired, my death.

This conceit, and finding my elfe faint, did make me trive to get unto the River of Garrone, and by chance I came unto a place where the bank was very teep, and under it o full of points of little Rocks, that I thought when I fell I hould certainly be dahed in pieces before I came to the water; but my faithfull Servant whoe eye was never off me, perceived my deigne, as I thinke by my eyes which perhaps were tartled at the horrour of death, and to prevent it, tepped neerer, and catched hold of me. But ee Madam, what a man will doe that is reolved to dye: I forced my elfe o uddenly and vigorouly from him, as I fell, and never touched any of thoe harp Rocks, becaue I over leaped them: Thus Fortune was pleaed to ave me againt my will, and my extreame deire of dying may be aid to be the caue of my not dying. My Servant cryed, and ran preently about to looke for me at the bottome, and finding me neere the ide, he took hold of me; but the tream was o trong as it pulled him into the water after me, and it was a very miracle that he ecaped drowning, for the place was o full of weeds as his feet were intangled in them; but it is to hew others that the Gods never forake thoe as are faithfull to their Maters; he was o intangled that he lot me, and knew not what was become of me, for I being further in the water than he, the tream was o trong and impetuous, as it carried me away, ometimes under, and ometimes above the water, neer halfe a mile from the place; and doubtlee I had beene carryed into the Sea, had I not been topped by ome Fihermen, who by fortune were upon the River in their little boats: They pyed me afar off, and not knowing at the firt what it was; a deire of gain moved them to eparate, ome one way, and others another, to be ure of catching me; but when I was a little neerer them, they plainly aw that I was a man; and then, beides aurance of booty, a charitable dipoition moved them unto their bet endeavours, and with a long hooke catched hold of my clothes, and then pulling me into one of their little boats, they carried me on hore, where laying me along upon the and, and tripping me, they perceived that I had everall wounds, and that they were freh; at this they were much atonihed, and much more when rifling my pockets, they found a good quantity of money, and on my fingers three or four Rings of good value: Upon which, one of them aid, that this day was either their enriching for ever, or ele their utter undoing: For, aid he, here is riches enough to erve us all as long as we live: But if ever this come to the eares of jutice, it will be aid that we killed him, and condemne us for not revealing it; o as if we conceale it we are made for ever, and if revealed we are all undone, all of them apprehended the ame, and knew not what coure to reolve upon; at lat, one of them having a little more reolution than the ret: Brothers, aid he, let us bury him, let us hare and keep the riches which Tautates hath ent us, & not reveal it unto uch as who doubtlee will take them from us; we know that we are not guilty of this mihap, and ince we are not, be aured that God will protect the innocent, and therefore let us divide what we have found, and live happily all our dayes after it.

As oone as this motion was made, it was conented unto by the ret, and preently they fell to divide, but in the firt place they made a grave, in which they would inter me, and till then would not divide, to the end every one hould worke at it with the better will.

Whilt they were thus buied, there was an old Druid, who eeing thee Fihermen afar off, he had an opinion that they were dividing their Fih; this Druid was a holy man, lived a very godly and exemplary life, and fated almot every day and therefore he was loved honoured and reverenced by every one. This grave old Druide, had in his younger dayes followed the glitering follies of the world, as others did; but having found them all to be but empty pleaures, he retired himelfe from the frequent ociety of men, and
lived in a little Cabin upon the top of a Rocke cloe beides this River, and that he might the more freely be devoted unto his contemplation, he deveted himelfe from a good etate which was decended unto him from his Ancetors an action which brought him o much eteem in all the Country, as he was reputed, loved and feared as a acred Servant, and reall friend unto Tautates.

This Druid then, pying thee fihermen digging in the ground, he came unto them, and they were o buie at work, as he was very near them before they aw him, and o near, as he could ee a naked body, riffled from its clothes; I know not which were mot atonihed, they in eeing him o near as they could not hide my body, or he in eeing as he apprehended, o many murderers. For he verily believed that they had killed me; and the rather, becaue coming nearer, he aw the blood freh; for blood ran till out of my wounds, as freh as if the wounds were newly given. When he was come up unto them, and aw thee wounds thus freh, and them bloody, he began to reprehend them very everely, and menace them with the punihments of God and men. Doe you think, wicked wretches as you are, aid he unto them, that though you hould hide this body in the very center of the earth, Tautates would not dicover it to the ight of all? Can you think this blood does not cry to heaven for vengeance? and that you can fly into any any part of the earth where jutice will not find you? How durt you for a little mierable gaine which will deceive you, commit uch an execrable wickednee? Thee Fihermen, who were not of any wicked temper, as afterwards they hewed, did bear a very great repect unto this Druid; fell down upon their knees before him, proteted themelves innocent of the blood, told him how they drew the body out of the water, what their deign was, that they had no arms to make thee wounds, and that if they had been guilty, they could eaily have fled when they aw him coming, and paed unto the other ide of the River, but they tayed till, and would tand upon their jutification.

The Good man conidering all thee circumtances, he began to think they poke truth; but the better to know it, he came unto my Corps, and eeing the wounds o freh; Doe you tell me, aid he, that you are innocent of his death? We do weare it, aid they, by the acred Misleto: Then, aid the Druid, you may doe well to looke out for the Murtherer, for doubtlee he cannot be far from hence; and beleeve it, if you do not find him out, you your elves will be accued for it: And becaue I would not have the innocent punihed, and the guilty go free, where are his clothes which he had when you firt found him? The Fihermen, as if they had been already in the hand of the Judge, and never thinking upon their reolution, they did not onely produce what the Druid demanded of them, but alo the money and Rings, and all that they found. Then the good Druid, aid unto them; Now friends, I doe thinke, you really innocent, ince you doe o freely produce thee pretious things; be certain that God will ait you both in this occaion and all others. Then preently falling downe upon his knees, and making a igne unto them to doe the like.

Oh great Tautates, cryed he out, and lifting up his hands and eyes to Heaven; Thou who hat a particular care of men, we beeech thee to turne thy vengeance from us for the death of this Man, and let thy infinite goodnee forgive and amend them that did commit this inne.

And becaue my wounds till bled, he commanded them to wah me, and then do that charitable office which they had begun in burying me: According to his command, they did wah me, then he asked of them a peece of money, which he intended according to the Cutome when any was buryed, to put into my mouth: The poore Fihermen did all as he commanded them; and the good old Druid, weak though he was, did take me in his arms, and thought that he found ome heat in me, which made him lay his hand preently upon my heart, which he perceived to move and tremble. Courage, my Children, aid he, I hope this man has life enough to cleere you from the Calumny which may be laid upon you, and to lay the fault where it rightly deerves, for he is yet warm, and I perceive his heart to beat: Then letting my head hang a little downe, the water came out in great abundance, and the good Druid bound up my wounds with Hankerchers as well as he could; then he commanded them to make a devie with their Oares, whereon they might carry me with more eae; and whilt they were working about it, the good Druid went to eeke out ome hearbs by the bank ides, which he knew were
good to be applyed unto my wounds, and which would a little frehen and invigorate my pirits; he was not long about them, but bruiing thoe Simples betwixt two tones, he put ome of them into my wounds, and applyed ome to my heart, and preently the blood tayed: Preently after, I began to breathe, and my pule came unto me, whereof they were all o glad, that after thanks unto the great Tautates, they carried me upon their Oars into the Cell of this good Druid, and laid me upon a good bed, where one of his Nephews ued ometimes to lye, when he came to viit him; for as for himelfe, his bed was onely a few dry leaves without any order or delicacy.

I was all the ret of the day and never opened an eye, or gave any igne of life, but onely my breath and my pule: The next morning about breake of day my eyes opened, and I was never in my life more atonihed, than to ee my elfe in that place; for I remembred the Combate which I had, and my reolution of throwing my elfe into the River; but I could not poibly imagine how I hould come there. I continued long in this thought; at lat, the room growing lighter, and the little loophole which was in lieu of a Window being towards the un riing, I looked about, and the ight made me wonder more, for my Chamber was onely a Cave, the roof Rock, and Ivie my hangings: Seeing all thee things as I lay on my bed, I endeavoured to raie my elf a little, the better to conider them; but I was not able, both in repect of my weaknee, and alo by reaon of my wounds. Bening then forced to lie till as I was, and as they had laid me, I began to put my hand to the places where I found my paine, and finding the Napkins and uch other things as they had applyed unto me, I was till more amazed. Then, not being able to imagine how all thee things hould come to pae, I began to think upon uch tories as I had heard of concerning Water-Nymphs, and Goddees, who dwelt in Rivers, almot condemning my elfe of incredulity that I had not believed them, and now thought that this place could not poibly be any other, then one of their habitations: But as a wandring mind does uually rove immediately from one thing to another; I preently began to think upon the injuries and ingratitude of Madonthe. The memory of which went o near my heart, as it forced from me o deep a igh, as the good man of God heard me; for he was et at the door, attending till it was time to come and ee me. As oon as ever he heard me, he came into the Chamber, and without aying any thing, after he had a little looked upon me, he went and opened the window wider, that he might the better ee in what condition I was: Afterwards coming to me, feeling my pule and my heart, and finding me much amended, did eem to be very glad of it: Then itting down in a Chaire which tood by my beds ide, and looking a while upon me, he began thus to peak. My Son, ince the great God hath made his love unto you evidently appeare by ending you uch unexpected Aitance, you are the more obliged unto th • nkes for o great a mercy and favour, and to be obedient unto whatoever he command • : For as the acknowledgement of favours received from him, does invite his hand unto more liberality, o ingratitude provokes him to lack his mercies, and in lieu thereof, to chatie. Take good heed of this my Son, and let us ee how you will expree your thankes by your words, and with what demontrations you will acknowledge the particular Cure which hath been over you: upon this he was ilent to ee what I would anwer. This good old man, had a very venerable and grave apect, a pleaing look, a weet Phyiognomy, and o mild a voyce, as it eemed as if ome God had poken by his mouth: But yet my amazement was o great, as it was long before I returned him an anwer; He fearing that it was my weaknee, or the pain of my wounds, which hindred me. Son, aid he, if your paine and weaknee will not permit you to anwer; yet make a ign in tetimony of your deire, and God will o well accept it, as he will give you further trength. Then recollecting my pirits, I forced my elfe to anwer him with a feeble voyce, in thee words: Father, it is not the wounds of my body hath brought me into this condition wherein you ee me; but it is the wounds of my oul, which expecting no other cure or remedies, but uch as death ueth to give unto thoe that are mierable, made me look for an end of my life from a River, which it eems is o pittilee, as he will not not afford me that help which he never denyes unto others. Thee things are till in my memory, but I cannot tell how I came out of that River wherein I threw my elfe; nor how I came into this place, and in your preence.

Son, replyed the Druid, I perceive your crime, and the favour of Tautates are greater then I did imagine them: For I had an opinion, that ome of your enemies had thus ued
you, and that the great God had aved and delivered you out of their hands but for ought I ee you would have procured your own death, a in o great & execrable both unto God & man, as his mercy is infinitely abundant in not chatiing you in his anger Fratricide & Patricide are • innes of a very high train, becaue they are neere unto us: How montrous then is the murther of our elves, ince none can be o neer us as our elves are. Madam, hould I relate all his intructions I hould be too long; and he would have continued longer, if he had not been prevented by the Fihermen who came into the Chamber, and brought with them a man tyed with cords, o as at the firt I did not know him, as well becaue my mind was ditracted another way as becaue he looked with a trange affrighted looke, and his habit had o diguied him, as he was much changed.

As oone as ever he aw me, he would have falne upon his knees, but he could not becaue he was bound. At lat looking more earnetly upon him, and hearing him ay A • my Mater, my Mater, I knew him to be Halladine my Servant: You may imagine Madam whether I was amazed to ee him in that condition; for I could remember how I pulled him into the water, and thought he had been drowned but I was much more amazed when I heard one of the Fihermen addree unto the Druid, & aure him, that this was the man who had brought me into the condition I was, and that he was not content with what he had done, but he was looking about for the corps that he might hide it and his wicked act together. The good old man would have poke, when I interrupted and told him No, no, my friends, you are mitaken, he is innocent, he is my Servant, and the mot faithfull Servant I ever had, et him at liberty I intreat you, and let me imbrace him once more. The poore men wondered to ee me hug him o affectionately, and he falling downe upon his knees at my bed ide, with eyes howring tears, he was o tranported with joy, that he could not peake: But when he was unbound, I embraced him as tenderly as if he had been my borther.

I was extreamly deirous to know whether he had delivered my meage as I commanded him, and how he came to be brought thus unto me, but I durt not aske him, leat I hould dicover what I deired to keepe ecret. The Druid who was dicreet and wie did perceive as much; For preently upon it, eeming as if he would go and enquire the manner of their meeting with this Servant, he went out of the Cell, and carryed with him all but us two. My curioity would not uffer me to be any longer without asking him whether he had eene Madonthe, what he and Lerian •
had aid and done, and how he fell into the hands of thee men? He anwered me a farre off that he had accomplihed my commands, and failed in nothing, that all thoe who heard of my death, did extreamly lament me, that had he thought to have found me alive, he would have brought me an anwer unto my letter; but being deirous to doe me the lat ervice he could; he came to looke for my corps along the River ide, that he might give it buriall, intending afterwards to retire himelfe from that Country and all habitable places: And this morning going along the River ide, he met thee Fihermen, of whom he enquired for what he ought: And they, after they had looked upon him, and whipered a while together, they fell upon him and bound him, as I aw he was thinking it was he who had treated me in that manner; that doe all they could; he would not tell my name, nor give them any light by which they might know whom I was But Sir, aid he, I beeech you by what good fortune came you hither, and what good God was it that retored you unto life againe? Then joyning his hands together, and lifted up his teare welled eyes to Heaven; for ever happy may he be, aid he, that did this good worke. Halladine, my Friend, aid I unto him, I thanke thee heartily for thy good will, and I am very glad thou hat not revealed my name, for I would not have any know me to be alive: And as to thy quetion, how I came hither, you mut enquire of ome body ele than me, for I am as ignorant as thou art. And yet let me tell thee, that though Heaven has preerved my life againt my will, I cannot chue but thank it, ince I can by thee heare of Madonthe, Madonthe whom I beeech the Heavens to preerve, and unto whom I wih all happinee and contentment. Oh Heavens (aid Halladine) is it poible you hould continue till in this errour? you have little reaon to make that prayer for her, or ever to remember her, unlee to detet her and to be revenged both of her, Leriana, and Therander: And were I as you, I would doe it, and be as eager to dipleae her as you have been to do her ervice. Were't thou, as I, replyed I thou wouldt not give harbour unto any thought o ill; and be aured that were I not confident thy language proceeds from thy love unto
me, I would never looke upon thee againe with a good eye, o extreamely contrary are thy thoughts unto mine; and therefore if thou wilt continue, with me unto the end of my dayes (which will beere long: if it be as I deire) never offer any uch language unto me againe, nor againt a peron whom I love, as he deerves above all the world.

Upon this, I was o weake that I could ay no more; for whether it was my udden urprize of joy to ee Halladine, or my anger to hear him utter uch language, I cannot tell, but my wounds began to bleed o freh, as I grew cold and pale, and almot without pule. I perceived it, at the beginning of my talke, but becaue I did not much deire to live, I would not peake of it, and but for Halladine who tooke notice of my changing colour, doubtlee I had then put an end unto all my mieries; but that faithfull Servant ran preently to the Druid, and told him: He who during all the time of our talke, was preparing what he thought bet for the dreing of my wounds, and tayed but for the terme of fifteene houres, before he would apply the firt plaiter, he came preently into the Chamber, and finding me all in blood, did conceive that ome extraordinary emotion was the caue of it; yet not eeming to take any notice of it then, but alter he had carefully dreed me, and made me take ome broth, he hut the window, and bad me ret a little; for this econd loe of blood had brought me o low, as I was not able to lift up my hand.

In the meane while he took Halladine aide, did put into his hands all that he had taken from the Fihermen, and enquired very particularly who I was, and by what accident I came to be in that condition, and thereupon related unto him all circumtances, how I was aved. My Servant gave him very many thanks for the aitance he had hewed unto me, and aured him, that he would not be orry for the paines he had taken; conjured him by the great Tautates to continue it, and that both God and men would reward him for o good a worke; as for the other quetion which he asked him, they were things he durt not anwer without my permiion, becaue I had exprely forbidden him; but he might aure himelfe, I was uch a one, as when he knew me, he would not repent of his paine and time imployed in my ervice; all he could ay, was, that I was one of the principall men in all Aquitane Is he then a Gaul, replyed the Druid, and not a Viigot? Mot true, replyed Halladine, but he was brought up by the King of the Viigots in his houe: It is enough, aid the good Druid, all I deire to know more, is onely what beliefe he has in the great Gods, for I tooke notice that he is extreamly troubled in his mind, and mot auredly, the mind mut then be cured before the body can. Indeed, Father, anwered Halladine, you have rightly oberved his ditemper, for never was mind more poeed with a deepe melancholy, than the mind of this Cavalier: And for my part I beleeve there are onely two remedies to cure him. What doe you thinke them to be, asked the Druid? The one, aid Halladine, is God who is able to doe any thing: Then replyed the good old man, we mut have recoure unto God, and pray unto him to direct us in his cure; but what is the other? Death, aid Halladine: Still I ee no way, aid the holy man, but to have recoure unto God. And ince this time, he had o great a care of me, as he would never be from me, at leat as little as poibly he could: And one day when he perceived me to be a little better, he ued o many arguments unto me, and alledged o many reaons as in concluion I did acknowledge that nothing did come to pae but by the appointment of God, who loving us better than we can do our elves, it is to be in common reaon uppoed, that whatoever he does is to our advantage, though the Phyicke he gives us be ometimes bitter, and hard to be wallowed. As oon as I was grounded in this knowledge, I preently rejected my barbarous reolution of dying, and reigned my elfe o into the hands of great Tautates, as I began to think all things weet ince they came unto me from the Soveraign goodnee. This reolution did operate o well, that in a little time, I was pat danger, and within a few dayes after that, o recovered, as I wanted only a little more trength; which indeed by reaon of my loe of o much blood, was o great a want, as I mut refer it unto time for my recovery.

During which time, having nothing to buie my elfe in, but my owne thoughts, I was mot commonly out of the little Cell, under the excue of taking the freh Air, though it was only becaue none hould interrupt me. The good old man pent mot of his time in prayers and contemplation; and Halladine went out unto the neighbouring Townes and Villages to provide Victuals, and other necearies, whilt I in the meane time, was
upon the top of the Rock, looking alwaies towards the place where I left Madonthe.

As oon as it was day, I was alwayes wont to leave my little Cell, and crawl a weak march to the top of this Rock; where itting upon a moy Cuhion, I ummoned into my memory all paages unto that very time, not forgetting neither my good fortune, nor my bad, which went deep to my heart; for the miery pat did wound me, as much as the miery preent; and I reented the happinee which once I had, and then had not, as a loe which was preently ravihed mot injuriouly from me

After dinner, retiring my elfe under ome Trees which made a pleaant hade not far from the Cell; there I contemplated the mierable condition unto which fortune had reduced me: my own mieries, and the happinee of another did equally offend me: the one, by my own reentment; the other, by envy and jealouie of that contentment which was ravihed from me. But after Supper, walking along the River ide, my contemplation was buied in conideration of thoe mieries which might fall upon me for the future; and what little hopes there was of preventing them, o as all my dayes journey was divided into three kind of coniderations; the morning, in things pat; the afternoon, in things preent; and the evening in things future: and the lat of thee would lat o long, as they would take mot of the night; being invited thereunto by the olitude of the place, or by the ilence of the night, or by the pleaure I took in thinking upon my dipleaures. For, Madam, life was a thing of o little value to me at that time, as there was nothing I deired more then to ee the end of it: And being now reolved to ue no violence againt my elfe, I wihed that ome accident or other would be o friendly to me, as to doe that good office for me, without my contributing unto the homicide of my elfe: And I had an opinion, that if orrow increaed on, as it had done of late, it would doe the worke for me; o as I uffered this opinion to way o much in my mind, as I could eldome begotten unto my lodging, unlee the good old man or my ervant, came to fetch me.

This kind of life, was o agreeable to my humour, as I was oft in a mind to quit both Arms and Fortune, and tay here all the ret of my dayes. And in order to this deigne, I acquainted my ervant, adviing him to retire himelfe with thoe goods which fortune had given me, which I would freely betow upon him, if he would leave me in this place where I would depie fortune, and bid her defiance. But Halladine in a flood of teares, could ay nothing ele, but that nothing under heaven hould eparate him from me, unlee onely death; and that he wihed for no greater wealth then to erve me. Then preently after he had gotten me to bed, and hearing me igh he came unto me; and ince he perceived I could not leep, he aid thus unto me Is it poible, Sir, you hould harbour uch trange thoughts of ruining your elfe? Ah my friend, aid I unto him, I hall not be o ruined here, but griefe and orrows will find me out. And o they may very well, ir, (aid he unto me) as long as you doe thus forget your elfe, and what you were wont to be, in o much as you will not endeavour your happinee, and try if you can retore your elfe unto that tate which you have lot. Halladine, (aid I and ighed) It is the height of imprudence, to attempt things impoible. Why, ir, aid he, hould you give the name of impoible unto that which you have not tryed, nor has any reaon to be o perwaded? For my part, I have uch an opinion of my elfe, that any thing which a ervant can doe is not impoible; and I am much more certaine, that whatoever any Cavalier in Europe can obtaine, you can if you will. If this Therander who is the caue of your miery, had this conideration, he would attempt to remove you from Madonthe. And why hould not you doe as much for him? you were once in her favour, and he removed you; and believe it, ir, o may you him for that which has once been done, may be done againe. Dot thou not know, (aid I unto him) that Madonthe loves him? Yes, aid he, And did he not once love you? But now, anwered I he wihes me ill. Have I not een, ir, anwered he, her corn him, and corn is much further from love then hatred? Hatred, replyed I, is further from friendhip then corn: 'Tis true, replyed he, but there is much difference between love and friendhip; for Love is more proud, and never looks upon things that are depieable, but alwaies upon the raret, highet, and mot etimable things. And this is it which makes me thinke, that Madonthe after he had corned Therander o much as he did, and afterwards did love him; o he may as well you, againt whom he had onely hatred, but never the leat hadow of corn. Friend, replied I, It is the love thou bearet unto me, moves thee to talke thus in
my advantage. I talk, Sir, replied he, as any that is without paion may: Well, aid I unto him, what is it thou wouldt have me do? My affection, ir, aid he, is it which moves my tongue; and I beeech you ir, receive my language as proceeding from thence: And ince you command me, let me tell you, I would have you aume the ame kinde of life you were wont to live, and try if any happy encounter will help you to recover that happines which is ravihed from you: For I cannot ee how it hould any way advantage you to tay here: I have ever had an opinion, that Madonthe does not hate you; or if he doe hate you, yet that he does not love Therander o well as you imagine: or if he doe love him, yet as he has changed once, o he may change againe: For I have heard ay, that the whole world is nothing but change; but ay he hould change, and yet believe you dead, this change would not availe you at all; whereas if he doe but ee you, it is impoible but he hould revive her firt parks of good will unto you. Put out a Candle, Sir, and bring it to another that is light, you hall ee how uddainly it will light againe: The heart of one who once loved, is of the ame nature, when it comes in the preence of the peron loved; whereas abence puts all hopes out, and is the very ruine and death of love.

Well, well, Halladine, aid I unto him, we will thinke upon it, and ee what the heavens will advie us unto; then turning me about, I eemed as if I had an inclination to leep; and yet it was onely becaue I would not heare any more diwaions from my olitary humour: but the Candle being put out, and I not being able to leep o oone, I began to conult and conider upon the reaons and arguments which Halladine urged; and finding them upon erious conideration to be very olid and good; I was almot in a mind to leave this place, being epecially invited unto it out of a puiant deire of dying. For I hoped, that being in quet after adventures, I might perhaps meet with one that would bring me to my death. Beides this, I conidered that it was impoible for me to tay long there and not be known, ince certainly thoe Fihermen would be blabbing out all they knew of me: And being not far from the place where Thorimond kept his Court, I could very hardly conceal my elf any longer.

Thee coniderations, and ome others which I will omit, let I hould be too tedious in my dicoure, did move me to take the advice which Halladine gave: And as oon as it was day I walked, then told him that I would take his counell; and that he hould look out to buy Hores for himelfe and me, alo to provide me Arms and other things requiite. Away he went immediately, the gladdet man in the world to ee me in this mind: and though he made all the hate that poibly he could, yet he tayed ome twelve or fifteen dayes before he could get my Arms fitted unto my directions. During his abence, I grew more olitary and private then before, in o much as the good old man did wonder at me. I mut confee, that at this time, I often diputed with my elfe, whether I hould break Prion, and hake off my hakles or no, and uing uch arguments as might be urged by Generoity unto a man of courage, I was a while taggering in my reolutions. But this all-commanding Love, whom none is able to reit, unlee by flying, did out of pite, load me with new Fetters, and renewed my chains by new meanes, o as I plainly aw there was now no hopes of ever having liberty.

The Fihers, Madam, with whom I often talked when they came to ee me, as well to know how I did, as in gratitude for the money which I had given them for their paines: and becaue they carried their Fih once a week unto the Town where Thorimond dwelt, to ell them there, they would oftentimes bring me the news of the Town. There was one amongt them, who was elder then the ret, and hewed to have more wit, of whom I ued to enquire; and asking him what was the talk of the Town, he anwered, that all the talk was of a great Lady, who was brough to bed of a Childe; and becaue the Lawes of the Viigots was to punih uch by fire, he was condemned unto it. Oberve, Madam, how the heart will ometimes oretell uch things as it feares: and though I did never in my life, ee any action in Madonthe which could in reaon move me to upect her guilty of uch a fault; yet I did preently think it was he? And for more aurance, I asked him the name of this Lady, but he told me that he had forgotten it; yet he aured me he was one of the principal Ladies who was unmarried.

Then did I take my upitions for certainties, when I reflected upon the kindnee which was betwixt her and Thera • der; and becaue I would have no notice taken of my dipleaure, I was contrained to leave their company, and retired my elfe under ome Trees
that were neere the houe; and there being alone, oh what contrariety of thoughts came into my mind to torment me? My vexation or rather my rage that I had been o extreamly guld, moved me to a deire to revenge for this injury: But how uddenly did I check my thoughts when I conidered my affection unto her: I mut confee, that tifling all thoughts of revenge, I could not retraine my teares, which flowed mot abundantly when I thought upon the mierable condition unto which Fortune had brought me: I had continued longer in this Labyrinth of confued thoughts, if Halladine who was returned, had not come to fetch me away. At firt when I aw him, I did imagine that he had omething to tell me, but durt not, yet ince the old Fiherman had broke the ice, I was o bold as to aske him. Come Halladine, aid I unto him, hat thou provided Armes and Hores? Yes Sir, aid he, all are ready, and I thinke you will be well fitted I have brought the Hores hither, but I have left the Armes at the Townes end, where I have caued them to be locked up: Thou hat tayed o long, replyed I, as I was almot out of all patience But good Halladine, I charge thee upon thy Fidelity, to tell me truly, hat thou heard any newes of Madonthe? Shall I tell you Sir, aid he what I know? With all my heart, replyed I, for I doe extreamly deire it; I feare, replyed he that I hall but vex and grieve you Sir, if I hould.
