Oh Heavens, Halladine (cryed I out) thou hat told me enough, my upitions are all truths; Is he condemned to the fire for having a Child? tell me truly. Whooever told you o, replyed he, told you the truth; but Sir, how came you to know it? The Fihermen, replyed I, who ue to goe and ell their fih, are my informers: But Halladine I conjure thee to tell me all thou knowet, and conceal not any thing, as thou lovet me. Sir, aid he, ince you are pleaed to command me with o many aeverations, I will; though I know that this new Newes will vex you as much, as it ought to doe the contrary. Then he related unto me, how ince the workmen required o much time, before they could finih my Armes, he thought that he could not pend his time better, than in going to Court, being confident that I would be glad of newes at his returne; that being there as privately as poibly he could, he was put unto no great matter of paines for newes, becaue Madonthe was the Towne talke all over; that Leriana was her Accuer, and that Leotaris and his brother would maintaine what Leriana aid, concerning her and Therander. How, replyed I preently, is it poible that Madonthe hould looke o low, as upon a man o bae? Halladine, who thought that this conideration might make me corne her. Yes Sir, aid he, it is o held for certaine, and conidering what proofes Leriana makes, none beleeves the contrary.

I mut confee Madam, that hearing this newes confirmed, I was o atoniht at it, as but for Halladine, I had falne to the ground. At lat, recollecting my elfe, and retiring a pace or two, I folded my armes one with the other, and lifting up my eyes to heaven, with a deep igh I aid: Oh God, how deep are thy judgements? and by how many trange wayes dot thou dicover truth? Then tanding a while ilent, as ravihed with admiration, at lat I broke out againe. Oh Madonthe, is it then true, that you have made choice of Therander, and preferred him before me, was your pirit o low, as to make him Lord of your will, whom your Predeceors did highly honour in making him their Servant? Is is poible that generous heart which heretofore I have eene in you hould be thus changed, As not to die rather than endure the hame of uch a choice? Oh God, oh Heavens, why would you infue uch a bae diembling pirit into o faire a body?

After this, I tood a long while ilent, as having o much to ay, that I could not peake at all, reembling a bottle that is full which will not come out but with ome difficulty. Halladine who conidered my affection, thinking to comfort me, and eeing me o long ilent, he took occaion to peak unto me. Had I thought Sir, aid he, that this news would have relihed o ill, you hould never have known it by me: Why Halladine, aid I unto him couldet thou ever thinke I would not be enible of her hame whom I loved above all the world? And why hould you doe o Sir, replyed he, ince he proves a peron who has given you occaion to hate her above all the World. Love, replyed I, is greater in me, than any wrong can be in her, and dot thou not know that the wound which is once made will never heale? If maladies may be cured by Antipathy, and contrary medicines, replyed Halladine, then that love which was caued by vertues and favours may be cured in you by the injuries which you have received from her, and by the knowledge of o
foule a fault. That which caueth love, aid I unto him, is fate and detiny unto whom the heavens have ubmitted it, and therefore there is no thought that it will change, untill the very heavens and detiny themelves doe change: And as for matter of hame I am reolved to be her Champion againt all thoe who hall oppoe her fame with any Calumny. Heavens forbid it Sir, aid he unto me, for you will have to deale with two of the turdiet Cavaliers in all Aquitane; beides you will too apparently wrong your elfe, and exceedingly offend a jut God in maintaining a quarrell that is unjut. As for the valour of Leotaris and his brother (aid unto him) it is not unknowne unto me, and it hall not be that which hall divert me from the Combate: But as to the offence which you mention to be againt God, I doe referre it unto him, ince it is his pleaure to make me love Madonthe o paionately, as it is a thing impoible for me to doe otherwie. Good Sir, aid he, will you offer to imploy your courage in taking arms for the defence of one who has mot unworthily ued you? are you not enible of uch injuries, and would you have all the World take notice of this inenibility? Doe you not remember how inupportably rigorous he was to you, whilt he was in the arms of Therander, and loaded him with more favours than he could deire? Will you againt all reaon expoe your life in defence of one who to content another, corned you? Shall it be ever aid that you did unjutly arme your elfe to preerve the pleaures and delights of Therander? He would have continued longer had not I interrupted him. Enough, enough Halladine, aid I unto him, no more of this language to me; the tone is already throwne, and it cannot be recalled; I am fully reolved upon it, all that thou hat aid or can ay, cannot unreolve me

When I doe thinke upon Madonthes death, and that I hall never ee her more whom I doe love o well; when I conider the paine and confuion in which he is, and the hame which is prepared for her, and when I doe remember, it is he whom Damon hath o long erved, and that he mut now be throwne into the Fire. Oh God, oh Heavens, Halladine, dot thou thinke I am able to indure it? and can any injury or corne hinder me from giving her all the aitance I can? No, no, Halladine, Damon mut either ceae to live, or ele he mut not ceae from doing what is his duty: It is the duty of a Cavalier to relieve afflicted and ditreed Ladies, whether this Lady be accued jutly or unjutly God knows; as for us we ought rather to think the bet, than to upect the wort: And ince Leriana is her accuer, I mut thinke Madonthe wronged, knowing the extreame malice which he beares unto her; I will therefore render Madonthe this proofe of my affection. I know, Halladine, thou wilt ay that he will thanke me no more for this ervice than for others he hath received from me but, friend, it is no matter if he do not; I hall atisfie my duty in it, and then I have the recompence I expect. My Servant eeing me o fully etled upon it, he told me, that ince I was o reolved, he could doe no more but pray unto God for a bleing upon my intentions and endeavours; but if I would execute my deigne, I mut not loe a minute of time: For the lat hour which the King had given unto Madonthe, would expire to morrow by noone, and that from the place where we were, the neeret way was five Leagues at the leat unto the Towne of Tectoages, and above eight Leagues to pae by the place where my Arms lay; o as it was full time to depart that very hour.

Upon this intelligence, I reolved to take Hore preently; and leat the good old Druid hould make me loe any time, I thought it bet to depart without acquainting him untill afterwards, and then if I proved victorious, I would make my excue, and thanke him for the great obligations wherein I was bound unto him. I tooke Hore then, and made all hate I could to the place where my Armes lay, I tryed them, and found them to be very good and fit, they were blacke, and on the Shield a Tyger feeding upon the heart of a man with this Motto. Thou giv't me death, and I utaine thy life.

Then, without more delay, I rode to the Town of Tectoages, and made uch hate, as I came a little before noon: I alighted, to give my Hore a little ret, for indeed he was weary; and this might well have been Madonthes ruine; for when I came to the lits, I found the Combate already begun, but one Cavalier againt two: and certainly had I tayed never o little longer that Cavalier had dyed, and Madonthe been convicted; for
he fell into a woon when I was entred not ten paces into the lits; and had he falne before I had entred, the Combate had been ended, and it would not have been permitted me to begin it againe: But God was pleaed I hould arrive o opportunely, as the innocency of that Lady was made known: For to omit the particulars of the Combate, it will uffice to tell you, that it pleaed God to give me victory over thee two valiant Brothers, who were overcome rather by the innocency of Madonthe, then any trength or virtue in me, unlee o, that being armed for the life and honour of my mitree, the whole Univere could not reit me.

Thus I was victorious; and when I leat though of it, the truth was manifeted; Leriana detected, Madonthe cleared; the Childe known to belong unto one that was Neece unto Leriana: and to be briefe, all things o cleared, that the wicked Leriana was cat into the ame fire which he had prepared for Madonthe; Madonthe et at liberty, and I the gladdet man that ever was, to ee he had beene wrongfully accued: and that though he had injured me, yet it was without the leat taine unto her honour or chatity. This was uch a high contentment unto me, as I eteemed all the paines I had taken in her ervice, more then recompenced.

Seeing this thus ettled, and thinking it not expedient to make my elfe known, untill I knew a little better whether or no he loved Therander; or whether all that I had een concerning it, was onely the artifice and ubtilty of Leriana, I went unto her caffold, to know whether I could erve her in any other occaion: She gave me many thanks, and had two requets unto me; the one was, to tell her who I was; & the other, to conduct her unto her houe: As for telling her my Name, I excued it as well as I could; and as for conducting her, I aid I would, upon condition it might be preently: And becaue at the ame time, a throng of Ladies came to congratulate her delivery, and alo becaue I feared the King would caue me to declare my elfe, alo becaue I had ome wounds which required dreing I went into the croud and o tole away; o as every one being diverted another way, none took any notice which way I went: And o I came to the place where I left my ervant, where binding up my wounds as well as I could, and letting my Hore graze a little, I got up againe, and went to my good old Druid.

I forgot to tell you, Madam, That meeting a man going to the Town, I entreated him to make my excue unto Madonthe; and, let he hould think me uncivil, I feigned to be engaged another way by promie, but if he had any further ervice to imploy me in, he might hear of me towards Mount d'Or, and that I would till weare my enigne of a Tiger. My deigne was, to make her believe I was gone that way, though I did not intend it, leat the Kings curioity hould be uch as to find out who I was.

I cannot, Madam, expree unto you, with what joy the good Druid received me, nor his thankes, when he knew the caue of my voyage, and the uccee and ervice I had done Madonthe in her great neceity: For he told me, that her Father brought him up; and that in this action I had over paid him, for all the paines and care he had taken about me. And becaue he aw my arms bloody, he took them off, and looked about every part of me; then finding ome wounds, he was o careful of me, and took uch coures, as I was well again in a little time.

But ince the bet Phyick, and no other could cure me, but to hear more of Madonthe, I intreated the good old Druid to end one of the Fihers unto the place where Thorimond was, to inquire what newes. The good man did as I deired, and the Fiher inquired o well, as at his return he brought me but too much newes for my contentment: That Madonthe was gone to her houe, and carried Therander with her wounded as he was; for it was he who before I came, was in Combate with Leotaris and his Brother. I undertood farther, that a little after the departure of Madonthe, how King Thorimond was killed by his Chyrurgion, who in letting him blood had cut the vein, and that his brother Eurick ucceeded him. I cannot expree, Madam, how near thee two accidents went unto my heart; onely thus far, I never think upon them, but the memory is o ad, as I conclude no ret belongs unto me but in my Grave.

Thus every thing from whence I expected comfort, augments my miery; all my hopes are now quite blated, olitary places dipleaed, becaue there I thought upon nothing but the Towne of Tectoages, and my thoughts grated upon my very oul, when they repreented unto me the ingratitude of this woman. To be brief, I was angry with my elfe, becaue I loved her againt reaon, and could not chue but love her. My condition
grew wore then ever; my wounds indeed being but mall, did heal in a few days; but I became o pale as if I were dead, and this palenee preently after turned into uch a yellownee, as if I had rubbed my elfe with Saffron. Halladine, who had heard omthing of Madonthes actions, did upect what the caue was of my being thus diordered, and watched for an opportunity of peaking unto me But the good old man not knowing what to thinke, he advied me to change aire, hoping that exercie and diverion might recover my health; and I according to the advice of this good man, reolved to ee the world, and wander from place to place, and ret no where, till death arreted me.

After then, I had given mot hearty thankes unto this good man, I departed, without any other deigne in my voyage, than continuall wandring: yet as fortune was, our way did lie towards Madonthes houe, where we heard uch newes, as did more and more aggravate my miery. For we heard that this ill advied woman (as Halladine calls her) was gone, or rather tolne away, without any in her company but her Nu • e and Therander. Imagine what operation this report had upon me; my Servant would have perwaded me, that he did me no wrong in it, but onely herelfe; for he believing me to be dead, as all Aquitane did, I had no reaon to blame her: But however, my dipleaure was o great, as not being able to endure the ight of uch places where formerly I found uch delight, and now dipleaure; I reolved to leave Europe, and never to leave wandring till I met with omething that would horten my ad life. So I paed into Africa, there I aw King Generick and Honorius his Son, and found every where that Love works the ame effects that it did in me: I meane, that it augments and diminiheth, changes and rechanges, delights and dipleaures, in all thoe that are ubjects unto it, according to its own pleaure without any reaon. For being amongt thee Vandals, I heard of the fortunes of Uraes and Olimbres, and of young Placidia, and her Mother Eudoxe, wife unto Valentinian, all whom by their examples, could not divert me from till loving; but I learned rather this leon, That whooever will love, mut prepare themelves for good and bad, and receive them both with the ame viage. And conidering the various changes in the fortune of Eudoxe, the long perervance of Uraes his love, the prudent behaviour of young Olimbres, and the happy concluion of their loves; I reolved not to afflict my elfe o much at the croes which I had in my affection, but thence forward, to endure them with more patience. And becaue Halladine who was tired out with my long and tedious travels, did advie me not to love her any longer, who did not think me o much as in the world, thinking that if he could bring me to this conideration, I hould eaily be perwaded to return into Aquitane: I told him, to put him out of all hope, that I would love her till.

In concluion; finding no ret any where, nor atisfaction in any diverion, I aw that all humane prudence was to no purpoe, and therefore I would have recoure unto divine Counells; o as hearing that at the further end of the Pirenian hills towards the Sea, there was an Oracle which was called the Temple of Venus; I returned into Europe, and enquired of the Oracle, of which I asked nine dayes together, what it was which would either put to an end, or ele cure my <> The Oracle anwered, Forrets: The next morning I asked where Forrets was? it anwered againe, Forrets; and notwithtanding my importunity, the Oracle was mute, and would give no other anwer but Forrets; o as I reolved to look for Forrets all Europe over. I will not tell you, Madam, how many everall places I paed, and all in vaine, onely in generall; how after I had run through all Spain, Cantabria, Gaul, Narbon, and Aquitane, I came into the Country of the Gebennes, and reolved to ee Hircania and Ardennes, and all other places through the world: For I cannot be perwaded, that this God who is mot true and jut unto all other men, hould be a deceiver unto me alone: but on the contrary, I hope that in thee olitary places I hall finde that contentment which is promied unto me.

Thus Damon concluded the Hitory of his mierable life. And Galathea, who had formerly heard the firt part, was very glad he had heard the ret, and deired to give him all the contentment this Country afforded. Therefore when he had finihed, he aid thus unto him. I mut needs confee, ir, you have reaon to complaine againt your fortune, having without any reaon been o long afflicted, but till you mut not let your hopes droop: for the Gods are no Impotors, nor deceivers; and having received uch an
anwer from them, you mut beleeve that you hall find that contentment which you deire. Tis true they are pleaed ometimes to give ambiguous and obcure anwers, and that to teach us, that there is no happinee to be obtained without a mixture of miery, and that they are pleaed humane wits hould buie themelves in finding out the truth, and true meaning of their Oracles; and if you will have my opinion upon this anwer you have received, I think you have not rightly undertood it, in conceiving that this word Forrets, does ignifie Woods and olitary places, peopled only with Trees; but you mut know that this Country wherein you now are, is not only called the Country of the Seguiaus, but more particularly called Forrets, o as I do beleeve, it is this Forrets in which the Oracle intends you hall find that happines which you are to receive. And to tell you truly it is very probable that this is the Country and place, and not in Woods & places olitary: For it may o fall out that Madonthe may come hither upon ome occaion which may be hid from you; therefore take heart, and beleeve, that as one evill never comes alone, o one good is alwayes accompanied with another. It is a happinee you hould light upon the place which the Oracle foretels hall put an end unto your mieries, and ere long it will be econded with uch another as may afford you the effects of all.

Madam, anwered Damon and ighed, I find all you ay to be grounded upon great reaon, and I doe believe I hall hortly ee the accomplihment of the Oracle which promieth that in Forrets I hall finde an end of my miery: For I hope Death will doe that which Love could not. No, no Sir, aid the Nymph, you mut have better hopes than o, and being to inquire with me to morrow of the Oracle in this place, I hope you will receive better contentment; and in this opinion, I have taken order to provide all things neceary for the Sacrifice, both for you and me. In the the meane time our Coaches and your Servant may returne, but I have one requet, unto you, Sir, which is, that you will not leave me untill you have brought me unto the houe of Amais my Mother, who I am ure will bid you mot heartily welcome. The Cavalier, anwered her, That it was his intention to conult with the Oracle of this place, and that he tooke it for a great honour he would permit him to inquire with her; alo he would wait upon her unto Amais, and tender his ervice unto her, that as for the hopes which he gave him, truly he did hope, but it was onely in death, which could not come o oone as he did paionately deire.

In the mean time Galathea dipatched a meenger unto Bonlieu to the venerable Chryante, to acquaint her that he would come unto her, and upon the meengers returne undertood that Atrea, Diana, Phillis, and all the hepherds dined there, and intended to goe and viit Alexis, the daughter of Adamas: This meenger was a young fellow that had been brought up in her ervice from his infancy, and therefore being very familiar with her, he ued to acquaint her with all the newes he met withall in any place where he had been. At this time, after he had delivered the anwer of the venerable Chryante, he followed his cutome, and aid.

I aure you Madam, that except your elfe, I never aw any o faire as Atrea and Diana: Galathea, deirous to make him peake on, and to heare more of thee hepherdees, hoping to find omething concernin •
• er beloved Celadon, and to heare what was become of him, he poke alowd before Damon, and aid unto him: How Lerindas, (for that was his name) doe you thinke thoe hepherdees o faire, that you prefer them before all my Nymphs? It is not I who prefers them, aid he, but it is truth. But how cant thou make us believe, replyed Galathea, that uch Country wenches as they, are o very faire? Madam, aid he, I vow, that were I a Cavalier, I would maintaine their beauties againt all the World; and did you ee them, I am confident, that for all your valour you would not enter into the Lits againt me upon o bad a quarrell. But tell me Lerindas (aid Galathea, and miled) which of them does pleae you mot? Doubtlee, anwered he, Atrea is the fairer, but he is o ad and melancholly, as therefore Diana pleaeth me bet: For thoe wenches that are o deepely in Love, never pleaed me o well as others. Who is it, replyed Galathea, whom Atrea loves? I can onely tell you, Madam, replyed he; that he is ad and melancholly, and they ay he is o becaue a Shepherd was drowned about four or five Months ince. And Diana, aid the Nymph, is he in love with any? They ay No, anwered he, & yet there are two about her who torment her much if he doe not love them; the one is called Paris, and the other Silvander; the truth is, if I were to chue, I hould give my voice for Silvander; for though he be but a hepherd,
yet I never aw one more Gentile, nor civilied. If thou goet on, aid Galathea, thou wilt make us all deirous to become hepherdees, onely to enjoy uch good company. Madam, anwered he, you may chance beleeve thee to be but Fables, but I am confident two or three dayes could not, be better imployed then amongt them. Then Galathea turning towards the aged Cleontine. Mother, aid he, I am halfe in a mind to tay here two or three dayes, that Damon may a little eae his wounds whilt in the interim walk towards Lignon, and ee whether all thee reports of the hepherdees be true. Madam anwered Cleontine, their converation is the weetet and pleaantet you can imagine; and beleeve it, there is nothing of Rutique in them but the name, o as if you deire to take that pleaure, now is the mot conveniency; for the great Druid is to come and offer a olemne acrifice of thankes unto Tautates for the Misleto, which is found neer their Towne, What kind of ceremony is that? asked Galathea; for they ue to gather this Misleto the ixteenth of the Month of July. Tis true, anwered Cleontine, but this is only a acrifice of Thanks, that Tautates would be pleaed to honour that place with it, before any other, and making it to grow, as they ay, upon the goodliet Oake that ever was een, and in thus favouring that Towne it is a igne he loves it above others. How do you know (aid the Nymph) that the great Druid comes now to performe this Sacrifice? becaue, aid Cleontine, he promied it hould be within eight dayes, whereof four are already pat, o as if he keepe his word, he cannot deferre it no longer: And I am certaine, his hate would be the more, did he know it was your pleaure to honour the olemnity with your prefence.

This made Galathea reolve to retard her journey unto Bon-lieu, as well to eae Damon, as to ee thee hepherdees; and becaue he had not yet ent to acquaint Amais with the accident which had hapned, and likewie becaue he might wonder at her tay o long, he dipatched one of Cleontines Servants, to acquaint her with all that had hapned, with the caue of her tay at Mount Verdan, by reaon of Damons
• ounds, and the occaion of his coming into this Country. Asoone as Amais received this Newes, he was much pleaed, and much dipleaed both: For he was very glad to heare that Damon was alive, whom he thought dead, becaue he was her Kinman in a near degree, and the carriage of Polemas did extreamly dipleae her, it being againt a peron of o much merit, and in the preence of her daughter, whom it was his duty to reverence: And to hew how ill he reented it, he tooke Coach immediately, and went as fat as he could unto Mount Verdan, where her daughter was amazed at her udden coming, and asked her the reaon of her udden reolution. She told her that he came to ee Damon, and offer him whatoever was in her power, as her Kinman, and as one who had much obliged her.

Damon being advertied of her coming, he aroe out of bed to meet her for his wounds were uch as he might doe it without danger, but being urpried upon uch a udden he accoated her onely with excues, and thankes for o great a favour. I am obliged, aid he, unto you more than this, as well by conanguinity, as by memory of him who gave you life, who at the returne with Thorimond King of the Viigots, made unto Tectoages, after he had fought Attilas in the Catalaunique fields with o great an Army, did prevent the ruine of this Country, turning his paage by the Sequanois, by the lower Allobroges, by the Veblomiens, and by the Mountaines of Gebbenes, and o into his own Kingdom. And this Obligation was not o little as it was thought of: For the young King I know not how, did fall in love with one of my Nymphs, who having no mind to marry he ravihed her away by force, doubtlee upon my intigation of her unto that deniall.

Madam (anwered the Cavalier) all men are obliged to erve Ladies, particularly thoe of your quality and merit: And my father in doing you this little ervice, which you are pleaed to remember, did right unto the title of a Cavalier; and I ucceeding him, doe offer unto you my blood and life.

Much more dicoure of civility paed betwixt them, & in concluion he told him, that he would have him carryed unto Marcelles in a Litter, that his wounds might be there better looked unto: But he excued himelf o, as he permitted him to tay there for ome dayes till his wounds were better: and this he deired, becaue he would be more quiet, and out of the world, ince Madonthe was not in it for him, reolving that as oon as he had conulted with the Oracle, and conducted Galathea to her Mother, he would get himelfe o farre as where he hould not be known, nor the name of Madonthe mentioned
by any. Galathea was very glad of his not going to Marcelles, becaue he might the more conveniently tay at M • unt Verdun with him, under a pretence that he might pend ome dayes amongt the hepherdees, where he hoped to heare ome newes of Celadon, or at the leat to ee the beauty of Atrea, which had caued that hepheard to didain hers.

p.U: eeing he would not tir from the place where he was, and fearing to be too troubleome unto him if he tayed any longer, becaue the houe was little; he returned unto Marcelles after many excues, for the dicourteie which Polemas had hewed unto him, and which he proteted hould not pae unpunihed. Damon who was all weetnee and civility, and who had often paed the like hazards, he beeeched her to think no more upon it, becaue it was a thing above his merit; and becaue the offence of Polemas was ufficiently punihed by the loe of his kinman. He did o extenuate the fault, that though Galathea who was extreamly offended at Polemas for being o inolent in her preence, did give the crime all due aggravations; yet Amais promied Damon to doe whatoever he deired, intending to give him all the atisfaction and contentment he could: Yet at her return unto Marcelles, he did let Polemas ee how much this action dipleaed her, though he excued it as well as he could, aying it was not done by his command: but whilt he was buie in helping Arganteus, his ouldiers eeing him in that cae, would needs revenge his death. Amais who was very well informed how all paed, commanded him to turn off his ervice all uch unworthy perons, as would offer uch a bae act; which Polemas did with o ill a will, and was o vexed againt Damon, as he reolved to be revenged upon him. Beides, he being of an envious nature, and eeing how much the Nymph did eteem him, he was not able to endure it. But that which came neeret the quick, was, that having ome hopes of marrying Galathea, and finding that he could not with all his tricks make her love him, he began to contrive the meanes how he hould mak • himelfe overaign Lord of the State, and to compae that by force which Love denyed him: he was the more induced unto this enterprie, becaue he aw much facility in bringing it about; Clidemant being abent; with Lindamore, Gugamant, and all the Grandees of the Country: All the chief places of trength in his hands, and all the Souldiers lited; and being backed by a great number of his kindred and allies, both within and without the State: Alo, on the contrary, Amais having nothing but jutice on her ide, having conferred all the power upon that faith and confidence he had in him.

div.p: He thus apiring unto this enterprie, and being prompted thereunto by Love and Ambition, he could not ee any able to give him a top; for Amais had not one Cavalier which had not dependence upon him, and were under his Authority, except Damon, who though ingle, made him afraid of his valour: And fearing that Amais being dipleaed by this lat action, hould keep him in the Country, and confer Authority upon him by the un-hine of her favours, he reolved to prevent it. For he remembred that heretofore, the Father of this Cavalier hould once have married Amais, and all the great value and eteem which he now et upon him, he did attribute it unto the remembrance he had of that. This conideration was a caue, why taking aide ix of the Souldiers whom Amais had commanded him to dicharge; he poke thus unto them, after he had made many a complaint againt her.

Friends, aid he, It is a thing impoible to change the nature of any thing, ue what art, or doe what one can: you know with what care and paines I have erved Amais, and how I have not pared any thing which depended upon meor my friends, which might contribute to her ervice: And this, not once, but upon all occaions that el out. I mut confee I have not given my bet friends all that atisfaction which I owe unto them. But it is a thing aboutely impoible, take what paines, and ue what art one can, to tay a wavering mind, which is naturall unto all of her ex She is now wayed wholly by a young tranger, who by killing Arganteus, has got a little reputation; he who by chance, and not by any vertue that is in him, killed my Nephew before our faces; probably he had ued ome treachery before we came, otherwie it is not likely he hould by plaine trength vanquih the valour and skill of Arganteus. Your reentments of it at this time has o much obliged me, as I hall never forget it as long as I live, but will be ready upon all occaions to require you. But I am much afraid the meanes of doing it will be taken out of my power ere long, unlee you will arme your elves with tout reolutions,
and follow my directions. Amais to gratifie this new up-tart, has commanded me to caheir you out of my Lit of Souldiers, with expree charge to banih you this Country, your own natural oil. This blow, though it hit you by the by, yet it will trike me down, and is done purpoely to etablih this new comer in this Province, which he is no way able to doe, but by taking from me that Authority which my Services have gotten. She conceives that if he hould do it all at once, and upon a uddain perhaps I might oppoe her; and therefore he undermines me by degrees, thinking that the greater the building is, it will the ooner fall by its own weight: And to begin her worke, he firt takes from me my bet friends, uch as you are: I know her drift well enough, and if all things go well, as I hope they will, I hall ere long prevent thee diorders but as things are at preent, if the remedy do not proceed from your courage and reolution, I am afraid you will be forced from u • for a time, which would be one of the greatet dipleaures that can befall me, but if you have till the ame courage which I have een in you, I am confident you will end him out of the world, who would end you out of your native Country: It is a matter of no difficulty, for he is a ingle man; he is not able to reit one of you, much lee all ix. Do but kill his Hore that he cannot run away, and the victory is yours. As for Amais, he will be highly enraged at the firt, and would be revenged upon thoe that tooke from her her vnew Adomis; but her anger will be onely a blat of wind, and quickly over: For he being a tranger, none will proecute in his behalf: I mean, none will care for his death; beides, I know your dicretion, as when you have done the buinee, you can be cloe, o as none hall have the leat upition of you. Then, when all the power is in my own hands, be aured that you hall not feare any danger, whatoever become of my elf. Conider well upon it, and be reolute, that I may know what to doe, both for you, and for my elfe, in a buinee of this importance.

Thee Souldiers were oon perwaded by uch an Orator, and promied to attempt upon this tranger what he had propounded; as for their parts, they had no other coniderations, but to obey him; and at the danger of their lives, to keep up his grandure and authority.

This attempt being thus reolved upon, the next morning, he aembled together all thoe who were with him that day, and who had aaulted Damon; and told them, that by expree command from Amais, he commanded them, not onely to retire from his ervice, but to depart the Country within ix days; that he was orry to treat them o but he mut obey; that they mut not fail upon paine of death; and yet not being able to forget thoe good ervices which he had received from them, he promied to obtaine the favour of Amais for them, as oon as he could, and to get them retored into their former ervice. And that they might be better able to ubit in the meane time, beides their pay which Amais allowed for the time pat, he would out of his own pure give them three moneths pay: deiring them not to be angry with him for it; but to believe that he did execute this command with much griefe, being very orry to part from thoe that with o much valour and fidelity had erved him, and in whom he had great confidence. By this mooth language and hew of orrow to part with them, he did not onely get the good will of thoe who were dimied, but of all the Souldiers beides; and on the contrary, did teal away their hearts from Amais, which was no mall advancement to the deign which he had plotted in himelfe; for what he took from her, redounded unto his advantage.

Adamas, who was extreamly deirous to welcome all the good company in his houe, and particularly to make good his promie unto thoe faire hepheardees, in going unto their Town to offer the acrifice of Thanks; as oon as it was day, he ordered the Sacrificers to go before with their Cattle, and other things neceary; and to give notice unto all the neighbouring Towns to be preent. And whilt he was putting all things in order, the fair Daphnide, and all the ret of the company, did dree themelves, and took the way unto the place where the Sacrifice was to be offered. Alexis, amongt all the ret, was mot out of tune; for at firt going out, when he cat her eye upon the River of Lignon, and aw the place of her habitation: She did imagine that this voyage was not reall, but a dream onely. As he was walking down a little hill with Atrea, Hylas did o awake her by his dicoure, as he perceived it no dream, but a reall voyage; and then he was o full of contentment, that every one might perceive it in her eyes and face.
Atrea on the other ide, who could not wih for more happinee then to be with this diguied Druid, in whoe face was uch a lively picture of Celadon, he was o fully contented, as almot forgetting the averenee of her pat fortune, he was now the happiet hepherdee of Lignon. And becaue Adamas did let her undertand that he intended to lie this night with Phocion, and that Leenide and Alexis hould be there alo; he dipatched a meenger to give them notice.

In the meane time they all walked on, a gentle but a merry pace, ome inging, others talking, all doing omething or other to beguile the length of the way. Calidon who till had in memory the cruel anwer which Atrea gave him, not having o much confidence as to accoat her, yet not being able to conceale his dipleaure nor his extream affection, he walked ometimes before her, and ung ome veres, which imported that to love her, was recompence enough.

Hylas who was next him, and could not endure any of thee obtinate affections, as oon as Calidon ended, he ung ome other veres which imported, that Let them change that that would, for his part he would never change. Every one did laugh at the ong of Hylas, and becaue Stiliana, who walked with Carlis and Hermantes next them, did hearken very attentively unto what Hylas aid; urely Hylas, aid he unto him, thoe who accue you of incontancy, doe you much wrong, ince never was man more contant than you are: For from the very firt time I ever aw you untill now, you were till the ame: Oh, good old Mitree, (aid he unto her) I wonder you hould not know this before now, have all the men and women of our age o little wit, as not to know this truth? This, replyed he, and miled, is a bad recompence for a good office; you call me old Mitree, and doe you not know Hylas, that there is nothing under the Sun more offends a woman than to be called old. I doe beleeve o, aid Hylas, but it is o long ince we were acquainted, that I thought it no injury. Daphnide, who was talking with Adamas hearing thoe that were about Hylas to laugh o heartily, and being deirous to know at what; he inquired of Diana, who was next her, and he acquainting her with the caue; I mut confee aid Daphnide, that his humour is the mot pleaant that any one can meet with, in his kind; and I beleeve all the company would be very orry to loe him. But I beeech you tell me, how long is it, ince firt he came amongt you; what moved him to come, and what buinee has he here? To which Quetions, Diana anwered, it is about four or five Months ince firt he came; as for the caue of his tay, I thinke it is uperfluous to tell you, knowing his humour o well as you do, for you may eaily imagine it; but for the occaion which brought him hither, I think none knowes, except himelfe, not that he is of o cloe and retired a temper, as that he will not tell any thing, but becaue alwayes when he began to tell us his tory, either he has been interrupted, or ele time would not erve him to tell it out: And I aure my elfe, Madam, if you would but intimate the leat deire of knowing it, he would without any difficulty tell it, for he thinkes himelfe obliged unto any that will hearken unto him in the relation of his fortunes.

I thinke, aid Daphnide, that it would be a very good diverion, if he would entertaine us with it, and the way would eeme lee tedious unto us: but the bet way to bring him to it, will be this faire Druid, aid he, and pointed at Alexis, if he would be pleaed to command him. Alexis hearing her elfe named, and eeing Daphnide point unto her, to hew that he was not too erious in her dicoure with Atrea, did aske her if he had any ervice to command her, and knowing by Diana what he deired, I aure you Madam (aid Alexis) that none has more power than your elfe, yet ince you are pleaed to put me upon it, I will try what I can doe: Then calling unto him, Servant, aid he, I am growne very jealous. Fairet Mitree, aid Hylas, you have no occaion for it. Yes, (aid Alexis) the occaion is very great: For beides the beauty of thee faire trangers, which is occaion enough; you know there is good reaon to upect one of theft who is accutomed to teale: You meane, anwered Hylas, and miled, that I have been accutomed to teale away the hearts of thoe who looke upon me, and you feare I hould doe the like by thee new hepherdees; but never feare it, fairet Mitree; for it may be I hall commit this theft, but though I doe take their hearts, yet I promie you, they hall not take mine, for it is only yours. This aurance, Servant, aid Alexis, does pleae me very well, but that is not my meaning: For it is, that thee trangers are very fair, and you doe make it your glory and boat to love all thoe who have any beauty. Hylas
then going neerer Alexis, I perceive Mitree, aid he unto her, that you doe not yet know after what manner I ue to love. You mut know that I ue to doe as Merchants ue; when any of them has an intention to buy any commodity, they looke well upon it, and conider what it is worth, and lay by uch a tocke of money as is equall to the worth and as far as that um will go, they will bid, and no farther, and when they have bought the commodity, they value it at uch a um as they gave, and pend accordingly: Now I ue to doe the like; for when I firt intend to love a Lady, I preently looke upon her beauty (for you mut know that it is beauty which ets the worth and value upon a woman) and when I have conidered the full value of it, preently I lay by a tocke of Love in my oule, equall unto the price and value of beauty which he has, and when I love, I bid o much as that tocke comes unto, and pend upon it. Then, after I have pent all that um in her ervice, for whom I firt laid it by, I have no more for her; but if I will love, I mut looke out for another beauty and lay by another um for it, o as in this, my money and my love are alike; I mean, that when I have pent them, I can pend no more; therefore Mitree, you might have ome reaon to feare, if I never had loved thee new hepherdees before, but it is o long ince I pent all tocke which I laid by for their beauties as I have none left for them, my money is gone, and it will not come againe. But Servant, aid Alexis, Merchants that are rich, though they have once or twice emptied their pures, yet will they fill them againe, to buy that at the econd bidding, which they could not at the firt. Perhaps they may, replyed Hylas, but Mitree, uch rich Merchants and I am not alike; for they will chaffer and bid two or three times, whereas I bid all at the firt: beides, if they have no money, they will borrow upon their credit, and I pend and trade only upon my owne tock; This, replyed Daphnide, and miled, is the finet way of loving that ever it was my fortune to heare of. It is o, aid Alexis, but not very advantageous unto me, for I am affraid that you will quickly have pent your tocke of Love, which you laid up for me, and then you will love me no longer. Tis true indeed, aid Hylas, that, hould I pend it all, you could not hope for any more in me, but that is abolutely impoible; for when I firt lay by a tocke of Love, I do make it equal unto the beauty which I love, and yours being infinite, you mut thinke that the heap that I laid up to equall it, is a vat Mountaine. I am glad of it, replyed Alexis, and eteeming you as I doe, hould be very orry to loe you; and this moves me to intreat you, that if this Mountaine be not o big as you doe ay it is, you will abate a little, and leen your expences to the end your Proviion may hold out the longer; I had rather you would pend a little lee, and imitate thoe good Husbands who pend one day, as it may hold out the whole year. Mitree, aid he preently, if that be all your care, et your heart at ret, for my mountaine of Love to you, will lat as long as I live. But good Servant, aid Alexis, though your mountaine be as bigge as you ay, yet methinkes you hould deire mine hould be as big to you, leat this love hould be lame, and let downe of one ide? You ay very well, replyed Hylas, and I doe deire it with all my heart. Then aid Alexis, you mut ue ome meanes whereby you may come to the knowledge of it I have heard, that nothing is more requiite unto Love, than the knowledge of the thing loved; and how doe you thinke I hould love you, unlee I know you? Hidden treaures are not etimable; your actions, I make no quetion would render you of high eteem, if they were once known; and therefore if you do deire that I hould love you, than you mut let me know the Story of your life, epecially at this time when you may have o good an Auditory, and therefo • I would not have you let lip the opportunity. What Mitree, aid Hylas, is all this long preamble onely for this? the very leat yllable you could have hinted would have commanded it, and you hall ee that my affection is above your curioity, though let me tell you I hold the maxime in Love to be fale, that one mut know before one can love, as well as I doe all the ret which Silvan • er mot aburdly vents. But to hew my obedience I will tell you all I know of my elfe. Then placing Adamas in the middle of the Company, every one was very attentive, and to heare the better, ome almot trode upon his heeles. And then eeing all ilent, he began thus.

div.head: The Hitory of Chryide and Hylas.
div.p: IGnorance has this quality, that it caueth many things to be condemned, which in themelves are laudable: And this I have often found to be true, ince I came amongt thee hepherdees about the River Lignon, where the fale Tenents of Silvander are o much followed, as all he ayes is Oracle, and it is held an offence againt the very Gods, not to believe what ere he ayes. This is an error o rooted in the opinion of all that fect, as it is, in matter of Love, a crime of the highet nature, to contradict him. Yet I, who am not wayed by opinion, but by truth; and who will not be convinced by words, but by reaons; I have ever followed that which reaon dictates unto me, and bids me doe. Can any be o irrationall as to blame experience, which is the mother and the Nure of Prudence? yet talke to Silvander, or any of his hereticall ect, and they will maintaine it even with their lives that all experience is vicious and fallacious; and that they mut cleave unto their own errors, like nailes which once ticking to a wall, mut not part from it: As if the Gods had not given us a judgement and reaon to dicern things that are good, things that are better, and things that are mot perfect.

Thee Coniderations, I beeech you, fairet Mitree, et before your eyes, when you ee that I have ometimes loved and changed; and yet do not feare I hall change you for any other, becaue it is impoible to find one that is better or more perfect; For when I am come once to the highet tep, I cannot go any higher. You are not the firt, fairet Mitree, that has deired to undertand the equell of my trange fortune; many others have had the ame curiotry, and ome in this company. What I have formerly related into them, I will not relate now, becaue they can inform you as well as I: And therefore I will onely tell you, that I am originally of Carmargues, where I began my Apprentihip with Carlis, and ended it with Stiliana. Afterwards, being but yet a novit in my trade, I quitted that place and came to Lions, after that I had by the way loved the faire Aymea, the fool Ploriante, and the ad Cloris,. Then being come thither, I aw Circena, whom, as my love unto her began in the Temple, o it dyed as oon as I was out againe, and revived it elfe in the charitable Palinice; and from her was transferred unto the kind Parthenopea, afterwards to the crafty Dorinde, and the proud Florice. And becaue Florice is the lat I named, I will begin my dicoure where my love to her ended, that you may the better undertand what you deire to know concerning my life.

Periander, a very brave Cavalier, and one that was paionately in love with Dorinde, to pleae her, was a caue of my declining Florice, by tealing from me (though my friend) ome Letters which he had written unto me: And Dorinde to be revenged both of her and me, hewed them (like a pitefull woman as he was) unto Theombres the husband of Florice, who upon this, fell into uch a upition of her, as he carried her out of the the Town, o as in a little time I began to forget her: for Mitree, I mut ingenuouly confee, that as my love began firt by my eyes, o it ended as oon as it wanted nourihment from my eyes, according to that true Maxime Out of ight, out of mind, and what is far from the eye never troubles the heart. Florices tay out of Town a whole moneth (a term long enough to kindle and extinguih a dozen everall loves in me) had been enough to quench all my flames to her. But her tay being to continue a longer time, I reolved with my elfe to take my leave of her: for I could never like thoe loves, that can feed themelves with thoughts and fancies, and fond imaginations. But finding Love to be a fire, and my elfe burned with it, I thought the bet Cure was by ympathy, and to cure my elfe by another fire; and in order to this, I ought out for ome new beauty which might cure my old burn; and at lat, heaven which alwayes favours deignes that are jut, ent me uch a fire as I tood in need of.

One evening as I was walking without any other deign, but taking the air by the River Arar, cloe by a Bridge, and looking about, I epied three Coaches drawn by ix Hores apeece: And becaue that was amongt us an equipage unuual, I drew neerer the bridge to ee them pae. In one of them was four Ladies habited much different from our Mode, and very rich; and their uncouth habits made me look upon them with more curioity and eagernee. The firt whom fortune fixed my eye upon, did keep it upon her as long as
I could ee; She was in the firt Coach, and eated in the bet place; her hair was faire, omething inclinable to Chenut; her Complexion, no dye could make a mixture of uch perfect vermilion upon now; her eyes black, but o quick, weet, and piercing, as no heart had humour good enough to reit them; her lips exact Corrall, her N • ck a Column of puret Alablater, and every part proportionable in perfection: as for her tature, I could not perfectly ee it, but as near as I could judge, it was neither tall nor little: as for her Hand, which he often hewed in lifting up her haire which lay upon her houlder in curles, it could not be equalled unto any thing o well as to the whitenee of her neck.

Judge, Madam, whether uch a beauty could be looked upon and not loved; he was the fire by which I cured all my other burnings, o as quite forgetting Circinea, Palanice, Dorinde, and Florice, I devoted my elfe wholly unto her. But perhaps you will thinke it trange, that he being in a Coach, and onely paant, I hould oberve o many particulars in this beauty; but you mut conider, that I looked upon her with more eyes then my own, and had thoe of love to help me in looking upon this wonder. Nor mut you believe any uch thing which Silvander is often alleadging, that Love is blind: but on the contrary, that thoe who look with his eyes, can look through drees and ee uch beauties as are hid from others. But it eems that love had a deign upon me at this time, for he would not let me make ue of his eyes and my hands, but loadned the Coach heavier then it was before, becaue it carried my heart away with it.

I ee Silvander, you laugh; and I know you would ay that the Coach was not a jot more loadned for having my heart in it; but know, that my heart as light as it is, yet is as heavy as yours. I know not that, aid Silvander, but I am ure the Coach which carried your heart, had need go very fat, or ele your heart would quickly be out, for it cannot endure to be long in a place. This aid Hylas, was Perianders opinion, when he found me looking upon thee trangers as they paed. This good friend of mine perceiving me halfe out of my elfe, did begin to upect the caue; and coming unto me, Courage, Hylas, aid he unto me; you will recover of this, I warrant you, as well as you have done of others.

I anwered him with a love ick look; I ee Periander, you mock me; but did you know how great my pain was, you would pitty me, though I mut confee it proceeds from love, Ah, ah, my friend, aid he and laughed, have a good heart; this is not the firt time you have been ick of the ame dieae and never dyed. 'Tis true, aid I unto him, then I did know who was the caue, but now I am ignorant of it: How friend? aid Periander and laughed; What? in love, and knows not with whom? So it is, aid I unto him, and I cannot help it, Love has catcht me. That you do love, aid he, I doe believe, but that you hould love, and not know her whom you doe love, though I hould believe you in any thing ele, yet in this I am incredulous: And if it be true, I ay it is a thing as eaily done, as to perwade any to believe it. Whether you believe it or no, aid I, and ighed, yet I am ure it is o. How long, aid he, have you been ick of this fantatical dieae? A little longer, anwered I, then we have been talking of it. Upon this, Per • ander laughed, and laying his hand upon my houlder, aid; Well friend, if you be long ick of this dieae, I will pay your Doctors: then he offered to go away, but I laid hold upon his Cloak: What? aid I unto him, is this all the helpe and conolation I mut expect from your friendhip? What can I doe for you, anwered he, as long as you doe not know her that is the caue of your malady? You may help me, replyed I, and contrive it how I hould come to the knowledge of her whom I adore. This is trange folly, aid he, Can I know her better then you doe? Why not, replyed I; Is it not ordinary for people in health, to tell ick folks their dieae, and to give them uch remedies as they themelves knew not? Ah, Periander, did you love me as well as you profee, you would not deny me that aitance which friendhip requires. To which he anwered; In the name of Heaven, Hylas, what would you have me to ay or doe? upon my faith I think you are become a fool. A fool, aid I, is it folly to love her whom I adore? he whom I am ready to die for, will not yeeld unto any Goddee in beauty; he has more Graces, then all the Graces themelves; and if Love were not hood-winckt, doubtlee he would dote upon her: but the truth is, I know not who he is. This is fine folly indeed, replyed he; where, and when did you ee her? Oh Heavens, aid I, are you blind, that you could not ee the Sun when it hin'd? Did you not ee the Coaches which
paed by? In the firt of them was he whom I love, and know not, Is it o, aid he unto me, then friend know, that you are a Prioner unto a Prioner; Gondebunt our King did take them beyond the Alpes, and hath ent them hither as Trophies of his Victory.

Thus I undertood who this faire tranger was, and had it not been very late I had endeavoured to have een her that night, but deferring untill the morning I retired to my lodging o tormented that I could not ret all the night. As oone as day appeared, I left my bed: And becaue Periander promied to accompany me to the Pallace, where we might ee them as they went to the Temple, and taying in my Chamber till he came, I took my Glae, and trimmed my elfe up as gay as poibly I could, and kept uch a tirre with curling my haire, and etting my elfe in a right quirpo, as none about me were able to pleae me. Then taking the Glae into my hand and and finding my haire appeared a little too much of the gilded hue, alo thinking that it would make but a bad impreion in the fancy of women, I loaded my head with o much Cypree powder, as it looked more like the head of a Miller than the head of Hylas: And Periander uprizing me, looked on a long while before I perceived him; at the lat, turning about, and lifting up my eyes, I aw him laughing. Periander, aid I unto him, you are no good friend of mine, ince in lieu of help and pitty, you laugh at me. And o I may very well, aid he, and I cannot beleeve your paine to be o great, unlee Love in revenge of your folly, doe make you find that in your elfe, which you would hardly beleeve in another. Wherein, aid I, have I beene o incredulous? In that o great an affection cannot be found, aid he, as will efface all other cares but uch as concerne, and depend upon it.

You are in the right (aid I unto him) but did you ever ee me o deirous to pleae any of thoe I loved? Nay, put all the Loves I ever had unto this time together, they cannot all equall the affection which I have unto this one, and therefore you need not think it trange I hould be o carefull, and take more paines with my elfe for her, then for all the ret: For I know very well that the firt impreions which are made in the minds of women, are not eaily blotted out. Thus talking to him, and till tricking up my elfe as fine as poibly I could Come, come, aid he, and make an end of all your finerye, for otherwie they will be gone before you come; then taking my hand, and pulling me almot by force from my glae, he contrained me to follow him unto the Pallace, where thoe faire trangers were lodged, unto which we were no ooner come, but we aw them going to the Temple, two and two together, holding hands.

I was o attentive in eeing them pae along, and oberving which was he who had thus wounded me, that Periander, by way of mockery whipered me in the ear; take heed, aid he, that he whom you admire o much, doe not pae by, and you not know her; hould my eyes commit uch a fault, aid I, I would pull them out, and they hould never deceive me againe. Well, well, aid he, I am much mitaken if he be not pat already: Is it poible, replyed I preently, doe you not mocke me? Upon this, not taying for any anwer, I ran a little forward, that I might ee them pae againe; but then I found Periander onely mocked me, for preently after, I aw her whom I expected, the lat of them all, adorned with o many beauties, as he attracted the eyes of all upon her. This econd viion did o ravih me, that I knew not what I did, onely I remember that when he paed before me, I could not chue but ay with a deepe igh; Here comes the fairet of all; and it hapned, of all thee Strangers none but he undertood the language of Gaule, o as I obliged her without diobliging the ret, becaue they undertood me not; for mot certainly to undervalue a womas beauty is a wound almot incurable. And on the contrary, of all flatteries none more pleaing unto them than thoe that applaud their beauties, for let it be never o groe, yet it will be beleeved true. The Temple was a good ditance from the Pallace, and yet I found it o hort, that I thought the way o hort, as they were there before I imagined it halfe way, and I thought the Sacrifice o hort, as it was ended before I thought it begun, and this becaue I received uch extreame contentment in looking upon this fair tranger, and my eye was never off as long as the Sacrifice lated. Thee Ladies alo were as full of curioity as we, and were not o fervent in their devotions, but they would ometimes looke round about the Temple, and it hapned that this faire Stranger never turned her eye towards me, but he aw mine fixed upon her.

Then Diana miled and aid, Hylas I mut needs interrupt you a little, and put you in mind you doe not blapheme Veta and the good Goddee. Temples were made to pray unto the Gods and not for any amorous deignes; Why, aid Hylas, will not the Gods permit us to doe that on earth, which they themelves doe in Heaven? Then, not taying for Dianas anwer, he full into his dicoure again.

The Sacrifice being ended, they returned in the ame order as they came; and as fortune was, at their coming out of the Temple, which as you know tood high, and had many teps to decend from it, this Faire one looking another way, and wearing very high hooes, he fell at the lat tep, but without receiving any hurt: I who had my eye continually upon her, ran preently to her, and taking her by the arm, I helped her up, with o much contentment unto my elfe, as I thought all the paines I tooke that day very well imployed, having done her this triviall ervice, which as he ince confeed was the firt knowledge he had of my good will; and this was the reaon why ever ince in all my other affections, I did never omit the leat occaion, though never o triviall, which might be any way erviceable unto thoe I loved, oberving from hence, that in imitation of good Fencers, it is better to make many blows, though they be not mortall, then to tay all the day for one ingle blow, becaue he is very ignorant in the mitery that cannot defend himelfe from one blow; but when he fals on pell mell, and gives blow after blow; it is almot impoible but ome hould take effect. In this I doe hint particularly at Silvander, who is o proud, that he will never doe any lee ervice unto his Mitee than the aving of her life, thinking that other lee ervices doe not deerve to be put upon accompt.

S • lvander, leat he hould interrupt, would not anwer, but eeing the eyes of all the Company upon him, epecially Diana, as if he expected omething from him, he thought himelfe obliged to peak. Hylas, aid he, I doe confee part, and part diavow what you doe ay of my humour; for uch trifling ervices as doe not merit the name of ervice, and are no more than common Complements, they are not worthy of uch accompt, as you doe make of them, ince the greatet ought to be blotted out of the memory of him who renders them. How, aid Hylas, and hoke his head, mut one blot out of memory a long ervice? Why then hould one ever doe them, if things pat mut be forgotten? Beleeve it my good friend Silvander, women will eaily conent unto uch a Law, for Ingratitude, which is their Nature, is the mother of Oblivion; but I have o oberved the ervices which I have done them, as if they doe eeme not to remember them, or to take no notice of them, I hall tell them of it, as they hall be deafe if they doe not apprehend them. And to tell you truly, I beleeve if your ervices did merit as much as mine, you would not et o low a rate upon them, or to ay better, you would not make uch good ue of them: As for me, I doe thinke the very leat ervice I doe, does deerve a great recompence Did I not know, aid Silvander, and miled, that the Ile of Camargue is your Country, I hould thinke eeing you et o great a value upon a little, that you were borne in a certaine Country of the Gaules where the Inhabitants have three qualities which are not much unlike your humour. What are they? aid Hylas. I would not willingly tell them, aid Silvander, but ince you urge me, you hall know.

The firt is, that they are rich, yet have but a little; The econd is, they are Doctors, yet have but a little learning; And the lat is, they are extreamly proud, yet have but a a little honour. Hylas would have anwered halfe in anger, but the laughter was o lowd that he could not. And afterwards when he offered to peake, Silvander was before him, and with a mile, aid, let it atisfie you Hylas, that I aid not this of the Province of the Romans, where you were borne; but if you thinke your elfe obliged unto ome reentment of it, I give you leave with all my heart to ay as much of the place where I was borne, if you pleae. No quetion, replyed Hylas preently, but that if your Country were not as much unknown to me as to your elfe, I hould not be long mute, but hould ay as much for you, and with more truth, yet not knowing where this trange Land is, one may eaily judge that it produces nothing but ruhes and thitles, ince it hath ent forth uch pricking and biting pirits as yours. To which Silvander having no mind to reply, becaue he would not hinder him from his tory; Hylas after a little ilence, continued thus.

The cutome of the ancient Towne of Lyons which is to welcome and entertaine all trangers, and mot religiouly to oberve all Lawes of Hopitality, was a caue that Amaonte
Aunt unto Periander, a few dayes after the arrivall of thee faire trangers, did enquire of thoe who had the guard of them whether it would be permitted to viit them, and undertanding that the King was very well pleaed to allow it, he went unto them, and offered unto them all manner of aitance and ervice; he had a daughter called Orinda, who was not unhanome: This daughter was at the firt viit o much pleaed with thee Ladies, and o was Amaonte, that they went very often afterwards to ee them. By fortune the greatet intimacy they had, was with that Fair one who had o captivated me. And it was, as I beleeve, beides thoe perfections which he had above the ret of her companions, becaue he poke the Gaul language, and becaue he had been brought up in thoe Countries, Periander acquainting me with thee paages, I told him, that he mut needs contrive it o by any means, that this good Aunt of his did might us admittance without acquainting her with any deign.

And we parting in this reolution, that ame day Periander dining with his Aunt, eemed to be inquiitive in hearing her to tell of thee trangers, and enquired very particularly how they behaved themelves, and whether they were civill and affable, to whom Amaonte and Orinda, both giving very high and advantageous Characters of them, he feigned an extream deire of eeing and talking with them. If you will, anwered Orinda, you may go with my Mother and me, o atisfie your curioity. 'Tis true, aid Amaonte, if men may be permitted to viit them, and of that I have not enquired: but to morrow I promie you to ask the quetion, whether any men have yet or may be admitted, and if any have been allowed, you hall I warrant you, as oon as any. And indeed; the good Aunt was as good as her word; for the next morning he undertood that any might come and viit them; for the King did not feare any could teal them away, having them o farre from home.

When Periander brought me this newes, it was not unwelcome unto me, as you may well imagine, epecially when I heard, that the next day in the afternoon, they would conduct us thither. The day eemed o long to my impatience, as I asked what a clock it was, above a hundred times, thinking the Sun a luggard and lower then uual: I was no lee unquiet all the night, nor had any more patience all the morning, untill the hour came, when Periander was to go unto the Palace Royall; there I o well meaured my time, as when they came to the Gate I met them, and eeming as if the meeting was meerly accidentall; I asked Periander whither he was going? He anwered, that he was to wait upon his Mother (for o he called Amaonte) then he addreed her elfe unto me, and aid, If, Sir, you be a friend, you will not leave Periander alone upon this occaion, I will never enquire what it is, ince you command me, anwered I, and ince it is to erve my friend. And as I aid o, I took Orinda by the arm; Periander could not chue but laugh, when he aw me eem o ignorant of the voyage, and the readinee I ued in taking hold of the occaion. Thus we entred into the place where the trangers were; and at the firt, I aw the faire one whom I o much admired come with open arms, a miling countenance, and great demontration of good will unto Orinda, whoe happinee I envied.

After the firt alutations and complements of coure, Amaonte deiring I hould receive ome good looks from this faire Prioner, by her meanes, did let her undertand who we were, acquainted her with the great intimacy betwixt Periander and me, and with the deire we had to doe them any ervice: and therefore addreing unto us, he hewed her elfe as weetly kind, as civility would permit her: Then turning towards me, he remembred how I helped her up when he fell at the Temple tairs. I perceive, Madam, aid I unto her, One hall never complaine of any ervices done unto you, ince you can o well remember o mall a matter; Though our Ladies in Gaul either out of pride or want of memory, doe not onely forget mall ervices, but alo the greatet one can do them. I pray, Sir, aid he unto me, how can you attribute this unto their pride. They have uch a high opinion of their own merits, anwered I, as they thinke all the world is obliged to erve them: • nd receiving all our ervices as but due debts, they depie them, and depiing them, <> not daign to remember them. Sir, aid he unto me and miled you decribe your Ladies to be of a very trange humour. But take heed let what you ay, doe not proceed from ome other occaion: Our ex is o the Butt of detraction, that we are very often contrained to eem as if we did not ee things, which yet we doe ee as well as men themelves; and in this, we are rather to be pittied then blamed.

Periander and Orinda, were retired a little on the other ide, and purpoely that might have ome dicoure with her, whilt Amaonte entertained the other trangers: This incouraged me to be more bold in my anwer. Had thee Ladies, whom you, Madam, excue o much, replyed I, but uch bodies, and uch wits, and pirits, as you have, though they were much more cruel then they are, yet would they need no excues; for then, be they never o autere, yet would they not onely be erved, but even adored by all men.

This language did not at all tartle her, but with a miling eye he anwered thus: I ee, Sir, flattery is in ue here in Gaul, as well as amongt the Romans: I thought it h • d only been beyond the Alpes, but I perceive the Gaules who are reported to peak from their hearts, have it amongt them, as well as other people. Madam, anwered I, I cannot tell whether your Nation doe call truth flattery, or whether to flatter be in your language to peak truth; but I doe weare and protet by our Great Tautates, which is the deepet oath I can take, that I did never in all my life ee any face comparably o fair as yours, nor any wit o good and perfect as yours is.

Thus, Mitree, I continued my dicoure, and before we parted, I did let her undertand, that I had a deire to doe her particular ervice: perhaps you will think it trange, I hould thus at the firt make this remontrance unto her; but you mut know, that my humour was not to languih it out in amorous Trances, nor to let my eyes be Orators as long as my tongue could tell her my heart. For I ever thought that delayes doe rather marre then make it better, and that in love, not to vanquih quickly, is to be vanquihed; but the principal motive why I would no longer deferre the declaration of my affection unto this faire tranger, was a double conideration, which at that time I had in my mind: I conidered that he was in the power of another, and not as others are under a Mother or Parents: but a Prioner of War, and kept by command from Gondebert, as the ret of her companions were. And becaue it was hard to know what deigne he had upon her, I feared let this opportunity hould be taken from me, either by being guarded more trictly, or removed unto ome other place. I conidered alo, that he came from beyond the Alpes, where the women are much bolder to attempt what they deire, and execute what they attempt, then our women of Gaul are: I ound this to be their temper by my convere in Camargue, and in the Town of Arles, which made me think that this faire one would not derogate from her Climate, nor thinke this uddain declaration trange.

Following therefore the genius of her Country and my own, I did acquaint her with my affection. And though perhaps my words were not at the firt taken as proceeding from love, but civility; yet however, they did break the Ice, and facilitate the way to my enuing addrees, and made her believe that which I did deire to perwade her of: I had an opinion that he had no thoughts which tended unto what I deired; and yet he took more pleaure in talking with me, then with Periander, or any that came to viit her; he thinking that this affection which tyed me unto her, did oblige her to trut more in me. And though I had no other knowledge of her good will then this, yet I can truly ay, that there were very few things which he did not communicate unto me, though never o private or important; and within a moneth after the firt time I had een her, there was o great familiarity betwixt us, as he advertied me, how he and her companions intended to walk in the Athenian Ile at the evening, in a Garden which was where the Rone and Arar met, a place very pleaant, both in variety of Wal • s, and Groves of Trees. I reolved not to mis this appointment, as well becaue I had no other exercie nor deign, as becaue I thought he would be much offended if being o ecretly advertied of it, I hould let lip that opportunity which he gave me. When he aw me firt, he eemed unto her Companions, as if the meeting were by chance and not deigne. What fortune brought you hither, Hylas, aid he unto me, where my companions and my elfe did think to pae away the ret of the day uneen by any? This diimulation of the matter, did pleae me very well. For it is a good igne of love, to hide from others the addree which is made unto any Lady. And to econd her in her artifice, I anwered very faintly. It is impoible Madam, but that the fortune which brought me hither hould be good, ince I am o happy in meeting uch company; and it would be much better, if I knew any way how to doe you any acceptable ervice.

Thoe who began to undertand a little of our language did thanke me in mot pittifull
broken words, yet as kindly as they could, and went away into everall walkes, leaving us two together as we deired to be. I tooke her therefore under the Arm, and began to walke, but leat he hould thinke o much familiarity trange, I aid unto her, though this Madam be not the cutome and fahion of your Country, yet it is in Gaule, and therefore I beeech you take it not ill, if I ue our owne priviledges, and by taking your arme doe helpe you to walke, Hylas, anwered he, your kindnee unto me obligeth me unto more familiarity than this: Tis true, that the condition wherein I am will not let me acknowledge it more than in words, o as I cannot require your amity as I ought to doe; upon this I oberved her to igh and change colour, as if the thought of her condition did exceedingly trouble her: And being very deirous to know the particular caue of her adnee, after many thankes for her kind expreions, I beeeched her to let me know what Fortune brought her into this Country, and what tayed her in it: And becaue it is no mall advantage (marke well Silvander what I ay) to know the fortunes and humours of thoe, whoe favour we deire, I was the more urgent with her: For I hould be thereby the better intructed what will pleae, and what will dipleae her Hylas, aid he, doe you not know that I am a Prioner unto King Gondebunt, and how much my Companions and I am obliged unto him? And I anwering that I knew it onely by vulgar report. Then anwered he, I hall acquaint you with thoe particulars which you deire; and you hall heare the mot lamentable Adventure that ever befell a poore woman; onely I beeech you to be very ilent in it, and impart it unto none.

div.head: The Hitory of Cryeide and Arimant.
div.p: FOrtune is pleaed to trouble not onely Monarchies and great States, but alo to hew her power upon private perons, to let us know that all things under heaven are under her lah; the mieries I have indured, and the lamentable life I have hitherto led, does but too well manifet this truth, as you may judg: For, I being but a poor illy woman, yet his tudy is to croe me, and not to let me injoy a minute of quietnee, never ince I had the judgement to diceme betwixt good and evill. I am of a Country whoe people are called Salaes, a place confined by the golden Baltea and the Libices on the Eat, by the Po, on the South; the Taurinois, Centurons and Catur • es on the Wet; and the Alpes on the North.

This Country is very well known unto the Romans by reaon of the many Gold Mines which are in it, and for which the Inhabitants of the place have beene forced to revolt o often. I have made this decription of my Country unto you, that you may the better undertand what was foretold my Father when I was borne, by a female Druide, who came out of Gaw into this Country, by the command (as he aid) of a great God, whoe name was unknown unto us, and I think it was by him whom you did wear. Is it Tautates; aid I unto her? The ame, anwered he whom this woman aid was a great God, and all others depended upon him, Now this female Fortune teller came to my Fathers houe, at the ame time when my Mother was delivered of me: And my Father eeing her look very earnetly upon me, he asked her what my fortune would be: It will be, anwered he, like unto the Country where he is borne. This anwer was very darke: But ome yeares after he chanced to come againe unto the ame place, and my Mother being very inquiitive did pree her to explaine her former prediction. To whom he anwered, that this woman hall have the ame fortune which the Country wherein he was borne hath; the Romans by reaon of the Gold found there have o harraed the people by wars, as it is almot depopulated, o as her abundance is the caue of her poverty; even o hall this your daughter be very much troubled by reaon of her beauty and merit. And certainely this Druid was very knowing; for I have found ever ince, that never was woman more croed by fortune than my elfe, as you may judge by the enuing dicoure.

I was born, as I told you, amongt the Sallaes, in a Town called Eporides, eated between two great Hils, where the golden Baltea runs: my Father was called Leander, and my mother Luira, and though my owne praies be not hanome out of my owne mouth, yet that you may the better undertand the equell of this dicoure, you mut know, that
there was none in all the Country, who did not yeild unto my Father, in grandure, in antiquity of Family, in offices which he poeed, or in authority which he had gotten, as well by his owne merit, as by the favour of Honorius, and ince of Vaelentinian, and all thoe who ince him ruled over Italy, who advanced him unto that height, that if his death had not prevented it, when the Empire was in decline, doubtlee he had not only made himelfe Soveraigne Lord over the Sallaes, but alo of the Libices, of the Centrons and of the Veragrois.

This his death was the firt blow which I received from Fortune & did not reent it, for want of capacity: For, being but nine yeares of age, I knew not what it was to loe a Father, and to be at the dipoition of a mother who was more carefull of her elfe than her Children, yet I lived very contentedly till I came to be fourteen of fifteen years old, for till then. Fortune did not thinke me able to feele the weight of her blows; and ee how ubtilly he undermined me: for he gilded over her bitter pils of poyon with a gloe of good, knowing very well (cruell one as he is) that any miery that comes under the hrowd of a happinee, makes it elfe much more enibly reented.

In the ame Towne where I was, did dwell very many Cavaliers: for that Gaul, which is called Cia • pine is not as it is here, for I have heard, that here Cavaliers and men of quality doe live in the Country. Amongt the ret, there was one young Libicinian Gallant, who certainly was as much favoured by Nature in all the graces he could betow, as was poible; nor did he want any noblenee of Ancetors, nor alliance to the bet Families, nor any other good quality that could poibly be deired, but only Riches; and in that, he was little beholding to his Father, who was all his life more thirty after the acquiition of Honour than Wealth, little conidering that the one without the other is like a bird that has good wings, yet has uch a clog at her foot that he cannot fly. This young man did dwell in Eporides by reaon of the hatred which Rhithimer bore unto his Father. I uppoe, Hylas, you have heard, how this Rhithimer though a Goth by Nation, yet through his valour and good conduct was made a Citizen of Rome; afterward, Patrician, and latly Governour of Gaul Cialpine, or indeed, rather the Lord of it; for his Commiion was o large, and his authority o abolute, that he might be called Lord as well as Governour.
