The Father of Arimant (for o was the young man called) had mot jut occaion to feare his Enemy; For though otherwayes he was very well accomplihed, yet he had ever in him the Nature of a Goth: And this was the reaon why he came into this Towne that he might o much the ooner goe out of Italy, in cae he was forced to it, either by the Centrons, by the Veragrois, or by the Helvetians.

This young Cavalier of whom I peake did accidentally ee me at a marriage which was kept in the houe of one of my Cozens. The cutom of the Country is, that upon uch occaion, entrance is permitted unto all as freely as into Churches. I ay that as ill lucke was, he aw me there: For there he fell in love with me, and this love was the cource both of all his mieries and mine. He tooke occaion to declare his love unto me in a Ball, wherein many ue to dance at once by two and two, walking only round the roome, and oberving the cadency a little. The name of it was the great Ball, and invented purpoely to give a hanome opportunity unto Cavaliers of talking unto Ladies. Arimant tooke me out, and though it was with a deigne of dicovering his affection, yet was it long before he durt begin; yet at lat, leat he hould loe uch an opportunity as was hard to be met with againe, he forced himelfe, and aid thus unto me. Fair Chryiede aid he unto me (for he had enquired my name) the Iawes of this Country are too rigid, if not unjut, in keeping o cloe, that which is mot faire: I doe not know (aid I unto him) upon what you doe ground your peech. Upon cutome, anwered he, which is to keepe the Ladies up o cloe: as that they hew themelves o eldome, as a man can hardly ay he ees them, and not to goe farre for an example: Is it not extreame cruelty I hould be ix Months in this Towne, and this is the firt time I have the happinee to ee you? Faire Ladies Sir, aid I unto him, doe conceale themelves upon very good conideration. For too often eene, too much contemned: But why hould you put me in the Catalogue of faire ones, or complaine of eeing me o eldome? Since certainely the ight of me mut needs be very indifferent unto you? It is too much, aid he and ighed, to overcome one peron twice; it was enough your eyes had already got the victory over me, without doubly urmounting me by the weetnee and charms of your refined wit.

This uddaine declaration did urprie me, yet I cannot tell how, it did not offend me, and I anwered him thus. You are eaily overcome, Sir, if vanquihed by uch imple arms, as your Conqueror is owner of; and ince he never o much as thought of obtaining this victory. However, aid he, I am vanquihed, and I am neither ahamed nor orry, for being vanquihed by uch arms.

I knew not all this while, who this young Cavalier was, having never een him before: yet ince he was o confident as to addree himelfe unto me, I did imagine him a man of principall Rank amongt the Sallaes; his hanome preence, and the expreion of his affection, made me very deirous to know his name: And I mut confee I had been put hard to it for an anwer, if the Ball had continued longer. But it being ended, I had opportunity to enquire of what I deired. He who began to be enible of loves firt blows, which commonly are full of impatience, and who thought that perhaps it would be long before he had uch another opportunity, he took me out to dance againe although it was not the cutome; but being grown more bold, and a better husband of his time, he aid thus unto me; I have been aured, that faire ones will never believe things that are true, and rather hearken unto things things that are not o. Though I hould leave it unto fair ones, to give you an anwer (aid I) yet ince they doe not hear, I will aske you, why you accue them of that fault? Becaue, anwered he, I find it o in you. Pardon me, fair Cryide, if I offend you. Why do not you believe me, when I ay that I am your mot devoted ervant, for it is mot true? Ar • mant, aid I, words onely cannot perwade me to believe what you ay, ince reaon gives your tongue the lye; and ince I know that men make profeion of giving much for a little money. If it be o, aid he, then I doe protet that I am not a man. What are you then, replyed I preently? I am, aid he, your ervant, and the mot faithfull and zealous ervant that ever was. I mut needs confee, Hylas, that his noble extraction, and his neat wit, had obliged me to give him another kind of anwer then I did, but for ome other coniderations which hindred me, and therefore I onely aid thus unto him; we hall ee Arimant, whether you continue in the ame mind the next time we meet, and I will deferre my anwer until then.

The Ball now ended and the company parted, for it was upper time, and doe what he could, I would not give him any opportunity of peaking unto me againe, thinking that for the firt time he might be very well contented with uch anwers as he had received. And becaue the joy for this marriage continued many dayes, the next day, and as oft as the meetings continued, he did not omit any opportunity of tetifying the truth of his expreions: which at the lat, I was perwaded to believe, and to atisfie him o farre, as to let him thinke I loved him. 'Tis true, I tayed until the very lat day, before I did o declare my elf unto him, let if I had done it ooner, he hould pretend to any greater favour, and had I tarried any longer, I could not have told him o much; but I would not upon any terms, let him go without ome aurance of my good will.

Since this time, it was long before we aw each other, except in Temples and publique places, which I mut confee did trouble me, becaue indeed, I did begin to love him, conidering his dicretion in the carriage of the buinee, o as none could upect his deigne. He would come often in the night to my window, and preent me with ome Serenades: but that was all the viits I had from him.

My dicoure, kind Hylas, would be too long and tedious, if I hould relate all the particulars of this Courthip. Let it uffice, that Arimant could not with dicretion tetifie the good that he wihed unto me, although he ought out all wayes, and neglected no opportunity of doing it. Oh Hylas, how full of ubtilty Love is? and though they paint him but a boy, yet what old tricks he has? They are very ignorant who know it not, or who think to mater him. I know, and I know it by experience, and to my grief, that they who would overcome him, mut fight as thoe doe who get their victory by flying, for otherwie if they come to handy-blowes, he will get the better, it is abolutely impoibly to reit him: for he has o many tricks, and can ue o many everall orts of Arms, as with one or other doubtlee if he doe not wound, yet at leat he will foile and make cratches, and his weapons are alo impoyoned, that as oon as ever they draw blood, there is no hope of health for him that is o wounded, for his wounds will o itch, as he himelfe will cratch them and make them ore. Oh that I had known this before? For, Hylas, at the firt I did not admit of this addree, but onely to ee Arimant languih
before my face, as a tetimony of my beauty: Afterwards, his obequiouhee and kindnee, moved me to look upon him a little better, and then his Noble Extraction, his Merits, his Generoity, and his Dicretion, made me thinke very well of him, and a little after, to eteem him o, as I hould be orry to loe him And love was no ooner poeor of heart, but preently I was contrained to render it unto him, ince time did put me out of all doubt of his loving me. But I beeech your conider how uddenly my humour changed, when love had gotten this victory over me: As long as I did not love him, I cared not at all who knew of his affection to me: but on the contrary, was very glad it hould be divulged, as thinking that the more paionately he loved me, and the more it was known, the more was the honour of my beauty. But then, as oon as I began to love him, I cannot expree how I was offended at the leat knowledge of it, in o much as every time I talked of him, my principal charge was to be ilent and ecret, and carry all cloe. Our affaires then tanding upon thee terms, and our affections growing every day to a higher traine, our onely endeavours were for hanome occaions to tetifie them unto each other. But uch was the contraint in which the women beyond the mountaines lived, being kept as it were Prioners, as it was impoible for us to ee one another, unles by chance, nor to peak together but in the preence of ome, and that too, very eldome. This made him think upon an old woman, who got her living by going unto houes and elling Laces and Ribbands; that by her meanes we might peak unto each other by Paper, though not by voyce. He eaily gained the woman, what by promies, and what by Gifts. And he coming to the houe where I was, eeming to take meaure of me for a piece of Lace to a Gorget, and to that end drawing me to the window, he would have thrut a Letter into my hand, aying not a word but onely Arimant. I knew well enough it was a Letter from him, but being unwilling to be obliged unto the dicretion or fidelity of this woman whom I knew not; and knowing well enough, that uch kind of people being ininuators into the ecrets of uch as are o fond as to trut them, would afterwards prove very Tyrants, or ele ell their ilence at o dear a rate, as it was impoible to content them; I would not receive it, but on the contrary rejected it with uch harpe language, yet low, that the poor woman was quite out of countenance, and carried it back unto him that gave it her, intreating him to imploy her nomore in any uch matters. He who thought it would have been very welcome to me, and hoped for ome aurance of my good will in the anwer to it; eeing this refuall, and hearing what harpe words I ued, he was the mot atonihed man in the world; and not knowing unto whom to complaine, he came that very night into our treet with a conort of Muick, after they had played a leon or two, and uppoing I was come unto the window, he came jut under my window, and ung ome Veres which contained a complaint that he would not receive his Letters.

I eaily apprehended the reaon of his complaint; and becaue my refual did not pro
• oed from want of affection, I thought my elfe obliged to advertie him of it; o as taking Pen preently, I writ thee lines as fat as I could, and threw it out of the window.

div.head: Cryeide's Letter unto Arimant.
div.p: MY complaint would be more jut, if my affection to you would give me leave to complain of you; and if yours be equall to mine, it will not give you leave to complain of me for my lat refuall; nor to take it as an argument of little love, ince it proceeded from no other deigne but the preervation of my honour and your tranquillity, which in that act you put in danger: I doe not accue you of want, but rather excee of affection, which would not uffer you to conider the danger into which you put me, by putting me into the hands of one unknown unto me, and perhaps not faith full to you, ince mercenary, end no more yours, but as your money makes he • ; Be hereafter not lee loving, but more prudent, and be contented that I know you love me.

Now Hylas, you mut know, that conidering with my elfe, it was impoible to continue this ecret affection long, without a third peron, becaue as I told you before, the contraint of women was o great as we knew not which way to meet: Therefore I thought it a neceity to trut my elfe unto ome dicreet peron, who might both comfort
and counell me. In order unto this, I cat my eye upon all that were in the houe where I lived, and found none more fit than my Nures daughter, who was brought up with me and loved me o very well, as he thought her elf happy in any ervice he could do me. This wench was of my owne age, and uch a one, as I tood in need of; for he had more courage than I, and was o tout as he would often laugh at my feares and doubts. Moreover, he had wit at will, and was full of uch petty contrivances as I tood in need of. As for her fidelity and dicretion, I was o confident of them, as I durt trut her as oon as my elfe with any ecret: Moreover, he did govern • her owne Mother, who had the guardianhip of me, and lay in my Chamber. This was he whom I made choice of for my aitant, and acquainting her with what I thought expedient, I found her o utable to my deires, as at lat I imparted the very b • ttome of my heart and that my reolution was never to love any but Ar • mane.

Now Clarina (for o was her name) conidering the danger unto which I expoed my elfe, in throwing the Letter o out of the Window; he found out an invention to write with lee danger, and it was this. The evening before I intended he hould receive my Letter from me it was agreed betwixt us, that I hould hang out a Hankercher out of my window as if it were to dry, and by which we undertood, that the next morning at the time when others went unto the Temple, he was to go alo; and where we aw the greatet throng of people there we would be, to prevent upition. If I could let a little Book fall, in which I hould eem to be at devotion, and none ee, then I hould doe it: otherwie when I went away, I hould pretend that I had carelely left it behind me in the place where I kn • eled, or to let it fall ome way or other when he aw me; and he who had his eye till upon me and who at that time was to be as near me as he could, he hould preently reach it up: if none aw, then he was to look into it; but if any did perceive it, then he was to give me another which reembled mine, and which was made purpoely alike. Now in thee Books we writ our Letters, but with uch devices as were not eaily dicovered: my Mother and my Nure, have had thee Bookes in their hands everal times, but could not make any thing of them, becaue they undertood not the Charracters. Since this way was agreed upon, not a day paed, but we writ unto each other, which was no mall comfort unto us in the contraint wherein we lived. But Love was in this reemblant unto Fire, which the more you feed it, the more it augments; o did my favours unto Arimant, for they did o inflame his deires, as not contented with what I had done, he importun'd me by a thouand upplications, to admit him into my Chamber, unto which at lat I conented, o the meanes could be contrived, and o he would promie to require no more of me, then I was willing to permit. This permiion being given unto him, his wits were at work, how to facilitate all thee difficulties. The firt was, how to enter, but that was eaily contrived; for by a Ladder made of a Rope, which he would give unto Cla • ina, he might eaily get into the window of her Chamber when the caement was open. But my Nore whoe bed was cloe to mine, and who was not of our conpiracy, was a much greater difficulty unto us, and yet he found out a remedy for that. There was in Epocedes, a very famous Mountebanke, who had many mot excellent receipts. This man was o much obliged unto Arimant, that he was infinitely deirous to erve him. Love advieth this young man to make addrees unto him, and to ask him for a Receipt which would caue leep; he who made a particular profeion of uch ecrets, did give him an ointment, which being put under the Noe of the party that was faln aleep, would o tupifie the enes, as no noie whatoever would awake the party until it was taken away. Before Arimant would make ue of it upon this occaion, he tryed the operation of it upon one of his Dometiques, who lept o foundly, that no houting at his eare could awake him; but he removed him from place to place, and he never tirred, until taking away the Box, and throwing a little water in his face, and then he awaked.

All things being thus prepared, execution onely wanted. I mut confee, my heart began now to faile me; and when I conidered the danger into which I hould put my elfe, I wihed that a top might be in the proceedings: But Clarina who was more couragious then I, told me that I was gone too farr to retreat now; that had I put the Cavalier out of hope at the firt, he would not have been offended; but now as things tood, it was a manifet wrong unto him and knew how to argue the matter o well, and to hew the eainee of it, as at lat I reolved to goe through. Bed time being come, we all retired
and eemed to take our ret: and my good Nure who never dreamed of our buinee, by chance did fall aleep ooner then her cutome.

As oon as Clarina heard her nore, as he ued to doe when firt he lept, he laid the Box under her noe, and called upon her as if he was affrignted at her dream: but the good old woman was o fat, that if the houe had falne, he could not heare it. Clarina joyed at this good beginning, did rie from her leeping Mother, and helped me with my Night-dree, as he pleaed o to have it; For I protet Hylas, I was o farre beides my elfe, as I knew not what I did: The Candle ued alwayes to burn in our Chamber, and therefore C • a • ina brought me my Glae, and bad me trick up my elfe <> fine as I could, telling me that when Souldiers go to fight, they mut put on their Arms that they may get the victory.

p.U: aid unto her, you are a fool, for if the victory were not already gotten, we hould not now trouble our elves as we doe. But take heed aid he unto me, that the victory be not on both ides. I am more afraid, aid I, that the loe will be on both ides. Nay, nay, replyed he, never think o, heaven loves you better then to ue you o hardly: but pray tell me, ince the victory will fall on your ide, what Ranome mut the Conquered pay into you? His heart, aid I unto her. His heart? anwered he: but if he part with his heart, what hall he have for himelfe? and how can he afterwards love you? In lieu of that I take from him, aid I unto her I will give him mine. Yours? replyed he and miled? if he have your heart, he will be the veriet cowardly Cavalier that ever lived. Come come, aid I unto her, you are a cold, and tand and pend the time in tattling whilt he tayes. Upon this, we went to the window, and no ooner looked out, but I aw Arimant at a corner of a treet over againt us. He had his eye o continually up in the window, as it was impoible to look one and he not ee us; and therefore the Caement was no ooner open, but he was under the window, expecting when the Ladder would be thrown out. I began to tremble o, both for contentment and fear, as I was contrained to fit down upon my bed, leaving Clarina to all the paines, who with abundance of confidence, fatned the Cord, and threw out the Ladder, by which Arimant o uddenly mounted, that he was in my Chamber before I thought his foot upon the firt tep. As oon as he was entred, he fell down upon his knees before me, whom he found in uch a maze, as I could not o much as peak unto him. Clarina pulled in the Ladder, hut the window, and then came to ee what we did; but finding the Cavalier till upon his knees, and I peaking not a word to him, nor he to me; I to ee a man in my Chamber at uch an hour, and he with an extaie of contentment to have this aurance of my affection, he aid unto me; Methinks, Mitree (for o he called me) you are not very civil towards this Cavalier, in letting him be o long in this uneaie poture: for God ake, aid the Cavalier, let me alone where I am, for I am where I mot earn tly deire to be, and think my elfe beyond all expreions, happy in it. Then recollecting my elfe, I mut needs confee, aid I unto him, that Clarina is in the right, and if my atonihment doe not plead my excue, you may very well tax me with incivility, and indicretion. Upon this I tood up, and taking him by one arm, whilt Clarina took him by the other, we forced him to it in a Chaire which was by my beds ide. Then Clarina taking Arimant by the hand, Sweare Cavalier (aid he unto him) and promie me upon your honour, to oberve the conditions, upon which you were admitted into this place. Then Arimant tood up, and aid, I doe promie and weare, not onely to performe all I have aid, but alo not to faile in my very thoughts; I call God, Heavens, Earth, and all the world, to witnee my Oath, and pray them all to inflict their mot evere punihments upon all perjured Perons.

div.p: Thee Oathes and imprecations, Arimant, aid I unto him, are needlee, your owne word would have atisfied: As for my part, I have o great a confidence in you, as I daie trut my elfe with you as much as with my elfe. Then we both at down, and Clarina taying by her mother, let by any accident the Box hould tumble from her noe, Arimant aid thus unto me:

It is the quality of Gods and Goddees, fair Cry • ide, to conferre the greatet favours, to the end that their power and their goodnee may be een and acknowledged. So you, Madam, reembling them both in beauty and in virtue, you have done me a favour which does not onely infinitely trancend my merits, but alo all the hopes that ever I could imagine. Since it is o, and fince I mut needs acknowledge it o; what hould I
doe, not to acquit my elfe, for I cannot pretend unto it, knowing it to be impoible; but onely to avoid the brand of ingratitude? I mut confee, the more I think upon it, the more I am confounded and ahamed, that my fortune hould he to receive uch high benefits, and have o little undertanding as not to know, how I hould be thankful as I ought I have no other way to come out of this Labyrinth, but this only refuge, which is to referre my elfe wholly unto your will; that as at my requet you were pleaed to doe me this favours o that I may by your commandment do what I ought, to acknowledge it. After this expreion, he was ilent, in expectation of my anwer, which was this: Arimant, aid I unto him, that you hould acknowledge that what I have done for you, to be omething that is great and extraordinary, is as full atisfaction as I can deire; but I cannot endure you hould eteem your elfe at o low a value, as to thinke that you doe not deerve this favour; for in o doing, you doe not onely offend againt truth, but againt that judgement which I had of you, when I thought you worthy of my amity. Doe not thinke, Arimant, that I have done any thing at random, or without ound deliberation. When I firt gave entertainment to your good will, I mut confee it was without any deign, and onely becaue your addree did invite me to it: But when I betowed my good will upon you, doe not thinke unlee you have an ill opinion of me, that I did it without long and erious debate in my elfe: whether I ought to doe it or no, and whether I hould be blamed for uch a choice. I conidered your family, becaue I would not diparage my own Ancetors; and I found it o full of noblenee, as I could not chue but be contented with it, I looked upon the peron, and I could take no exception againt it, either in your body or mind: I have oberved your behaviour, and I could not find any thing which was not noble, and to be eteented, all your actions being full of honour and virtue. Briefly, I have cat my eyes upon your affection, and I find that you doe really love me. Now, Arimant, can you think that he who is owner of thee qualities, does not deerve any favour from the peron whom he loves? Madam, anwered he, and kied my hand, this favour which you are pleaed to doe me now, is greater (if it can be) then the firt; and I ee you will put me out of all hopes of ever being able to pay o great a debt. I received all thoe applaudes which you are pleaed to betow upon me, not than I am o vaine as to think them my due, but becaue I deire you hould think them o, that they may o much the more oblige you to continue unto me the honour of your favours Arimant, replyed I, you know very well, and I alo, that what I ay of you is true; and this may be a great tetimony of your merit, that Cryeide loves you; for you mut either think her without wit or knowledge, or ele think your elfe amiable becaue he loves you. But let us leave this dicoure, and tell me I entreat you, whether the report be true that you are to marry? and whether, as I am told, you intend it? At this quetion Arimant bluht, and though I poke it ignorantly, yet o it was, that his Father had made uch a motion to him not long before, and therefore he anwered me, 'Tis true indeed, Madam, uch a thing is talked of, but my Father hall ooner make me die, then ever conent unto it, for I am reolved never to marry any but the fair Cryeide, if he will blee me with o much happinee. I would not be any meanes, replyed I unto him, of your diobedience unto your Parents. Madam, aid he I am obliged to obey God before a Father, and it is he who hath commanded me to be none but y ••• s: but why hould we pend time, or conult upon a thing which is already done? Then kneeling down before me, I doe weare and protet before all the Gods, aid he, and call them all to witnee what I ay, That I will rather die then not be yours; and that I will never rie off my knees, untill you receive me for the husband of the faire Cryeide. Ar • mant, aid I unto him, I am obliged unto you for your good will unto me; and you may think I would never have permitted you entrance into this place,
<> I had not the ame •• tention. But being both of us at the dipoition of others, this is a promie which we neither can nor ought to make o rahly, but it deerves to be more eriouly, thought upon. Why, Madam replyed he preently, have you given me all there ignal favours and deny me this which I ask with o much reaon? but you mut reolve either to have me continually kneeling before you, or ele grant my upplication. I could not chue but mile when I heard his lat words, for he uttered them with uch an action, as hewed him to be in good earnet, Yet, I aid unto him, Perhaps, Arimant, you may quickly reperit, if I hould take you at your word. Oh God? Fair Cryeide, (aid he do not offend o extreamly againt my affection, and your own beauty. And to put you out
of all doubt, I call Hymen and Juno to witnee, that I will never be husband unto any but the fair Cryeide: and upon this word, I perceived that he would have put a Ring upon my finger, which caued me to draw away my hand, and rie up; but he held me by force, and aid unto me; Will you, Madam, make me perjur'd, and rie from hence, where I have vowed to tay eternally, unlee you accomplih my requet? Your requet, replyed I preently, is unjut, and your vow invalid ince your firt which you made at your entrance is contrary to it. Why aid he unto me? You promied, anwered I, and bound it with an Oath, that you would move me unto nothing but what I was willing unto; and ince I am not willing you hould make this requet, you are obliged to pres it no further, and what vowes oever you have made ince, which are contrary unto that firt, is of no force nor cannot bind. It is mot impoible, aid he, (and then roe up) to reit either your beauty, or your will: And I know, I hould receive but too great a load of happinee, if this were added to the number of the ret. Arimant, aid I then unto him, doe but till preerve your affection unto me, and I will freely promie, that if I can make thoe who have the dipoition of me conent unto it, I will marry you, and give my elf entirely unto you. It is impoible I hould expree how this young man was joyed when he heard this; and I was as glad as he, though he made greater hew by words, and all the thanks that could be invented. But yet, this was the caue of our ruine, for calling Clarina to witnee what I promied, and o he coming hatily towards us, did draw the Box from the noe of her Mother, and o unluckily, as it fell off the bed, was broke, and the liquid ointment ran about the floor.

It was a thing very trange, for almot as oon as ever the Box was from under the noe of my Nure, he awoke, but her head o dizzy with the mell, that he knew not what he did, and was like one that was drunk. As oon as Arimant heard the Box fall upon the floor, he doubted it, and aid unto me hatily, rie Madam, and tand before the old woman, whilt I get out at the window, for certainly he is awake. Upon this, I ran to the bed, • he to the window, and Clarina to the Ladder; and I coming to her, I laid me down upon her bed, began to embrace her, laid my hand upon her breat, and eeming as if I thought her to be very fick; I bad her take good heart, told her, he would be well againe preently; called for Clarina, and ent her for ome Vineger or water to throw in her face, and make her come to her elfe againe: I did o deceive her by my talke, and by rubbing one while her Pule, and another her Noe, as I gave Arimant time to be gone, and Clarina to hide the Ladder: Then eeming to be very buie about her, we threw water into her face, and did o dah her, as he had been oundly aleep, had he not awaked with it. Then in a great atonihment, auming her pirits: Oh my God, aid he, where have I been? how trangely have I been taken, what in the name of God is the caue of it? Oh my good Children, I thank God and you, for bringing me to my elf again, for but for you I had dyed. Oh Mother, aid Clarina, you have been in a woone above two hours, we have held you in our Arms, and done all we could to revive you, and I believe if you had not vomited, you had dyed. And good Children, aid the good old woman, what did you doe to waken me? Why, aid Clarina, as I was lying by you, I heard you keep a great tirring and a rattling in your throat as if you were choaked; upon which, I called upon you two or three times, and eeing you did not anwer, I leaped out of bed and waked Cry • ide; then taking the Candle, we came both to help you, and thanks be to God you came to your elfe againe. And did I vomit, aid the old woman? Vomit? aid Clarina, Yes certainly, and happy you did, for if you had not, I believe you had dyed, ince uch black and filthy tuffe did lie upon your tomack. Oh God, aid he, and held her Noe, doe you not well it? This he aid, becaue of the ointment which was pilt upon the floor, and melt very ill: Yes, yes, (aid my Nure) I doe mell it; Good Clarina, aid he, take the beome and make it cleane, let it hould doe you hurt, Clarina, who deired uch a command, did fetch ome water, and wahed the place as clean as poible, and afterwards threw it out of the window. But the accident of the next morning, may move one to laugh a little; for this ointment falling in the treet, and a Dogge paing by and melling at the oyle, he licked it, and there lay as if dead. Clarina, who aw this out of the window, and doubted the caue, he threw a little water upon him, then the Dog roe up, hook his eares, and went away. The evening after, Arimant, according to his cutome, came with Muick under the window, and after they had played a while, he ung ome Veres which intimated, that he would mot inviolably
keep his promie. And while we lived in this manner, both our affections encreaed to uch a height, as I cannot tell which was the more loved. But now fortune begins to mix many bitters amongt our weets, or rather to ravih from us all our weets, and leave us none but bitters. Alas, alas, well may I phrae them Bitters: for ince this time, I cannot ay I enjoyed any delight or contentment. Rithimer of whom I have already poke, a great Captain and a Favorite of the Emperour Majoranus had obtained, not onely to be a Citizen of Rome, but alo to be a Senator and Governour of Gaul Cialpine, and he attained unto uch high eteem, as he dipoed abolutely of all that was in Gaul. This large Authority did not proceed onely from good will and favour of the Emperours, but much from the great exploits which he had done againt the Vandals, for the preervation of Italy. This valiant Prince, married one that was of kin to my Mother; and deiring to ee me well matched, did cat his eye upon a young man, a little of kin unto Rithimer, very rich, but of a mot vicious pirit, and the mot ugly and deformed body that was in all Gaul Cialpine. My Mother who deired to be rid of me, becaue he thought me to be a rub in her way of marriage, he took occaion by the foretop, and reolved to carry me unto this Princes, hoping at the leat to leave me with her as he deired.

This being reolved upon, and unknown to me, it was almot as oon executed without my knowledge. For beginning to oberve how I did much favour the addree of Arimant, he thought to prevent me, which doubtlee he would not have done, had his etate been equall to his merit and noblenee. But ince it was not, he thought that ending me away, was the bet remedy he could ue againt it. Yet eeing her o bufie in etting her houe in order, and o carefull, that I hould dree my elfe in my finet trim, I did imagine that ome voyage was intended. And becaue I could not depart without advertiing Arimant, I commanded Clarina to let him know it, and give unto him the Book which was accutomed to pae betwixt us, and in it was this Letter.

div.head: Cryeide's Letter unto Arimant.
div.p: THey are hurrying me away from hence; I hould have aid from you, had you not been alwaies in my heart; and had not my affection been uch, as it is impoible I hould live and not be near you. However, change places we mut, though I know not into what part of the world: but let it be the bet in the world, it will be but a place of torment to me, if I doe not ee you in it. When I know where it is, I hall advertie you, to the end that if it be poible, you may be there in peron, where you hall be alwayes in my thoughts.

Arimant read this Letter with abundance of disatisfaction; my going away vexed him to the very oule, and much more, when he heard from one that was my mothers kinman, how I was to go unto the wife of Rithimer; becaue then he thought that his Father would not uffer him to go thither, by reaon of the enmity betwixt Rithimer and him. But he writ this Letter preently back, and gave the Book unto Clarina.

div.head: Arimants Letter unto Cryeide.
div.p: IF this be not the mot hard piece of fortune that ever could befall, I know not what can deerve the name. I undertand you are to go unto Rithimer, the only place in the world which is forbidden me. But however, ince it is your command, I will ere long be there, and make it appeare unto you, that my affection is greater then all impediment that can oppoe it.

I received this Letter, as we were taking Coach to begin our journey; o as I could not read it, becaue I had not time to look it out, it being mingled amongt many others in the Book, which was no mall dipleaure unto me. Arimant on the other ide, knowing I was to depart that day, met us upon the way, as if accidentally with two Cavaliers his friends, whom he had not acquainted with his affection unto me; and who yet were not altogether ignorant of it; and who upon this occaion, being very familiar with my
Mother; as oon as they met the Coach, they aluted us, and enquired of her voyage. She who now did not care who knew it, did freely tell them, and began to talk of Rithimers Grandure of the power her Couen had with him, and of the hopes he had of doing great matters for me. In the meane time, Arimant had got himelfe on my ide, but in uch a ad and afflicted poture, as he moved me to pitty him: and was o tranported out of himelfe, as he began to rove, and talke very idlely; and yet to augment our miery, for feare of making known the good correpondency betwixt us; he durt not addree his peech unto me, though his eyes were never off me; thoe who heard him, and did not know the caue which thus ditracted his mind, they began to laugh at his ridiculous language.

I who confidered that ometimes to be over ubtle poiles all, I thought it expedient to peake unto him as a peron indifferent; and therefore I asked him, from whence this great orrow proceeded, which caued every one to take notice of it? I doe aure you, aid he, and ighed, it proceeds from nothing but envy. I did not thinke, anwered I that a peron of your merit could envy any one; but of whom and why are you envious? I envy your Coach (aid he unto me) that is going towards the I • bices, and becaue I may not go with you, although it be my Country. Why, replyed I, are you uch a lover of your Country, as you hould envy things that are inenible? What hould I doe, aid he, ince uch inenibles are more happy than I am? Heaven, I hope, aid I, is better unto you than o. This is the conolation, anwered he, which is given unto thoe who are mierable, yet I aure you any better hall never be deired by me, but rather the contrary. Thoe who are icke, aid I, doe the like, they thinke all medicines bitter, and uch Phyicke is commonly given unto them, as is contrary to their deires, though conducing to their health. Great is the difference, aid he, betwixt the dieaes of the body, and dieaes of the mind: For thoe of the body are cured by contraries, but thoe of the mind, by the poeion of that thing which caues the dieae. If ambition wound us is there any better cure than to arrive at the thing apired unto? If beauty offend us, will any thing o quickly ture, as the injoyment of that beauty? And therefore they ay, that deires atisfied doe coole at the very firt, afterwards are quite glutted; o as to the maladies of the mind mut be applyed uch remedies as have the qualitie of the Scorpion, which can cure the wound it makes. It is long ince you were in your owne Country, aid Clarina; and what makes you thinke upon it o frehly now? Your journey, aid he, and ighed, brings it freh into my memory.

Thoe who heard our dicoure did not undertand it, though if my Mother had not been diverted by the quetions of thoe two Cavaliers, doubtlee he would have melt out omething, but he eeing us thus talking, he would not uffer them to goe any farther with us, although they told her their way did lye that way, but he was o urgent with them, that they were contrained to leave us. Now did I find, that to part from a peron loved might well be called a death, both by my owne reentments, and by Arimants, for he looked as pale as death it elfe, and was o out of himelfe, that he could not bid adieu unto me: or any in the company, which my Mother interpreted to be incivility, and perhaps on purpoe, though he beleeved the contrary; as for me, I knew the caue finding in my elfe the orrowes of this cruel eparation.

I cannot at this time tell you Hylas, how adly both Arimant and I reented it; onely this, that both fell icke, and Arimant much wore than I; for mine was only a certaine languihment, and drooping of pirits, which many feared would in a little time bring me into a Conumption: But his dieae was o violent as none looked for any life; every one came to ee him dye; he himelfe was of the ame beliefe: but having a deire to take his leave before he left his life, he forced himelfe to write thee lin • t unto me.

div.head: Arimants Letter unto Chryeide.
div.p: FOrtune eemes to be weary of tormenting, and will put an end unto my paines, out of which I beeech you, Madam, give me leave to go: I beg thus with that affection which brings me to my grave, and which hall never Ieen whatoever becomes of my ahes.

This Letter o hort, and o ill written, together with the common report of his icke etate, was a very death unto me: And when Clarina had enough to doe in giving me comfort, I gave her this anwer, that his death and mine hould be both together, and therefore I deired her to end this Letter unto him and to command the meenger to return with all hate poible, and bring me News how he was.

div.head: Cryeide's Letter unto Arimant.
div.p: IT was ever your promie to doe whatoever I appointed; and now I doe command you to live, that yon may the longer love me, I hall ee whether any thing have more power over Arimant than my elfe: live therefore and love me.

We undertood by the returne of the Meenger, that the ame day he came, Arimant was at the height of his dieae, and that the Phyitians had good hopes of his recovery; and alo that the next day he was out of all danger. For my part, I flattered my elfe o far as to beleeve, that the contentment which he found in my Letter was the caue of it; but whether that was true or no, I know not, but it is certaine, that he perfectly recovered, which was o great a joy unto me, that I alo began to mend of my malady, as if there was ome ympathy in our Dieaes, both falling icke, and both recovering at one time.

When I came to the houe of Rithimer, and his wife aw me o much out of temper, what through my long journey, and what through my orrows to be o far from him I loved, he thought it bet to recover me before I was expoed to the view, and not to peake of the marriage which he intended till then, thinking that it was beauty which would bring on Cloringus (for o he was called whom he aimed for my Husband). My mother cheered me up as much as he could, and told me that within few dayes I would recover, and to my miery it hapned o as he aid: For I was told that Arimant would come and ee me, either in diguie, or ome other way, in which he hould not be known. This hope gave me health, and my face became as it was wont to be, o as I began to hew my elfe; and indeed many began to cat amorous eyes upon me, epecially Rithimer, as ince I undertood, his wife at the ame time olicited the match, propounded unto Rithimer, and deired him, that in repect I was her Kinwoman he would be aitant He having a elfe deigne upon me, and knowing Clorangus to be a man of that deformity, he did approve of it, thinking that the lee I loved my husband, the more it would make for himelfe; o as faigning all that he did was at his wifes intance and deire, he ent for Clorangus, propounded it unto him, advied him to imbrace it, and at the ame time got his conent. I know not whether that which they call beauty in me, or my misfortune was the caue, but o it was, that the match was concluded upon, before a yllable was poke of it unto me. Oberve how Heaven does mocke at all humane intentions; when I fancied unto my elfe the fullet contentment, even then was I overwhelmed with the greatet misfortune that could befall me.

My mother came one night into my Chamber when I was undret and ready to goe into my bed; and after he repreented unto me the mieries of poverty, he extolled the happinee that would accrue unto me by matching into a very rich Family; he propo • nded Clorangus, and told me, that Rithimer and his wife had made up the match, that within two dayes the marriage was to be olemnized, and that he thought good to acquaint me with it, to the end that when Rithimer did me the honour to peake unto me of it, I hould be prepared to et a good face upon it, and to thanke him, as the paines he had taken in my behalfe deerved; that though Clorangus was a little defective in his body, yet he had many other qualities which upplyed thoe defects, and rendred him amiable and etimable; that he was in love with me, and o deeply, that if I would but flatter him a little, I might make him doe what I would.

To be hort, Hylas, he neglected no argument which might induce me to this marriage; and not taying for my anwer, he went preently to bed, thinking that I would not relih it at the firt, but hoping alo that my Pillow-cogitations would make me reolve according to her deires.

Oh Heavens, Hylas, in what a trange dumpe was I truck when I heard this, and yet
it was ome comfort that my Mother was gone, for I could cry with more liberty; I threw my elfe upon my bed, and leat my complaints hould be heard I topped my mouth with the heet, but all would not hinder Clarina from hearing me, who being advertied of it, came unto me, and would have given me ome good counell; but turning towards her, I aid; Away, away, Clarina, I am tormented enough without any addition from you; let me weepe away that little time I have to live, and lament that misfortune, which cannot be lamented enough; he who did mot tenderly love me, and knew well enough what it was I thus grieved at: I come not, aid he, with any intentions of comforting you, but onely to helpe you into bed to the end none may molet you. I had rather, replied I that you would helpe me to my grave: Upon that I uffered her to undree me, and lay as till as if I had been dead: For o deepe were my reentments that I could not cry; but when I was in bed, and the Light taken away, then teares began to flow in uch abundance downe my cheekes and bret, that my bed was all water: Sometimes my thoughts were all upon Arimant, his merits, and all thoe tetimonies of his affection to me; otherwhile I reflected upon Clorangus and his crabbed deformities, and finding uch a vat difference between them, I was in uch an extream Labyrinth of griefe, that truly the Gods were mercifull unto me, that I did not fall into a mot violent depaire; all Night long I did nothing but lament, and Day found me in bed without ever cloing an eye; and ee what a violent affection may ometimes doe. I was fully reolved to dye, knowing that my Mother would not be tirred at any prayers, o as till thinking upon Arimant, and his affection to me, I thought it better to dye once, than be dying every hour as long as I lived.

The next morning when I aw Clarina and mot of the houe were gone to the Temple according to cutome leaving none to looke unto me but a young Boy, who erved me, I deired him to goe preently and fetch a Chyrurgion, without telling any one. When he came, Sir, aid, I am much troubled with a paine in my head; and I deire you to let me blood in my left arme, for I have ued to doe o when the paine tooke me, finding alwayes preent eae by it. He eeing me looke red, and my eyes heavy, verily beleeved me, o as he bound my arme, opened my veine, and went away; he was no ooner out of the houe, but I called the little Officer, and deired him to fetch another, for this lat had done me no good; the Boy made hate, and brought another, I told him the ame tale I told before; I opened my other arme, keeping the other cloe, he did as I deired, and went away.

Thinking that this was enough to end my mierable dayes, I caued the Curtaines to to be drawne, and the windowes hut, as if the light offended me; then thinking how ad the Newes of my death would be unto Arimant, but withall thinking it would be a great comfort unto him to hear I dyed loving him, I tooke my Hankercher and preading it upon the bed, I dipt my finger in my blood, and writ in it thee words, Arimant I dye thine, which was all I was able to doe, for preently my eyes began to faile me, and my heart fainted, o as I lot my knowledge, yet I doe remember, that my lat thought being of Arimant, I aid aloud, Now Fortune the Victory is mine: After this, I remained as dead, and certainly had been o if Clarina had not come into the Chamber, who knowing that all my griefe proceeded from my loe of Arimant, he came to bring me a Letter from him, brought by him who ued to bring them before; but when he drew the Curtaines and found me wimming in blood: Oh God (cryed he out o loud as was heard into my Mothers Chamber) Oh God, he is dead, Chryeide is dead, and wringing her hands together, he ran out of the room all in tears, not knowing what he did. The windowes were immediately opened, and every one ran unto me; they aw I was all in blood, but not imagining it came from my arme, they were long in earching for the wound. Clarina in the mean time laying her hand upon my Hankercher, and opening it he aw what I had writ with my finger; and though it was o ill written as he could hardly read it, yet he put it in her pocket leat any ele hould ee it, and running out of the Chamber to my Mother told her of the accident: By fortune, as he went, he met him that brought the Letter from Arimant, who asked her for an anwer, becaue his Mater had commanded him to returne as oon as he could, to whom he anwered all in tears, it is a ad anwer which you mut carry to your Mater at this time, Chryeide is dead, becaue they would have forced her to marry Clorangus. Carry him this Hankercher, there will he find writ with the hand and blood of Chryeide the caue of her death:
Upon this, he went all teares to tell my Mother, who was then with the wife of Rithimer: when they heard this aid newes, they were extreamly atonihed. But the Prince, like one that was tranported, ran preently to the place where I was, and eeing me o in blood, by chance he took me by the arme to lift me up, and finding my leeve full of blood he has cut her veines (aid he); and then turning up the leeve of my mock, he found that the bloud did not run, becaue my leeve tuck to the wound (and I believe that aved my life) for as oon us it was pulled away, he aw it began to bleed afreh; he put his finger upon it, and bad Clarina doe the like to the other arm, for he oberved the other leeve bloody alo; then cauing ome cold water to be brought; for certaine (aid he) he is not yet dead, for I find he is hot: Then throwing ome of it into my face, and rubbing my Temples and pule with ome imperiall waters, and uch like, my Pule began to returne, and I began to breathe. Then ending in all pot hate for Phyitians, and they coming before it was • ight, I returned to my elfe againe, and recover'd my knowledge. Rithimer never tirring from me all the while, till he aw me out of all danger: Afterwards he told me, that he never aw me o faire as then; for the los of blood making me look pale and white, and that whitenes being as it were painted with blood, one eemed to adde beauty to the other. Moreover, his pitty of me did augment his love, and his love was covered under the vail of compaion.

But when I was a little better ettled, his wife and my Mother, asked me, what, and who it was that had brought me into that condition? but I knowing that they were the caues of all my miery, to avoid their importunity, eemed not to heare them, and would not peak. And one of the Phyitians told them, that it was better not to trouble me, for peaking might doe me harme; but it was requiite I hould take omething, and be left unto my ret, which accordingly they did; and in the meane time Rithimer enquired of the boy who waited upon me, whether he perceived what I did unto my elfe. The boy fearing a beating if he confeed, anwered; No, and that onely I commanded him to hut the windows, and draw the Curtaines. This caued Rithimer to call for Clarina: Doe not leave Cryedd, (aid he) for if you doe, he will make her elfe bleed againe and die, therefore be very carefull of her. Sir, aid he unto him, you may if you will ave her life, which certainly he will now, or ome other time loe, unlee you doe remedy it. I doe vow and weare (aid he) by the life of Anthemius, that I will do all I can to ave it: Clarina thinking he had found a fit opportunity. Sir, aid he, I beeech you in the firt place, not to dicover me; and next, be aured that Clorangus is the caue of her death, and he will rather chue a Grave then him. Thinke you o? aid Rithimer. More then think. Sir, aid he, for I am ure, and if you will know the truth, oberve what alteration will be in her face, when I tell her of it in her ear. Then both going to the bed and cauing all others to retire from us, he aid unto me in a low voice; Be of good courage Cryeide, Rithimer weares by the life of Anthemius, that you h • ll never marry Clorangus. I was o weake, as I could not move any thing except my eyes: but this newes was o welcome unto me, as lifting them up towards heaven, I eemed to give hearty thankes for o great a favour: Afterwards, turning towards Rithimer, I forced my elfe to peake. Sir, aid I unto him, is it true. Yes weet heart (aid he unto me) and I weare it, not onely by Anthemius, but alo by the head of my Father, and all that is holy. Then replyed I, I will live. Live then, anwered he, and be aured I will ooner conent unto my own death, than break my promie of it. Upon this I changed countenance, and mot miraculouly aumed vigour. Rithimer admired this reolution in me, and calling his Wife and my Mother: I tharge you, aid he unto them, that there be no more talk of marriage between Cryeide and Clorangus; for I vow and protet, I will ooner conent unto the loe of all my fortunes; then unto a match o unutable. They offered to reply, but he interrupted them by aying, I have worn it by the life of Athemius, by the head of my Father, and by all thats holy. Not a word more of it; and whooever hall doe otherwie, hall find my dipleaure. Upon this, both of them went away, and poke not a word, Rithimer highly eteeming my generous reolution, his good will unto me did o augment, as from thence forward it may well be aid, be was in love with me. He went away, and viited me a hundred times in a day, and mot commonly by himelfe. And becaue he durt not peak unto me, let it hould be prejudicial unto me, he talked with Clarina, would ometimes aske her how he came to know that the marriage with Clorangus made me take that reolution; other whiles he
would thanke her for acquainting him with it, and did o manifetly make the greatnee of his affection appear, as his wife perceived it, and Clarina alo. As for me, I took all his actions as proceeding from that compaion which uch an accident caued in his generous oul. Beides, the condition wherein I was, would not permit me any dicoure with him; for I was o weakned as I did nothing ele, but leep and ret my elfe.

I reted thus two or three dayes, and never remembred my Hankercher wherein I had written with my blood; but one morning when I found my elfe a little better, it came unto my mind; Clarina oberving that he never went from me, but he heard the • igh, he asked me whether I felt any new pain. My paine, anwered I faintly, is in my minde: But, good Clarina, were you the firt that found me in that condition, into which I had brought my elfe? Who doe you thinke, aid he, has the greatet care of you • I know very well, aid I, that it is Clarina; but if you were the firt, did you not ee a Hankercher which was potred with my blood? Yes, anwered he, I did ee it; and alas now you put me in mind, I have committed a great fault, which I mut preently remedy For Mitree, that unhappy morning, Arimant had written unto you, and I came with all joy to bring the Letter, when I found you in that ad condition, I ran through the houe like a fool, crying and tormenting my elfe; and being thus out of my elfe, I met the meenger which Arimant ent with the Letter, who not knowing of the accident which had hapned unto you, he was urgent with me for an anwer: I told him you were dead, and gave him the Hankercher whereof you peak, to carry unto his Mater in tetimony of your affection to him. How? aid I, Has Arimant the Hankercher? Doubtlee he has, anwered he, for it is three dayes ince I ent it to him. Oh God cryed I, I feare it will ruine him; what will become of him, Clarina, when he ees that aurance of my death? Upon this, he tood mute a while, and at lat anwered, 'Tis true, Mitres, aid he, that if the meenger did depart without any further enquiry of the particulars of your death, it might perplex Arimant. Of whom, replyed I, could he enquire but your elfe? Indeed Clarina, you were much to blame: and if when you aw me pat danger, you did not advertie him of it, your econd fault was wore then your firt. Mitree, aid he, I beeech you pardon me: my griefe was o great, as when I aw you dead, I was reolved to follow you; and I mut confee, that I ent the Hankercher unto Arimant, purpoely to invite him unto the ame. But ince that danger was over, I have been o buie about you, as I have hardly remembred to eate my meat. Go, aid I unto her, and write unto him preently from me; if I can, I will adde a word with my owne hand, Clarina upon this, hut the door left any hould urprie her, and taking Pen, Ink, and Paper, did write thee words.

div.head: Clarina's Letter unto Arimant.
div.p: I Do give my elfe the lie; for, Arimant, Cryeide lives till, and has commanded me to acquaint you with it; the truth is, he was dead when I ent you that meage, but the Gods have revived her for you. You are the mot happy Cavalier that lives, in the love of the fairet Lady in the Univere; and unhappy onely in this, that you cannot be a witnee of your owne happinee.

Then with much ado, I took the Pen, and potcribed thee words (Arimant, I doe live, and live onely for Arimant) Then ealing it up, he went with all hate unto him, whom he had formerly imployed upon uch occaions, commanding him to make all pot hate. Afterwards eeing none in the Chamber but our elves, we opened the Letter, which Arimant had formerly ent, and found in it thee words.

div.head: Arimant's Letter unto Cryeide.
div.p:
IN the day, I am nothing but a compoition of frights and panique feares; in the night, I doe nothing but dream that you are going to die, and I am going to follow you; this does o much trouble me, that I cannot call this a life, which I live o distane from you. I have ent this meenger to know how he who is my life does, I will follow him as
oon as I find by his returne, my way to be ready: and at this time the hatred which Rithimer beares unto me, mut yeeld unto the love which I bear unto you.

This Letter did infinitely comfort me, upon everall coniderations; the one, becaue I thought the neerer he was this place, the ooner he would hear the reports of my death to be fale; Another was, becaue I found that he did really love me; and latly, becaue I hoped ere long to ee him, and to communicate unto him a deigne which I had in hand. But in the mean time, his meenger made uch hate, that travelling both night and day, he found him in bed, intending to depart that day: And the meenger coming unto him: Sir, aid he, I have very great Newes to tell you, and therefore let all the men retire: Then commanding all to goe out, and to hut the doore, and eeing the Man tand and tare as if he were out of his wits, he upected to heare of ome great accident: Then riing up in his bed, and as it were divining it; What, aid he, is he dead or alive? Then the Meenger falling into tears, and preenting the Hankercher unto him: Alas, Sir, aid he, this will tell you that which my griefe will not uffer me to relate, and then he weeped and ighed as if he would have dyed. Arimant preading the Hankercher, and reading what I had written with my finger. Oh God, aid he, he is dead and then falling a croe the bed, there he lay as if he were dead: The Man taking notice that the Cavalier poke not, did run unto him, and finding him in a woone, he raied him up, called upon him, and pinched him to make him come to himelfe; but eeing all would not doe, and fearing he hould dye in his arms, he preently laid the Hankercher upon the bed teter, and ran to call for helpe: All the people in the houe ran to him, and brought uch remedies as at lat they recovered him; the firt word he poke was, Alas; but preently taking notice that the Chamber was full of people, he retrained both his ighes and his teares, leat he hould give knowledge unto any of the caue. And becaue his contraint did almot trouble him as much as his malady, he intreated the •• all to leave him unto his ret, telling them that he deired to have none with him but that young man. They who had not the leat upition of the caue, and thought it nothing ele, but ome faintnee caued by fating, they obeyed him. Then eeing the roome cleer; What is become, aid he, of the Hankercher? Sir, aid the young man; I am unwilling to let you ee it again, ince I know the ight will but greeve you the more. No, no, aid he, let me have it, for in lieu of augmenting my griefe, it will be a comfort unto me, eeing he had a memory of me unto the l • t minute of her life. Then giving it unto him; Oh mot deer Hankercher, aid he, the dire meenger of the greatet dyater that could befall me, what name hould I betow upon thee? Then being ilent, and fixing his eyes upon the blood: Well, aid he, he has hewed me the way, and I am ready to follow it; I grieve at nothing more than that I did not goe before, at leat keepe her company. Then turning himelfe towards the young man; but Friend (aid he unto him) you have not yet told me how this accident came to pae. Sir, aid he, if you will be pleaed to give me a little time, and promie me that it hall not afflict you more, I will tell you all I know: No, no, replied Arimant preently, nothing can either augment or leen my griefe, therefore tell me all. I hall then tell you Sir, aid the young man; That I came thither betimes in the morning, and according to your intructions, I watched when Clarina went to the Temple, where I found her and conveyed the Letter o cloely into her hand that none perceived me, and deiring her to dipatch me with an anwer as oone as he could, he told me, that tomorrow morning I hould have it. Preently after, I went into the houe of Rithimer where he lodged, and I was no ooner entred, but I heard a great biling on every ide, and Chryeide, Chryeide, continually named. I went up the tairs, and found Clarina all in tears and great diorder, who as oon as he aw me; It is but a ad anwer (aid he) that you mut carry your Mater at this time; alas Chryeide is dead, and onely becaue they would needs force her to marry Clorangus, carry him this Hankercher, wherein he will find written with the hand and blood of Chryeide, caue enough to love her memory. After this he cryed, and went into another Chamber. Oh Heavens! cryed out Arimant, can I live, and heare this? But go on, I intreat you. You may imagine Sir, aid the meenger, that this did much amaze me, and to know the more certainty of the matter, I tayed a little longer, and aw three or foure perons come out of Chryeides Chamber all in tears, holding up their hands, and aying, that truly he dyed very trangely. This inpired me with more curioity and boldnee to enter into the room, eeing all the houe
did the like. There, Sir, I aw her; Oh dimall ight! I aw her dead on her bed, and it o full of blood, that it ran downe upon the ground. At this time Rithimer and many women entred; and I heard Rithimer cry out and ay, he had cut her veines. I was then afraid leat any hould know me, and becaue you had exprely forbidden that, and thinking I could hear no more, I came preently out of the Towne, and made all hate that poibly I could, becaue you had o commanded, though with much orrow to be the meenger of uch ad Newes. Alas, alas, (cryed he) I ee it is but too true that Chryeide is dead, ince you have een her o with your owne eyes; could the Gods ever conent unto uch a cruelty, and can I heare this Newes and till live? He would have continued on, when his Father hearing of his being ill, and who loved him mot tenderly, being his onely Son, came and knocked at the Chamber door. The young man knowing his voice, he advertied Arimant, who etting as good a face upon it as he could, bad him open the door. The windows were yet hat, and the curtaines drawne, o as when his father came into the Chamber, he could not well ee the adnee in Arimants face; but coming to him, and taking his hand, he asked him how he did? Well Sir, anwered he, but only for a little faintnee which proceeds from repletion of humours, for want of exercie, but if you thinke it good, I deire to ride abroad and take ome journey, as well to diipate thoe humours, as for change of Aire. I like it very well, aid the Father; but whither would you goe? My greatet fancy, anwered Arimant, is to the Libicens, as well becaue it is the place of my birth, and naturall aire, as to ee my kindred and friends. I hould like it very well, aid the Father but that I feare the hatred of Rithimer. Sir, replied Arimant, never fear it; I mut confee, that for you to goe would be dangerous, but not for me, for there will not any advantage acrue unto Rithim • r by me, if I were dead; beides, being there amongt o many kindred and friends, he could not have any intention againt me, but it would be told me and eaily prevented. The Father beleeving what he aid, was eaily brought to his opinion, which was not a little happinee unto us all, epecially unto Arimant: For having before reolved to kill himelfe, he now deferred the execution of what he intended unto the end of this voyage. He accoutred himelfe therefore as well as he could, and the next morning et forward, taking none with him but this man, and another to walte upon him in his Chamber, telling his Father it was more afe to goe with a mall Traine, than if better attended, becaue lee notice would be taken of him. His deigne of going to the Libicens, was to meet with Clorangus, and when he had dipatched him, then to go unto the place where I was interred, there to acrifice himelfe unto my ahes. And truly it was happy that this revenge was thus intended, for it retarded his intention of killing himelfe, and the meenger whom I ent had more leaure to carry him our Letters.

The ame day he departed from his Father, halfe of it was gone before Arimant thought either upon eating or reting himelfe; and the meenger whom I ent met him at a paage over a River which is called Tein, and not knowing him, paed on, as well becaue he did not thinke of finding him in any place but Eporedes, as becaue his grief had much changed his face, and was but lenderly attended, o as he never o much as dreamed of Arimant. And Arimant he rid on o penive, and his eyes o fixed to the ground, as he did not o much as ee him when he paed by: But as good lucke was, the meenger who came unto me from him, was not heedlee, for he eeing the meenger who came from me, acquainted his Mater, telling him that if he would he might heare all the tory of Cryeide, for yonder was the man who once brought Letters from her. What can I hear, anwered Arimant, more than I have? Is it not too much that I have heard he is dead? o never o much as turning his eye towards him, he rid on; but the young man being deirous to know how I was interred, and all other paages, he went unto the meenger whom I had ent, and taking acquaintance, asked him of Clarina, and how he took the death of Cryeide? Cryeide, aid he, why, he is alive, and thanks be to God very well.
<> replied the other, Cryeide alive? Yes, yes, replied he, he is alive, and has ent
<> your Mater; then imbracing him; Oh mot welcome Newes (aid he) and
<…> thee for it: Come, come, follow me a little, and I will horten your voyage a great deal.

Upon this, the young man putting purs to his Hore, cryed out to his Mater, Stay, tay, Sir, tay, and I will tell you good newes: Arimant hearing his voyce, though not undertanding what he aid, and eeing him clap his hands as an action of joy, he was amazed
at it: and when he was come a little nearer, What is the matter, aid he; and what would you have with me? Sir, aid the young man, Good newes, Cryeide is not dead but alive, and has ent this Meenger to you. Cryeide alive? aid he and tranported, is it poible? Sir, aid the Meenger whom I ent, it is certaine, and I am a Meenger from her; upon this, Arimant lifted up his eyes and hands to heaven. Oh ye good Gods, continued he, be ye for ever bleed, for this favour you have done me. Sir aid my Meenger, Clarina commanded me to give you this Letter; Arimant was o much out of himelfe, as he took it with a trembling hand, and knew not what he did. But at lat, recollecting himelfe, he asked him how I did. Sir, aid he, he is very well, and in good health, Clarina commanded me to tell you as much. They told me, replyed Arimant, that Cryeide was dead: upon this, opening Clarina's Letter, though he would have diembled it, yet his countenance betrayed his joyes, epecially when he aw my Potcript, without which, he hould have thought that Clarina deluded him; but eeing my hand, and knowing it, he aured himelfe I was alive, although he imagined I was very weake. But tell me, my friend, aid he, Was it true that Cryeide was in uch a condition as I heard? Sir, anwered the Meenger, he could not be well wore reported then he was; for it night well be aid he was dead, and afterwards returned to life: Then he related unto him how I had been, how I was, and what they had done unto me. I mut confee, (aid Arimant then) that Cryeide trancends all Ladies in beauty, and all Cavaliers in grandure of courage: but fearing let he hould ay too much, he held his peace, and riding on repate I himelfe at the next Town, where he did nothing but repeat unto himelfe all that had paed.

New Accidents cauing new Counells Arimant taying in this place all the ret of the day; all the night took up his thoughts in contriving meanes how to ee me. And not being able to reolve upon it alone, he called for the young man whom he was wont to end unto me, and who beides his love to his Mater, wanted neither wit nor judgement. Unto him he did communicate his deire of eeing me, and that he hould never enjoy himelfe till then: And yet he told him, that Rithimer did o extreamly hare his Father, as he could not with any afety come where I was, much lee into my Chamber. The young man after he had a little conidered upon it: Sir, aid he, you mut make a Virtue of Neceity: firt end away this Meenger, that he may not dicover your deignes: Next, diguie your elfe in the habite of a Merchant; o may you afely enter the Towne, and remaine there a while unknown; and being there uch opportunities may happily preent themelves, as you cannot here imagine.

Arimant liking the opinion of the man, as oon as it was day, he dipatched my Meenger away, who the next day brought me Letters from him, told us where he met him, and by what chance he knew him; I will not now, Hylas, tell you what his anwer was, but you may imagine it full of thankes and extream contenment; and in the concluion of it, aured me, that he would ee me ere long what fortune oever he ran; in the interim, he lot no time. For thinking it no dicretion to come into the place where I was without a diguie, he caued there uits to be made in the mode of Merchants, with all poible hate; and going into a wood, they hifted themelves, and put their owne clothes in a Portmantle. Thus clad, and diguied as well as they could, they came into the Towne where I was, and lodged in an Inne near the Gate. As for Arimant, he kept his Chamber all the ret of the day, but he ent his Valets abroad to heare newes: he commanded him whom he was wont to end unto me, to enquire how I did, and to ee Clarina if it were poible. At night both of them returned to him, and told him what they heard; and he whom he imployed unto my lodging, told him that he had een Clarina, and poke with her, none perceiving him; that he carried him to her Mitree, who was o weake through loe of blood, as he till kept her bed, and wore unto him, he never aw her o faire in all his life: That by fortune none being in the room, he talked to me along while, and to tell me how he was diguied for feare of Rithimer, or ome of his <> , conidering the old enmity he had to his Father; that Clarina and I laughed he <…>
heare he was in that habite: And that I told him; ince he was o diguied, he <…>
ome good Laces, and extraordinary Ribands, and uch knacks, and pretend that he would ell them; that if he found any in my Chamber, to excue it, and ay he would come againe when I was more at leiure; but if I was alone with Clarina, at it hapned very often, he might enter, and peak to me with all freedome and confidence Arimant
hearing this direction, did finde it very good, and in order to the execution of ie. he <>
into quet of uch Merchandize as was requiite for him As for his man, the newes he brought, was the feares of the Townmen, of a certaine trange King, who they aid, came into Gaul to plunder the Country as he had done divers times heretofore; then falling into particulars, he aid, the Townmen murmured, becaue whilt this King was Pillaging and Ravaging all the Country, and carrying away both men women and children Prioners. Rithimer was making love to a young Lady called Cryeide, and did not only neglect the people over whom he governed, but lot that reputation which formerly he had gotten by o many martial exploits.

This lat part touched Arimant to the quick, yet being o near me and hoping ere long to ee me, he waved the thoughts of it; but giving his mind wholly to provide uch Merchandize as would admit him to my Chamber, he loaded both himelfe and his man with the finet Laces and Ribands he could poibly procure, and pretended to come from Gaul, from whence uch things commonly come: beides, having that language, he might the better be taken for a Merchant of Gaule. He pent all the next day in triming up his equipage of Merchandize; and having very well furnihed his Packes, he came to the houe of Rithimer, and paed for a Pedler. The young man who had been already there, conducted him to my lodging: Thoe who aw him go up with his Packs, never quetioned whither he went; for taking them for Pedlers, and many uing to come thither, they thought it not trange to ee them there. They tayed with their Packs in the Anti-chamber, where the little boy which waited on me, paing by chance, did ee them; and coming into my Chamber, told Clarina, that there was Pedlers in the Anti-chamber, who asked if any would buy any Laces or Ribands. Clarina did preently apprehend it to be Arimant, and coming unto me: We will ee, Madam, aid he, whether or no they be our Merchants; Go and ee, aid I unto her, and if it be they let them enter, for we are at leiure to ee what Wares they have, ince none is in the Chamber. Clarina went preently; and becaue the little boy followed her, he eemed as if he knew him not, but asked what Wares they had? very fine Laces, Madam, anwered Arimant, in the language of Gaule, and very cheap. You come in very good time, aid he, for my Lady is alone, and will be glad to ee what Laces you have; and upon this he conducted them to me.

I mut confee, Hylas, that I was trangely tranported, and he alo when I aw him come into my Chamber, and none but we three in it: For Clarina had ent the little officer into the Town of an errant. At the firt when he entred, I held out my armes, and he kneeling down by my beds ide, I held him a long time cloe to my bret, o urpried with joy, that I could not unlooe my armes. My dearet friend, aid I unto him, here is thy Cryeide, whom the Gods have retued, becaue they would not be o unjut as to rob thee of her. I doe acknowledge, Madam, aid he, that they are Gods, ince they are jut But, Madam, aid he, what doe you meane, when you ay my Cryeide? Arimant, replyed I, be aured, that if Cryeide be not yours, he is no bodies. I writ it in my blood, and if you would have a greater Tetimony, you hall have all I can give, and that honour will permit me: For I thinke it reaonable that ince I expoed my life to preerve my elfe yours, I hould reerve nothing but render my elfe wholly unto your dicretion.

He would have anwered, when Clarina took him off, becaue he heard ome walking in the Anti-chamber. Retiring therefore with all hate, he went to his Companion, who was begun already to lay open his Merchandize, and to hew them unto Clarina, who eemed to be very buie in looking upon everall Laces, when Rithimer came into the Chamber. He ued to come unto me very often; as if the report which went about the Town, of his love to me, were not fale: oever ince the accident which hapned unto me, his affection to me was increaed to uch a flame, as his Wife perceived it; he being naturally jealous; and unwilling any hould hare with her in that which he hould enjoy alone he began to hate me extreamly, and was reolved to remove me from Rithimer, as oon as I was able to go abroad: And eeing my Mother extreamly angry with me for refuing Clorangus, he told her of it. As for the was, Clarina heard their dicoure unknown to them, and told it unto me.

This remove which was intended did not trouble me at all; but on the contrary I was rather glad of it, hoping it would be a meanes of my returne unto Eporedes, but I was
much perplexed at the cruelty of my Mother, who wore and vowed that as oon as I was out of Rithimers reach, he would, whether I would or no, make me marry Clorangus.
This reolution of my Mother moved me unto another, which otherwie perhaps I hould not; it was to give my elfe wholly unto Arimant, and avoid that tyranny which he threatned againt me.

But to returne unto Rithimer; eeing him enter into my Chamber, I deired Clarina to tell the Pedlers that they hould go away now, and come againe in the morning, and that then I would buy their Laces. This I did purpoely, becaue if Rithimer aw him againe, he hould not think it trange. Arimant knowing how reports went, concerning this Princes love unto me, eeing him very amiable, and conidering what favour his Quality might procure him, he looked upon him with an eye not like a Pedlers, and vexed he was to quit his place unto him; yet eeing there was no remedy, he put up his ware, made a low leg, and went away; and I eeing him going, aid unto him; Farewell good Friend, be ure you come again to morrow.

This was the firt interview, but to horten my dicoure; Know, Hylas, that the next day he came againe, when all was gone to the Temple, and when none was in the room but Clarina and my elfe. But to loe no time, eeing my Mother was reolved as oon as I was well, to marry me by force unto Clorangus, we thought it expedient to be beforehand, and that in the habit of a man Arimant hould teale me away, and carry me where he thought fit, upon a promie to marry me at the firt place where it could conveniently be done, and that in the mean time we hould live as Brother and Siter. This being the reolution, Arimant provided clothes, as well for Clarina, as for me; he brought them unto us, and promied without faile to be in the houe where he lodged, the fifth day after, which he hewed unto Clarina, that he might conduct me thither. See Hylas, unto what the everity of Parents may drive their Children, and ee what came on't: The five dayes being expired, and making no quetion but Arimant was at his lodging according to appointment; I trimmed my elfe up like a man, and Clarina alo, and diguied our elves o well, as meeting my mother when he came from the Temple, he knew us not; but I was much amazed when I came to Arimants lodging, and found no Arimant there, and much more when night came upon us, and could heare no newes of him: Then did I begin to repent of my rah act, and being o haty as to tirre out of the houe till firt I knew he was in his lodging: But the greatet trouble was the report pred abroad all over the Towne that I was lot, and could not any where be heard of; that I was earched for all over; This made me tell Clarina, that come what fortune would, we mut ome way or other get out of the Town, and that ince Arimant was not there, certainly ome great michance had hapned unto him: When we were thus conulting, extreamly perplexed and knew not which way to turne our elves, I aw the young man who waited upon Arimant enter into the Chamber; imagine Hylas, how great our contentment was when we aw him: Oh my good friend, aid I unto him, where is thy Mater? He is in his owne houe, aid he unto me, but o wounded as he cannot come unto you. Who wounded him? (replied I, and trembled every joynt): One, anwered he, whom he has kild, and to be hort, you mut know that my Mater not being ignorant of the deigne which Clorangus had upon you, he challenged him, they fought, and he killed him; but yet he came not off without two great wounds, which though not dangerous, yet are o troubleome that he can neither ride nor go, the one is in his thigh, and the other in his leg. Now eeing he could not come hither as he promied, he ent me to wait upon you, and conduct you where he is, having furnihed me with hores and all things neceary.
