Friend, aid I unto him, I knew ome great occaion hindred thy Mater from being here, I am glad both he and I are rid of the trouble of Clorangus, but I wih it had not cot him o deare; when thou wilt, we will be going that we may the ooner be with thy Mater, and ee his wounds dreed: Truly, aid he, I thinke there is no better alve than your elfe; then calling Clarina we conulted what we hould doe to ecape, it being probable, trict guards would be at the Gates: and after a long debate we concluded that the young man hould goe unto the Pallace of Rithimer to heare what people aid, and to learne if it was poible, in what manner they earched for me, and that in the mean time we hould cut our haire, to the end that if they did earch for us, they might not o oon know us.

This being reolved upon, the young man went accordingly, and was o nimble and ubtle, as he mingled himelfe amongt the Dometiques of Rithimer, where he heard all their dicoure to be of nothing but upon me; ome aid I was fled, and had good reaon for it, becaue they would needs force me to marry Clorangus, the ugliet fellow amongt all the Cialpine Gaules; others who thought themelves more wie, murmured againt the wife of Rithimer, aying he had packt me away, being jealous of her husband and me, and this opinion went o far that Rithimer beleeved it, remembring he had erved him uch a tricke before, and this was the reaon that when my Mother fell downe upon her knees and beeeched him that a trict earch might be made for me, he anwered her with an angry mile: Go, go, Madam, if you doe not know where you daughter is, aske your Cozen, and without further anwer turned away from her. This was the reaon, that my mother telling this unto his wife, and how Rithimer lighted the earch for me, he beleeved that Rithimer had ent me away, and hid me in ome place for his pleaure.

As for my Mother, he knew not whom or what to upect; one while he thought Rithimer had ravihed me away; another while, that it was his wife, who out of jealouie had done it; and to thinke of Clorangus, he could not imagine he hould be any intrument in it. And o not knowing which to be the caue, he upected both Rithimer and his wife. Hence it was that all three being jealous of each other, they were not very hot in earching for me, but rather laughed at one another when uch a thing was propounded.

This gave we the opportunity of getting out of the Towne by noone, for it being the market day, we eaily paed amongt the crowd, none being at the Gates who had any charge to looke or take any notice of us. So when we were out of the Suburbs of the Towne, we tooke Hore, and when we came to a Wood we fell to eat uch Victuals as the young man had provided for us: Then etting forward, we travelled all the night, and the next day till noone; then the young man brought us into a Houe, the Owner whereof was a friend unto Arimant, and unto whom the young man delivered a Letter from him, for whoe ake we were entertained with all poible welcome; but I was o weary with my travell, as I fell aleep almot with the meat in my mouth, o as we went all to bed, and reted our elves here all that day and the night following; For my part I doe not thinke I ever wakened all the time, at leat I am ure the Sun was up before I opened my eyes, and before I got out of my bed; then the young man called me, and methought the night had been horter than uuall: As oon as we were all ready, we et forward againe and travelled untill night, when we came to the Towne of the Libicians with all contentment. But I cannot expree the joyes of Arimant, when I came unto his bedide; it was uch, as his wounds did open again, and began to bleed afreh as he was forced to keep his bed till; his joyes were o great to ee me in the houe, as I beleeve, if I had not taken notice of it, he had aid nothing for fear of affrighting me; but eeing his colour to change, I asked him whether he did not find himelfe ill: It is nothing, Brother aid he (for o it was agreed we hould call each other) onely I beeech you let a Chirurgion come to me whilt you pull off your boots, for though I be in bed, yet I will up with you. Then after I had imbraced him, I called for the Chirurgion, and retired my elfe a little to my Chamber: But oh how jocund were Clarina and I when we were together: for, having paed over o many frights, we now thought our elves returned even from death to life. Whilt we were thus rejoycing together, one came to advertie us that Arimant had lot o much blood, that his wounds were much wore than they were before, and he in great danger. I ran in a fright unto him, and found that the blood was topped, but the Chirurgion deired me to let him ret all that night, and told me that there was no great danger yet, but that there might be, if good heed was not taken. Then was I forced to retire my elfe without eeing him: And ee, Hylas, what love can doe; the day before I was o weary with travelling, as I was not able to keep my eyes open, but now after as much more pains taken, I could not cloe an eye all the night long, but was till ending to know how Arimant did, and could not ret till the next morning it was permitted me to ee him. Brother, aid I unto him, were you o ill and would not tell me? I mut confee indeed, aid he, that I did perceive my wounds to bleed, but I mut confee withall, that I was deirous to loe a little blood for you, as in payment of the abundance which you lot for me. Oh Brother, aid I unto him, our deignes in that were much different:
for in loing mine, the intent was to preerve my elf for you, but you by this would take your elfe from me.

But, Hylas, why hould I tand relating all thee paages, ince this time, which I mut accompt the happiet of all my life, is thus changed, and nothing remaines of it, but o much memory as to lament the loe of it? But however, let me tell you, that after we had tayed ix weeks in this place, for the recovery of Arimant, his Father ent for him; for he hearing of the Duell with Clorangus, he was in continuall feare of him, not onely in repect of the wounds he had received, but alo of Rithimers hatred. His being thus ill of his wounds, was the caue why he deferred all his deigns that he had upon me, until he was better recovered, and quitted his bed. And now when he was recovered and well, he began to urge me further then I would permit him: I told him, that he might conider, I was his, and that thoe Tetimonies which I had given, might well put him out of all doubt of it: That what he deired was not reaonable, unlee upon uch conditions as might be free form all manner of blame: That he might well thinke, that when I put my elfe into his hands, it was with a deigne of giving up my elf entirely unto him, as I had done, and yet would doe; but yet I beeeched him to have regard unto what both of us ought to doe; for as I owed unto him all manner of contentment and atisfaction, o he owed unto me the preervation of that thing, which onely could make me worthy of him, which was my chatity. And when he anwered, that he never had any other deigne; and that he had rather die then move any thing unto me, but upon conditions of marriage, I told him, that it was impoible the marriage could be in that place, but Rithimer would know it, and purue his revenge, and therefore it was requiite to deferre unto ome other time and place which was out of danger. Beides this conideration, it were good that his Father were acquainted with it And though we were both reolved to go through with our deigne, yet it was but fit and reaonable to render him that duty. I put him in minde that the Gods were well pleaed with the reverence and obedience of Children to their Parents; and that if we did o, they would blee our intentions and actions the better.

To be briefe, Hylas, I ued o many arguments and reaons to him, as he taking me in his armes, and kiing me; It is impoible (aid he) to reit againt any thing you pleae; and therefore order and dipoe of my life and contentment, as you hall think good. And when he received his Fathers command to go unto him; doe you not ee, aid I unto him, how God begins to proper our deigne, ince we are going unto that place where we may more eaily accomplih it?

He therefore went unto him, and carried me alo; but being unwilling his Father hould know me, before he had conented unto his marriage, he changed my name, and called me Cleomires, aying I was a Tranalpine Gaul, and that I having that language, I hould the better pae o. Then for a better colour of keeping me with him, he aid I had aved his life in his Combate with Clorangus, having hindred two of his men in ambuh from falling upon him, and forced them to fly; o as this generous act forced him never to part from me.

Thus we et forward in our journey, and arrived at Eporedes, where Arimants Father received us with uch welcome, as did manifet the affection which he bore unto his Son: And when he undertood me to be Cleomires, of whoe valour and aitance his Son had informed him, I cannot expree thoe thankes and offers which he made unto me: for truly he was a very noble minded Cavalier, full of virtue, and worthy of the Title which he had.

Both Arimant and I were very glad of o good a beginning, hoping that ere long this good entertainment would bring us to a happy concluion of our deires. Some dayes being pat, and Arimant not able to ret until our marriage was concluded, we conulted together how to bring it about; In concluion, we did all foure concur in opinion, (for Clarina and the young man, were alwaies admitted to our Counells) that the bet way was, for me to make the over • ture unto the Father; becaue ince I came, I had ininuated my elfe o farre into his good opinion, us he believed whatoever I aid, and would be counelled and advied unto any thing I would. I took this charge upon me much againt my heart, thinking it to be againt cutome for me to be the wooer, it being ordinarily the mans part: Yet having already broken the cutomes of other women, and aumed the habit of man, I thought my affection at this time, might well make me undertake
it; and eeing it was Arimants mind, I thought it a crime to contradict it.

I went therefore unto the Father, who was walking by himelf in the Garden; and after a alute, and ome dicoure of the fine cituation of the place, I fell at length to talk upon the contentment which every one had in eeing themelves perpetuated in their Children: And afterwards hinting unto him that it hould be his alo, when • e conidered Arimant as the mot nobly accomplihed Cavalier, not onely of all the Salaes and b ••
bicians, but alo of all Aemilia; he anwered me, that my affection to him, made me blind, and moved me to think him o. I mut needs confee, Sir, aid I unto him, that I doe love him above any Cavalier I ever knew: but I doe aure you, Sir, before I did love him in that high degree, I did eteem and thinke him o, and all thoe that ever aw him are of the ame judgement. But Sir, ince I am gone o farre, give me leave to tell you, I cannot chue but wonder, that it hould be o long before you marry him; It is full time, his age requires it; and I believe it would be a great addition of contentment unto you, to ee your elfe a Grandfather of many weet Children it is very true, anwered he, and I deire nothing more; but good wives are o very rare, and I ee o few of them, <>
we mut of neceity tarry till heaven find uch a one out for him. Perhaps Sir, aid I, you are too curious in your choice. I beeech you pardon me, aid he, for truly I am not; provided I could find out a noble and a vertuous woman, in whoe family there is no blemih, I hould not init mut upon Riches. Methinkes, Sir, aid I unto him, that you omit one principall quality: What is that, aid he, it is, Sir, aid I, that they doe love each other very well. Mot true, replyed he preently; but I did not inert that quality, becaue it is to be firt preuppoed; proteting unto Cleomires, I had rather die, th • n to ee my elfe driven to uch a neceity, as to force Ariman •
to marry a woman unworthy of himelfe, or one he could not love: having already broke off one marriage, becaue it was not according to his fancy. In this aid I, you are a good Father: But, Sir, what will you ay, if I that am a tranger, hould propoe one in this Country, who has all the qualifications and conditions which you mention? and • one with whom it hall be long of your elfe, if it be not a match. I will then ay, replyed he, that you do know more then we doe. No, Sir, aid I, not that I know more; but becaue perhaps I have had more opportunity of knowing her better then others: and if you pleae I will propoe her unto you, but it hall be upon condition, that you honour me o farre, as to take all I ay, to proceed from one who infinitely honours you, and loves Arimans above all the world. You have already given, my Son, good tetimony of what you ay, anwered he, and I have uch a beliefe of your affection unto me, as you need not quetion but I hall take whatoever you propound; as coming from one whom I ought to love, honour, and belive, before any that I know.

In this aurance Sir, replyed I, I hall tell you, that there is one in this very Towne, whoe noblenee of Family, virtue, and uch love as ought to be betwixt Husband and Wife, may be found in her; and as for her Portion, it is utable to uch as are of her quality Thee things altogether, are not inconiderable. Good Cleomires, aid he, name her quickly. It is, Sir, replyed I and bluhed, Cryeide. Truly, aid he then, as for her Family and Portion I mut needs confee it; but as for the ret, I know not what to ay: and I mut tell you, the time was when I thought to motion it unto her mother, and had done it, but that he was o neare of kin unto the wife of Rithimer, who is my mortall enemy. Sir, aid I unto him, will you be pleaed to let me peak in her behalfe, without offence unto your judgement? unto which he anwering, yes, I went on thus:

Cryeide has done two things, which may well make you change your judgement of her: The firt is, The cutting her veines and chuing rather to die, then marry Clorangus: And the other is, Her flight out of the hands of her Mother. But to cleare thee two things unto you, Sir, I mut dicover a thing unto you, which I believe you did not know, and which I beeech you not to take ill, ince all due repect was ever preerved unto you. Be pleaed therefore to know Sir, that Arimant having een her of whom we peak, and conidering her beauty, he fell in love with her, and ued all wayes to make himelfe loved: She being enible of the honour which you Son did her; after long Courthip, and uch addrees as are uuall amongt perons that love, he aked him what his intention in it was, Arimant, in this, as well as in all other his actions, hewed himelf a noble Cavalier, and one that did not degenerate from the vertue of his illutrious Predeceors, but anwered her, that his pretenions were to obtaine her favour in way of marriage:

And when he et before him the hatred which Rithimer bore unto you, and the neer relation betwixt his wife and her mother; Arimant anwered, that the Gods who would not have this emnity perpetuall, perhaps intended to reconcile the two Houes by this alliance; and aured himelfe, that when you Sir were acquainted with it (for he would do nothing without your permiion) you would like of it, and commend his jut deign. After this, Love did every day o increae on both ides as they promied each other to marry, provided your approbation could be procured, and in the mean time both of them to ue their utmot endeavours to obtain the conent of their Parents.

When things was brought to this pae, Chryeide was carried away unto Rithimers houe, where they would needs force her to marry Clorangus; you know Sir what kind of man he was, the mot deformed and vitiouly minded of all men living, but though he had been the mot compleat and pleaing, yet Cryeide could not marry him, having already given her elfe unto your Son: Yet in this, you may ee her vertue, becaue he had promied nothing but upon condition of their conent upon whom he depended, and finding their minds o far from her deires, he reolved to dye; this was an act of vertue beyond Lucretia's; for Cryeide would prevent the crime before hand and dye; but the other dyed not till after the crime committed. If this be not a great demontration of her love to Arimant, and whether he was not reolved to preerve her affection intirely for him, I refer it Sir, unto your judgement. But o it was, that he being miraculouly recued from the grave, and began to recover the great loe of her blood, he was advertied by one of her Mothers maids, that her Mother and Rithimers wife would packe her out of the preence of that Prince to make her marry Clorangus whether he would or no. Now he thought it high time to have recoure unto the lat remedy, and doubtlee had if Arimant had not come unto her, and with tears in his eyes diverted her from that mortall reolution, and told her that mot certainly if he did dye he would follow her, and therefore it was better to retire her elfe from this cruell tyranny of her Mother; that if he would trut him, he would vow by all acred and inviolable oathes, he would carry her amongt the Vetals, where he might tay untill he could obtain your approbation of their marriage.
Now Sir, I beeech you judge whether thee two actions can be diliked, or whether there wanted any either generoity or love in this woman, or any other quality or condition which you can deire?

And thus I ended, extreamly atonihing the father, who walked two or three turnes without peaking one word • whilt I was in expectation of the entence either of life or death: At lat lifting up his head which he had all the while hung downe, he anwered thus.

I mut confee Cleomire you have told me mot trange things, which may well plead my excue for being a little penive. But conidering that there is nothing in this world which comes by chance, but by the wie providence of the Gods, I will beleeve that all thee things which you have told me, have happened by their wils, & ince it is o, I hould be very harh if I offer to croe them. My Son, you ay, loves Cryeide, and I do beleeve it, for I have heard that his voyage to the Libicians, was only to make addrees unto her, and fight with Clorangus who pretended unto her. Cryeide hath alo given very great tetimonies of her love to him. I doe conclude from hence, that the Gods do never make uch contraries to meet, and ympathetically agree, but they are contented with the good will which is betwixt them. Friend, I do commend my Sons choice, for Cryeide doth highly deerve to be loved, and now I know her reaons which induced her unto what he did, my eteem of her is double unto what it was. Tell therefore my Son as much, for I ee that it was he who imployed you to peak unto me? Tell him, that ince according to his duty he has repected me o much as not to contract with Cryeide without my conent, I doe take it o kindly, as I both approve and commend his choice, and pray unto the Gods that I may oon ee them both together: And though I doe foreee that Richimer will rage more hatred againt me, and colour it with my Sons offence in ravihing his wifes Cozen out of his houe, yet that hall not make me alter my opinion being reolved to countenance and maintain them in pite of all danger that can come unto me.

I beleeve Hylas, you thinke that this anwer did give me as much contentment as I could deire, and well you might; for after I kneeled downe and thanked him in behalf
of his Son and Cryeide (not daring to declare my elfe without the advice of my dear Arimant) I thought he would never have atisfied himelfe with thanking me, hugging and kiing me. Then I parted from him, and went to acquaint Arimant with my happy uccee which ravihed him beyond all expreion: At lat it was reolved amongt us, that ince I had told his Father I was amongt the Vetals, I hould not yet declare my elfe, let I hould be taken in a lie; For all lies have this quality, that when they are known, they make truth it elfe upected. And to avoid the rage of Rithimer and my mother we thought it bet to conceale our marriage for a while, whilt in the mean time endeavours were ued to pacific them: Arimants Father approved of this, and from thence forward referred the whole matter unto the will of his Son.

Now Hylas ee, how men purpoe, and God dipoeth, who would have thought but that their buinee was brought to as good a pae as we could wih or expect? And yet all our croes hitherto were but playes in comparion of what enued; For Arimant and I deiring to conummate our deign, pretended to go unto Cryeide, and after we had provided womens cloths, and all that was neceary for our marriage, and were come into a Towne of the Caturges, we intended to tay there o long as to make the father beleeve we were gone unto her whom we had with us. But as ill luck was, Gundehunt King of the Burgundians having paed over the Alps with a puiant Army, did fall into the Territories of the Taurinois and Caturges o unexpectedly as he found them without any defence, or thoughts of any Enemy: And by fortune, the very next day we came into this Towne, he fell upon it, where all they could do was to hut the Gates againt the urprie of the firt Comers; but when the maine body of the army came up, all the inhabitants could then do was to render their Town upon uch pittifull condition as little mended the matter, unlee that the women were not ravihed nor their Temples pillaged as they were in other places, and all the ret left to the dicretion of the ravenous Souldier. • Oh heavens! Hylas what a lamentable ight was it to ee women carried away Captives out of the arms of their husbands: No intreaties, no tears, nor no offers could redeeme them: So adly did I reent this miery, as I can peake it experimentally: as fortune was, I was that day in woman • habit, and as I thought not ill dreed, though my haire was o hort that I could not trim my elfe o well as I deired; and poor Arimant did carae me, as if he did foreee it hould be the lat time: The Towne was preently ditributed into quarters; and every place aigned unto ome troope, who by degrees turned the Owners out of doors, both men, moveables and hores Arimant hearing of this bae capitulation, went crying through the Towne, that it was better to dye than ubmit unto uch unworthy termes, telling the people that their wals were yet up, that the Enemies had no wings to fly over them, that their arrowes were not all pent, nor their bowes broken: he promied them that he would defend their Towne till Rithimer came to relieve them, who was already upon his march, and that they hould never be branded with o much ignominy. But eeing there was no remedy, and that none tirred upon his words, he drew his Sword, and cryed in the open treets that the principals of the Towne had betrayed and old the people; that for their parts they would receive no harm, but all would fall upon the poor people, o as it was better to give them up to the Enemy, and ave the ret: And thus he cryed out o lowd, as he was followed by ome, with whom he eized upon a Gate, which he defended o well, that Gondebunt was forced to retreat, and fall on upon another Quarter, where the Inhabitants did let him in: And thus betrayed by thoe of the place, whilt he was repuling thoe Enemies which were before him, he was aaulted o furiouly upon the backe, as at lat, vertue being over powred by number, and he receiving many wounds, he was taken and killed, though he would never yeild, chuing rather to dye, then fall into the hands of thoe, whom he called Barbarians. As for me, to my miery, though I may call it good fortune, that part of the Towne where I hapned to be was aigned for the Quarter of King Gondebunt; and thoe who were with him tooke me and many other Ladies prioners, and all committed to afe cutody; where we tayed untill the coming of this great King, in hopes his generoity would give us liberty, as well as his vertue had preerved out chatity.

Now Hylas you know both me and my fortune which I beleeve you will thinke to be very trange; ince when I was even at the very top, heaven dahed them, and took away my •• berty, and thus you ee my mierable condition.

Thus has the fair Cryeide (aid Hylas) related her fortune unto me, and I was o delighted
with it, as I did not thinke it a quarter of an houre ince her firt beginning, when it was o late, that all her companions came to tell her it was time to retire. And waiting upon them unto the ide of the River Arar, I then retired as full of love, as I was of atisfaction, to know that this faire one had learned how to love, and that her affection was not ettled any where, ince the death of Arimant, which gave me abundance of hope to arrive at the Port of my deires.

All the company tood very attentive, and deirous to heare the concluion of this Relation; Hylas tood ilent, and o as it eemed as if it was onely becaue they were then come unto a place where onely one could pae at once: And when all were paed, thy flocked about him, as deirous to heare the continuation of his dicoure, giving great attention unto it. What? what doe you expect more from me? aid he, and wondred they hould expect it: If there be any amongt you, that knowes any more of the tory then I have related, I hall willingly lend them audience; but if you look for any more from me, good friends, you will be mitaken, for I have not a jot more to tell you. All the company broke out into laughter to ee their expectations thus frutrated. Servant, ervant, aid Alexis, did you thinke that you performed your promie with this hort come off? Did you not promie me a relation of your everall loves? and you have related onely the misfortunes of Cryeide and Arimant: you have told us what you did not promie, and left untold that which you did promie; reembling thoe who had rather give where they doe not owe, then pay their due debts. Hylas being thus twitted, miled, and aid not a word, knowing that Alexis was in the right. At lat cating up his head; Mitree, aid he, I doe confee all you ay, but the fault is your own: but if the money which I payed you was not good, why did not you refue it: I mean, if you did not like what I told, why did you not interrupt me? for my part, I thought the money o good, that when I received it from Cryeide it contented me, and was pleaed with the repetition of it unto you. However, aid Alcidon, and interrupted, ince you have begun the tory of this generous Lady, you hould have ended it: I aure you, Sir, aid Hylas, I have emptied my Pure of all that money: I mean, that I know no more of Cryeides tory, onely this, that he went away without bidding adieu unto any, and I could never hear, whither. Madam, aid Florice then, and turned towards Alexis, are you deirous to heare the concluion of that tory? Yes, anwered the Druid, and I hould be obliged unto thoe that would tell it me, and I believe the ret of our way will permit it. I hall be very glad, replyed Florice, to atisfie your curioity; for Cryeide ince the departure of Hylas, related unto me at Lyons, all that he hath, and that I hall tell you, But it hall be upon this condition, that Hylas hall make good his promie another time; and he auring her he would, he began thus:

div.head: The equell of the Hitory of Cryeide and Arimant.
div.p:
BE pleaed to know, Madam, that this generous Lady being detained a Prioner in Lyons as you have heard, going one morning unto the Temple, a young man came unto her, and in the croud did put a little Book into her hand, and aid unto her in the Italian language, To morrow about this time you hall ee me here, and uddainly thruting himelfe among the people he left her in the greatet atonihment that ever was; for he knew him not, not undertood the meaning of this little Book; yet being very dicreet, he made no hew of her amazement onely as long as divine ervice lated, he beeeched Mercury to grant that it might be good newes. The Sacrifice eemed longer unto her then ordinary; and being extreamly impatient to know what this Book was, he opened it: her Companions who aw her very intent upon it, thought it to be a Prayer Book, as indeed it was, and never took notice of any thing ele: After he had turned over many leaves and found nothing, he was more zealous in her devotion unto Mercury and Apollo, who is the revealer of all obcurities, to direct her in the undertanding of this, never remembring all this while the way of conveying Letters betwixt poor Arimant and her elfe: he thought him dead, and therefore could not imagine any ue of uch a Book; but at lat, looking upon it more preciely, and turning over more leaves, he found a Letter, the upercription of which he knew; Oh how he was tartled <> it; he bluht, her hands and legs began to tremble; and all being ready to go away, he remained
till upon her knees not knowing what he did, nor what he hould doe; yet none took great notice of it, onely thought that her tay proceeded from her devotion. At the lat, her companion pulled her by the leeve, and made her follow the ret who walkked two and two, as Hylas related.

She was no ooner in the houe, but he went into a Cloet, hut the doore after her, and looking upon the Letter; alo imagining Arimant to be dead, he thought it ome trick of Hylas; but opening it he found thee words.

div.head: Arimant's Letter unto Cryeide.
div.p: MAdam, I live till, if it can be called life to be from you: I have ent this faithfull meenger to know how you doe, and to tell you how I am: Oh ye Gods, preerve Cryeide, and grant Arimant patience enough to endure all his misfortunes.

Till now, he knew not what to thinke; but when he found the name of Arimant, he knew that he was alive: he fell down upon her knees, and lifted up her eyes to heaven. Bleed be the Gods, aid he, for this trancendent happinee, when I had the leat hopes of it. Afterwards riing up, he at down upon the bed, where he kied the Letter a hundred times, accued her elfe of oblivion, for not knowing him who brought it; and calling her memory to account, he knew him to be the faithfull Bellaris, that young man who ued to bring Letters from Arimant, and brought her from her Mother unto Arimant. Where were my eyes (aid he to her elfe) and where was my judgement, that eeing him, and hearing his voice, yet I hould neither know his face nor his tongue? Then looking upon the Letter againe, and knowing mot certainly that it was the Character of Arimant: Oh ye Gods, aid he, I thank you mot heartily for preerving my life o long, as to heare this good newes. I praie ye, oh overaign Goodnees, and I now deire no more, but onely to be o happy as that thee eyes may ee him, and that this mouch which hath o often lamented him, may kie him. She had continued longer, if Clarina who would neverforake her, had to come to look her; he opened the door unto her Oh Clarina, aid he, and kied her; I have good news to tell you; but Clarina telling her that dinner was upon the Table, and that every one tayed for her, he could not then tell her any more; but the joyes of her face did ufficiently peak the inward contentment of her oul.

Cryeide did love Clarina very well, but though he had loved her lee, he would willingly have lot her dinner to tell her this newes; for it is the quality of all thoe who receive any great contentment, never to thinke it compleat, until they have communicated it unto thoe they love. On the other ide, Clarina was o netled with impatience, that he no ooner aw her Mitree from the Table, but he followed her into the Cloet where he found her before; and the door being hut, Oh Clarina, aid he, and took her about the neck, Oh my deare friend, I have great newes to tell you. Know, my wench, that A • imant it alive: Oh heavens, aid Clarina, Arimant alive! Yes, yes, Clarina, replyed Cryeide, he is alive, and has ent me this Letter: and now I value not all my mieries, ince he is alive to helpe me in upporting them. But, Madam, I beeech you, aid Clarina, How came you to know all this? Here weet-heart (aid he, and gave her the little Book) here is the meenger of the welcome newes. Clarina then tooke the Book, and kied it a hundred times, and did o wet it with teares of joy, as Cryeide aid unto her; Oh Clarina, you poile it with your teares, methinks you hould better preerve it: Then whilt Clarina took the Letter in it, and read it, Cryeide related unto her all the paage in the Temple, and how he did not know Bellaris, whom yet he hoped to ee againe the next day when he went againe; but if by fortune I cannot peak unto him by reaon of my companions, and others who have eyes upon me. Then Clarina, aid he, you mut by any means go unto him, and enquire how all quares go with my dear Arimant: In the mean time, provide me Pen, Ink and Paper, that I may return an anwer. I hall not faile, Madam, anwered Clarina, and it hall go hard but I will peak with him; for in this Country they are not o circumpect over us, as in ours. But, Madam, let us not tay too long together here, let we hould give any caue of upition unto thoe who guard us. True, Clarina (anwered Cryeide) the Gods have
ent thee into the world to be my comfort and Counellor.

Upon this, they went out of the Cloet unto the ret of the Ladies Prioners, who began already to aske where Cryeide was; for he having the firt rank, he could not be well mied; and beides he was o exceedingly loved of them all, as there was not one amongt them who would not erve her with their lives. She began therefore a hundred pretty ports amongt them, to pae away the time of their Dete •• ion, or rather imprionment: For Gondebunt had in his abence commanded they hould be o treated, as that they hould have no caue to grieve for being out of their Country.

This day eemed long unto Cryeide and Clarina, and the night longer; and the morning being come, they both thought that they went unto the Temple later than accutomed: At lat, the o much deired hour being come, they went together: And Cryeide cat her eyes on both ides, in hopes of eeing Rellaris; and he had no ooner received the holy water at her entrance into the Temple, but he epied him, taying there purpoly the better to ee her when he paed. Cryeide going as neere unto him as well he could, had no more leiure as he paed by, but to ay unto him; Clarina followes me; he quickly undertood her meaning, and conceiving it the bet way to avoid upition; he looked about for her paing by, which was after all the Ladies; and becaue the women went without order, he thrut in amongt them, and going neer her, he aid unto her, and looked another way as he walked; Where may I meet you Madam? In the Athenian Garden, anwered he, if we go thither this evening: but how does Arimant? He is in good health, anwered he • Upon this, he lifted up her eyes unto heaven, and went on, to avoid upition: Bellaris went preently and enquired about the Towne v • ry warily, to know where this Athenian Garden was, and being informed of every thing, he went unto the Gardiner, and for money got leave to walke there, when he would: For the Gardiner never refued uch a courtee unto any that eemed to be of any kind of quality, epecially he pretending that he was icke, and the Phyitians had precrib • d him to walke for recovery of his health. Having therefore put his buinee into uch good order, he went to the ide of the River Arar, that he might ee when they went unto the garden.

In the mean time, as oon as Sacrifice was done Clarina acquainted her Mitree with the dicoure he had with Bellaris, and how it was appointed to goe that day unto the Athenian garden; how he aured her, Arimant was in good health, and could not have any more particulars from him, the reaon was, becaue the place was not convenient, and it may be he deired to tell the good News unto you firt: I do like very well of the Athenian garden, anwered Cryeide, becaue there none will interrupt us. They had talked longer if dinner had not beene upon the Table, and becaue Cryeide did paionately deire to peake with the truty Bellaris, he went to walke omething ooner than uuall, and all the Company did like well of her humour.

As oon as Bellaris aw her enter into the boat, for the River Arar was betwixt the houe and the garden, he got before them and entring in, walked in an Alley neer the door. When the Ladies went to walke, Clarina and the ret of the women who waited in their Chambers did not go with them, but might goe into the Towne with any of the guard, and this was the reaon why Cryeide went alone. As oone as he was entred, he cat her eye on all ides, and preently epied Bellari • , and he eeming to be very inquiitive, firt looking upon one, and then another, as they walked; then as if he were extreamly moved unto compaion, he poke aloud in Italian: Oh what a loe hath Gaule Cialpine, being deprived of o many faire and virtuous Ladies? But when Cryeide paed by; Oh heavens • cryed he out, Is this Cryeide? Oh mot unfortunate Mother, can he endure this loe? then peaking till Italian, and falling down upon his knees before her, Madam, (aid he aloud) I hould think my elf the happiet man alive, if I could do you any ervice, being o much obliged unto it, as I hould thinke all my misfortunes nothing if I could but have that contentment; for having received my education under your family, I thinke my elfe commanded unto it, unlee I were the mot ungrateful peron that lives. Cryeide was a little urpried, and not knowing how to peak, was a little ilent; and this made thoe who looked upon her to be lee upitious. And becaue Bellaris aw he was urpried; It eems, Madam, aid he, you have forgotten poor Bellaris, who was brought up in the houe with you, and who had not left you, if a fond deire of erving men when they travell into trange Countries, had not moved me to follow the Noble and Generous
Martiantes: Oh my friend Bellaris (aid Cryeide then, as if he remembred him) who could expect to ee you here? what is it which brought you hither? Until now, Madam, aid he, I thought that • bad fortune brought me hither; but now I ay, it is the greatet happinee I could wih for, ince I have the honour to ee you, and offering my elfe unto your ervice. I thanke thee good Bellaris, aid he unto him, but we can expect no helpe but onely from God; for being in the hands of King Gondebu ••
who but God can take us out? Why, Madam, doe you not try to • anome your elfe aid he? I offer my elfe to go to Eporedes unto your friends, and <> any thing I can for you. Friend, anwered Cryeide, I doe not refue your helpe; but we mut tay untill the King return, and then we will ee what may be done.

The ret of the Ladies hearing this man peak Italian, they gathered about him, as very deirous to know what he was. One of them did aske him the quetion; Madam, aid he, I am a Sallaia • , brought up under the family of Cryeide, and one who does o well remember the benefits I have received, as I would at the perill of my life doe her any ervice: I was brought into this place not as a Prioner, but as a ervant unto Martiantes, a Cavalier well known in that Province: he was taken and killed by a company of Souldiers, at the foot of the Pirennian hills, who left me for dead by him, but the Gods Kept me alive, to bring the ad newes unto his friends, and to lament the loe all the dayes of my life. Alas (aid Cryeide, eeming to be orry) is Martiantes dead? He is, Madam, anwered Bellaris. I aure you, aid he, I am very orry for it, for he was a Cavalier of great merit. Upon this, all the Ladies divided themelves into everall walkes, leaving Cryeide alone with Bellaris: and when he aw none were in the compae of hearing; Ah my friend Bellaris, aid he unto him in a low voyce, now tell me, how does my deare Arimant, and through what fortunes has he paed? Madam, anwered he, Arimant is in health; but as for his fortune, it hath been very various, and I doubt I hall not have time to relate it I believe we hall anwered he, and if we have not, we will take another time for the ret. Then, Madam, aid he, I will be as briefe as I can: Be pleaed to know, that Arimant being o baely foraken by the Townmen where we were, he till defended himelfe mot valiantly a long time, and at lat was left for dead: Doubtlee but for me, he had never ecaped; but I being near him, I ued uch care as I was obliged unto; though I was much wounded, yet not being o bad as he I feigned my elfe dead and fell at his feet, for he was faln to the ground: The enemy having other deignes then riffling the dead, all the Plunder of the Town being theirs, they left us; and when I aw the cot cleare, I roe up, and bound up my wounds as well as I could; afterwards went to my Mater, and by the help of a young man of the Town, I carried him unto an uninhabited table which was neare, not daring to carry him into any houe, becaue all were full of Souldiers; I had an opinion, that he was not quite dead, thinking the Gods would never uffer uch a brave man to go out of the world in the flower of his age; I earched his wounds, and to the bet of my poor skill, I did not thinke them mort • ll: but not knowing well what to do, and eeing him bleed till, I tore my hirt, and tyed up his wounds as well as I could, and laying his head in my lap, it pleaed God that he revived: when he opened his eyes, he wondered to ee where he was, and I fearing his atonihment might do him hurt; courage, Sir, aid I unto him, the Gods will end us better fortune: The Gods, Bellaris (aid he) are indeed very good, but my detiny is bad, o as I can hope for no ret but in death: But Bellaris, what is become of Cryeide? Cryeide, anwered I, is afe, the wife to the Burgundian King, who followes him all about, caued all the women to be put into the Temple there to be preerved from diorder, and keeps Cryeide particularly with her. Heaven be her reward, aid he, foro good a deed.

I feigned all this, Madam, let his griefe hould have caued his death. But, Sir, aid I unto him, doe not trouble your elfe too much: No, no, aid he, now Cryeide is out of danger, I care not for any thing ele. Then, though with a little difficulty, I got him upon his feet, which was no ooner done, but we heard many Souldiers quarrelling at the table door; and preently after, drawing their words, they fell to fighting, about ome Plunder which they had gotten, and could not agree about the Diviion: The dipute was o hot that many were killed; and the noie encreaing, many others aembled, who as oon as they came, took ides; at lat, a Captain paing by, and eeing this diorder, he would needs regulate the matter; But the Souldiers thinking he would take all their Plunder
from them, in lieu of obeying, fell upon him, and o, as he was forced to ave himelfe by running to the table door where we were. The Souldiers who had laid aide all repect, and knew that if he ecaped their hands, he would have them all punihed; they reolved to kill him, hoping then to be afe and enjoy their Plunder. In order to this deigne, they endeavoured to enter in; which Arimant conidering, let us defend this Captain, aid he, perhaps heaven ent him for our aitance, o as if we doe him a courteie, he will doe the like for us: Upon this, drawing both our words, we took his part; and though my Mater was much wounded, yet his courage which never failed him, gave him trength enough to repell the fury of thee ouldiers; ome were killed, others taken, and the ret fled.

The Captaine eeing himelfe out of danger, and not knowing Arimant: Cavalier, aid he unto him, I am obliged unto your valour for my life; and in requitall of this aitance, which I have received from you; command me any ervice within the compa of my power, and I hall be mot ready to doe it. Sir, aid my Mater, I was obliged unto all I did, and if I have done you any ervice, I deire no other recompence, but that you will take me as your Prioner, and ue me like a Cavalier, as both you and • are. The Captaine upon this looking better upon him, and eeing by his habit that he was no Burgundian, he aid thus unto him: Sir, I do receive you as you deire, not to ue you as a Prioner, but as my friend, and a Cavalier of merit. Alo I pae my word, I will rather die, then you hall receive any dipleaure from our Army.

Thus was Arimant and I, under the protection of this Captaine whoe name was Bellima • t, a man indeed of great Credit, but much devoted unto his wealth, as afterwards we found, and who according to the cutome of the Viigots did eldome remember any benefits; for though he was a Viigot yet he followed the King of the Burgundians, as a peron who ought for fortune whereoever he was in hopes to find it. The firt day, we received all the kind uage we could expect upon uch an occaion; But the next day, being better informed of the quality of his Prioner, by ome in the Town, he began to keep us under better guard, pretending it was becaue he would have us keep our Chambers, that our wounds might ooner heale, forbidding any to peak with us: Afterwards, eeing the Army was to move, and he not knowing whither, he took my Mater apart, and told him, that in performance of his word, he was forced to end him over the Alpe • ; becaue the King being informed, that it was he who had raied the oppoition in the Town, and had caued the death of many of his men; he has commanded him to be earched for throughout all the Army, intending to put him to death, as a terrour unto the neighbouring Towns: that perhaps he could make a hift to protect him againt any but the authority of the King: That he would willingly let him pae free amongt his own Souldiers if he durt, but it would hazard his life if the King hould heare he permitted uch a thing without his conent: yet on the contrary, he could without any exceptions end him beyond the Alpes, ince it was permitted unto all the Souldiers to end their Prioners and Pillage thither. But as oon as the Army was returned unto Bungundie, he would end him back unto Eporedes, or any other place he pleaed. Arimant then asked him, whether the Queen had ent her Prioners thither alo? The Queen, anwered the Captaine, is not here; but they have ent their Prioners thither, to the end the Army may be dicharged of them. My Mater looked upon me, as if he had aid, you are mitaken, and afterwards continued; I will go, aid he, whither you pleae, auring my elfe that a Cavalier o courteous and noble as you are, will not ue me otherwie then is fitting for a peron of my quality, and as one may expect from uch a Cavalier as you are.

Do the next morning betimes, not without great danger of my Maters life, by reaon of his wounds, we were carried away by aconvoy, which guarded many other Prioners not knowing Madam, what was become of you; onely that the King had put all the Ladies together, let they hould receive any injury. After we had paed the Alpes, they brought us unto this Town; and preently after, being parted from the ret, they carryed us into the Seguian Country, by the Mountaines of Gebennes: And at lat, they put us up cloe into a little Catle neare the Town of Gergov •• : Well may I ay [cloe up] for we were guarded o cloe, that we hardly aw any light, and o we continued for a time: but the merit, and weet converation of my Mater, did work o well upon this harh Keeper, and the promies I made to gratifie his courteie, when Bellimart gave him liberty,
did move him to let me go out and treat with him about our enlargement. This, Madam, has been my Maters fortune; but nothing touches him o at heart, as being ignorant of your etate; hearing onely in generall, that you were in the hands of the King. It was not any deire of his enlargement, or treating with Bellim ••
which brought me hither, but only to know in what part of the world you were, or whether you till retained any memory of him.

How? replyed Cryeide, any memory of him? what hould I ele have an my memory but him? Yes, yes, Bellaris, I mut be dead, before Arimant be out of my memory. The Gods doe know, there is not a day, nor an hour, nor a minute, in which Clarina and I have not talked of him with eyes full of teares. Now my deare friend, I will declare one thing unto you, which I have not yet mentioned unto any; but finding my elfe in this condition, and foreeeing that it will be wore with me, I am forced to tell it unto you, that by your Counell I may find a remedy. Know Bellaris, that Gondebunt the King of Burgundie, is faln in love with me; I know it both by his deportment towards me, and his expreions. I would not upon any termes reject him at the firt, becaue an incened love may drive a man unto violent coures: but after I had given him many thanks for the honour he did me; I told him, that I was none of the common ort of people, but extracted out of the bet Families amongt the Sallaes: Rithimers wife, who was iter unto the Emperour Anthemius, was my near Couin: That this conideration might well move him to treat me according to my quality; and by this meanes • e might not onely make Rithimer his friend, but Anthensius alo who was allied unto me. Unto this he returned no other anwer than this, that I did him great a favour in telling him as much; and that upon his returne he would make it appeare, how much he eteemed my merit, and my alliance. Now Bellaris, I do foreee a harp Combate: For I am told that the King is upon his return, and I ee all preparations are making for him: Perhaps he may change his humour and fancy to me and perhaps not: Now if he doe continue it, judge you, how I hall be perecuted. To marry him, I had rather die: To refue him, he is a young arrogant man • and blown up o high by o many victories obtained, and al • s what can I doe; o as I doe foreee a mot dangerous torme of miery hanging over my head, and know not how to helter my elfe from it, unlee you advie me in this great neceity. Bellaris tood a while and poke not a word, at lat he aid unto her; Truly, Madam, thee coniderations doe peake you full of affection unto my Mater: and it mut needs be confeed, that he is infinitely obliged unto you, in lighting this King to preerve your elfe for him: I will mot freely expoe my life to doe you both any faithfull ervice: I beeech you, Madam, therefore tell me, Doe they keep you very cloe? You ee, aid Cryeide: if they ue you no wore then o, replyed he, you may eaily ecape: But aid he, if I hould make an ecape, whither can I go? For, to pae over the Alpes, is the way to be taken againe, it is impoible to avoid it: Never trouble your elfe, Madam, aid he, o you could get but out of this Town; I know a place whither to carry you, where you may tay in afety, untill Arimant be gotten out of the place where he is, by a way that I have thought upon; and when you are both together, I am confident you will contrive a way how to pae into Italy. Oh my dear friend, aid he, Couldt thou but doe as thou ayt, my obligation to thee would be extream; if thou cant but get a Boat upon the River Arar under my window, it is o near the ground, that by the help of thy hand, I could come down in the night. Enough, aid he, I can do it; but how hall we pae the Chaines which are at the end of the Town, before we come to the River? Friend, replyed he God will help us; and if thou wilt but take a little paines, thou wilt eaily find the meanes; for I have heard that others have ecaped the ame way: But Hores mut be provided for Clarina, for thee, and for me, and that I look upon as the greatet difficulty; for whom cant thou trut to hold them? That is nothing, anwered he, for I will get one to hold him, who hall not know what he does: But the wort is, I have not money to buy Hores or Boat, or to make you clothes in the fahion of that Country: for the ouldiers have gotten all I had, and my Maters alo. Let that be the leat of thy cares, aid Cryeide, for I have yet good tore of Rings: then pulling a Diamant of good value from her finger, he gave it to him: Go friend, (aid he) ell it, and buy uch things as thou wilt; if that will not erve, thou halt have more.

It is not materiall to relate every particular; Bellaris provided Clothes, bought Horses,
found a Boat, and all with uch expedition, that in two dayes all was in readines.

In the meane while, he took notice of the place where they were to pae, where their Hores hould tay, and of every circumtance: And the Chaine, being onely Boats fated together a cros the River; he went the night before and filed the ring of one Boat, o as it was held together by a little trength. All things being thus ready, and the hour appointed being come, Cryeide roe out of bed, and Clarina alo; And being in their firt leeps in the dead of the night, they went out of the window without any noie, and took Boat; and Bellaris being their conductor, puhed the Boat from the hore, and hit right upon the Boat whoe ring he had filed, which breaking out right, with as little noie as he could for feare of being heard by the Guards, he paed through with his Boat, though a little after they were all in great danger of being drowned For the Rone, into which the River Arar runs, it was o rough, and the Boat o little, alo the Waterman not being very skilfull, as the danger was great, but at lat he gained the hore: And though it was much lower then he aimed at, yet by the help of the Moon which began to hine, he found the place where a little boy held their Hores, who alo promied him to be his guid.

Whilt they were fitting all things about the Hores, Cryeide and Clarina did take their new habits, which what by reaon of hate, and darknee together, they did put on o il-favouredly, as if they were ome mungrell Gentlewomen that would be fine if they knew how But being as they were they took Hore and paed through the Country of the Segu • ans, carrying till their guid with them, let he hould make ome dicovery: And after they had with much wearinee paed the Cemmenian Mountaines, travelling more by night then day, and eating alwaies in ome wood, in which the Country was abundant; they came at lat to the Town of Gergovia, in which Cryeide was not afraid to lodge, becaue it was in the Dominions of Eurick King of the Viigots. She took up her lodgings therefore in an Inn; and the faithfull Bellaris went the next morning unto Arimant, unto whom dayes eemed very long, little expecting to hear uch good newes o oon: Cryeide had given Bellaris another Ring of very good value, to the end that if he who guarded Arimant would be corrupted, he might give it unto him, and promie him more if need were.

As oon as he was returned, the Captaine of the Catle brought him to his Mater: Come friend, aid Arimant unto him, dot thou bring me Life or Death? Sir, anwered he aloud, I doe not bring any bad newes, onely that King Gondebunt being not returned, the valiant Bellimart is not returned neither, o as I have lot my journey. I met with one that was your Couin, who was very inquiitive of you, and offers you all aitance unto the King and Bellimart, and is confident of finding favour, otherwie my journey is to no purpoe: and I believe that ere long; I mut have another; for the King is dayly expected You had done very well to have tayed, aid Arimant, and not returned with o little contentment unto me. Sir, anwered he, I was in feare you would have thought my tay too long; and having none to wait upon you I thought it better to return, then tay o long to no purpoe. Then the Captaine began to peak; you had better have tayed, aid he, then make another journey; for according to the intelligence which we have, if the King be not come already, he will not tay long.

But as oon as the Captaine was gone, and they two alone, Bellaris fell down upon his knee, took his Maters hand, kied it, and with a miling countenance, aid unto him; I perceive Sir, you are dipleaed with my journey, but I believe you will bid me welcome when you know all How does Cryeide, aid Arimant? Does he endure her imprionment well, and does he till love me? Suppoe, Sir, replyed, Bellaris, I hould bring you better newes then all this; would you then ay I were welcome? What better newes (aid Arimant) cant thou bring then this? I will not onely tell you, Sir, replyed Bellaris, That Cryeide is well and that he loves you as well as ever: But more, he is at liberty: nay more yet, he is coming to you; Clarina and he doe tay for you in Gergovia, Bellaris, aid the Cavalier and miled, is this all true thou ayt? Doe you thinke, Sir, aid this faithful ervant, that I would bring you any lies? The goodnee of the Gods be praied, aid Arimant, and lifted up his hands and eyes to heaven Then turning himelf towards Bellaris: But friend, is it poible all this hould be o? Can o much happinee come all at once? Sir, anwered he, doe not make any doubt of what I ay; and to tetifie my affection and fidelity, you may to morrow, if you will, ee this fair one,
who has taken o much paines to give you contentment: but then I am afraid it will be the lat ervice I ever hall doe you: Alas, aid Arimant, I would not buy my contentment at o dear a rate as the loe of thee; but if it could be any otherwie, I hould be mot heartily glad of it. I will tell you, Sir, aid he, what I did determine to doe Then he began to relate unto him, how he met with Cryeide in the Temple, and in the Garden; her reolution to ecape, how they got away, how he was in Ger •• via in the Gaulih habite where he expected him, and briefly all the whole paage. Then he continued; Now, Sir, you mut make all the hate you can to get from hence for doubtlee, King Gondebunt is even very now upon his return; and then you may aure your elte, that Bellimart will either come or end for you; you know his covetous and greedy mind, and God knowes how he will ue you: you may remember his ingratitude towards you, and you cannot hope for any courteie from him, who has hewed himelfe already o unworthy. Beides, it is impoible that Cryeide hould tay long where he is, and Gondebunt not be advertied of it; and you mut know, how that King is o much in love with her, as he has declared ome intention of marrying her. You ee therefore it is full time to make all poible hate out of this Country and judge whether or no Cryeide love you, chuing rather to run all thee hazards for your ake, then to marry o great a King? You mut therefore deire the Captaine to let me return this night to Be •
limart; you mut eem much dipleaed with me for not taying till his returne, he will eaily grant it Then as oon as the doors are open you may put on my cloathes, and I will tay in your room. Oh Bel • ar •• , aid Arimant, I am afraid thee men will doe you ome hurt, and if it could be contrived ome other way it would be better. No, no, Sir, aid Bellaris, there is no other way: For in the firt place, time does pree you, and there is no probability that this man who guards you, will be corrupted by Gifts, becaue he thinkes your Ranome will be very high and it is probable that Bellimart has promied him a hare. And as for me never let it trouble you for I am confident the Gods will help thoe who hope in them, and are faithful to their Maters, by ome unexpected meanes Can I doe you any better ervice, Sir, then in a buinee of this importance? But uppoe the Barbarian hould ue me with the wort of his cruelty; hall any danger whatoever deter me from doing you ervice? If I die, it is no more then I ought to doe for you And I can never doe it with more honour then in gaining your liberty and contentment: If on the contrary, I hould not, I may be upbraided all the dayes of my life, for loing o faire an opportunity of tetifying how much I am devoted to you. Doe not ravih from me this Glory, I beeech you, ir, I aske it in recompence of all the ervice I ever did you, and onely require three things from you: The firt, That if I die, you will remember, you never had a more faithfull ervant: Secondly, if I live, that you will give Clarina unto me for my Wife: And latly, That when you are got out from hence, you will make all hate away that poibly you can, let you hould be taken againe. Thus continuing his dicoure with o much urgency, he prevailed o far with Arimant, as not to deny him his requet, though it was with abundance of orrow to leave him in o much danger.

Night then being come, Arimant entreated the Captaine, as Bellaris propoed, to give him leave to goe again, who the King knowing would ere long beat Lyons, and deirous to be fingering of the Ranome as oon as he could, whereof he was to receive a good hare; he did not onely give leave, but advied him unto it, and that he would end a Letter by him unto Bellimart.

Thus the departure of Bellaris was reolved upon; and the Gate was ordered to be opened for him when he would: Bellaris informed Arimant in all things; to wit, where he houl • find Cryeide; in what place the Hores tood, and which way he hould pae; telling him it was better to go a little about, and go more afely. In uch dicoure as this, they pent a good part of the night; another part in hifting habits, and taking order for all things requiite; o as when it was break of day, after Arimant had embraced his faithful ervant with many teares, and recommending himelfe unto Mercury, he et forward towards the Gate in great feare of dicovery; for though he had the clothes of Bellaris, yet he was not like him, being much bigger, and faces o unlike as it was impoible not to know the one from the other, if the leat notice was taken; yet he paed without any rub, it being dark, and peciall order being given for it Bellaris looked after him out of his Chamber window, as farre into the plain as his eye could reach, and he
oberved how Arimant looked often back to ee whether any followed him. At lat, when he was out of ight, then the danger wherein he was, began to preent it elfe before his eyes, and he thought upon the horrors of death: But neither death nor danger, nor any thing, could make him repent of what he had done, or be orry for it in the let manner. Yet, as every one deires to prolong his life as much as poibly he can; o oon as he had got his Mater away, he would now try what he could doe for himelfe. He turned the Doublet and the Stockings of Arimant the wrong ide outward, and ullied his Hat, o as it had a reemblance of his own. As fortune was, Arimant had left his Cloak behind him, perhaps on purpoe to be the lighter: To be briefe, he tricked up himelfe as well as he could, and with a confident countenance he went to the Gate and offered to goe out: The Corporal who commanded there denyed him, aying, that one was already gone out, and he had no command for any more. But Bellaris hewing him a Letter which was directed unto Bellimart, and the Captaines hand which was known unto all thoe at the Gates, they permitted him to pae. But firt, the Corporall who was exact in his office, would not uffer it without a new command, and therefore ent him with a Souldier to know the Captaines will; the Souldier went, but being very early, and they keeping uch a noie at the Captaines Chamber door, they awaked him: then he was very angry with the Corporal for not letting any to pas who had Letters for him; o the Captaine being angry at his being wakened, he turned about and fell fat aleepe againe.

Thus Bellaris got out of the Catle, and taking his way towards Gergovia, he made as much hate as if he had wings at his heels: But his Mater having got the tart of him, and finding out the Inn, he went and knocked at Cryeides Chamber door, who being but in a lumber did preently hear him, and called upon Clarina to ee who it was: Clarina he aroe out of bed, put her Petticoat on, and a Mantle over her houlders, and went to the door with her eyes hardly open. Bellaris, aid he, thou art welcome, we have long looked for thee. And Cryeide being very impatient, did ask who it was: It is Bellaris, Madam, aid he, let him come in, aid Cryeide, perhaps he brings good newes. Yes, Madam, aid Arimant, I doe bring you very good newes. Cryeide hearing him, and knowing his voyce: Oh my good God, aid he, and tarted up, it is the voyce of Arimant: Then drawing the Curtain, he aw him already upon his knees by her beds • ide. Imagine, Madam, how this did urprie her, and how infinitely he was joyed? She cat her armes about his neck, and kied him o long, as if he intended never to part from him againe. As for him, he was o over-joyed to have his deare Cryeide in his armes, that he held her o cloe againt his breat, as he was afraid he would have topped her breath: Clarina having hut the door, did look upon them, and tood immoveable, o ravihed with admiration, as he knew not whether it was waking or dreaming. After he tood thus like a tatue a long while, he went to open the windows, afterwards went to them againe, and found them till embracing, and her elfe as much ravihed as before: Then fearing they would even die with over joy, he thought good to part them for a while, that they might take a little breath; but checking her elfe, he let them alone to glut themelves with kiing and carraing; and doubtlee they had not ended o oon, if they had not heard one knock at the Chamber door. Clarina wondred, and could not imagine who hould come o early to trouble them. Arimant aroe, and laying his hand upon his word, he went to the Chamber door; but never was man o urpried as he; for he aw Bellaris, beyond all hope or thought; Oh Heaven my dear friend, aid he, Is it thee? Yes, Sir, aid he, the Gods have delivered me, that I may doe ome ervice yet again. O good Gods, replyed Arimant, Can all this good fortune continue; Cryeide at liberty, I at liberty, Bellaris at liberty too? this is happinee beyond all hopes. Then taking him by the hand, he carryed him to Cryeide, related unto her how he had got him to ecape, and unto what extream danger he expoed himelfe. When he and Arimant began to give him thanks, he interrupted them, aying; pare your words, Sir, I beeech you, I am obliged more then o to erve you: and loe not your time which is o precious unto you: I am afraid they will follow you, let us pack out of Town and away, and when we are more at leiure I hall tell you how I ecaped.

Cryeide approving of what he aid, he dreed her elfe o uddainly, that he was at the tairs feet before the Hores were ready; Arimant helped her up, and Bellaris Clarina; and after the reckning of the houe was dicharged, Arimant took the hore of his faithful
ervant Bellaris, and o etting forward with their Guide, who was already very affectionate unto Cryeide, by reaon of her naturall weetnee, and liberality towards him, they went a good pace at the firt; but when they were got a little from the Town, they went lower, becaue Bellaris was on foot; and who by the way, telling them how he ecaped, did make them laugh heartily at the extream feares in which he was, when the Corporall denyed him paage, and at his hate which he made when he was once out of the Catle.

Thus they paed on the way as pleaantly as perons in uch conditions poibly could; and being tirring betimes in the morning, they went over the great Mountaines of Cemenes; & afterwards through the gloomy wood, called Black-wood, and came very late unto Viveros hunning as much as poibly they could all great Towns, and high-wayes, the better to deceive thoe who perhaps might follow them: But it hapned unto them, as unto thoe who thinking to avoid an ambuh, doe leave their right way to fall into it. For the Captain who had Arimant in Guard hearing that he was ecaped, took with him even or eight of his men, and reolved to purue him, or at the wort, to go and acquaint Bellima • t with it; becaue he believed, that doubtlee they would goe to Lyons, either to embarque themelves, or ele to take the way of Heluces. They being that Country men, and knowing the hortet wayes they got before them, and that night came into the very ame Inn where Arimant and his company were to lodge: Bellaris was alwayes wont to goe a little before and provide lodging and coming into this Inn, the Captain knew him preently, and thought Arimant not farre of; he aembled his men lily, thinking to urprie them both together, which Bellaris oberving, he ask • d for the Mater of the houe, and asked whether he had any lodging, and being anwered, yes; Well then, aid he in a loud voyce, I will go and fetch my Mater: The Captain who was in the next Chamber and ready to eize upon him, hearing this, would not dicover himelfe, becaue he would catch them both together; but wary Bellaris, returning as fat as he could to his Mater; Sir, aid he, Let us ave our elves as well as we can, for the Captaine is in the Inn. Arimant was extreamly urpried at this; yet conidering what a hort time he had to conult upon the matter, he thought it bet that Cryeide and Clarina hould go unto the Inn with the guard and invent ome tale or other to excue their journey, and the next morning they hould take the way to Vienna, and to know which way they paed, they hould tick a little branch in the way they took, when they met with everall paths; and thoe who came firt to Vienna, hould lodge in an Inn next the bridge on the other ide of the River Rone, and there tay for the ret.

The, would have aid more, but they thought they heard Hores trampling in the treets, which caued Cryeide and Clarina with their guide, to put on their Hores the one way, and Arimant with his faithful ervant the other: The Cavalier by the favour of the night and the thick wood, did eaily ave themelves; and the third day came to Vienna betimes, where they lodged in the Inne next the Bridge: At night asking newes of his Hot, he heard how King Gondebunt was returned from Gaul Cialpine, loadned with victory and poil; but at his return had received a very great dipleaure, becaue an Ital • an Prioner with whom he was much in love with, had ecaped from him, and no intelligence could be given of her. And to manifet the truth of this, aid the Hot, I will hew you the Kings Proclamation to that purpoe this day publihed: Then pulling out a great Paper printed, he read thee words.

Gondebunt, the on of Gondioch, King of Burgundy, Lord of the Seguanois, Lingones, Vellaundonois, Ambarres, Heduois, Catalauniques, Matiques, Alexens, Allobroges, Bailians, Latobriges, Sebuians, Secuians, Secuienes, Vabromaines, Sedunois, Augutes, Sallaes, Centrons, Bramovices, Ebroduntians, Segovellaunians, Galloligures, Governour of the Alpes, Sempronians, Jovinians, Pennines, Coties, Sebatians, Maritimes, &c.

Unto all to whom this our Will and Pleaure hall come, Greeting, In as much as there is nothing that more offends a generous courage, nor gives it a more jut deire of revenge, then Ingratitude and Treaon. And whereas, to our great griefe at our return from our
long, glorious, and dangerous voyages, we are advertied, that Cryeide one of our Prioners, and one upon whom we had howred abundant favours, has ungratefuly ecaped our Guards, which was impoibly for her to doe, without the counell and aitance of ome perons ill affected unto us, who have perfidiouly toln her away, in contempt of our royall Power and Authority For thee caues, and many others, thereunto moving us, and by the advice of our Great Councell, to chatie uch ingratitude and Treaon, We doe Declare and Promie, by the Great God whom we adore, by the oul of our mot honoured Father, and by the majety of our Crowne, That whooever hall bring unto us this ungratefull Cryeide, our fugitive Prioner, or hall reveale him or them who are the caue of her flight, or who does perfidiouly keep her, give her any aitance or favour, of what quality, nature, or condition oever, we will grant unto him uch favour as he hall aske of us; and will not upon any caue, ground, colour, or conideration whatoever, break this our Royal word, promie, and olemn Oath: And we do enjoyne and command all our Sheriffs, and other Officers, to publih this our Will and Pleaure throughout all our Dominions. Given at our Royal Town of Lyons, in the I • es of July, the econd year of our Raign.

Arimant hearing this Proclamation, was in extreame feare let Cryeide hould be known as he entred into the Town, epecially when the Hot continued his dicoure, and told him, that the King had ent perons who knows her, unto all Bridges, and advenues of Towns. This caued him to take Bellaris apart, and command him to provide mens habit both for Cryeide and Clarina in all poible hate; and as oon as they were ready, to carry them that way they were to come, that they might o diguie themelves before they entred into the Town. Bellaris did as he was appointed, and all being ready he went to meet them. In the mean time Arimant furnihed himelfe with better Cloaths, then thoe he had from Bellaris. But fortune who was minded to vex thee two generous Lovers yet a little longer, and to have greater tetimonies of their love and courage, did o contrive the matter, that at the very ame time Bellaris met Cryeide; and when he thanked the Gods for Arimants afe arrivall unto Vienna, the King Gondebunt being hunting the Hart, he rode cloe by her, onely with five or ix who followed him: and becaue he oberved that as oon as he pyed him, he retired her elfe behinde the next buh which tood a little out of the way, he followed her onely out of curioity: But Bellaris knowing him at the very firt, he clapped himelfe flat down upon the ground in a valley, which Cryeide could not doe, nor Clarina neither, becaue they were on horeback; o as the King overtaking her, and eeing her in the Gaulih mode, he thought at the firt that he was ome of that Country, who becaue he would be retired, went out of the high way: but asking her who he was, and whither he went, as oon as ever he opened her mouth, he knew her; for though he had the language of Gaul very good, yet he had the accent and tone of a tranger. And looking a little neerly upon her, though he endeavoured to hide her face all that poibly he could; Oh Heavens, aid he, it is Cryeide: Then lighting from his Hore, he ran to embrace her; How long is it, faire Ladie, aid he unto her, ince you firt took this diguie? What good Angel is it that hath bro • ght you again into my hands? and what Devil was it that took you out of them? Poor Cryeide, more amazed then is imaginable, to ee her elfe in the power of him whom he mot feared, and falne from uch a height of happinee, into uch a gulph of miery, he tood a while and could not anwer: At the lat, eeing there was no way to conceal her elfe, he reolved to take heart, and mot couragiouly anwered thus; You ask me, Sir, when I aumed this habit and diguie? and I anwer, ever ince Love did command me: And becaue you call that good Angell who got me out of your hands, a Devill, I mut vindicate his honour, and let you know, Sir, that it is unworthy in o great a King, to break both the Lawes of Humanity, and the Lawes of Chivalry, which commands you to ait, relieve, and honour Ladies; and not to take them Prioners, and keep them againt their wills. The King hearing the freenee of Cryeides language, and his love not letting him conent unto what he knew was the duty of a Cavalier, he anwered her; Before any hould doe you any wrong, Madam, I will loe both my Crown and my life; and in this which I do, I intend it for your good and advantage, and not to harme or wrong you in the leat degree. She would have replyed, but the King was o over-joyed at this happy encounter, and not willing to enter any further into dicoure, he took her Hore by the bridle, and led him into the high-way,
where taking his own Hore, he returned to Lyons preently, more contented with this prize, then with all his Victories. When Cryeide was thus taken, Clarina could eaily have aved her elfe, if he would as well as the Guid; but having no mind to leave her, he did follow her voluntarily. Thus was the ad Cryeide carryed back to Lyons, and put amongt the ret of the Ladies Prioners, but under a more carefull Guard then before; although the King did really intend to marry her, as well for her beauty, as for her affinity to Rithimers wife, iter unto the Emperour Anthemius and commanded that he hould be waited upon with all ervice and civility: and his joyes that he had met with her were uch, as he caued Bonfires and great Feats of rejoycing to be made. In the mean time, Bellaris having ecaped through Ruhes and Bogges, he came in a pittifull fright, to bring this aid Newes unto his Mater, who was o much urpried with wonder and orrow, that he was not able to peak one word; but throwing himelfe upon his bed, there he lay till night, and ay what Bellaris could by way of conolation, he would not anwer him: Afterwards, he went into bed, and would not eat nor leep all the night; In the morning he called for Bellaris, bad him go unto Lyons, and enquire how Cryeide did, and how they ued her: This faithfull ervant, though with much danger to himelfe, did as he was commanded; when he came into the Town, he found no great need of any enquiry; for Cryeide was the talk all the Town over, and the Kings favours were uch, as it was generally believed he would marry her though he was much againt it, for ome reaons which yet were unknown unto them. But eeing o great a difficulty to peak unto her, he returned to his Mater, with a reolution of perwading him to retire into Italy, ince it was now not likely but he who was courted and honored by o great a King; Ambition to be Queen, would quench all her love to Arimant: Being returned then unto Vienna, he related unto him all he heard, afterwards did et before his eyes the levity of Women, their Ambition; the gilded flattery of being Queen, and the great probability that he would entertaine the honour which the King did her. He would advie him, not to buie himelfe any more in the matter, but to conider how his Father would grieve for his loe: How it might be the caue of his death, and the utter ruine of his houe; That to tay any longer here would not be afe, becaue their Guid might dicover him, and caue him to be taken: And that for thee reaons, and coniderations, and many others, it was requiite he hould with all peed retire to his houe. Arimant did heare Bellaris all this while, though his mind was quite another way. But when he had done; Bellaris, anwered he, I hall perhaps follow thy counell, after thou hat done one thing yet more for me: Go againe preently to Lyons, give this little Book unto Cryeide, procure me an anwer, and then thou halt ee what I will doe. This ervant infinitely loving his Mater, did aure him he would doe it, ele loe his life; but entreated him that he would not grieve o exceively; to remember that his virtue is able to urmount the greatet misfortunes; that he ought to hope till, and not to ink under his orrows. And Arimant promiing he would take his counell, Bellaris departed with his little Book, in which was a Letter that contained thee words.

div.head: Arimant's Letter unto Cryeide.
div.p: SHall this misfortune have a greater power over you then all others? Mut Ambition of being Queen, make you unfaithful? Doe you intend to betray me, and make me the mot mierable amongt men? If o, then end me word, that my death, I may keep you from being perjured.

Bellaris had no other way to deliver this Book unto Cryeide, but as he went to the Temple; and therefore he got himelfe as neare the Baon of Holy water as he could, and as he had done formerly: when he paed by, he conveyed the Book o nimbly into her hand, as none could perceive it: She preently apprehended the buinee, and poke not a word, but onely, To morrow: In the mean time Bellaris went out of the Temple, and as he ued, into the Town, where he heard that the King did really intend to marry Cryeide •
that he did deny him; and that for all this, he would go through with it, auring himelfe, that when he had married her, he would then change her mind.

The next day, Cryeide failed not to return the Book again unto Bellaris, by the ame
