ubtilty, aying unto him as he paed by, I will die firt: He undertood well enough her meaning; and admiring the love and generoity of this woman, he returned to his Mater, and acquainted him with what he aid, as he gave him the Letter, which was o great a conolation unto Arimant, that he almot forgot his miery; Then taking the Letter, he found thee words.

div.head: Cryeides Anwer unto Arimant.
div.p: I Will die, before I change; I will make it appeare how farre the reolution of a woman can go, who whether alive or dead, will never be any but yours: be the like to me.

Well Bellaris, aid Arimant, Cant thou advie me to forake a woman, who has thee reolutions towards me? I mut needs confee, Sir, anwered he, that I doe admire her: her virtue is above my opinion of her: But good ir, what doe you intend? and which way can you relieve her? The Kings power is too great, and his love is too violent, to afford any hopes for you? And your danger in taying here is o great, as I will give you for lot, if you tay any longer. Never feare it Bellaris, anwered Arimant, I have thought upon a way to ecape, and doubtlee it will take effect. Then he gave order for his departure, and the next morning went unto Lyons, where he arrived in the evening when it was dark, and took up the mot private lodging he could chue. There he heard the continuation of the ame reports, and more; That the next morning the King intended to offer a acrifice upon the Tombe of the two Lovers, in hopes that they would mediate for him unto the Great Tautates, to change the heart of Cryeide, and move her to conent unto his deires; and for the greater olemnity, he would have her preent with all the ret of the Lady Prioners.

Arimant was very glad of this newes, and thought it a fit opportunity to effectuate his deigne, therefore he prepared himelfe againt the next morning. In the interim, the King olicited her with all manner of Courthip, and ued all his Rhetorick to perwade her unto compliance with him: But he tood as contant and firme to her reolution as any Rock againt the waves of the Sea, which cannot be moved. And this was the reaon why, before he had recoure unto force, he would eek the favour of Tharamis, and by acrifices obtaine from him o much grace, as to change the heart of this generous Maid. When he entreated her to be preent, he willingly conented: For, aid he to her elfe, if the God Tharamis be a jut God, he will move the minde of this King, to deit from any injutice.

The next morning, when it was time to go unto the Sacrifice, he prepared for her a mot glorious Chariot, and contrained her to weare the Royall Crown, cauing all the ret of her Companions to wait upon her in great tate, as if he were already the Burgundian Queen; thinking to hake her contancy with uch Grandures and Pomp: he appeared indeed very faire and lovely, and this dree was not a little addition unto her beauty: but for all that, the inward digut of her oule appeared in her face, and all her actions. The King was o much pleaed to ee her in this deck, as he did imagine her already his wife. Thus they paed through the Town, and came to the Monument of the two Lovers, where the acrifice was to be offered.

When they were there; and the King, Cryeide, and all the ret of the Ladies had taken their places; the Sacrifices came, and the Victimaries brought the white Bulls, and the Priets approaching as neare as they could to the Tomb, they commanded the Victims to be killed; when they were opened, and their intralls earched, they were found to be • ound and perfect, uch as preaged happinee, of which the King was was very glad, and told Cryeide that it was an evidence the Gods were well pleaed with their alliance. She, who till then, had ome hopes in the jutice of this unknown God; and now eeing her intent frutrated he knew not what to have recoure unto you but depair. In that reolution he eemed deirous to ee the intralls of the Victim her elfe, and asked permittance to go unto them.

The King who was confident in the Reports of the Priets, she was very glad he had uch a deire, thinking that the ight would make her more inclinable unto him, when he aw the will of the Goddee. So being helped down, he went unto the place of the Sacrifice,
eemed very buie in looking upon the Liver, upon the Heart, and the ret of the Noble parts. And whilt the Sacrificers were all very buie in hewing thee things unto her, he eized upon a Knife yet all bloody, wherewith they killed the Victims: Afterwards running as fat as he could unto the Tomb of the two Lovers, he laid hold upon one of the corners, and then lifting up the Knife with a mot reolute countenance, he aid aloud, Dot thou ee this Knife which I have in my hand, magnanimous Prince? I will preently run it into my heart, if any one offer any force unto me; and th • n etting the point of it againt her breat, he continued thus.

The great God of Heaven and Earth be my witnee; Oh great and invincible King, that I do eteem and admire thy peron, and all that proceeds from thee: I ee thou art favoured by the Gods, loved by thy Subjects, honoured by thy Neighbours, and feared by the enemies: I acknowledge Prudence in all thy actions, Generoity in all thy enterpries, Jutice towards all in generall, and a particular love towards me, which does not onely oblige me to admire thee, and erve thee as all the ret of the world doe; but alo to eteeme thee, and love thee as much as poibly I can: Knowing therefore all thee things, and being enible of the honour you are pleaed to do unto me in uch an advantageous marriage: It mut needs be omething that has a great power over my affection, and over my duty, that can divert my will from accepting of it. Would you be pleaed, Sir, to conider this, I hould hope for a pardon if I doe any thing that dipleaeth you • for believe it Sir, could I dipoe of my elfe, I hould be more willing to content you, then you can be to command me.

But be pleaed to know, Oh great King, that as oon as ever I came out of my infancy, the Gods would have me love a Cavalier, I ay the Gods would have me for had it not been the will of the Gods and had not they written it in the unalterable Role of Detiny, doubtlee this affection would have long ince withered away with o many bitter blats and tormenting tormes of fortune. Firt, my Parents, who had power over me: Next, Rithimer, whom you know is puiant: and now, you oh great King, would pull me out of the arms of my Husband: for o may I call him unto whom I have promied marriage, calling both Juno and Hymen for witnees of our reciprocal oaths, and to end jut cures upon uch as break them. If all this be not true, may thee two faithful Love • s who ret in this Tombe, and whoe oules are with God, and enjoy the reward of their fidelitity; may they, I ay, punih me with all the rigour of divine jutice. But if all I ay be true then I d • e conjure them by that inviolable love they bore unto each other, to hew their power in thee, oh Great King, by obtaining of the Gods to change and divert thy mind another way. Be aured, oh Great and generous Prince, that this is all thou cant obtaine of me, unlee by force; which if thou wilt ue, then this knife hall end my oule out of my body, and leave nothing in thy power but a cold carcae, without either life or love. But if thou dot indeed love me, and art that Great King who has made all Italy to tremble at the very noie of thy Arms; make it now appeare, not onely in etting me at liberty, but alo retoring him unto me whoe I am, and from whom nothing but death can divorce me: If thou wilt get the name of jut, thou mut render unto every one that which is unjutly taken from them And if thou wilt hew thy elf magnanimous, doe it in urmounting thy elfe; thy elfe, I ay, who hitherto has been invincible. If all this thou dot not doe; then O King, expect the vengeance of the Gods, who at this very hour doe it in Heaven, and ee how thou wilt carry thy elfe in this action, and will mot certainly either punih or reward thee for it: And you, oh perfect and bleed oules, aid he, and turned towards the Tombe, who perhaps whilt you lived here, reented the ame mieries that I do, have compaion upon me, and let m • not this day before o great an aembly, embrace your Tombe in vain, or call upon you without reliefe.

Thus Cryeide ended, and embracing the corner of the Sepulchre, he held the knife againt her breat, ready to trike it to her heart, if he aw any offer to pull her from thence. All the aembly were infinitely atonihed, when they heard and aw the reolution of this Lady. But the King above all the ret, was confounded at the Accident. For the Sepulchre of thee two Lovers, was a anctuary unto all thoe who laid hold upon it, and received any wrong in matters of Love; and was o religiouly oberved, that neither Father nor Mother themelves could recal their own Children, when they held by one of the corners. The King could not imagine, that Cryeid •
hould make this ue of it; or
that being atranger, he hould o much as know or thinke of it. But eeing it o, he knew not what to reolve upon: To let her go at liberty he would not; to violate the priviledges of the Sanctuary he durt not; both out of fear of the Gods, and tumult of the people. At the lat, after he had conidered and debated the matter with himelfe, he reolved to pull her from thence, without any regard either of the place or the aembly; thinking the forces which he had about him, would keep the people within compae; and as for any offence to the Gods, he hoped to doe well enough with them by Sacrifices, and hereafter duties.

In this reolution he advanced, thinking himelfe to go unto her; and he eeing him coming, had given her elfe the fatall blow, if the Priets had not oppoed the King; telling him, That a Prince o jut as he and one that feared the Gods, ought not to violate and infringe their franchies. But his love which had more trength in him then all thee coniderations, had doubtlee driven him beyond his duty, if Arimant, who was a pectator, and feared let Cryeide hould be driven to the extremity, had not preed through the Guards, and tepped between Cryeide and the King, and falling down upon his knees, aid thus unto him; Sir, I come here intrudively, unto your Majety, in full aure of your Promie and Oath, that I hall receive the favour which you have promied and proclamed unto him, who hall tell you who it was which helped this generous Lady to ecape your Guards. Stranger (aid the King) I never will break any promie that I made: declare therefore the man, that I may punih him; then ask what favour thou wilt, and obtain it. Sir, aid Arimant then, and roe up, The man is in your preence, and you may punih him when you pleae, for it is my elfe. This, replyed the King, is inolence in the height; and how durt thou preent thy elfe before my face? Onely in hopes, Sir, aid he, of the favour which I hall aske: Never think, Sir, that it hall be my life, or the leening of any punihment upon my elfe, which I hall require; but that in obervance of your promie unto which you obliged your elfe by the great God whom you adore, by the glorious memory of your Father's oul, and by the Majetie of your Crown, you would grant me another favour which I hall aske. The King tood amazed at the reolution of this man, and going back a pace or two: Stranger, aid he unto him, certainly thou art out of thy wits, otherwie thou wouldt never peak thus; but how wert thou the caue of Cryeides ecape? Sir, replyed he, my name is Arimant; and I am the happy Cavalier whom this faire one ayes, he loves: I was taken Prioner when he was; I was carryed Prioner to the Town of Gergovia, where I found meanes to let her heare from me: She who thought me dead, as oon as he heard I was alive, he reolved to ecape and come unto the place where I was, and help me out, which he did accordingly, and was the caue of my liberty. You ee, Sir, how I was the caue of her ecape, and having declared it unto you, you are obliged to grant me the favour which you have promied. The King, who was on the one ide atonihed at his reolution, and on the other ide offended with him, as thinking himelf leighted by this tranger Yes, yes, aid he, it is very true, I doe owe thee a favour, aske it therefore, and prepare thy elf to uffer the punihment of my jut indignation. Sir, replyed Arimant, I never expected lee from o great a king as you are: and therefore I doe freely put my elfe into your hands, not fe • ring any of your punihments or torments, provided that firt I doe obtaine the favour which I hall aske. Ask it then (aid the King) and by all the oathes which I formerly took, I do oblige my elfe to grant it. Sir, replyed Arimant, then I doe aske that Cryeide, whom I ee at the corner of the Tombe, and who is your Prioner, may be et at liberty, and ent unto her friends, or whither he hall pleae, without any force or compulion offered unto her. Oh Heavens, aid the King, mut I my elfe be the intrument of my own miery? and having imprudently promied, mut either be perjured, or ele be the mot mierable Prince that lives? Then tanding a while ilent, and being inflamed with anger, and ahamed to be accued before all the people of breach of faith and promie; he reolved to maintain it, but withall, to atisfie and vent his anger upon Arimant. And therefore with eyes inflamed with fury; I do declare, aid he, that Cryeide is at liberty; and I do trictly charge upon pain of my great dipleaure, that none whooever, doe offer her the let violence or injury: vowing by the oul of my Father, that he hall never obtain either favour or pardon from me: Then turning towards Arimant, Well tranger (aid he) art thou contented with me? Yes ir, anwered he, the mot contented man in the world. Then turning towards the Souldiers; Take away (aid he)
this turdy contemner of my anger, and let him uffer torment till he die, that other rah men like him, may by his example learne to dread my anger. Arimant looked up with a cheerful apect, and oberving Cryeide to weep: Oh Madam, aid he unto her, I beeech you let not your teares diturbe the tranquillity of my oul: Alas, my life could never be better imployed then in procuring your liberty: Liberty? aid Cryeide, I value not liberty at o dear a rate, I had rather uffer perpetual imprionment, then ee you o ruined in the flower of your age: But go Arimant, and if I have my liberty, I will not be long after you; I will make it appeare, that I can die as well to follow you, as you can to ave my honour.

Whilt he was talking thus, and Arimant conjuring her to live as long as it hould pleae the Gods to prolong her dayes, they had finihed the tying of his armes with chaines. The people were all o moved at the contancy of the Cavalier at the compaion of Cryeide, as they ighed and cryed at uch a pittifull eparation. Bellimart who was with the King at this Sacrifice, and hearing Arimant peak, he knew him to be his Prioner, and o did the Captaine who was come to acquaint him, that he was ecaped. And eeing that if Gondebunt did put him to death he then hould loe all his hopes of any ranome; he addreed himelfe to the King, and aid; That it was not to thwart the will of his Majetie in any thing, becaue all he had, his Majetie might freely dipoe of, but onely becaue he was unwilling to loe his right; that he beeeched him to wave the execution of Death againt this tranger, until he had informed him of his reaons; and the King permitting it, he repreented unto him the great paines he had taken in his ervice the hazards he had run, and the wounds he had received: And Sir, aid he, the ranome of this tranger whom I took prioner who ecaped from me, was all the reward I ever hoped for: But if this entence of Death be executed I hall loe all my hopes, and all that fortune gave unto me; which I believe, Sir, is not a little; for he is one of the chiefe of the Province of the L • bians, and his Father who has no Children but he, is raied to that credit, as that great Souldier R • thimer has more apprehenion of him, then any in all Cia pine Gaule. He had no ooner poke thee words, but Bellaris that faithful ervant, not knowing what his Maters deign was, running unto this place as almot all the Towne did, and hearing what he had done to ave Cryeide, he was extreamly deirous to free his Mater from this danger, by the loe of his own life; an • therefore crouded in, and cat himelfe at the feet of Gondebunt in uch a reolute manner, that he hindred him from giving Bell • mart any anwer: and when he aw the King hearkned towards him, he began thus:

Sir, you have this day gotten the title of a promie-keeping Prince; and I doe here cat my elfe upon my knees, beeeching you to be no lee an oberver of your word towards me, then you have been towards this Cavalier, called Arimant. Stranger, aid Gondebunt, neither thou nor he, nor any living, hall ever have any caue to upbraid me with breach of word: Sir, aid Bellar • s, this action peakes you worthy to be the Monarch of the whole world. Then riing up, he continued thus: You have promied, oh Great King, to betow a favour upon him who was ayding and actually aiting in the ecape of this Lady: I have o, aid the King; Then, Sir, aid he, I come to inform you of him, againt whom you have jut caue to be angry, and everely to punih: for indeed he is in all the fault, and you cannot in reaon accue this poore Cavalier of any crime; though it is true, he was a caue of her ecape, becaue he did not contribute any thing toward it, farther than that he lived and loved her: I mut confee that had he not been amongt the living, he would not have had any mind to ecape: But, Sir, is it a crime to live? Did he ever give her any counell or advie her to it? or did he ever take any paines or indutry about it? No, no, Sir, not at all, further then to let her know he was alive. But on the other ide, he whom I hall dicover unto you, is onely culpable; he firt gave the counell, he contrived the way; it was he who looed the Chaine of Boat • which blocked up the River; he helped Cryeide to pae through; he found out Hores for her to fly away: To be briefe, Sir, he did all; and by conequence deerves all the punihment.

The King hearing this tranger peak thus; Why, aid he, art thou o long before thou namet him unto me, that I may everely punih him? Sir, aid the faithful ervant, I hall quickly name him, and more then that, I will deliver him into your hands, when according to your Royal word, you have granted me the favour which I hall ask. I doe promie it, aid the King, and confirme my promie by atteting all that is acred. Then,
Sir, aid Bellaris, the favour which I ask is, That this Cavalier may be et at liberty, and that all his fetters may be charged upon me; for it was I onely, that helped Cryeide to ecape: It was I who brought her newes he was alive; It was I that has been with her ever ince. To be brief, Sir, It is I onely that deerves all the punihment, becaue I was, I only, that am the caue of your high dipleaure. But now ince I have made good what I have promied, it is your part, Oh great King, to make good yours and grant the favour which I asked: I was from my infancy brought up in the houe of this Noble Cavalier, I do owe unto him all that I am; I have been a witnee of his affection unto Cryeide, from the very firt beginning of it; and I have een o much virtue and noblenee of minde between them, that I thinke the end of my dayes mot happy, if I can be a meanes of their long living together by virtue of the favour which I ask; I hould think my elfe culpable of ingratitude, if being able to ave the life and honour of him who gave me life, and who by his example has taught me all things vertuous and honourable, I did not freely doe it. And therefore, Great Sir, I deire you will abolve Arimant from all kind of punihment, and not onely et him at liberty, as you have already Cryeide; but alo, that you would be pleaed, out of your incomparable magnanimity, to make them marry each other, as they are already by the conent both of themelves and their Parents. Let all your anger which you aimed at him, be imployed, good Sir, againt me, and adde as many torments as you will, o they be afe; for the very Glory of doing what I ought to doe, will make them all o weet unto me, as I hall not reent the harpnee of the paine.

And becaue, Sir, I hear that the valiant Bellimart pretends to have ome right unto my Mater, becaue he was formerly his Prioner. Give me leave to contradict his pretenion in the preence of your Majetie. Firt, What can he pretend unto my Mater, but onely this, that my Mater gave himelfe unto him? When you took the Towne of Cartures, Oh great King, Bellimart knowes very well how much he is beholding unto this valiant Cavalier, for his life; I will not repeat it, let it hould blemih uch a generous courage as that of Bellimart: But I mut needs ay (and he knowes I ay truly) that it was not he who took my my Mater; But my mater after he had done Bellimart a very notable piece of ervice, did entreat him to take him as his Prioner, upon condition to ue him like a Cavalier, and a man of •• ality: whether this make my Mater a Prioner of War, or a Prioner of Courteie, I refer it unto the judgement of your Majetie. But to wave this, and admit him his Prioner; what is it he would now have? If he was his Prioner then, why did he not keep him? Did he let him go upon his Parole? No, Sir, he guarded him as well as he could, and he could not keep him. Now if a Prioner doe ecape, and he who had him, do meet him in another Province, can he take him again? No, ir, this concerns the grandure of your Majetie. I doe not ay, but that if Bellimart had kept him till his Prioner within your Dominions, he might now have had ome Law to demand him: But ince he did not keep him afe within your own Realme, but ent him into the Country of the Viigots; what reaon has he to take him againe now, ince he ecaped as for afety into your Dominions; and o much the rather, becaue your Majetie having made a peace with all the poor people of Cialpine Gaul, there is no likelihood that all thoe who fly hither for refuge, hould be eized upon as Enemies. This, Sir, is the lat ervice I am like to doe for this noble Cavalier, unto whom I doe owe much more then I am able to pay.

Thus the faithful Bellaris ended his peech, which contained in it o much affection and reaon, that the King could not chue but admire the love of Cryeide, the Generoity of Arimant, and the fidelity of Bellaris; in o much as he tood amazed at them along while, and began to relent; At lat he broke out into thee expreions: Great are the Judgements of Tautates, and his wayes are o deep, that no mortal man can find the bottome. I made choice of this acrifice, in hopes of perwading Cryeide to love me; and on the contrary, he flyes to the priviledge of the Tomb of the two Lovers, I publihed a Declaration, thinking by promies to regain lot Cryeide, and that Declaration is it which hath ravihed her from me, and made me quite loe her even when he was in my own hands; and all this to hew that all humane widome is but folly, compared to the infinite widome of that great God whom we adore. And though I do ee all thee things do conduce unto the confuion of all my deigns, and plainly foreee that there is no hopes for me in the fair Cryeide: yet mut I needs confee that all things have been alleadged
upon uch ound reaon as I protet that had I known the beginning and progree of this great and vertuous affection, I would ooner have dyed then uffered it to be eparated. And therefore, oh you happy couple of Lovers, I doe declare you free, and exempt from all manner of punihment or imprionment, be it either in relation to me or unto Bellimart, upon thoe reaons o trongly urged by that faithful ervant, whoe offence I doe alo mot freely remit, wihing rather uch a friend and uch a ervant, then uch another Kingdome as I have; I do give you all three free power and liberty to live in any part of my Dominions or ele to go whither you pleae; yet if you will afford me o much contentment as to ee you married before you depart, I hall think both my Kingdom and my elf much honoured and very happy in it.

Upon this, he commanded that Arimant hould be unlooed, who with the generous Lady and faithfull Servant, came and cat themelves at his feet upon their knees, ome kiing his hands, others his knees, and all the Aembly did commend the Magnanimity and jutice of the King, who by the grandure of his courage, knew o well how to vanquih himelf.

Thus Florice ended the relation of the fortunes of thee two perfect Lovers, every one admiring their virtues; ome did highly eteeme Cryeide for refuing the Scepter and Crown of Rithimer and Gondebunt, to preerve her fidelity unto Arimant: Others admired the reolution of Arimant, in offering o voluntarily to die for the liberty of Cryeide, but all with one commune conent commended the fidelity and affection of Bellaris. Hylas onely laughed at all three, and at all thoe who did commend their actions. Was ever the like folly een? aid he. Cryeide like a fool as he was might have beene a Queen, and now he is onely a illy Country wench; Arimant alo, like a fond obtinate Coxcombe in his courthip of Cryeide, mut loe his time, be wounded, taken Prioner, and after abundance of perill and trouble, be at lat like to loe his life in digrace, and had done o if Gondebunt had not been more courteous in performing his promie, then he was wie in putting him to it: Had it not been better for both parties if Cryeide had been a Queen, and afterwards given Arimant that atisfaction he deired? But Silvander, all their perplexities and mieries do proceed from that which you call Contancy. It is that onely which tormented them o pittifully; onely that, which had like • o have cot them their lives, and made them the port of fortune and chance. Silvander hearing himelfe named, came neerer Hylas, and anwered him thus; All thee things which you have named, Hylas, are indeed the conequents of contancy which you doe o much condemn; aud how much they are accompanied with paines and dangers, o much more are they to be eteemed: they are onely generous pirits that dare attempt difficulties to accomplih their deigns: They are but imple oirits, aid Hylas, who run after a hadow and leave the ubtance: Arimant is tyed to a thing called Contancy very finely; he mut pend all his youth in the ervice of Cryeide, and when he is old, then he will give her elf unto him, this is as much as to give a hard bone to knaw upon unto a Dogge that has no teeth: Had not this Cavalier done better if he had tayed in Eporedes, and comforted his poor old Father who loved him, than to break his heart with griefe, or at leat made his old age o full of orrows and misfortunes, as death was welcome to him: And then for Arimants own proper contentment doe you thinke there was no women in all the Town but Cryeide? Ah my friend Silvander, what groe folly is it to loe ones time, and pend all one has upon one Commodity? had he followed my Lawes, when he met with o many difficulties oppoing his deires he would have wiely turned his back upon them, and have made his addreses unto ome other whoe conquet would have been more eaie, and perhaps more advantageous: Every one did laugh at the opinion of Hylas; and Tircis began then to peak; I perceive, Hylas, (aid he) that you are one who will never build any Temple unto Fortune, becaue you will not have any thing to doe with her. And I perceive (aid Hylas) that you are one whom onely thoe that are old and ugly will adore. And why? aid Tircis: Becaue, anwered Hylas, thoe who are old & il-favoured, to invite any to love and erve them, do propoe you as a God: You, I ay, who are o far out of your enes as to love one that is dead. This, Hylas, replyed Tircis, is inhumane, to repreent unto the afflicted the caue of their griefe; but be it o, that I hould be eteemed by thee old ones of whom you peak, and propoed as a God, what hurt is it unto me? Is it not better, my friend, to be thought a God, then to be held for an uncontant man? And Hylas, are not Altars and Sacrifices
pleaing unto the Gods, whom we adore? and why then hould they not be o unto men? Do you think, Tircis, anwered Hylas, that I have not as many Altars and Sacrifices as you? certainly I have; for I can make my elf more adoreable then you can: This onely is the difference, you are the God of the old and ugly, and I the God of the young and faire: And therefore the acrifices which are offered unto you are old and wrinkled, and mine are young and plump: Unto your Altar comes none but ancient Matrons, crawling upon Crutches, and crooked, their heads and hands haking and trembling; but unto mine comes none but the fairet, younget, and jolliet wenches in all the Country; o as I am then the God of Pleaure, of Joy and of Life; and you the God of Envie, Sorrow, and Death. Now tell me, Tircis, without p • ion, which of thee two Sacrifices doe you think more agreeable and etimable? Tircis would have anwered, when the venerable Cryante being advertied, that Adamas with his company would pae by very near her houe; he came through the wood which joyned to the Meadow belonging to the Temple of Atrea, and by her coming interrupted their dicoure, becaue the Druid advanced to alute her, and calling Alexis, preented her as his Daughter. The venerable Cryante, kied and embraced her with abundance of joy and o did the ret of the virgin Druids, much admiring her • eauty and behaviour. In the meane time, the venerable Druid addreing her elfe unto Adamas, beeeched them not to think her o uncivil or negligent of her duty, but that he would wait upon them if he could; yet being commanded by A • ais to wait upon her, he was afraid he could not; which, aid he, does mot trouble me; for I perceive he will come unto me ooner then he thought, by reaon of this new accident which happened: What Accident? aid Adamas: I thought, replyed the venerable Cryante, that you had been acquainted with it. You mut know, Arganteus was killed in the preence of Galathea and Polemas, by a Cavalier tranger, and in the concluion of the combate one of the Lyons which guarded the inchanted Fountain, eeking about for food, came upon the place, and o affrighted the Hores of Galatheas Coach, as they ran away, over <> the Coach, and broke is all in pieces; So as he, who by fortune was on foot, to ee the Combate and part them, was forced to walk on foot unto Mount Verdune, where he tayes, expecting her Coach, and the recovery of the Cavalier who killed Arganteus, and I believe is there till. Whilt they were thus talking, they were interrupted by the coming of young Lerindas, Galathea's meenger, who addreing himelfe unto the age Druid; Father, aid he, The Nimph Galathea has ent me unto you, to let you know that he intends to be preent at the acrifice which you intend to offer for the Misletoe; and fearing he hould come too late, he deires you to tay a little, and end her word in what place you will offer it.

Adamas hearing this meage, was a little urprized at it, becaue remembring that Galathea had formerly een Celadon in womans Clothes, and therefore he feared he would know him now in the habit of a Druid: Yet not to give any notice of his feare, he anwered him thus: Friend, I deire thee to tell the Nimph, that I hould be very willing to obey her commands, but the time is o hort now, as I am afraid I hall not: For I know he would not have the ervice of Tautates retarded: all things being in readinee, and the hepherds and hepherdees aembled upon the place, o as it is indeed impoible to defer until another time, without great diorder and candall; but if he have a deire to ee thee faire and dicreet hepherdees, I promie to bring them unto her within two or three dayes unto Mount Verdune: for I believe he would be at the acrifice, only out of a deire to ee them altogether: I aure you Father (aid the young Lerindas) you have divined aright; For I have heard her ay, that he deires nothing more, then to ee whether the hepherdees of Lignon be as faire as they are reported: I thought as much, replyed Adamas; For this Sacrifice which now we are about, is but a private acrifice of a few, and not worthy of her preence; but the great Day of Solemnity is the ixth day of July, when I hall be happy in her preence, if he pleae to honour us o far: Tell her therefore, Lerindas, that the hortnee of the time, and the little olemnity which is now to be ued, is not enough to invite her hither, and that I know thee faire hepherdees will make good my promie. I aure you, Father, aid Atrea, none of us will be againt whatoever you hall promie, epecially in paying a duty unto which we are all obliged: You doe very well (anwered the meenger) to peak for all the ret; for I believe that you and Diana, are the two whom he deires mot to ee, and you Atrea,
above all. Had I thought (aid <> ) that <…> had been o happy <> to be known unto o great a Nimph, we hould long ince have paid the duty which we <>
Your Names, and your Beauties, aid Lerindas, cannot be <> in thee <…>
and I mut confee that I think I have been partly a <> of her deire <> ee you having told her whom I aw. When he ees us (aid the hepherdee) <> he will ay, you poke too high in advantage of our beauties I feare •• plyed he that he will accue me for peaking too little in your advantage, rather than too much but I know he expects me with impa • tience, therefore I will go and tell her of you, and wear • unto her truly, that he mut hide all her Nimphs when you come, unlee he would have: <>
bluh for hame, and pine away with envy. Leonide hearing thee words, and ee • ing to be offended: How now Lerindas, aid he, doe you ue my companions thus? I protet unto you, I will tell them. If you doe, anwered he, you will doe them a • double dipleaure The one, in making it appeare unto them that they are not o fa •• : and the other, in letting them heare a reproach which will offend them, and which in reaon they cannot contradict. Upon this, without taying for an anwer • he ran away towards Mount Verdune. And Adamas fearing till left Galathea hould come to the acrifice, to the end he might dipatch it the ooner, dimied the venerable Cry • n • e, who would willingly have been preent, had he not feared that Amai •
and Galathea would come in the mean time unto Bon-leiu.

A little after all the company came into the little Meadow which was before the entrance into the Temple of Atrea, where there was a very great aembly of hepherd •
hepherdees, with their <> Eubages, Bardes, Sarronides, and Druides of the Neighbor-hood, and all things requiite for the acrifice in readinee. Amongt the Pators there aembled, was the prudent Phocion, and the age Diamis, o commendable for their yet
• erable age: Amintor alo the Nephew of Philidas was there, and by fortune, Daphnis the deare friend of Diana, who being come the might before, would not faile to be there with Callirea, as well to ee the acrifices, as her deare companion from whom he had been long abent As oon as they aw each other, they left all other company, and running with open armes, they embraced one another with uch abundance of joy, as they made it appeare, that abence had no power over their affections After they had long embraced, Atrea and Phillis came and parted them, and deired to be participants in the Carraffes. See here my companion (aid Diana to her) ee what I have got ince you aw me, here are two other Daphnis whom I doe love as I doe my life, and would have you love them alo, being certaine that according to your merits, they will love you as well as you love me. Then Atrea and Diana, confirming that aurance with a hundred protetations of amity, and Daphnis receiving them with the like cordial affection, they contracted uch a ociety amongt themelves, as never after was broken.

In the mean time, Adamas being detrous to know whether all things neceary for the acrifice was ready, he found that the Priets had been very careful in their offiecs. So as after they had wahed their hands and faces in the fountaine which was at the entrance into the Temple of Amity; and being clad in white, and crowned with Vervine, He, and the Vaites, Eubages, Sarronides, and others appointed for the acrifice, they took all thoe things with which they would acrifice. One carried the Gilden Hatchet wherewith they ued to cut the Misletoe: Another, the white ilken Rope, in which they tyed it: Another a bundle of Savine: Another, of Vervine; two carried the Bread and the Wine which they were to acrifice: At lat came two white Bulls, Crowned with Savine and Vervine, decked almot all over their bodies with Flowers, and driven by • ight Victimaries.

The age Adamas, all thee things thus prepared and paing in order before him, he came with a Gravity becoming a great Druid, and taking two or three turnes about the acred Meadow being followed by all the hepherds and hepherdees with great <>
rence, he et the Misletoe upon an Altar which was erected at the foot of the happy <>
upon which the new Misletoe did grow.

The place was where the Temple of Atrea was made, by lapping together little trees one with another in form of an Arbor, by the hepherd Celadon •
And because, they mut firt pae through the Temple of Amity, as formerly I told you many of thoe who followed the acrifice, were contrained to tay there, becaue the Temple of <>
was too little to hold o great a company: Moreover, the two white Bulls, and the
eight Victimaries took up a great deale of the room; and yet Adamas was forced to offer the acrifice there, becaue the Tree wherein the Misletoe was, did b • are up almot all the roofe of this Temple and according to the cutome, the Thanks mut be given at the root of this Tree which heaven had o much favoured.

After the Great Druid had ranged every thing in order, and aw all the people zealouly at their devotion, he caued a great Chaffing dih of coles to be brought, and putting it on the Altar, he took three leaves of the Misletoe, as many of Savine, and three branches of Vervine, and threw them into the fire. Laying his hand upon the Altar, he aid thus:

Unto thee, O great Heus, Bellinus, Tharamis, that this people doe render thankes for the Misletoe which thou hat ent amongt them; It is unto thee as their onely Tautates, that in this Wood they offer the acrifice of Thanks, in this Bread and Wine, together with the blood and lives of thee white Bulls: The one in tetimony that we acknowledge it to be from thee, we have the preervation of our lives: And the other to hew our incerity with which we doe adore thee, and conecrate thee pure and immaculate Victims. As Heus, trengthen the arm of our Cavaliers and Souldiers, and infue uch courage into them, as they may be able not only to defend us from our enemies, but alo to get the victory over them: As Bellinus, be thou the God of men, and preerve them: As Tharamis, clene and purge us from all our innes: And as our Tautates, be till our onely one God, and look upon us through this Goddee Atrea, from whom we hope for all manner of Benediction.

Upon this, he threw a little of the Bread and Wine into the fire, and made a figne to knock down the Victims: Two did receive the blood in Baons, and two held the legges of the Bulls let they hould hurt the Victimaries: Afterwards, the Priets cauing them to be carried into the acred Meadow; they opened them, and earched their entralls, and found them to be very ound, perfect, and of a good Augury At which all being very joyfull and contented, they made the report of it unto the Grand Druid before all the Aembly, he thanked Great Tautates for being pleaed with their acrifice of Thankes, beeeching him to continue till his favours towards them. Then after a Benediction the acrifice ended, all were full of joy and contentment, and mot of the old hepherds returned to their homes.

In the mean time the Victims being cut in pieces, and the fire having conumed a part according to the cutome, the ret was dreed and eaten by the Priets and other hepherds as would be in their company: None taying in the Temple of Atrea, but Adamas, Daphnide, Alcidon, aud the ret of the hepherds and hepherdees that came into their company. And becaue Daphnide, who had beene accutomed onely unto acrifices after the Roman manner, was very deirous to know, why they ued any other ceremonies in this Country: Madam, aid Adamas unto her, Though this Country of the Seguians which we call Forrets, be in extent much lee then any Province in Gaule; yet the great God hath had a greater care of it then any other: For to ay nothing of other, the Gallo-ligures, which is that Country commonly called the Province of the Romans, becaue they had a great affinity with the Romans; and the principall Towns are Colonies of Focenes, and are addicted unto plurality of Gods, though at the firt as Gaules they had the Religion of their Fathers; yet as errors are apt to ininuate themelves by degrees into all things, they did the ame amongt their Ceremonies, and brought into their acrifices the fale and idolatrous opinions of everal people, and made a Micellany of the Gaule, Roman, and Greek Religion, and o became much corrupted. But on the contrary, this little Country of Forrets, never having any communication with trange people, unlee with ome Romans, have been exceedingly careful to preerve thee Ceremonies which you ee pure and entire as they received them of old from thoe Ancients, who after they had long floted upon the waters, brought in that true and pure Religion which they learned from that great friend of Tautates, who with his family aved himelfe
<> the generall inundation.

Now this man taught them, that there was but onely one God, whom he called Tautates, whom by everall urnames, he ometimes called Heus, that is to ay, God omnipotent and omnicient ometimes Bellinus, that is to ay, God and Man, becaue of all mortal Creatures man onely does acknowledge him: ometimes Thamires, that is to ay, God purging and taking away the innes of the living: and this beliefe has beene
ever preerved pure amongt us untill this time: And we may boat that we are the onely people of all the Gaules, who have had this happinee; for ome by compulion, others voluntarily, and by convere with the Romans, Viigots, Vandalls, Almains, Picts, and Burgundians, have lot this purity which we have till retained, both in our beliefe and practice.

Whilt Adamas was thus talking unto Daphnide and Alcidon, dicovering unto them the ecret myteries of his Religion; Atrea hewed unto Alexis, the rarities of this Temple, which he had een before the hepherdee, and yet eemed to admire them, epecially when Phillis told her, that this Temple was made by an unknown hand and that there was not a hepherdee in all the Country who knew him that made it. 'Tis trange, (aid Alexis) for it is not the work of one day: and yet, aid Atrea, none took any notice of it, untill it was finihed as you ee. But I beeech you, Madam, aid he, tell me whether your opinion doe agree with ours; look well upon the Picture of the Goddee, and tell me whom you thinke it doth mot reemble? It does reemble, aid Alexis, the fairet hepherdee in the world: Then, replyed Atrea, you are not of the opinion of us all; for thee hepherdees aure me, and I thinke they are omething in the right, that this face doth much reemble mine. Mot certaine, replyed Alexis. For the Picture does extreamly reemble you; and yet that doth not at all hinder, but that you are the fairet hepherdee in the world. I receive this commendations, aid Atrea, from Alexis, becaue I deire to be the more pleaing unto her, and becaue he being no hepherdee but a Druid, I doe not any injurie unto her in accepting of it. Though I were a hepherdee, anwered Alexis, yet you ought to accept it, ince it is o much your due: And though you refue it out of exces of modety, yet reaon will force you unto it by the judgement of all. But fairet hepherdee, let us talk no more of that which cannot be denyed by any, and let us ee, I beeech you, what is upon this Altar, which I think have been dedicated unto you by the Pans and Egypans of this Country, under the name of the goddee Atrea. The hepherdes hearing Alexis, he thought that he heard the very voice of Celadon, as he was wont to dicoure unto her; and he was infinitely joyed at this reemblance, as he could not hide her joyes from her companions. And at the ame time when they came unto the Altar, Diana and Phillis came alo having Daphnis with them, who being atonihed at what her Companions aid concerning that place, went along with them, looking upon all the rarities in it: and by fortune, Diana laying her hand upon one of the little Roles of Paper, of which there were many upon the Altar: he opened it, and found certaine Veres in it, and hewed them unto Phillis and Atrea. Methinks Siter, aid he unto her, that I hould know this hand: It is Celadons, anwered Phillis, and I cannot chue but be ravihed with wonder at what I ee in this place. Atrea bluhed at the name of Celadon, and Alexis much more, who to diguie it the better, did ask who this Celadon was, of whom they poke; He was, aid Diana, one of the mot courteous hepherds in all this Country, and by unhappy misfortune was drowned. In what place? aid Alexis: It was, aid Atrea, in the fatal River of Lignon: but, aid he, let us talk upon ome other ubject, and look upon thee other Roles; Then taking one which was in the hands of Daphnis, he aw ome Veres which were written in another Character: for they were written by the Nimph Leonide, when not being able to perwade Celadon to forake the melancholly life he led in that place, he did viit him almot every day; and becaue he could not conceal her paionate affection to him, he writ thoe Veres as a tetimony of it: When Phillis heard the name of Celadon, certainly, aid he, this is the place of wonders, for there is no quetion but every thing in it relates unto Celadon, and yet we all know that he is dead. How do you know that, aid Alexis: Nay, aid Atrea, it is but too true, for I aw him die, and ince have eene his Ghot, but I beeech you let us leave off this dicoure: and then offering to go away, Diana tayed her, and looked in another Paper which was written in the ame Characters the firt was, and contained thee words:

div.head: I.
div.p: Sighs, the Children of that thought which o inceantly torments me; why doe you not, either blow out that fire which is in my oule, or ele • inflame it as it may quite conume me?

div.head: II.
div.p: Sighs, which were wont to be the Cordialls of him who gives you being; why doe you now change your cutomes of comforting, into a coure of tormenting?

div.head: III.
div.p:
Sighs, which do come from my heart; why doe you not carry that heart unto her for whom you are created, that o you may either give me a death by taking it from me, or a lif •
by carrying it unto her, who is the originall of my life?

div.head: IV.
div.p: Sighs; why doe you come from my heart, ince all my hopes are gone, and all my deires ought to be quenched?

Thee faire hepherdees had not left one Role unopened which was upon the Altar; if Adamas, who was hewing unto Daphnide and Alcidon, the myteries of the Temple of Amity, and the Temple of the Goddee Atrea, had not interrupted them. They to give him place, went all out; though none of the company knew more of them then Alexis, yet he eemed as much amazed at thee things as any, and was as inquiitive to be informed in every circumtance. When they were come out, they found Hylas at the Fountaine, and would not enter into the Temple now no more then the firt time As oon as Alexis aw him, and not knowing the reaon why he did not follow them: How now ervant, (aid he) What makes you tay here, whilt we have been viewing the raret place in all the Country? Mitree, anwered he, my intention was to make you more deire the ight of me, in being a little deprived of it: That needed not, anwered he, for I cannot deire it more then I doe: If you had, replyed Hylas, you would have tayed here with me, and not have preferred your curioity of viewing a woody Grove before your contentment in being with Hylus. I had thought, aid Alexis and miled, that my ervant had been more religiouly devoted unto thee acred Groves, and had been the firt that would offer himelfe at the Altars; o as thinking him gone before me, I went after to eek him. You aw me when you entred in as I did you, aid Hylas; and if your affection to me had been equall unto mine to you, you would have tayed behind them. Good Servant, aid Alexis, may I not as well tax your affection in not following me, for I hould willingly have tayed behind, had I known your intention of doing o? Nay, nay, anwered Hylas, this is but an excue, you might well ee that the God of this place was not pleaed I hould enter, if you had looked upon the incription over the door: Then Alexis eeming not to ee it before, looked up, and found written, That no prophane perons who were not inpired with a contant love, hould not enter into that acred place. And what of all this, aid Alexis? his meaning is, aid Silvander, That ince he is not inpired with a contant love, he dares not et his foot into the acred place, let he hould prophane it; and in this, Madam, he hewes himelfe more religious then a perfect lover Servant, (aid Alexis) Is this true which Silvander aith? Mitree, anwered Hylas, Do you deire I hould love you? Yes, aid Alexis, with all my heart. Then, aid he, Lend not any eare unto any uch owers of edition in love as Silvander. Then turning towards him, Do you think Silvander, aid he, that I did not enter into this acred Grove, becaue I was no perfect lover, as well as religious? What ele would you have me thinke? aid Silvander; I think you were afraid of punihment, and therefore
durt not enter now, no more then the firt time we came unto it; I will not deny, anwered Hylas, but that I do tand in fear of angering the Gods, and let me tell you, th •
this my feare is more commendable then your arrogance: For is there any who have not a Tincture of ome humane imperfections? Ah my good friend, Dot thou thinke thy elfe unullied? and therefore how <> you be o imp •• ent as to et •
<> in this forbidden place? I confee my elfe, aid Silvander, ubject unto humane imperfections, but am not o groly follied with them as ome men are: I know thou it <…>
company without common imperfections, and yet for all then they <…> into this acred place; ince the condition of their entrance is, that there be no fault in their love: Now I • m mot certaine there is none in mine, for I had rather die a thouand deaths then uffer the let tain of imperfection in it.

A very fine fancy, believe it, aid Hylas; Good Silvander, tell me if there be any uch pure pieces in the world as you doe imagine your elfe? and if there be any, pray tell me where they are? You may very well ask where they are (aid Silvander) for I doe believe you know not any, though there be many in this place? Pray tell me? What doe you take Phillis to be? She aid Hylas, is too merry. What then, of Atrea aid Silvander: She, anwered Hylas, in too ad. What then of Diana? aid Silvander: he, replyed he, is too wie. What do you ay unto Alexis? aid he: She, aid Hylas, knows too much. L •• nide (continued Silvander) he aid Hylas knows too much, <>
too little, What faultin Celidea, aid Silvander: Her virtue replyed he • is <> unto me. What do you ay of Florice? aid Silvander; That fine has a jealous <> , answered he: What of Palanice, replyed Silvender She, aid Hylas, does too oon believe that he is loved: Of <> aid Silvander: She, aid Hylas, is ••• oluto: What fault in Carlis? aid Silvander: She loved me too much, anwered he What do you think of Stilliana? aid Silvander; She is too ubtile, aid Hylas: What of D •• phnide, continued Silvander; That he has lot him, anwered Hylas, who would have made her eteemed more faire: What do you ay o •
L • anies? aid Silvander. I ay, replyed Hylas, that I do not love her: And of Ma •••• he, aid the hepherd; She, anwered he, is too like Diana. Oh Heavens (aid Silvander •
) Can I propoe none in whom you will find no fault? You have forgotten one hepherdee amongt us (aid Diana) and that is Stella. Very true indeed, aid Silvander; what do you ay of her? I mut confee (aid Hylas then) that if he continue pleaing me, as well as he hath done this morning, I think that I hall find her according to my own mind. How, how? ervants aid Alex • s preently, will you quit me for her? Hylas, after he had thought a little b ••
ter with himelfe, anwered very faintly: No, no, Mitree, I would not quit you, but I hope I may let you have ome company Why, replyed Alexis, cannot you content your elfe with me? Fie, fie, I mut needs complain of you to all the world. <> you are too blame, anwered Hylas; for have you not alwayes told me, that our loves hould be equall: Mot true, replyed Alexis: Then, replyed he, if it be equall, you hould let me love another beides your elfe, ince you doe the ame. Whom do you ee me love, aid he, beides your elf? Whom? aid Hylas What <> you doing all the day upon this Country wench, called Atren? Oh ervant aid Alexis, he is a woman •
Well then, aid Hylas, may not I alo love a woman? Servant, aid Alexis, if you were a woman as I am, it were then allowable to love a woman; but ince you are not, I have great reaon to be jealous. I beeech you, Mitree, aid Hylas, let <> law be equall betwixt us: No, aid he, I can never conent unto o much wrong to my elf And believe in, Mitree (aid Hylas) I will not loe any of my priviledges. I pe •• cive (aid Diana) there is like to be a divorce betwixt you: For my part, aid Atrea, I hall be <> ga ••
ner by it, which way oever it be; for if they do break off, I hall poee that <>
one to my elfe alone; and if they doe not, yet ince he <>
Hylas to love Sre •• a, I hall have the more opportunities of talking with her, whilt he is entertaining his new Mitree: And for my part, aid Hylas, I hall be alo a ga •• er By it; for if we be divorced, then I hall be free, and if we continue, then I hall have <…> to love me <…> of one. I perceive, aid Alexis, that the loe will be onely <> For if Hylas doe ceae loving me, I hall loe the friendhip of a peron whom I value an a high rate of eteem: and if he do till love me with a condition of loving another I hall have but one half of a ervant, whilt Stella has the other
<> as which way oever the wind blow, it will be againt me: But ervant, is there no meanes to make you <> , and <>
Stella from
having a hare? Alexis poke this in uch a reenting manner, as one would have thought her in good earnet. Hylas, whoe contancy could not continue any longer, and fearing to offend againt his old principles: Mitree, aid he, I cannot continue any longer upon uncertaine terms; you mut either leave Atrea, or let me take in Stella, or ele break all off; our Market is quite done, for I am a Merchant at a word; your own law of equality obliges me unto it. Do what Alexis could, he could not chue but laugh at the dicoure of Hylas, and taying long before he anwered; What? aid he, are you laughing in lieu of an anwer? Truly ervant (aid Alexis) I mut tell you truly, I had rather be alone, then to have ill company: It is in your choice, Mitree, replyed Hylas: Well ervant, aid he, ince I ee you are a merchant o punctuall to your word, I will believe you are reolved to quit me: Stella hearing her elfe named, came in, and knowing that it was of her whom Hylas poke; Madam, aid he unto Alexis, if you will but pleae to let Hylas erve me, it will redound unto your advantage; for when he finds my unworthinee, he will more eteem your merit. Kind hepherdee, anwered Alexis, I rather feare the contrary; for when Silvander asked him what faults he found in me, he found ome, but in you none. Nay rather, anwered Stella, he found o many as he could not name them all. No, no, (aid Alexis) Love ueth to blind the eyes of all thoe who love well. Come, come, aid Hylas, to what purpoe is all this talk? Mitree (aid he) are you reolved; I pay tell me, for I cannot tay any longer. Alexis, who began to be weary of him, becaue he often interrupted her dicoure with Atrea, he anwered thus; Servant, we Druids ue not to be o haty as others; for we ue to conult with the Oracle in all our affaires. But Mitree, aid Hylas, do you never any thing without the leave of the Oracle? Nothing, aid he. If as a reward of my erving you ome moneths (aid Hylas) I hould ask you a kie, would you conult with the Oracle about it? Servant, replyed Alexis and laughed, we never ue to aske leave of the Oracle for uch things, for we know that we ought not to do it. How, how, aid Hylas, not after a long ervice, allowed one kie? No, replyed the Druid. What hopes then is there, aid Hylas, in erving you any longer? The contentment, aid he, in loving and erving me. Contentment, aid Hylas, I take no delight in uch a journey, as will not bear its own Charges: Well Servant, aid the Druid, I perceive you intend to leave me, and I will not tay you. Methinks, aid he, that o many ervices as you have received from me, may very well permit me to kie your hand at parting. Although (aid Alexis) I am very orry to part from you; and though the trict Lawes of the Druids do in ome ort forbid it, yet Hylas for a parting blow, I will permit you a kis of my hand. Upon this, Hylas kneeled down, and aid, I receive this favour in tetimony that I eteemed Alexis the mot perfect in the quality of a Druid that ever was; and having kied her hand, he ran to Stella, and taking her hand, Unto you faire hepherdee (aid he) do I come and offer all thoe favours which I obtained from thoe I loved; and that you may not thinke me very poor, receive in the firt place this kis which this faire Druid hath given me. If you have no others, aid Silvander that are greater then this, I believe, Hylas, you have not many to brag of. Why? anwered Hylas, Do not you eteem it a favour which Alexis hath done me? I think it, aid Silvander, rather a Ranome then a favour. What Ranome doe your mean? (aid Hylas) I mean (aid Silvander) that this fair and wie Druid, rather then be any longer troubled with you did free and ranome her elfe from you, by permitting you that kie of her hand. I do believe, aid Hylas that you are much mitaken: but I know Silvander, that you have been long my enemy, and I will not believe any thing you ay, no more then I deire you hould believe any thing I ay againt you But fair hepherdee, I beeech you believe not a word from this hepherd, for if you doe, I am ure we hall not long love each other. Stella who was not ignorant of the humour of Hylas, nor much dipleaed with it: Now ervant, aid he, I am o well acquainted with Silvander, that you need not ay any more concerning him: But pray tell me? are you in good earnet my ervant? How? replyed Hylas, Do you think I diemble as the hepherds of Lignon ue? No; no, be pleaed to know that my heart is in my tongue, and all my words are true: do you not ee that I have let loving Alexis, as I told her I would. I hall believe all you have aid, replyed the hepherdee, and more if need be; and therefore I deire you would do as much for me in what I hall ay; And to the end we may live contentedly together, I deire that Articles of agreement may be drawn betwixt us, which will oblige us to the obervance of them, and which we will call the Laws of Love.
And for our better remembrance of them, I deire they may be put in writing, before we make a full concluion. My future Mitree, aid Hylas, for o I will call you untill our conditions beet down in black and white; I doe foreee o much contentment in our future amity, that I will not delay it a jot longer: I think I have an Inkhorn in my pocket, and as for Paper, I hope to find ome alo ome way or other. All the company who heard this new way of loving, could not chue but laugh, and were o deirous to ee the conditions, as they every one began to look for ome Paper, and a piece being found, Hylas himelfe would needs be the Secretary; But Stella aid, that it was more reaon it hould be he, becaue it was he that firt made the Propoition. At lat, after a long dipute, Hylas agreed that he hould dictate unto him, and both parties hould conent unto every Article: But till Stella feared that Hylas would not et down according to her Dictates, and Hylas feared the like of her, o as they durt not trut each other.

This dipute could not be without abundance of delight to the company; and becaue Atrea aw her dear Druid laugh heartily at the buinee, he told Silvander that he might do very well to be the Secretary unto them both. I hould willingly undertake the office, fair hepherdee (aid he) if that true and perfect affection which I beare unto Diana, could uffer my hand to write things o contrary to the fidelity and purity of my love; and truly I had rather die, than any uch conditions hould ever be een under the hand of Silvander. Nay, nay, crupulous Lover, aid Hylas, never trouble your elfe for an excue, I will ave you the labour of it; For the true love which is to be betwixt this hepherdee and me, cannot endure that any one of o different an humour, hould ever be Secretary unto our Ordinances. Corilas who heard all this dicoure, and was extreamly deirous to ee Hylas and Stella linked together ince never two was more like. Hylas, aid he, Pray put the office upon me, and I promie to write jut as it is agreed upon betwixt you; unto which both conenting, he at down and writ thee enuing Articles, as they agreed upon them.

div.head: The twelve Articles and Conditions upon which Stella and Hylas doe promie to love each other for the future.
div.p: EXperience being that which makes perons the mot prudent, and hewes them wayes to avoid inconveniencies, wherein we have een many ruined; and eeing by the everall events which we have oberved amongt Lovers, that mot of their dientions and bitter quarrells have proceeded onely from that Tyranny, which the one would exercie over the other. We Stella and Hylas, to avoid all thoe inconveniencies are agreed upon thee Articles and conditions following.
That the one hall not uurp over the other, that overaigne authority which may truly be called Tyranny.
That both of us hall be at one and the ame time, both the lover and the loved.
That our affection hall be eternally without contraint.
That we hall love one another as long as we pleae.
That the party who would ceae loving, may doe o without any brand of infidelity
That without any breach of Amity, we may love whom we pleae, without asking any leave.
That jealouie, complaints and teares, and all uch pulings be banihed from amongt us, as things incompatible with our perfect amitie.
That we hall be free in our converation, and both of us ay and do what they pleae without any offence unto either.
That to avoid being lyers and laves, either in word or deed; all thee termes of fidelity, ervice, and eternal affection, be never o much as named betwixt us in our dicoure.
That we may both of us, or ele one without the other, continue or ceae loving one another.
That if this Amity doe ceae on one ide or of both, we may renew it when we pleae.
That, let we hould be tyed unto a long love, or a long hatred, we be obliged to forget, both favours and injuries.

Thee Articles being thus written; Well Hylas, aid Stella, doe thee conditions pleae you? Do they pleae you? aid Hylas. Who I? replyed the hepherdee; I would never have uffered them to be written, had I not thought them mot jut and reaonable. If the cae were mine, aid Silvander, I would add one Article more, What is that (aid Hylas) It is, replyed Silvander; That wh • n you hall pleae you may break any one of conditions which you have written, for otherwie you contradict your own intentions, becaue you aim is to love without any contraint; Now if you be obliged to oberve what you have writ, are you not contrained to follow what you have writ? • protet, my dear future Mitree (aid Hylas, after he had better thought upon it) this hepherd does not peak without reaon. Why? my future Servant aid Stella, will you change your opinion upon the advice of Silvander? Silvander, I ay, whom you have publihed to be your pro • eed enemy: I do not think it any hame (aid Hylas) to take any counell which I think to be good: It is a Maxime I have ever followed, That none o bl • nd as they that will not ee: As for Silvanders being my enemy, I doe confee it; But is there any thing more venemous then a Toad? and yet it is ued in Phyick. Wie men will gather ome good from their very enemies, and o may I from Silvander. But let us conider whether his advice be good or bad; for my part, I have ever lived in a perfect and abolute
liberty; and it would vex me to the oul, that a bit of cribled Paper hould tie me to alter my way of life, which I hould be if I hould ubribe unto thee Articles; for all manner of obligations are contraints, unlee Silvanders condition he included. For my part, aid Stella, I am contented it hould be added, for my liberty is as weet unto me, as yours can be to you: but becaue I am afraid let there be ome hidden ubtilty in his words, I would have them written as a condition added by Silvander: I revoke that, aid Silvander, for I will not be mentioned in your conditions, neither as advier, nor as witnee. You cannot chue, aid Hylas, but be both; for every one ees you are a witnee of what we have done; and every one hears that we add this thirteenth condition unto the ret by your advice. All the company did fall into uch a laughter, that the noie reached unto Daphnide and Alcidon, who were talking with Adamas: and they out of curioity to know what the matter was, came out and asked Silvander what was the caue of their laughter; he anwered, that Hylas and Stella offered him wrong, which he had rather uffer death than endure. Then he related unto them all the paage, and hewed them the writing which was approved of by both ides And I advied them, aid he, to add another Article, that either of them might break any of thee Articles when they pleaed; they will needs add this Article unto their own, under the name of Silvander. The reverend Druid, Daphnide, and Alcid • n could not forbear laughing at thee fine conditions, and alo to ee Silvander o angry his name hould be ued in uch a contract; but the more Silvander refued, the more earnet was Hylas and Stella to have it o Then Adamas began to peak; Children aid he unto them, Are you contented that I hould decide the difference? For my part (aid Hylas) I give conent both for Stella and my elf And for my part, aid Silvander, I do not only conent, but beeech him unto it. Tell me then, Hylas, aid the Druid, Why you would have Silvander to be inerted both a witnes and author of that Article; becaue (aid Hylas) I am • a lover of truth, and cannot abide ingratitude Now the very truth is he is a witnee of the Conditions betwixt Stella and me, and gave us the advice unto it, o as we hould be ungratefull if we did not acknowledge it to proceed from him. And you Silvander (aid Adamas) what can your object to the contrary: I ay, anwered Silvander that though I was preent, yet I would not be a witnee, and in reaon I ought not to be contrained unto it. For is not the Great Tautates witnee enough for all, and of all? and yet when any evill act is committed, do they ue him for a witnes? And why not? aid Hylas; becaue, anwered Silvander, he is to be judge and punih all wickednee; and upon the ame reaon I cannot be a witnes. But you, aid Hylas, are not to be our judge, for we have caue enough to except againt your judgement. Though I mut not be your judge, aid Silvander, yet I may be your Accuer, which I cannot be if I am a witnee. And as for the ingratitude of which you peak, it will be much greater, if you hould o extreamly againt my will, publih that which I deire hould be concealed; and I hould take the very concealment for a ufficient recompence. Then the reverend Druid, after he had heard the reaons on both ides, he gave this entence. Children, aid he, upon erious conideration of your difference, I conceive that th • e Conditions of your future Amity, being for the conervation of that liberty which you pretend to enjoy; there is no reaon you hould take that liberty from another, nor by compulion oblige any againt their wills. But becaue you have thought this Article worthy to be added unto the ret, I doe ordain, that it hall be written down amongt the others, in this manner.

div.head: The thirteenth and lat Article,
div.p: Added by advice and counell unto the Conditions upon which Hylas and Stella doe promie to love for the future, and which they do wear to oberve mot religiouly.

That notwithtanding all the aforeaid Articles; we Stella and Hylas, are o tender of our liberty, and o much enemies unto all manner of contraint, that it hall be lawful for us, whenoever we pleae, not to oberve any one of thee Conditions here above written and agreed upon.

Thus was the difference ended by the age Adamas, unto the contentment of all parties:
Corilas, eeing Hylas and Stella, was beyond all meaure joyfull. Now Stella, aid he, thou art fitted in thy humour; and Hylas might have, earched all the world over, before he found one o fit unto his: I mut needs acknowledge the heavens mot jut in preerving them for each other, and linking them together in a mutual affection.

Hylas and Stella began to love one another in this manner; at the firt but a little, and after in jeat, but at lat it grew to be in good earnet: For Stella was a very fine and pleaant hepherdee, and one of a quick and prightly wit: Hylas on the other ide, was as good and jocund company as could be imagined, and thee conditions o utable both in Servant and Mitree, that there was nothing dilikeable in each to the other; o as living together in great freedom, they did by little and little, conceive uch affection the one to the other, as they met not with any that pleaed them better.

But Dinner being ready, and the Table pred under a hady Tree, as near the Fountain as the conveniency of the place would permit, all the company at down. The Vaices, Bardes, Sarronides, Eubages, and Druids, did it at a Table by themelves, where they did eat what was their due of the acrifice; But Adamas, to render the more honour unto Daphnide and Alcidon, did dine with them, and the bet of the hepherdees and hepherds. As long as dinner lated, the dicoure was all upon the Rarities of the place, and of the anctity of that acred Grove. But Dinner being done, and the un too hot to tir from under the hade, Adamas thought how to pae away the time in the bet diverions; and remembring the judgement which Diana was to give 'twixt Silvander & Phillis, he thought both the time and the occaion very fit for that purpoe; and the rather, becaue Daphnide who tayed in the Country onely to be acquainted with the weet lives of thee hepherdees and hepherds, would be very glad to hear this difference argued and what judgement Diana would give upon it. He went unto Atrea and Phillis, and having acquainted them with his deign, he deired them to joyn with him in obtaining Dianas conent unto it. Believe it, Sir, anwered Atrea, there will not need much olicitation; for I know that he has deferred it o long, onely becaue he wanted the preence of the Nymph Leonide, who ince he was at the beginning of that contet, he thought it fit he hould be alo at the end of it. I feare, if Silvander know of your intention, he will break off company. Phillis, who thought the Druids Propoition very reaonable, and beides was weary in imploying any time, but in the entertainment of her dearly beloved Licydas, which was omething hindred by her Courthip of Diana. No, no, iter, aid he, we mut urprie our enemy when he leat thinks of us; then addreing her elfe unto Diana, Mitres (aid he in a loud voice) This company deires you would be pleaed to come hither, and hearken no longer unto the dicoure of him who is talking with you; for I aure my elfe, he peaks nothing unto my advantage. Silvander was he who was talking with her in the abence of Paris, when Phillis thus interrupted him; at which being very angry, Oh Phillis (aid he) you are an evill pirit which continually torments me, and at this time interrupts my happinee. Your happinee, replyed Phillis, will quickly be at an end, and my upream fellcity begin: For, Mitres, (aid he, and addreed her elfe unto Diana) you are entreated by all this good company, to give judgement upon the merits of Silvanders ervice and mine. Diana was a little urpried at this; for though it was her intention to give judgement ere long, yet he did foreee that after it, he could not allow any longer of Silvanders addrees of love unto her. But the urprie of the hepherd was much greater; for he aw there was no poibility of delaying it any longer, and then the fiction of his wager, which was the cloak for his, reall affection would be taken from him, and he hould be no longer permitted to make his amorous addrees unto his adored hepherdee. Thee coniderations made them both ilent for a while, which Phillis oberving; Mitree, (aid he) I beeech you anwer me; I am afraid you are loath to confe • that glory upon me by your judgement, which you cannot deny unto my ervices: or perhaps you are afraid of loing that hepherd, and unwilling to be exempt from his importunities. Then Diana, left he hould let her dicontent appear, did mile, and anwer thus; I know not what glory you can pretend unto by your ervices, ince you doe thus publiquely upbraid me with them; nor doe I know why you hould phrae the ervices of Silvander to be importunities more then your own, ince both do proceed from the ame caue. Silvander kneeled down, and humbly thanked Diana for that favourable anwer. Afterwards, riing up, Mitres, aid he
unto her, This hepherdee not knowing how to love, and finding that the longer he continues, the more defects he hould hew in her affection; he would not be put to any further Tet of it, but deires an end of that which he cannot prolong any longer. For, Phillis, aid he, and turned towards her, why ele hould you peak thus unto our Mitree? Your ervices wherewith you upbraid her, are o mall that the reward of them mut needs be accordingly; and her feares which you mention of loing me mut needs be lee, ince mot auredly as long as I live he hall never loe me. Even thus, replyed Phillis, does all faint-hearted Souldiers fly all occaions of any danger: but I on the contrary, dare look the grimmet dangers boldly in the face, and give tetimony of my courage: Why good Silvander, do you hrink like a coward from the hazard of that judgement which is to be the touch-tone of our merits? And what other excues than thoe I have named, can Diana have for her retarding it any longer? I am afraid, anwered Diana, that your rutick dicoure will be troubleome to the aembly, epecially unto the faire Daphnide, and the valiant Alcidon, who being ued to more high and noble ubjects, will think Country patimes very tedious; and becaue Diana would have continued her excues, No, no, dicreet hepherdee, you are mitaken, aid Adamas, Daphnide and Alcidon, are now become hepherds of Lignon, having aumed the ame habits, and will conform themelves unto us; and you mut thinke, that as they know how to behave themelves in their own high qualities; o they can as well condecend, and uit their minds unto the humble innocency of your lives: and therefore I did make this Propoition, to the end that by your judgement, this new hepherd and fair hepherdee may ee and learn how to behave themelves after our Country mode and the rather, becaue the Sun does hine o hot, that we cannot yet go into the great Meadow where the hepherds ue to perform their accutomed exercies after the acrifice: and therefore the time cannot be better imployed, then to heare the difference betweene Silvander and Phillis argued and judged. I know, reverend Father, aid Diana, that nothing can proceed from you but what is grounded upon great reaon, and we are all obliged unto whatoever you hall command; and therefore without more adoe, I will doe whatoever you hall pleae; onely I beeech Daphnide and Alcidon, to look upon the implicity of our trifles with a favourable eye, and attribute them unto that obedience which we are all obliged to render both unto you and them. Fair hepherdes (anwered Daphnide) all that I have hitherto een amongt you, has filled me with o much contentment and admiration, that you need not doubt but all your patimes will be very pleaing unto me. Then the Reverend Druid commanded, that eats hould be et in a round circle, and one higher then the ret for Diana, againt the back of a Tree, whoe branches doe overhade the Circle. And when all were placed according to his deire, he caued three Garlands to be made of Flowers, and put one upon the head of Diana another upon the head of Phillis, and the third upon the head of Silvander; Afterwards taking Diana by the hand, he placed her in her ea • of Judgement; before her, a little on the right hand, he placed Phillis, and a little on the left hand, Silvander; and after ilence deired, he appointed Leonide to make known unto thee trangers, the beginning of the dipute betwixt Phillis and Silvander, to the end they might better judge of the difference: thinking it fit and reaonable that Leonide hould be the relater, becaue he was partly the caue of it. Leonide, who little thought of being more then an Auditor in this aembly, was a little urpried to ee her elfe an Orator; but in obedience to the Druid he undertook it, and after he had a little recollected her memory, he turned towards Daphnide, and began thus.

Perhaps Madam, you have oberved, that Silvander and Phillis called Diana their Mitree, and have been as officious and ready to erve her as hepherds could be; I believe you will think it trange, that o fair and amiable a hepherdes as Diana is, hould be o free in the entertainment of that hepherd: I believe alo, you wonder that Phillis who is a hepherdee, hould court her as if he were a hepherd, and ue the ame expreions and behaviour of a mot paionate lover: for it is not uual to ee a woman o aiduous and courtly unto another woman. But to atisfie your wonder, Madam, be pleaed to know, That Silvander lived long amongt thee fair, young, and lovely hepherdees, yet never was in love with any; inomuch as he got the Name of the inenible hepherd. None of all thee young beauties having power enough to kindle the leat flame in his heart.
Phillis admiring that a hepherd o young and hanome, hould live o long near uch beauties, and never hew the let park of any heat, he could not chue but enter into ome interrogatories with him; faigning to believe that the reaon why he did not undertake to erve ome one or other, was either want of courage, or ele conciounee of his owne imperfections and want of merit: And becaue the hepherd whoe delight was all hunting, and looking to his flock, maintained the contrary, and aid that the reaon why he did not love, was onely becaue he had better imployment. Atrea, Diana, and I, being preent, we condemned him, to give us ome good tetimonie, that the reaon why he did not love any, was not as Phillis had alleadged: And Diana being a hepherdes both of beauty and and judgement, fit to judge of his merit, he was propoed to be as it were his Mitree, and he was to court her under that Notion, unlee he wanted the courage to undertake it Upon this he began to erve her, and court her as cloe as if he had been really in love: Phillis was not exempt from the ame task, he was alo condemned to love and erve Diana with all the paion that hepherds ue unto thoe whom they doe paionately love; and at the end of three moneths Diana was to judge which of them two knew bet how to love.
