Ever ince, there has been uch an emulation betwixt this hepherd and that hepherdee, that they have neglected no manner of behaviour or expreion which could manifet a mot ervent and real affection: And though the prefixed term of three moneths be expired, during which time they were to demontrate their merits unto Diana; yet their addrees unto her has continued longer becaue it was thought reaonable, that as I was at the firt condemnation unto that task, o I hould be preent at the judgement which Diana was to give; o as it eems the heavens did prolong it untill now, to the end this judgement might be given with more olemnity in your preence.

Thus ended the Nymph Leonide; and then Daphnide began to peak: I mut needs confee, aid he, and turned towards Adamas, that it was not without ome wonder, I hould ee Phillis court Diana with the very expreions of a man: But now, changing my wonder into envy, I mut needs tell you, Father, That I never did envy the happines of any o much as yours; for heaven has exempted you from the inquietudes of wordly affaires, to live in this weet and harmles tranquillity. Infinitely happy you are in all repects: happy are you in this Country of Forrets; happy in being obeyed and loved as a great Druid; but much more happy in being o near a Neighbour unto the pleaant bankes of Lignon, which is furnihed with more accomplihed hepherds and beautifull hepherdees, then ever bore the Name. Madam, anwered Adamas, I acknowledge all you ay, and do profes, that I would not change my happinee with the greatet Monarch upon earth; having nothing to pray for from the Great Tautates, but onely that it may continue for many yeares. As for the commends you are pleaed to betow upon our hepherds and hepherdees, I am aured that they will not receive them without bluhes, though they will take any thing well which proceeds from you. But Madam (aid he) as you have heard the caue of their courthip, will it pleae you to hear their judgement? With much contentment, aid Daphnide; Then the Druid turning towards Phillis, It was you, hepherdes, (aid he) who firt provoked Silvander unto Combate, and therefore it is reaon you hould alo be the firt who hall produce your Reaons and Arguments why the victory hould be yours.

div.head: The Speech of the hepherdes Phillis.
div.p:
I Did not think, Mitres, that amongt all the hepherds in this Country, epecially about Lignon, any one would have been found o full of vanity, as to think himelfe worthy of the eteem and love of a hepherdee o full of merit as Diana: Diana I ay, the mot exactly accomplihed, and mot perfect beauty that ever bore the name of hepherdee. And yet, fairet Mitree, you ee this man, this arrogant man tand before you in a poture of Love, and his head crowned with a Chaplet of Flowers, as if he had already got the victory, which he mot unjutly pretends unto. But hepherd, I pray tell me, from whence proceeds this rah preumption? and what pretended reaons can you poibly have? Thy hopes cannot be grounded upon thy own hallow merits, when thou dot but look upon the perfections of Diana; for they are uch as holding no proportion with thine, love cannot be produced by things o farre unequall. I am confident thy own impudence cannot be o braz • n-fac'd as to deny the truth of this; but thy own oul mut needs tell thee, that there is nothing in thee which can equall her perfections. How durt thou be o arrogant and rah, as dare to love her? But as this is high impudence; yet methinks that to pretend unto her love againe, is much more extream. But Silvander, what colour cant thou have for this thy fond pretenion? what hould make thee think of obtaining her love before me? Thou cant not deny, but every thing is naturally inclined to love its like; and I being a woman, as our Mitres is, certainly he mut needs naturally love me more then thee. But beides this; what will caue love ooner then long acquaintance and continuall convere? By it, perfections come to be better known; and by it, merits being better known, love mut needs take better and deeper root; and by it, occaions doe preent themelves every minute to render reciprocall amity and devoires, which are the very Nures of a true and reall affection. Now thou cant not deny, but that I have had a longer and more intimate acquaintance with her then thou hat, he her elfe knowes it, and is able to contradict thee if thou dot deny it. But hould I wave all thee Reaons, yet I have one which will put thee to ilence at the leat, unlee thou bee't impudence it elf. You mut of neceity acknowledge, that • whatoever is mot faire and perfect, is alo mot amiable, and to be mot eteemed; then hepherd your caue is quite ruined; for our ex, being much more perfect then that of men, thou art driven to confee that I ought to be loved before thee. But wave all thee coniderations again: can counterfeiting, lying, and diembling, ever caue love? Do you think that the faire Diana does not know that all thy addrees, all thy ervices, and all that affection which thou trainet thy elfe to make appear unto her, is onely in repect of that wager which is betwixt us? and proceeds only from a deire thou hat to overcome me, and not from her beauty or wit? Methinks I heare the anwer already, that it is true, and that this reaon might not be alleadged againt me, ince the wager is reciprocall, and all the demontrations of affection which I make, may have the ame fault. But hepherd, you are mitaken, for I loved her long before our contet began, and I am ure he loved me, which is more then thou cant ay, ince all thou didt was onely to come amongt us, and never look upon hepherdee in way of love, nor I believe, hadt thou o much confidence as to dare it. But peak the truth, Silvande, and confee that before this wager, thou didt not dicern any difference betwixt Diana's face and mine, or any other hepherdee of Lignon? And dot thou not thinke that all thee extream paions which thou dot counterfeit in thy dicoure, all thee languihings, raptures, tranports, and follies, does rather invite one to laughter then to love? This man • Mitres, that is all in flame and rapture, that does o Idolize your beauty at every word, and that is ready to die with uperabundant love: This is the man, that a minute before our wager began, did hardly know whether uch a one as Diana lived; or at mot, had no deeper knowledge of you then what your name gave him: And yet he can at a minutes warning, be all in a flame, all affection all love, all yours; will not uch folly as this move more laughter then affection? But admit that your beauty has kindled ome parkes of love in him: Is it not my elfe unto whom all the recompence is due? ince it was onely I that am the caue of it? It is mot certaine, and Mitree you know it, that, if I had not upbraided him,
the wager had never been made; and if it had not, he had never been o bold and confident as ever to look upon you: o as if he will pretend unto any favour from you, for any ervices which he hath done unto you ince that time, is he not obliged unto me for it, for making him what he is? It is I then who in all reaon may pretend unto any merits that are in him, • ince all his devices, and all his actions which made him amiable in your eye, ought to be put upon my account, and teckoned unto my advantage Ceae then hepherd contending with me, for a thing which thou knowet to be my due; prevent that judgement which thou cant not avoid, conent that the glory hall be given unto me, which my Fortune, my Quality, and my merits have given unto me before thee; which if thou dot, thou wilt make thy elfe appeare to be a man of wit, and of judgement: Thy wit, in knowing o well how to diguie a • alfe affection, under a vizard of reall love: and thy judgement, in acknowledging and eeing the great advantages which I have above thee. But if thus thou wilt not doe, then expect the due punihment for thy arrogance, and doe not think to deferre the jut judgement of our Mitree, by tedious and frivloous anwers: And becaue I will be a good manager of time, and haten to receive that Glory which he will confer upon me, I will wave and omit many other reaons and arguments which I could alledge, and refer the whole matter unto the wie conideration of our fairet Mitree; auring my elfe that he is better able to dicern, then I am • able to peak my mot jut pretenions, which are as clear as the Sun in the fairet day: onely Mitree, I deire you to conider this: That Silvander does not onely make himelfe hateable by his fictions and diimulations, but alo drawes an odium upon all other men, and makes all their Courthips and expreions of affection and idelity upected; o as his crime is of o high a nature, as he cannot expect any thing but punihment from a evere but jut judge. But, faire and wie Mitree, I refer my jut caue, and his counterfeit Gloes, unto your wie and jut cenure.

Upon this, Phillis making an humble reverence unto Diana, and the ret of the company, he et her elfe down, cating a miling eye upon Silvander, who being commanded to peak for himelfe, went unto Diana, kneeled down, and laid his Chaplet of Flowers at her feet; Then returning to his place againe, he began to peak thus.

div.head: The Anwer of the hepherd Silvander.
div.p:
WEre I not before the Temple of Atrea, who is the Goddee of Jutice, and had •
a wore Judge then Diana, who is the intimate friend of the other Atrea, I hould feare the micarriage of my caue, and tremble at the enuing judgement: Not that I am at all tartled by the ophiticated language of this hepherdee, and any of her gloed arguments he has urged againt me, though I mut needs ay, he has very cunningly contrived the matter, but my greatet feares proceed from a more valid conideration, for the dipate betwixt us, is grounded only upon this point, which of us two can bet win the love of the faire Diana, whom we have choen to be the Center in which all our ervices, and all our affections ought to meet. • his is the point which we both aim at, and which is o hard to be approached, as I hold it almot impoible, if it did not pleae the Great Tautates to hew himelfe as well a Tharam • s in purifying my love and clening it from all imperfections which might make it unworthy to be offered unto this a • e Diana, as he makes himelfe appear a Heus, which is as much to ay as puiant, in making her o fair and perfect, as no mortall is able to equall her either in beauty or perfection.

Perhaps Mitree, you may wonder, that being in this acred place, dedicated unto the Goddee of Jutice I dare pretend unto a favourable judgement, ince I am deficient in this main point. But oh my jut Judge, I beeech you heare upon what bais I ground my jut pretenion. It is the propriety of Jutice, not alone to judge trictly according to the Lawes which are given us; but alo, after he has conidered the true tate of every thing, to etablih with equity the Law of Nature, which is; that he who does all he can, is not oblig'd unto any more and though he do not reach o high as is neceary, yet is ought not to be imputed a fault in him, but rather attribute it unto the Ordinances of Nature, who was pleaed to etablih it o: And he is o far from being blameable for failing in uch a cae, as he is to be much eteemed, that can arrive at o high a point as no other of his kind can go beyond him, and as very few can arrive at: And therefore fairet Mitree, why hould I fear to preent my elfe before the Throne of this jut Atrea's friend, although I can never attaine unto that height of perfection which is requiite in any that pretend unto Dianas love; for my affection is arrived to as high a point, as any other can reach, and higher then any lover will ever attain unto.

Why then, injurious Phillis, to fortifie your weak pretenions, hould you without any reaon blame me, ince I cannot love with more adoration then I do: It is not my fault, but Natures, who gave me no greater capacity, if I do not love her to the height of her merit: but I cannot complain, ince the ame law is common unto all mortals, none being able to doe it more then my elfe: But wie nature would have it o, and perhaps purpoely to manifet the high beauty of Diana, who contraines me to love her, an Act far above all humane force, or power to doe, and againt the rule of equality, which Phillis you propoe to be in them who love.

Then hepherdee, were you not jealous of Dianas Glory, you would not blame me for loving her, nor tax me with arrogance, ince it is the force of her beauty which contraines me, and ince by this, the grandure of her perfections are more evidently een. Aks me no more, I beeech you, how I durt love her: for though I doe acknowledge my elfe as unworthy as your elf is, yet I cannot chue but be the mot lot man in love that ever was.

But in asking me from whence proceeds my rah pretenions unto her love, and therein calls me the monter of Arrogance and preumption; you doe plainly make it appear, that you doe not know what it is to love, nor what effects Love ueth to produce. You have often confeed unto me, that love in it elfe is good, and I thinke you will not now ay the contrary, your ilence makes <> believe your conent unto it; and truly otherwie you would <…> reaon: For if every thing produce its like, that love which proceeds from th •
•••• ledge of any faire and good thing, mut needs be faire and
good it elfe: And that which is faire and good, cannot be een and known, but it mut needs be loved: I cannot think you o out of all reaon, but that you will confee that I hall convince you out of your own words. Bea • ty, ay you, has uch powerfull attracts, as it doth often dim the eyes of thoe who behold it, and makes their deires go beyond all reaon. If then that which is faire and good cannot be een, but it mut be loved, and if love be fair and good; why doe you call that Arrogance in me, which is reaonable in another? Why hould you ay my pretenions to obtaine her love, are rah? For love being good, and he knowing my love; how can he know it, but he mut needs love it? if he did not, it would argue a defect in her judgement which I thinke none, except your elfe, will offer to imagine. Confee therefore, Phillis unlee you will extreamly wrong her, that knowing my love, he does love me; and that my pretenion is not o nighly impudent, nor I uch a deformed monter, as you would decribe me: If you object, that this does not prove her love unto me, but onely my love unto her. I anwer, hepherdee, That the love which her beauty produceth in me, is an ineparable accident of my oule, o as the one cannot ubit without the other: And hould I ay, that they are o incorporated the one into the other, that my oul is this love, and this love is my onle, I hould peak a mot certain truth: For it is not more true, that I cannot live without this oul which gives me life, than it is, that I cannot live without this love which I bear unto her.

If you reply, That though this hould be granted, yet it does not follow that this hepherdee hould love me, becaue he has not yet een or known this love in me: I hall anwer, hepherdee, That indeed I doe not believe he knowes yet the grandure and extream immenity wherewith I doe love and adore her, becaue there are no ervices nor demontrations o great as can ufficiently illutrate it: But yet I am confident, the excellency of herwit cannot chue but ee and oberve it in part, and that in a great part alo and that my actions cannot doe it o well as I deire; yet your own reproaches and language has ometimes helped me againt your knowledge; nay in the preence of all this Noble company you told her, that I did preent my elfe before her in raptures of love: and urely the tetimony of an enemy, when it is to our advantage, is much more credible then the tetimony of perons indifferent. So as, fairet Mitree, you cannot doubt of my affection, ince it is tetified by one that cannot be upected of untruth.

But Phillis, what hallow argument did you ue in having recoure unto thoe favours which Nature hath betowed upon you? imply alledging that you being a woman, therefore he ought to love you before a hepherd, thinking that by this quality you have the advantage of me. But let me tell you, that it is more naturall for a woman to love a man, then a woman. And if you will but look into the Lawes of Nature, you will find that it is o amongt all Animalls: Does not the Hen follow the Cock ooner then another Hen: Will not the widdowed Turtle lament her loe? Does not all femalls of all kindes the like? you know this, Phillis, as well as I doe; or if you do not, common experience will teach you: Nay, things even inenible, doe oberve the ame law of Nature: The Palme, will it thrive, unlee by another Palme? Will the femall Myrtle live without the male? Therefore, Phillis, It is not by the lawes of Nature, that Diana mut love you more then me; for if he follow them, they will turne her eyes from any thoughts of you. But if you will have it o, I am content, hepherdes, that he hould love you as a woman, o you will alo conent he hould love me as a man, and her mot devoted ervant. You cannot be againt this, for as certainly as you are a woman, o certainly am I her ervant: nor is it more naturall for one woman to love another woman, then it is for every one to love whatoever loves them: This is the way for us both to obtaine what we aske: But I ee now, that you will alter your opinion, and without any further recoure unto this naturall amity, which cannot be advantageous to you, you will fly unto uch advantages as proceed from election. You conceive he mut love you better than me, becaue of your more intimate convere together, which you ay does beget a neerer and more mutual affection. But Phillis, you may be much mitaken; for by the very ame reaon you may perhaps as well me • t with hatred, as with love; for by continuall converation, cloe and hidden imperfections are better dicovered,
as well as good qualities: And let me tell you, that being perpetually together, does oft break off amity as well as augment it: little eparations makes love more violent, continuall preence is apt to cloy.

I would not urge this point o farre, Oh my enemy, did I thinke you could make any ue of it to my diadvantage: But I mut tell you, that you have done as ill Orators ue, who in lieu of maintaining their Clients caue, doe marre it, and dicover the reaons which make againt them; otherwie could you imagine that continuall converation hould get you more love, ince on the contrary, it hewes the defects of your affection which are very great, and of which you cannot deny, but I have convinced you a hundred times in the preence of my fairet Mitres.

But oh my mot jut judge and fairet Mitres, my hope is that you will punih her impudence in pretending unto o much of your love, by reaon of her continual convere, when as it hath onely hewed her imperfections: and therefore, Phillis, the advantage which you get by your intimate converation, does more hurt then help you; And indeed your Allegation has much more malice in it then matter, and all things rightly conidered, I think my elfe more happy in my converation with her, then you can be in yours; for your tay with her is onely in the day, and that alo you imploy much of it out of her preence, either in the buinee of your houe and flock, or other diverions which teal you from her, o as you dedicate the leat of the day unto my fairet Mitres: whereas I on the contrary, what day did ever dawne, which I pent not wholly in her company? When was the night I was not with her, as long as decency would permit me? Could ever any diverion draw me from her? And when any unwilling accident did keep me away, did I not continually think upon her, and in my heart adore her? Can you ay, Phillis, that you are more with her then I? Fie, fie, hepherdee, never think it, but know, that he is not more with her elfe then I am: for he is ometimes diverted from her elfe by the preence of other hepherdees, ometimes by viits of civility, ometimes by dometique cares, and ometimes by cros accidents, whereas I am continually with her as Prometheus upon his Rock, or rather as the body and oul are linked by the ligaments of life: For it is not more natural for the body to die, as oon as the oul is eparated from it, then it is for me to die, if I be but one minute eparated from my weet thoughts of her.

I ee very well, hepherdee, how you laugh to heare me ay that I am continually with my Mitres, thinking that it being onely in thought, I am a man much pleaed with my own imagination. But Phillis, what would you have me doe? I mut confee that if I could be alwayes preent with her both in thought and body, I hould be more contented: but how ever let me tell you, that as I am, I am more perfectly with her then you are, ince when you are preent with her, your thoughts of her are farre off, retaining nothing with her but your body which is the inferiour part, whereas my heart is with her, though my body be ditant: If you doe object that thee imaginary thoughts are not at all erviceable unto her, becaue they are meer fancies, I mut anwer you, hepherdee, that it is in thought onely that we adore the great Tautates, and never peak unto him but onely in contemplation. And I doe erve and adore Diana upon the earth, as all the world does adore the great Tautates in heaven which is in heart and thought.

You ee therefore, Phillis, how this reaon argues more for me then you. And as to that advantage which you ay your ex hath over mine, I anwer thus; That I doe mot ingeniouly confee, that women are really of more merit then men; and doe come nearer the divine and immortal Intelligences: I do believe that women may well be ranked amongt them, and they doe o much excell us in perfections, as it is a kinde of wrong to reckon them amongt men: we may with reaon eteem them the medium betwixt Angels and us, ince we find by experience, that all the good thoughts which men have, do take their beginning from them. It is at them they aim, and terminate themelves in them; and quetionlee it is by them that we come unto thoe pure thoughts; And God hath placed them on earth to draw us unto heaven: For my part, I do believe it, and will maintaine it unto the end of my life. But this does
not at all argue you, Oh hepherdee, to be the better loved by my Mitres: but rather will produce contrary effects.

I told you before, that when one has done all that nature has given him power to doe, and hath raied himelfe unto that height to which naturally he may rie, it is highly to be eteemed. And I ay again, that whooever does lee then naturally he may doe, is much to blame, epecially when the thing is in it elfe laudable, and he through naturall impuiance leaves it undone. Now, hepherdee, does not this argument much condemn you, who being born a woman, of a ex o perfect as you hold a medium betwixt the Angels and us; and yet to love o imperfectly as you do, epecially a ubject o full of perfection? I am mot confident, that Diana did never out of her naturall weetnee conider my extream affection, without eteeming it, nor look upon the hallownee of your Amity without condemning it For when he found mine o perfect, o pure, o entire, and o exempt from all exceptions, he could doe no lee then highly commend it, that uch a perfect love hould be found in o imperfect a ex as the maculine. And on the contrary, he is ahamed that o many faults and imperfections hould be found in you and your ex, which is by nature o much above ours.

But Mitres, let us examine her other reaons, whereby he argues me o guilty in matter of love. She ays, that all my demontrations of love are onely fictions, diguiements, and diimulations; and he thinks he has proved this Calummy very well, when he ayes that I began to love you onely upon the wager, and did not love you before. But I beeech you, my fair and jut judge, take notice of the evill conequences which he drawes from thee preuppoitions: I doe confee, Phillis, That the wager did move me firt to love Diana, and that this wager did give beginning unto my affection: But mut it from hence be concluded, that my love is only diimulation; or that becaue I never loved any before, therefore I do not love Diana now? Thee, hepherdee, are aburd concluions. If one do run for a wager, and win it, can it be thought he did run for it in jet, and not in good earnet? Tell me no more my enemy, that my extream paions and raptures are but diguiements, fictions, and diimulations: For it is true, I did love upon that wager, but it is more true that my affection is mot real: And I am not o ure I am Silvander, as that I am the mot real ervant of the fair Diana. What a illy yllogim is it to ay, that becaue I did not once love Diana, therefore I doe not love her now? If uch a concluion may be drawn, then one may ay, that becaue Phillis was not in the world forty years ince, therefore he is not in it now. Had you aid, it was not long ince this love began, you had aid truly, and I would have confeed it with you, with orrow that it was no ooner: But to prove that I doe not love, becaue the time was when I did not know her, is as much as if you hould ay, that he who is not born to day, will never be born.

Now Mitres, be pleaed to oberve, how he does contradict her elfe; But it is not trange, for it is the property of lying and calumny to be in everall tales, whereas truth is alwayes in one and the ame. But admit, aid he, that your beauty did a little move him, and by this meanes, he is in ome ort become yours: Is it poible, Phillis, you hould be o long converant with the fair Diana, and know her perfections no better? Doe you think it is poible to love her but a little? Oh ignorant Phillis in the force of her beauty, not one dart flyes from her faire eye, which does not reach the heart and wound it mortally. You might well keep your littles for common beauties, which when they have cratched the skin a little, do think they have given a great tetimony of their power; But as for Diana's beauty, it eems you have not felt the blowes of it, ince you can talk o of a little. But know, Oh my enemy, that a Remora which can tay a Ship under full ayle, has not halfe the force of her perfections: Diana's beauty takes not hearts by Littles, but by Alls; and he aured that the Gordian knots are more eaily diolved, then thoe by which he fetters oules. That fire which our Druids tell us mut conume all the Univere, has leer flames then thoe of her fair eyes; ay not therefore, ignorant hepherdee, that one can love her a little, or that one can be in ome ort hers: All thoe who love her, doe love her extreamly; and all thoe who are hers, are hers entirely; o as when you grant that I doe
love her a little, you doe grant that I do love her infinitely, and by conequence that nothing can equall the grandure of my affection Whereas you, Phillis, that can peak o, doe thereby argue your elfe incapable of being moved, and is inenible of that which is able to kill others. But I beeech you, Mitres, ee what a fine peece of ophitry my enemy ues, to prove that I doe not love you, and to make you depie my affection; and judge whether he ever o much as heard of uch a thing as love? Is he not very ubtile in accuing me, for never loving any but you? and that you were the firt that ever fettered me: If this be a crime, I mut confee I never heard of it before, and mut needs acknowledge my elfe culpable: for, Mitres, you are not onely the firt, and onely one that ever I loved; but more, you mut alo be the lat, and onely one that ever I will love: And if ever it be otherwie, let the Sun cover me with eternal darknee; let the Earth which nouriheth me, wallow me alive as not worthy to live in it; Let the Air become my poyon, and may all the elements become my enemies: and wie men are all mitaken in their Tenet, that whatoever has a beginning mut have an end: For Phillis, this affection which you have eene begin, hall lat to all eternity.

But Phillis, I admire you hould ay, that if my affection deerve any reward, it is all due unto you: You tell me that you were the caue of it, and that all which does proceed from it, ought to be attributed unto you as the originall caue. But hepherdee, take heed, let this being granted, it doe not turn to your diadvantage; for thoe who are the caue of any evil, deerve punihment: And as you ay, that my Mitres ought rather to laugh, then love me; o it mut conequently follow, that he ought to laugh at you, and not at Silvander, becaue you attribute all unto your elfe.

But Phil • is, let that be the left of your feares; I doe not meane to quit my jut pretenions upon any uch t • rmes; when any one does any thing for another, the intention of the doer is to be conidered: if the intention was good, the evill which inues ought not to be laid unto his charge, if he be no other way culpable: but if the intention was evill, he ought not to have any hare in the benefit or glory which hall enue by it: this being granted, as needs it mut, let us conider before we either commend or condemne you, what your intention was when you propounded this wager. We hall not be put unto much pain, Mitres, before we dicover it: for he her elfe has told us: The fictions, aid he, and the diimulations once knowne will procure him hatred: But Diana knowes, that all my Courthips, and amorous addrees unto her, doe proceed onely from the wager which you made; and if all the conequents of it be fictions and diimulations, then you are the caue of them. You may oberve, Mitree, how he thought that I would ue onely fictions and diimulations in this wager. Now ince it is the Intention which makes the Action either good or bad, have I not jut caue to ay, It was you, Oh Phillis, who by your diembling wager, gave your elfe unto faire Diana, but it was my heart which did really give me unto her, by the knowledge which it had of her perfections, and o by conequence all the punihment which uch diimulations deerve, are due unto you; and all the favours which a reall and unfained affection deerves, are due unto my heart.

Wih me no more to quit the pretended victory unto you, to hew my wit and my judgement; my Wit, in o hanomly diguiing a fale affection under the umbrage of a reall love; and my Judgement, in acknowledging the advantage which you have over me: For on the contrary, I hould hew my elf the veriet fool alive, if I did counterfeit a love unto her, who deerves to be perfectly loved above all the world: And I hould hew but little judgement, if I did not ee the advantage which my true and perfect affection does give me over your faigned follies. I would have you, hepherdee, recant all your reproaches, and be the firt who hall ay, That there is no affection, be it never o ill begun, either by a wager, or patime, but may prove in earnet, and become reall, as mine for an example.

But, oh my enemy, all this dicoure is but aire, and I believe in vain; for we are contending with one another for the victory, whilt whooever conquers, perhaps may not be the couquerer I make no quetion, but if either of us doe obtaine the victory which we pretend unto, that this Chaplet of Flowers at the feet of the faire Diana
will be mine. But alas, Phillis, my great feare is, and with abundance of reaon, that it will prove to be neither yours nor mine; for all our arguments which we have alleaged to merit her favour, may be valid as againt one another, but not at all in relation to Diana: Diana, whoe trancendent perfections and merits is above all the power of Nature, and therefore will not be ubervient unto the lawes of Mortalls. And then, when we ay, That love ought to be paid with love; and that long and faithfull lovers are worthy of reward and acknowledgement; This is right, and good reaon, as to men, and does oblige them to follow thoe precepts, but not at all, Diana For he is one whom heaven has elevated above the degree of mortals, and is equall unto Angels. To whom then hould I addree my elfe, unto what hould I have recoure? Shall I addres my elfe unto Love, and have recoure unto Jutice, by whom all things are equally ballanced and recompenced? But alas, Love and Jutice has nothing to doe with Diana, he is above them all. Addres then thy elfe Silvander, and have recoure unto her elfe; and waving all other powers and reaons, ay thus unto her.
Then he kneeled down before Diana, and holding up his hands, continued.

Oh Diana, the onely honour of her Country, the glory of Men, and the Ornament of the whole world: Be pleaed to look upon a hepherd here before you, who does not onely love you, and offer at your feet his ervice and his life, but does even adore you, and does acrifice his heart and his oul unto you in a mot zealous and devout manner. As Nature cannot make any thing which can equal you; o Love cannot kindle o great a flame and perfect affection as can equall your merit. It hath pleaed the great Tautates to advance you o high above all the ret of his works, as no extremity of love, no incerity of devotion, can in any reaon hope for any grace or favour from you, or that you condecend o low, as to look at my complaints and grievances: I doe humbly acknowledge, that all human hearts, and all mortall ervices, are mot due unto you, and cannot be denyed you without a inne: But alas, we can merit nothing, all we can do is to love erve and adore you, and when all is done, we cannot claim any reward, becaue all is but a jut duty. Under thee Notions and Qualifications, I now preent my elfe before you, as before a Deity, not daring to aske any recompence for all my ervices, or my affection, for that were a demand too arrogant, and above my hopes and deerts: but onely to beeech you, that you will be a witnee how none knowes better how to love than Silvander, nor any that deerves to be more loved again.

Thus Silvander ended, and would not rie, but till continued kneeling in expectation of her judgement. And becaue Phillis offered to reply, Adamas eeing the time of departure to draw on, he told her, that it was not to be allowed; o that Diana after a paue of conideration, he gave entence in thee words.

div.head: The Judgement of the hepherdes Diana.
div.p: LOve being a thing which requires better tetimony then words; and the difference between Phillis and Silvander being of that quality, we have been no lee obervant of their actions and behaviours ever ince the firt beginning of the wager, then we are now attentive unto their Reaons, which both have at this time alleadged. And having eriouly and deliberately ballanced every thing in an equall eale, we doe declare and pronounce, That Phillis is more amiable then Silvander, and that Silvander knowes better how to love then Phillis; And to make our intention more manifet, We doe ordain, That Phillis hall it in the eat where I am, and that Silvander hall kis my hand: That Phillis hall retore the Chaplet of Flowers unto Adamas, who gave it unto her; and that Silvander hall take his from my hands, and alwayes wear it hereafter, by renewing it with freh flowers when thee decay.

Upon this he roe up, and took Phillis by the hand, cauing her to retore her Garland unto the Druid: And taking up Silvanders Garland, he put it upon his head, and gave him her hand to kis as he kneeled; which he received with o much contentment and joy, that the hepherdee was well aured, it was not a kie which proceeded from any diembled affection.

The heat of the day was much abated, when Diana gave her judgement; and Adamas being deirous that Alcidon and Daphnide might ee the exercies of the hepherds; he aroe from his eat, which caued all the ret to doe the like, and o they parted; And becaue Phillis and Silvander did dipute the matter amongt themelves, as quetioning unto whom Diana had given the advantage; and the Druid perceiving that the dipute was not eaily determined: he advied them to talk of it by the way, becaue it would be a good diverion to make the way eem horter. As oon as they were et forward, Phillis began to fall upon the hepheard: Well, Silvander (aid he) what doe you think of Dianas judgement? Shepherdes, anwered Silvander, I never hoped for o much as our Mitres hath given unto me: And I will maintaine, that never was judgement pronounced with more equity nor wie coniderations, then this which he hath given. Why hepherd? (aid Phillis) doe you thinke that Diana has given you any advantage above me? Whooever doubts it, anwered Silvander, does either not undertand her judgement, or has no judgement to undertand. For my part, aid Phillis, I doe not onely undertand it, but doe admire it; for I do very well undertand that I have won the wager, and do admire it, becaue both parties are pleaed; for commonly in other caes, one party complains of injutice. In this as in all her other actions, anwered Silvander, the admirable wit of Diana hewes it elfe: and yet (aid Phillis) It is I that am declared the more amiable; and it is I unto whom Dianas eat is given, as unto her who bet deerves it; intimating thereby, that it is I unto whom Silvander owes the ame duties, and honours which our Mitres formerly received from us. Oh hepherdee (aid Silvander) the mytery of this judgement is very deep, and abundance of tudy is requiite to undertand it: And if our fairet Mitres would be pleaed to contitute a Judge to declare her intention in it, I hould quickly make it appear that her judgement is more in my advantage then yours: And if it pleae her to heare us now, you hall ee that it is my part to thank her for the victory which he has mot jutly judged on my ide. Silvander, aid Diana then, There is no neceity of any further explanation, for I think I have declared my elfe o plainly, as there is no neceity of it. But I beeech you, ince now there is no wager betwixt Phillis and you, and ince I am not now either your Judge or your Mitres, I pray remember that my name is Diana, and o let me be called. Thee words were uttered with uch a erious brow, that Silvander aw it was her will to have it o; yet eeming to take it in another manner, he anwered thus I doe know very well, that you are the faire Diana, whom Phillis and I have erved: I know alo, that you permitted me
to take you for my Mitres, which I did; and doe you think I am of the humour of Hylas? Pardon me I beeech you, if I hate incontancy, and let me continue as I begun, for I cannot change; Hylas, who did not hate Silvander; but though they were continually in contet with one another, yet he thought him the mot accomplihed hepherd in all the Country. Methinks, fair Diana, (aid he) that you are obliged by many reaons, to like this hepherds propoition, which you cannot deny without offence againt your own judgement. But if to eae you of that labour, you will let me declare what your intention is in your judgement, I hould have quickly condemned Silvander. I perceive, Hylas, (anwered Diana and miled) That you would be as good a judge unto them, as you are a Counellor unto me No, no, aid Phillis, I will not admit of any partial Judge, and Silvander has the ame reaon; But if it pleae the Reverend Adamas to undertake it, let him ordain and compoe the matter. No, aid Adamas, there is no reaon that any hould be judge but Diana her elfe; but if you pleae to alleadge what you thinke conducing to your advantage, we hall all give our advice unto her. Then, aid Phillis, I doe wonder Silvander, you hould be o prejudicated with the love of your elfe, as not to ee a thing which is as clear as the Sun: I am confident that none here but thinks you to be a man of reaon, and that you doe this onely to hew the ubtilty of your wit: Could ever any peak more plainly then Diana did? I doe declare, aid he, that Phillis is more amiable then Silvander, and the better to clear her intention, he added the honour of etting me in her own eat, to hew that there was as great a difference betwixt you and me, as there is between you and Diana, and that in this regard you hould behave your elfe unto me with the ame repect and honour: Could he doe more to hew my victory? or declare it in more expres words? on the contrary, in aying that thou knowet better how to make your elfe loved then I doe; this was as much as if he Irad aid, that you are uller of ubtilty and art then I am, and o far I confee it; but whatoever is amiable in it elfe, needs no art or ubtilty to make it elfe loved. Although he did give you a Garland of Flowers, and caued me to retore mine unto him who gave it unto me; yet this was onely to hew, that he aw nothing amiable in you but uch things as reemble flowers which grow and die in a day. And becaue he thought my merits more olid and durable, he would not emblem them by things o fadeable: And to the end you might the better know it, not being willing any thing hould pae without recompence; conider Silvander, what it is which he gave you: and what it is which I receive in recompence of my ervice: he permitted you to kis her hand, which is a gratification ued unto laves, and uch as are in little eteem; but unto me he urrendred her place, to hew he thought none more worthy then my elfe, and to intimate unto you, that he adjudged it your duty to doe me the ame honour which you did unto her. Boat then, Silvander, of the advantage which you pretend to receive by the this judgement: Keep well in memory the great victory which you have this day obtained: Go unto the Temple of the good Goddes, and there let it be Chronicled in the Annalls, that future ages may alo know it. After this, Phillis was ilent: and when Silvander would have anwered, Hylas prevented him, aying; If I were to give my opinion, I hould declare Phillis victorious. Hylas, aid Adamas, and miled, you give your judgement with too much precipitation; for you condemn a man before he be heard; Silvander has not yet poke for himelfe: 'Tis true, aid Hylas, but all's one, for I know he cannot anwer any thing to the purpoe. Every one began to laugh at the dicoure of Hylas; and when they were all ilent, Silvander began to anwer thus.

div.head: The Anwer of the Shepherd Sylvander, upon the Judgement of Diana.
div.p: I Have learn'd in the Mailian Schools, that Prometheus had uch a ubtle wit, as he mounted up to heaven, and from thence tole that Fire from the Gods wherewith he did animate the Statue which he made; and that for a punihment of his Theft, he was ty'd to a Rock, where an Eagle did continually feed upon his Liver. Shall not I run the ame Fortune, if in declaring the intentions of the fair Diana, I hould teal from her that ecret which he would reerve unto her elf; for I think the Theft not inferiour to that of Prometheus, nor that I in againt a les Divinity. But on the other ide, hall I comply with the crime of Phillis, who to my diadvantage, and againt all equity, and the good judgement of Diana, does attribute unto her elf more then is her due? Truly, hould I let fall o jut a caue, when I am able to maintain it by clear Reaons, I hall fear my elf extremely culpable. What then wilt thou do Sylvander? Cant thou not do what is fit to be done, unles thou incur a danger? Have recoure then unto the fair Diana her elf, and by upplications, ask that by way of gift, which thou may't jutly teal from her. It is unto you therefore, O fairet and divine Mitris, that I addres my Prayers; begging leave to declare the equity of your judgement, and the truth of my Victory; Proteting, that in this action I will have a greater regard unto any thing which hall concern you, then unto any thing that hall concern my elf. For the matter would not concern me o much, though Phillis had the advantage of me, becaue notwithtanding I hould be no les your ervant then I am; but that Phillis by her ubtle gloes hould make it thought that you are the Author of a judgement againt all manner of Reaon: This would wound the honour of your Wit and Judgement. But in a confidence that your ilence gives conent, I will anwer Phillis thus.

It eems Shepherdes that you have a mind to be twice overcome, and will make me your uperiour by two Judgements; I ee you would have appealed from Dianas Throne, unto another; and if our prudent Druide had not hindred you, perhaps this injury had been done unto her: But it is no wonder, that he who does not know how to love, hould be ignorant in the ecrets and ordinances of Love: yet to the end that neither you, nor thoe who hear you, may not ret any longer in that error, hearken Shepherdes unto this Truth, which I hall briefly declare unto you.

That great God which is in the highet heavens, and who with one ingle look doth behold, not only all things which the Sun doth hine upon, but alo all the ecrets that are hidden in the Intrals of the Earth, and deepet Abys of Waters; he was pleaed to give this priviledge unto man, that he only can know and undertand his mind; and for his further help, he did not endue him with this knowledge, to conceal it from all, but to communicate and participate this knowledge unto others: And that he might do it the more intelligibly, he gave unto him two ways whereby he might declare himelf; which is, by Speech, and by Actions: And by thee two every one may dicover their intentions, and make them more intelligible unto one another: And therefore when our Actions are Ambiguous, we add Speech, to make them the more plain: And when our Speech is obcure and dubious, we do interpret them by our Actions. And the great Tautates was pleaed to order it thus, to the end that thoe deluding pirits which take delight in deceiving all thoe they have convere withal, may be without excue, when their decreitfulnes is dicovered.

Now the mot wie and jut Diana, being willing to let us know what he thought of our difference, and to manifet her mind more clearly unto us, hath ued thee two ways whereby to expres her elf. Firt, She has declared her elf in clear words; and to her words he has added actions, which demontratively do peak her mind: Yet ince the ignorance of Phillis is uch, and to leave none in any doubt of the Truth, I am forced to go a little further, and to ay, That to dicover this Truth, it is requiite to ound it to the bottome, and to know who has got the victory by the judgement of Diana; It is neceary to conider the beginning of the Difference, which caued our Wager.

The Nymph Leonide did very faithfully relate the Truth, when he aid, That three months being expired, Diana was to judge whether Phillis or I did know better how to make our elves Loved: For our wager was grounded upon the aying of Phillis, that the reaon why I did not attempt to erve any of our Shepherdees was, becaue I was defective in uch things as might procure Love: And becaue I maintained that the only reaon was want of will, both Phillis and I were ordered to erve the fair Diana three months; and afterwards he was to judg, which of us two did know better how to make our elves Loved. This being well undertood, I beleeve there is none here, who does not plainly ee, that by the words of the fair Diana, I have obtained that which I did pretend unto: Her words were thee, We do declare, that Sylvander does know how to make himelf beloved better then Phillis: Could he expree her mind by any words more intelligibly and cleerly? And yet to leave no cruple of any doubt, he has added actions unto her words; and uch as none can conider, but they mut preently confee my victory. Her Actions were two, Firt, putting the Crown upon my head, econdly, giving me her hand to kie; both of them are favours o high, as hardly any can be greater: For Phillis, Unto whom are Crowns given, but uch as overcome? and unto whom do Mitrees ue to give their hands to kie, but unto thoe whom they think worthy of their Loves? I cannot tell Shepherdee what Country it is, where the cutome is to permit uch kies unto their laves, and uch as they little eteem: but if they ue to confer uch favours upon thoe whom they di-eteem, what will they do unto thoe who are high in their Favours? Believe me, O my enemy, that after this rate, there are very few, who would not be very glad my Fairet Mitree would depie them, and I aure you, I would be contented to live and die in uch dieteem. And as to what you ay, That our judge in giving me a Garland of Flowers, does intimate thereby, that whatoever is amiable in me, is like thoe flowers, which grow and die in a day: I beeech you conider what he has added unto thoe flowers, as if he did foreee that this would be objected: We do ordain, aid he, that Sylvander hall take his chaplet of flowers from my hands, and wear it hereafter, by renewing it with freh flowers: Can you think Shepherdee, that he intended it to wither in a day, ince he would have me wear it for eternal memory? But in this, I mut confee you are excuable: For it is one of thoe miteries in Love which you do not undertand, and which I will unfold unto you, to the end you may know, why our jut judg did ordain, that you hould retore that Garland which was given unto you, and why I hould wear mine alwaies.

Love, which our age Druides eteem to be the great Tautates, whom the Doctors in the Mailian Schools do ay, was the firt of all the gods who after the Chaos did eparate things mortal from things immortal, and gave them life and perfection. And becaue man was only created to know, to love, and to erve this great Tautates, whom we were not able to comprehend by any corporeal repreentations or Ideas, he did et before our eyes a body o perfect, as might in ome ort repreent unto us, that which he would have us know of him: To the end, that knowing him, we might come to love him, and loving him, to erve him. And in as much as nothing is o bright and pure as this great Tautates, he created that which he thought mot pure and perfect, and did imbellih it with all the beauties, and accomplih it with all the perfections that a body could be capable of, and called it the Sun. Thus the Sun, appeared preently from one ide of Heaven unto the other, gave life and motion unto all that was upon the earth, and wrought uch admirable effects, as many did think it to be the great God, of whom it was only but an imperfect reemblance, and did adore it in lieu of that which it did repreent. Now Phillis, if you would know in ome ort what this great Tautates Love is, you mut learn it by the Sun, and uch things as fall under our enes: And when you ee how the Sun gives life unto all that is in the univere, you ought to ay it your elf, that Love gives life unto all ouls, when it hines, not only in heaven, but alo throughout all the earth: you mut acknowledg Love to be the light, which gives undertanding unto all pirits; for there is none o blind, but it is able to open his eyes, and make him cleer ighted. And if this Sun of Love do not hine, then is he all in darknee, without any light or undertanding: conider alo, how as the Sun does alter and change eaons, Love does the like: It caueth the Spring, by producing in our pirits the flowers of hopes; It caueth Summer, by giving us the fruits of thoe hopes; It caueth Autumn, by letting us enjoy them; and it caueth
Winter, by giving us o much undertanding, as to know how to preerve them long. I hould be too long if I hould relate all the reemblances betwixt Love and the Sun: Let it uffice Shepherdes, that by this reemblance already intanced, you may undertand, how thee flowers, which you o much undervalue, & ay are withered as oon as blown are the hopes which Love produceth in his Spring: Oh Love! What greater favour could I receive from my fairet Mitree? Oh Phillis! how dear and infinitely pleaing are thee flowers unto me? epecially when I conider the conequents of this favour Thee fair and weet flowers, are the Spring of my hopes; and can you think that Summer will not preently follow after the Spring? Is not that kie of her fair hand which he was pleaed to afford me, the fruit of thoe hopes? Does not this Glorious Sun of my oul, afford me alo an Autumn and a Winter? Doubtlee Phillis, my fairet Mitree did not omit them, when he ordained I hould wear that Crown of flowers continually amongt the Shepherds, and renew it with freh ones: Is not this an Autumn and Winter both, ince I mut preerve it long, and renew my happinee? Conider, O my enemy, how in taking thee flowers from you, and retoring them unto Adamas, he intimates, that you mut not hope for any thing. And if you have flattered up your elf with any fond hopes, without any ground of reaon, it is fit you be deprived of them before all this venerable company.

There remaines nothing now to anwer; but only to tell you, why my fairet Mitris was pleaed to ay, that Phillis was more amiable then Sylvander, and upon what reaon he placed you in her own eat. For the better undertanding of it, know Shepherdee; That whatoever is good is amiable: but if the good be unknown, it is like unto a hidden treaure, which none can eteem until it be known: when Diana did declare that you were amiable, he did it with good reaon, for doubtles the vertues which are in you, are good: for reembling my fairet Mitris in ex, and other gifts of Nature, there is no doubt but therein you are amiable, and much more then Sylvander: But being deficient in other things which hould make you loved, and which he finds in me, he has declared me to know better how to make my elf loved, then you do. And this Shepherdee, if you do rightly undertand it, is mot jut, and not at all di-advantagious to you: For all three mut be conidered; Diana is he who was to receive our ervices and our paions: And you and I were to erve and Court her. It is the property of a man to erve and Court a fair Mitris: I have done according to the duty and office of a man, in my Courthip of Diana; and he has done the right office of a woman, in receiving my ervices: But it is prepoterous and aburd for you, who are a woman, to Court a woman, and therefore it is not at all trange, that though you be more amiable, yet Sylvander hould know how to procure love better then you, ince it is his part to court, and yours on the contrary to be courted; and certainly our jut Judge did o intend it, when he placed you in her room, intimating, that as it was hers, o it was your part, not to erve, but to be erved. Confes therefore Phillis, that I have won the wager, and I will confee you to be more amiable then I: And let us both ay, that never was a more wie and jut Judge, nor a fairer Mitris, then Diana, whoe judgement has given me the victory, and whoe perfections have made me eternally hers.

Thus Sylvander ended, leaving every one very well atisfied with his reaons and modety. Phillis her elf was forced to yeild unto him: and therefore Diana eeing there was no need of a econd judgement, he aid no more. Hylas only, who jeared at all he had aid, and held Stella under the Arm, eeing all was ilent, he began to talk. Well Sylvander, (aid he) To what purpoe is all this long Dicoure? And what can we learn from it? You may learn (anwered Sylvander) that the jut judgement which Diana gave upon uch olid reaon, had like to have uffered the ame injury by the mi-interpretation of Phillis, that mot Oracles do receive from thoe who will turn them according to their own deires, and wret them o, as they uit with their own paions. And Stella and you may learn, That as there is but one Sun which reembles Love, o all ought to have but one Love. If it be o, aid Hylas, that Love, like the Sun, gives life, and that none do live without it, and that you never loved any until of very late, then you have been alive but very lately: And if o, good Sylvander, tell me, how you did being dead, to look o well to your Flock, to hunt, to talk, to ing, to run, and wretle? I hould be very glad to learn that trick of you, that I may do the ame when I am dead; for I have een ome aoon as they are dead, cat preently
into the earth, and there's an end of them; but I mut confes you are the finet dead man that ever I aw; and if I could but do as you did before you were in love, I would not care a ruh for death. Sylvander could not chue but laugh at the dicoure of Hylas; but by way of anwer, he aid: 'Tis true, that Love is the life of our ouls, if it be rightly undertood; and to that end, you mut know Hylas, that there are two kinds of life in a oul: The one, is that which it lives in the body; and the other, which it lives with it elf. The firt doth animate the Body, makes it walk, talk, eat, and do all thoe things which you knew I did before I had the happines to love Diana. And the other gives life unto the Soul, and makes it live in it elf: For it enlightens the Undertanding, forms the Imagination, and takes up the Will. The firt kind of life is common unto man, as unto all other animals; for all living do produce the ame actions: But the other oaring higher then the Body, does give the Soul another kind of life, which is common unto thoe pure thoughts of which we poke before. Now Hylas, when I aid that Love gives life unto Souls; I did not then ay that the Body was dead, in that ene which you apprehend it; for then I had aid things impoible. Impoible, becaue none can die before he live; and he who never loved, never lived; and he who never lived, cannot die. Ask me no more therefore, how being dead, I came to talk, ing, leap, run, and uch like; for all thoe actions do depend upon a life, which love daigns not to meddle with. Then I perceive (aid Hylas) that your love is only in thought and imagination. No quetion of it (replyed Sylvander) and as for other things, I leave them unto that intinct which Nature gives unto every one. Then (replyed Hylas) It is pity but we two hould love one Shepherdes; for we hould both agree excellently well: You in the Favours which he hould hew you in thought and imagination; and I, in thoe which your love leaves unto that intinct of Nature. Alcidon, and mot of the Shepherds, did laugh heartily at the merry humour of Hylas; and epecially Sylvander, who at lat returned him this anwer. Ah Hylas, Did you know how to Love, you would not peak thus, nor confound things as you do. Though my Soul doth live in its own thoughts, yet for all that, it gives life unto that body which it animates: The Sun, which as I told you, is the true Embleme of Love, though it do hine upon Celetial things, yet it does alo cat his rayes upon Bodies here below: And why hould not Love, which enlightens our Undertanding, and forms the thoughts of our ouls, give uch deires alo unto our Bodies, as are natural unto it? No, no Hylas, here lies all the difference; Thoe who love as I do, they have none of thoe deires whereof you peak, but becaue they love: And thoe who love as you do, do not love, but becaue they have thoe deires. But Sylvander (aid Stella, who was a little netled at this dicoure) ince you have thee deires, Are you not very bold, when you conider who you are, and who Diana is? I mut needs confes, anwered Sylvander, That when I do look upon my elf with eyes of equality, I think you are in the right; but when I conider my extream love, and the hopes which he was pleaed to give me, I think my elf not too blame. Your extream love (aid he) and your hopes alo, are things inviible. But the actions of my fairet Mitris (anwered Sylvander) may make them viible: And though mine have not hitherto been o great as to demontrate them, yet I hope to render her uch ervice, as hall evidence it to her, and all the world, that my Love is the greatet that ever was. But had you oberved her actions as well as I, you would not have upbraided me with my hopes, as you have done: For is not every flower a hope? And to what purpoe do you think he ordained I hould wear them upon my head? It is true replied Stella; but as you received thoe flowers from the age Adamas, o you mut expect your hopes from him, and not from Diana. O Stella, aid Sylvander, I perceive your eye was only upon Hylas: for had you looked about you, you might have een, I had them not from that Druide: It is true, I had them firt from him, but I laid them at the feet of Diana; to hew, that from her I expected all my hopes: and now you ee them upon my head, from what other hand do you think I would receive them, but from hers, upon whom all my hopes depend? Did I not receive this Crown of Flowers from her fair hand? And did he not thereby as much as ay, HOPE? But yet, replied Stella, thee flowers, and thee hopes, did come from the age Adamas: This, anwered Sylvander, is not without a deep mitery, for perhaps the great Tautat • s would have me know, that the beginning of all my hopes mut take original from age Adamas.

The dipute betwixt thee Shepherds, and Shepherdees had continued longer, had they not come at the ame time unto the great Meddow, where the Shepherds ued to perform their exercies. A great company was already aembled from all parts, and were prepared with all things neceary, when eing the grand Druide and his company a far off, they came to meet him, with many demontrations of joy, to have him amongt them. After the Complements of Courteie were performed, the Prizes were et up, for Running, for Wretling, for Leaping, and for throwing the Bar: Sylvander had the honour of the firt, Lycidas of wretling, Hylas of leaping, and Hermantes of throwing the bar: As for Sylvander, every one was glad of his victory, and of that of Lycidas alo; but as for Hylas and Hermantes, who came with Daphnide and Alcidon; the Shepherds of Forrets did a little grudge at them: and Hylas going unto Stella, becaue the prize which he had won, was a little Crown compoed of Feathers; he beeeched her to let him put it upon her head; Sylvander eeing this, by way of mockery, aid unto him, That, Hylas, is a very right reward for thy faithful paines. What do you ay? (aid Hylas, after he had put the Crown upon the head of Stella) I ay (anwered Sylvander) that thoe who know you, and dare leap with you, are very bold; for having uch a light head as you have, they might eaily imagine your heels like unto it, and be out of hopes to overcome you: but they who made that Crown, hewed more judgement, for nothing could ute o well to your light mind, as a Cap of Feathers. I am not at all ahamed of it, anwered Hylas; for unto you who are lumpih and dull, they did very well to give uch things as the gros earth produceth, as that Garland of Flowers, which you have in your hand: But unto me, as unto one who is compoed of a more noble temper, they have preented Feathers, to hew, that I do elevate my elf in the Element of Ayr; as depiing uch a lumpih piece as you are; you I ay, who does envy that which you upbraid me withal: ince I will run againt all the ret of the Shepherds, to get the glory of being lighter then they. You are mitaken (anwered Sylvander) I did not run, to make it appear I was lighter; but becaue I was deirous to be the firt at my fairet Mitris, who at at the end of the Race: o as you are deceived, if you thought I did run for the honour of running bet: for my aym was only to make it appear, that none could go before me, when I was going towards her. By Fortune Diana was o neer, as he heard all the dicoure, and therefore addreing her elf unto Sylvander; Shepherd, aid he unto him, thee names of Mitris, and Fairet, and thee expreions of a particular affection, were in eaon as long as the wager lated; but now, let me entreat you to ue them no more, unlee you will di-oblige me: but remember that my name is Diana, and o, I pray, let me be called. Sylvander anwered, That he who deired life no longer then to do her ervice, had rather die then dipleae her: but I beeech you, (aid he) allow me the ret of the day to unaccutome my tongue, before you lay this command upon me; and in the mean time, I mot humbly beeech you, to accept of this Crown which I have won, to the end I may put this day in the Calender, as the happiet I ever yet lived. The Shepherdee who did love this Shepherd, and began to reign that place in her heart which Philander had, he was inclinable to grant his requet: but fearing let her good will would too much appear, he refued it, and had gone away, if Atrea and Alexis had not tayed her; telling her, that Sylvanders requet was o reaonable, that he would offend her own Natural Courteie, if he did refue it: and almot by force, at leat in appearance, made her conent unto it. I wih, aid the Nimph Leonide, that this Chaplet of Flowers, which Diana wears upon her head, were given unto Paris; for otherwie, it will grieve him at the heart, to ee Sylvander's Garland upon the head of his Mitris. That Title Madam (aid Diana) is not my due: but however, I hall conent unto whatoever the Nimph Leonide hall think fit: upon this, taking off the Chaplet of Flowers which he wore upon her own head, and receiving that which Sylvander preented unto her, he et her own upon the head of Paris, and put Sylvanders upon her own head: This caued no mall dipute between Paris, and that Shepherd, to know which of them was mot favoured; but for that time they aid no more: becaue the Sun was very low, which caued them to retire homewards.

Atrea and Alexis walked together: Adamas, Alcidon, and Daphnide, kept together: Phillis was with Lycidas; and Paris entertained Leonide with the dicoure which he formerly begun in the houe of Adams; o as Sylvander addreed himelf with all humility unto Diana: Fairet Mitris (aid he) will you permit me to wait
upon you unto your Houe? Sylvander, aid he, I accept of your curteie; But I would gladly have you accutome your elf betimes to call me by my name. Believe it fair Shepherdes (anwered he) you have no truer Name, then that, when I call you Mitris. For I mot earnetly beeech you to believe, there is nothing under the Sun more certain, then that I am your ervant. Diana who had no mind to be quit of Sylvander, though he aw that he had no reaon to love him, being but a poor unknown tranger, he was at a tand what to do; but thinking that then there was no better way then to eem contented he hould behave himelf the ret of the day as he deired, he anwered him thus; I am contented Sylvander you hould end the remainder of the day, as you began it, ince Alexis and Atrea would have it o. If I thought (anwered he) that when this day is ended, I hould have done loving you; I vow by him that gave me life, I would not live it out. You are permitted (replied Diana) to continue on your way of behaviour, as long as the day lats; but take notice, that the Sun is going to et, and that then the day ends. The day (anwered Sylvander) doth lat as long as there is any light. I confes it, anwered Diana, and therefore within an hour after the Sun is et, there will be no light, nor by conequence, any day to continue the behaviour which your Wager permitted you. Give me leave to tell you, Fairet Mitris, aid he, That no time can limit the ervice which I owe you, nor any forbiddance has power to divert me from that real Affection, which I have vowed unto you: And fairet Shepherdes, Let me further tell you in words of Truth, That this Wager firt began without any other Deign then to conquer Phillis, and for patime unto the company; But ince, thoe perfections which I have found in you, have made it appear, that there is no jeting with Love; and that it is impoible to be long neer a great fire, and not be burned. Sylvander (aid Diana) If you do intend I hould believe thee words, I mut anwer you, That I am o much di-obliged by you, as I cannot tell whether I hall ever forget the wrong, if I did not think you intend to cloe the day according to your Wager: I hall yet receive all you ay, as I have done, ince the difference betwixt Phillis and you began: But when the day is done, Take heed how you anwer me, that I may know what to do; And I heartily entreat you to think well upon it. Sylvander eeing Diana more in earnet then he imagined, and fearing that if he went any further, he hould for ever banih him; he reolved to incene her no farther, but to refer it unto time, which by his long ervices might have better influence upon her; hoping, that perhaps he might be glad of the like occaion to receive his Services, and aurances of his Affection, under the ame cover which he now received them: and therefore looking her full in the face, Fairet Mitris, aid he, The day is not yet done; and when it is, I hall be-think my elf how to anwer you; In the mean time, give me leave to ue the priviledge which you granted me. Upon that account (anwered Diana) I hall mot willingly entertain your Dicoure; But me-thinks you hould begin now to talk as you mut then; for you ee the Sun is almot et. It is long, Mitris, anwered he, before you and I hall come to an accompt; ince the day you have granted me mut lat as long as I live. As you live! replyed Diana, I hou'd be orry your life hould be o hort; and am o much obliged unto you, as to wih it may lat long. Will you be pleaed, Fairet Mitris, aid he, that we make choie of one to regulate this matter betwixt us? Who would you chue? anwered Diana. Whom you hall pleae, replied Sylvander, o it be one that ever in their life loved. Shall we refer it, aid Diana, unto Atrea and Phillis? With all my heart, anwered Sylvander, though I know Phillis to be my enemy. You are mitaken, anwered Diana, and mil'd; for however he eems the contrary, yet there is not one Spepherdes that takes your part more really then he: But I would not have our dipute to be made a publique buines, as that was betwixt Phillis and you; for everal coniderations: Let it be this night, when every one is retired, for we all up this night at Atreas houe, where Phocion does treat Adamas, and Daphnide, and us all; and there we may talk as privately as we pleae.

Oh, what conolation were thee words unto Sylvander! For Dianas deire of ecrecy was an argument unto him, that his buines was upon good terms: And the truth is, The good will of this Shepherdes was by degrees more and more inclinable unto Sylvander; o as though he knew not well what to do, yet it was impoible for her to di-ingage her elf.

In the mean time, Area and Alexis went talking together; and as it is uual in
Dicoure, to pas from one ubject unto another; they fell at lat upon the judgment of Diana. Fair Shepherdes, (aid Alexis unto Atrea) Shall I peak my mind freely unto you? As unto your elf, anwered Atrea. Then, aid Alexis, What do you think of Sylvander's love? I think, anwered he, that this Shepherd is very deeply in love, and that if Diana did not carry her elf very prudently, I hould fear he does not dilike of it. For my part, replied the Druide, I am of opinion that he does not wih him ill. You are not ingular in your opinion, Madam, replied Atrea; for I have oberved that the addrees of this Shepherd are not at all dipleaing unto her; and the truth is, Sylvander is no depieable Shepherd, nor have I met with many of more merit. Upon this he tood ilent, and o did Alexis. At lat Atrea began again, with a deep igh; It is mot certain (aid he) that Diana does love this Shepherd, and both Phillis and my elf are the caue of it; for we did contrain her even by force, to permit Sylvander to make addres unto her; and though it was at the firt in jet, yet it proved afterwards in good earnet; and I foreee, that unles he take good heed, he will not o eaily di-engage her elf as he imagines. Be pleaed to know Madam, that Sylvander is a Shepherd unknown, and nothing beholding unto Fortune, ince he has concealed from him, both his Country, and the knowledge of his Parents: So as Diana, who has as high a mind as any Shepherdes in all the Neighborhood, will never permit Sylvander to erve her openly, be his merits never o great: nor would her Parents, who are the principal of all about the Banks of the Fatal Lignon, allow of it: And yet I ee that Sylvander is o much taken with her Beauty and Perfections, as I dare lay a wager, that nothing in the world, neither the rigour of the Shepherdes, nor the forbiddance of Parents, nor any other obtacle whatoever, can divert him; o as when Diana commanding him to peak no more unto her, as he did, during the wager, he will contrain himelf a little, but it will be abolutely impoible for him to overcome himelf; o as after o many great expreions of his affection, the more he would hide it, the more will he ee it through his contraint. I will not ay any thing of what I have already thought concerning Diana; for loving her as I do, I hould be very orry to ee her any way micarry; and yet conidering the way he takes, it is almot impoible he hould do otherwie. What does he intend to do? asked Alexis. The good opinion which he jutly has of her own merits (anwered Atrea) will not permit her to allow of Sylvander's Courthip, but makes her reolve to have recoure unto thoe extream remedies of forbidding him, which women ue unto uch whoe Courthip is dipleaing unto them. I do not like her way (aid Alexis) and if he follow it, he will repent it: For Sylvander loving her as he does, he will not be diverted by it; and then, as you ay, the buines will become the talk of the Country. But he had better take one of thee two ways, either to let him continue his addrees under the vail of a Fiction; for which excues enough are to be found; or ele permit him ecretly to make his addrees: For I mut confes, Fair Shepherdes, that the Vertues of Diana, and the Merits of Sylvander, makes me deire they may live contentedly, though it be to the diadvantage of Paris my Brother, who I know does love her; but it is better he hould mis of his deires, then by-obtaining them, to make two of o much merit, mierable all the ret of their days: Beides, Diana loving my Brother only by reaons of Etate, Doubtles the los of one o dear unto her as Sylvander is, would make her o full of orrow, and o much change her, that my Brother could not take any great delight in her: And though this do at the firt dipleae Paris, yet he will better pas it over then Sylvander can, having not o violent an affection unto Diana as that Shepherd hath. Moreover, we hall more eaily divert him from it, by propounding ome other marriage unto him, more utable unto his quality.

In uch dicoure as this, they came unto the Town of Phocion, who received them very kindly, and treated them with o neat a upper; that Alcidon and Daphnide confeed, he hamed the great Cities. But Atrea was not o well contented as he deired: For Phocion had young Calidon there, and et him at the Table jut oppoite unto her: This young Shepherd was o paionately in Love, that his eyes were never off her; which troubled Atrea extreamly: for he could never look up, but till met with his eye upon her. Alexis, who was of Calidons mind, did the very ame, though with much more atisfaction unto Atrea, who alo could not atisfie her eyes with looking upon Celadon under the umbrage of a woman: But Alexis had the advantage of Calidon,
for having Atrea on her ide, they could talk together and not be heard, which they did almot all upper while: And becaue Alexis oberved the eyes of Calidon, he aid unto Astrea: Fair Shepherdee do you not think that you it in a very ill place? I hall never think o, anwered Atrea, as long as I am o neer you, which is the greatet contentment I can have; but I wih that ome troubleome eyes which are continually on my face, were turned ome other way, or ele that the owner of them were further off. The trouble which you endure, aid Alexis, is a conequent of your beauty; and you mut not think it trange, that Shepherds hould Love you, ince I who am a woman, and one who never aw you before this three or four dayes, am o extreamly taken with you, that I think my elf in Love with you. As Alexis poke thee words he changed countenance: The Zeal of her expreion, or her fear of peaking too plainly, was the caue of it. Astrea anwered her with a miling eye, I wih with all my heart Madam, that there were any thing in me which might do you any real ervice, and ingratiate me into your favour: For I am o perfectly yours that nothing but death can ever me from you and I think the happines of it o great, that I would not change contentment with all the Kings, Emperors, and Monarchs upon earth. Alexis fearing that if thee expreions continued, hearers would think they talked too paionately for women, he took her hand, and wipered unto her, I will ooner refue life then this aurance you give me: but for ome reaons which afterwards I will tell you, let us break off this dicoure, and talk of it at night when we are alone, or to morrow when we walk in the woods.

After upper ended, and tables removed, many Neighboring young Shepherds came to dance and ing, and rejoyce, for finding the Misletoe of the New-year, for o they called it. And becaue Daphnide and Alcidon were deirous to be pectators of their harmlee ports, they deired Adamas he would be pleaed they might wa •• out and ee the Shepherds and Fair Shepherdees dance. Adamas who was willing to give them all poible atisfaction, he took Daphnide by the hand, and led her forth, leaving Leonide to conduct Alcidon, and all the ret of the Company, who followed them into a great room, where uch publique rejoycings were wont to be kept, and where they found abundance of Shepherds and Shepherdees dancing and inging.

The Sun had been long et, and no day appeared; but the Moon hined o cleer, as if he had borrowed more light then uual, purpoely for that night: Daphnide was much taken with the pleaantnes of the place, and coolnes of the air: And all itting down, ome on one ide, ome on another, they began to dance and ing, and performed their parts o handomly, that Daphnide and Alcidon could not chue but admire the Shepherds and Shepherdees of Lignon. After they had danced half an hour, there came from the neighboring Towns, a company of Shepherds diguied in the habit of Egyptians, who danced after the manner of that people: And as they had been formerly taught by Alcippe the father of Celadon, upon his return from his long travels, they danced unto ongs, and ang as they danced: And when they had done, they went unto all the company, and offered to tell the Fortunes of all uch who would hew them their hands. This patime having lated long, and it being almot midnight, Adamas thought it time to retire: So as they all parted, and went unto their Towns, Phocion carried unto his houe, Adamas, Paris, Alexis, and Leonide, being very orry that his houe was not of capacity to lodge Daphnide and Alcidon with their company alo. But Adamas thinking before hand that he could not do it with any conveniency, he appointed Lycidas to lodg them in the houe of Celadon, where Diamis his uncle expected them; but by reaon of his old age left the management of all things unto Lycidas, which that Shepherd did perform very exactly, though he was extreamly perplexed, that he could not have the company of his dear Phillis in his houe: For he told him, that if he would bid thoe trangers welcome, he would go with Atrea, and lye with her.

Thus every one retired to their lodgings, Atrea, Diana, and Phillis being attended by Sylvander, they carryed Adamas unto Atreas houe, where Phocion tayed to bid them welcome as well as he could. The Chambers were ordered thus; Adamas and Paris did lie in one, where Phocion was wont to lie; Alexis and Leonide were ordered to lie in that which was wont to be Atreas, and Atrea took another. When Adamas undertood that the chambers were thus ordered, he did not like that Alexis and Leonide hould be alone together in a chamber, fearing let the Female Druide, hould, by a
miracle of Love become a Shepherd, and let Leonide, whom he knew did not hate Celadon, hould carres Alexis o much, as to make him cat off his Druides habit: And therefore, taking Leonide aide, he aid unto her, that when all the Shepherdees were retired, he would have Alexis come ecretly, and lie in his chamber; and though there was but two beds in it, yet it was no matter; for Paris hould lie with him, and Alexis hould lie in the other.
