I thought upon that before, (anwered the Nimph) but I thought it not expedient, becaue ome of the houe might perhaps come in and ee her, which would be no mall candal: beides, Paris perhaps might take notice of her. What coure (replied Adamas) would you then take? For I do not think you can find a better way: Pardon me good father, replied he; I conceive it much better for Atrea and I to lie together in one bed, and Alexis in the other.

But perhaps (aid Adamas) that Atrea loving Alexis better then he does you, he will deire to lye with her rather then with you. If he needs will do o, anwered the Nimph, then let her, and I will take the other bed: but you may do as I ay very eaily; for if you come under pretence of eeing us: you may ay it is unreaonable we hould put Atrea out of her Chamber, that it is enough you have diplaced Phocion out of his, and o you may appoint that Atrea and I hould lye together, pretending that the daughters of Druides never ue to lye with any, but by themelves. Adamas thought this invention to be good: And Phocion being retired, he commanded Paris to go to bed, and then he came to viit Alexis and Leonide; but he found the Chamber fuller then he expected, there being with Atrea, Diana and Sylvander, who was dicouring upon his difference with Diana, when the Druide entred: Daughters, aid he, I come to ee how you are lodged, but I perceive you are very troubleome unto the Fair Atrea, for I undertand that it is her Chamber. It is true Sir, anwered Atrea, but both my Chamber and my elf are much honoured in that we are able to do any ervice unto uch whom I love o infinitely. Daughter, replied Adamas, I will not upon any termes uffer you to go out of it; Leonide and you may lye together; and did not the Laws of Druides daughters forbid it, I hould intreat the Fair Diana take half of a bed with Alexis. Father, aid Leonide, the bed is o large, as we may lye all three together without any trouble. And becaue Atrea out of repect unto the Nimph, eemed not to be willing. No, no, replied Adamas, Leonide and my daughter hall go into my Chamber, were we will lye as well as we can, unlee you reolve to lye altogether, for I will not by any means, you hould have any other Chamber then this, Diana, then eeing it was the will of Adamas, gave her conent, and Atrea, eeing Diana conented, obeyed the Druide: All this while Alexis tood mute, o amazed to ee her elf in Atreas houe, and to lye with her, though not in the ame bed, yet in the ame Chamber with her, as he thought this to be a fault unpardonable if ever it was known unto her. Adamas oberving it when he bad good night unto all the ret, took her hand and aid unto her. I think daughter, the length of the way has much wearied you, it is good for you to lie long in bed to morrow, and ret your elf; for Phocion has deired me to retain Daphnide and Alcidon here two or three dayes, o as if you be but ready againt dinner it is time enough: Afterwards he whipered her in the ear; Alexis, (aid he) what makes you o ad? Take heed you do not poil the plot which we have thus far carried on o well; and from which you may expect o much contentment. Then Adamas retired to his Chamber, leaving Alexis o atonihed that Atrea took notice of it; and believing that the length of the way had done her ome harm, he hewed abundance of orrow to ee her in that condition. But Leonide who knew well enough where her hooe did pinch her, did anwer for her; No, no, Atrea, aid he, never trouble your elf, her pain will be quickly over: I have een her often in thee fits, and well again preently. But me thinks (aid he and turned towards Sylvander) that it is time for this Shepherd to retire, it being not long before it will be day. Madam, anwered Sylvander, I hall be quickly gone, o I may but carry with me what I brought hither. Diana knowing that he meant her; Shepherd aid he, I do not intend to tir from hence this night, but I will put Phillis in my room whom you may wait upon home as if it was my elf, and to morrow I will expect you give me an account of her
here, where I promie to expect you about ten or eleven of the clock in the morning: What power, I beeech you, anwered Sylvander, have you to give her unto me? The ame power, replied Diana, that he has to dipoe of me, when he pleaeth. I had rather, replied he, tat her liberality then yours. It is enough for this time (aid Leonide) that Diana to hew what an abolute victory you have gotten, does let you carry your enemie away as a prioner. I had rather Madam, replied Sylvander, be a prioner unto her, who gave me the victory, and be tyed never to tir from her, then to be the Conqueror of this enemy, whom he hath put into my hands. Phillis offered to reply, when Lycidas, according to his promie, came to wait upon her; and then looing her elf from the hands of Sylvander, ee ungrateful Shepherd, aid he unto him, how the Heavens does punih you! I have now nothing to do with you, and before you get me your prioner again, you mut provide better Arms. Upon this, bidding good night unto Alexis and Leonide, and kiing Atrea and Diana, being very orry (as he aid) to leave them, though indeed contrained for want of room, he went to her own houe, and was conducted by Lycidas and Sylvander, who according to their cutome, did wrangle and argue, all the way.

In the interim, Atrea was o buie, and officious about her dear Alexis, in helping to undree her, as he would not uffer her to unpin, one pin; and the Druide was willing to allow it as long as poibly he could: but when he came to put off her Gown, fearing let he hould find ome fault with her brets, he beckned unto Leonide; who knowing what he meant, came unto Atrea: Come, come, Fair Shepherdee, (aid he unto her) let us undres our elves, for I ee you do but trouble my iter, and will trouble her more, unles vve make hat to bed; for he has a cutome to fall a leep immediately; and if we do not the like, we hall awake her, and then he can leep no more that night; therefore let us make all the hat to bed vve can, leat vve hould diturb he • This caued Atrea to vvithdraw, and give the Druide time to undres her elf, and get into bed uneen. Her hair, which he let grow vvhilet he was in her cave, and ever ince he had the name of Alexis, vvas now o long as might vvell become a vvoman; and if he had but any reaonable care in dreing her elf, he might eaily make it pas: but it vvas impoible for her, to remedy her brets, and therefore he took all poible care to hide them, though it vvas a hard matter to conceal them from any that vvould take any particular notice. Having therefore pinned her mock before her brets, and at the leeves, he drew the Curtaines towards that ide where Atrea undreed her elf; and calling Leonide, iter (aid he) you vvill much oblige me, if you come hither and undres your elf by my bed-ide, to keep me from leeping untill you be all in bed; Leonide vvho knew the reaon vvhy he aid o: I vvill iter (anwered he) but then I mut have thee fair ones to keep me company; then all three came unto her bed-ide: Leonide did it in chair, Atrea upon the bed, vvhilet Diana went unto the table, to reach omething vvhich Leonide left: Alexis, raiing her elf up in her bed, he helped Atrea to undree her, one vvhile taking off a knot, another vvhile unpinning a pin, and Atrea vvould ometimes kie the hand of Alexis as it paed neer her mouth; and Alexis in requital of the favour, vvould kis that part of her own hand vvhich Atrea kied; o ravihed vvith joy, and contentment, that Leonide took great delight in eeing uch exces of happines. A great part of the night vvas thus pent, and had they not heard thoe birds, vvhich ue to rejoyce at the approach of day, they had hardly parted o oon: but Leonide with much ado, caued Alexis to let Atrea go; vvho being all undreed at her beds feet, Alexis aw her naked arm, as vvhite as any Aliblater, and alo her naked brets, as vvhich no Snow had o perfect a vvhite: Love vvounded the heart of Celadon mot deeply, at the ight of thee: How oft vvas this diguied Druide in a mind to lay aide the habit of a vvoman, and become a Shepherd? And how oft did he again check himelf for his boldnee? At lat, Leonide, vvho oberved his raptures, and diorder, thought fit to part them. And bidding the lat good night unto her iter, hee vvith Atrea, and Diana, vvent to bed, leaving poor Alexis alone in appearance; but indeed o accompanied, that it vvas impoible for her to cloe an eye: So as it being light day, and he not able to leep, he cat her eye upon the
bed where Atrea lay; it being very hot weather, in the beginning of July, thee Fair ones left their Curtains open; and the Sun dipered its Rays o plendidly into the Chamber, that the curious eye of this diguied Druide, might eaily ee Atrea, who by chance lay almot out of the bed; Leonide lay in the midt; that, as he aid, he might make it her boat, he had lain between two of the greatet Beauties in the whole world: And indeed, he did o; for never was two different Beauties more exactly perfect then thee two. Judge then what a Viion had Alexis, when he aw Atrea thus; one of her Arms hung carelely out of the Bed, and hardly any difference could be found betwixt her mock and it in whitenes; her other Arm lay under her head, and caued the right ide of her Breat to lie naked, with which the Sun eemed to be in love, and kied, by hining upon it. O Love! How many everal ways thou hat to torment thoe who are thy Subjects! How didt thou treat this Shepherd in his olitary Cave, when being deprived of the ight of his Shepherdes, thou madet him to lament his abence from this Fair one? And at this time, How dot thou torment him with too much light, and blinding his eyes by two Suns; o as whether abent or preent, he is till tormented? This thought did o poes the mind of Alexis, that before ever he took any notice of it, the Sun was a great height; And had not Atrea by chance turned on the other ide, and by that means taking this pleaant Viion from his eye, doubtles he had looked longer: but being deprived of the light of this glorious Sun, he thought her elf in darknes, and that the other Sun gave no light. At the lat, not being able to abide in thee impatiences, he aroe oftly out of her bed, dres'd her elf without any noie, and went unto the bed of Atrea, who was turned towards Leonide, with her right Arm over her, and her cheek upon her houlder. What jealouie, or rather, what envie did he not conceive againt this Nymph? Oh heavens! (aid he unto her elf) too happy Leonide, how cant thou leep, and have uch a glorious occaion to wake? Cant thou hut thy eyes, and employ them upon any thing then looking upon this Beauty, which every one ought to adore? Then taying a while mute; What extream Injutice is in the Fate of things here below? (replyed he preently after) Why hould this inenible Nymph have a happines which he cannot enjoy? And why hould I who am infinitely deirous of it, be thus unjutly deprived? Then folding her Arms upon her Breat, he retired back a pace or two, not removing her eye from this pleaing object: And after he had long contemplated upon it; Oh Atrea (aid he a little louder) will you never recal me from my banihment? And mut I, without knowing the caue, Live continually in your preence, as if I were ditant from you? But againt whom hould I complain, ince Fortune has brought me nearer my happines, then ever I could expect or hope for? And why hould I not try Fortune a little further? Perhaps he will as well give me as high contentment, as before he dejected me into the Abys of miery: Courage Shepherd, why art thou o fearful to approach this Fair one? Why dot thou not beg her pardon, and retore Celadon unto her, whom thou hat toln from her under the habit of Alexis? Say unto her, Here is the Shepherd whom you o much loved; Here is Celadon that has given you his heart, and all that's his: You did once love him; and if Celadon has done any thing which hath offended you, then open this Breat which he here preents unto you, and take that which is your own, his heart; which mot certainly never conented unto any thing that could offend you. As thou ayet thus unto her, fall down upon thy knees, and preent thy naked Breat unto her, that if he pleae, he may take that heart which loves and adores her, and which cannot ret until it be in her fair hands. Upon this Alexis all in a rapture, tepped forward, as if he did intend to effect his thoughts; and perhaps had now dicovered himelf, had he not upon a udden reprehended himelf thus. Oh Celadon (aid he) cant thou be thus diobedient unto the command of this Shepherdes? Mut thou be upbraided with failing in the Laws of perfect Love? Hat thou thus long erved this Fair one with untained affection, and now by an imprudent and rah Act, which will bring thee too late repentance, poil all? O Celadon, Dot thou not remember thee words? Go diloyal Lover, and never ee me again, till I command thee; Cant thou (I ay) remember this, and have o little affection as to dare to diobey? No, no (a • d he) Die, die firt, and carry to the grave a pure and innocent love, without any tain or reproach.

Upon this, with teares in her eyes, he went out of the chamber to view thoe places where formerly he had received o much contentment, and to ask an account of all thoe ighes and deires which he had o often committed to their cutody. At firt he went into the garden, through which an arm of the River Lignon runs: Then looked upon the Fountain, which is in the midt of it; over which tands the Goddee Ceres upon an Arch, upported by great Columns; and under which is a great Bain, reembling a Crown, that receives this pleaant ource. Approching unto this Fountain, he there wahed her hands, and her face, as formerly he was wont; and looking upon it, here is the very place, aid he, where Atrea has o often vowed eternal affection unto me. This is the Fountain where taking my hand in hers, he wore that he would ooner ceae to live then ceae to love Celadon: Then tepping forward with a trembling pace to the bain which held the water, here are the Letters of our Names, aid he, engraved by her own hand; Oh ye witnees of my extream affection! and now ye jut accuers of the fairet Shepherds in the world, why are you not defaced out of this Marble, as well as out of her heart? Or do you remain here till to upbraid her with her change? Then going from this Fountain, he went into a little wood of Haels, where the walks are contrived with o many turnings and windings, that they will deceive thoe that walk in them, and make them loe their way in going out again. This was the place which brought into his memory his pat happines, which he now reented o bitterly, that his teares did tetifie his grief: For it was in this little wood, where he was wont to talk often with his Fair Shepherdee, when their Parents even weary with croing their loves, did permit them more liberty of eeing each other, and talking together, then before they ued. Calling into memory therefore all the paions which he reented in that place, and all the vowes of fidelity which he received from her Shepherdee, he could not chue, but wonder that he could forget all the vowes and oathes which he had worn in that place.

This thought entertained her a long while, not without the company of many a igh, and many a tear; and had not her walk conducted her before he was aware unto the ide of that arm of the River Lignon, which ran about all the Garden, he had not o oon got out: but the ight of this River did o frehly revive the memory of her former happinee, as he could not chue but it down upon the bank, and was o much tranported out of her elf, as it was a long time before he knew where he was.

All this while he did not remember that perhaps Atrea would wake, and that Leonide and he, not finding her in the chamber, would wonder extreamly what was become of her. And o it hapned; for it being already late enough Atrea wakned, and the Sun hining very gloriouly into the room, he looked towards the bed of Alexis: but eeing all the Curtaines open and none in bed, he raied her elf a little higher in the bed to look a little better, and eeing he was not there, he could not chue but igh o loud that Leonide heard her, and asked her whether he was ick: No, anwered Atrea, but I am troubled that I cannot ee Alexis in the bed where he lay the lat night; How! aid Leonide, and tarted up, is hee not there? Then raiing her elf a little, and finding it true, and that the door was open: what in the name of Heaven is become of her? aid he. I beleeve, aid Diana, that he is gone to walk before the heat of the day begin: Leonide was afraid that the melancholy humour of Celadon might make Alexis take up ome new reolution: yet leat he hould dicover too much of her thoughts unto thee Shepherdees; I beeech you, aid he, unto them, let me dree my elf as oon as I can, and ee if I can find her: for if Adamas hould know that I let her go alone, he would be very angry with me: The Shepherdees roe all out of bed, and made uch hat, that they were ready before the Nimph although he made all the hat that poibly he could. And going by Fortune out of the ame door, which opened into the Garden, they went unto the Fountain of Ceres, which Leonide found to be a very fine piece, and exquiitly wrought: From thence they went forward into the grove of Hazels, and as if they were guided through that Labyrinth by the thred of Ariadne, they came directly to the River ide, where Alexis was lying upon the ground; and as fortune would have, it was riing up to view the ret of
thoe places, where he had left o many marks of her former contentments, and extream affection. Astrea pied her firt, and hewing her unto the Nimph, aid unto her, I think Madam, that Diana can divine; for ee where the Druide is walking all alone upon the banks of the water, which runs into that fatal River of Lignon, Leonide then eeing that Alexis had no uch intention as he feared, he was very joyfull: but as he was advancing towards her, he heard one call upon her, and turning her elf about, he aw it was Paris, who eemed a far off very deirous to peak with her; and becaue he knew not what his buinee might be, and perhaps it might be uch as was not for Diana to hear: Fair ones, aid he, I beeech you go you unto Alexis, and tay with her, whilet I go and ee what buinee Paris hath with me. The Shepherdees were very glad of this commiion; for Atrea longed to ee the face of Celadon in that Druide, whoe voice, words and getures, were o reemblant unto that Shepherd, as he took extream delight in her company: and Diana was glad alo to be thus rid of Paris, as well becaue he did not love him, as becaue love made her think very well of Sylvander, and he could not permit her eares to hearken unto any words of affection, which came from any mouth but of that kind Shepherd.

Leonide then went to meet Paris; and the two Shepherdees went towards the diguied Druide, whom they found looking upon an old willow which time had decayed, and which retained no more of it elf but a hollow bulk, and a withered bark: Oh Willow! aid Alexis to her elf, what is become of thee letters which I truted thee with all? And why dot thou not render me the ame good offices thou wert wont, in auring me of my Shepherdees good will? For thou eet me now with no les love nor les affection then I had at that time: Oh beloved Willow, I know thy meaning, for had the heart of my Fairet Shepherdee retained the memory of my ervices, thou vvouldt have till retained thoe characters, vvhich vvere the dear tetimonies of her good will; but I ee that time has vvorn both thee, and them, out of her thoughts; had he poken thee words any louder, the Shepherdees had heard them; but as luck was, he expreed them unto her elf only in thought: And becaue they were unwilling to interrupt thoe pleaing imaginations, vvhich they thought he fancied, they topped; and vvhen the Druide vvalked, they did the like, not vvith any intention to dicover any thoughts of her oul, but only let they hould divert her by their preence from that which he thought mot pleaing; Alexis then, thinking her elf alone, continued on her thoughts, and likevvie her vvalk along the River ide, until he found a Tree on her right hand, where two dayes before her unfortunate accident, he had engraved ome veres, which tetified vvith how much contraint he courted the Shepherdee Aminthe; and cating her eyes thereupon, Oh how this ight did vvound her memory!

Perhaps the reading of thoe vvords had made her peak omething o loud as to be heard by thoe Shepherdees, which followed her, if by fortune Sylvander at the ame time had not a far off began to ing; and the voice came o ditinctly towards them, that Alexis turning her head that way, epied the Shepherdees cloe by her; hee vvas orry to ee them o neer, and perceive them no ooner, fearing let her paion had made her utter ome vvord, or ue ome action, vvhich might dicover vvhat he deired to conceal: But that which mot troubled her vvas her eyes, vvhich vvere full of tears, and which being o urpried he could not hide; yet faining not to ee them, he turned the other way, and vviped her eyes as well as he could, and then etting a good face upon it, he came unto them, and bad them good morrow, calling them luggards, and faining he could not leep, becaue the pretty birds began to ing o weety at her chamber-window: It was rather Madam, anwered Atrea, becaue they troubled you. No indeed, anwered Alexis, for I took o much delight in their Muick: that I could not chue but rie to hear them more plainly as I walked by this River ide; and I think the time o hort, that it eems not above a quarter of an hour ince I came hither. But Madam (anwered Diana) you have lept o little, that I fear it will do you ome injury: It is true indeed, anwered Alexis, and you may ee my eyes have done pennance for it; but I was o much delighted in hearing the warble of thee pretty birds, and in taking the freh ayr, that it is impoible to receive any harm. The
bet remedy will be, replied Atrea, to go to bed betimes at night, that you may enjoy your ret and leep before the day do break, and before thee little chanters of the wood begin to ing; and then we hall Madam be glad to bear you company, and carry you unto places which are better furnihed with this kind of harmony. Alexis offered to reply when Sylvander began to ing, and becaue they pied Phillis coming towards them, they tayed for her, whilet Sylvander ung. Phillis being come unto them; after he had aluted the Druide and her company: Madam, aid he, how do you like this Shepherds voice? I like it very well, anwered Alexis, and think him to be a very well accomplihed Shepherd, and a very perfect lover. Madam, (anwered Diana, and both miled and bluhed) perhaps you may be mitaken in your judgement of him; for the Shepherds of Lignon, do often hide diembling ouls under the innocent habit which they wear. Perhaps indeed, replied the Druide, that this may be o in ome, but I am mot confident, I am not mitaken in my opinion of this Shepherd. Tell her Madam (aid Phillis, and interrupted her) that he her elf thinks the ame; and that if the Shepherdees of Lignon were not greater diemblers then this Shepherd, he would not have poken o as he did. Siter replied Diana, I am much beholding to your rallary: for peaking thus of me in the preence of this Druide, you will infue a trange opinion of me into her. Do not fear (aid Alexis and miled) that thee words can make me believe any thing of you but good: I know the virtue and merits of Diana very well; beides, diimulation is ometimes o neceary unto our ex: as it may well be taken for a kind of virtue. But ince we have gone o far, give me leave to tell you out of my affection to you, what Phillis hath formerly aid unto your dear friend here, upon the ame ubject: Madam, anwered Diana, you will do me an honour in it, but the wort is, I fear it is nothing worthy of your paines, which you can tell me that concerns my elf. I make no doubt, wie Shepherdee (aid Alexis) but you have often heard the ame which I hall tell you: but becaue we are all oftentimes partiall in our caues, and becaue the advice of friends will do no harm, I will tell you what dicoure Atrea and I, had yeterday, concerning you: and I hall deire Phillis alo to give her advice, becaue I know you have a great confidence in them both. Upon this, he related unto Diana all the coniderations which they had upon Sylvanders love: and after they had all concluded, that it was no fiction nor by reaon of the wager, but reall and in good earnet, he continued thus: Now Fair Diana, it concerns you to conider well upon it; as for Sylvander, to love or not to love you, does not depend upon him, he has but the choice of thee two wayes, either to grieve, or to live happily with you, even as you hall appoint.

But upon you does depend not only his miery, and his happinee, but your own alo: And though I may believe that perhaps you are not enible of thoe torments, which his love inflicts upon him; yet I conceive it very hard that one hould be loved, and erved o dicreetly by uch a very excellently qualified Shepherd, and have no park of good will towards him: but however it be, can you think to exempt your elf from all the torment of it? And that you are not acceary unto his? You are mitaken, wie Shepherdee, if you be in that opinion; for if you hould forbid him to love you, you may as well do nothing; for you may be certain he will not obey: and if by any rigorous language, you command him to get out of your ight, then the violence of his affection, will o divulge it elf all over the Country, as perhaps not a Shepherd but will know it: So as I ee the inconvenience is unevitable, unlee you reolve upon ome wie expedient. All thoe that know Sylvander, do think him a Shepherd o amiable, as they think there is not a Shepherdee, but may well daign to love him, and that the Shepherdee whom he loves may, if he have any wit, very well do the like: what opinion then will the world have of Diana, whom every one knows to have wit, and judgement, when they ee how this Shepherd loves her, erves her, and adores her with o much affection? I hall by way of advice propoe two wayes unto you, the one of which I conceive more afe then the other: The one way is, ince I ee it a thing impoible to divert this Shepherd from his affection to you, permit him to erve you ecretly; and this permiion will be a way by joyning his prudence unto yours, to hide this affection from all uch as have nothing ele to do, but cenure and p • y into the actions
of others. But if you do not love this Shepherd, this counel is naught; becaue this ecret correpondency will oblige you unto certain indulgencies, and tetimonies of affection, which may cot you very dear: Therefore I conceive this other expedient to be better; Let him continue that guie in which he hath hitherto erved you; by this permiion, his flame will not flah with uch violence: and if by fortune it hould o break out that every one takes notice of it, they wil not at all think it trange, becaue he is already accutomed unto it: and his Courthip being under that pretence of diimulation, they will not think he loves you in earnet: I know there will be ome malevolent minds that will be pending their cenures, but who can avoid the lah of uch tongues? But mot will not believe it: And the bet thing of this way is, you will not be obliged unto him: For there is nothing o dangerous, as for a woman to commit her elf unto the dicretion of him he loves; becaue mot men being naturally of a wavering temper, when they change their affection, they will not for all that loe the memory of things pat; but on the contrary, thinking to make themelves the more eteemed, they blaze them abroad, and brag how much they have been loved by uch a one; and the bad condition of our age being as it is, and people more apt to believe the evil then the good, it is preently believed that uch a woman is a very loving oul, who will love more then he is loved. Now Fair Diana, by permitting him to continue his guie of diimulation, you will not be in any danger this way, becaue you are not obliged to render him any knowledge of your good will: But on the contrary, may take his real affection as if it were Fiction, and he cannot complain againt you. This alo is another thing coniderable in this coure: I know very well that Diana has a little vanity, and good reaon has he for it, being a Sherherdes o full of perfections, and the principal in all this Country; on the contrary, Sylvander being a peron unknown, and Owner of no Fortune but what his own Indutry can get, I am afraid that Diana would bluh if any hould ee her allow of any real addres from a Shepherd o much her inferiour. But fair Shepherdes, you are by this expedient, exempt from this inconveniency, having a good excue when you receive his complements of Love, as if all were but in jet, to exercie his wit, and harpen it with feigned conceptions of an imaginary Love.

Thus Alexis ended; and when Diana would have anwered, Atrea interrupted her: Nay, nay Siter (aid he) there is no more to be aid, after this fair Druide; She has cleared all doubts that could poibly be foreeen, and fully anwered them, o as I hall not think you to be o wie as I ever took you, if you do not follow her counel; Phillis I am confident will be of the ame opinion. But one thing does a little cruple me, againt which a remedy may haply be applyed; which is, That if Diana do permit this diguied Courthip of this Shepherd, he mut have a good occaion for the permiion, otherwie I am afraid the Artifice hould be dicovered: And you know, Madam, that if one he found jugling in one trick, all the ret of their actions will be upected. Never trouble your elf (aid Phillis) about that, for Sylvander himelf did yeterday give an excellent occaion to colour the permiion: For Diana told me, the lat night when we were retired, that Sylvander having obtained leave to continue his Courthip all the ret of the day, he pretended that this permiion was to lat alwaies; and both he and he falling in difference about it, the buines was referred unto Atrea and my elf; and hould have been determined that ame night: But becaue Diana was not willing the matter hould be argued in Publique, and both you, Madam, and Leonide being in the chamber, the difference was deferred until another time; and Sylvander accompanying me to my Lodging, he told me how glad he hould be if it could be deferred, becaue till then he might enjoy his Priviledge: There is no neceity therefore, that the buines hould be made o private; but on the contrary, I am of opinion, that the matter is to be argued in ome publique place; to the end, that when all do ee Sylvander continue his addrees to Diana, they may know it is upon the old core as he begun it.

Alexis and Atrea did very well approve of this advice; and Diana, who perhaps did like of it as well as they, and till then tood mute, he eemed to be convinced by the reaons of Alexis, and the approbation of her two dear friends; o as it was reolved, that the difference hould come to hearing at uch a time when Adamas, Alcidon,
and Daphnide were preent; and that Atrea and Phillis hould give judgment in the behalf of Sylvander.

As fortune was, Sylvander hearing the voices of thee fair Shepherdees o near him, he turned that way, and pied them; and eeing all their backs towards him, being prompted by a Lovers curioity, he got as near them as he could uneen; and creeping upon the ground, he got behind a Buh which was within two or three paces of the place where they were et; o litning attentively, he heard what Alexis had propounded, and what was reolved upon. Oh how much did he think himelf obliged unto that fair Druide, for giving uch counel unto Diana? And when they went away, he did accompany them with a thouand wihes of happines: and when he aw them o far off as they could not think he heard them, he roe up and followed; and to make them look back, he began to play upon his Corner.

Alexis who loved this Shepherd very well, as one whom he ranked in the catalogue of her bet friends: Come Sylvander (aid he unto him) Do you not think your elf much obliged unto me for bringing the fair Diana hither? For had I not been, he would have been till in her chamber, and you deprived of your happines in eeing her. Madam, anwered the Shepherd, you cannot do me o great a favour, as I expected always from your fair face. Why (aid Alexis) does my face promie you o much? Yes Madam (replyed Sylvander) for it has uch a lively reemblance of a Shepherd who would have expoed his life for my contentment, as I can think no les. I am very glad (anwered Alexis) that Nature has been o favourable unto me, as to make me like unto any whom you love; for I make no doubt, but though I do not deerve it, yet you will love me for his ake. Madam, replied Sylvander, were he alive, I hould love him for your ake; your merits being o high. as not to yeild unto any: And to let you ee the truth of my words, I will put my life into your hands, if you will be pleaed to take o much pains as to judge a difference which is dearer unto me then my life. Shepherd, replied Diana, Why would you change the Judges which you have already choen? Not but that I am willing to ubmit unto whatoever the fair Alexis hall ordain; but me-thinks it is a igne you know your caue to be bad, and would corrupt your Judges by flatteries, and reject thoe who are already choen. I did not think, fairet Mitris, anwered Sylvander, That any praies which one could give unto this fair Lady, was eteemed flattery; for merit cannot be flattered, nor can any flattery equal her perfections. I would not have you think I refue thoe Judges which you were pleaed to chue; But I propounded this fair Druide only to be an Umpire in cae thoe two Judges cannot agree amongt themelves; and that then he hould ordain what he thought mot cononant to Jutice. I cannot deny (anwered Diana) the advantagious language which you give of this fair Lady, nor any commendation that can be given her, and therefore I do mot willingly accept her for our Umpire.

Sylvander would have replied, had they not een coming Adamas, Daphnide, Alcidon, and all the company which upped the night before at the houe of old Phocion, except Leonide and Paris, who parted from the ret of the company, to finih the dicoure which they had begun in the houe of Adamas: for Paris adoring Diana beyond all meaure, and having received from her another kind of anwer then he deired, he would take Leonides counel in the buines; and he being very affectionate to him, was willing to give him the bet advice he could: And therefore retiring themelves into the Grove of Hazles, Brother (aid he unto him) I have twice deferred the giving you my opinion in the buines whereof you poke, hoping that time would alter your mind; but now, ince I ee nothing will work any alteration in it: I beeech you tell me what your intention is. Siter, replied Paris, my intention is, to Court Diana in the way of marriage. And do you think (aid Leonide) that Adamas will approve of it, for you ought to have a pecial conideration of that? I have not exprely acquainted him with it (aid Paris) but he knows that I do love her, and does not diapprove of it. This (anwered Leonide) is not enough; you ought to acquaint him with it eriouly, and ask his conent. In the econd place, which indeed ought to be the firt, you ought to conider eriouly with your elf, whether this marriage be fit and convenient for you: For Love is a partial Judge, and many things are handome in a Mitris, which are inufferable in
a Wife. Oh Brother, there is abundance of difference betwixt Love and Marriage: for Love lats no longer then one pleaeth, but Marriage mut continue long, and therefore is more dipleaing: Love is an Embleme of Liberty, becaue it never forceth the Will; but Marriage on the contrary is an Embleme of ervitude; becaue nothing but death can break the Bonds. 'Tis true, when a marriage is made between fit and utable perons, I believe there is no greater happines amongt mortals, becaue all joys and contentments are doubled; the joy of the one, is the joy of the other: And becaue uch is the miery of all Mortals, as they are ubject unto a thouand diaters of Fortune, a faithful companion in marriage, does help to bear the burthen of them. To be brief, it is almot impoible to enjoy any compleat happines without a econd elf, unto whom all things may be communicated. But Paris, give me leave to tell you, that the man who marries, mut not conult altogether with his eyes, or his deires; but with his reaon and judgement; and you mut conider whether there be any thing deirable in Diana beides her Beauty, not only as a Mitris, but alo as a Wife: For Beauty does ordinarily deceive, and is often like an Inn-igne before a poor Inn, where no good accomodations can be had. Beauty reembles thoe Spectacles which makes every thing look greater then they are, and is at bet but a fair fading Flower, which when once decayed, and one is tyed unto it, repentance comes too late: So much in conideration of Beauty. Then Brother, Great heed mut be taken that nothing be done which may redound unto your dihonour and reproach; You are on unto the Grand Druide; Diana I mut needs confes is a Shepherdes of much merit, but yet he is a Shepherdes; and do you think that uch Alliance will not be much wondred at? We are not born for our elves; we mut omtimes leave our own contentment, for the atisfaction of thoe who love us, and thoe unto whom we are obliged: Conider Brother, that Marriage is the happines or the miery of every one: and therefore be not too rah in your actions. But to wave all thee coniderations, this only is enough for all: That one had better be a Gally-lave, and be tyed to erve a Tyrant, then marry one that loves him not; Imagine Brother, What delight can one find in eating, or drinking, lying, or leeping with his enemy? It is requiite therefore that you know her mind; For if he do love another, or cannot love you, I would advie you to marry a grave, rather then Diana. Think well upon all thee things; and after you have eriouly conidered them, tell me what you think of them, then I will further tell you what I conceive bet to be done.

Paris hearing Leonide peak with o much conideration and eagernes, did think at firt that he had ome deigne to marry him omwhere ele, and therefore deired to divert him from Diana; But afterwards eriouly conidering her reaons, and finding much olidity in them, he altered his opinion, and found that all he aid proceeded from her affection to him: and therefore he returned her this anwer: That it was true, he ought to acquaint Adamas with his intention; That he did not doubt but to find him a very good Father, as formerly he had upon all other occaions: That as for the conditions of Diana, It was meer folly to dipute upon a thing that was already reolved: and that he could as well live without a oul, as live happily without her; and that this did anwer all thoe coniderations. That as for the approbation of his Parents, he thought none of them did love him better then he did himelf, and that therefore he was obliged to atisfie and content himelf before any Kindred or Friends. That as for the good Will and Affection of Diana; It is true indeed, Siter (aid he) I mut ask your counel upon that point; for you being a woman as he is, you may better judge of her intention then I, whoe paion perhaps has diturbed my judgement. I have everal times attempted to know her Will; and the lat time he was at the houe of Adamas, when we walked o long together, I complained unto her, that all my ervices were o ill accepted, and almot thrown away: unto which he returned me an anwer full of courteie and civility: And when I replied, that it was neither courteie nor civility, but only Love which I looked for from her; he anwered, That he did honour me as much as any man in the world, and loved me as well as any Siter could love a Brother; and told me; that this was all he was able to do. But when I reply'd that my deigne and hopes was to marry her; he anwered me, that he had Parents who had the dipoition
of her, and he alwayes referred uch things unto their dicretions: But Paris (aid he) if you will know my mind, let me tell you, that, I do not intend to marry, either you or any ele; no nor ever will, I will alwayes love you as a brother, but never as a Husband: upon this, Siter, we were interrupted, and I would not urge her any further, until I had your advice, how to behave my elf: I conjure you therefore by the affection you have ever expreed towards me, to ait me: for to think of diverting my affection to her, is meer folly, becaue death only is able to do it. Brother (aid Leonide and miled) you ask my advice in a buines, which it eemes you are reolved upon; but I beleeve your deire is I hould tell you, how you hould demean your elf to win the affection of this Shepherdee: and truly, ince you are in uch an extremity as you ay you are, I conceive your bet coure is to obtain leave of her to peak unto her Parents; for they, doubtlee conidering the advantage which will accrue unto Diana by it, will not be againt the propoition: and hee who is very wie, and one that hath alwayes carried her elf with abundance of prudence and virtue, he dares not be againt their opinion, leat he hould be thought either wilful or in love with ome other, or ele tax her dicretion: Thus may he before he be aware, engage her elf o far, that he cannot handomly retire. But my opinion is, that your bet way is, not to peak unto her untill the very day we depart from hence, to the end, that if you do obtain this leave, he may not know where to find you, in cae he have a mind to revoke it again, or at the leat not find you before you have made the overture unto ome of her Parents.

This was the opinion of Leonide, which Paris reolved to follow; And whilet they were thus dicouring, Adamas and all the Company joyned with them. And becaue Sylvander was grown very bold, by the dicoure which he had heard, as oon as all complements were paed, he addreed himelf unto Diana: Mitris, (aid he aloud) I hall not refue the judgement of thoe whom you appointed, o you will but be pleaed to do the like: you need not quetion, (aid Diana) but I hall conent unto it, ince I know my caue to be good, and made choice of my Judges: The difference (replied Sylvander) needs not o much arguing, as that betwixt Phillis and me; and therefore, I beeech you, that without any more delay, the matter may be judged. I hall never be againt it (anwered Diana) ince I hope for a decree to pae on my ide. For my part, replied Sylvander, I derive all my right and title from the permiion which you gave me, which was to continue my behaviour towards you always, as I did during the wager betwixt Phillis, and me: How, replied Diana, did I ever permit you to continue alwayes o? Good Shepherd, do you take one day, for alwayes? And yet I permitted you the ret of the day only, which being ended, you was not to make any more ue of your fiction. I beeech you Mitris, (aid he) do you remember how you permitted me to end that day which remained after the judgement, as I had begun it, and to continue my behaviour, as I did before? It is very true, (aid Diana) but that day is ended, and I have begun another. You had good reaon, fair Shepherdee, (aid he) to ay that you began another day; becaue it is the quality of the Sun to begin and limit days, and you are the Sun of all our Horizon; and therefore you cannot ay, that the day which you granted unto me is ended: For I beeech you, fairet Mitris, as long as the light continues, does not the day continue alo? I confes it, anwered Diana; but you mut confes alo, that when the Sun is et, and cannot be een, it is night. I do confee it, replied Sylvander, and thereupon I have gained what I asked: for my oul and my eyes acknowledging no other Sun, but thoe glorious rayes of your beauty, and perfection, mot certainly as long as I am not deprived of this Light, and of this Sun, it is not night unto me: and ince it is not night, have I not good reaon to ay, that the day which you allowed me was not ended; but on the contrary that it will lat as long as I live, becaue your beauty, and your merits, will be alwayes in my oul? Diana a little urpried, or at leat eemed o, returned this anwer; I cannot deny, (aid he) but that when you asked me leave for a day, you might mean uch a day as you peak of: but I know that the day which I granted, was only one of our natural days. Fairet Mitris, (aid Sylvander) things that are ambiguous and doubtful, ought to be interpreted
to the advantage of the poor, and him that begs: Liberality and Generoity, are qualities o becoming a Noble oul, as I am confident, O my Judges, that you will not diminih the leat of what is the fair Dianas due, Alexis miled and aid, For my part, under the favour of Astrea and Alexis, I mut needs condemn Diana, and think Sylvander in the right; becaue thoe who give, ought to retrain and explain their gifts, if they do not intend to give all that is asked: for otherwie it is to be believed, it is in the ame intention that he had who receives the benefit. Ah me! cryed out Diana, I am afraid my caue will go againt me: for I know Atrea will accord unto all that Alexis thinks good; and Phillis will not contradict Atrea. And I aid Adamas, do ordain, that if Sylvander do hereafter reent the power of a beauty in good earnet, he hall not complain, neither of Diana nor his Judges, but of himelf only, who was the procurer of his own miery, and that the Shepherdes hall not be obliged by his ervices to pity him.

p.U: aid this, becaue he had a deign to give Paris unto this Shepherdee, and eeing that Sylvander was not dipleaing unto her, he was afraid the continuation of this courthip hould ingage her more. But Sylvander eeming to take no notice of what he aid, but kiing the hands of his Judges, he kneeled down before Diana; Fairet Mitris, aid he unto her, if ever any of my actions do contradict that vow, which I make of my faithful and perpetual ervice, let me immediately be condemned unto the mot cruel torture, that ever mortal endured. Diana anwered him, very faintly: Remember Shepherd aid hee, that you are permitted no farther then to faign and diemble, and that I hall take all your actions only as fictions and diimulations.

div.p: Sylvander had replied, had not Diana, and all the Company, entred into the grove of Hazels, and there met Leonide and Paris, who at the ame time were coming to look them: and after they had walked a while, they all went together into the houe to dinner, where they found the Table furnihed with many delicate varieties, far above the rate of a Country Village.

Lerindas, leat the Nimph Galathea, hould think him long, he made all the hat that poibly he could unto Mount-verdune. And being a good Footman, alo infinitely deirous to pleae his Lady, he made uch hat, that he was there again before dinner. Madam, aid he unto her, Adamas cannot retard the acrifice, becaue the people were already aembled; but becaue I told him you were very deirous to ee the Shepherdees of Lignon, he ends you word, that if you tay any time here, he will bring them all hither. I am very orry, aid Galathea, that I cannot hew this acrifice unto the Generous Damon, that he alo might have een thee fair Shepherdees; but if Adamas keep his word, we hall ee them as conveniently here; which if we do not, we cannot better imploy our time then in going to their Town. Madam, anwered Cleontine, ince Adamas has aid it, you may be aured he will doo't: Doubtles he will come before he return to his houe, and will be glad that all thoe fair Shepherdees hould accompany Alexis, when he preents her unto you. But as to Alexis (aid Galathea unto Lerindas) is he as full of beauty as they report her to be? For I know thou art a peron of judgement, and would be ure to view her: Madam, he is fair, anwered he, but in my mind there are three others which are fairer, and pleae me more; and ince you ask me, I had rather tel you o, then let Leonide have that advantage of me: I am of opinion Madam, that if they were changed for your Nimphs, you would have the fairet women in the world to wait upon you. How Lerindus? (aid Galathea) dot thou think them fairer then my Nimphs? Then your Nimphs Madam? anwered he, Yes, yes, Fairer then all the Nimphs in the world. What Lerindas? (aid Galathea) are they Fairer then I am? Ah Madam, (anwered he, and was a little urpried) I peak not of you, for you are the Lady and Mitris of all Nimphs; but I ay, that all others mut yield unto them in beauty, for they are as much above your Nimphs in beauty, as your Nimphs are above me. You hall ee, aid Silvia, that Lerindas is faln in love. Love (anwered he with a didaining look) Nay, I hould never fall in Love, with them, if they were as cornful as you. Galathea then laughed extreamly; Certainly, aid he, Silvia is in the right, Lerindas is auredly in Love with one of thee Shepherdees: but which of the three does pleae
the bet? Stay a little Madam (anwered he) I cannot upon a udden reolve you: The one has more Attracts, The other has more Modety, The third more Beauty: The firt is called Daphnide, the econd Diana, the third Atrea. I aure my elf replied Galathea, that this Atrea is the fairet, Is he not Lerindas? Certainly he is, aid he, and Diana is more modet, and Daphnide more attractive. To tell you truly, Attracts do much take me, Modety does much move me, but I love Beauty bet of all: And therefore I conclude, that if I be in Love, it mut of neceity be with Atrea. Believe it Madam, when you ee them, you will ay that I am a man of judgement; and Silara, as didainful as he is, would be glad to change Beauty with them. Then Galathea turned towards Cleontine, Mother aid he unto her I beeech you what does Celidea think of thee Shepherdees? Madam, anwered Cleontine, always when he begins to commend them, he will never almot make an end o as you will think her in love with them as well as Lerindas: But indeed I never heard her peak of this Daphnide, and if you pleae, I will call Lerindas to give you more particular atisfaction: And becaue Galathea was very deirous to know all circumtances concerning thee Fair ones, he called for him. But Mother, aid he unto Cleontine, I could wih you would end for C • lidea, that we might have a full relation from her. Madam, aid Lerindas, and miled, you will hardly peak with her this night it is o late; for I left her near the Temple of the Goddes Atrea, where he was to offer a Sacrifice, and Thamires with her: But Madam, he can tell you no more then I can, either concerning their Beauty, or any thing ele. If you deire to know who this Daphnide is, I can tell you, he is a tranger, late come amongt them, with one whoe name is Alcidon: For though I tayed not long amongt them, yet eeing her o fair, I enquired who he was. Madam (aid Cleontine) it will not be long before Celidea and Thamires will be here, and then you may be better informed of all paages.

Thus did Galathea enquire of thee fair Shepherdees; and the more he enquired the reaon he thought Celadon had to love Atrea, ince every one gave her uch a high Character above others: And Dinner being done, he went to viit Damon, who tirred not yet out of his chamber, becaue his los of blood, and going o far on foot in his Arms, had o wearied and weakned him, that he was contrained to keep out of the Ayr, for fear of a further inconvenience. In the mean time Halladine was come unto him, and never tirred from his Beds feet, but waited upon him with o much care and vigilance, that Galathea did much eteem him for it. It was now the third day ince he received his wounds; and the Nymph who thought her elf much obliged unto the valour of this Cavalier, for being wounded in defence of Ladies; moreover, being her Kinman, and injured in her own Dominions and preence, he reolved never to leave him until he was perfectly recovered: And to divert him a little, he would have Lorindas relate in his preence, all the paages of his voyage.

Thus was the day pent, and when it was night, Celidea and Thamires returned, Galathea would needs ee them preently; as well becaue he highly eteemed that Shepherdes, as becaue he deired to know more particularly of thoe Shepherdees, whom he had viited. Come wie Shepherdes (aid he unto her) tell us, I beeech you, the news of your Voyage. Madam, anwered he, we have done our duties both unto God and man; for we have offered a acrifice of Thanks unto Tautates for the Mietoe of the New Year; and we have done our duty unto Adamas, in viiting his daughter Alexis: and I aure you, we are all very well atisfied. For be pleaed to know Madam, that Alexis is the mot fair, mot lovely, and mot courteous Lady that ever eye beheld; and has given uch contentment to us all, that there is not one of us who does not even adore her: and Adamas has entertain'd us beyond all expreion. As for the Sacrifice, the great Tautates has well accepted of it; for all the victimes were as ound and perfect as we could deire: The Mileto which we aw is o large and great, that we call it another Tree that is fixed unto the Oak, o as our Druides have no reaon to pare either us or our cattel this year in our Sacrifices. But beides this, we have alo been highly delighted with the Loves of Hylas who is the mot pleaant humored Shepherd that ever was; that no diverion could equal it: Alo we heard the judgement of Diana upon the controverie
between Sylvander and Phillis; And the preence of Daphnide and Alcidon was no mall grace unto all the Aembly. Who is that Hylas of whom you peak, aid Galathea? He is a young man, anwered Celidea, who falls in love with all the Shepherdees he meets, and maintains, that it is not incontancy, with uch pleaant arguments and quirks, as it is impoible to hear him and be ad: For Madam, he is not above twenty, or one and twenty years of age, and he reckoned up above twenty with whom he had been in love, and mot of them preent; The lat he quitted was the fair and wie Alexis; and God knows for whom: I aure you Madam it is not for a fairer, for he has made choie of Stella, one that is old enough, and not comparable to the fair Druide in point of Beauty.

But I beeech you, aid Galathea, Does the daughter of Adamas uffer him to erve her, and before the eyes of every one? Yes Madam, anwered Celidea, but I aure you, without any candal; and if you aw her, you would ay as much: There is not the daughter of any Druide whom he does not Court. Nay Madam, I am confident that if he had the honour to ee you, neither you, nor any of your Nymphs would ecape his Courthip; for he would expres his mind at the very firt. But what is the judgement of Diana, replied Galathea. Madam, anwered the Shepherdes, It hapned upon a time that Phillis and Sylvander were in a hot dipute which of them had mot merits to make themelves loved: For Sylvander, although he be as well a qualified Shepherd, as any in all the Country, yet did he never love any particularly, nor was loved: And becaue Phillis did upbraid him that reaon was his want of courage and merit, and Sylvander aid as much by her, they were both of them condemned by the company to Court Diana, and at three months end, he was to judge which of them won the wager. Doubtles, aid Damon, Diana would adjudge it on the womans ide. Her judgement, anwered Celidea, is omthing doubtful: She adjudged Phillis to be more amiable then Sylvander, and that Sylvander knew better how to make himelf loved then Phillis did. Certainly (aid Damon) Diana is a very dicreet and wie Shepherdes; for I ee he had a mind to content both; and he has done it with much dicretion. But Madam, continued he, and turned towards Galathea, you have not yet asked her who that Daphnide is? I heard Lerindas ay, he was one of the fairet of all the Shepherdees, and I would gladly know who he and Alcidon is, for ome repects which afterwards I hall tell you. Then Thamires began to peak; Sir, aid he unto Damon, Lerindas was in the right to ay he was fair, for indeed he is o; but he was in the wrong in aying he was a Shepherdes; for he is not o, but only to diguie her elf, does wear the habit of a Shepherdes: We undertood by Hylas that Daphnide is one of the greatet Ladies in the Province of the Romans, and Alcidon the greatet Favourite of King Euriche, and that they came into this Country out of curioity to ee the Fountain of Loves Verity. It is enough (aid Damon) and then turning towards Galathea, Madam, aid he unto her, you mut by all means ee thee two perons, and be acquainted with them, for Daphnide is one of the fairet of all the Gallo-Ligurians, and was highly loved by King Guricke, o as had he lived, he had been his Queen: As for Alcidon, I hall commend him unto you, Madam, for the mot accomplihed Cavalier in the Court of Thorimond; and I aw him o careed and loved by that King, as he could not give demontrations enough of his good will towards him. I could relate many things worthy of knowledge, but ince he is o near you, it is better you know them from his mouth then from mine. Damon then began to whiper with the Nymph, which caued Thamires and Celidea to remove a little further ditant, But Madam (aid Damon unto her) Is the face of this Shepherdes thus poiled with cutting? She eems to be very wie and dicreet, how came this misfortune to pas? Thee cuts in her face, anwered Galathea, are the mot glorious marks that ever woman wore: thereupon he related the whole tory, and how happily her deigne propered ince the fond affection of Calidon was extinguihed, and the perfect Love of Thamires augmented by it, o as never was any more tenderly loved then he is now in her deformity. Damon admired the reolution of this young woman, epecially in a Shepherdes, becaue uch generoity is eldom but amongt higher and more noble pirits. You are mitaken, Sir, aid the Nymph, The Shepherds of this Country are not Shepherds of neceity, nor contrained
to keep their flocks, for a livelyhood, but have made choice of this kind of life, purpoely to enjoy more tranquillity, and live at eae: for the truth is, they are of kin and allied unto the greatet Nobility in all our Dominions. Madam, anwered Damon, although the cars in this womans face, were made with the point of a Diamond, yet I do know one that can mot certainly cure them, provided he have o o much courage, as to do what is requiite thereto: As for her courage, replied Galathea, you need not doubt o much as her will. How? (replied he and was amaed) has he no will to become fair? Truly, I believe, he is the only woman in the world who is of that opinion. Call her, aid Galathea, and you hall ee what he will ay. Upon which he calling her by her name; he came to know what Galathea would be pleaed to command her. Celidea, aid the Nimph, here is a Cavalier who pittying the mi-fortune of your face, and inquiring how it came to pas, does ay that mot certainly he can get you cured, and make you as fair as ever you were, if you pleae. Shepherdee, aid Damon, It is mot undoubtedly true, for when I was in Africa, one of Eudoxes women was wounded in her face with a Diamond, and o deep that the bone in her cheek did almot appear; yet there was a skilful Chirurgion, who wetting a little tick with her blood, did dree the tick with a remedy, called the Sympathy Salve, and o cured her againt the opinion of all the world. And becaue I thought this cure to be very rare; I was o full of curioity, as to ask ome of the Salve; but he anwered me, that it was a thing which he could not give unto any, becaue he was obliged to it by oath: but that whenoever I had any need, if I would but ent unto him a little piece of wood, bloodyed in the wound, he would preently work the cure, though he were a thouand miles ditant, if I would only keep the wound clean: Therefore Shepherdes, if you would be cured, you need only but cratch the wound, o as blood may run a little, and you hall ee you will recover your former beauty.

Sir, anwered Celidea, your kindnes, and the care you have of my face, obliges me very much unto you for it: but give me leave to tell you, that this beauty, which you are pleaed to peak of, is at this time a thing o indifferent unto me, as if I could recover it again by going to the door, I hould hardly tir a foot that way, if there was any other way out of the houe. When I call to memory, what abundance of trouble, and importunity, it caued me, I aure you Sir, I would rather go out at the window then that way, or have any correpondency with it again. Surely, aid Damon, all women have a particular deire to be fair, or at the leat not to be deformed. Thoe who are o eager after beauty, replied Celidea, perhaps have ome deigns to procure the Love of ome whoe amity they deire. But for my part, I do protet unto you Sir, that I deire to be fair only in the eyes of Thamires, and if I would, make my elf inviible to any ele. Me thinks yet, replied Damon, you hould deire that Thamires hould ee you fair. It is very true, replied he, but I believe thee cars in my face do eem as fair unto him, as all beauty, or delicacy of Features can be ince they came unto me only for his ake. This conideration, replied the Nimph, may make him have a great opinion of your affection, goodnes, and virtue; but perhaps he deires you were fair, as well as virtuous. For my part, Sir, replied Celidea, I am o very well contented, and atisfied, with being as I am, that I think I hould offend Tautates, hould I deire to be better: yet if Thamires do deire to have it o, I am mot ready to do whatoever is his pleaure. Dearet, aid Thamires, were you never o fair, mot certainly I could not Love you better then I do, as you are: But I mut needs confee, that if I thought it were poible to retore you unto your former beauty, I would pare no paines, or cot, to procure it; for I am obliged unto it, and hould think my elf mot ungreatfull, if I did not: and therefore Sir, aid he to Damon, if you know of any remedy, I beeech you, acquaint me with it, and I hall think my elf eternally obliged unto you for it. Mot certainly, aid Damon, he will be cured, and without much pain; for I have een the experience of it. A little tick mut be wet in the blood of the wounds, and carried unto the place which I hall direct very carefully; you will not be above twelve or fifteen daies in going, and I will write unto a Chirurgion, who quetionles will preently work the cure: Now did Celidea hate the very thought of this beauty ince, for the gaining of it, he was to be o long deprived
of her dearet Thamires: Oh Heavens! aid he, with teares in her eyes, did I take o much paines to deprive my elf of this beauty, to buy it now again at o dear a rate? Ah Thamires! content your elf with your Celidea as he is; and do not run your elf into o much hazard of loing her for ever. For if you go o far into a trange Country from her, grief perhaps may bring her to her grave, before your return, becaue he is not able to be o long abent from you. Hat thou not told me, a hundred times Thamires, that thou couldt live with me as I am, the happiet Shepherd in the World? And what, dear Thamires, needs more? Wouldt thou be better then happy? No, no, the joy of my life, enjoy that happines which Heaven has given thee, and trive for no more then thou art like to obtain; content thy elf with what the Gods have thought good for thee to be contented with: If it be for my ake, dearet Thamires, you deire this beauty, believe it, that your abence is o odious to me, as I had rather die then be deprived of you one week; the journey I perceive is o long, o full of danger, that I cannot conent unto it: you are to go amongt the Barbarians, perhaps he unto whom you go, is dead: who knows whether his receipt be proper to cure me? Perhaps it has his right upon another, but I am confident the wound which this Cavalier peaks of, was made by ome piece of glae, or ome other counterfeit tone, and not with a right Diamond: the wound he peaks of was dreed, and the receipt applied unto it, as oon as it was made, but mine is old, and out of all hopes to be helped. But uppoe it poible, I may recover this o much depied beauty, by the torments which you will put me unto, and which at bet is but doubtful: yet Thamires, ince I do not value it, and ince it is only to procure your elf a little more contentment; will you buy that contentment at a price which is o dear unto me? In the firt place, you mut carry my blood, but alas! the blood is nothing; I would give it all to keep you with me: but Oh? how many tears will your abence caue? What ighs? What orrows? What mortal dipleaures hall I have in this ad eparation? Oh Thamires! didt thou know how thou wilt torment thy Celidea by it? I cannot think, that for uch a fading thing as this beauty, thou would be o long from her. When all is done, Thamires, when after a long and weariome journey, ful of dangers, thou hat brought back with thee this beauty, what will it avail thee Shepherd, if a Feaver, or icknes, or orrow, or the happines of a child bearing, hould take it away again? But admit, it do ecape all •• ese has not time wings? Will not age creep on a pace, and ravih away this fading flower, almot as oon as thou art returned? Celidea tears did o accompany her words, that Damon was moved unto much compaion: Wie and dicreet Shepherdes (aid he) your virtue makes you admirable unto all thoe who know you, and obliges every one to erve you, not only upon this occaion, but in all other. I mut confee you have reaon to deire the preence of Thamires; but me thinks you might well dipence with him upon uch an occaion; yet to atisfie you both, I will promie to bring this Chirurgion hither ere it be long, and he hall cure your face without parting you from your dearly beloved Shepherd. Oh Sir! aid Celidon, if you will do this favour for a poor Shepherdes, the great Tautates will reward you, for I hall never be able; but I will pray for your happines as long as I live.

Damon admired the virtue and affection of this Shepherdee, aured her, that Thamires hould not be put unto the trouble of parting from her: And it being late, the Nimph retired with a reolution to offer her acrifice the next morning, and the day after to ee thee Shepherdees: conceiving that Damon would be in a condition to tir abroad, and by his means, he would try if he could bring back Daphnide and Alcidon with her, that he might do them all the honour their merits deerved; and having made her deign known unto Damon, he prepared himelf, with an extream deire to know what his Fortune would be: The morning being come, and all things ready for the acrifice, Cleontine put upon her head a Chaplet of Flowers, girded her elf about with Vervine, took a branch of Misleto in her hand, caued the fire to be kindled, and after the white Buls were acrificed, he prinkled her elf with ome of the blood, afterwards he prinkled ome upon the Nimph, and then upon Damon: Then throwing the Savine, the Mileto, and the Vervine into the Fire, he ran to the Vault of Bellinus, and touching the Lock with the Branch of
Mileto, the door flew open with a great noie, and he leaning her elf as far into the Cave as he could, he received the Wind which with a kind of murmuring voice came out of the Cave: Then, as if inpired with Enthuiatique Rapture, he ran unto the place where the Sacrifice was offered, which was in a little Grove near the Temple, according to the ancient Cutome; There he found the Nymph and the Cavalier upon their knees, expecting the anwer of Bellinus.

Then laying one hand upon the Altar, and holding the branch of Mileto in the other, with taring eyes, diordered hair, and trembling hands and head, he uttered a voice far different from what it was wont to be, in thee words.

lg.l: GO Nymph, and know, that thou halt find
Ere long, the Errour of thy mind:
But till beware, Incened Love
Should Fury turn; and worer prove.
And thou, O perfect Lover, when
Thou hear't a Diamond peak; Oh then,
From Death to Life thou halt return,
By help of him whom thou didt corn.

div.p: The Nymph and the Cavalier having received this Oracle, they tudied a long while upon it; but it being impoible for them to undertand it perfectly, one of the ancient Priets who was preent, and who was accutomed to interpret uch ambiguous anwers, he came unto the Nymph, aid this unto her.

Oracles, which are the words of the great Gods, are ordinarily rendred very obcure; becaue future things ought to be concealed from Humanes: For did we know the hour of our death, we hould not relih the weets of life, but live as if we were going to our graves. Great Tautates, who • ves us as his children, does advertie us of future accidents but darkly, and will not let us know more then is fitting for us to know, that we may have a dependency upon him. The great Tautates does foretel you, that ere long you hall ee your errour, and your in; and this in words o clear, that nothing can be more manifet: Alo to hew, that he does love you, let you hould be urprized by the evil which • e foreees is to fall upon you, he does advertie you of it betimes, to the end you may prudently prevent it, or patiently receive it: Furthermore, I mut needs tell you, That by the corrupt Intralls, and blood of all the Sacrifices which we have offered, we expect ome trange accident ready to fall upon our heads: For the Victims do fall all upon the left ide, and when they did fall, did beat themelves extreamly upon the ground, and died very impatiently; their blood would hardly come out, and was defective both in quality and quantity: and as for their Intralls, their Hearts and their Livers were rotten. To be brief, we ee o many apparent ignes from heaven, that it is manifet unles we do appeae the great Tautates by humble and fervent Prayers, we mut expect ome heavie judgements ready to fall upon us.

As for the Oracle which is rendred unto you, O valiant Cavalier, you may expect great contentment from it, for it peaks good unto you: In being called from death to life, is to be undertood your coming out of ome eminent danger; Death ignifies ome deep dipleaure out of which you are ere long to be releaed by the aitance of him whom you corn and hate: And therefore Madam, and you generous Cavalier, it is your parts to render thanks unto Bellinus, for the favour he hath done you both, to the end your gratitude may oblige him to continue his goodnes till unto you.

Thus pake the Priet: And both the Nymph and the Cavalier upon their knees eemed to be very devout towards heaven, by many actions of thanks: Afterwards
retired to their Lodgings, with intention to go the next day unto the Temple of the good Goddes; and afterwards in their return to ee the Shepherdes of Lignon, with Daphnide and Alcidon, though Damon's intention was to make himelf as little known unto them as he could, intending to tay amongt them a few days, and afterwards, if he found no remedy againt his dipleaures, to go o far away, that he hould not hear either Aquitain, or any he knew poken of. Being et down at the Table therefore, with this reolution, and Dinner being almot done, the Nymph aw enter into the Room a Cavalier from Amais, who was in great favour and confidence with her. This Cavalier (after all due reverence) came unto her, and told her in her ear, That he had great matters to impart unto her from Amais, but the dicoure of it would be long, and fit to be kept in ecret, and therefore he would peak no more of it, until he commanded him to wait upon her in private. The Nymph hearing this, and eeing his face in a kind of confuion, he began to think upon what the Priet told her concerning the defects in the Victims: And not being able to think upon any greater misfortune then the los of her Mother, he asked him aloud how Amais did? Madam, anwered he, thanks be to heaven he is in good health, and does paionately deire to ee you, thinking every hour an age you are abent from her. We will wait upon her preently, aid Galathea, ince Damon is in a condition to ride; for it was not reaonable to leave him in a ick condition, ince he received his wounds by defending us againt the injuries of Argenteus. Upon this he retired preently into her chamber, and caued the Cavalier to be called. Has my Mother (aid the Nymph unto him,) received any News from the Army of the Francks? And does he hear how Clidemant does? Madam (anwered the Cavalier) he did receive ome news this morning, which is not very good, but he deires to communicate it her elf unto you, and would have you make all the hate you can unto her: She commanded me to let you undertand, that the Francks have been in great Tumult upon King Childerick; who was forced to retire into Thurin; I am afraid that this was not without great bloodhed, and you know Clidemant, Lindamore, and Gayamant were always with him, I beeech God no misfortune have befaln them. I can aure you of one thing, Madam, That Amais your Mother is very ad, and much troubled, and extreamly deires to peak with you. Friend, aid Galathea, your dicoure does much amaze me, and I wih either that I knew not o much, or that I knew more: I mut before I end you away, talk a little with the age Cleontine, and with Damon, who is a peron which may be very erviceable unto us in uch accidents as may happen; and cauing them to be both called, he acquainted them how Amais had ent for her: And becaue he knew not whether he hould return preently, or firt go unto Bonlieu, to offer ome prayers there, as the Oracle did wih her, he asked the opinion of the old Cleontine; who anwered her thus: I conceive Madam, that in all our affairs we hould have recoure unto Tautates, and you epecially, ince by the relation of the Priet, you are menaced with ome great misfortune; and to divert it, the bet remedy is to have recoure unto him, from whom all proceeds, and to beeech him he would with hold his chatning hand. And therefore my opinion is, your bet coure is to go unto the good Goddes, offer your acrifice unto her, and the ame day go into Marcelles. Damon was of the ame opinion. You hear (aid Galathea unto the Cavalier which Amais ent) what the opinion of Cleontine and Damon is; Aure Amais, that to morrow I will wait upon her, and in the mean time, will pray unto the great Tautates, for a bleing upon us all.

Thus the Cavalier went away, leaving Galathea in uch a perplexity, as he had no mind to ee the fair Shepherdees, or Daphnide and Alcidon, but reolved to depart the next morning betimes: which being come, Damon armed himelf according to his cutome; and having put Galathea and her Nymphs into their Coaches, he mounted a Hore which the Nymph gave unto him, and which was one of Clidemants her Brothers. This Cavalier appeared o gallant in the eyes of Galathea, that he put her in mind of the generous Lindamore; and paing from one thought unto another, he imagined that the news perhaps that Amais would tell her, was of that Cavaliers death; and then he plotted how to get Polimas to go in his room, as well to pack him further from her, and be rid of his importunity, as in hopes that Amais
would cat her eyes upon Damon, in cae Lindamore was dead: and yet remembring his actions and glory he had gotten in this voyage, together with the affection he had born unto her, he could not chue but lament the loe of him; and in cae he was not dead, and that he could be convinced of the impoture of Clemanthis, then to have ome advantagious thoughts of him. Thee thoughts entertained her a great part of the way to Bonlieu: But paing over the river of Lignon, he began to think upon Daphnide, Alcidon, and all thoe Shepherdees whom he intended to ee: but being unwilling that this tranger Lady hould go away, and hee not ee her, he ent unto the age Adamas, to deire him he would come to her unto Bonlieu, and in cae he was gone before he came, to follow her unto Marellis, and that he would infinitely oblige her, if he would bring Daphnide and Alcidon with him: Afterwards, he arrived at the Temple of the good Goddes, where the venerable Chriante received them with all honour and civility; and becaue the Nymph acquainted her with her hat unto Marelles, Chriante caued all poible hat to be made with the acrifice, telling her that the Victimes which was offered for the publique and the happy voyage of Clidamant, were found o defective, as it was evident ome great diater was towards.

But in the mean time Sylvander, who had obtained that permiion which he deired, he was o intent and buie in it, as he had forgotten to tell Madonthe and Therander, that there was a Cavalier in quet of them, with many terrible menaces and threats; and had he not accidentally met them one morning, as they were walking to take the ayr, certainly it had been long before they had been acquainted with it; for he was o much taken up with his paion, as he had no room in his oul for any other thought: But meeting them o opportunely, he acquainted them with all that Paris told him, and the danger which they had incurred, if they had met with that Barbarous Man, who ought for them with o much deire of revenge. Madonthe did thank him for the intelligence; and having long debated amongt themelves, who it hould be, they could not imagine it could be Damon, becaue he was dead in their belief: but rather that it was ome of Madonthis kindred, who not being able to uffer her flight away with Therander, did eek to he revenged upon him. Sylvander, who alwayes carried much good will unto Madonthe, both becaue of her reemblance unto Diana, and becaue he was very vertuous and modet, eeing her hed abundance of tears, he had much compaion of her, and asked her the caue of them. Oh Shepherd! aid he unto him, have I not great reaon to lament my mierable Fortune, which thus cruelly torments me? Was it not enough, and too much, to perecute me in my own Country, and amongt my friends, but I mut be alo tormented here, where I hoped to find ret and tranquility. O Heavens! O Gods! What crime have I committed lately, that after I had foraken my Country, my etate, and all my acquaintance, I hould be purued til, & find no hopes of any ret, but in my Grave. Upon thee words, her tears did flow in uch abundance, as he was contrained unto ilence, and to have recoure unto her handkerchief. Sylvander who was moved when he began her tears, was moved much more at her continuance of them, and offered to guard and defend her from all injuries this tranger could do her, by the aitance of his friends, if he would tay in the Country. As ill luck was, Laonice meeting them at the ame time, and being very familiar with Madonthe, he advied her to retire into her own Country, where he might live more quietly, and not to refue the aitance of Sylvander to accompany her, at the leat as far as Forrets reached. Madonthe fearing to receive ome burt for this tranger, he reolved to be gone, and accept of Sylvanders offer, to guard her with his friends: But Therander was much againt it, and diwaded her; o as he thanked Sylvander for his good will, and would not permit him to go any farther then the place where this tranger was een: Then preently at the ame hour, after he had taken leave of ome Shepherdees, which he met with by chance, he deired Laonice to excue her unto the ret, he et forward with a reolution as oon as he came into Aquitane, to admit her elf amongt the Vetals, or the Drui • es daughters, and forake the world and all its adventures.

In the mean time Alexis lived freely with the fair Atrea, and made ue of all the Priviledges, which the daughter of Adamas could have, and had been two dayes
