in her own Town amongt the Shepherdees and Shepherds, and was never out of Atreas ight but when he was in bed; for all the day they talked together, and were all the night in a chamber, where their beds were not far ditant: and the impatient Love of Alexis not permitting her to leep; he aroe the econd morning to contemplate upon the beauty of her fair Shepherdes, before it was perfect light, and put on Atreas Gown in tead of her own; and he took uch extream delight to be in that Gown, which covered the body of her dearet Saint, that he took the ret of Atreas Clothes, and trimmed her elf compleatly in the habit of a Shepherdes, o as any one would have taken her for one: and though Atreas Gown was a little too trait for her, yet it was not o unit, but it might well deceive the eye of any that was not too trict an oberver: being thus decked, he went unto the bed where Atrea was aleep, and kneeling down, he began to adore, and contemplate upon her beauty as he lept.

And though Alexis uttered many raptures in a loud voice, yet none of the three awaked: Alexis till looked upon Atrea, and the more he looked, the more he Loved: And being tranported with her affection, he went neer her to teal an amorous kie, but preently checked her elf, out of her repect. But till having a longing deire unto it, he uttered ome veres in a lone voice, upon this ubject; That her Mitris lept, and he durt not kis her; and perhaps he had grown a little more couragious, if Leonide by fortune had not waked, and perhaps again Alexis was o loud in her expreion, as he was the caue of it. As oon as he opened her eyes, he took her for Phillis, and bidding her good morrow, asked her, why he was o early: Alexis miled, and returning no anwer, covered her face with her hand, purpoely to keep her the longer in her mitake: Atrea and Diana waking at the ame time, they were both deceived as well as Leonide, both of them aluted her, and asked the ame quetion which the Nimph did, Alexis eeing all thus mitaken, he grew more confident then when they were aleep, and going unto Atrea, kied her cheek, & bad her good morrow. Atrea hearing a voice unlike unto Phillis, pulled back her cheek, and looking a little better upon her, he knew her. Am I mitaken, aid Atrea, or do I ee Alexis in the habit of a Shepherdes? Upon this, Leonide and Diana, looking alo better upon her, they knewher to be Alexis indeed.

Atrea then, raied her elf up a little in her bed, and taking Alexis in her arms, kied her, with abundance of joy, to ee her in her clothes. Give me leave, new Shepherdes, aid Atrea, to kis you; and give me leave alo to tell you mot truly, That Forrets never aw o Fair a Shepherdes.

Then all three looking upon her with admiration, they were all ravihed to ee her o Fair in that unaccutomed habit: Alexis all this while, aid nothing; but at lat, when he aw that he was known, Siter, aid he unto the Nymph, do you not think, that thee clothes have not changed for the wore? I do think (anwered the Nymph) that you are a Fairer Shepherdes then a Druide; and that if Hylas aw you, he would preently lay by a new tock of Love, to pend in your ervice. And I think, aid Atrea, that thee clothes, could they be enible of it, would be infinitely happy, in being worn by the Fairet that ever lived. But (aid Diana, and interrupted) it were pity to put this Fair Druide unto o much paines as to undree her elf, and therefore it would be better, if Atrea took thoe of Alexis, and wear them all the day: I am confident it would be an excellent mask unto Adamas, and he would certainly take the one for the other: Truly, aid Leonide, I dare venture a wager, that mot of thoe who ee them, mitake them; epecially if my iters clothes were as fit for Atrea, as Atreas are for her. Alexis, thinking it an happines to be in thoe clothes, which ued to cover the body of her Fairet Mitris, had a great deire to wear them all the day. Atrea who did paionately Love this Druide, had alo a mot extream deire to wear the clothes of Alexis; and yet, neither of them, durt publih their deires. And becaue Diana was very earnet with them to have it o. But iter, aid Alexis unto Leonide, what will my Father ay when he ees me in uch a diguie? What will he ay? anwered Leonide; he will laugh, and be very glad to ee you in uch a merry humour: he knows that nothing is more prejudicial to your health then melancholy and adnee: and thinks nothing more conducible to your health, then jollity, and mirth. Could
I believe, replied Alexis, that I hould delude the eyes of thoe who hall ee me this day, as well as I was deluded in the choice of my clothes, I hould be glad: For though there was much difference between our clothes, yet I took Atreas for my own, and yet I ee you mitook me: Believe it, aid Atrea, one would believe, you took much paines in dreing your elf, for it is impoible you hould be better dreed; and as for me, I will take ome other clothes, to make it the more believed that you are a new come Shepherdes, No, no, (aid Diana) you mut needs take the Druides clothes: otherwie, what will they think is become of her? We will ay, anwered Leonide, that my iter is not well, upon condition Atrea will promie to take her clothes to morrow, that we may ee whether he will be as fine a Druide, as my iter is a Shepherdes. I hall do as you deire, aid Atrea, but I believe her Gown will be too big for me. As much, aid Alexis, as yours is too little for me; but both may be eaily helped. Since Madam it is your pleaure to have it o, aid Atrea, I hall be the Druide to morrow: but I am confident, that if Hylas aw this new come Shepherdee to day, he would burn all his Artieles of Agreement with Stella, and add this Fair Stranger unto the great number of his Mitries: I am ure, aid Alexis, that neither he nor any ele can ee you, but both he and all mut needs Love you.

And becaue now it began to grow late, and full time for thee Fair Ones to rie; Atrea was contrained to rie out of the bed in her mock, to fetch another Gown, and other Linnen, which were in a Trunk at the other end of the Chamber; and thinking none in the room but Women, he aroe very confidently, and carelely.

The firt thing the diguied Druide aw, was her bare Foot, and Leg; and half her Thigh: The delicacy, and whitenes of her Feet, the handome proportion of her Leg, the plumpnes of her Thygh, and the beauty of her Neck, could not be equalled by any things, but themelves: And Alexis tood in uch a poture of amazement as he looked upon her, as invited Atrea, to take her in her arms and kis her: The embraces of Alexis might well have raied a upicion, that they were a little more affectionate and cloe, then uch as women ue: And Atrea was as zealous in her imbraces, as Alexis was, and perhaps received them, not as the kies of an Alexis, but as the living reemblance of Celadon. Leonide oberving thee amorous kies and carees, and growing a little jealous, he aid unto the Druide: Take heed, new Shepherdes, let holding Atrea o long in your arms, you caue her to take cold. No, no, anwered Atrea; I cannot take any harm in being o neer Alexis, I hould be very orry Fairet (aid the Druide) to be the caue of any inconveniency to you, but I hope my iter peaks only out of envy: then Alexis took Atrea in her arms from off the ground, and carried her to the Trunk, unto which he was going; and there etting her down, kiing ometimes her Eyes, ometimes her Mouth, and ometimes her Neck: And Atrea, thinking her a Woman, did freely permit it; and was o extreamly contented to be thus carreed by one o much reemblant unto Celadon, as he payed back her kies unto Alexis with double interet. None can expree the fulnes of this diguied Druides joy, unlee ome that have been ravihed by the like accident. But it may eaily be imagined, that Alexis was very neer making her elf known who he was, although he knew that all her happines would be blated, if he were dicovered; and perhaps had dicovered all, had not Phillis in the height of their carrees knocked at the door: And therefore, Atrea fearing it hould be ome body ele, ran preently to bed, and looked through the Curtaines who it was which entred. Alexis, vexed at the heart to be thus interrupted, he went to the door, and asking who was there, did open it unto Phillis, o much againt her mind, that he looked not pleaantly all the day. When Atrea aw it was her Companion Phillis, he bad her good morrow, and looked about for Alexis: and when he aw that he was not in the Chamber, he thought that he was gone to walk, as formerly he had done; Phillis alo enquired for her, and they anwered that he was not very well, and was gone into another Chamber, but would return preently. Phillis did eaily believe them, epecially eeing her clothes upon the table. But when they were all dret, and ready to go out; I beeech you, aid Phillis, let us ee Alexis before
we go: No, no, anwered Leonide, he deired to be alone, but we will return after our walk, and ee how he does: So taking Phillis by the hand, he carried her out.

In the mean time, the new come Shepherdes being walked into the Hazle Grove, where he thought to be mot private, and might bet entertain her own thoughts, in contemplation of thoe beauties which he had een, and of thoe favours which he had received, or rather under a borrowed notion, had toln.

But the day being now well on, and mot Shepherds retired with their Flocks under the hade, he heard many Shepherds inging under hady trees, and expecting the coming of their Shepherdees: Amongt the ret Calidon, who was up that morning betimes, and was come over the River of Lignon in hopes to ee Astrea, and to try his Fortune before he poke any farther unto Phocion; And he meeting Hylas by the way, they came together unto this place, where both of them began of ing: And Calidon, thinking upon Atreas cruel anwer, began to chant his complaints againts her cruelty, in a doleful tune.

Alexis not being accutomed to the voice of Calidon, although he heard him ing, and undertood his words, yet hew knew him not; but he knew Hylas, and heard him ay: Is it poible Calidon, that Atrea hould ue you thus? Alas Hylas! anwered he, it is but too true, and I wih I were able to ue your receipt againt uch cruelties: The Druide heard no more of their dicoure, for being deirous to pas unknown, he left them; yet Hylas continued thus: Believe it Calidon, there is one Shepherd, who is to be blamed for all the mieries that befal all the Shepherds of this Country in this kind; Sylvander is he, I mean, for he having a very ubtile wit, does ininuate himelf o in the good opinion of the Shepherds, as by his fale and ophitical arguments he perwades them, That a Lover is a man lot in point of reputation, if when he is ill entertained, he change his affection, as if a man were a Rock, immoveable, and able to abide all the angry bl • ts and torms of a raging Sea: o as a Shepherd becomes o much enlaved, as in pite of all injuries, he cannot dicontinue his ervice and good will, but he mut preently be branded with incontancy; and thus all become ubjects unto the Tyrany of Women: whereas if thee maximes were not, they would not delight o much in eeing their ervants to languih, but would add every day freh favours, in hopes to keep us from changing. Unto all this Calidon anwered thus; you are much mitaken Hylas, if you think Sylvander to be the firt Author of thee opinions: The Shepherds of this Country have for many ages oberved the ame Laws; and though cutome did not oblige us unto it, yet the beauty of our Shepherdees would contraine us: For is it poible to Love them once, and not alwayes? I ee, replied Hylas, that now you do Love Atrea, and therefore one mut not argue the matter with you, according to the rules of reaon: But I hope to ee you as far from this affection, as you are from that of Celidea. Several reaons, anwered Calidon, did divert me from her you lat named, and many more do oblige me never to ceae loving the other, unles I ceae to live; for beides the accident, which took away the beauty of Celidea, and which was the firt caue of my affection, I was obliged to retore her unto Thamires, in point of honour; but etting this and all other coniderations aide, having ubmitted my elf by oath unto arbitration, doubtlee I hould have drawn upon me, both the anger of Heaven, and hatred of men, if I had not been obedient unto it. On the other ide, all things do induce, and invite me, never to change my affection unto Atrea; for in the firt place, her beauty is uch as cannot be equalled. She is o much the prouder for that, aid Hylas: No matter, anwered Calidon, a little pride in a Woman makes her the more amiable. Yes, aid Hylas, o he be proud unto others, and not unto us: but is not beauty very ubject unto the injury and blats of time? Oh Hylas! anwered Calidon, when age has blated the beauty of Atrea, the ame age will make Calidon not much care for beauty: moreover, Parents who have the government of her, and thoe who have the power over me, do allow of this affection. The contentment of Parents, replied Hylas, is often a caue that Women will not Love thoe who otherwie are not dipleaing unto them; as well becaue, they cannot abide Parents hould be courted more then themelves, as becaue contraint is odious unto them: For Love
never comes by contraint, nor the opinion of others; but only by the will of thoe who love.

But Atrea is o wie (replied Calidon) that he will be conformable unto the opinion of her friends. May be not (replied Hylas) Atrea is able to build upon her own reolution. I hould eaily believe it (aid Calidon) did I not ee that he is diengaged, and free from loving any: and as yet I have not done her ervice ufficient to engage her: o as hould he be eaily won, he would not be o etimable. Oh Calidon (aid Hylas) Do you think long ervice will make her love? Alas, alas poor Shepherd, I pity you, if you be of that opinion; you had need to make proviion of Spectacles to ee her Beauty withal at that time; for when it comes, I believe you will not be able to ee without them. Did you never hear how Celadon loved her? Yes (replied Calidon) but he being dead, that makes nothing againt me: Nothing againt you! aid Hylas, Yes, yes perhaps more then you imagine: For why ele, according to Sylvanders doctrine, hould he preerve the memory of him o frehly, as Tyrcis does of his dead Cleon? But this is not that I would ay: Do you know how long this Celadon Courted her? Some four or five years (anwered Calidon.) Well friend, anwered Hylas, Do you not think a pair of Spectacles will do very well at five years end? I do not think (aid Calidon) that o long a time is requiite to win her; but though it be, yet I hould not be reduc'd unto any uch neceity as you peak of. Shepherd, hepherd, replied Hylas, you may flatter your elf as long as you pleae, but you may conider, that nothing is more certain then experience, and what you have formerly een come to pas. Conider if you be wie, that it may come to pas again: You ay he is not engaged in her affection unto any: Why, this is it Friend which makes me think wore of your buines; for thoe women which will love any, may be drawn and won to love us; but thee inenible Creatures are uch things as do not o much as know what and whom is to be loved.

Calidon began to boggle at the reaons which Hylas urged, and thought them very trong. I aure you Hylas (aid he) I tand in need of all thee conolations which you give me, I think my elf happy in meeting with you. If you would have me flatter you (aid Hylas) I could peak in another dialect, but if your judgement be ound, you will ee I peak like a friend: If you deire to find comfort in your miery, you mut ue the like remedies which I alwaies did in the like caes; which if you do, I will warrant you from taking any harm from uch a dieae as this. But let me tell you (anwered Calidon) that if you mean, quitting Atrea, or loving any other, I had rather loe my eyes then look upon any other Beauty then hers; and loe this heart which gives me life, then ever love any other Shepherdes then Atrea. Upon this, being a little angry with Hylas, he would have gone away from him: But Hylas held him, and miling, aid unto him. Nay (aid he) if you be upon that lock, and deire o much to ee Atrea, you may go into the Grove of Hazles: For I aw her there alone, but would not tell you, becaue I feared you would but loe all your labour: For a woman is omtimes like unto death, which comes upon us before we be aware, and leat think upon it. Hylas (aid Calidon) It was not friendly done, to keep me o long from my happines in being with her. Nay, nay, aid Hylas, take heed you come not oon enough to receive a coure entertainment. Calidon having not o much patience as to tay o long to reply, he went as fat as he could to the place which Hylas named, thinking it the mot happy opportunity that poibly could be, to find her in a place where none would interrupt their dicoure.

Hylas thought he had told him right; for eeing Alexis only behind in the habit of Atrea, he was mitaken. In the mean time the Druide being deirous to enjoy her own weet Imaginations of that Viion which he had lately een. he went a great pace unto the wood, where the olitude of the place, and the freh memory of thoe Favours he had received, did repreent before the eyes of her fancy, the Beauties and weet Kies of Atrea in uch lively apprehenions, that folding her Arms, and lifting her eyes up to heaven: Oh good Gods, aid he, that Alexis could be happy without Celadon; or that Celadon could be happy without Alexis: Were I really Alexis, and not Celadon, how happy hould I be in Atreas favours?
And oh how much more happy hould I be, if being Celadon, he did not do me thee Favours as being Alexis! Was ever Lover o happy and unhappy both, as I am? Happy in being careed by the Fairet and mot Lovely Shepherdes in the world; and unhappy, in that all thee favours would mot certainly be turned into Torments, were I not hrouded under the vail of Alexis. Here topping a little, and afterwards beginning again; But Celadon (aid he) how long mut this diguie lat? What end dot thou aim at in this thy deigne? Dot thou think thou cant delude always? Why (foolih Lover!) dot thou not declare thy elf? Does he not as good as tell thee, that all her amity with Alexis proceeds only from her reemblance unto Celadon? This manifets that he does not hate this Shepherd, ince thinking him dead, he does cherih his memory: And dot thou think thy preence would not be welcome to her, when he ees himelf upon his knees before her living, and adoring her? Go, go and cat thy elf at her feet; ay thus unto her, Here Fairet Shepherdes, is Celadon mot humbly before you; he died when you were dipleaed, and now is revived again, ince you are pleaed with him in the face of Alexis: If he hath inned in any thing againt you, he hath done penance for it: but if you think his fault yet unexpiated, command him what torments you hall pleae, and you hall find him more ready to obey, then you can be to command: Upon this, tanding a while ilent, he conidered whether this reolution was good or no; but afterwards beginning again, Peace, peace Celadon (aid he) content thy elf with being dead, and envie not the happines of Alexis; ince thou cant not thy elf, let her enjoy it: for all the hopes thou hat, is by the interceion of this Druide, unto whoe conduct thou ought wholly to ubmit thy elf: And do not flatter thy elf o much, as to think that he loves thy reemblance in her; Perhaps indeed thy face may be like hers; but it is thy fault which invites her to hate thee: If there be any thing in thee which can pleae her, it is that in thy oul thou didt never infringe the Laws of a perfect affection; and wilt thou tain the innocency of thy Love by o great a diobedience as this? I do command you (aid he unto thee) never to ee my face until I do allow it. Love her then, oh Celadon! Obey her, and be ilent, if thou wilt live and love without reproach. Thus did this Druide think her elf in a place where he might enjoy her own thoughts with delight; and Love, who perhaps was jealous of the Favours which Fortune had done her, did venome them with thee mortal imaginations; o as her eyes being over-flowed with Tears, he was contrained to the ue of her Handkerchief: And becaue Calidon at the ame time came into the Wood, he no ooner pied him, but he tarted back, as if he were ready to tread upon a Serpent; and went away (hunning him) into another Walk, which was in the high Wood, out of the Grove: But as Fortune was, Hylas was walking there; and eeing her, did upect the reaon of her coming into that Wood; for he aw her run, and oberved the place into which he entred; and tayed a while to inform Calidon, whom he believed was not far off; and yet he was deceived, for Calidon not thinking her to be gone out of the Wood, he ought her in every place there, as if he had looked for a pin: But finding all his labour lot, he then believed that he had purpoely hid her elf from him; and thinking this indignity too great to be endured, he was o vexed to ee himelf thus lighted, as firt in anger, and afterwards in depair, he reolved an hundred times never to love Atrea any longer: But then, aoon as he thought upon her Beauty and perfectious, he changed that thought, and was more entangled in this affection then ever. In the mean time, Hylas, who tayed to hew him which way Atrea paed, began to be weary of this tay, when he aw coming from towards the Houe, Leonide, Diana, Phillis, and amongt them (as he thought) Atrea. At the firt, he durt have worn the contrary; for he thought that he had een her on the other ide; but going neerer, he could not give his eyes the lie, which aured him that Atrea was in the company; when one came behind him, and laid their hands upon his eyes, intending to make him gues who it was.

p.U:
tood till; feeling her hands, and finding them to be the hands of a woman: I know (aid he) who you are; but my wonder is, how you got behind me: whilt he was talking thus, all the company came up, and could hear Hylas continue his talk: I do know (aid he) that you are Atrea: Then letting him go, he aw himelf
mitaken, and that it was Laonice. What Hylas (aid he) do you know your friends no better then o? No wonder Shepherdes, aid he, that I hould thus mitake you for Atrea, for I aw her jut now enter into that Wood; and as oon as you laid your hands upon my eyes, I aw her jut before me amongt this company: What hould I think, when eeing her in everal places at once, but that he can be every where? How Hylas! aid Atrea, Did you ee me enter into that Wood? I did ee you, anwered he, and I am not alone that aw you; for Calidon is till amongt the Hazles looking for you. Atrea and the ret of the company did know well enough his mitake; but eeing otherwie, Certainly (aid Diana) your eyes are not very good this morning; for this Nymph and we all are able to witnes that Atrea has been all this day with us. I ee Atrea is there (aid Hylas) and I know that the Atrea which I aw yonder, could not poibly be o oon with you, for he went the quite contrary way: But I am certain that I did ee one Atrea there, ele Ile never trut my eyes again. Leonide and all the company laughed to ee him in uch a maze: And becaue Atrea was very deirous to ee this Atrea which he pake of, Hylas (aid he) we will think you out of your wits if you do not hew us this other Atrea, and therefore hew us which way he went. You may think me as much out of my wits as you pleae (aid Hylas) and I aure you, I think as much my elf; for I am the mot mitaken man alive, if I did not ee one Atrea there, and another yonder, and therefore I beeech you let us go and look for her. Upon this he led the way into the high wood, and having looked long in vain, at lat he thought that he aw her itting by an arm of the River Lignon, under a hady Tree. Hylas went on as fat as he could hye, and when he came o neer as to know her, he beckned unto the ret of the company to come neerer; and taking Atrea by one hand, and pointing at Alexis with the other: Look Shepherdes (aid he unto her) Are not you itting under yonder Tree? Unto which Phillis anwered, I believe late ervant (aid he) that you are of the nature of Lions, who know their Keepers better by their clothes then by their faces. Why do you ay o, anwered Hylas? Becaue (replied Phillis) thoe clothes which you ee are like unto thoe which Atrea wears, therefore you are perwaded it is he. They talked o loud, and Hylas made uch a noie, that Alexis turned about, and aw all the company coming towards her: Therefore wiping her eyes, and etting as jolly a look upon it as he could, he roe up and came to meet them; And becaue Atrea and Diana beckned unto her to eem as if he were a tranger, he demeaned her elf o, that both Hylas and Laonice did not know her: As for Phillis, they had acquainted her already with the paage. Hylas went to her, and aid, I aure you, fair Shepherdes, you had almot turned my mind when I aw you at a ditance; and now I ee you neerer, I am afraid you will quite make me alter my affection.

eeming not to know him, or what he aid, I beeech you Shepherd, aid he, pardon me if I do not anwer, for I do not undertand what you ay. I mean, replied Hylas, that taking you for Atrea in one place, and eeing Astrea preently in another, I was almot out of my wits; but now I do ee you perfectly, I fear you will teal away my heart, which I gave unto another. You do very much oblige me (anwered Alexis) to take me for o fair a Shepherdes, whom I have o much deired the happines of eeing and knowing; but then you do as much di-oblige me, in upecting me for a Thief; for you mut know, I never ue to take anything but what is my own: But if you will repair the injury you have done me, hew me which of all thee fair ones is Atrea, and I will pardon the offence. I believe, aid Hylas, that did you know me, you would not think, that in letting you take my heart from another, I have committed any offence, for Hylas never gives it unto any: yet ince it is an eaie matter to repair the injury which you pretend I have done you, I will not dipute it any further; upon condition, that when i have atisfied your curioity in hewing you Atrea, you will not didain to accept the gift of this heart of Hylas, and o free your elf from the guilt of theft. Firt (anwered the new Shepherdes) hew me which is Atrea, and we will talk afterwards of the heart of Hylas, as it eems you call your elf. This is he (anwered Hylas) and hewed her Atrea, who could not chue but laugh as well as all the company, to ee Hylas o blind as not to know Alexis; who going unto Atrea, aluted her, and
held ome dicoure of civility, purpoely to deceive Hylas the more, who was o much taken with the behaviour of this tranger, that he could not chue but pres her to the reception of his heart: How now my late ervant? aid Phillis, what will Stella ay when he hears you offer your elf unto this Fair tranger? What hould he ay, anwered he, but that I have oberved our articles, by which it was permitted me, to Love whom, when, and where I lifted, without any offence to her? How Shepherd (aid the new Shepherdes) can you think I will allow of any harer in Love? Why not? anwered Hylas, as long as I love you as much as you can deire? But I beeech you, aid he, would you in earnet Love me, and Love another beides? Yes aid Hylas: and if after dinner there remain any meat, would you have have me throw it to the dogs? And o after I have Loved you as much as you can deire, and have ome Love yet to pare, why hould I not imploy it in loving thoe who tand in need of it? Oh Shepherd, aid the tranger, believe it, I will not allow of any harers with me; he that Loves me, mut Love only me, and therefore you are not like to have me for your Mitris: Nor you me (anwered Hylas) for your ervant; and ince you are of uch an humour, I advie you to look out for one Sylvander, who is uch a one as will fit your turn. Now Sylvander is mentioned, aid Phillis, where is he? for I wonder we do not ee him this morning? It is well for you Hylas that he is not here, for he would have checked you for thus talking of Love unto this Paire tranger, at the firt ight. Hylas would have anwered, but Laonice interrupted him; Nay, nay, Hylas, aid he, you may talk of Love, or what you will to day, for I am ure you will not ee him; and though he were here, I could not contradict you, for he is imployed in the like ervice, and offered himelf unto it. What ervice is that? (aid Diana preently) You mut know, anwered the piteful Laonice, that Paris chanced to meet with a trange Cavalier, who thundered out many menaces againt Therander; and Sylvander, undertaking to acquaint Madonthe with it from him, he did this morning tell her of it; and he fearing let Therander hould receive ome hurt by reaon of her, he reolved to return preently into Aquitain, and deired me to make her excues unto you all, giving a thouand thanks for the favours he has received, and promiing never to forget them. But poor Sylvander, eeing her ready to depart, and not able any longer to hide the ecret affection which he bare unto her, in the firt place he ued al the arguments that poibly he could to divert her journey, and then eeing he could not prevail, he offered himelf to wait upon her: but he, being unwilling to accept of his offer, let (as I believe) he hould make Therander jealous, he refued him an hundred times: He eeing he could not obtain that favour from her, he fell down upon his knees, kied her feet, and conjured with the mot earnet olicitations that ever I heard, to give him leave; and he not knowing how in civility to put him off after uch importunity, he permitted him to go with her a days journey or two.

div.p:
I believe (aid Astrea) that you are mitaken, if you think Sylvander in Love with any: In Love with any, aid Hylas, pray what do you think of his behaviour towards Diana? Oh! anwered Phillis, that is only a Fiction. Yes Hylas, replied Laonice, his behaviour towards that Shepherdes is but a fiction; he himelf wore it this morning a hundred times, when Madonthe charged him with it. Well, well Sylvander, aid Madonthe to him, though my abence do a little trouble you, yet the preence of Diana will comfort you. Diana, anwered he, does merit more then my ervice, neither hould I ever have rendered her any, but in repect of my wager with Phillis; and I wih he were here, that you might ee the truth of my words. Phillis who knew that this dicoure would much dipleae her Companion, did anwer thus; I cannot poibly believe that Sylvander does Love Madonthe, for he never made the leat hew of it. I believe (aid Diana and interrupted her) that you are much mitaken; for I have een ufficient igns of it: and why hould not a young Shepherd that has Wit and Spirit enough, Love a Woman that is o amiable as Madonthe? Epecially ince Laonice peaks it knowingly, and aw him obtain this permiion to wait upon her with o much importunity? But good Laonice, aid Atrea, is it certain that Sylvander has followed Madonthe? Do you think (aid the ubtile Shepherdee) that I would ay it unles I aw them depart? Why
hould I verifie a thing which if it were not true, would o eaily be proved to be a lye? Farewel Sylvander, aid Diana, and come back again even when you have a mind. Upon this, eeming as if he were not troubled at it, he turned away, and went from them; but Phillis followed her, and heard her upbraid Sylvander with incontancy: Ah Shepherd, aid he, are thee the effects of that Love which you hewed unto me? Is this the eternity of thy affection? And didt thou trouble both thy elf and me with thy diguie, to quit me for Madonthe? Hat thou o often and o long blamed the Incontancy of Hylas, to become as ill thy elf? Then Diana eeing Phillis follow her! Well Siter, aid he, what do you now think of Sylvander? I mut needs confes, anwered Phillis, that if Laonice ay truly, I was never in my life o mitaken as in this Shepherd; for I have een him make uch demontrations of a real paion, as I thought it impoible to be ever extinguihed. But is there any credit to be given to Laonice? Yes doubtles (aid Diana) for beides what he hath told us, I have alwaies oberved a great affection in him towards Madonthe; and when Paris ent him word of the menaces which were threatned unto Therander, how ready he was to be the Meenger? It mut be confeed that Madonthe is very fair and dicreet, yet truly in my eye he is not very amiable; and were I a man, I hould erve many others that are not o fair, rather then her: and all this while he has been amongt us, have we een any that loved her except Hylas and Sylvander? For my part, aid Phillis, I have the ame opinion of Madonthe which you have, but I cannot believe that Sylvander loves her; and as for your obervations of him, truly I think them only effects of his curteie and civility towards that tranger. But, replied Diana, what do you think of his o earnet olicitation to wait upon her? Think, anwered Phillis, That it was till his curteie. It had been curteie ufficient, anwered Diana, to have undertaken the office of Laonice, and brought us her excues; but to fall upon his knees, to hed tears, and to go with her almot by force, and leave us without bidding one adieu, if this be curteie, and not Love, I know not what is Love. But its no matter, I am ure he has much obliged me in this action; for I mut confes, his continual courthip, and his dicreet behaviour had begun in me uch a good opinion of him, as I began to be inclineable to wih him very well, and indeed to love him. What a lamentable condition had I been in, if he had tayed a little longer: And ince he is of this humour, I had rather both he and I were dead, then he hould have known my mind.

Phillis perceiving that Diana did love this Shepherd, and foreeeing that he could never decline it without mot mortal dipleaure; Siter (aid he unto her) let us not give uch eaie credit unto Laonice; tay till Sylvander return; and condemn not a man before you hear him anwer for himelf. Nay, nay Siter, replied Diana preently, the tone is already thrown; let him ay and do what he will, I know what to think. But iter, aid Phillis, It is unjut to condemn before you hear. No, no aid Diana, all that hear him, will judge him in the wrong: and if you love me, offer not to divert me from the mind I am in. But becaue I remember he has a Bracelet of my hair, which once I made for you, I beeech you ask it of him from me, the next time you ee him. I know that Shepherds of his humour ue to brag of uch favours as they can get from unadvied Shepherdees; and if I could, I would not have him do o by me. Phillis eeing Diana much vexed, and thinking it not a time to contrary her, he was ilent a while; and when they offered to continue their dicoure, they aw all the company coming towards them, but much encreaed, becaue Adamas, Daphnide, Alcidon, Paris, Hermantes, Stiliana, and Carlis were there: Amongt them alo was Lerindas, the meenger from Galathea unto the great Druide, who would not return before he had een Atrea and Diana, of whoe Beauty he thought he could not peak too high. But Adamas was much perplexed ince he undertood by Lerindas the mind of Galathea; for he was unwilling to dipleae her, and he aw there was no going to her without Alexis, and he feared that he who had een Celadon in the habit of Lucinda, would find him under the diguie of Alexis. Therefore not knowing whom to advie withal but Leonide and this diguied Druide, he acquainted that Nymph with his perplexity. Leonide having an excellent wit, preently returned this anwer. Sir, aid he, you mut leave Alexis and me here; for be aured, if Galathea ees her, he knows her; and if
he hould know her, it would be a great blemih to your profeion: The Gods do eem to direct you unto this coure; for you ee Alexis o diguied in the habit of a Shepherdes, that Hylas does not know her; and which is of mot concernment, I am confident Lerindas will not; o as it is an eaie matter to perwade all the trangers that Alexis is not well, and keeping her bed, you left me to keep her company, for I have no mind to ee the Nymph as long as he continues in the humour wherein I left her; But if you reolve upon this coure, which as I conceive is the only way to keep Alexis out of ight: Two things mut be done, firt, This new Shepherdes mut handomly teal out of the company, and get into her chamber, let Lerindas or Alcidon, or any ele, hould come at lat to know her. The other is, That I do ue ome artifice or other to get thoe Shepherdees who know of her diguie to entreat you, Father, that we may tay here a while under colour of Alexis recovering her complexion which he lot in her icknes; for otherwie they may upect omthing, and it is not yet time for our plot to be dicovered. Adamas who had not yet taken notice how Alexis was diguied, did wonder he hould not know her, and upon erious cogitation, did approve of Leonides opinion: But Alexis much more when he knew it; as well becaue he thought Galathea would know her, as becaue he was afraid that then he hould loe thoe weet contentments which he enjoyed with her Shepherdes, whoe kies and carees could not chue but be pleaing unto her, though he received them only under the notion of Alexis, and Celadon only the Bearer of the name. All three therefore concurring in opinion, the thing was preently reolved upon; and the new Shepherdes tole away from the company, and looked her elf in her chamber; where undreing her elf, he went to bed, after he had dreed her elf as if he were ick, On the other ide, Adamas having bid good morrow unto Diana and Phillis, I am very orry, aid he unto them all, that I mut leave you ooner then I reolved; for fair Shepherdees, Galathea has ent for me, and I mut go immediately unto her; Lerindas here wears he will not leave me till I go. Atrea, who was mot orry for the news, Oh Sir, aid he, is there a neceity of your going o oon? Can you not prolong it a little? Lerindas began then to peak; He cannot go o oon (aid he) nor be with the Nymph o uddenly as he deires. It is not to you Lerindas, that I peak (aid Atrea with an angry look) for I know meengers are always in hate. Adamas knowing very well why he aid o; Sweetheart, aid he, I cannot now tay, becaue the Nymph ends me word he has buines with me, and Lerindas tells me there is a tranger with her, of whom he makes great account: perhaps the buines is of ome great concernment, and delay may do much hurt. The Shepherdes hrugged her houlders, and with a ad look retired to Leonide, who beckned to her with her inger. In the mean time Adamas deired all the company to go homewards, and after Dinner, to go with him. Of all the company, none was o much amazed as Hylas; for every man looking for one to wait upon particularly, his deires were devoted unto the new Shepherdes; and after he had looked all over for her, and all in vain; Fair Nymph aid he unto Leonide, I beeech you tell me where and what is become of that Shepherdes with whom Adamas and you were talking but almot jut now? Unto whom (anwered Leonide) did you commit the cutody of her? Unto my eyes, aid Hylas. Then, aid he, you mut ask your eyes; for we who were otherwie buie, did take no notice of her. Believe me, aid Hylas, if he return not again, I laid by my tock of Love in vain, which I intended to employ in her ervice. Why, replied Leonide, were you o haty in making your proviion? I thought you would have taken more time before you reolved upon a buines of that importance. Nay, nay, aid Hylas, that would be enough for Sylvander, who had need to aemble all the Orders of Gaul, before he can reolve whether he hould Love or no. For my part, I can reolve upon uch a buines in a day, as well as he can in an hundred years: For aoon as ever he ees a Fair one, he conults with himelf whether he has all the qualities that are fit for his Tate: Perhaps he will finde her too tall, or too low: too black, or too Brown: her eyes may be too gray, her noe too long, or too little, her mouth too big, or too little, perhaps her chin too harp, her cheeks too lean; and if he be defective in any of thee, he has done: But aoon as ever my eye meets with a Fair one, and he eem
fair unto them, I never tay to examine any particulars, but preently my will conents to Love her, and makes proviion immediatly to beiege the Fort, or lay by uch a um of love, as I think will buy it. Me thinks Hylas, replied Leonide, ince you have taken o much paines about this tranger, you hould take a little more, and go to eek her, whilt this Shepherdes and I, do talk about ome buines, which much concerns us.

Upon this, both of them turning another way, they eperated themelves from the ret of the Company, to the end none might hear them: then Leonide poke thus unto the Shepherdee: You heard, Sweetheart, how Adamas aid he was contrained to go away, and he was of neceity o to do; for otherwie the Nymph would have occaion to be angry with him. But let me tell you, that I was never in my life in a place from whence I am o unwilling to depart as this: and not only I, but Alexis alo, who I could never have believed would have liked it o well, if I did not ee it; for having been brought up in great aemblies, and continually converant in the buinee of the world, it is hardly imaginable, that a life o retired and olitary, hould ure with her dipoition: And yet I have oberved, that ince he came hither, her complexion is much bettered, which I believe proceeds from the affectionate Love he has taken unto you, which is o great, that yeterday he wore unto me, that a eparation from you would wound her very heart and oul. Madam, anwered Atrea, It is an unexpreible happines unto me that our kind of life, and our patimes, are pleaing unto you, and the Fair Alexis, for my part, I am mot entirely devoted unto both your ervices, and think your Company my greatet honour and happinee: uch is my affection unto Alexis, as I protet Madam, that nothing upon earth can or hall eparate me from her, o he will but be pleaed to accept of me: And therefore I do mot humbly and heartily beeech you, to ait me with your favour in my addrees unto her and Adamas, for I am fully reolved to follow her unto Dreux, and Carnutes, when he returns. The greatet difficulty concerning that, aid Leonide, rets not in them: for I could find a way to procure both their conents; but it rets in your own Parents: Oh Madam! aid Atrea, let that be the leat of your care, for I know wel enough what to do in that, you know it hath pleaed God to leave me without either Father, Mother, or Brother: As for Procion my Uncle, I ow him no uch obedience, but I may very well dipoe of my elf amongt the Druides Daughters without any reproach: No, no, Madam, there is nothing o jut as to devote our elves unto him who gives us all we have. Were it a matter of marriage, or dipoition of my etate, it were another cae; but in reigning my elf up into the hands of the great Tautates, I cannot be blamed: and therefore, Great Nymph, my only buines is, by your mediation to procure me the approbation and conent of Adamas and the Fair Alexis. I will do you all the good offices I can, anwered Leonide; and let me tell you, that Adamas does extreamly Love Alexis, and o, that there needs no more but to get her favour and conent: But why hould I ay, get her favour? Doubtlee you have it already; you need no more but keep her company, and he will be the firt that will be againt the eparation. I believe her Love to you, urpaeth yours to her; but my advice is to keep continually in her Company, and entreat Adamas to let her and me tay here for a few days, which we may eaily do under a pretence of her being ick: And I, eeing what delight he took in this weet place, I did advie her to retire into her Chamber, and pretend icknee, purpoely for an excue of taying here: And though Adamas knows that he is not ick, yet he is willing to let it pae o, becaue it will excue his carrying her unto Galathea, who has long deired to ee her, and keep her with her: But Adamas has no mind unto it, deiring he hould continue her coure of life which he has begun, ince Tautates eems to approve of it, by all the acrifices which he has offered, for that purpoe. You ee, Fair Shepherdee, how freely I peak of things; and I do it, becaue I do much eteem you, and would give you all the contentment that poibly I could. It is a thing impoible to repeat the thanks which this Shepherdes rendred unto Leonide, and as they were thus talking, they wandred a little out of the right way, and becaue the Company had got a great way before them, they took into a path, which might have brought them that were behind, to be before, had they not heard a
voice, which Atrea knew to be Calidons: and becaue he turned out of the way to avoid hearing any more, thinking that to hearken to him were to offend againt the memory of Celadon, Leonide oberved her, and knowing him to be the ame Shepherd that Phocion deired to marry her unto; let us hearken a little, (aid he) for I am confident he is inging omething that concerns you, and you may pae away through the wood uneen, when you pleae: Madam, aid Atrea, you will but pend the time in vain, for I am ure uch a ubject is not worth it. Leonide anwered not, but began to hearken, as he began to ing out his reolution not to Love her longer. I knew (aid Atrea) that you would loe your labour and time in hearing him. Me thinks, aid Leonide, that he is extreamly angry; may he be o eternally, anwered Atrea. Upon this, both turning upon the left hand, they continued on their way.

In the mean time, Paris, remembring the Counel which Leonide gave him, to ask Dianas leave, for asking her Parents conent that he might marry her; and knowing that Adamas was to go unto Galathea as oon as he had dined, he reolved to lay hold upon the opportunity which preented it elf: For, as Fortune was, Diana chanced to be all alone. And though Paris aw much adnes in her countenance, yet after ome ejaculations unto Tautates to proper his enterprie, he accoted her, and taking her under the arm, he aid thus unto her: You ee, Fairet Shepherdee, that my Father is to depart as oon as dinner is done, and that I am contrained to go with him; ome comforts I beeech you give me, to preerve the life of the mot faithful ervant that ever you had. Paris, anwered he, in the quality you mention, I cannot give you any, but in the quality of a peron whom I do much honour, I will give you all I am able. In the quality you mention (anwered Paris) I hould find nothing but death; and if you will not receive me as really I am, I beeech you command me to dye: for I am not able to live and endure the torments which I do. Now, ee how far pite and revenge may carry the heart of a woman, be he never o wie. Diana to be revenged upon Sylvander, will alo be revenged upon her elf: I do eteem you o much (aid he unto Paris) and do think the preervation of your life o dear, that there are very few things which I would not do, to preerve it. Tell me therefore what kind of contentments do you deire I hould give you? That you would be pleaed (replied Paris, and kied her hand) to give me o far permiion as to ask the conent of your Parents, that I may take you as my Wife, and one whom I will Honour, and Love as long as I have life. Bel • nde, anwered he, is my mother, he only has the dipoe of me, and I give you all the leave you deire.

p.U: poke thee words as briefly, and as fat as he could; imitating thoe who take a medicine, and make all the hat they can to get it down: For he never uttered any words more againt her heart, and poke them only to vex Sylvander; for had not paion poeed her undertanding, he would never have conented unto it. For if Sylvander did not Love her, he did not at all vex him by giving her elf unto another: and if he did Love her, why hould he offer to give him any caue of vexation? For he did not give this permiion unto Paris, but only to be revenged upon Sylvander; and would make her elf for ever mierable, rather then not prejudice him: and in this, Paris found that there is a critical hour in which Women can deny nothing; and happy is he that can hit upon it, either by Prudence or by Fortune. The thanks he gave unto the Shepherdes, were very great, but to no purpoe, for he was o much out of her elf, that he undertood not a word; but as oon as he came unto the houe, he tole away, and retired all alone to her Cabin, where giving her eyes leave to weep, he ceaed not all the ret of the day, teaching us at her own expenes, that ometimes we Love more then we do think we do, and never come to know it, but by ome imaginary corn from the peron loved, or when ome contraint deprives us of ight and preence.

div.p:
Adamas hearing by the way that Alexis was ick, the better to diguie his deign, he entreated Daphnide and Al • idon to let him go and ee in what condition he was, eeming to be much troubled at his haty departure: And becaue both of them would accompany him, Atrea and Leonide finding her in bed, they hut the windows, and made the room o dark, that her face could not be een. Alexis pretended
to be exceedingly troubled in her head; and when Adamas told her how earnetly Galathea had ent for him, he offered to rie, and aid, he hoped her dieae was not o great, but that he might follow him. But Astrea beeeched Adamas not to uffer her to walk in the heat of the Sun, which doubtles would make her wore; he told him, that all the Town would be extreamly orry his daughter hould go from amongt them in uch a condition, and that every one would be as officious and ready to erve her with all things that hould be requiite, as he himelf could be; and therefore, as a witnes of all this, he beeeched him to let Leonide keep her company: Phocion and all the ret joyned with her in this deire, and ued o many Arguments, that Adamas was eaily perwaded to leave this diguied Druide amongt them, yet eemed very orry for her, and aid he was afraid he would be too troubleome unto them: But Phocion anwered all thoe objections with words o full of civility and affection, that Adamas told him, he would leave her and Leonide amongt them, commanding them both to come away as oon as Alexis was well again: Afterwards going unto the Bed, and taking Leonide by the hand, he told them in a low voice, that as oon as Galathea was pat, he would either end unto them by Paris, or come himelf; Then hearing that meat was upon the Table, he left the p • etended ick peron; and as oon as Dinner was ended, thanking Phocion and Atrea, he went away with Daphnide and Alcidon, and the ret of the company. But Paris, who did not ee Diana amongt the company, did ask Phillis and Atrea where he was? Who anwered, that perhaps he had ome buines at her houe: Which Adamas and the trangers hearing, they deired Phillis and Atrea to preent their orrows unto her, that they had not taken their leaves of her, and that if poibly they could, they would ee her again before they went out of the Country.

All being thus parted, and thoe who accompanied Adamas returned, Paris would no longer delay his buines; but addreing himelf unto Adamas, he beeeched him he would be pleaed to let him communicate a thing unto him by the way, which concerned himelf and Diana. Adamas imagining his buines, told him, with all his heart: But Paris having obtained this leave, and not knowing how to begin, he tood a long while, and pake not a word: yet Adamas knew well enough that love was the caue of his ilence. Well Paris aid he, and miled, Is this all you have to ay? Paris opened his mouth two or three times, but bluhed and trembled o, as he could not utter a word. Well well aid Adamas unto him, I undertand you very well, and to put you out of your pain. I know that you are in love with Diana; but does Diana love Paris? Or rather, Does not Sylvander poes that place which Paris deires to have? This infued o much confidence into Paris, that he anwered Adamas, That he was afraid he had done amis in uffering his affection unto that Shepherdes to go too far, before he made him acquainted with it: That having ued the habit of a Shepherd, and eeing her o oft, his love was grown to that height, as he was not able to live unles he had uch contentment as thoe who really love do deire; and therefore conidering that thoe Shepherds and Shepherdees were extracted out of as ancient and honourable Families as any was in the Country, he thought it would be no diparagement unto his Houe, if he married Diana; and that Love did at lat force him to acquaint her with his paion. And what anwer did you receive from her, aid Adamas? That Belinde (anwered Paris) was her mother, and had the ole dipoition of her. Then aid Adamas unto him, I have long oberved that you have loved that Shepherdes; and had I diliked that alliance, I hould have forbidden the Banes before now: I do commend your choice, for Diana and Astrea are extracted out of the bet Families not only of this Country, but all Gaul: Amais her elf when he knows of it, will acknowledge as much: Alo the Vertue and Modety of this Shepherdes is uch, as I hall think him very happy that marries her: I mention not her Beauty, becaue that is one of the leat coniderable qualities in a Wife; though he may brag that he is one of the fairet about all Lignon, and this Lignon includes all Europe. And therefore, I do not only give you all the leave you can deire, but do counel and advie you not to loe a minute of time: And becaue I am now going to Bonlieu, where Galathea may perhaps tay me a day or two, I advie you to go home, and make all ready for your
journey, and when you come to Bonlieu, I will have a letter ready for you to carry unto Belinde, that he may know who you are, and treat you, according to your own deires. Upon this, Paris kied the hand of Adamas, gave him a thouand thanks for this favour, and taking leave of him, of Daphnide, of Alcidon, and of all the ret of the Company, he took upon the left hand, and went unto the houe of Adamas, full of contentment, and joy.

As oon as dinner was done, the Nymph Galathea and Damon departed from Bonlieu, to go unto Amais, who being very impatient, or rather troubled at the news which he received, had ent another Cavalier to hate them away. This was a caue why Adamas etting out later then the Shepherds and Shepherdees, he did not find her at the Temple of the good Goddee as he extreamly deired; but he, being very diligent to oberve her as his Lady and Mitres, and knowing he was gone, he entreated Daphnide and Alcidon to continue on their journey, and he would end Lerindas to acquaint the Nymph, who he was confident would tay for them and take them in her Coach. Thee trangers were willing to atisfie his deire, and continued on the way, and Lerindas at the Druides command, ran before.

In the mean time, the Nymph and Damon, went on their journey, and talked upon everal things as well as the way would permit them: For Damon would not go in the Coach, but armed, rid upon an excellent Hore, which the Nymph ent him, thinking himelf in a condition to defend Fair Ladies; and therefore that day, he wore his Head-piece, and his Buckler, which at other times his ervant was wont to carry. Riding on in this manner, when they were pat the Bridge of Bouteres, and entred into a wood, through which the high way paed, not far from the houe of Adamas, Halladine who was behind Galatheas Coach, aw three Cavaliers come ruhing out of the wood, betwixt him and Damon, and ran with their Launces in their Ret as fat as their Hores could ride, againt his Mater: This Faithful ervant, could advertie his Mater no other way, then by crying out as loud as he could; the Cavalier turning his head at his ervants cry, aw the three Cavaliers o neer upon him, as all he could do was to draw his Sword, and heild himelf with his Buckler. Thee three were no ooner out of the wood, but Galathea aw other three, who galloped as fat as they could up to Damon alo: who having not een the firt three, he and her Nymphes in the Coach cried out, which caued Damon to turn about towards them, and mis the hock of two Launces, which otherwie would certainly have thrown him to the ground: the third who came a little after the other two, received the wages for all three; for Damon in a fury to ee himelf thus unworthily treated, did cut off mot of his Arm, and he fell at his Hores feet. Damon till hearing the Nymphes to cry out louder and louder, he turned towards them, and aw the other three Cavaliers; who more advied then the firt, ran all three with their Launces at his Hore, o as he fell immediatly, and gave his Rider no more time then to get his feet out of the tirrups. Damon then leaping out of the Saddle, and eeing himelf et on by no fewer then five at once he thought his bet coure was to keep neer his Hore which lay dead; and thoe who aaulted him, eeing their hores to boggle at the dead one, three of them alighted, and two kept till on hor-back, and thus all five fell upon him at once mot furiouly. Damon who had formerly been in the like condition, reolved to fell his life as deerly as he could; and the firt footman he met with, he gave him uch a blow on his head, that the mans Arms being good, but he not able to bear the weight of that blow, he fell down in a dead woon, and falling with his head againt a tone, his head piece fell off: o as the fight being neer the Coach, Galathea and all the Nymphs knew him to belong unto Polemas, o as all the Nymphs perwaded Galathea to tay no longer there for fear of ome Treaon againt her: In the mean time the Souldiers were very buy about Damon; but the Nymph anwered, that it were a hame for her to leave o brave a Cavalier in the midt of a danger, whereof he her elf was the caue. Whilt the Nymphs were thus talking, Damon had weathed his word up to the very hilts in the body of one of his enemies; but another of them, pying his opportunity, did cloe with Damon, and threw him to the ground, but yet Damon was fully revenged: for there being a defect in the
Souldier's Armour, Damon's word ran him into the belly, o as he fell dead ome two or three paces off: Of ix, there remained now but three that were able to offend him, and all on foot; and they fell upon him o reolutely, as doubtles they had dipatched him, had not a Shepherd and a Shepherdes come luckily to the place: For the Shepherd eeing o many upon one, he went to Damon's ervant, and asked him why he did not defend his Mater? Alas friend (aid the ervant) mot willingly I would if I might; but not being of the Order of Cavalry, my Mater has charged me not to preume unto o much honour as to ue a weapon. A mot cured conideration it is (aid the Shepherd) that hinders thee from helping o brave a Mater in his need: Upon this the Shepherd ran to one of the dead Cavaliers, took his Sword and Buckler, and fell couragiouly upon one of them that was upon Damon, giving him uch a blow upon his houlder, that he made him turn towards him, and upon his turning, the Shepherd ran his Sword through the Cavaliers body under his right Arm, o as he fell down dead cloe by his companions: This did extreamly amaze thoe that were upon Damon; and one of them eeing the Shepherd diarmed, did bid his companion chatie him who had killed their fellow; which he did accordingly, and fell upon him o furiouly, that having the advantage of fighting with one unarmed, he gave him two or three great wounds in his Body, although the Shepherd defended himelf very bravely, and with much courage and dexterity; but alas, all the blows he made were againt hard Armour, and all thoe he received, upon his naked body. Damon in the mean time having now no more but one to deal with, yet he received two or three wounds in his Thigh; but however, he cloed with his Antagonit, and ran him into the Belly, o as he fell dead at his feet. Then running to relieve the Shepherd who had relieved him, he fell upon the Souldier who had newly o wounded the Shepherd, as he was taggering and ready to fall: Damon preently with a dexterous blow divided his head and his houlders; and the poor Shepherd having een his revenge, he fell to the ground almot dead. The Shepherdes ran preently unto him, and itting down upon the ground, did lay the Shepherds bleeding head in her lap, o full of orrow to ee him in that ad condition, as he wihed her elf in the ame. Damon was going to help her, when Galathea cryed out, and bade him take heed; and doubtles he had been in great danger, had he not cryed out; for he thinking that all the ix Souldiers were dead, he never imagined that he who lay in a woon hould rie again, and come behind him; but turning preently about upon her cry, he aw the man with his Arm up; who gave uch a weighty blow upon his Buckler, as he clove it in two; had this blow been given behind upon his head, doubtlee it had cloven it alo in two, for he had put his Helmet off. This fellow being both tout and deperate, and Damon being both wounded and weary, the fight was very dangerous unto him, for he was not o nimble and dexterous as uual: yet at the lat, he ran his Sword into the very throat of his enemy, who fell choaked in his own blood.

In the mean time Adamas came to the place, and Alcidon and Hermantes eeing all this, alo thinking that perhaps there would be no more work, they ran preently to thoe that lay dead, and eized upon their words and bucklers; then they went unto the Nymphs Coach to defend her, and preented themelves in uch a poture, as made it apparently appear, they could do omthing ele beides keeping of Sheep, although they were in that habit: As for Adamas, he went to the Shepherdes, and finding him whoe head lay in her lap to be very much wounded, he helped her to binde up his wounds, which he had finihed; when Galathea eeing the Souldier dipatched, he went unto Damon, to know how he did. Damon who aw that the man who had relieved him was in a bad condition, he ran preently to help him, but he found that Adamas had already bound up his wounds, and the Shepherdes leaning over him o welled with Tears, that he never looked up. The Shepherd finding that his end was near, did offer twice or thrice to turn his head and look upon her, but he could not, becaue he lay the contrary way; yet hearing what ad ighs and tears he hed for him: Be of good comfort Madam (aid he unto her) and fear not, but that he who is the jut Judge of all, will end you ome in my room to conduct you into your Country: the greatet grief that I hall carry to my grave, is, to leave you in this Country, and ee none with you that will erve you as faithfully as
hitherto I have done: but I know that the great and good Tautates will hear my prayers, and guide you out of the place o full of danger. He would have poken more but his weaknes would not permit him. Then the Shepherdes began: Alas (aid he) will you leave me in my greatet need? Have you not promied never to forake me, till we find the Cavalier whom we eek for? Madam anwered the Shepherd, it is the fault of Fate, not mine: for I protet, I would never leave you untill I have put you into the hands of the Knight of the Tiger, as you deire. Alas Madam, you cannot jutly accue me of any thing, but undertaking more then I was able to perform; In all this long voyage, I have rendered you all the honour, all the ret, and all the ervices I was able, and the great Tautates be my witnee, I would have continued it till, if my life might continue: and could I but ee you in any place of afety, death hould be mut welcom unto me.

Damon as I told you, ran to held the Shepherd; but as oon as ever he cat his eye upon him, and aw his face, he was amazed, and tood looking upon him as if he were immovable: and doubtlee his admiration had been more, had not the Shepherdes lifted up her drooping head, o as he thought that he hould know her face, and the tone of her voice: but the habit of a Shepherdes and a Shepherd, and the wan palenes of both their faces, made him tand in doubt, whether his eyes and his eares did deceive him. In the mean time Halladine came unto him to bind up his wounds; but he was o taken up with the ight of this Shepherdes and Shepherd, that without anwering Halladine, or o much as eeing him, he uffered him to take away his Buckler, and began to di-arm him, where he aw the blood run, when Adamas and Galathea came to him, and when the Shepherd, cating his eye by chance upon the Buckler which Halladine laid upon the ground; Oh good God, Madam (aid he unto her) what is this I ee? and with much a do, holding out his arm, he hewed her the Buckler with a Tiger feeding upon a mans heart: o as knowing it to belong unto that Cavalier whom they were in quet of; Oh happy Therander (cryed he out) now dye when thou wilt with full contentment, ince Heaven has been o favourable unto thee as to ee Madonthe in the hands of her o much deired Protector. Damon hearing the name of Therander, and afterwards Madonthe; and both of them looking upon him, he had been blind if he had not known them. Now did he plainly ee his long lookt for Madonthe, and Therander alo, whoe life he o reolved to take away. His love of Madonthe, his hatred of Therander, and his unexpected meeting with them, did make him tremble, as if he had an extream fit of an ague upon him: He knew not what to do; whether he hould go away, or whether he hould take revenge, and kill the raviher of his happines before the face of her whom he thought had ued him o ill: The injury which he conceived he had received, did invite him to it; and his affection and repect tayed his trembling hand: But at lat, thinking upon the Oracle which he had received at Mount Verdune, he quenched all deires of revenge. But haking from him all thoe that were o buie in di-arming him, who thought that his trembling proceeded from his wounds, he ran preently to the Shepherdes.

Oh Madonthe, Madonthe! cryed he out, has Heaven been o favourable to me, as to let me once more ee you before I dye? Upon this kneeling down upon the ground before her, he offered to take her hand and kis it; but Madonthe urpried beyond imagination, firt, to have met with the Knight of the Tiger whom he ought for, and econdly, eeing him to be Damon whom he thought long ince dead, he was o ravihed with wonder, that eeing him upon his knees before her, when he leat hoped for him, he could not chue but with open arms embrace him: But this unexpected meeting, and udden joy, made her look as if death were in her face. Damon, on his ide, looked as pale as he, o as if Halladine had not run preently to hold them up, doubtles they had both faln to the ground. Therander now knowing him alo to be Damon, and hearing him peak, he lifted up his eyes to Heaven, having not o much trength as to tir his hands: Oh God! aid he, How jut, how good, and how omnipotent thou art? Jut in rendring Damon unto Madonthe, and Madonthe unto Damon; good in making three perons happy at once: Thee two Lovers in meeting that happines they deired, and Therander in eeing o good a concluion of his ervices; and omnipotent in bringing all thee
things to pas when we leat hoped for them: Oh Madonthe! Oh Damon! may you enjoy all fulnes of contentment, and live happily together many, many years. Upon this expreion he grew pale, and reigned his lat breath with uch a miling countenance, as plainly hewed he left this life with contentment. Galathea in the mean time, and Adamas, who with all the ret of the Nymphs were come to this Cavalier, they were all in extream amazement, to ee all thee three perons look as if they were all dead alike. But Halladine who loved his Mater extreamly, Madam (aid he) if there be any parke of pity in you, I beeech you command Damon to di-arm himelf, leat his los of blood prove the los of his life. How friend, aid Alcidon to Halladine, is this Damon the Valiant Cavalier of Aquitane? The very ame Sir, aid Halladine, who has lot more blood in eight dayes he has been here in this Country; then he has of many years in all other places: Oh Father! (aid Alcidon unto Adamas) I beeech you let us contribute all the help we can; for I can aure you, there is not a braver and more accomplihed Cavalier in all Aquitane then this: Then kneeling down upon the ground, he began to di-arm him, Damon not being enible of it. As for Madonthe after he had continued a while in a woon, he came again to her elf; and eeing every one o buie about Damon, he thought that he was dead of thoe wounds which he received in the combate. Oh my God! cryed he out, and wrung her hands, mut I loe thee Damon as oon as ever I have found thee? And mut I ee thee now, never to ee thee again? Mierable wretched Madonthe, what malevolent Star is predominate over thee? Mut thou receive a happines only to be the more enible of its los? Oh Heavens! Oh Fate! was ever uch bitter torments reerved for any that lives? Life I defie thee; and torments do your wort till you have brought me to my grave: upon this, her ighs and her tears did o top the paage of her voice, that he was forced to be ilent; but her ilence moved o much compaion in all the Nymphs, that whilt Alcidon, Daphnide, Hermantes, Adamas, and Galathea, were about Damon, they took the Shepherdes under her arms, and removed her almot by force from the place where he was, every one giving her all the conolation they could.

In the mean time, Damon was di-armed, his wounds bound up as well as the inconveniency of the place would permit; and a little after he began to open his eyes: but being o weak as he was not able to rie, he turned his head two or three times about to look for Madonthe: and Halladine knowing very well what he looked for; Sir, aid he unto him, do not trouble your elf o much, Madonthe is not far from you; aume to your elf Sir a little courage, and all will be well: Halladine (anwered Damon) what doet thou talk of courage? Dot thou think I can want any, that had o much as to love the perfections of Madonthe? But where is he? And what is it, which hinders me from a ight of that Fair Face? is he till with Therander? Therander Sir, anwered Halladine, is dead, and dyed to ave your life, by which you may ee the truth of the Oracle, and what great reaon you have to rejoyce, ince now your troubles are all to end. Halladine, aid Damon, help me to rie, that I may ee whether all thou ayt is true. Madonthe hearing all that Damon aid, he took heart; and being extreamly joyed to ee him in a better condition then he imagined, he roe up, and ran as fat as he could unto him, and without any regard unto thoe about him, he almot mothered him with embraces; but being taken off by Halladine, who feared that her exceive kindnes might make him wore, he at down upon the ground by him; and looking upon him with eyes full of admiration: Ah Damon! aid he unto him, is Heaven o good unto me, as to let me ee thee once more? Is it poible that the Knight of the Tiger, who recued me from the hands of the perfidious Leriana, hould prove to be Damon, whom he had o craftily given o much occaion to hate me? And is it poible, Cavalier, that thy affection to me hould be above her malice, and that out of thy generoity thou houldet ave her life, whom by her ubtilty thou hadt reaon to hate unto death? But Cavalier, if thou art indeed that Damon of whom I peak, and if all thoe caues, together with o long abence from me, have not changed thy affection, why dot thou tay o long before thou givet me ome aurance of it? Damon then taking her hand; yes, yes Madam, aid he, I am the very ame Damon you peak of; and weat that I am nothing changed, unles it be in loving you more then ever I did:
All the venom of Leriana, nor all the happines of Therander, was not able to diminih the leat park of my vowed affection to you; Heaven is the witnes of all my thoughts, and the Sun has een all my actions: and I challenge them both to upbraid me with the leat tain of my fidelity to you. I mut needs confes, replied Madonthe, that the treaon of Leriana was enough to make you hate me, and to believe all that he had infued into you concerning the happinee of Therander: But I do vow unto you by the memory of my honoured Father, and by all my deires and hopes of any happines, that all I did was only to be the more loved by you; and all the favours done unto Therander, was only to reclaim Damon from an imaginary affection; and my deign in abenting my elf from my Country, and my friends, was only to eek out Damon under the Notion and Arms of the Knight of the Tiger. Oh ye good Gods! (cryed out Damon) Never was Cavalier in the world o happy as I am, ince I have received thee aurances from the mouth of Madonthe.

She would have replied, when Adamas mitruting the ecurity of that place, and fearing let the wounds of Damon hould grow wore, he told Galathea, that he thought it convenient to carry this Cavalier unto ome place where his wounds might be better dret, and ince he was very weak, he deired he might ret himelf ome dayes in his houe, becaue it was the neeret place of conveniency. Neceity made the Nymph conent unto this motion; o as ending unto ome of the Neighboring Hamblets, they got Damon to be carried unto the houe of Adamas, and the corps of Therander unto the Town of Marelles, to give it an honourable Funeral. In the mean time Galathea advertied Amais by Lerindas, of all thee paages, beeeching her that Damon might be put into ome place of afety, which when he had done, he would preently come and receive her commands.

Madonthe could not poibly chue but lament the los of poor Therander, and certainly it had cot her many more tears had he not met with Damon: But however; his long fidelity, affection, and ervice, might well claim ome tears for his diaterous Fate, and in reward of all his pains, which he did mot zealouly pay. In the mean time, they began to carry away Damon, who turning his head every way to ee what Madonthe did, and pying the body of Therander, he could not chue but igh, not yet knowing whether he hould wih him alive or no. Yet conidering that he dyed to ave his life, his generoity contrained him to ay, Farewell Friend, ret contented, in that having Damon for thy enemy, thou hat obliged him to lament thy los, and to call thee his Friend. Upon this, he held out his hand unto Madonthe, who came unto him, and never left him until he was in the houe of Adamas, although Galathea did mot earnetly deire her to come into the Coach, chuing rather to follow Damon on foot, then to be one minute abent from him.

On the other ide, Adamas having preented Daphnide, Alcidon, and the ret of their Company unto the Nymph, and he receiving them with all expreions of civility, that the trouble wherein he was would permit; he took them into her Coach: as for Adamas, he would needs follow Damon, whom they carried a horter way then the Coach was able to go. In the mean time Lerindas, leaving thoe that were to bring the corps of Therander, he ran as fat as he could before, to advertie Amais, according to the intructions of Galathea; and though he aw everal perons running up and down the fields on his left hand, and though he thought them to belong unto Polemas, yet he went on, having a command to peak unto none but Amais: yet he whom Polemas had et as a py upon the way, to oberve who paed, ran preently unto him to acquaint him; and preently after, another brought him word that they aw a Company coming, who carried omthing like a corps. Polemas who tayed there only to know the ooner what was become of Damon, did preently beleeve, that is was he whom they brought dead, or at leat wounded. And rejoycing much in himelf, though eeming to be much troubled, he walked oftly to the way, eeming ignorant of Galatheas removing from Bonlieu, he asked thoe who were with him, whom it might be whom they brought in this manner. None knew what to anwer, becaue he had not dicovered his enterprie unto any about him, being more politique then to divulge thoe deign, which he
intended to execute: after he had walked a little farther, one of his men came and told him, that it was one who was dead, whom Galathea had caued to be carried unto Marcelles, and who was killed in her preence within the next wood. Now did he begin to think that the Souldiers had executed what they had promied, and began to gut all the weets of revenge; but it lated no longer then till he met this corps: for oberving it to be the corps of no Cavalier, and asking where they found that corps, and whither they carried it? The men anwered, that Galathea had been et upon by ix Cavaliers, that one ingle man had defeated them all: that this Shepherd offering to ait was killed, but all the ret lay dead upon the ground, and that they carried the corps of this Shepherd unto Marelles, by command of Galathea, to be there honorably interred. But, aid Polemas, what is become of the Cavalier that reited all the ret? He is much wounded, anwered they, and is carried unto the houe of the grand Druide. Polemas then eeming to know nothing of the buines: This it is (aid he as went away) to cahier Souldiers without a caue; I do verily believe, thee are ome of them that were cahiered, who being angry againt Damon, did now eek to be revenged upon him in this wood; and this he aid as a preparative to an excue when Galathea hould complain againt him, for he did imagine that the men would be all known. Then continuing till his hunting, to take away all thoughts that he had any hand in the buines; he preently dipatched one of his men to congratulate Galathea from him, for the good Fortune which Damon had in this Country, and commanded the man to take epecial notice of all the words, and have an obervant eye over all the actions of the Nymph. And at the ame time dipatched another man to acquaint Amais with the accident, beeeching her not to uffer Galathea to go abroad any more alone, and without uch guards as are fitting for her Grandeur: he alo commanded this man to have a pecial obervance of all that Amais aid and did.

Clidamant, Guyemant, and Lindamore, with mot of the Cavalry in the Country, being now in the Army of the Franks, Polemas tayed at home as Lieutenant unto Amais, in the room of Clidamant; And an ambitious deign welled him with hopes to make himelf Lord of this Province; and yet conidering what abundance of difficulties he was to meet withall, in altering the Fundamental Laws of a State, and in taking the whole frame from off its bais, he thought it expedient, firt, to try all wayes if he could marry Galathea, and left nothing invented which might probably bring it to pas: Now eeing but only two ways to compas his deign, the one by weetnes, the other by violence, he would firt try if he could win her good will; and if that failed, then to have recoure unto the fat remedy.

In order to his firt deign, he would imploy that pretended Druide, called Climanthes, who had formerly told Galathea her Fortune, having an opinion, that the Nymph had a Genius, very apt and inclinable to hearken unto uch impotures and Novelties. He procured him therefore to et up his Cell again neer the Garden of Mount Brion where it was before; and etting all his things in better order as he thought, then formerly; he hewed himelf two or three dayes, in hopes that Galathea would come and viit him as before he had done. And Polemas to make the bet ue of the abence of Clidamant and Lindamore he could, he provided himelf of many Souldiers in the Dominions of the Viigots and Burgundians, who remained quietly in the neighbouring Towns in expectation of his commands.
