He had already courted himelf into the amity of the neighbour Princes, by corrupting their principal Officers; and was o liberal in the Seguian Country, o Courteous both to people and Souldiers, and o repective unto the Druides, Fubages, Sarronides, Vaces, and other Sacrificers, as every one deired nothing more then the marriage betwixt Galathea and him, unles ome few, who being wier then the ret, did plainly ee that all this was not his nature, but only forced to compae his ends in obtaining Soveraign Power, which once gotten, he would not keep by the ame means he got it, but by more harp and Tyranique coures. It was long before Amais could ee thee things; becaue an honet and good oul cannot imagine that a peron obliged hould ever become ungrateful and traiterous. But at the lat, he began to perceive it by a letter which dropped from him, in which he found out what great
intimacy there was betwixt Gond • bant and him, and therefore aoon as Lerindas told her of the accident which had hapned unto Damon, and that it was by the Souldiers of Polemas, he believed him to be the etter on; yet knowing how dangerous it is to hew any mitrut of a Prime Officer, before one be in a good capacity to oppoe him: when the Meenger of Polemas came to deliver his meage, he eemed very thankful unto him for the care he had of Galathea, and ent him word b • ck, that his Counel was o good, as he would follow it in this and all things ele; And dipatching away the Meenger, he left Marelles, and went unto the houe of Adamas with a good guard of Cavaliers to wait upon her: For the news which he had received from the Army of the Francks, did extreamly trouble her; and he feared that ince it could not be long kept in ecret, Polemas would reolve upon ome ill deign, as of late he began to think he was apt to do.

Galathea was no ooner come to the houe of Adamas, but the Meenger from Polemas came alo, and delivered the meage of his Mater very bluntly unto her; but he not being able to hide the dipleaure which he had conceived againt him, anwered him very harply: Go and tell your Mater, aid he, that I am very much dipleaed with thoe that belong unto him; and if he do not take ome better order, I hall be very angry with him.

In the mean time Damon was got into bed, and when the Chyrurgions earched his wounds, they found them to be more painful then dangerous; For though he was run through the Thigh in two or three everal places, yet as happy luck was, no Nerve nor Vein was hurt, which joyed Madonthe beyond all expreions. The Chyrurgions knowing that the contentment of the mind was highly conducible to the cure of the body, they intreated Madonthe not to tir from him; and becaue he was deirous he hould know all her adventures ince he came out of Aquitane, he did not only anwer unto all his quetions, but related all the plots and ubtilties of Leriana, which he had contrived to the advantage of Therander: But when he came to reheare the grief which he conceived at his death, when Halladine brought the Handkerchief full of blood unto Leriana, and Theranders Ring unto her, he was not able to refrain from tears: then he related the horrours of that ignominious death which he was to dye, and the unlookt for relief which he received from the Knight of the Tiger: And his departing unknown, continued he, was the caue of my reolution to eek him out. But cruel Damon, aid he, for I mut give you that Title, how could you find a heart to go away and never tell me who you were? Why hould you after you had given life to my body, ravih away the life of my oul? Why would you not let me know you were alive? Oh Damon! how many ad ighes, orrows and tears, had you pared me if you had? Afterward he related unto him her reolution of eeking out this unknown Knight, whom he was in quet of, though he knew no reaon, why he hould be o earnet after him: But the allwie providence of Heaven would have it o, that I might find Damon under the name of another: The truth is, continued he, I had a far fetched conceipt, that I hould find him thus, or ele I hould never find him; and you ee how happily God brings all things about: Therander was the firt caue of our eparation, and Therander is the lat caue of our conjunction; how faithfully has he waited upon me, and kept himelf within the limits of a repectful ditance, maugre all the falacies and fale hopes that Leriana had inued into him; by which the bet advied man might well have been deluded? Upon this he acquainted him how her Nure dyed at Mount Dor; how he met with Laonice, Hylas, and Tirsis; and how the Oracle caued her to come into this Country, where he had pent her time in the Company of Atrea, Diana, Phillis, and other Shepherdees of Lignon, from whom he departed that morning, with a deign of returning into Aquitane, and there pend the ret of her days amongt the Vetals and Druides Daughters. To be brief, he omitted nothing, but made a mot faithful relation of every paage unto Damon, who hearkned unto it with o much joy and contentment, as he knew not which way to be thankful enough unto his good Fortune, for this favour: and after a while of ravihment in this contemplation, he aid unto her, I hall Madam another time give you an exact relation of my life ince I had the happines of eeing you lat; but at this time the Chyrurgions forbid me peaking, and therefore I will not ue any
long dicoure, only let me tell you, that I hope our future Fortunes will be better then they have been: For the Oracle which I conulted with at Mount Verdun, aured me that I hould be retored from death to life by that man whom I mot hated and contemned: And ee how this poor Cavalier brought you hither, where I find you: For the Truth is, I might mot rightly be aid to be dead when I was deprived of you; and alive again in the happines of being with you; when I do conider the paage, I cannot chue but admire at the wie providence of the Great Gods, who has ordered Therander to give me a double life, the life of my body, by that relief which he brought me, and the life of my oul, in conducting you Madam unto the place where I was: There is only one doubt in the Oracle, which I do cruple at:

lg.head: The Oracle.
lg.l: AND thou, O perfect Lover, when
Thou hear't a Diamond peak: Oh! then
From Death to Life thou halt return,
By help of him whom thou didt corn.

div.p:
I ee, (aid he) that all is mot perfectly accomplihed, except this hearing a Diamond peak, unles the Oracle will have me to take you Madam, for a Diamond in contancy and excellency of amity. Adamas hearkned unto this Dicoure very attentively; Sir, aid he, and miled, if I had been known unto you, the obcurity of this Oracle would vanih: for my name is Adamas, which ingifies in the Roman Language a Diamond; o as this Oracle let you know, that as oon as you hear me, this accident hall befall you; and o indeed it did: For at the very ame time that Alcidon, Daphnide, and I, came unto the place where you were, you met with Madonthe. I mut confes (aid Damon) the Oracle is fully cleered, and I am mot humbly thankful unto that Deity which ordained me this happines when I leat expected it: But Reverend Father, continued he, and looked about the Chamber, I heard you name two perons, whom I infinitely eteem, and hould think my elf very happy to ee in this place. Then Alcidon tepped to him, and imbracing him, aid, yes Damon, Daphnide and Alcidon are here, and are conducted unto this Country of wonders, by the ame Love which brought you into it: At the ame time Daphnide came unto him, and aluting him, aid, yes, yes Damon, Madonthe can tell you, that Daphnide is alo here, and preents her elf unto you under the notion of one of your bet Friends. Damon being urpried to ee this Cavalier, and this Lady, thus clad in the habit of Shepherds, he knew not at firt whether he was aleep or awake; but afterwards touching them, and hearing them peak, he embraced them, and cryed out; O Alcidon! I mut needs confes with you, that this Country is a Country of Wonders, but they are wonders full of joy and happines, greater then ever I could hope to ee. Whilt Daphnide and Alcidon were aluting, Madonthe, and they were all rejoycing together at their happy meeting, news was brought unto Adamas that the Nymph Amais was entred into the Court; and he was no ooner out of the Chamber to meet her, but he found her at the door, where after he had tayed a little, he entred into the room where Damon was: I think, valiant Cavalier, aid he unto him, that I hall never come to ee you, but hall find you thus unfortunately wounded. Madam, anwered Damon, I hall never complain againt any of thee wounds which I have received: For the firt, gave me the honour of eeing the Nymph Galathea, and then you Madam; and thee lat have made me meet with her, who only in all the World can make me happy: o as in lieu of complaining againt this Country, I have caue to Love it, eteem it, and peak well of it. Upon this Amais being informed of the quality of Madonthe, he went to embrace her, and cares her according to her merits; and becaue he took no notice of Daphnide and Alcidon; I perceive Madam, (aid Damon unto her) that thoe two perons are unknown unto you, but be pleaed to know, that they are worth your acquaintance; for though you ee them thus diguied, yet Madam
the one is Daphnide, and the other is Alcidon; the very ame Daphnide whoe merits o much commanded the affection of the Great Eurick: And the very ame Alcidon, o Feared and Loved for his valour by Thorimond King of the Viigots, and all thoe that ucceeded him. Amais, upon this, gave him thanks for his advice, and went to embrace them: It had been enough (aid he) if you had only told me their right names; for as oon as I had heard them, I hould preently have known thee two to be the Great Favorites of King Eurick: But I mut needs confes, that eeing them thus habited, I hould not have known them for what they are, and therefore I am obliged unto you for telling me. The obligation Madam, replied Daphnide, is on our ides, ince he has made us known unto the greatet, mot eteemed, and honoured Nymph amongt all the Gaules. But Sir, aid Amais unto Alcidon, how came you to be thus diguied? And where met you with this Shepherds habit? The Story of it Madam, anwered Alcidon, would be too long; but I beeech you, who can be in Forrets and not become a Shepherd? The Country is o full of accomplihed Shepherds, and Fair Shepherdees, as I rather wonder that you Madam, and all your Nymphs, are not in the Habits of Shepherdees.

I am very glad (anwered the Nymph) that you have found any thing in this Country which pleaeth you; but when we have the happines to ee you in Marelles, perhaps you will not think my Nymphs les lovely then the Shepherdees, nor find them in any humour of changing habits with them. Madam, (anwered Alcidon) I do not doubt of any thing you ay; but I beeech you give me leave to be ilent, and to ay nothing unto what I do not yet know.

The Nymph had continued the dicoure longer, if he had not been very deirous to have ome talk with the age Adamas: and having held a long dicoure with Galathea and him, upon the news which he had received, he went at lat unto Damon, and asked him how he did after his wounds were dreed? And undertanding that he found himelf much better, he left him with Madonthe, aying he would not hinder them of their contentments in talking privately together: Then he commanded Silvia, and the ret of the Nymphs, to entertain Daphnide and her Company, and to hew Alcidon that the Nymphs of Marelles do not yeild unto the Shepherdees of Lignon. Upon this taking Adamas by one hand, and Galathea by another, he went into the Gallery, where the doors being all hut, he took a whole turn before he began to peak: afterwards auming another look more erious then before, and eeming to be much troubled, he turned her elf toward Adamas and poke thus.

Father (aid he) I have things of great importance to impart unto you; and you mut give me that Faithful and Prudent Counel, which you were always wont: and becaue I may perhaps forget ome material paages, I deire that he who brought me the news, may make the relation of it unto you, if we have but as much time afterwards as to return unto Marelles: Madam, anwered Adamas, I pray Heaven you be not mitaken in my Prudence, and I dare anwer for my fidelity; and as for your return unto Marelles, I hall hope that unles your hate be very great, you will honour me and my houe o much as to tay this night in it: Father, (anwered Amais) if the urgency of my affairs would permit it, I hould be very willing; but when you hall hear what the Cavalier will ay whom Lindamore ent unto me, you will not judg it convenient: Then cauing Galathea to call in the Cavalier whom Lindamore ent, and the doors being hut, pray Sir, aid he unto the Cavalier, make us a relation of all the meage which Lindamore has ent unto me, and omit not any particular either concerning our affairs, or the affairs of Childerick and Guyemant, ince they are o linked together, that they can hardly be eparated. Upon this, placing the Cavalier between her elf and Adamas, and holding Galathea in her other hand, they all walked together; and the Cavalier in obedience to her commands, with a deep igh, began thus.

div.head: The Hitory of Childerick, Silviana, and Adrimartes.
div.p: I Cannot Madam without a World of grief, make this relation which you have commanded me: And yet I cannot refue any thing which comes with a command from you; if you find any diorder in my Dicoure, or if perchance I forget any thing, I beeech you impute it to my orrows, and let it find a pardon: and you hall ee by what I hall relate, how all thoe who have dependency upon a Prince, are intereted in his conduct: and how their good and their bad Fortunes have their influences from him.

The King Merovius who by the grandure of his actions has got the Title of Excellent among the Franks; and in their own Language Mervoch, ignifies Excellent Prince. After he had gained many victories, as well over the Huns, Gepides, and Almaines, as over the Romans and Burgundians; and after he had Reigned twelve years, he died full of glory, and lamented by the people, leaving by his wie Methina, the Daughter of Stuffart King of the Huns, and Predeceor of Atillas, urnamed the Scourge of God, only one Son whoe name is Childerick.

The Reputation of the Father, and the Love which he had got amongt the people, moved all the Franks with a common conent to make choie of Childerick the Son; and having et upon his head a double Crown, the one to intimate his ucceion, and the other to peak the conquets of his Father, they carried him upon their houlders throughout all the treets of Soions, and proclaimed him King of the Franks: before him went the Heralds of Arms, carrying in their hands Enignes won by Merovius from the Huns, Gepides, Alaines, Burgundians and Romans, all which they trailed upon the ground: after followed the Enignes of the Franks, which were emi-Flower de Luces in an Azure Field: and lat of all followed the Enignes of Merovius his Father; The firt was a Lion endeavouring to mount a teep Hill to devour an Eagle which ate upon the top, with this motto; With Paines is the Prey obtained; and another was a Crown upon a Buckler, with this motto: A Buckler ecures a Crown. Thus going Triumphantly through all the treets, the Air did Eccho with the loud acclamations of the People and Souldiers: Bonfires blazed befory every door, and when they were extinguihed, great Wax Tapers burned all the night before every mans houe, and nothing but dancing and joy could be een in the treets; Tables umptuouly furnihed were et out for all commers: And it is impoible for me Madam, to expres the great hopes that the people had in this young King: looking upon him as the Son of Merovius, whoe memory was yet o freh, that all his great victories eemed to be before their eyes, and the generous actions of the Father made them hope for the ame from the Son, both in matter of Arms, and management of publique affairs. But he quickly hewed them that Dominion is a place o lippery, that few perons can attain to it, and fewer can find firm footing without a fall: For in a hort time after he was Crowned, he began to lay Arms aide, and addict himelf unto all manner of pleaures; not remembring that it was the magnanimity, and martial exploits of his predeceors, which had promoted them unto that Dominion: o as now the Court was quite changed and warmed with eeminate Sycophants, whilt valiant and brave minds had nothing to do, but tand with their hands in their pockets; young Gallants who under Merovius began to bud in valour, are now after the example of Childerick turned women, and look not like the ame men they promied to be. So as all the hopes of conquet were turned unto fears, let the tate which they had conquered hould revolt; and the utmot limits of all their hopes was only to keep what they had already gotten. Clidamant, Lindamore, and Guyemant, were much dipleaed at the alteration of this Prince, epecially Guyemant, as one mot concerned, and one who had devoted all his ervices unto this King. So as when Lindamore
advied Clidamant to return into his own Country, becaue this Prince was o drowned in pleaures, that there was no more glory to be got by taying there, Gayemant with tears in his eyes diwaded him, aying, that if any thing under Heaven would awake Childerick from his drowie ecurity, it would be the generoity and virtue of Clidemant; and if o much happines befel the Franks by his means, he would get more glory by it then any other way: beides, he was to conider, that he having aited Merovius againt o many potent enemies, it would torn extreamly to his di-advantage if he did not alo ait Childerick, having made many Princes his enemies by taking part with the Franks. Clidemant who was a generous Prince, and who did love the peron of Childerick, he was eaily perwaded to tay with him, and o topped his eares againt the ound advice of Lindamore, as all his prudent propoitions proved fruitles.

There was in the Court a young Cavalier called Andrimartes, Son unto one of the mot valiant Heroes of all the Franks: he had the honour to be educated with this young Prince, when he was o young, as he was not fit to follow Merovius in the Army. This Andrimartes with many other children of the Prime Cavaliers, were continually with young Childerick, and intructed in all manner of Noble exercies, that might make them fit to erve their Prince and Country. And thee yourhs were not only taught in all things requiite unto courage and war, but alo in all things that might polih their minds, and temper the Natural Ferocity of the old Sicambrians, and the inhabitants of the Meotidan Lake. Alo to render them more plauible unto the Gaules, who are a people the mot civilized of all Europe, they were very often amongt the young Ladies, which belonged unto the Queen Methina, and there was uch pritty familiants amongt them, as they would propound everal marriages amongt themelves: this Queen had command from the prudent Merovius her Husbandi to entertain as many of the Gaul Ladies as he could, deigning by this way to make himelf King of the Gaules by Love as well as by Arms.

Amongt thoe that were thus entertained and educated during the infancy of Childerick, Silviana had the firt place, as well in repect of her merit, as of her family from whence he was extracted: This young Lady was adorned with all uch qualities as have power to caue Love; both Fortune and Nature had equally been favourable unto her: And beides her beauty which was very high, he had a wit o weet, as all thoe whom her eyes attracted, were held by her courtey, and weet converation. This young Lady was not yet above ten or eleven years of age; and Andrimartes who was about thirteen or fourteen, did cat an amorous glance upon her: Silviana was eteemed the only Star about the Queen Methina; and Andrimartes amongt all thoe about Childerick carried away the commendations, either for dancing, leaping, or any other exercie of the body. Moreover he was of uch a weet and tractable dipoition, that when he got the better of any of his Companions, he was o far from inulting, that none was orry to be urmounted by him, but very willing to yeild unto him that glory which was his due.

At this age the young Andrimartes began to cat an eye upon the Fair Silviana, who being uch a beauty as could not be looked upon and not loved, he began to court her, and give her uch tetimonies of his affections as his green age could afford. Shee, who yet hardly knew the name of Love, received his boyih ervices, as other children ue to do, without any further deign: yet in a little time he began to like him better then any of the ret, and reented omthing which inclined her to talk with him, and to be glad when he was with her from all the ret of her companions, though this inclination yet could not be phraed either love or affection in her: But as the longer one tands by a fire, the more heat he feels; o Andrimartes could not hold uch intimate familiarity with Silviana, without kindling uch parks of Love, as at length o inflamed his oul, that neither time nor any thing ele could extinguih them.

The firt time that he made it known unto her, was one evening when the Queen Methina, according to her cutome, went to walk upon the banks of Seine: for he reided mot at Paris, as well becaue it was the center of the conquets of Merovius, as by reaon of an Oracle, which was lately received from the Temple of Ijis, and which aid thus:
WHen Paris is the Prime of Gaul,
A Gaulih tranger govern hall.

Now Merovius and the Franks thought that their Ancetors being Gaules, this Oracle was poken of them; and I aure my elf that Madam you know how this delectable River of Seine runs round about that City. And when the Queen went to walk upon the banks of it, all the Ladies and Cavaliers waited upon her, and walked alo two and two, where and how they pleaed. One evening therefore after upper, Methina went to take the Air, and Andrimartes taking Silviana under her arm, he entertained her as he was wont with his young affections, unto which he anwered in as innocent Language, as infancy it elf could imagine: As they were wandering amongt the thick of the wood, they ate down at the firt under an old Willow, which grew by the River ide; but the young Lady, not liking to tay too long in a place, and being weary with itting, he roe up and went unto a little tree of Oiers; and making choie of one whoe bark was mooth and tender, he had a mind to engrave her name upon it; o as taking a Gold Bodkin which he wore in her hair, he engraved the Letters of Silviana. Andrimartes eeing what he began to do, he went upon the other ide of the tree, and write upon the ame talk, as if it were in the very ame line, thee words, I Love: o as what he writ, meeting with what Silviana had written, both together made, I Love Silviana: but he going on his ide, he could ee only what he had written; how Andrimartes, aid he, do you Love? I beeech you who? You may ee Madam, (aid he unto her) if you will pleae to read on the Line: For my part, (aid he) I ee nothing but what you have written; look a little better Madam, (aid he) and you may find that which is engraved upon my heart, as well as upon that bark: where is the name, aid he, that you peak of? Look well, aid Andrimartes, and you will find it not far off: I do not undertand you, anwered he, for I ee nothing but that which you writ; what then is this? (anwered Andrimartes, and pointed unto what he had engraved) That is Silviana, (anwered he) Then, aid Andrimartes, joyn what I writ, and what you writ, together. I ee, replied he, that by joyning them together, there is, I Love Silviana; but it was my elf that wrote it: Mot true, anwered Andrimartes, and it is you who has engraven it in my heart. Your heart, replied he, and wondred, how could I do that, for I never aw your heart? I know not Madam how you did it, anwered he, but I am ure that with you Fair Eyes you have done it. Fie, fie, (cryed he out) I cannot believe it, for my eyes cannot engrave, or if they could, I hould urely have een when they did it; had they that quality, I hould not have ued my Bodkin to engrave upon this bark. This childih anwer did plainly hew Andrimartes how ignorant he was in matters of Love: yet for all that, he continued on; It is no wonder Madam, aid he, that your Fair Eyes cannot engrave your Name upon a bark, becaue it is a thing inenible; but aid he, I have often looked upon the Queens little dogs, which he loves o well, and can you find one letter of my Name upon them? No, no, replied he, they are animals without reaon; it is only upon the hearts of men, and men who are mot worthy of that character. How? aid Silviana, can I do it and not perceive it? I beeech you Madam, aid Andrimartes, do you perceive your elf to grow? Alas, aid he, I do that naturally; and you do naturally, replied Andrimartes, make wounds in hearts. Oh my good God, replied he, I have heard ay that all wounds upon the heart are mortal; and if my eyes have wounded yours, I hall be the caue of your death, and you will have all the reaon in the world to hate me: Tis mot certain, replied he, that all wounds upon the heart are mortal, and thoe which you have given me will caue my death, unles you give me a remedy: but however, I cannot hate you, ince on the contrary, I think that I cannot love you o much as I deire, and as you deerve. I conceive the bet way will be, (anwered the young Silviana) that ince my eyes do hurt you o much, to hide them from you for the future. By no means Madam I beeech you, anwered he, unles you would have me die, as oon as you begin that mortal remedy for you mut know,
that if any thing under Heaven can ave my life, it mut be by giving me new wounds. This remedy, (aid the young Silviana) is very trange, and leat you hould dye, I will not only do as you ay, but deire all my companions to do the ame, in hopes that the multitude of wounds which their eyes do make, may eae you in thoe you receive from me: The eyes of your companions (anwered he) can neither hurt nor heal me: what difference (aid he) do you find betwixt my eyes and theirs? For my part, I know not any. There is o much, replied Andrimartes, That I had rather be dead then want the leat wound which I have from you, and I would accord theirs as much as I can. I do not undertand (aid he) why you hould think o; for wounds are wounds, from whomoever they be received. There are (replied Andrimartes) wounds that are honourable and pleaing, and others that are ignominious and painful: thoe which I receive from you are of the firt ort; and thoe which your companions can give are of the other. I cannot imagine (anwered the young Silviana) what the difference hould be. If there were other Silvianas (aid Andrimartes) as Fair and full of Excellencies as you are, and as able by their beauty to make uch welcom wounds, I hould then agree with you that they would be all deirable alike; but ince that cannot be, aure your elf Madam, I hall think nothing to be a favour or a remedy which comes not from your Fairet elf.

Silviana was very young, and yet not o young, but hearing Andrimartes peak thus, he undertood his good will unto her; for elf love is o natural unto us, that nothing does oblige more, at what age oever, then a good eteem which is held of us; and that made him to return this anwer: the good opinion which you have of me, moves you unto this language; but believe it Andrimartes, you are as much obliged unto it by the good opinion which I have of you. Perhaps their dicoure had gone farther, but for the coming of Childerick, who with a great number of young boyes came running and leaping through thoe woods, and parted them; for this young Prince carried away Andrimartes almot by force to leap and exercie with his companions, as he who excelled them all in agility and nimblenes. He left the Fair Silviana with an ill will, and he remained alone with no les dipleaure; for though till then he never had the leat reentment of Love, yet thee lat expreions infued trange imaginations into her fancy; and preently after, conidering upon the merits and perfections of the young Andrimartes, and calling into memory the expreions of his particular good will unto her: Love did begin o gently to cratch the skin, that it became uch an itch, as by degrees became a wound incurable.

As oon as ever Andrimartes could teal away from Childerick, he returned to Silviana, begging a thouand pardons for leaving her alone, and excuing it with the force which that young Prince ued unto him. I cannot blame him, anwered Silviana, nor your friends, for deiring the happines of your company. Oh Madam, anwered Andrimartes, that you would rank your elf in that number, and think it a happines to have my company. Do you doubt of either? (replied Silviana) No, no, Andrimartes, you have merits enow, to make all become your friends, and deire your company, and I have known you too long not to eteem them accordingly. Madam (anwered he) I hould think this evening the happiet time of all my life, could I think the Fair Silviana did ever daign to cat her Fair eye upon my actions, and if I could have any aurance in what you are now pleaed to ay. The young Silviana, not dreaming that Love would oblige a heart to give it elf away, but thinking it only a piece of pleaing complaiance and delight in the company of one peron with another, he did believe that Andrimartes did Love her, and alo did intend to Love him, as a Siter may Love a Brother, or a Daughter a Father; and therefore according to the innocency of her age, and implicity of her oul, he anwered him thus. Be aured Andrimartes, that I do really Love you; and whereas you deire to have ome aurance of my words, I will mot willingly give it, proteting unto you, that I do not Love any Brother o well as I do you. Andrimartes who was older, and more capable of Love then he, did know very well that all this was but the words of a child; yet thinking that he had already brought her to a very good pae, he contented himelf for that time, hoping that time and
continuance of his Courthip would work this innocent Love into uch a perfect affection as he deired; and therefore taking her hand, he kied it, and with a miling look aid, Now Madam, do I think my elf the mot happy and bet contented man alive, ince I have received this declaration from you, which I deire above all the world: only one thing more I beeech you Madam let me beg, which is, that you will be contant unto this aurance which you have given me, and that you will be pleaed to let me bear the name of your Brother, and to call you Siter, as an obligation unto us to continue in this amity: With all my heart (anwered the young Lady) and I do promie to Love and eteem you as much as if you were my Brother. Andrimartes would have anwered, had it not began to rain, which caued them both to remove: however, ince that day, he courted this young and Fair Lady o cloe, as by degrees he taught her know, that Love was not to be confined by the Laws of Friendhip, nor kept within compas of a meer good will; for in a few days he loved him in uch a height, as he perceived it to be a thing impoible for her to make a retreat: So as one day when he met him upon the banks of Seine, where Methina, according to her cutom, was walking, and taking an occaion to retire themelves under a hade of Trees, he aid thus unto him; Do you remember brother (for o he called him) what dicoure we had in this place, when I engraved my name upon the bark of yonder Tree? Doubtles I do Siter, (anwered Andrimartes) and hall remember it as long as I live: no time is able to deace it out of my memory; for it was then I received my greatet hopes of happines from you. What did I then ay, replied he, which gave you o much contentment? Thee Madam, anwered he, were your own words; Be aured Andrimartes, that I do really Love you. Brother (aid Silviana) will you have me confes the truth unto you? I would have you believe (aid he and miled) that when I poke thoe words I knew not what I aid: how Siter! replied he preently, not know what you aid? Certainly I did not, anwered he, for how could I give you aurance of a thing which I was ignorant of, and did not know? Then, aid he unto her, you did deceive me: 'Tis true indeed (aid Silviana) I did deceive you; but it was when I was firt deceived my elf: for I mut confes, that when I aid I did Love you, I did not know what it was to Love; and yet the good will which I had unto you, did make me think it was Love, which was only a childih kind of an inclination. Andrimartes hearing her ay o, he was a little tartled, fearing that he intended to break her promie with this excue: But he who had other intentions eeing him o mute, and upecting the caue of his ilence; Brother (aid he) be not troubled at what I ay, for it is only to give you a fuller aurance of that affection which I have unto you; let me tell you now, that I am more knowing then I was then; and am better able to dicern your merits and affection to me: I know now what it is to Love; not only as a Brother, but as Andrimartes; and knowing this, I do protet unto you, that I do Love you as well as you ought to deire. Andrimartes hearing this welcom expreion, kneeled down upon the ground, and aid; Should I employ all my dayes in thanks Madam, and pend all my blood in doing you ervice, I were not able to recompence you for this happines which you have conferred upon me by this declaration: but ince you are pleaed to be o infinitely good, give me leave to beg, that you will alo be pleaed to compleat this my happines. What is it, aid Silviana, that I can ay more? Have I not profeed that now I do know what it is to Love, and that I do Love Andrimartes as much as he ought to deire? I deire a little more Madam, anwered he, for perhaps you may ay that I ought not to deire o much as I do. Then Andrimartes, anwered he, I do Love you as much as I oght to do: yet a little more, good Madam, anwered he, for there is not amongt men that can aume o much honour to himelf as to ay that you ought to Love him: Then replied he, I do Love Andrimartes, as well as he does Love me: upon this, Andrimartes was atisfied. Now, aid Silviana, I will go further, and do more then you deire; for I do Love Andrimartes more then he Loves me: and I vow by all the Nymphs and Deities of the River, that I will never Love any ele: Only one thing Brother I hall requet, which is, that you will promie me upon your Faith, never to deire of me any thing which my honour and decency may not allow. Let all the torments of Hell fall upon my head anwered
Andrimartes preently, and may Heaven blat all my hopes and deires, if ever I do entertain the leat thought of offering beyond thoe Limits which you hall freely allow me.

When this dicoure paed betwixt them, Silviana was about thirteen or fourteen years of age, and Andrimartes about ixteen or eventeen, an age o apt to take all amorous impreions, that Love did imprint in their young hearts all the characters of it elf: o as ever ince that time, they did both o grow in affection, that had not their young and familiar education together been an umbrage for all their amorous actions, and hadowed them with a vail of courtey and long acquaintance, certainly many had taken notice of it: but ince this familiarity did begin when they were little children, none did wonder at their kindnes unto each other, epecially both of them being yet but very young.

Thus they did live together in all poible atisfaction and contentment, waiting until uch time as they could handomly procure the conent of their Parents unto a marriage. And this happy condition lated until uch time as Childerick did unluckily cat his eye upon this hinning Star: for eeing her at a Ball where Silviana was diguied, according to the cutom of the Romans, he took uch a liking to her, that ever ince he loved her mot deperately: Silviana took notice of it preently; and becaue he thought it would be a in unpardonable in her, if he did not impart all that he knew unto her dear Brother, as oon as ever he aw him, he acquainted him with all paages: Andrimartes was apt to believe it; Siter, (aid he unto her) it is no wonder if all the World do Love you; but mut your ambition to be the Mitris of a Kings Son, extinguih your affection unto a Brother? And mut I be the widdowed Turtle left deolate without a Companion? Brother, (aid he then unto him, and took his hand) be aured that you hall never be the Turtle which you peak of, until death do ravih me from you: and if I thought any uch doubt did enter into your oul, the affection which I bear unto you would be extreamly angry: be confident Andrimartes, that death it elf hall not alter my affection; for I will preerve it unto that econd life, which our Druides tell us of after this: Here Brother, (aid he) take this Ring; and if you be the ame Andrimartes, which I take you to be, ummon me by it either in this or the next life, to keep that promie which now I do mot olemnly confirm for ever unto you.

I want words, Madam, wherewith to expres the joyes of young Andrimartes; he fell down upon his knees, he kied her hand, and the Ring which he gave him, a hundred times, with a vow to preent it unto her at that time when he commanded him. Then taking a pin and pricking that finger whereon he wore the Ring, he caued it to bleed in everal places, and making his handkerchief all bloody, he preented it unto Silviana: Madam (aid he unto her) I do eal the vow which I have made with my blood, and I conjure you to retore me this handkerchief when you command me to retore unto you this Ring; to the end that by thee marks both the living and the dead may know how great the affection is which Andrimartes bears unto Silviana, and how happy this affection has been above its merits, in meeting with her reciprocal affection. Thus did Love link the hearts of thee two young Lovers together with fater knots, as if all the powers upon earth were not able to unty them.

But for all that, Childerick continued his begun Love, which grew to that height, that he could not enjoy any contentment nor ret, but when he was with her. At the firt, let Merovius hould be advertied of it, he hid his paion as much as he could, and this was the reaon why he durt not in words declare it unto Silviana, though all his actions did make it o apparent unto every one, as it was a thing uperfluous to tell her that which none was ignorant of.

At the ame time, taking infinite delight in looking upon her, he commanded an Artit to take her Picture unknown unto her, thinking that he would not permit it otherwie: and the Picture-drawer was o ready to atisfie this young Prince, as he took her Picture very exquiitely, at two or three times eeing her in the Temple: when Childerick aw it, he kied it a thouand times; and thinking that his happines was not compleat unles Silviana did know what • ewel he poeed, and meeting her in the Anti-chamber of the Queen his Mother, he took her aide and
aid thus unto her; Fair Silviana, I can tel you ome news, which perhaps you are ignorant of; for you think your elf to be the only Daughter of your Mother, yet let me tell you, that you have a Siter: Did I think this news to be true, Sir, aid Silviana, I hould think it the bet that ever I heard, and think my elf much obliged unto you for telling me of it. You have good reaon to be glad of it (aid Childerick) for though he be not o fair as you are, yet he does very much reemble you; and becaue your elf hall be judge whether or no I peak the truth, pray look upon this. As oon as ever Silviana aw it, he preently knew it, and tarted to ee her elf in any other hands then thoe of Andrimartes, and deiring to look upon it, he gave it unto her. After he had a while looked upon it, and not knowing how to get it handomly from him; he threw it into the fire, and it was burned before Childerick took notice of it, yet he did not cat it into the fire o oon, as he repented of her hate, when he aw that young Prince tand as if he were planettruck with amazement, and to excue her elf in ome ort: Oh God Sir, aid he, it was o ill-favouredly done, that I could not endure to ee my elf o ugly. Silviana, anwered Childerick, you have angered me to the oul, and I cannot tell whether I have patience enough to endure it. Sir, anwered Silviana, and bluht; I am extreamly orry for it: but the truth is, it was o very ill done, that I had rather have een the Picture of death then it. Love and anger had now a great debate in the heart of this offended Prince; but Love, at lat triumphing; I hall ee (aid he) whether that was your reaon or no, or whether you did it as an affront unto me; for if it be as you ay, then you will permit that another be taken with more leiure, that the Artit may do it better then he could the firt: but if you deny me this requet, then I have reaon to think that you did it by way of affront, and that you corn a Prince who never adored any but your elf. The young Silviana fearing the dipleaure of her friends, was contrained to grant what he deired in uch a civil and courteous manner, as he could not chue but be very well contented with this atisfaction. Will you permit (aid the Prince) that another Picture may be taken? Sir, anwered he, I will permit any thing you pleae as far as is in me; but doubtles the Queen will take it very ill if I hould uffer it without her permiion, or at leat without the permiion of my governes. It is enough, aid Childerick, that I know I have your conent unto what I deire, and that you threw the Picture into the fire, only becaue it was ill done. And becaue he eemed to be much troubled at her o much dipleaing him, lat ome by-tanders hould take notice of it, he himelf confeed that it was indeed o ill drawn, that it deerved no les punihment then the fire.

If this Picture were good for nothing ele, yet it erved this young Prince to make his Love known unto Silviana, for this young Lady durt not but receive all that he aid with a favourable apect, lat otherwie he hould complain againt her for cating this Picture o hatily in the fire: and continuing till his Courthip, he omitted no occaion which might tetifie the grandeur of his affection to her: and becaue it is extream hard for the violent paion of Love to be confined unto the limits of reaon and dicretion, it o increaed, that very often trangreing the Laws of modety, it hapned one day hearing her ing, that he was o tranported with this puiant paion of Love, that though it was amongt many Ladies and Cavaliers, yet he could not forbear from kiing her per force. Silviana having no inclination at all unto Childerick, eemed to be extreamly offended with him for this violence, and eeing it was done in the face of all the Court, he made many great complaints againt him; and the rather, becaue Andrimartes was preent, unto whom he would not give the leat thought, that the Courthip of Childerick was able to alter her from her vowed reolution. But the young Prince, though he aw her much offended, yet he turned all to rallary, and laughed it out,

But yet Silviana would not take the continuation of his Love as in jet; and Andrimartes, as good a face as he et upon the matter, yet was he netled to ee his mater become his Rival; knowing very well that Love and Dominion will not admit of any Companions: and therefore he reolved to ask the Queens conent to marry Silviana; but becaue he would not do any thing that might dipleae Silviana, he did communicate this reolution unto her, which he approved of very well, as well
(aid he) to be out of the Tiranny of Childerick, as that we may afterwards live together freely without any contraint. Andrimartes therefore whoe only deire was to be the ole poeor of his Fair and dear Silviana, made it his ute unto his Father, that he might not longer trifle away his time amongt a company of boys, but rather imploy i • nobly in the way of Arms under Merovius, to the honour of his Family, and after their examples, epecially his own: for he was now ahamed to be alwayes amongt none but boyes and women: and therefore humbly deired him that he might leave off the name of child, and aume the name of a Frank, in memory of his predeceors, and after his own particular example, his humour and his age prompting him thereunto. The Father who had a generous oul, eeing his Son o inclinable unto Arms, was very glad to find this generous dipoition in him, and promied to give full atisfaction unto his deire; and to defer it no longer, he acquainted Merovius with it, who approving of it, made it known unto Childerick, and intended to honour him with the order of Knighthood, and with all thoe Ceremonies of gird • ng him with a Sword, and putting on a Spur, in imitation of Arthur King of Great Brittain, when he admitted young Cavaliers into the Rank of Knights, Childerick who was extreamly in Love with the Fair Silviana, was very glad of this honour intended unto Andrimartes, in hopes, that as oon as he was become a Knight of Arms, he would be contrained to go into the Army, and leave Silviana olely unto him, whoe favour he hoped more eaily to obtain wh • n this young man was out of her eye, who he aw wihed him very well. Every thing thus favouring the deign of Andrimartes, he was dubbed a Knight by the hands of Childerick, who had received the ame honour a little before from the hand of Merovius. When Andrimartes was to be girt with the Sword, and demanded what Lady he would make choie of to be his Mitris, he kneeled down, and beeeched the Fair Silviana to let him make choie of her, that he might make it his boat, that he received his honours from the Fairet Hand, and Fairet Lady that lives.

Childerick was extreamly urprized at this requet, and was ready to break out into ome violent demontrations of his dipleaure, yet the preence of the King his Father retrained him, though not from bluhing, and letting many ee how much this Act dipleaed him; and much more was he incened when he aw in what a joyfull manner this Fair Lady gave conent unto the requet which Andrimartes made, and expres her contentment by her eyes, and all her actions. But the joyes of this young Knight was unimaginable, when thanking her for the favour which he received, he proteted and vowed to imploy both his word and his life in her ervice: And he, who never offered to hide the good will which he bore unto him, knowing that ere long he would ask the Queens conent unto a marriage, prayed heartily unto Heus to make his Sword victorious, and aid, that he would with all her heart do any thing within the compas of her power, to tetifie the great eteem which he had of his merits. But Sir, aid he, I neither will, nor can confer this favour upon you without the Queens conent, who has the dipoition of me. Andrimartes thinking that he poke with much dicretion, he kneeled down before Methina; Madam, (aid he unto her) Is it your pleaure I hould this day receive the greatet honour that ever I can pretend unto? Childerick tranported at this beyond all patience, interrupted him and aid; Me thinks Andrimartes, that unles you were too impudent, you would never offer to make this requet unto the Queen and Silviana, until you had by ome noble action made your elf worthy of it, Andrimartes who knew very well what it was which made Childerick peak o; Sir, aid he unto him, I mut needs confes that I do not deerve this favour and honour; but yet I ask it out of a deire I have of doing you ome ervice: and I know that when once I am honoured with the Title of Silvianas Knight, that glorious name will o invigorate and encourage my pirits, as no enterprie can be o difficult, but I hall bring it happily to pas. This thought, anwered the angry Prince, were good, if it were not unjut: But it is not reaonable you hould aume unto your elf a name which cannot be merited but with blood. My blood, replied the young Cavalier preently, hall never be pared in uch a caue, no more then my life in the ervice of the King: But Sir, I find my elf much mitaken in my hopes; for I thought that in this, and upon all other occaions, you would have been my Protector, and furthered
thered me all you could, as a Prince, unto whom I am devoted both by nature and my own inclination. Childerick would have anwered, and perhaps according to the violence of his paion, if Merovius miliking the action of his Son, had not interpoed; and to cover the imprudence of Childerick, aid thus, You had reaon Andrimartes to expect all favour from Childerick: I know that he intends it, and I do command him unto it; what he aid was only by way of rallary, and both he and I will become your Mediators unto the Queen, to conent that Silviana may receive you as her Knight; for it is but reaon o Fair a Lady hould have o brave a Cavalier for her Knight. The young man all tranported with joy, offered to kis the hands of Childerick and the King, and though the young Prince did permit him, yet it was with uch a brow, as plainly hewed that he did it only out of repect unto the King: and though Methina aw this as well as Merovius, yet he commanded Silviana to receive Andrimartes as her Knight, ince the King did approve of it. The young Lady never obeyed any command more willingly then this, and did it with a face o full of contentment, as every one took pecial notice of it: This did o ting the heart of Childerick, that he reolved, whatoever came of it, to break off this Love which went o much againt his heart.

And becaue he knew that he had too much dicovered his paion, and that the King was not well pleaed with it, he contrained himelf as much as poibly he could, to make it believed that what he had done was only out of rallary, as Merovius aid: but there was not one in all the company which did not know the contrary, epecially Andrimartes, who knew very well that it proceeded from his affection unto Silviana, and well did plainly foreee many a torm towards from him: however, come what come could, he reolved to continue his Love; and becaue that Honourable Order of Knight-hood, which he had taken upon him, was an obligation upon him to hake off the drowie life of being always among women, he reolved to quit that idle and effeminate kind of life, and to go into the Army as oon as he had obtained Silvianas leave, and not to return until ome ignal act had poken him meritorious of the Fair Lady. She who aw a kind of neceity upon him to take this coure, and thought that it would much conduce unto that contentment which they both aimed at; he conented unto it, though with abundance of orrow to part with him: and knowing that it was the Kings cutom to incite all Generous young Spirits unto gallant actions, and to recompence thoe that by their valour did ignalize themelves in the Army; they did both of them overcome themelves, and with a River of Tears parted, in hope that their abence would bring them to their deired end, ooner then their preence.

To relate all the paages of this ad parting, and the demontrations of good will unto each other, is neither pertinent to the tory, nor indeed poible: let it uffice therefore, that Silviana expreed her affection as far as her modety and honour would permit, and Andrimartes, as became a perfect and noble minded Lover. But I conceive it neceary to acquaint you with the equel of this deign when he was in the Army, though the day be not long enough to relate the hundred part of his brave deportments; for he gave uch tetimony of his courage and valour, that Merovius made choie of him to command that relief which he ent into Belgium, againt the children of King Clodion, Renald and Alberick; who being come at full age, Alberick being Lord of Cambray and the bordering Countries, and Renald Duke of Autraia, and having married Huemide, Daughter unto Multiades King of Tongres, they contracted a league with the Saxons, and with a formidable Army, fell into Autraia, o as had not Merovius very prudently ent this relief under the conduct of the valiant Andrimartes, certainly their Arms had reached as far as the gates of Paris; and perhaps had not only retarded all the conquets of this Valiant King, but alo, had put his very Crown into great hazard. But the Valour and Prudence of Andrimartes was uch, that giving a top unto the progres of thee two brothers, he contrained them to keep within the confines of Autraia, until Merovius had quelled thoe enemies which the Romans had ecretly tirred up againt him: and this piece of ervice was o great, that Merovius did highly acknowledg it; and thought no recompence ufficient for uch ervices as he had received from the brave Andrimartes.

It is a hard matter to expres the joys of Silviana, when he heard of all the valiant exploits of her beloved Andrimartes, whoe preence he did infinitely deire, that he might rejoyce with him for his happy ucces: and yet he was well contented with his abence, ince he her elf was a harer in his glory, and ince it conduced o much unto the advantage of the Crown of the Franks; hewing her elf by her wie and virtuous moderation, to be the Grand-child of Semmon Duke of Gaul Armorique, the faithful friend of King Merovius.

There was not a man who did not love, and highly commend the Valiant and Wie Andrimartes (and for ix years together which he continued in the Army, he met not with one accident which did not end in happy ucces) Childerick only excepted, who grudged at all his victories, though they were all to the advantage of that Crown which he was to inherit after Merovius: but his love being above his ambition, he diliked all his actions, and detracted from his glory as much as poible he could; knowing very well, that all thee applaudes of him would kindle the affection which Silviana bore unto him. But at length, Andrimartes not being able to live any longer from his adored Lady, though he received Letters continually from her, he obtained leave from the King to return unto Paris, to ettle ome affaires which he pretended, did require his preence. He preented himelf therefore unto the Queen, who received him with all poible welcom; and he thought it expedient to trike now whilt the Iron was hot, and peak unto the Queen concerning his marriage: and in order-thereunto, he entreated a neer Coen of his to make this requet unto the Queen in his behalf. Methina who was well acquainted with the merits of Andrimartes, and conidered what ignal ervices he had done the King her Husband, he was very glad of any occaion to give atisfaction unto his deire; and to tetifie how he approved of that marriage: Tell Andrimartes (aid he unto the party that was imployed to deliver the requet unto her) that I do not only conent unto his deire; but alo Silviana being Grand-child unto Semnon our dear friend, I promie him to procure his good will, and the Kings alo: and in tetimony of my forwardnes to gratifie him all the wayes I am able, I do allow him to live with her, not only as her ervant, but alo as him that is to be her Husband.

This anwer which was as favourable as Andrimartes could poibly hope for, was received with o much joy, that it was impoible for him to keep it ecret: o as the news of it was preently all over the Court and Army; and Methina having acquainted Merovius with it, it pleaed him o well, that he poke of it openly, and aid, that he was obliged to acknowledg the ervices of that brave Cavalier, in the highet manner: o as to defer his atisfaction no longer, he preently dipatched a Meenger to Duke Semnon his dear and ancient friend, to procure his conent unto this marriage, promiing to advance Andrimartes unto uch a height, as he hould never repent of betowing his Grand-child upon him.

But Childerick hearing this news, firt by the letters of the Queen his Mother, and afterwards by the dicoure of Merovius his Father, he was o dipleaed at it, that he could not chue but peak of it unto him, under a pretence of doing him ervice; Sir, (aid he unto him, finding him alone) I do undertand by the Queens letters, and alo by your dicoure this morning, that Andrimartes intends to marry Silviana: now Sir, the ervice which I ow unto you, commands me to hint unto you a thing which I think worthy of your conideration. And though I do not doubt of your high prudence, yet your multitude of other great affairs, makes me fear that you have not time to think upon things of lower importance. I mut needs confes Sir, that the ervices of this Cavalier does deerve a recompence, but not o far as to make you commit a greater offence againt Semnon your dear friend & ally, and alo againt your elf: for certainly recompenes ought never to be made to the di-advantage of our friends, or uch as trut us with things that are mot dear unto them: Semnon Sir, you know, is Duke of Gaul Armorique; it was he who at your firt coming into this Country received you into his friendhip; aited you with all his trength and counel; and it may be aid, that he and Guyveline Governour of the Edvois, were the two uret Pillars, upon which you laid the foundation of your Dominion. Is it therefore reaonable Sir, that if he trut you with his Daughter,
who is to be the upport and comfort of his age, you hould dipoe of her without his conent? Or is it fit, to propound a match o unequal and o di-advantagious unto him? Will you Sir, let it be aid that Merovius does recompence his ervants at the charges of his neighbour Princes and friends? Pardon me Sir, for peaking o boldly unto you; and if it be a crime, blame my natural deire to cleer your name from aperion, which I know is contrary to your intention, and al your former actions: not but that I do think it reaonable, and worthy of commendations in you, to remunerate Andrimartes: But then Sir, I beeech you, let it be out of your own charges, and with omthing in which you have an interet; in o doing, you will get the name of a Generous and Magnanimous Prince: you will then be called the King of Hearts as well as of Franks; there are other matches in your Kingdom, which Andrimartes himelf cannot chue but think much more utable and fit for him, then Silviana, whom if he pretend unto, in lieu of getting friends unto himelf by that unequal alliance, he will draw a mortal odium upon himelf, and have enemies that will never pardon that offence which he hall commit by your intigation. Thus without advantage to himelf, he will caue you to loe that credit and amity, which you have gotten with o much paines, and which with o much care and prudence you have hitherto preerved with all that know you. Do not think Sir, that I am the firt Authour of thee coniderations, for many of your bet ervants that dare not tell you as much, have addreed themelves unto me, thinking that great Princes who are full of high imployments, will not reflect upon things of a lower phere, which though mall in themelves, yet may draw after them many dangerous conequences: I believe if Andrimartes did but conider of what importance, or rather what prejudice this marriage will be unto your ervice, he would be the firt (as deeply in love as he is) that would decline it; I am confident he would not offer o much di-ervice unto your Majety, as to dicontent your people, in cauing you to loe the amity of your Allies. So as Sir, if you will pleae to command me, I will undertake to divert him from it, and ue uch pregnant Arguments and reaons, as hall o convince him, that he hall think no more upon it.

Childerick found uch a patient hearing from his Father, that he hoped preently to obtain commiion for peaking unto Andrimartes. But that wie King, having long ince oberved how this young Prince was in Love with Silviana; and knowing that all thee intances proceeded only from his deires of enjoying her himelf, having given him a full hearing, and eeing that he expected his anwer, he aumed a erious look, which tetified the mal atisfaction which he received for his long Oration, and gave him this anwer.

I am very orry Childerick, to find in you uch humours as I leat deire, epecially in two things, which believe it my Son, will become your ruine, if they be not prudently corrected. The firt is an effeminate inclination, which does bebauch you unto a diolute kind of life, devoting your elf wholly unto pleaures and love: for if from contraries, contrary effects may be expected: How can I imagine but that when I hall leave you this Crown, which was gotten by o many hazards and toyl from the valiant Romans, you will as oon loe it as it was gotten? Alas you do degenerate from the martial vertue of your Nation the Franks. The other quality which I do extreamly condemn you for, is; The imploying your wit to cover your vice with a vail of virtue. Do you think me Childerick o little vers'd in the affairs of the world, that I do not ee how all your pecious arguments are only to hinder Silviana, whom you do love, from marrying? Do you think I have forgot your Language which you ued when Andrimartes was made a Knight? Can you believe me ignorant of her throwing a Picture into the fire, which you had gotten of hers, unknown unto her? Do you think I never heard how violently you kied her by force? Do not think Childerick that any of your actions towards her is unknown unto me; and though hitherto I uffered them, and eemed to take no notice, yet it was only in hopes that you would reclaim your elf from uch a manner of life, as you could not chue but know would exceedingly dipleae me. You take upon you to be a very great States-man, and will needs teach me how much I am obliged unto Semnon, hinting upon all the good offices he has done me: Pray
Childerick, unto which of all my neighbours have you een me deficient, and backward in paying my duty unto their amity and good will? Why hould you think me o negligent of him whom I love and eteem above all the Gaules? If you cannot dive into the depth of my deigns, why hould you not think thoe things which pas your undertanding to be done with as much reaon, as thoe things are which be within the compas of your capacity? What have I done hitherto, which any of my friends can upbraid me withall? Nay, can any of my enemies charge me with any neglect of duty to them? And is Childerick the only one that can condemn the actions of his Father? Good Son give me a reaon for your cenure: Nay, I believe you have no reaon; but becaue I conent to the marriage of a Lady, which out of a fond affection you would dihonour: do you think it better and more honourable for Semnon, our generous and ancient friend to marry his Daughter unto you, then unto Andrimartes? But Childerick, do you deire to marry her? Can your foolih humour hurry you unto uch a crime? I cannot believe it, and had rather you were dead then ever ee the day; or that you hould entertain uch a thought: not but that I do highly eteem the virtue of the Father, and like the Lady, for both are very worthy of much honour: but I had rather retore back unto Reynald or his Brother Aberick, the Crown of their Father Clodion, then conent that uch a puillanimious courage as yours hould have the Soveraign Power over uch a war-like people as this which I command. Now if your drift be not to marry Silviana, what would you do with her? Would you make her your whore? Do you think the honour of my houe can brook it? Will the reputation of the Queen your Mother uffer it? Or the courage and generoity of Semnon endure it? Fie, fie, Childerick, tifle uch leud thoughts, and abominate them: let not uch a fond love blind your undertanding; and then you will plainly ee that if I do not conent unto this marriage of Silviana unto Andrimartes, I am infinitely to blame; for Princes as your elf ays, are obliged to recompence ervices done, with benefits and honours: and if o, how much am I obliged unto Andrimartes? Who, not to mention his other exploits which he hath done for us, has not only repuled the power of Clodions children, but forced them to keep within the limits of Austraia: he may be aid to have preerved all the ret of our Dominions, by his valour and wie conduct, and repreing the inolency of our enemies, has given us the means to make new conquets. Now tell me Childerick, how great is my obligation for uch ignal ervice? How jutly might I be branded with ingratitude, if I hould deny his affection, his fidelity, his courage, and his merits, the firt requet that he hall make unto me? But you bid me pay my debts with my own mony, and not with Semnons, who keeps this Daughter for the upport and comfort of his old age. Let me tell you Son, that if I hould deny unto his Grand-child uch a utable and advantageous marriage, it would be a great prejudice and injury to her aged Father; for there is no Prince, nor King, though never o great; but would be glad of his alliance, who is able not only to preerve a tate, but by his valour and prudence is able to get a hundred Kingdoms: What greater advantage or comfort can Semnon have in his old age, then to ee Silviana his Daughter in the hands of o brave and virtuous a Cavalier, and his State under the guard of uch a valiant, prudent, and properous Captain as Andrimartes is? Conider Childerick, that I do ow this gratification unto Andrimartes, for his Excellent ervices which he hath done; and I do ow it alo unto Semnon, for the friendhip and fidelity which I have always found from him. I believe you your elf will acknowledg as much, and if you contradict me, it is not Childerick which does it, but a foolih effeminate paion which will ruine him, and which if he do not preently correct, will make him loe that Crown which now I wear. If therefore you have any deire to pleae me, leave off this drowie kind of life, which will render you the corn and odium of all that know you, epecially of the Franks, whoe martial dipoitions will never love nor endure uch an effeminate peron to be their King. Alo Childerick, I would have you leave off all your tricks of diimulation, with which you would cloak your effeminate deigns with a vizard of virtue: otherwie, let me tell you Son, that though I am your Father by name, yet I am not in affection, but will make it appear both unto you and all the world, that I do not conent unto uch a contemptible life, as you do live.

Childerick was extreamly confounded at this anwer which Merovius gave him, for his own concience did convince him; yet according to the common cutom of of all uch as would put a glos upon their faults, he offered to excue himelf of part of thoe things wherewith his Father upbraided him, by denying the one abolutely, and o diguiing the other, that perhaps he had made his caue good, if he had had to do with one les Judicious then Merovius. But the wie Father after he had heard all his gilded excues, at lat he interrupted him. I perceive Childerick (aid he unto him) that you are very orry I have been o quick ighted as to ee your faults: but you ought not to grieve for that; repent rather the committing them, then my eeing them: for being your Father, I hall be as careful to conceal them as your elf; but if you be wie, continue no longer in this coure of life, which will mot hamefully become your ruine: and conider that a Prince who is to govern a people, ought to render himelf more wie, and more virtuous, then the people, which are to obey him; for otherwie his government will be only by Tyranny, which is les afe unto him, and more dipleaing unto them.

Upon this Merovius would hearken unto no reply, but leaving him, he dipatched a meenger preently unto the Queen Methina, which let her undertand, that without more delay, he hould propound this marriage unto Semnon Duke of Gaul Armorique, and to aure him, that he would raie Andrimartes unto uch a degree, as he hould have no caue to repent the betowing his Grand-child upon uch a brave Cavalier. The Queen who was as desirous to give Andrimartes contentment as the King, he dipatched an Ambaador immediately unto Semnon, whoe conent was eaily obtained; and who having heard o great a Fame upon the Name of Andrimartes, did embrace the motion, with many thanks unto the Queen, for her deires of uch a Match for Silviana: thinking himelf o obliged both unto her and Merovius for it, as he thought himelf ufficiently recompened for all the ervices he had ever done them, and beeeched them to dipoe of him and his Grand-child as they pleaed. Only this he deired, that he might ee Andrimartes, to the end he might be better acquainted with him, who was to enjoy Silviana and his etate.

This anwer being received, the Queen did preently acquaint her Husband with it, who thought it expedient for Andrimartes to make this journey unto the good Duke; and the rather, becaue at that time he had either Peace or Truce with all his Neighbours, and could bet pare him. Andrimartes and Silviana, hearing of this intended eparation, though they knew it conduced much unto their future contentments, yet their extream affections unto each other, could not conent unto it without abundance of grief; for whilt he was in the Army, he heard from him every day: but now the journey was long, and they foreaw that the good Duke Semnon would not uffer him to return o oon as they deired: yet neceity contraining them, Andrimartes departed, more deirous to return, then to be the poeor of Gaul Armorique.

I hall not Madam, here relate the paages of his reception both by Semnon and his people, who undertanding the intentions of their Lord, did make preparations to receive him with all manner of honour and joy; infinitely applauding the election of their good Duke: Let it uffice to tell you, that after Semnon had welcomed Andrimartes with all manner of magnificence, and kept him a while in his Court, he did not only grant Silviana unto him, as he deired; but alo proclaimed him his Succeor in Gaul Armorique, and caued all his vaals and ubjects to acknowledg him o: o as all the Grandees, all the Souldiers, and all the Knights, received him as their ucceeding Lord with great applaue.

Preently after this or a little before, Clidemant was come into the Army of Merovius, and aw Andrimartes, being a witnes of his brave exploits: So as when this news was divulged in the Court of Merovius, it was very welcom unto all the brave Cavaliers, Childerick only excepted, who was much dipleaed at it: for though he made a hew of the contrary, and ince his Father had chid him, was not o bold as to let his love unto Silviana appear, yet in lieu of diminihing, it encreaed every day: not that he had any intention to marry her, for he aymed at omething higher; but his deign was to enjoy her in another quality. When he heard any
commend the choie which Semnon had made for his Grand-child, he could not forbear peaking very di-advantageouly of it, and charge him, ometimes with injutice, and ometimes with indicretion: of injutice, in depriving his right Succeors from his Etate; and of indicretion in ubmitting Gaul Armorique unto a Frank who was a tranger. So as not being able to quench his flaming paion, and finding an opportunity of dicoure with Silviana, he aid thus unto her: Is it poible, Fair Lady, you hould ever think of marrying Andrimartes? Sir, anwered he, is he not a Cavalier of greater merit then I can deerve? It eems, replied he, that you are ignorant in matter of merit, ince you do not ee that the leat of your perfections does infinitely trancend all that is in Andrimartes. Sir, anwered he and miled, If I be of uch worth as you eem to make me, I hall quickly make him rich; for I will wholly betow myelf upon him: and for my part, I hall think my elf ufficiently payed if he do but love me, and unto that I hall hope to oblige him, by the extream affection which I do bear unto him. This peaks your judgment to be wonderous weak, aid Childerick, and that your will tranports you beyond reaon, Sir, anwered he, if you think to vex me by uch dicoure as this, you are to blame, ince my will was alwayes to honour you. And if it be to cros Andrimartes, I hall wonder, ince the only ambition of that poor Cavalier, is to imploy his life for the propagation of your Crown. Fair one, anwered the young Prince, my deign is neither to vexe you, nor cros him; but only to prevent your ruine, which I foreee will be if you do not retire your elf from this young and indicreet affection: believe it, I do not peak without reaon, and did you conider what good fortune is offered you, perhaps you would not thus precipitate your elf: Sir, replied Silviana, et your heart at ret, and believe this for a mot certain truth, that all the great advantages in the world, hall never divert my affection unto Andrimartes: The Queen and the King allow of it, Semnon approves of it alo, and what then can make me backward? Why good Silviana, replied Childerick, do you make no reckoning of my will? And do you not think that my conent is alo neceary? Certainly I do Sir, (anwered he) but I cannot think you will ever cros the will of Merovius. The Love which I do bear unto you is uch, (aid he) that if I aw it would be neceary for your good, I would cros even Tautates himelf. But ince you care o little for your own good, adieu; and remember that I am Childerick, a Kings Son, and one who hereafter will let you ee what a fool you are to depie that good will which he offers unto you. Upon this, not taying for her anwer, he went away in an angry mood: At which he was very orry, not in any conideration of her elf, but out of fear let his anger hould reflect upon her dear Andrimartes.

In the mean time, Semnon having kept Andrimartes a long while with him, and thinking it now time for him to return unto Merovius, he dimied him, upon condition, that as oon as he was married he hould return and bring Silviana with him, with a reolution of taying alwayes, and taking upon him the care of his Etate, and pending the ret of his dayes in ret.

At his return every one received him with all imaginable honour, and carees. Merovius who treated him already as Duke of Gaul Armorique, was very glad that one of his own nation, and one over whom he had o much influence, hould command o great a People, and become his Neighbour; thinking it to be a great ecurity unto his Crown: and in this conideration he commanded Childerick to make much of him, and to love him, not as his Vaal, but as his Neighbour, and one who might give a great ettlement unto his conquets. But all thee carees were nothing unto Andrimartes, in comparion of that welcom which he received from his dearet Silviana, who now took him for her Husband, and lived in all honet liberty with him; and though he did not conceal any of her actions or thoughts from him, yet he would not acquaint him with the dicoure of Childerick, as well becaue he knew that all he aid was fale, as becaue he thought that it would much dicontent him: But he reolved to retire her elf with him as oon as poibly he could, into the dominions of Semnon; and o avoid that Tiranny and thoe inolencies, which he expected from him when he hould be abolute Lord of the Franks.

There being no top in the accomplihment of this o much deired marriage, Methina by the Kings authority, and by conent of Semnon, caued the articles of marriage to be drawn; and about eight dayes after, the ceremonies were accomplihed, to the contentment of all, and with o much joy and atisfaction unto Silviana and Andrimartes, that never two Lovers were better contented. Childerick only ighed whilt all other rejoyced.

But as if Heaven tayed only until this marriage was pat, before all Gaul hould become all orrows, within even or eight dayes after, Merovius fell ick, and preently after dyed, full of glory and honour, and infinitely bewailed by the people. Childerick was preently et upon the Throne, and proclaimed King of the Franks, in fale hopes that he would be the Imitator of his Fathers virtues. Silviana remembring the harh language which he had received from him, advied her dear Husband to get out of the reach of this young King, and to retire into Gaul Armorique, as well to avoid the malignity of Childerick, as to keep his promie with Semnon. But Andrimartes who was ignorant of the lat language which he had ued unto Silviana, and who thought himelf obliged to tay a while with this new King, and ee the Crown etled upon his head, he would not hearken unto the counel of Silviana, thinking it againt his duty to retire before all was etled, and o delayed the time under pretence of furnihing himelf with all things neceary for their journey: in the mean time he was alwayes with the King, and o full of affection and care in all his expreions, as any other but Childerick would have thought himelf obliged: But he on the contrary remembring the injuries which he thought he had received, deferred the reolution of his oul only till the Ceremonies of his Coronation were pat: In the mean time news was brought unto the Valiant Andrimartes and Silviana, that the good Duke Semnon was dead, and that all his ubjects earnetly deired them to come into their dominions.

Silvianas grief was very great, and that of Andrimartes was no les; for having received o many benefits from that Prince, it grieved him extreamly, that he hould die before he had done him any ervice. But when their firt tears were almot dryed up, Heaven gave them caue for new ones, and more bitter then the firt.

Childerick now thinks all well enough, and his Crown fat upon his head; and he fell into uch a licentious coure of life, as every one was out of hopes to find his Fathers virtues in him. The People complained, the Grandees grumbled, and his bet lovers lamented him. After they had a while endured his hameful kind of life, and uffered many Preures and Tyrannies obtruded upon the people, the Grandees of the State aembled themelves together at Province, and afterwards at Beauvois; where after deep debate and erious conideration, they reolved to declare him unworthy and incapable of the Crown of Franks; and at the ame time to make choie of one, who though a Roman, yet they thought to be a peron of great merit and worthy to be their King: his name was Gillon, who had long ince left the Roman Empire, and followed Merovius, unto whom he had done very great and faithful ervice, and had added unto the State of the Franks the Town of Saions, of which he was the Governor. But for my part, I believe, they made choie of this ambitious man, becaue there was not any Frank that would take the Title and charge upon him, and maintain it againt their natural and legal King: For treaon was a mot detetable in amongt them, and abhorred by all. But you may ee Madam, how when the great Tautates has a mind to chatie men for their faults, he can furnih out unexpected occaions. Whilt Gi • lon was ecretly preparing and arming himelf, and all the Grandees confederating and plotting together, Childerick drowned in a dull ecurity, was mot indicreetly contriving how he hould get Silviana by force from Andrimartes; not by any deign of marrying her, for that he could not do, he being married already, but to ue her at his pleaure, as he had done ome others, ince the death of Merovius: This young Prince was much induced unto thee diorders, by the poionous advie of ome bae Flatterers about him, who cryed up, that all things were Lawful unto a King; that Kings made Laws for their Subjects, not to tye up their own hands; and that ince the lives of his Vaals were in his power, he might do what he would with their
etates or any thing of theirs: Thee flattering but fale maximes, moved him to offer this injury unto Silviana, and the Valiant Andrimartes.
