The Queen Methina retired her elf to Remois, becaue he would not be any witnes unto the dihonourable and debauched actions of Childerick, and becaue he deired to comfort her elf after her great los, by the conolations of one Remy, a peron who hined in all virtue, and one, who though the God whom he adored was unknown unto the Franks and us, yet never any afflicted peron parted from him without much comfort. Childerick, taking the opportunity of his Mothers abence, he deired no more but to make Andrimartes leave Silviana by her elf; in order to which he took him aide, and told him that he had matters of very great importance to imploy him in, and uch as he would not commit unto the fidelity of any one but himelf: he told him that the buines o neerly concerned his Crown, and required uch extream hate, that he hoped he would not deny him, but prepare himelf for a udden departure. Andrimartes who did not think the Son of Merovius hould ever entertain any uch damnable thoughts, did freely anwer him, that he was ready to erve him in this occaion or any other; and that though he loved Silviana as his wife, yet he loved Childerick as his Soveraign: and to hew that thee two affections were not incompatible, he would tetifie that he held nothing more dear unto him then his ervice. Upon this Childerick gave him ome colourable intructions, and gave him no longer time to prepare himelf for his journey then that night, and therefore Andrimartes acquainted his dear Silviana with his imployment, and told her that he hoped to return within five or ix dayes at the furthet. The wie Silviana gave a patient hearing unto what Andrimartes told her, and having a quick and apprehenive wit, he anwered him with a deep igh, thus: This journey, I am afraid, will not bring me any contentment, and I beeech Heaven, I be deceived in my thoughts: Andrimartes, you may remember that Childrick did once love me, or at the leat eemed o whilt his Father lived; and he has ued very trange expreions unto me, uch as I never did impart un • o you, but uch as make it manifet that he lights all thoe ervices which you have done for him and Merovius; and having all the power in his own hands, Heavens know how far he will extend it: you ee what kind of life he lives, and how apt he is to be hurried unto any violent act; and therefore, what good can we ever hope for from him? for my part I am extreamly afraid of the man; and he has two qualities which may well make any to fear him; that is, a wicked will, and abolute power: what imployments can he have for you that are good? Why hould he be o haty in packing you away? I beeech Heaven, it be with a good deign: upon this, he took him about the neck, and kied him, but bathed her kies in a flood of tears, which did exceedingly move the heart of this Generous Cavalier unto compaion: then eriouly thinking upon the dicoure of Silviana, and finding much reaon in it, he anwered her thus: Thee teares, my dearet, do infinitely well my oul with orrows; and I mut confes, I find all your words o full of reaon, that I wih ome other were imployed in my room: but ince I have already taken it upon me, and have his intructions in my keeping, what excue can I make to come off withal? And how can I be quit of my imployment without an extream dipleaing him? It cannot poibly be: but ince I have gone thus far, I mut go further, and do as well as we can; and therefore, I will tell you what I think we ought to do: Firt, I mut go, and return with all the hate that poible I can make; in the mean time, go you unto the houe of Andrenick our old and truty ervant, yet unknown unto any: If Childerick have any bad deign, doubtles he will either come unto you, or end for you; by this his intentions will be known unto us: if they prove good, I hall be very glad that no more noie is made of our jealouies of him: and if they be bad, I hall give him but a very mal time to execute his deign; for he hall not live a day after my return: becaue I will give his wicked oul a paage out of his body in the midt of all his guards and ouldiers: but being yet in doubt of it, I would not have <> aid, that ever Andrimartes committed uch an act upon a bare jealouie.

This was the reolution of Andrimartes, who etting forward in the morning very early, acquainted the truty Andrenick with his purpoe concerning Silviana; commanding
him to keep it ecret from all the world. This Andrenick was an old ervant, who had the government of him in his youth, whoe affection was o great, and his fidelity o well known, as Andrimartes was as ure of him as of himelf. His houe was neer the houe of Andrimartes, and he took it, becaue he thought that ere long his Mater would go into Gaul Armorique, and he having a wife and children could not go with him.

As oon as ever Andrimartes was gone, Silviana without acquainting any of her maids, went unto the houe of Andrenick; and commanded them, that if any Ladies came to viit her, to ay that he was not well, and deired to ee no body. Silviana in the interim, locked her elf up with the wife of Andrenick, trembling at every noie which he heard, and thinking that he aw Childerick at her Chamber door. It is very trange to oberve, what a blind knowledg we hall ometimes have of accidents that are to happen. Silviana indeed had reaon to fear the exorbitant inolencies of Childerick; but yet ince the death of Merovius, he needed not have any uch deep apprehenions, ince his inolencies fell upon ome others; o as he might well imagine his thoughts to be diverted from her, and carried another way: but I cannot tell, ome good Genius told her, that he hould never ee her Huband again, and that ome mi-fortune would befal both him and her: this was the reaon of her fears, and tudy to prevent all manner of diaters; and becaue he had a great confidence in the wife of Andrenick, he acquainted her with her fears, and they two plotted together what coure was bet to be taken. Silviana asked her what they hould do, if Childerick not finding her at her own houe, hould look for her there. Firt of all they ought out for ome private place where he might hide her elf; for it was impoible to reit the power and force of the King: but finding the houe to be very little, and very inconvenient for uch a purpoe, there being no places of privacy in it, he began to think upon having recoure unto death as her ultimate refuge: but the good woman loving her very well, and knowing that Andrimartes would never urvive her: No, no Madam, (aid he) never think upon any dying; but if you will follow my directions, I will ecure you from all manner of violence. You are young, and tall, you have a good leg, and no big brets; I would advie you to diguie your elf in the habit of a Cavalier: I have here a uit of Clothes which is newly made for one of my Sons, he never wore them, and therefore none can know them; and I am confident that none who ees you with a Sword by your ide, and a Feather in your hat, will ever take you for Silviana; as for your hair, what if you did cut it, though not till we ee an abolute neceity of it? in the mean time therefore, whilt we have leiure let us put you into this trim, for however, there is no harm in it, whether you hall tand in need of it or no. Oh Mother (cryed out Silviana) bleed for ever may he be that bore you; for now by your prudence I hall hope to preerve my elf for my dearet Andrimartes: there is no better way under Heaven then this; dear Mother, let us make all the hat we can; for my heart tels me, that we hall be preently put unto all our hifts: and as for my hair, let the Sciers be in readinee, for I will not make any cruple of it.

Upon this the virtuous Silviana began to undres her elf, whilet the good woman went to fetch the Suit of Clothes which he poke of; and becaue he deired to do her all the ervice he was able, he returned again immediately, he hut the door fat, he helped to trick up Silviana, who appeared to be the bravet Cavalier in all the Court, and o diguied her, that the good woman verily believed he would pas unknown by any: the uit did fit her o well, and became her, that when he girded the Sword about her, now, aid he, do I create you a Cavalier, and under that name oblige you to defend the honour of Ladies. Mother, anwered Silviana, this Sword will defend the honour of one Lady at the leat, and having it by my ide, I fear not the violence of Childerick, but will make ue of it againt him, or if he prove too trong for me, againt my elf, who as feeble as I am, have courage enough to pas into another world without any tain unto my honour: but Mother, me thinks I want Boots and Spurs: for if this Tyrant do come hither, it is not likely I hould tay here; and if I go away, to be in this habit and on foot, is not handom, but will rather render me more upitious: ince you are o courageous,
(aid the good woman) I do not fear your afety; as good luck is, there are two hores in the houe, which I have heard Andrenick ay, are very gentle and fair conditioned; I will accompany you, and before I diguie my elf, I will command them to be made ready: the Footman of Andrimartes hall hold them, and if we tand in need of them, we will then mount them.

Whilt the good woman went down to take order about thee Hores, and Boots, and Spurs, Silviana tayed alone in the Chamber, o glad of her diguie, that he knew not how to be thankful enough unto Heaven for this happy occaion of preventing the deignes of Childerick: for remembring his lat language unto her, he verily believed that he had ent Andrimartes away, only to have more opportunity of offering ome violence unto her; this memory filled her full of chill fears: I know, aid he in her elf, that the Tyrant intends violence unto me, and becaue he feared the courage of Andrimartes, has packed him away with a deign of getting him to be killed at his return. As he was in thee thoughts, the wife of Andrenick returned unto her, to whom with a trembling voice and tears in her eyes, he aid thus; Oh Mother! I am but a dead woman unles you help me; for this wicked man, knows very well that the courage of Andrimartes will never endure the injury which he thinks to do unto me, without revenge, and therefore for certain, he will caue him to be murdered at his return, if we do not ome way or other prevent it. Madam, (anwered he) let me dres my elf as oon as I can, that I may follow you; for me thinks I hear ome noie in the treets: what you ay Madam is not without ome probability, for a Tyrant never acts his villany by halfs: She had no ooner dreed her elf, but a meenger brought them word that the King had been at the houe of Andrimartes, that he ought for Silviana, and menaced Andrenick, and the ret of the Dometiques, to know where he was.

Silviana now did cut her hair, and the hair of Andrenicks wife, and then went all three to the hores, and o opportunely, that they were no ooner out of the houe, but Childerick with all his guard entred in at another door; making uch a noie, that the poor Ladies trembled out of fear of falling into their hands: but the footman who had been in everal dangers with his Mater in the wars, he was not at all affrighted: follow me, aid he, and fear not, for I wear by the life of my Mater, that I will kill him who hall offer any injury unto his wife. Thus hating them away, becaue the noie encreaed, he got them over the bridg; and mending their pace, he carried them towards the Mount of Mars, and in a cloe valley under the Mountain, they did hide themelves, intending when it was night to go unto ome Town, a little farther off. But the wife of Andrenick, who was in great fear of her Husband, and Silviana being very deirous to know what Childerick did when he found her not; they commanded him to go into the Town, and hear what news: the Footman went, & as luck was, came into the Town jut as they were ready to hut up the gates, leaving thee two Ladies o atonihed to ee themelves in uch a olitary place o diguied, as they could not chue but be in great perplexity. But Silvianas great affection unto Andrimartes, when he conidered the danger he was in at his return, made her deire to be going towards him; and certainly had he known the way, he would not have tayed for the return of the Footman: but adviing with the good woman upon the bet coure, it was judged dangerous to venture without a guide; and therefore, comforting themelves as well as they could, they tayed until Heaven hewed them a better coure. Expecting therefore the return of the Footman with much impatience, and time beginning to eem very tedious unto them, at the lat they pied him coming, and running as fat as he could; and becaue they perceived that none could ee them, they went to meet him, being extreamly deirous to know what news he brought.

As oon as he came unto them, he wanted breath to peak; Madam, aid he, unto Silviana, the Heavens have helped you beyond all expreions; and you could never have taken a better coure, then thus diguiing your elf and getting away: for Madam, that ungrateful Childerick (for he deerves not the name of a King) that wicked man, that Tyrant, has committed more trange inolencies and violences in your houe, and in the houe of Andrenick, then any Barbarian would ever have offered in the acking and plundering of an enemies Town: Oh Friend, (aid
Silviana) prethee tell us the whole tory of his actions, Madam, (aid the wife of Andrenick and interrupted her) firt let him tell me how my husband does. Your Husband (anwered the man) is well, and was joyed beyond all meaure when I told him what coure you had taken; but becaue this place is too neer the Town, I think it bet Madam to get us further from it, and by the way I will make a full relation unto you. Good Friend (aid Silviana) conduct us towards the place where Andrimartes is, for I am reolved to go unto him, and tell him my elf what has hapned.

The man then directed them the way which his Mater told him he would come when he returned; and becaue it grew late, and Silviana was not ued to travel in that manner, they reolved to go no further that night then Clay: the man therefore placed himelf betwixt them, and began to peak thus unto his Mitris by the way.

Madam, aid he unto her, Though it is but a while ince you left your houe, yet uch and o many trange accidents have ince hapned, that I know not where I hould firt begin the relation of them. Happy you are that Tautares inpired you with uch feares of Childerick; and it is no les then a miracle that you have ecaped his inhumane hands: for he came unto your houe in a more inolent manner then ever was heard of. Be pleaed to know Madam, that when I came to the gates of the Town, I wondred to find them half hut, o as had I tayed but a minute longer, I could not poibly have entred: all the Town was up in Arms; and in uch a tumult, that every treet was chained, and all doors hut. With much ado I got unto your houe, which I found full of people and ouldiers ready to fall together by the ears; in the mean time, I heard many cryes and much lamentation made, ome aid that Silviana was there, that Childerick would ravih her; and to have a better opportunity for it, had ent away Andrimartes unto the good Queen Methina: many did grumble at it, and aid, it was a hame for the people of Paris to uffer uch a piece of violence before their faces: that if they endured this, they hould encourage a Tyrant to commit the like actions; that now, neither their Wives, nor their Daughters, were in afety, ince all was at the will of a luxurious Prince, and that they had much better die once, then live alwayes in uch ignominy and lavery. I oberved that amongt thoe who ued uch plain language, there was both Gaules and Franks: and I perceived that a very little purring on, would move them unto Arms. To the Franks therefore I aid thus; Oh Sirs, can you endure to ee Andrimartes thus unworthily ued before your faces? And unto the Gaules I aid; Oh Friends, mut the virtuous Daughter of the good Duke Semnon be thus ravihed in your Town, and find no relief amongt you? There needed no more to et them together by the ears, and with uch furie, that of the Tyrants guard and ouldiers ome were killed, others put to flight, and all in uch diorder, that he himelf had much ado to get into his Palace, to which the people flocked, and God knows what they did further. As for me, I ran preently unto your houe, where I found Andrenick, without either hat or cloak, and pitifully abued by the followers of Childerick; yet he received not a wound: but all the houe was plundred, and all the women with their hair about their ears, and never was greater violence and diorder offered unto any houe. As oon as ever Andrenick and thoe women aw me, they all cryed out for joy, and asked me where you were; unto whom I anwered, that you were in a place where your greatet orrow was for them and their injuries: and taking Andrenick aide, I told him what you had done, and where you were; at which he was o tranported with joy, that he fell down upon his knees and held up his hands to Heaven; Bleed for ever be the great Tantates, aid he, for directing you how to foreee and prevent o great a mis-fortune: then riing up, he asked me of all circumtances; whether his wife was with you, and what hift you made to ecape: and having atisfied him in all his quetions as briefly as poibly I could, I left him the mot contented man in the world; but when he aw me ready to depart, he commanded me to tell his wife, that he hould rather die then forake you. And becaue I feared let you hould think the time long, I made all the hate that poibly I could to return unto you, but with much ado, for I found every treet chained up, and it was long before I could get
a pas: but at lat, eeing the people o much incened, and hearing them all peak very advantageouly of my Lord, I told them openly that I belonged unto Andrimartes, and that you had ent me unto him to acquaint him with the violence that Childerick had offered unto you. I cannot expres Madam, how affectionately they all offered themelves to ait me when they heard this; I found my paage very eaie after this, and every one offered me any favour and courteie I could deire: o as when I came to the gates, they were preently opened unto me, and when I was out, he who kept the guard, call'd me, and aid; good friend, bid thy mater make all the hate he can, and tell him, that we are all ready to venture our lives for him, in revenge of this injury which is offered. Thus the man ended his relation; and in the mean time Silviana went on as fat as he could out of her extream deires of meeting Andrimartes, that he might acquaint him with this accident, and move him to take that revenge which the people promied.

Be pleaed to know Madam, that as oon as Childerick was ure that Andrimartes was gone, he aembled a company of young Ruffians, which ued to prompt him unto uch violences, and went unto the houe of Andrimartes, where finding none but the faithful Andrenick, and thinking that he had hid the Fair Silviana, or at leat knew where he was, he eied upon his peron, and offered him a thouand injuries; o as but for Clidemant and Lindamore, he had put him to death. But they hearing that the people aembled themelves tumultuouly together, they Armed themelves, and ran into the throng of the tumult; and well it was for the King they did o, for ele he had found the danger of an incened people, who upon great reaon had Armed themelves. But Clidemant eeing Childerick in this danger, he drew his Sword, and di-engaged the King from amongt them, though Clidemant and Lindamore alo were much wounded, yet not o dangerouly, but they accompanied the King into his Palace: unto which all the Seguians preently flocked, and amongt them Guyemant, who though he was known to be the ervant of Childerick, yet was not hated by the people, becaue every one knew that he was none of that debauched number, which prompted the King unto thee unworthy and ignominious coures. When Lindamore pied him, Oh Guyemant, (aid he unto him) mut Clidemant do pennance for a fault which he never committed?

Heavens forbid, (anwered Guyemant and was much troubled) I hope o great a mi-fortune will not befall us: Then going neerer unto Clidemant, he kneeled down by his bed-ide, and taking him by the hand, Sir, aid he unto him, let your courage make it appear, that you are able to overcome a greater mis-fortune then this. Dear friend (anwered Clidemant) I do not want courage, but yet I am not able to reit the power of death. Guyemant with tears in his eyes, then aid unto him, I hope that Tautates will not afflict us o much, as to ravih from us a Prince o neceary for the happines of men, but will let us enjoy him longer to our happines and comfort. Guyemant, anwered he, we are all in the hands of the great Tautates; he may dipoe of us as he pleaeth: and for my part, o he will be pleaed to let me leave this life, with that good reputation which my Ancestors did leave unto me, I hall be well contented and atisfied with the time that I have already lived. Then calling Lindamore unto him, who was wounded, though not o mortally as he, and who was all in tears to ee his Lord in this extremity: You two (aid he unto Lindamore and Guyemant) are the perons in whom I have greatet confidence; Guyemant I conjure you to tell Childerick, that I do die his ervant, and am very orry that I have given no greater tetimony of my affection: yet tell him, that if the ervices which I have done unto the King his Father, have any influence upon him; I hope he will not take it ill if you tell him from me, that if he do not leave this ignominious life, which he hath lived ince he was King, he mut expect a punihment from Heaven. And you Lindamore, as oon as I am dead, or at leat, as oon as your wounds will permit you, carry back all the Seguian Cavalry into their own Country; retore them back from me unto the Nymph my Mother, unto whoe ervice, I conjure you, to continue faithful as you have begun: deire her not to grieve for the los of me, ince it is the will of Heaven to have it o; and deire her to comfort her elf with this, that I have imployed the time which I lived, in the way of honour, and die without reproach. Alo tell my dear Siter, that if any thing make me
unwilling to die o oon, it is my deires of eeing her, more then any thing ele; then cauing us all to be called for, and eeing mot of us tanding by his beds-ide, with tears in our eyes, he tretched out his hand unto us, and commanded us to obey Lindamore as himelf; but above all to erve you Madam, and the Nymph Galathea, with all the fidelity of true Cavaliers, auring us that we hould receive from you a full recompence for all the ervices which we had done unto him.

He would have aid omething more, but his Spirits fail'd him, and he dyed in the arms of Lindamore; who eeing this, for grief fell into a woon. I cannot expres our orrows, nor the orrows of all the Court, when they heard of his death: the very people of the Town, who commonly are very dull in uch reentments, did lament him, and alo applaud him to the Heavens, aying; that the death of this Prince was a great los unto their Nation and Crown; they were ure he never conented unto the Violent Extravagancies, and Tyranny of Childerick, and doubtles our condolements had been much more, but for the imminent peril and danger which preently after did threaten us; the fear of our lives forced us to tand upon our guard: And at the ame time, as fortune was, all the Lords and Grandees which were aembled at Province, not knowing of this accident, came all to feel the pule of the people; and finding them to beat after their own tempers, and with Arms in their hands, they put it into the peoples heads to go and clamor at the Palace Royal, with abundance of Drums and Trumpets; which making a great noie, Childerick began to fear the fury of thee mutinies. And becaue he had a great confidence in the valour of Lindamore, and in the advice of Guyemant, he ent for them both to advie about his afety: neither of them both would in this juncture of danger upbraid him with his faults; but both offered him their aid and aitance to the hazard of their lives. Lindamore though wounded, advied to fall preently upon the enemy, and counelled the King to die like a King, and a man of courage. But Guyemant, like a wie and prudent Counellor advied the contrary: Sir, aid he, let us not too deperately precipitate our elves, till there be no hopes of afety; though we were near a thouand men, yet we were nothing to the number of the enemy: time is the mater of occaions, and may unexpectedly fit us with them: it is widom therefore to ubmit unto time, and ail with the wind; nothing is now to be done but to ue our bet endeavours for the changing the mind of this tumultuous people, ince we ee all the Grandees both of Gaul and of the Franks are joyned with them; it is to be expected Andrimartes and all his Friends will alo comply, for he is already ent unto: Gillon the Roman likewie with all his adherents will doubtles be tirring; and who knows whether Renauld and his Brother the Sons of Clodion, will not be fihing in thee troubled waters? And therefore what good can we ever hope to do by force? I advie therefore, and Sir if you will follow my Counell, I will engage my life to retore you unto the Crown of your Father: I advie you, I ay, to yeild unto the violence of this avere piece of Fortune; retire your elf out of this Kingdom, and ret quiet with Bain, in Thuring; he is your Kinman and your Friend, he will be glad to have you in his houe, and ready to ait a great affied Prince: In the mean time I call the Gods to witnes, that when you are abent, I will imploy my whole interet and endeavours to reconcile you unto the People, and I make no doubt but to effect it, if you will follow the advice which I hall give.

Guyemant had no ooner done peaking, but they heard a Trumpet, which being come neerer the draw Bridge, ounded thrice, and afterwards they heard thee words uttered in a loud voice:
The Druides, the Princes, and all the Cavalry of the Franks and Gaules, aembled and united, do declare and proclaim GILLON King of the Franks; and Childerick a Tyrant, and incapable of wearing the Crown of his Father.

Childerick and Guyemant upon this looked out of the window into the treet, and they aw Gillon carried, according to the cutom, upon the peoples houlders, with uch loud acclamations of the people, that Childerick aw Guyemant told him truly, and therefore fearing let his own ervants hould betray him, he retired himelf with the faithful Guyemant, and after ome hort dicoure together, he parted from him; carrying with him one half of a piece of gold, for a token, that when Guyemant ent him the other half, he might return into his Kingdom in afety: the Figure of this piece being joyned together, was on one ide a Tower, to expres contancy; and on the other a Dolphin amidt the Surging Waves, with this Motto about, Detiny does not Cros any: Then changing his habit, he entreated Lindamore, though he was wounded, to accompany him with his Seguian Cavalry, until he was out of the hands of this tumultuous people; Lindamore conented; and Guyemant promied to give an honourable funeral unto the Prince Clidemant. Night being come, the King got ecretly out of the gates, and was conducted by us Cavaliers as far as Thuring, and becaue Lindamores wounds would not give him leave to travel, he was forted to tay upon his return in the Town of Rhemois, where the Queen Methina had a particular care of him and his cure.

There we heard how the Generous Andrimartes having met with the Fair Silviana, preently reolved upon revenge; but hearing the ame day how Childerick was punihed, he thought it bet to retire into his own dominions, and pardon the fault of Childerick, which he did in ome ort excue, conidering the uperlative beauty of Silviana.

Lindamore on the other ide, thought it expedient to acquaint you Madam with the news, which though it be extreamly ad, yet fearing the neglect of it might be di-ervice unto you, I did undertake his commands, and became the meenger.

Thus the Cavalier ended with his eyes full of tears; but Galathea hearing of her Brothers death, although he contrained her elf as much as poibly he could, yet he fell into uch a flood of tears, that he did ufficiently pay the tribute of human imbecility, and hewed her good nature. Her Mother gave her time to dicharge her elf of her jut grief, and in the mean time asked the Cavalier whether Lindamore intended to return ere it was long: and he anwering, that he tayed only for his recovery, he took Adamas aide, and commanded the Cavalier to withdraw, until he ent for him again, but gave him a mot trict charge, to acquaint none living with the death of Clidemant, nor of any accidents that had hapned unto Lindamore, or King Childerick.

When the Cavalier was gone, and none within compas of hearing but Galathea, he turned towards the Druide and aid unto him: You hear Father this ad news, and I mut tell you that the los of my Son goes very neer my heart; nights can bet tetifie my tears: but the neceity of affairs forces me to diemble my orrows in the day; and Daughter it is very requiite you do the ame, for if the death of Clidemant hould come to be known before we have put our affairs into good order, I am afraid Polemas hould take advantage of the abence of all our Cavalry, and plot ome treaon againt us. I peak-not this without ome ground of reaon, for I have oberved of late, that this man aumes more authority to himelf then he ought; he has made two attempts already upon the life of Damon, even in your preence, and this becaue he feares I have no fancy to marry you unto him. But that which mot dicovers his bad intentions, is the letters which Gondebaut King of the Burgundians did write unto him, which I have een, and which intimate a very cloe correpondency betwixt them; Thee things being thus cloely hid from me, mut needs be
unto my diadvantage; and I believe his deign is to attempt againt the State, and to etablih his uurpation by ravihing Galathea from me, and marrying her either by good will or by force.

Oh Heavens Madam, cryed out Galathea; do you think this pernicious man has any uch abominable deign? It is not to be doubted Madam, anwered the Druide, and I ground my opinion upon his procuring that Impotor to place himelf o neer the Gardens of Mount Brion, to deceive you under a colour of Sanctity, and of being a Druide, and to try if by this means he could obtain your favour; but eeing that this failed him, and that Clidemant, Lindamore, and all the Cavalry are abent, he may very well take hold of this opportunity, and make ue of his correpondents to that purpoe, ince the whole government of the Country is in his hands; therefore, I humbly conceive Madam, (aid he unto Amais) that your bet coure is to haten Lindamore's return as oon as poibly he can, and that he bring with him al his Cavalry; in the mean time, retire your elf into the City of Marelles, where without any noie, I will end unto you as many Souldiers and Cavaliers as I can: within two dayes I will come thither my elf, and if it be poible bring Damon with me, for I do not think the Country afe enough againt the violence of Polemas. I do vow (aid Galathea) that if this wicked man do offer any attemps upon my peron, I will with my own hands and nails trangle my elf-Daughter, (anwered Amais) good Angels preerve you from any uch extremities; I had rather ee you in your Coffin, then under the ubjection of this inolent man; but I hope never to ee it: and yet it concerns us to ue that remedy which Adamas out of his prudence and fidelity, hath propounded unto us; this very night you hall go with me unto Marelles, we will carry Alcidon and Daphnide, and all their Company with us, and entreat them to leave off that habit which uits o ill with their qualities; to morrow, I will end a letter for Damon and Madonthe: But Father (aid he and turned towards Adamas) as for the Druide, who was formerly at Mount Brion, who told Fortunes, and lived with o much appearance of Sanctity, you mut know that he is returned again, and begins to live, and do as formerly he did: Oh Madam, anwered Adamas, he is a mot abominable Impotor, and did you but know how Polemas makes ue of him, you would think them both worthy of punihment: but the dicoure of it will be too long for this time, for I ee the Sun grow very low, and you have no more time then to return unto Marelles by day light; but if we could eie upon this Impotor, perhaps we hould dicover by him what the deign of Polemas is, for he is one of his great intruments. Galathea whoe very pleen againt this man had almot dryed up her tears, if you pleae (aid he) we hall eaily take him; for there needs no more but to pretend that I deire to peak with him: but I do not know how to manage the matter handomly, without the aitance of Leonide, and therefore it is requiite to end for her. Aure your elf Madam, anwered Adamas, that to morrow I will end her unto you; and yet I think it a good way to end Silvia to morrow very early unto this Impotor, to tell him that you Madam have a very great deire to ee him, and that within this two or three dayes you intend to come unto him; this will alo deceive Polemas, and perhaps may caue him to retard his wicked deign, which will be very advantageous unto us: for we hall have more time to provide for our defence, which I foreee we hall tand in need of. This being reolved upon, Amais without more delay, and to give Galathea time to dry her eyes, he called for Pen, Ink, and Paper, to write unto Lindamore, that he hould in all poible hate come unto her, and that he hould undertand the great neceity of his preence by the bearer: which done, he called for the Cavalier, gave him the Letter, and commanded him not to loe one minute of time, but pot unto Lindamore withal poible peed, and tell him that he hould ee his good affection by the hate that he will make in coming to her, and bringing with him all his Cavalry and Souldiers: And becaue the Cavalier was very truty, and Lindamore, had great confidence in him, he acquainted him with the wicked intentions of Polemas, purpoely to make him more quick in his imployment, and to bring back Lindamore the ooner. The Cavalier without more delay took his leave; and Galathea to oblige Lindamore to make the more hate, Good Sir, aid he unto him, tell Lindamore that I hall know whether or no he be my friend, by the hate that he hall make.

Upon this the Cavalier departed, and the Nymphs with Adamas went out, and after a little common dicoure, they entreated Daphnide and her Company to go along with them, and pas away ome dayes in Marelles. Daphnide cating her eye upon Alcidon, and eeing that he referred it unto her, he thought it not civil to deny the Nymph, and therefore aid he would wait upon her: for which Amais gave them thanks; and taking Daphnide by the hand, he went unto Damon and Madonthe. Damon, aid he unto him, I intend to end my letter for you to morrow, and I deire that for the reaons which Adamas will give you, you will put your elf to a little more paines in coming unto Marelles. Madam, anwered Damon, I have both trength and devotion to erve you in whatoever you pleae to command. After this, night compelled the Nymph to depart with all this good company; and he was o careful to end for Damon in the morning, that before ten of the clock, he was at Marelles with Madonthe, Adamas, and Leonide. But Paris being extreamly deirous of going unto Belinde, he entreated Adamas he would be pleaed to write the letter which he had promied: Adamas being alo very willing to give him all atisfaction, did write according to his deires: upon this, he departed immediately, o glad of Dianas permiion, and Adamas his conent, as he could not tell how to wih for more happines.

Adamas in atisfaction unto Galatheas deire, ent the ame night for Leonide, to the end he might be with her the next morning betimes. And ince he was to go unto Galathea, he writ unto her that Alexis hould not upon any terms go with her, let he hould be known; and therefore he hould provide her elf with ome handome excue, and that this eparation would not be for above two or three dayes at the mot. When Leonide received this letter it was almot night, and as it chanced, Astrea had carried them unto Dianas houe: o as whilt Atrea was talking with Diana and Daphnis, Leonide hewed Alexis the letter which he had received. At the firt, he was a little troubled at it, thinking it very odd he hould tay alone in a place, where if he hould come to be known, it would turn to her digrace. But on the other ide conidering, that if he went unto Galathea, he hould be utterly ruined, he was contented to tay till in that place, pretending that he was not yet well, and telling Atrea in private, that he was o much in Love with this retired kind of life, as he had no mind of going unto Galathea who had ent for her; and that he would fain her elf ick, purpoely to tay with her in a place that was free from the turbulent noie of a Court. Thus Leonide, got up betimes the next morning, and left Phillis in bed with Atrea; and taking her leave of them, he promied to return very hortly to ee them and Alexis; then going unto this diguied Druide who was not yet up: be ure (aid he unto her in her ear) that you manage your time handomly, and let not good opportunities lip Alexis anwered her only with a igh, and then Leonide went unto Adamas, and afterwards with him unto Galathea, leaving the diguied Druide in abundance of content, and more might have had, if he had had but confidence enough to make ue of that fair occaion.

Although Galathea out of a violent fit of jealouie had banihed the Nymph Leonide from her preence, yet he did after wih for her again, as well of her own natural goodnes, when he remembred the affection and fidelity of that Lady; as becaue her paion being now a little cooled, her judgment reaumed its trength, and uffered her to think her not o culpable, as in the heat of her anger he thought her: moreover the help of Silvia did not a little help her to dicharge Leonide of Celadons ecape, when they talked together. But that which mot made her forget all her anger againt this Nymph, was the death of Clidemant, and the enterprie of Polemas, who had ome deigns both againt her peron and etate. And becaue great paions have a quality which drown all inferiors, and makes the oul think upon nothing but it, this Nymph was o extreamly offended againt the boldnes and treaon of Polemas, that her mind did run wholly how he hould chatie him: hewing by this, that a generous Spirit can hardly brook any unworthy violence.

And oberve how Heaven does laugh at the ubtilties of men, and how eaily it can confute all human policy, and turn it to their own di-advantage: All the Artifice which Polemas had ued to ruine Lindamore in Galatheas affection, being once dicovered, it made her Love him more; and the rah enterprie upon which he laid
the foundation of his future Grandeur, did revive in her thoe parks which were almot quite extinguihed by the ubtilties of Polemas and Climanthes. Lindamore being abent, could not o oon be a witnes of thoe favours which this renewed Love prepared for him: and Galathea longed for one unto whom he might freely dicharge her heart of uch thoughts as were neceary to be concealed; when he looked upon thoe that were about her, he found none capable of the ecret: as for Silvia and her Nure, who knew mot of her ecrets, he thought the one too young, and the other too old; and though he was confident of both their affections and fidelities, and though the prudence and wiedom of Silvia was above her age, yet he thought that matters of State were things of too great a weight to trut them withall: and upon this reaon eeking for a good occaion to recal Leonide, and conidering that he never had any good ground to upect either her affection or fidelity, unles it was in the buines of Celadon, which being now out of mind, and new accidents coming in lieu of it, they blotted out the memory of the other. So as this new buines coming upon her, and o neerly concerning her, he accued her elf of too much rahnes in banihing Leonide, he intended to let lip no occaion of calling her back, and treating her better for the future.

And in as much as it is natural to deire the concealment of our faults, Galathea deiring not to be taxed with levity and inconideration in the banihment of Leonide from her, he did with abundance of care eek out for a good occaion of calling her back, without giving any knowledg of the caue why he did banih her: o as when it was aid that Climanthes was returned, and when he heard that Amais and Adamas deired to know whether it was the Impotor who had formerly deceived them, he aid that Leonide knew him better then any other, though he knew well enough that Silvia knew him as well as he; and not to let lip this opportunity, he deired Adamas to bring her back preently: Leonide on the other ide, when her Uncle acquainted her with Galatheas will, he was willing to obey her, le • t he hould eem too much dicontented: but with a reolution of returning unto the pleaant banks of Lignon as oon as poibly he could, as well to avoid the confued life of the Court, as to enjoy the weet liberty in which he lived amongt thoe dicreet and Fair Shepherdees: and though he did not tell her elf as much, yet the true reaon of her deires to return, was to ee Celadon, whom he left diguied under the habit and name of Alexis: for though he had endeavoured as much as poibly he could to quench that flame in her elf, yet he found how hard a matter it is for a oul to reaume its former liberty, after it is once captivated with a commanding love; and he could not free her elf from that paion, though he knew that Celadon would never leave Atrea: confuting hereby the opinion of thoe who affirm, that there is no love without ome hope.

When Leonide came unto the houe of her Uncle Adamas, though it was very early, yet he found all ready to depart: for the Druide knowing that important affairs requires all hate, and that it is hate which gives them both life and accomplihment, he had taken order for every thing requiite by the break of day; both for Damon and for Madonthe: Amais had ent a good guard of Souldiers to be their convoy, under a pretence of an honour unto them, and not as if he feared any injury would be offered unto them by the way.

Silvia, and mot of her Companions, who knew of Leonides return, went and waited for her at the outmot gate of the Catle, and did expres o many igns of good will, as made it mot evident that they loved her, at the leat, if any true friendhip can be found in a Court. Silvia above all the ret, embraced and kied her a hundred times: and as oon as he had aluted Amais, who received her very kindly, and had kied the hands of Galathea, who welcomed her with extraordinary carees, they eparated themelves as oon as they could from the ret of their companions, and related unto each other all paages which had hapned ince their lat being together. Leonide with a calm temper related how pleaingly he had pent the time of her banihment, in the company of thoe fair and dicreet Shepherdees, and told even wonders of their beauty, virtue, courteie, civility, and wit, particularly of Atrea, Diana, and Phillis: but in this, more ubtile then her companion, he poke not a illable of Celadon, thinking it no dicretion to trut a young woman
with a thing which once known, might bring her much dipleaure: and when Silvia asked her concerning Alexis, as thinking her to be the daughter of Adamas, he anwered very coldly and carelely, and aid, that indeed he was a very good harmles body, and had a wit utable unto the profeion, in which he had been educated.

Damon and Madonthe were in the interim received with all honour that Amais and Galathea could do them, as well in duty to their merit, as to oblige Damon to ait them in the urgent affairs which they foreaw. When he was got into bed, and the Chirurgions looked upon his wounds, though the haking in the litter had a little altered them, yet they thought that in a very few days he would be perfectly whole: for though his wounds were great, yet they were not dangerous; and his meeting with Madonthe, and finding her as affectionate unto him as he could deire, conduced much to his cure; and therefore every one conceived that the Chirurgery unto the body, was to begin with the cure of the heart and mind. Madonthe on her ide, finding how much good her kindnes did unto him, he was almot continually with him, hewing unto him all manner of civil favours: and foreeeing that he was to tay long in that place in expectation of Damon cure, he reolved to change her habit and become a Nymph; he knew that Damon would be better pleaed with it, as more utable to her quality: and her new dres did o well become her, as he appeared to be a great beauty, which manifets, that beauty receives no mall advantage from trimming up it elf.

Night being come, and Galathea having commanded Leonide to lie in her chamber; when he aw that all the ret were retired, he called unto her; and cauing her to take a candle, as if he had ome ervice for her: then looking a long while upon her without peaking a word: at the lat with a miling eye he aid unto her, well Leonide, are you till angry with me? With you Madam (anwered Leonide and made a low courteie) why, I beeech you, do you ask that quetion? Do you think me to be out of my wits? I mot humbly beeech you to believe that Leonide will never fail in that honour and repect which I ow unto you. But Madam (aid he, and miled) may I aume o much boldnes as to ask you the very ame quetion which you do me? Yes Leonide, anwered Galathea, and let us here make a full confeion, and o rip up the whole matter, that we never after have any occaion to jarr: the truth is, you was angry with me, and I with you; and for my part I will confes it proceeded from jealouie: but Leonide why were you angry? If you will needs have it o that I was angry, replied Leonide, it did proceed from the ame jealouie: How? replied Galathea, were you jealous of me? No Madam, anwered Leonide, but if I was angry, it was to ee you jealous, and that you hould upect me of a crime, whereof I was not guilty. Then Leonide, aid the Nymph, I would have all things to be forgotten, and if I was too rah, excue my error; for truly I had an opinion that all which the Druide told me, was as certain as if it had come from the mouth of an Oracle: Oh Madam, replied Leonide, that Druide was a mot vile Impotor, and had you been pleaed to have believed me, his villany hould never have deceived you. Alas, anwered Galathea, I was o deceived by his language, as I was extreamly offended with all thoe that poke unto me againt him. But Madam, aid Leonide, do you know the truth now? Oh Sweet-heart, anwered Galathea, I have ince found him to my cot, a very knave: I am mot heartily glad of it, replied the Nymph, for then you will find my innocency. Speak no more concerning your elf, replied Galathea, for I have quite altered my opinion, and believe, that if I could have met with an opportunity, I hould have called you back unto me before now; but I would not upon any terms that the caue of our difference hould be known; yet I protet unto you Leonide, I never wihed you any ill; it is true, I was angry with you, upon the ground that I have told you, but for all that, I loved you better then any that are in my ervice: and I think it may be excued for being angry, for Leonide confes the truth, did not you help Celadon to ecape? And were not you to blame for oppoing my will? Confes it freely Leonide, for now, I care not for him, and will pardon you. Madam, anwered Leonide and miled, I ee you deire I hould confee a fault which I never committed; and ince you have no more interet in him, I will freely confes, and protet
that I did nothing but change Celadon into Lucinda, and you your elf did approve of what I did, when I dreed him in the habit of a woman. But why hould I be o deirous of packing him from you? And what interet had I in it? If you had no interet, replied Galathea, why did you o often importune me to let him return unto Atrea? Many reaons, anwered Leonide did induce me thereunto: Firt, I was afraid let that a man hould be een amongt us, and what a blemih would it have been to your reputation, if it had been known? Next, the ingratitude and corn of that Shepherd did extreamly dipleae me: I thought him unworthy of that honour which you did him, and which he did o ill acknowledg: but my chief reaon of all was, becaue I was ure you was deceived, and that the treaon was invented by Polemas and Climanthes, thoe two unworthy wretches: and how came you to know there villany? aid Galathea. Madam, aid Leonide, I told you then, but paion kept you from believing me: when Celadon was ick, you ent me unto Adamas; and by fortune coming into an Inn, I was lodged in a chamber, next unto that where Polemas and Climanthes were all alone, and when they leat dreamed of it, I heard all their villany. Ah Leonide, replied the Nymph, I will remember that you told me as much, but time only could teach me how to believe you. Amais, my Mother was deceived in him as well as I, and would never uffer him to be punihed, according to his merit: but nothing is o cloe which time does not dicover, my Mother hath ince found out his knavery; for all that he aid in relation to Clidemant, is proved abolutely fale; o as now, he hates him as much as either you or I can. I am very glad, replied Leonide, that the knavery of this wicked man is known, and more glad to ee you convinced of that error which he infued into you, and hould be as glad to ee him punihed for an example, and in terror of all uch Impotors. Never fear it, aid Galathea, for I believe that ere long we hall be ufficiently revenged; you mut know, that he is of late returned again, and therefore I much deired your return alo. How Madam, aid Leonide, is that Impotor returned again? It is as I tell you, replied Galathea, and it is to be believed that he has ome grand deign in hand, for he is the great Counellor of that Traitor Polemas. Oh Heavens Madam, aid Leonide, how infinitely you joy me to hear you peak thus of thoe two wicked men; but, if I may be o bold as to ask, I beeech you what have they done of late? They have done uch things, anwered the Nymph, that when you hear them, you, will admire and abhor them both: they are plotting no les then the ruine of us and all the Country: I do love you, Sweet-heart better then I did before, for in your abence I have found your dicretion and affection to me; I will therefore trut you with a thing that none but Amais, Adamas, and my elf does know: then after a little paue, he began thus.

You know Leonide, that when this impudent villain was firt at Savignea, my Mother, as well as we, went to know of him the event of that voyage which Clidemant my dear brother was to undertake. This Impotor amongt many other things told her, that after he had gotten much honour and glory, he hould return afely and with much contentment unto all: But on the contrary, we have received news from Lindamore, that poor Clidemant is dead, and himelf o wounded, as he is forced to tay with the Queen Methina in the City of Rhemois. Oh Heavens Madam, (cryed our Leonide) is Clidemant dead? Speak low, anwered Galathea, let any hould hear us: for it concerns us to keep it cloe for a while, unles we would fall into the mot bae Tyranny that is imaginable. I beeech you Madam, aid Leonide, what does induce you unto uch feares? And from whom do you expect uch inolence? From him (anwered the Nymph) who did before plot how to deceive me, I mean Polemas: you mut know that this arrogant wretch out of an incredible preumption, does not only plot how to marry me, as you heard from his own mouth, and from Climanthes, but more, he intends to marry me though againt my will: and in order to that, he hath plotted mot damnable treaon both againt me and the State, ayming to make himelf mater of us both at once; you heard of his actions againt Damon, and we do undertand what great intelligence he holds with Gondebaut, King of the Burgundians, without acquainting us: certainly his treaon had broken out before now, were he not in fear of Clidemant; nothing ele retrains him: Amais hath therefore ent for Lindamore to return with all poible hate; and though I
aure my elf he will not fail, yet being o far off, we are full of many fears. We ee how Polemas has all the Souldiers at his devotion, and my Mother thinking he had done very well in it, has conferred upon him uch ample power, as he has the means to oblige them all to be at his own beck, though againt us. I aure you Madam, aid Leonide, in a great amazement, you have reaon to ay, that thee are things of great importance; o great, as I believe, nothing can more neerly concern you. Now Sweet-heart, aid Galathea, this Traytor who is yet ignorant of Clidemants death, hath caued him whom you call Climanthes, to come unto the ame place again where he was before: for my part, I believe, it is to try if by ome other ubtilty he can win upon my will to marry Polemas: and Adamas whom I believe you acquainted with the knavery of this Impotor, hath beeeched Amais, to know whether it be he or no, and if he prove the deceiver, to caue him to be eized upon; for it is probable that by him we hall know of all Polemas his plots: and ince he truted him with his deign upon me, he would not hide the ret of his deign from him. We were in the houe of Adamas when this coure was reolved upon; and I had an extream deire to have you with me, I aid that there was none who could manage this matter better then your elf, who had o often talked with him. In the mean time, we came hither, and do all that we can for our own afeties: but we are o unprovided of all manner of defence, as we know not which way to turn our elves. This, Sweet-heart, is the tate of our affairs, which when well conidered is very deplorable; for we have lot Clidemant: all our bet ubjects are either dead with him, or out of the Country; and we are almot in the hands of an inolent fellow, whoe impudent ambition threatens us with intollerable ervitude.

Upon this, the Nymph could not withhold her tears, nor Leonide neither, who after he had emptied her eyes and recollected her elf, did anwer thus: I mut needs confes Madam, that of all treaons this is the wort, which being grounded upon great ingratitude, it is to be hoped, Heaven will never let it arrive at the end of this wicked mans deires. The Gods are more jut then to favour him in uch unjut deigns, and you hall ee they will end us help in our neceity from uch means as perhaps we leat expected. Put all your confidence Madam, in God, and aure your elf, that he will not fail you; beides, your caue is uch, that though there was none but women to defend this place, I believe we are enough to keep it againt all men alive: and for my part, I believe, that upon uch an occaion I hould be more valiant then Lindamore: but Madam, ince you ent for me, as thinking I might be uefull unto you in the buines, what ervice is it you are pleaed to command me? I would have you go, (aid Galathea) and ee whether this man be the Impotor or no: if he be the ame Climanthes, as I believe he is, I would have you make him believe, that I have an extream deire to confer with him upon a buines of great concernment; and if it be poible, perwade him to come hither, and peak with me here: if you can prevail o far, we hall keep him o as he hall not go out when he will; if you cannot, becaue guilty perons are always upitious of themelves, appoint a day when I may be ure to find him there, for as you know, he ueth to hide himelf ome dayes: and if we hould go unto him with a trong hand, and he not be there, this would divulge our deign o much, as we hould loe the opportunity of ever catching him.

After much other uch dicoure as this, Galathea dimied Leonide unto her ret; but calling her preently back again. I mut needs know (aid he unto her) what character you give of your Fair Shepherdees, & how you have lived all this while of your abence from me. Madam, anwered Leonide, I can ay nothing of them but that they are the fairet, the mot dicreet and lovely women that ever I aw, and their converation is uch, that whooever is weary of their company, is certainly of a very ill humour: the golden age Madam, which men lived in long ince, and which is o much envied by all that lived after them, could never enjoy o much contentment and pleaure as is to be found amongt them. I profes Leonide, aid Galathea, you give them uch a character, as makes me wih my elf a Shepherdes. Certainly Madam, replied Leonide, did you but once tate thoe weets, and tranquility which they enjoy, you would not deire to leave them. And yet, aid Galathea, they alo have their ditempers and cares, and inquietudes; for when they lot Celadon, did
they not exceedingly reent the los? It is impoible, replied Leonide, to be in the world, and be exempt from paying the tributes of humanity: but I call them happy and free from inquietude, when I compare our cares and theirs together: I know not why you hould think theirs o little, replied Galathea, for I have heard ay that when Celadon was lot, not only Atrea, but all the Town made great lamentations. Truly Madam, anwered Leonide, they had hewed themelves very inenible if the los of o well an accomplihed Shepherd had not moved them: I aure my elf, replied Galathea very ubtilely, that as the los of him did fill them with orrow, the recovery of him was as joyful unto them. Leonide knew the reaon why the Nymph poke thus, and therefore he anwered her very coldly, doubtles, when they do recover him, it will be abundance of joy unto them all; for that Shepherd was exceedingly beloved of all that knew him: why (aid Galathea) is not Celadon yet returned unto them? No Madam, aid Leonide, and now they hardly o much as think upon him. Does not Atrea, replied Galathea, ometimes peak of him? She does, anwered Leonide, but never unles ome other begin the dicoure. Why (aid the Nymph) does he not love him till? Or has ome other ucceeded him in her affection? Did he love him, anwered Leonide, he would love in vain, for every one thinks him dead. I aure you, aid Galathea, that if he were dead I hould exceedingly lament him; for he was the finet Shepherd of all his Country; and I mut tell you truly, the knavery of Climanthes did firt move me to cherih him, and afterwards, his own merits moved me much more: and ay what you will, I cannot believe but Atrea, what face oever he et upon it, will have him in her heart, as long as he lives; for I who am les concerned then he, I cannot think upon him without much dipleaure. But, added he, it is late, retire your elf therefore; and remember you go to morrow with your companion Silvia, to ee whether yond man be Climanthes, or ome other like him, for the buines does not a little concern us.

This was the firt dicoure which Galathea had with Leonide in private, of which he was very glad; yet he perceived that Galathea was not o well cured of Celadon as he made a hew of; and therefore he reolved not to dicover or dicoure any thing of that Shepherd, which might bring him into memory, knowing very well, that a Candle newly extinguihed, will light it elf again even by the very moak. But becaue he would not fail in thoe commands which he had laid upon her, being of uch great concernment, after he had conferred with her Uncle Adamas, he went with her companion Silvia to make this dicovery.

When they came firt to the place, they made a doubt whether it was Climanthes or no; for they found every thing o changed, as they hardly thought it to be the ame place which formerly it was. Now was the place trimmed up very fine and larger then before, with windows to give more light. This alteration did at the firt atonih them; yet eeing the door hut, they reolved to knock and be better reolved. They went up eight or ten teps higher unto the Temple then it was before: and when they were at the top, through the windows which were on either ide the door, they aw an Altar at the other end of the Temple, and before it, a man at his prayers, but they could not know him, becaue his back was towards them. The Cell being but little, they could hear what he prayed, o it is; Oh mot Puiant Deity, (aid he) I beeech thee for a ign from Heaven; and having repeated the ame words thrice over in a loud voice, they aw the fire kindle upon the Altar of it elf, as readily as it was wont to do at other times, which made the two Nymphs believe him to be the ame Impotor whom they looked for: and they were not deceived; for he having pied them afar off, he prepared himelf into this diguie of Sanctity: but they eeming not to have the leat upition of his Artifice, they uttered unto one another words of great admiration, in an audible voice; which he hearing, did much rejoyce at it, believing that they did not upect his knavery; and the more to delude them by his new jugling, he turned his head towards them at the noie which they made: and becaue they deired to enter into the Temple and peak with him, he took ome Holy Water and wahed his eyes and his eares, becau • he had both een and heard thee Nymphs whilt he was at his devotion; then throwing ome Veruin, and a few leaves of Oak and Mileto into the fire, he elevated his voice and aid: If it be thy pleaure, Oh mot omnipotent Deity, that they hall enter into
thy Sacred Temple, then open thou the doors and let them in. He had no ooner uttered thee words, but the doors opened of themelves, though none touched them, which made the two Nymphs to wonder o much, that though they knew the fellow to be but a jugling knave, yet they could not chue but be afraid; and therefore they tood a while as if they doubted whether they hould enter or no; until he himelf in his Sacerdotal robes, and with a face full of gravity, came to invite them, ince it eemed to be the will of God they hould, by this particular ign of favour unto them. Leonide and her companion being grown a little more confident, and eeming to bear a great reverence unto him, they entred, and followed him as far as the Altar, where kneeling down after the example of this Impotor, they remained in that poture until he roe up, and aid unto them; Leonide and Silvia, the Deity of the place whom I adore, is pleaed with your coming into this Holy Temple; for having advertied me of your coming, and commanded me to let you enter without purifying you either by perfumes or holy water, I could not chue but be atonihed at it; and therefore I asked of him an extraordinary ign of his will; upon which, the fire did preently kindle of it elf. Then when you were come, I not being able to think that you hould enter in this manner, I beeeched him to hew his pleaure by opening the doors of the Temple unto you, which he mot miraculouly did, as you have een. Now, Oh mot Omnipent and infinite Deity, if it be thy pleaure, (aid he and turned towards the Altar) that thee Nymphs hould adore thee in thy Sacred Cell, as it eems it is, by opening the dore unto them, hew us ome ign of thy divine will, that thou art pleaed they hould make their upplications unto thee: When he uttered thee words, the fire that w •• upon the Altar did extinguih, and the doors did miraculouly hut of themelves; at which the Nymphs were o amazed, though they knew him to be a cunning knave, yet they feared that his tricks were done by ome inchantment or witchcraft; and therefore they would needs go out of that place which they thought warmed with fiends and divels; but he took them both by their arms, and aid, that ince the doors were hut by the will of God, they would greatly offend him, if they offered to open them before it was his pleaure: but he deired them to let him know the caue of their coming thither, to the end he might pray unto God to inpire him with an anwer. Though the Nymphs were both afraid, yet partly by force, and partly by •• king courage, Leonide acquainted him with the deire of the Nymph Galath • ; beeeching him, if it was his pleaure, to come unto her, and as oon as poibly he could, becaue he had a buines of great importance to communicate unto him, and delay might be very prejudical unto her: We are not, Oh age Nymphs, (aid he unto them) like unto other men, who may dipoe of themelves after their own wills; for we, who have dedicated our elves unto the ervice of Heaven, neither ought nor can dipoe of our elves, but according to the will of Heaven: and I mut tell you more, that I am exprely forbidden to go out of the Limits which are appointed unto me by this Divinity, without their expres permiion; and therefore, I cannot give you any direct anwer until I have conulted with the Oracle: if you will pleae to come again unto me about four or five dayes hence, you hall know what anwer I receive from it; but in the mean time, that we may have ome knowledg of his future good will, let us offer unto him a mall acrifice, which we will make of the Sacred Mileto, Veruin, and Savine, which are o pleaing unto him. Upon this taking a few Oak leaves, and making two Chaplets in form of Garlands, he put them upon their heads: then lighting the fire upon the Altar, he threw in ome of thoe leaves before named; latly, kneeling down, he eemed to make ome prayers in a low voice, and when he aw it was time, Oh Great and Omnipotent Deity, (aid he in a loud voice) if the requests and upplications of thee Nymphs be pleaing unto thee, open thou the doors of the Temple unto them, that after they have adored thee, they may go home unto their houes with content and atisfaction. The Nymphs hearing thee words, took particular notice of all the Actions of Climanthes, to ee if they could py by what trick the doors were opened; but they eemed to open miraculouly, for neither his hand, nor any other part of his body moved, which could move them unto any upition.

The doors then of the Temple being opened thus trangely, this Impotor taking
both the Nymphs by their hands, Go pure and innocent ouls (aid he unto them) Rejoyce in that the Heavens do love you, and for that there are few things which you can ask that will be denied unto you: then conducting them forth, he ued a few Ceremonies, lifted up his hands and eyes to heaven, and returned to the ame place where he aw them when they firt came: And becaue they were extreamly afraid that he was a Conjurer, they hated away as fat as they could, and thinking ome Demon followed them. But Climanthes thinking that perhaps they might hide themelves in ome Buh neer, to ee what he did, he kindled the fire upon the Altar, & made the doors hut of themelves; which the Nymphs eeing as they looked back, fear made them go away fater then they came. Thus did the knavery of this wicked fellow erve him for a cloak of piety.

Galathea was not out of bed when Leonide and Silvia returned, and when they came unto her, they looked with uch affrighted looks, that Galathea thought at firt that they had met with ome diater: But when they related all that they had een, and their fears at the opening and hutting of the doors, he could not chue but laugh to ee how they trembled at the very relation. I aure you Madam (aid Silvia when he aw Galathea laugh at them) that I am not of a very timorous temper, but I mut confes that when I aw thoe doors open and hut of themelves, the hair of my head began to tare, and I do think any that aw them would have done the like. Good Madam, aid Leonide, uppoe the doors of your chamber hould thus open and hut of themelves, would you not be afraid as well as we? We know the man to be a knave, but withal, we fear that he deals with the Divel, and is a Conjurer. No, no, aid the Nymph, you know he is a cunning fellow, and full of jugling tricks, and he did them o lightly, that he deluded your eyes. No no Madam, anwered Silvia, my companion and I both oberved all his actions o narrowly, that no motion, nor a cat of his eye ecaped us. However Madam (aid Leonide) we can aure you he is the ame Climanthes which formerly we aw, and it is to be believed that he has a deigne in project by his taying here: Whether he ue conjuration or not, I aure you he ueth abundance of Artifice and pains, and certainly it is to ome Deigne of importance. But (aid Galathea) when did he promie to come hither? How Madam! anwered Silvia, promie to come hither? Nay, nay, he is one that never moves a foot without God's leave; he ays he will conult with his Oracle, and if we come about five days hence, he will tell us whither God will give him leave to tir out of thoe limits allotted to him: But for my part, I believe he will conult with one that has as many Divels at his command as I have hairs on my head.

Galathea could not forbear laughing at their relation, and commanded them to tell what they had done and een unto all, epecially unto Adamas. Climanthes on the other ide pent all the ret of the day in his wicked (though eeming) Devotion, to the end that if any did come and urprize him, they might ee his anctity: But when it was night, and he thought none could ee him, he locked up his Temple, put on other clothes, went through the Wood unto Polemas, and acquainted him with all the adventures of the day, and conulted with him how to demean him elf towards Galathea in her quetions which he hould ask. Polemas was much joyed when he heard the Nymph had a mind to talk with Climanthes, auring himelf that now he gave credit unto his Art, which until then he made a doubt of. I do believe aid Climanthes in anwer unto Polemas, that the mot ubtle and cautelous men might be deluded as well as thee women; for never was deigne carried on with more prudence and circumpection then ours: For my part think you what you pleae, I can never be perwaded they have the leat upition o • any jugling in all that they have een; for I have been o punctual in every circumtance, that I think any one living might be deceived as well as they: whatoever they were by my firt devices, I am mot confident they are much more deluded by my econd.

Whilt they were talking thus, a Meenger brought ome news of concernment unto Polemas: upon this their dicoure was interrupted; therefore making Climanthes to go into a Cloet hard by, he caued the meenger to enter. Sir (aid the meenger unto him, when he aw him alone in the chamber) your faithful ervant Meronthes alutes you, and hath commanded me to deliver this letter unto
your own hand; and more, hath given me in charge after you have read it, to acquaint you with ome paages from him which relate unto your ervice. Polemas opening and reading the letter, and finding it only to be a letter of Credence, he took him by the hand, and drew him as cloe to the Cloet where Climanthes was, as poibly he could, purpoely that he might hear, auring himelf that it was omthing which was neceary to be communicated unto him, becaue Merontes was one of the prime Burgomaters of the City of Marelles, and long ince made his creature; asking therefore of the meenger, who was his on, what he had to ay, he acquainted him with the arrival of Damon and Madonthe, and the honour and carees which Amais and Galathea did unto them; the care which both of them had of him, and the opinion which the Chirurgions had of him: Afterwards he gave him an accompt of all the Souldiers that were in the Town, in what manner the Guards were placed, the little upition that either Amais or Adamas had of any attempts, and briefly aured him, that he would open a gate of the Town unto him when he pleaed: Polemas received this news with much joy; and after thanks unto Merontes for his affection and fidelity, he conjured him to continue it, with aurance that he would one day recompence him to the full: That when time erved, he would make ue of his offer, as from one whom he confided in, the mot of any man in the world: then fetching a bag of money which he kept always ready for a recompence of ecret Intelligences; Here aid he unto him, take this as an earnet of my good Will, and when occaion erves, I will do more for you: But pray tell me (aid he unto the man) is there any News at Court? Sir (aid the young man) all the talk is of a Druide who lives neer Mount Brion in o much anctity, that the Gods do grant unto him whatoever he asks: I cannot relate all the tories that are told of him, for they are o many, and o trange, as are incredible: His greatet reputation did pring from a voyage which Leonide did make unto him, who reports uch wonders of him, as does atonih all hearers: Amongt the ret (aid Polemas) what does he report to have een? Sir, anwered the man, he reports many wonders, and amongt the ret, of the Door of the Temple, which opens and huts of it elf, at the very command of this holy Man. For my part Sir, I go but eldom unto the Catle, and what I report, is only by hear-ay: But it is mot certain, that many trange wonders are reported of this holy peron. Well Sir, aid Polemas, Return unto your Father, tell him, I give him a thouand thanks for the News which I have received by you, and hall one day be as forward in real recompence, as I am now in my verbal thanks: Deire him to continue in his Affection and Fidelity, but above all, I deire both him and you to be ecret. Upon this, Polemas dimied the meenger, and returned to Climanthes; who hearing what the man reported of him, could not chue but laugh at the opinion which the world conceived of him: And let me tell you (aid he) that it is beyond the reach of a Female ubtilty to find out the Art which I have ued. Good Climanthes (aid Polemas) I beeech you tell me how you kindled the Fire upon your Altar, and how the Doors did open and hut of themelves at uch a ditance from you; for I mut confes I do not undertand how you can do it. The truth is, Sir, aid Climanthes, thee Arts, like all tricks of Legerdemain, are not to be undertood by words, as they may be mot eaily by ight and demontration; for I have ordered my Engines in uch a manner, as words cannot decribe them; but be aured, they are the eaiet things in the world to be undertood when they are once een. I mut needs ay, replyed Polemas, that Climanthes is a Mater in his Art, and now I am fully perwaded that thee Women are deceived by it: But dear friend, aid he, and embraced him, how do you think our Deigne will take? Doubtles Sir, aid he, as well as we can wih; for though the event of future things be uncertain, yet take it upon my word, a happy beginning is mot commonly econded by a happy end; and I am certain you cannot deire a more happy beginning then we have had. Within this Country all is your own; and out of it, there is not one Prince nor Neighbour who does not love and favour you: All thoe that can any ways hinder you, are at a far ditance from you, and o employed in the affairs of others, that they give you time enough to tranact ours; The bet of it is, Clidemant who is the only mote in your eye, he is o engaged in the aitance of a Prince o far ditant from us, that any relief from
him is not to be feared; whereas your Confederates and Allies, are at hand, o as we hall meet with no oppoition, unles from a Company of weak women, who though very potent in Wars of Love, yet are they but pitifully weak in the Wars of Mars. But you mut conider, replied Polemas, that Adamas whoe good will, will never be gained, is a very coniderable enemy, by reaon of the credit and reputation that he has in this Country; the authority of Amais, and the avere dipoition of Galathea, will be great hindrances unto us. Pray Sir conider, anwered Climanthes, that every thing will act according to its own nature: Adamas may hurt you in words, but not in deeds; take but Arms, and all his books are not worth a ruh. As for Amais, he is o affectionate unto Galathea, as he will not cros her in any thing he hall deire: there is the greatet difficulty, replied Polemas, for Galathea is young, and has no conideration of the States tranquility, but all her deignes and inclinations, are cros and avere unto mine. How know you that? replied Climanthes, perhaps he deires it as much as you, but knows not how to bring it about: I pray tell me, Has he not formerly loved you? True, anwered Polemas, but Lindamore has toln her affection from me: Pray Sir conider, aid Climanthes, that what was once, may be again. The Nature of a woman, epecially of a young one, is very wavering; catches at every object of novelty that pleaeth the eyes, and fixes olidly upon none, her mind is like a Ship at Sea without any Anchor or tay, which flotes as every wind pleaeth. Now if we may be conjectures guee all things hidden, I mut needs think he is fully intended to oberve whatoever I hall bid her; why ele hould he end Leonide unto me, to deire that I hould come preently unto her? I am either extreamly mitaken, or ele I ee her heart infinitely impatient to ee me, with intentions to put her elf wholly into my hands; aure your elf, that I gave her a very hot allarm, when I told her that if he married any but him whom the Gods had appointed for her, he would be the mot unhappy woman alive. But uppoe, aid Polemas, he hould dicover your ubtilty? But uppoe (aid Climanthes) the sky hould fall? There is as much likelyhood of the one as of the other: I would have you to know, that Climanthes is uch a Mater in his Art, that if he would attempt to make Amais marry him, he could bring it to pas. Polemas laughed and aid, I wih with all my heart that I were a witnes of your marriage with her, and you of mine with Galathea. No, no, aid Climanthes, I would be contented with Leonide, Oh my dear friend (aid Polemas) when I do marry Galathea, I will promie you Leonide: and I promie you, aid Climanthes, that I will give you Galathea within a few dayes, or ele I will loe my life. Upon this the quetion grew, whether he hould make Galathea come unto him, or he go unto her; at lat it was concluded better for him to go unto her, becaue in making her come into the Temple it was to be feared, let his tricks in opening and hutting the doors, might ome way or other micarry or be dicovered, and then the whole plot was poiled: beides, thoe things that are taken for wonders at the firt, and admired, do grow tale by often uing, and corned: Moreover, ince this opening and hutting is believed to be the Act of God, it will be thought trange that this God can do nothing but till one and the ame things. But by going to the Palace, all thee things are not to be expected, and nothing is to be done but talking with her. Upon this they parted full of hopes to arrive ere long at their deired ends.

But Polemas who was a man of a harp wit, and a ound judgment, and a pirit well'd with ambition, although he eemed to rely wholy upon the skil of Climanthes, yet he neglected nothing which might bring his enterprie to pas; and though he had ome hopes in the ubtilty of this fellow, yet he followed his other buines very cloe, o that if the ubtilty of the one failed, the force of the other might effect it. Beides the Souldiers of that Province, he had entertained many others, both within and without the State: He had made himelf mater of all the trong places, bridges, and paes; and not to do any thing at random, there was neither King nor Prince his Neighbour, with whom he had not cloe intelligence, and promie of aitance in cae of need; he provided himelf of a vat Magazine of Arms, and all manner of Amunition. And becaue the whole management of all thee correpondencies, and the whole enterprie reted upon himelf, he made choie of four men
