whom he imployed in things particular: thee four confidents whom he relied upon, were the four pillars of all his hopes and fortune; the name of the one was Pelidontes, unto whom he committed the charge of his Cavalry: another was called Argonides, unto whom he committed his Infantry; Litrandes had the command of the Artillery, and Engines; and Ligonias of the Amunition and victual. Thee four were acquainted with the deign of Polemas, and had long ince contracted a league, and linked their fortunes and lives together. As oon as Climanthes was gone, Polemas called for them, and asked them particularly, how many men he might build upon, if within the compas of eight or ten dayes he hould have occaion to imploy them? Pelidontes promied him fifteen hundred hore, and beides all the Inhabitants of the Country, two thouand trangers: Argonides promied twelve thouand Pikes, Archers, Slingers, and Cros-bows, and ix thouand trangers: Ligonias promied victual for four months: and Litrandes promied as many Arms of all orts as they hould need: now my friends, aid he and embraced them, my hopes are all in you; I do wholly rely upon you, and know that you will have as great a care of my buines, as I my elf can have; perhaps we hall not tand in need of all thee preparations, I hope Heaven will bring our enterprie to pas by fair means, and not by force. I deire it may be o, as well for the good of the State, as becaue that way eems every way the better. However, all preparations mot go forward, for I am reolved, within eight dayes to be either Caar or nothing; I beeech you therefore, and conjure you to have a great care of every thing under your particular charges, that they may be in readines when we hall tand in need of them. Thus with abundance of good language, and a thouand large promies, they parted; and hoped to ee the day when he hould be able to make them all good.

But whilt the mind of Polemas thus boyled over with ambition, and the Country was ready to break out into a flame: Love till boyled as fat as ambition, for it gave no ret unto Celadon whom Leonide left in the habit of Alexis, and in the houe of Atrea; who with all her Companions could not know him to be Celadon, o well was he diguied: But the wonder is, that neither Licidas, nor any of his neeret kindred or intimate friends hould have the leat upition of him; and that was the reaon why Phoceon, when Adamas brought her into his houe, did lodg her in the Chamber where Atrea was wont to lie: and indeed that Fair Shepherdes and her Companion Phillis, when Leonide was gone unto Marelles, did endeavour to leep, that they might let this diguied Druide take ome ret, whom they uppoed to be not well. But this new, or indeed old affection renewed, which Atrea bore unto this Shepherd, believing him a woman, and her reolution to follow her unto Carnutes, and conecrate the remainder of her dayes unto Tautates, did o poee her mind, that he could not entertain any thought or imagination, but what proceeded from them and that deire. Phillis on the other ide, who knew how the Fair and Wie Diana was perplexed ever ince the ubtile Laonices invention againt Sylvander, he bad deffiance unto any ret till he went unto her to comfort her in her grief, knowing very well by ad experience, what it was to be troubled with the panges of jealouie. Celadon who lay in the ame Chamber with thee Fair Shepherdees, had his enquietudes as well as they, and took as little ret; for calling into his memory how Atrea had formerly appointed him never to ee her until by her command; when he conidered his reolution to oberve this ordinance mot religiouly, and thought upon the reaons which the wie Adamas ued to make him quit that olitary kind of life, which he had begun when he reflected upon the artifice which Leonide and the Druide ued to bring him, not only into his own Town, and amongt his kindred, but alo into the very houe of Atrea, and leave him alone with her; thee thoughts did o imbroyl the imagination of this poor Shepherd, that he knew not what Councel, or what reolution to take; for though he had the ame thoughts in his mind before, yet the everal reaon and arguments of the Nymph, and the Druide, did help him to diget them; but now when he was all alone, he thought himelf urrounded with a thouand dangers, and without all humane help or comfort. He conidered that now he was amongt abundance of his familiar and intimate acquaintance, and that it was a thing almot impoible, to hide himelf long from them: and though the prudence of the great Druide Adamas, who
did acknowledge him for his Daughter, did cat a mit before the eyes of thoe that were the mot clear ighted, and much authorize his diguie; yet he knew very well, that thoe eyes which he was to deceive, were o quick ighted, that if any of his actions or words hould betray him, he was ure his diimulation would be immediately dicovered: Upon this conideration, he bethought himelf how prudently ignorant he was to eem of knowing any thing which related unto the quality of a Shepherd, how imple he was to eem in their way of life, their exercies, and how unacquainted he was to be with all his friends, kinred, acquaintances, and places, he thought this a task impoible to be undertaken; and though he did all he could, yet the face of Alexis was o very like unto that of Celadon, all her words, actions, and getures were o reemblant unto that uppoed lot Shepherd, as doubtles he hould be known in pite of all his diimulations and diguiements. But his hardet task was, to rule and check a mot domineering paion, which amidt his greatet felicities, would not give his oul leave to enjoy any full contentment. How oft did he command his tongue and ha • ds not to take too much liberty unto themelves, let they hould betray himelf to be Celadon? How oft did he turn away his eye from many Beauties which under the notion of Alexis were permitted unto him; and all, let his too much curioity hould bring him into upicion.

After all thee coniderations had long embroyled his mind, and the more he thought upon them, the more Hydras of difficulties he found, the bet counel he could think upon, was, to reolve to tay in that place as little as he could, knowing it to be a thing impoible to tay, and not be known, and that the uret foot may omtimes tumble; but this reolution he thought to be as full of difficulties in the execution, and therefore he reolved to tay till in that place: Upon which he began to think how he hould employ himelf; and he conceived that he could no way better pend his time, then in till engaging that Shepherdes unto a tronger league of amity, thinking very rationally, that if he hould afterwards come to know him, he would not o oon conent unto a econd Banihment. And becaue he knew that we are much led by the examples of thoe whom we eteem, and hall after them do thoe things which otherwie we hould never conent unto, he intended to expres a love unto her; not uch a kinde of love as one woman ueth to expres unto another, but uch a one as Celadon was wont to expres unto Astrea, and thus by his example to draw her unto the like affection, and o inenibly to bring her from Friendhip unto Love. But when he was to put this thought in execution, he found abundance of more difficulty in acting, then in propounding it; it being a hard matter to expres love unto that Shepherdes, and not make her to upect it to be more then became a Virgin Druide.

This chaos and confuion of difficulties did o ditemper him, that he could not chue but igh very oft, and o loud, that the two Shepherdees could not chue but hear him; for they did not leep, only eemed as if they did, becaue they would not diturb the ret of Alexis. But hearing her to igh o exceedingly, and knowing her to be awake, Atrea feared, that though he aid that he eemed ick, only as a colour for taying with her, yet I ay he feared let ome real ditemper hould be the caue of o many ighs. This doubt caued her to turn towards Phillis, whom he knew was awake: Siter (aid he in as low a voice as he could) do you not hear Alexis igh? I am afraid that he is wore then he will tell unto us. I heard her igh everal times (aid Phillis) and I had the ame conceipt, but me-thought they were ighs of one that was rather full of cares, then of one that was ick: For ighs of a ick peron are fetched from the breat with more violence, and thoe which I hear, are but ilent whipering ighs, uch as proceed from paion and ditemper of mind. I think, aid Atrea, that we hould do well if we diverted her from uch ad thoughts, and yet if he be aleep, we hould not waken her. Certainly, aid Phillis, he is not aleep, for he has turned her elf everal times, but perhaps he is ilent upon the ame reaon that we are, I mean, let we hould diturb each other. Atrea being very impatient to ee whether it was o, he opened her curtain and peeped out; but he could not do it o oftly, but Alexis oberved her, who for all his confued thoughts, had his eye and his heart towards her, and who had not lain o long in bed, but only to make Phillis believe her icknes was real. Astrea perceiving that
Alexis was not aleep, Madam (aid he unto her) we are much afraid you are very ill, for we have heard you complain very much ince Leonide wakened you. I thank you heartily, anwered Alexis, for your care of me, which were I wore then I am, would make me well again: yet truly I am not very well, and therefore I deire not to tir out of the chamber this morning, but will try whether a little head-ach will be cured with a little ret. Madam, aid Phillis, I have heard ay that leep is the bet remedy againt that dieae. I have tryed to leep ince Leonide went, replied Alexis but I could not perwade my eyes together, becaue many odd thoughts came into my mind, o as I think the bet way will be to divert it by dicoure; for I have heard ay, that pain will away when it is leat thought upon. What then hall we do, aid Atrea, to make you forget your pain? I deire, anwered Alexis, that you will come and dres your elves by me, and pas away the time with your weet dicoure. Madam (aid Atrea) we will do any thing in the world to obey you: upon this riing out of bed, he put on her Gown: But Alexis remembring that he promied to dres her elf that day in the habit of a Druide, he claimed her promie. Sweetheart (aid he unto her) if you will make good your promie, and aume the habit of a Druide this day, it would be a very great content unto me. Oh Madam, anwered he, you would never pardon me, if I hould commit o gros a crime: Indeed it is too much preumption for a illy Shepherdes. It may be o, replied Alexis, for a illy Shepherdes, but not for uch a Shepherdes as Atrea is, whoe merits, beauty, and perfections does trancend all the Druides that I do know; and therefore if you will oblige me, lay all uch coniderations aide: for the love of you I was a Shepherdes, and will be o as long as you pleae; why then for the love of me hould not you as well become a Druide: Come, come, continued he, Were I but dret, I would not put you to the trouble of coming hither, but ince I am in bed, I beeech you weet-heart come hither, and let me help to dres you. The Shepherdes in obedience to this command, went to Alexis, who • aiing her elf in the bed, and cloing her mock let her Breats hould be dicovered, did receive her with uch ravihment of joy, as it was well Phillis was on the other ide of the bed dreing her elf, for it was to be feared that had he een them, he would have entred into ome upition: and though Atrea was ahamed of it, yet uch carees were now grown o accutomed, that he took all in good part.

Celadon had a good will to continue his carees longer, but ome coniderations moved him to give over ooner then he had a mind, and helping her to dres her elf, her Breats, and almot every part of her fair Body was open to his eye, which being ravihed at the ight of o many trancendent perfections, he deired that Celadon were another Argus, full of eyes, that he might the better contemplate all thoe excellencies: His wonder at them o took up his mind, that not knowing what he did, he did and undid every thing about the dreing of her, above three or four times; at which Atrea, who did not oberve from whence the fault proceeded, could not chue but mile, and reward his erroneous pains with many carees, which the timorous Druide durt hardly repay, let his actions hould dicover more then became Alexis, o as it may be aid, that Love was mot paring, when it was mot prodigal of its favours.

Phillis in the mean time was dreing her elf as fat as he could; and becaue he did not ue much art in trimming up her elf, he was ready before Alexis had got on Atreas Gown; at which he miled, and aid unto them, If you be as long about all the ret as this you have done, Atrea will be ready about the time when others are going to Bed. No matter for time, Siter, aid Atrea, for it cannot be better pent then in diverting the pain of the fair Alexis. If that be your Deigne, replyed he, it is well employed; but if it be only to pas away the time with that fair Druide, I know a better diverion then yours; and if you will give me leave, I will go and fetch one that will econd me, and help out better then I can do: Beides Siter, you know that if neither of us go unto her upon this occaion, we hall be exceedingly to blame. Of whom do you peak, aid Alexis, if I be not troubleome in asking the quetion. Alas Madam, replyed Atrea, it is we that are troubleome in talking of uch things before you; for indeed 'tis too much pains for you to hear our trivial affairs: Then turning towards Phillis, Go iter (continued he)
and aure her we all believe that all which is reported is fale. Phillis then as he went away, I need not ask (aid he) where I hall find you at my return, ince it is not likely you will tir out of this chamber. If the ditemper of the fair Alexis would give her leave to tir out, anwered Atrea, I believe you might find us in the Grove of Hazles ooner then in any other place, but I believe you will find us here at your return.

Upon this Phillis went out of the chamber, and Alexis with a miling countenance aid unto Atrea, Do not think that the Grove of Hazles does delight me more then any other place where the fair Atrea is; for where he is not, no place is pleaing unto me: It befits me Madam, anwered Atrea, to ue the ame words, ince I have no contentment but in your preence, nor no ambition but in the honour of your favour, which I deire above all the world. Atrea aid Alexis, you need not deire that which you do mot entirely poes. Indeed Madam, replyed Atrea, I cannot wih for any addition unto my happines, further then the continuance of it; nor deire any more, but to employ all the ret of my days in doing you ervice, and never be abent from you: I have already entreated the Nymph Leonide to favour me with her credit and advice in order thereunto; and though he urged many great obtacles unto me, yet I account them but trifles in comparion of that happines which I hould have in it: As for the contrariety of my Parents, which he thinks o great an impediment unto my deired happines, ince it hath pleaed heaven to take from me my Father and my Mother, what Parent have I that has any dominion over my Will, or can hinder me from dedicating my elf unto that coure which the very Laws of Nature do oblige all Humanes unto? Upon this ground I do but laugh at the pretenions of Calidon, who thinks me his own already, becaue my uncle Phocion would have me marry him; for I know well enough how far the obedience and repect which I owe unto him does extend: I know him to be o wie and dicreet a peron, that he will not look for any more obervance then I pay unto him: But Madam, my fears and my doubts arie not from that ide; the great difficulty is to obtain your favour, and the conent of the ancient Druides, to be received amongt the Virgins of Carnutes, that o I may never be abent from you: This Madam, is the humble petition of your devoted creature, which I beg with all the humble and mot affectionate upplications I am able to expres. Fair Shepherdes (anwered Alexis) I cannot thank you enough for all your affectionate expreions of good will towards me, and I have uch an eteem of it, as I do wih with as much zeal as poibly you can, that we may never part as long as we live; and therefore be aured it hall be long only of your elf, if ever we eparate: But my fear is, that when I tell you what is to be done, your mind will change, and your deign alter. Oh Madam cried out Atrea, I beeech you wrong me not o far, as to have uch a thought. But on the contrary, be mot certainly aur'd, that both in life and death this reolution will continue in me. I am apt to believe (anwered Alexis) any thing that you hall ay, epecially a thing which is o advantagious unto my elf, and o utable to my deires; believe it therefore that I will do all I can to atisfie your deires. Know Shepherdes that there is no great difficulty in bringing your deire to pas, if you will your elf; and in this I am contrary to the opinion of Leonide. Thee two things, I hall only require from you; the one is, that you do love me, as well as I do you: and I hall tell you the other, when I ee you have effected this firt propoition. Atrea, with a miling look, kied the hand of Alexis, by way of thanks: If your econd propoition (aid he) be no harder then your firt, you have good reaon to ay Madam, that there is no great difficulty in the matter. For I beeech you, give me leave to wear, that if I do not Love the Fair Alexis far above my own elf, nay better then ever any peron loved another, then let the Gods deny me the honour of your favour, and blat all my hopes of any contentment: Oh Atrea, replied Alexis, do you think for all this, that you love me more then I Love you? Oh Madam, anwered Atrea, I cannot think my elf worthy of o much affection from you; but hould think my elf infinitely happy if I were ure that mine to you were accepted: Fairet Shepherdes, anwered Alexis, be aured that never Love did equal mine unto you; and in this, I cannot be deceived as you may, becaue I know what I ay by experience; for I think I told you, how
formerly I did Love one of my fellow Virgins, and I am confident it was impoible for any humane to equal my affection to her; but when I do compare my affection unto her, and my affection unto you together, I find that they hold no comparion, for mine unto you do infinitely trancend that unto her. Whereas you on the contrary, who never Loved any, you may eaily be mitaken, and think your Love great when it is not o, for you want experience. Madam, anwered Atrea, the dipute betwixt us is of uch a nature, that the victory is prejudicial to the Conqueror; and the conquered is victorious: and yet I will not throw away my Arms upon very eaie terms, though I will yeild unto you in what you pleae, but it would be a mot extream hame unto me, if I hould let you outtrip me in affection as you do in merit. Give me leave Madam therefore to tell you, that I began to Love when I was even in my Cradle, and have continued that affection o contantly, that no difficulties, no time, no abences, no commands of thoe that had the dipoe of me, nor any thing under Heaven could divert me from it, but death only: and yet I wear, and wear mot truly, that I do Love you better then ever I loved any; and though this be but a proud word to iue from the mouth of a poor Shepherdes, yet give me leave to pronounce it, and ay again, that though others may bear a greater repect, yet never any more Love and more Affection, then Atrea unto the Fair Alexis. Upon this, they embraced each other with uch mutual expreions of Love, that if Alexis durt, but have aid I am Celadon, nothing could have made them both more happy in each other. But the feares of this Druide, did make her relih all thee weet imbraces with a kind of bitter amongt them, becaue he till feared let her raptures of joy hould make her dicover her elf; and therefore he withdrew her elf a little with a bluhing collour which came into her cheeks; and after he had tood a while ilent, he uttered thee words with uch a modet hamefatnes, that if any of her actions had raied any doubts of what he deired to hide, it was enough to clear them all. But fairet Shepherdes (aid he unto her) I cannot tell, what the violence of my affection to you, may make you think of me, unles yours and your goodnes plead me excue: and yet I do wear unto you by Veta, and all that is acred, that I am o far from any uch affections as many women of my age are apt unto, that I did never love any man: but all my paions were wholly imployed in my love of one woman, whom truly I did love as much as I was then able, though not comparable unto you now; and though perhaps you may laugh at my humour, yet I mut tell you, that I took as great delight in kiing and careing of her, as if I had been a man, or he not a woman. And indeed I find the very ame humour to revive in me when I am with you, which I can attribute unto nothing but the exces of my affection which I bear unto you, and which I hould be infinitely orry if it were dipleaing or troubleome unto you: Atrea, hewing by her countenance, how well he was pleaed with thee expreions, did return this anwer; It is my part Madam, to ue the ame excues unto you, ince I have more reaon to fear being troubleome unto you, by following the inclination of my affection too far: I mut needs confes Madam, that I did Love a Shepherd; but let me tell you truly, that I was never more joyed at any tetimonies of his good will unto me, then I am of yours.

Oh Heaven! (aid Alexis) how much am I obliged unto it, and you, for this affection: my joyes and my atisfaction is compleat. But Fairet Shepherdes (aid he) hall we live together, in the ame freedom and affection when we are together in private, that we do now? I ay in private; for it is fit to be more reerved before other Shepherds and Shepherdees, leat we hould give occaion to upect us of omthing which may be diadvantagious unto us. How? Madam, (aid Astrea) do you ask me this quetion? Nay, may you not better ask whether I hould not die for orrow, if you hould forbid me? But Madam, ince you ee I have oberved your firt command, I beeech you what is the other? That by obeying it alo, I may call my elf the wot happy woman alive. Fairet Shepherdes, (anwered Alexis) it is not yet time to tell it; but ince I ee you are deirous to know it, I promie you, that when I think it fitting that you hould know it, I will not put you to the trouble of asking me. In the mean time, to try whether this kind of life will be as agreeable unto us as we imagine, let us begin to live together as we mut do all
the ret of our dayes; I mean, with that honet freedom and liberty that two perfect Lovers ought to ue unto each other. In the firt place I beeech you, let us leave off in our dicoure, thee terms of Madam, and Druide, and begin to be free and familiar, as we mut for ever be. Madam, (aid Atrea) in what place oever I be, and of what quality oever I am, I will alwayes render unto you, thoe repects which I am bound to pay; that will not be any hindrance to thoe contentments which I hope for from you, but rather further them by keeping my elf within the terms of my duty. You are mitaken, anwered Alexis, and though you can have o much power over your elf, yet I cannot; for I am not able to endure that one whom I take to be my other elf, hould ue uch words as peak any difference betwixt us: and if the principal conequence of Love be union, why hould we allow uch Tyrannies diguied, under the names of repect, or civility, or duty, to hinder that perfect union of wills, which ought to be betwixt us? I do ordain therefore that Atrea hall be Alexis, and Alexis hall be Atrea, and that we banih from amongt us, not only all words, but alo all manner of actions that may put any difference between us, and you hall ee that when we have lived long in this mutual freedom and liberty, Love wil double and till encreae. Then Madam, replied Atrea, I beeech you let it be under the notion of a command, that my obedience unto it may excue the fault which I hall commit in it. If that be all (anwered Alexis) to atisfie you, I do command it, with a promie that I will not repent it as long as I live. And becaue it is fit we conform our elves unto the cutoms of thoe with whom we are to live: know therefore Shepherdes that it is the cutom of the Druides at Carnutes, not to call themelves by their proper names, but by others, which their affection unto one another makes them invent; and their new names are called amongt them, Alliances, as much as to ay that they are Allied and obliged by thoe names unto more Affection and Love. I conceive it requiite we do the like as well to confirm our Loves, as to let thoe Druides ee when we come amongt them, that we do not only know their cutoms, but mot religiouly oberve them: now I cannot think of any which are fitter for us then the names of Mitris and Servant, as well becaue they are names not ordinary amongt them, as becaue me thinks they ound well betwixt you and me. I do accept of this honour, aid Atrea, with a thouand thanks, and with a protetation and vow unto the Goddes Vesta, that for ever, not only in name but in deed I will take you for my Mitris, and profes my elf your ervant. Alexis miled at this, I had rather, aid he, that you would take the name of Mitris, and let me have that of ervant: but ince you have made your choie, I am contented: Now Servant (continued he) give me your hand, in tetimony that you accept of this name, and that you will never break this alliance of Love which we now make; and I wear by the Great God of Love, who is the God that is adored at Carnutes, that I will eternally live with you as with the only peron whom I perfectly Love, and of whom only I deire to be Loved in the like manner. Then Atrea aid, I do not only give my hand, but both hands, nay more, my heart and my oul, in tetimony, that I will love you and you only, conecrating and dedicating my elf, my deires, my affections, and all that is mine unto you: and if ever I fail in the obervance of this promie, or ever tain that honourable Name which I have received, let me be abhorred by Heaven and Earth, and all that is in them. Upon this they both embraced and kied each other, as an aurance of what they had promied; and carraed themelves with o much affection as if they would never have ended.

In the mean time Phillis went unto Diana, thinking to find her in bed, but that Shepherdes was o very ill pleaed, that he could not ret o long; for he was up long before, and after he had put all things into order in her little houe, he went out with her flock, and without any other company but her own thoughts. By fortune, he came unto the ame place upon the Banks of Lignon, when the accident of Celadon did happen, when the jealouie of Atrea made him throw himelf into the River. After he had eated her elf, and long looked upon the current of the water, without any other action which hewed life, but only ighing; at lat, as if he had revived out of a profound Lethargy, and ending forth a deep igh. Thus (aid he) does all things mortal, run into the Gulf of Oblivion: then topping
a while, he broke out thus. This River is not the ame water it was yeterday, for it glides away, and freh comes in the room of it; nay I my elf am not the ame Diana that I was when I came hither: time by an uncontrollable power runs on and drives all before it. The Sun it elf, which is the meaure of time as all things in the univere is, is hurried on by time, and is not the ame it was when I began to peak: why then Diana houldet thou think an ordinary thing to be trange and extraordinary? Every thing changes, and rechanges again: If it be a generall Law amongt all things, that nature produceth to change, why houldt thou wonder that one particular peron hould do o? It is very unreaonable to oberve it in thy elf, and not allow it in another: cant thou ay that it is not thy elf which doth change, but art the ame thou wert wont to be? Ah fond flatterer of thy elf, remember what thou wert before Fiiander aw thee, what operation his Courthip had upon thee? and how thou didt behave thy elf after his deplorable los. Conider thy humour as it was when Sylvander, or rather that deceive, began firt unluckily to look upon thee: How wat thou won by his counterfet affection? And how dot thou find thy elf now after a knowledg of his treaon? Needs mut thou confes, that as the humours, complexions, and tempers, do change once every even yeers; thine changes ofter, and not only in even yeers, for a year is an age unto thee, but in a month, in a week, in an hour, nay even in a munite.

This thought touched her to the quick; for never having this opinion of her elf before, yet finding it now to be true, he was o atonihed at it, that he was not able to utter one word. At the lat, rouing her elf up, as out of a dead leep, he began again thus: Oh Heavens! Oh Earth! art thou not changed? Yes yes, Diana, and o that if thou dot but look well upon thy elf, thou wilt hardly know thy elf, thou wilt not find any thing of the firt Diana in thee, but only the very Name. Anwer me, I pray thee to thee quetions; how didt thou heretofore abhor the flatteries of men, what credit wat thou wont to give unto their upple language? Hat thou quite lot the memory of all thoe wie intructions and good Counels thou wert wont to give thy companions? Or dot thou think that thy elf does not need them as much as they? Ah Diana! do not deceive thy elf, but confes, that thou art now much different from what thou wert wont to be. Recollect thy elf a little better, and tell me; dot thou not remember the time when thou wert the firt Diana, and when all that this coening Shepherd either aid or did, was indifferent unto thee? And why hould thou now, if thou art the ame Diana, be angry at this loving Madonthe, at his following her, and at his going with her, whether he would or no? If thee things do vex thee, then confes that thou art not the ame Diana; and if thou dot deny it, will not thy own concience accue thee? Well, (aid he) if I be not the ame Diana I was wont to be, then what am I become now? Quite contrary (anwered he) to that Diana I was wont to be: Oh Heavens! what a deplorable alteration is this? How much better and more honourable had it been for me to have dyed in the dayes of the firt Diana, then have lived to ee this alteration?

When he was in the height of her dipleaure againt her elf, he was diverted by the coming of ome Shepherds and Shepherdees, which talked and diputed amongt themelves very vehemently; and though he was very buie in her own perplexed thoughts, yet they making a great noie, and he hearing them a far off, he had time enough to withdraw her elf uneen, behind a great Buh, which grew cloe to the way; which he did with intention to let them pas on, and then to return unto the place again, and continue on thoe thoughts which they had interrupted; but he was diappointed; for they, as if it was upon ome expres deign, went traight to the place from whence Diana came, and eated themelves upon the bank, as if they intended to tay there a long time: but he fearing to be dicovered, and perhaps contrained to remain with them, according to the Laws of civility, which were mot Religiouly oberved about the banks of Lignon, he thought the bet way was to let them enter into dicoure, and when they were mot earnet and attentive unto each other, then he to teal away uneen. Then peeping through the Buh, he aw them itting in a round figure, and that they whoe faces were towards her, were Shepherds and Shepherdees, which were not altogether unknown
unto her, having formerly een them at their general Solemnities and Sacrifices. Then he began to wonder more why they hould come directly to that place, and tay there as if it was upon ome premeditated deign; at lat he heard one Shepherd amongt them, begin thus: Oh Delphire, you are a mot partial and evere Judge, in condemning a peron without ever hearing what he can ay for himelf. I ee Thaumantes (anwered the Shepherdes) that you take more pains in pumping for excues and gloes unto your fale reaons, then I have done to convince and prove them fale: If the Gods, replied the Shepherd, had een your oul unbyaed, and fit to judge the difference betwixt us, they would not have appointed us to come and look for a Judge in this place. The Gods, replied the Shepherdes, are pleaed that the laudable actions of men hould be divulged and recompenced, and likewie their faults made publique and punihed. If punihments and recompences (replied he) be to be expected from their hands. Oh Delphire, I begin to pitty you, for you are never able to endure the punihments that are due unto your cruelty: and I know not how my heart, which is o much unaccutomed unto any happines, will be able to receive that blis and reward of my fidelity and affection. If we do meet with a jut Judge, anwered the Shepherdes and miled, I believe you will not o much pity as envy me: But Thaumantes, let us leave off this dicoure, I ee you ue it only to pleae ome that are in the company, but aure your elf, there is none that has a ound judgment will approve of it. I know, replied the Shepherd, that nothing angers a peron who is in the wrong, more, then to hear that tring touched upon, becaue it puts them in mind of the injury they do: but he that has Jutice on his ide, cannot be ilent at the injutice which is done him: yet ince you command me to be ilent, I will obey; yet I hope you will give me leave to ing: o not taying for her anwer, and having a very good voice, he began to ing a very invective and bitter ong, which upbraided her with cruelty and injutice. As oon as he had done, Delphire aid unto him; there needs no other tetimony of your change then this which you have given me, in contemning my commands which formerly, for your life your durt not have done: for inging and peaking are crimes alike, if what is forbidden be pronounced. The Shepherd anwered not a word, but hrugged his houlders and made a ign that his tongue was tyed: and this gave occaion unto another Shepherd in the company, to peak for him: This, aid he, is excee of cruelty; and very hard that a man may not o much as complain of his torment. That I mut confes is very hard, anwered the Shepherdes, but you mut alo confes with me on the other ide, that to hear a man baul and keep a coyl when he has no caue, is excee of patience. But I beeech you, replied he, if you will not uffer Thaumantes to peak, upon what deign did you come unto this place? We came hither, replied he, not to dipute and wrangle as we have done, but to ee if we could find that Judg which the Oracle has promied we hould. Are you ure replied he, that this is the place where you are to expect this Judge: No quetion but it is, anwered Delphire, for it is named, and we are told that this is the place where Celadon fell into the water. There is not one in all the neighbour-hood, who does not know it as a place obervable for everal diaterous accidents: and as for our Judge, we cannot be mitaken: for the Oracle is this:

lg.head: The Oracle.
lg.l: WHere Celadon they ay did find a grave,
There you, a jut and prudent judge hall have,
Who though uneen hall ee you, and hall hear
Your difference, and do you right, ne'er fear.

div.p:
This, replied the Shepherd, is an Oracle very obcure; for if you do not ee the party who is to be your Judge, how hould you ever know who he is: Nay more, aid Delphire, the Oracle ays, he hall hear us though we do not ee him: but certain it is, it mut be o, for the Gods have aid it, and we are bound upon pain of
diobedience to believe it, and therefore we mut expect he will make it manifet unto us. But I beeech you aid the Shepherd, how hould this Judge hear the difference ince he is not here? And how hould you tell it unto him? Thee difficulties (anwered Delphire) mut be reolved by the God that gave the Oracle.

Diana who was all the while behind the Buh, heard all this dicoure; and looking through the leaves, he knew all the Shepherds and Shepherdees, though he had no great familiarity with them; for they were neighbours, and dwelt upon the banks of Lignon towards the Mountains of Rochfort and Chevieres: and he had often een them at the publique Sacrifices of Mileto, and other aemblies: he remembred alo the high eteem which every one had of the beauty of Delphire, and merit of Thaumantes, and o was not altogether ignorant of the amity that was between them, becaue they did not offer to hide their affections. But eeing now uch a divorce betwixt them, he could not chue but wonder, and yet her wonder ceaed, when he conidered what occaion he had to complain againt Sylvander. When he heard the Oracle, he concluded that certainly it was he whom the Gods had choen to be their Judge, at which he was much dipleaed; for the ill humour he was in, made her deirous to hun all company, even of her own companions. Thus eeing her elf forced to tay all the morning, and to hear their difference, though it went againt her mind, yet he reolved to obey what the Gods commanded. Therefore he reolved to take little truce with her orrows, and hew her elf, and take upon her the office of their Judge, but to defer her judgement until the next day, hoping that in time he hould overcome her paion, and put her mind in better order. In order therefore unto this reolve, he poke in a loud voice thee words: Trouble your elves no further, Oh Delphire, and Thaumantes; for here is your Judge, whom the Heavens have ordained to determine your difference: upon this, riing from behind the Buh, and triving to hew a well contented countenance, he went unto them, who were all in uch an amazement, that they tood like o many Statues: but when they had looked well upon her, and knew her to be Diana, they broke out into an univeral joy: for there was not one of all the company, who did not know the virtue and merit of that Shepherdes: and Thaumantes was o over joyed to ee uch a Judge, as he fell down upon his knees, and offered to kis her hand; but Diana would not permit him, yet aluted him, and went toward Delphire, who imbraced her as heartily as Thaumantes, who eeing it and eeming to be very envious at it: I am afraid (aid he in a loud voice) he will be as partial in her judgement, as he is in her carees. Diana hearing this, miled and aid; Do not • ear, for I will ballance every thing according to equity, and render unto each one what is due. It is the cutom of thoe (aid Delphire) who have a bad caue, to upect the judgement of the mot jut perons, and corrupt it if they can by their impotures: But Thaumantes, thoe favours which I receive from this fair Shepherdes, are no more due unto me then unto you; and know, that whatoever is freely given out of meer liberality, cannot be claimed as a debt due, and therefore you are to blame in asking any part or hare in thoe favours he is pleaed to confer upon me, ince neither you nor I can pretend unto them as due. To which Thaumantes anwered, it is no wonder, Fair Delphire, that he who has o often troubled you with his angry quetions, hould continue to ask them, ince he has got a habit of them: and it is no wonder, anwered he, that you be denied now, ince you have been o accutomed unto it.

Their dicoure had continued longer, if the ret of the Shepherds and Shepherdees in aluting Diana, had not interrupted them. But when they had all done, Delphire began again; Fair and dicreet Shepherdes, aid he unto Diana, I have often heard ay, that the Graces are never painted alone; to intimate unto us, that the party who confers one, will immediately econd it with another; or perhaps that the party who receives one, may be encouraged to ask more: if it be o, then this Shepherd and I may hope that by what favours you have done unto us, you will add more, which we do mot humbly beg at your hands. Sweet Delphire, anwered Diana, it were a great dicourteie to deny any thing which o fair and o dicreet a Shepherdes as you are, hall ask; and therefore you may aure your elf of any thing within the compas of my power. The Gods (aid Thaumantes) are not like
unto men, for men may give and betow Offices as they pleae, but they cannot confer capacity to exercie them; But when the Gods do give any thing, they give with it all that is requiite and neceary unto it; And therefore, ince it hath pleaed the Gods to make choice of you, fair Diana, to compoe all thoe ditempers which have fallen out betwixt us, and which without you can never be reconciled, it is not to be doubted but that they have endued you with widom, power, and capacity to effect it. Thaumantes (anwered Diana) If I had been asked who I thought lived together in mot tranquility and contentment, I hould have anwered Delphire and Thaumantes; and I do exceedingly wonder to hear you ay that you eek for any reconcilements and compoures; But ince it is o, and ince the Gods have made choice of me to that end, I will obey them in the execution of their Ordinances, and as their Intrument, who though of my elf les capable, yet by their aitance, may render them the glory that is due unto them. Every one (replied Delphire) are mitaken as you are, in their opinions of this Shepherds and my happines, but ince you are pleaed to undertake the office of our Judge, we beeech you to hear what we can ay for our elves, and by your widom and judgement recover us out of that gulf of dicontent and inquietude wherein we are plunged. That which you do ask as a favour, aid Diana, I do think my elf obliged to pay as a due debt, as being enjoyned unto it by the Ordinance of the Gods, and prompted by mine own natural inclination to erve you: But I hall deire one favour from you both, which if granted, I hall take as a very great one; which is, that you will defer the whole buines until to morrow, at the ame hour and place; for I am obliged to do a piece of ervice unto a very dear friend, which cannot be delayed without much prejudice and inconvenience unto her. Unto which Delphire replied, Fair and Dicreet Shepherdes, we are obliged unto whatoever you hall deire or command, and therefore you may take that leave which out of your weetnes you are pleaed to ask of us, for you have a mot full and abolute authority over us. Since you are o well contented, replied Diana, I will go unto the place where neceity calls me unto, being very orry to part from uch good company, and promiing to be here to morrow at this place, and about this time: Upon this he took her leave of them, and went away as fat as he could, to hew that her buines was urgent.

Phillis on the other ide not finding her at home, he went to eek her in uch places as he ued mot to drive her Flock: But as Fortune was, he made choice of a place more retired that day, purpoely becaue he deired not to be een by any: o that Phillis, after he had ought for her in everal places, he came at lat to the great Meddow, and at the one end of it he epied ome Shepherdees, amongt whom he thought he aw Diana, but when he was come neerer, he found her elf mitaken; and that they were the three trangers, who came from the coats of Arar, I mean Florice, Cercinea, and Palinice: And becaue he aw them talking very affectionately unto each other, and would not tell any the caue of their coming into this Country, he thought that perhaps he hould learn omthing if uneen he could hear what they aid. This curioity caued her to creep from Buh to Buh, till he came o neer, that he could hear Florice ay, The truth is, I begin to doubt that the Oracle which caued us to come into this Country of Forrets, will either deceive us, or ele thoe that did interpret it unto us are themelves deceived: for we have been o long here to no purpoe, that it eems the Gods have either forgotten us, or ele laugh at us for undertanding them no better. For my part, aid Cercinea, I am the younget, and ubmitted my elf to the conduct of you both; if I have failed, the fault is Palinices, unto whom I wholly referred my elf; o as without diving into any deep myteries, I undertood the Oracle as he did interpret it unto me. I am ure anwered Palinice, that I did not deceive either of you; for you heard the Oracle which we received from the Temple of Venus: and as for the interpretation of it, I did not lye in a illable, but told you truly, as the old Druide told me. Since it is o replyed Cercinea, we mut not make too much hate away, and though the time be long, yet it is no longer here then upon the Banks of Arar, for the weet converation of the dicreet Shepherdees of Lignon, is as pleaing as any company we can find in any other place. I mut confes, aid Florice, that the company of Atrea, Diana, and Phillis is very weet and pleaing, and that here is
many pretty innocent patimes which are utable unto their honet implicity: but I mut tell you, that they are fitter for uch inferiour pirits as theirs are, then for us, who are accutomed unto a higher and more noble train; and to tell you truly, this kind of life begins to be very irkome unto me, o as if I tay here a little longer, I hall throw away my Sheep-hook and my Scrip. I know not why you hould o much dilike it (replied Cercinea) but me-thinks there is nothing in Cities which equals the liberty and freedom of thee Villages. Here (aid Florice) is nothing to be een but Sheep and Hares, and Shepherds and Shepherdees. Tell me no more of Shepherds and Shepherdees, anwered Cercinea, but find me out uch another Wit as Sylvander's amongt all your great Cities and Towns; or a Woman comparable unto either Atrea, Diana, or Phillis, either in beauty, wit, or dicretion: I mention none of the ret, bur do admire their civility and weet converation; and I do abominate all the contraints, tricks, and diimulations of Cities. I ee (aid Florice) that you are like thoe Sorcerers, who having ued ome charm upon the skin of a Wolf, do no ooner put it upon them, but they preently participate of their nature; for this habit of a Shepherd which you wear, has infued the wit and courage of a Shepherdes into you: But well Cercinea, be you a Shepherdes as long as you pleae; but for my part, I deire to be amongt thoe of my own quality, and in my own Country: For to tell you truly, I am mot delighted in eeing a Cavalier bravely Arm'd and Mounted, and breaking his Lance handomly: But what pitiful port is it to ee two Shepherds run for a Garland of Field-Flowers? To be hort, the Purple and Scarlet pleaeth my eye better then the Ruet and Gray; Sattin is ofter then Wool; and I love to be amongt my equals. Unto uch as ayme at their contentment, aid Cercinea, Grandeur, and uch vanities as you peak of, are not the way unto it: and uch as conider things as indeed they are, not embracing haddows for ubtances, will mot certainly condemn them; the gliter of gold, and ilver, and purple, which dazles o much the eye, are not half o pleaing as a green Field diapred with Flowers; What needs the Body more then uch a cover as will defend it from the injury of wind and weather? Provided uch a Suit be fit and handomly made, it is better then all the gaudery of Gold, which does but beguil the eys of thoe who are not able to look what is in the inide of uch a Suit: As for a comparion between the feats of Chivalry, and the harmles exercies of Shepherds, it mut needs be confeed the one is all blood, violence, injury and murder, and the other is all innocency, and gives no offence unto any; the one comes near the nature of Bears, Tigers, and Lions, and the other of men: And as for the reproach which you put upon me for loving the habit of Shepherdees, I ay that I wih I were exempt from all thoe turbulencies and cares which does torment thoe that do live in your perpetual confuion.

She would have continued on, if Palinice had not interrupted; It is not our buines (aid he) to dipute which of thee two Lives is the happier, but whether we hould tay any longer here to ee the fulfilling of the Oracle which ent us hither, I conceive it good for us to perue it again, and conider eriouly upon the words of it: Upon this he put her hand into her Scrip, and pulled out a paper, in which he read thee words.

lg.head: The Oracle.
lg.l: AGaint the paines which all you three endure,
In Forrets you hall find a certain cure:
One that was dead, and afterwards hall live,
Unto you all one medicine mut give.
Another medicine you hall have from one,
To whom againt her will, a good is done;
Which he rejected, with her will: 'Tis he,
Not you, by whom the overture mut be.
What he ordains, as if ordain'd by me,
Believ'd, as Oracle, by you mut be.

div.p: Phillis who till now never knew the caue of their voyage, he was very glad that he had found it out, even when he leat thought upon it; for finding them to be very dicreet and virtuous, he and her companions were exceeding deirous of it; not only out of a common curioity, but a will to do them ervice: And this had been impoible to dicover otherwie, becaue thee trangers in obedience to the Oracle durt not reveal it unto any. But Phillis having found it out, he endeavored to remember the Oracle, which he had never done, unles Circenea and Palinice had repeated it everal times, For my part (aid Palanice) I mut needs conclude that we ought to tay here yet a while longer, ince it is certain that the Druide told us, Forrets was the place where we hould meet with our atisfaction, and that our happines mut proceed from three perons, of which, two are hard to be found out; but the goodnes of God is great, ince that which mut intruct us, is o cleerly expreed that we cannot mitake: for (aid he, and I oberve it in the words) when you hall find a peron who hall tell you that God hath appointed you by his Oracle, that a living dead man hall be your Phiitian and Medicine, with a peron unto whom they hall againt her will retore a happines, which he did loe with her will. One of you three upon which the Lot hall fall, mut relate unto her the pain which you endure, and he will appoint you what he conceives bet for you. The wort of all this, is (anwered Florice) the los of time which will eem very tedious. Circenea anwered and miled, that no happines is attained without pains. Your happinee is compleated, replied Florice, for you are of a more Shepherdih humour, then the Shepherdees themelves. I have often heard you ay (anwered Circenea) that it is great widom to be pleaed with any thing that neceity makes inevitable.

Whilt thee Shepherdees were thus diputing amongt themelves, Phillis who had learned as much as he deired to know, did think it bet to teal off uneen; and therefore when he aw them mot eager in their contets, he crept away, and went to eek Diana, who on her ide was not a little perplexed; for as he deigned to eparate her elf from all converation, Fortune would have it o, that which way oever he went, he met with everal encounters; for having quitted her elf of Delphire and Thaumantes, as oon as he was out of their ight, looking for the mot unfrequented place of all the Wood, he had no ooner eated her elf under a hady thicket, but he heard a tranger ing very neer her, inging, and the effect of the ong was, That men are without any amity.

As oon as Diana heard this voice, he had a good mind to go and ee who it was, but hearing her begin to talk unto her elf, he thought it bet to hear what he aid; and he heard her ay thus: What a hard and evere thing it is which Nature hath impoed upon Women, that they mut not only live amongt their enemies, but alo be ubject unto their Tyrannical Dominion? Had he but put a little more trength into our body, we had not been ubject unto that proud and fierce animal, called Man: but why did he not as well ubject this man, unto an Ox or an Hore,
which are tronger then he, as he is tronger then us? For if weaknes be the caue of our ubjection, why hould not they be ubject unto them? Nay, upon the ame reaon, why hould not the weaknes of their minds ubject them unto our bodies? For the trength of their judgements cannot be equal unto the trength of our bodies. Is it not an infallible argument of a weak judgement, to deire a thing mot paionately, and mediately not to deire it? Which is he amongt men, that has not deceived her that truted in him? Shew me the man, who makes it a matter of concience to keep his word, his promies, nay his very oaths and execrations, when he intends to deceive? They think their diloyalty is handomly covered, when they ay, that the Gods will not punih the oaths of perjured Lovers: It is true indeed, they do not punih them immediately upon the very act, but yet they defer it only, becaue they will punih them according to their merits altogether: there is not a man breathing upon the face of the earth, that does not wear and protet, and vow, and yet his intention is quite contrary: their deignes are meer Chimeras, empty clouds; one is no ooner begun, but another econds it, and quite obliterates the firt their promies and their oaths reemble great claps of thunder, whoe noie is no ooner ended, but no more is heard of it: what God is there whom they will not call to witnes? What cure will they not call for upon themelves? And what aurance will they not give, when they would obtain any thing of us? But when the humour of it is pat, or when they have obtained what they deire, who cares for any performances of promie, or fears any cures they called upon themelves? But preently eek out for excues to avoid thoe chatiements which they deerve: they are the very Pets of the earth, the mot imperfect works of the Gods, ent only for our punihments and eternal torment.

Diana, who heard every illable that this Shepherdes poke, and thought all alluded unto Sylvander, he approved of all he aid, and going to her with a deire to ee her face, he could not tread o oftly, but he made uch a noie, that the tranger heard her; who thinking at the firt that it was ome man, out of a hatred unto the very name, he would have gone away: but afterwards perceiving it was a Shepherdes, he tayed, but looked about her with uch an affrighted countenance, and wild eye, as tetified, the words of her mouth proceeded from her heart. Diana eeing her in this condition, and thinking her atonihment proceeded from the ame caue that her own perplexities did, • he began to pity her; and aluting her with a kind apect, offered all the aitance and ervice he was able. The tranger eeing her o fair and full of curteie, began to leave her affrighted and wild looks, and aume her ordinary countenance and temper. After he had aluted Diana, and thanked her for her courteous offers, he anwered thus; I am very willing and deirous, Fair Shepherdes, to render the ame ervices unto you, which you out of your goodnes are pleaed to offer unto me, and wih with all my heart, I were able to econd my deires with real performances, as your civility does oblige me; but as the cae is with me, I mut now be all upon the craving ide, and not only beg your aitance, but alo that remedy, which by the appointment of the Gods, I come to look for in this Country. Aure your elf, anwered Diana, that you will find none here who will not be very ready to do you any ervice: but I believe you will not find any here o vain as to think themelves able to Counel others, the innocent implicity of our words will not permit o much arrogance to be amongt us: Yet two things, replied the tranger, makes me hope well in my voyage; the one, that the Gods are no lyars, nor breakers of their promies, but have left that quality unto men: The other is, becaue my firt encounter in this Country, is a very good omen that I hall find what I look for: your beauty, your civility, and your prudent expreions makes me hope for a happy ucces in my voyage. The Gods indeed, anwered Diana, are no lyars nor deceivers, but ometimes they are pleaed to render their Oracles o full of obcurity, that men do often mitake and deceive themelves in the interpretation: as for any thing that relates unto me, I wih fair Shepherdes that the meeting may prove as erviceable unto you, as it is pleaing unto me, and as I deire to erve you. If there be any thing in this Country which you think conducible unto your contentment, I beeech you, tell it unto me; and if without prejudice to your elf you may, tell me what occaion brought you hither,
and what reaon you have to enveigh o much againt men? Upon this the tranger tood mute a while, and looked upon the ground; at the lat, lifting up her head with a ad ih, he returned this anwer: The quetion which you ask, Fair Shepherdes, is o reaonable, that I will very willingly give you atisfaction; knowing very well that the patient mut dicover his dieae unto that Phiitian from whom he deires a remedy; but before I trouble you with a hearing of it, I beeech you atisfie my curioity, and tell me whether you be not either Atrea, or Diana; for one of my greatet inducements unto the voyage, was my hopes of o much happines, as to be acquainted with thoe two Shepherdees, as well by ight, as by thoe reports, which Fame gives of them. There may be many Shepherdees in this Country (anwered Diana bluhing) whoe names may be Diana, and perhaps ome one of them more favoured by the Heavens above the ret; o as the name of Diana which I do bear, cannot make me believe my elf the ame you peak of, ince Fame has no ground of any reports from me: but uch as I am, I will not deny the name, of which you have o good an opinion, and wih I were able, as I am willing to do you any uch ervice as might make you continue here. Are you (aid the tranger) the companion of Atrea? I am, replied Diana; Then (aid the tranger) there are no more Dianas in this Country whom I deire to know: it is you only and your companion who have filled me o full of curioity, and made me more willingly come into this Country, though the Gods did advie me unto it by their Oracle: upon this he aluted her with uch demontrations of good will, that Diana was obliged unto the like.

At the ame intant, Phillis, who had been looking for Diana in all places where there was any probability of finding her, aw them thus aluting and careing each other, and therefore he made the more hate towards them. The tranger eeing her coming, and being very deirous to ee Atrea, he hewed her unto Diana, and asked her whether that was her Companion? She is my Companion (anwered Diana) but I believe, not that Companion whom you deire to ee, for the name of this is Phillis; and though perhaps he mut yeild unto the other in point of beauty; yet I aure you, there is not one in all the Country that exceeds her in dicretion and virtue. I make no quetion of it (anwered the tranger) ince he is your Companion: Indeed he is, anwered Diana, and the dearet Companion that Atrea and I have, and uch a one, as when you know her, you will think worthy of Love and eteem. Upon this, Phillis was come unto them, and broke off their dicoure, and Diana going to her, Siter aid he unto her, make much of this tranger, and for my ake Love her, ince he is come to encreae the number of the Shepherdees of Lignon. Phillis, as well to anwer the deires of her Companion, as in obervance to the Laws of the Country, he preently advanced towards her, and the tranger did the like, infinitely atisfied with the kind entertainment of thee Shepherdees, whoe weet civility he could not ufficiently admire, thinking that they did much urpas all the reports that Fame had trumpetted in their praie.

But Diana, though he made no hew of it, yet, was her oul full of perplexity, by reaon of Sylvander; and the contraint wherein he was ince he met with this tranger, eemed intollerable to be endured any longer: and therefore he intended as oon as he had learned the caue of her coming into this Country, to leave her: Siter, aid he unto Phillis, This fair tranger is come into the Country to find a remedy againt a dipleaure which preeth her; and becaue he merits the ervice of us all, I hall deire her, ince you are come, to acquaint us with the caue of her voyage, that we may be better enabled to do her that ervice which we deire, and he deerves. Phillis on the contrary, who was not willing to loe o much time as to hear this dicoure, he anwered thus: I mut confes Siter, that you have great reaon for your deire, but me-thinks we hould much wrong our companion, if we do not anwer her expectation of our company; and therefore I conceive it bet to defer it until uch time as Atrea may be preent. Diana did quickly undertand the reaon which caued Phillis to ay o, and approving of it, they all went together towards the great Walk; into which, as oon as they entred, they aw Florice, Cercenea, and Palinice very near them; who having long debated upon the ubject which Phillis overheard, they came thither to pas away their time, till
the ret of the Shepherds and Shepherdees aembled according to their Cutome.

When the tranger firt aw them, he knew them not, nor ever imagined that they were in this Country, alo their habits of Shepherdees did o diguie them, that he might very well mitake them; and when they came nearer, he knew them by their voices, and not by their viages: I am either extreamly deceived (aid he in a great amazement) or ele I do ee my dear friends. Florice then and her two companions looking upon her, and hearing her peak, they knew her; they went unto her, and embraced her with uch extream joy, as made it manifet that people love one another better when they meet in a trange Country, then when they are together in their own: For they had not o much patience as to embrace her one after another, but fell upon her all at once; one kied her lips, another her cheek, and a third graped her hand, with uch demontrations of good will, as perhaps never paed amongt them when they met upon the Banks of Arar.

Phillis who aw all thee great carees, and was half weary of this company; Siter (aid he unto Diana in a low voice) had we not bet leave this tranger amongt her acquaintance? For I am afraid Atrea will not like we hould carry her unto her, before we have given her notice, as well in repect of Alexis, as becaue you know he will be in the habit of the Druide. Siter, anwered Diana, I am of your opinion, and am very glad that thee other trangers come in to relieve us; for otherwie I know not how we hould have been rid of her.

Whilt they were thus talking, Florice and her companions could not ufficiently atisfie themelves with careing their companion, and had not ceaed o oon, but for Phillis, who addreing her elf unto them; Fair Shepherdees, aid he unto them, ince my companion and I do ee there is o much intimacy and affection amongt you, we will not be any caue of eparating you; and therefore, ince we mut needs go and wait upon the Druide, who (as you know) tays at the houe of Atrea for the love of us, we cannot leave this fair tranger in better company then he has met withal: And therefore, aid he unto the tranger, I beeech you give us leave to pay our duties, and we promie that ere it be long we will wait upon you unto Atrea. Fair and wie Shepherdees (aid he) ince it is your pleaure I hould tay with my dear friends whom I have met withal, I will willingly do o: but upon condition you will be as good as you promie, in making me known unto the Fair Atrea, and in the mean time aure her, that you have met with one who with all her oul deires the happinees of her Love. All this (anwered Diana) we do faithfully promie, and more, we promie to do any thing ele which may conduce unto your real ervice.

In the mean time Phillis thought it expedient to engage Florice, Cercinea, and Palinice, let their impatience hould make them depart the Country too oon; and therefore when he aw that Diana had taken her leave of the company: Siter (aid he unto her in a loud voice) I beeech you tay a little for me, and I will wait upon you preently, for I mut needs talk a little with thee three fair Shepherdees. Siter, anwered Diana, what hate oever I have, yet I will tay for you, and therefore ay what you pleae unto them. Then Phillis addreing her elf unto thee three trangers, Florice (aid he, in a low and grave countenance, otherwie then he ued) and you Cercinea and Palinice, The Gods do let you know by me, that which they have already poken unto you by their Oracle, how that one who was dead, and yet lives, is to be your medicine, and likewie another unto whom is rendred againt her Will, a benefit which he lot with her Will. O ye Gods! cryed they all out, and clapped their hands together, oh bleed Shepherdes, whom the heavens have ordained for our happines and contentment, may you for ever find the accomplihment of your deires, as we have of ours in meeting with you: Then gazing upon one another, Is it not mot certain (aid they) that the Gods are no Deceivers, but will at the lat mot infallibly perform all their promies? Upon this, all three aluted Phillis with o many expreions of joy, that Diana, and the other tranger who knew not the caue of their coming, tood amazed: But Phillis who continued her grave countenance, after he had returned their alute; Now, aid he, I cannot tay with you any longer; the time is not yet come that your pain mut have an end, but it will be
very hortly: content your elves therefore with this, that the Gods have not forgotten what they told you by their Oracle, but will in fit time and place accomplih it. Florice then began to peak; now (aid he) we know unto whom the Gods have committed the care of us, we will with all contentment wait as long as you hall pleae; auring you age Shepherdes, that we are infinitely pleaed with the choie which the Gods have made of you. Diand and the other tranger was very attentive unto their dicoure, but not undertanding it, Diana asked Phillis, what contentment this was which they poke off. The Gods, anwered Phillis have ent thee three trangers into the Country to receive a remedy unto ome perplexities which troubles them, and by their Oracle have forbidden them to peak of it unto any, but unto that peron who hall repeat the anwer which they received from the Oracle. Now I have repeated it unto them, and more, I do aure them, that they hall receive all manner of atisfaction and contentment. As Diana was atonihed at the firt, o was he much more, when he heard thee words, for he could not imagine how her Companion hould come to the knowledg of this Oracle. But Phillis counterfeiting admirably well, that it was by divine inpiration; after ome other uch dicoure, he took her leave of them; auring them, that ere long they hould find eae and atisfaction to their minds: and by the way, he related unto Diana how as he was eeking her, he met with them, and uneen of them, heard them repeat and dicoure upon this Oracle.

Thus they went talking upon this encounter, till they came to the houe of Atrea, but finding her no further dret, then when they left her; Oh Siter (aid Phillis and eemed to wonder) what, not farther yet? Do I find you jut as I left you? It is to hew (anwered Atrea) that I am no changeling. Nay, nay, replied Phillis, my meaning is, you are dret no more then you were when I went to eek Diana: Pray what have you been doing all the while? Certainly Siter, anwered Atrea, you are very weary, ince the time eems o long unto you: I aure you I thought you but newly parted: It eems quite contrary with you, anwered Phillis, and that you have been o pleaed, that hours eem but minutes unto you. If contentment and happines can do it, replied Atrea, I mut needs confes what you ay: and yet Siter, do not think that I have done nothing ince you went, for in this hort time, I have gotten the Fairet Mitris that ever was: And I, aid Alexis, the weetet Servant that ever lived. I warrant you (aid Phillis) you have pent all this morning about this piece of work. Siter (aid Atrea) you need not light it o much; for it is not a work o eaily done; ome are whole months and years, nay whole ages about it. Yes, (aid Diana) and for all the hate which they make, they have time enough to repent all the dayes of their life: That is a thing (aid Atrea) which I hall never do, unles I repent that I begun it no ooner: I do believe it, anwered Diana, becaue your Mitris is a Woman, but if it were a man, believe it Siter, you would be no more exempted then others; and for my part, I hall advie all thoe that deire to have a quiet life, never to contract amity with any but Women, and to hun all the aurances of any good will which Men ue to make, as a Serpent does the words of enchantment. I do wonder (aid Alexis) you hould accue men of that vice which they do o much charge us with all. Madam, anwered Diana, did you never hear the Proverb, The Debtor demands money; Men likewie do prevent us, and blame us for that which themelves are guilty of: believe it, the greatet ervitude that nature did impoe upon us, is in that he contrained us to live in their company. Then (aid Alexis and miled) how happy are the ret of our Druides who are exempted from this inconveniency. Doubtles they are Madam, anwered Diana, and you will know it better, if you will but he pleaed to conider what I hall ay unto you; certainly if men be at any time pleaing unto thoe they court, it is when they are inflamed with Love, and eem as if they adored them, for then they are all complacency, all ervice, all cares, all ubmiion, all flatteries; briefly their continual tudy is to get the favour of thoe who hearken unto them: o as quetionles if ever a man be not troubleome, it is at this time; and yet if we do but well conider it, into how many inconveniences and troubles do they bring thoe poor unfortunate women, whom they have deigns upon? For if they do not Love them, then all their cares and courthips are o many wrongs and injuries unto them: and if
they do Love them, conider, I beeech you Madam, how unupportable they are if they find entertainment, and how troubleome they are if they be rejected: they think one favour to be a tep unto another, and never leave till they arrive at the highet: if you reject them, then they are all complaint, reproaches, and depaires, and very often driven unto hatred and revenge: if thou entertain them, they are till never contented, till they arrive at that which they cannot obtain, without the ruine of thoe that give the entertainment; if you do not grant them all that they deire, then, the more favours you have done them, the more occaions have you given them to ruin you. Then to Crown the work; when they are arrived at the height of their deires, you run a hazard either to be lighted, or to live in a continual inquietude for their incontancy. As for thoe that are repuled at the firt; how infinitely troubleome they are unto us? What inupportable torments they are by their importunities, and ubtilties? They will hang upon you like a bur; they will follow you as a haddow does the body; they will never be abent from you, but when night comes and eparates you from them and all others: you can have no other object before your eyes but them; and will be o troubleome unto you, that you will be glad to banih from you uch company as you love, only to be rid of them you love not. At the lat, if their love do die, as they are very ubject unto uch changes, what is it which their pite will not make them belch forth againt you? Their calumnies will blat the mot unblameable life that ever lived: the hercet Tygers that ever nature created, are not o full of revenge as they will be againt us. So then it mut be concluded (aid Phillis, and interrupted) that men are troubles at all times, according to Dianas Doctrine. For my part (aid Atrea) I hall not need to fear them, when I am with Alexis amongt the Virgin Druides of Carnutes: but to tell you truly, I do believe, there are very few men who have not a tincture of thoe vices, wherewith Diana upbraids them. Thee few words from Atrea, did touch Celadon o to the quick, that he knew not what to ay, yet let he hould give any notice of it, he thought himelf obliged to ay omething: For my part, replied Alexis, I know not what to ay, for I never made any tryal of thee deceivers, and have known ome changing women: Then turning to Atrea; Oh Servant, (aid he in a low voice) when we are amongt the Virgin Druides, we hall care but a little for the incontancy of thee wavering men, and we will laugh at your Companions who do live in that ervitude. I hope o, (anwered Atrea) and I protet unto you Mitris, I do with extream impatience long to ee the day when we mut depart.

p.U:
eeing them whiper, let he hould interrupt them, did tand a little farther off, but Phillis who was of a very pleaant and gay humour, and knew very well that Alexis would take delight in it, Siter, (aid he unto Diana) is not my prophecy come to pas? Does not Atrea who was wont to Love none but Diana and Phillis, and who took delight in no company but theirs, does not he I ay, didain them now? and Loves only this new Shepherdes? Whereby you may note, that men may well accue us alo of levity, and incontancy. Ah Phillis (anwered Astrea, and miled) do you not oberve that I am now no Shepherdes? Do you ee, how I am become a Druide? And do you not know that honours change manners? But I hope, replied Phillis, that when this Druide is gone, who has infued o much pride into you, then you will return unto your former humility, I beeech you angry Shepherdes, anwered Atrea, withhold your revenge upon me till that time, and then I will not complain of any hurt you can do me: your meaning is replied Phillis, that then you will be full of greater dipleaures then ours, and will not value what we can do: that, replied Atrea, is not my meaning. Then, aid Phillis, do you think us of uch good dipoitions, that eeing you afflicted for others, we will have no mind to augment your dipleaures? But you will deceive your elf in that; for ingratitude is a vice o detetable, that it turns the weetet natures into harh dipoitions, and makes the mot courteous and kind, become urly, and vindicative. That is not my meaning neither, replied Atrea, but it is, becaue you hall not ee my here after my Fair Mitris is gone; for I am fully reolved to follow her whitheroever he hall go, and he is pleaed to permit me. Nay, nay, aid Philis, Calidon will never permit that voyage; Calidon, anwered Atrea, has no more
to do with me, then I will have with him: But Phocion (aid Phillis) will order it after another manner. The will of Heaven and of my detiny, replied Atrea, is above the will of men. But I beeech you, added Phillis, has not thoe friends which you have here any prevalence with you? I mut needs confes, anwered Atrea, that if any have, it is they, and this conideration only can make me reent my dipleaures: but when I think upon thoe orrows, which I have received from the detetable River of Lignon; I hall deire to be o far ditant from it, as that the memory of it may be quite extinguihed. If that be your deign (aid Diana) then you mut reolve to carry us with you, for you know our affection will never uffer us to be far from you. Should Heaven conent unto that, replied Atrea, I hould be but too happy: I hope, anwered Diana, that Heaven will favour us as well as you, and deliver us from that ervitude wherein we live. Paris and Belinde (aid Alexis) will pronounce an arret againt you: Yes, aid Atrea, and Lycidas will no les oppoe the voyage, unles he may have leave to follow Phillis. Paris and Belinde, anwered Diana, will never ordain any thing againt my will, nor againt the ervice of Tautates; for both of them are Religious and Wie. But if they hould, I hould be excuable in my di-obedience to Belinde, becaue I ought to imitate my Mother in dedicating my elf unto the ame God unto whom he her elf is devoted: And as for Paris, I hope that I may dipleae him to exempt my elf from all manner of dipleaures. This conideration therefore, need not to hinder you from carrying us with you. If this conideration will not hinder, (aid Phillis and miled) I have one that will, which is, a reolution never to put Lycidas unto the trouble of following me o far; for I do not intend to be ditant from him, farther then the limits of our Town will extend.

div.p: Alexis and Atrea could not forbear laughing at Phillis, which caued her to add further; do not think Siter, whatoever I ay of Lycidas, but that I love you as wel as any Siter in the world can: but I mut needs confes, that the affection which I bear unto the Shepherd, is of another kind then that which I bear unto you: were I as well learned as Sylvander, perhaps I hould make a better definition of it; but o it is, that I can hardly be deprived of his ight for any other: I hope you will not take my freedom in an ill ence, but rather excue it, becaue lying is not permitted amongt us. Siter, anwered Astrea, I hall never be one that will condemn your humour; but perhaps I hall be extreamly orry to be o far ditant from you. Could I divide my elf into two parts, replied Phillis, the one hould wait upon you which way oever you went: but ince that cannot be, I beeech you, give me leave to make good my promie unto Lycidas. Diana then miled and aid, I perceive there is none but my elf who will keep the promie which we made unto Atrea. I hall upply the place of Phillis (aid Alexis) and perform the office of amity which that Shepherdes hath worn unto her. Do not think Madam, replied Phillis, that I will ever fail in my promie to her: but he knows very well, that when we contracted our league of amity unto each other, one condition was, not to deny any thing that the one hould ask of the other; and ince I ask her pardon if I do not follow her, he cannot, unles he be perjured, deny it. It is very true, anwered Atrea, and ighed, nor will I blame you for what you do, no more then you upbraid me with my pat mi-fortune.

Their dicoure had lated long, had it not been for Atreas dreing her elf: but Alexis being taller then he, and by conequence her Gown too long for her, Diana and Phillis did take it in, by tucking it up o handomly, that it was as fit as if meaure had been taken of her. The Druide, on the other ide thinking that he had counterfeited ick long enough, alo fearing that if he continued in bed, he hould dicover the defects of her brets; he reolved to get up, and walk in the little grove of Hales with Atrea; foreeeing that otherwie if he tayed in her chamber, they two hould never be alone, and o hould be deprived of the pleaure which he took in talking with the Shepherdes without interruption. In order therefore unto this deign, Servant (aid he unto Atrea) ee what an excellent operation your dicoure has had upon my icknes: Since you came hither, I have been as well as I can wih: if therefore you will let me rie, we will go and walk away the ret of the morning in the little Wood: If I have been any Intrument of your well being, anwered
Atrea, I hall think my elf the happiet Woman in the world, for I have no greater ambition then to do you ervice. Oh Madam, aid Phillis; we will all thank Atrea for being o good a Doctor. Indeed, aid Alexis, I find my elf very well, and if you will give me the Gown which I am to put on, I will dres my elf and go with you whither you pleae. Phillis ran preently to reach Atreas Gown, and helping her to put it on, he was dreed preently: then coming unto the window, he dreed up her head, and tricked up her elf o, that this diguied Druide appeared to be one of the Fairet Shepherdees of Lignon: Atrea eeing her, could not chue but ay unto Phillis; Well Phillis, do you think the time I pent in getting uch a Fair Mitris, was not well imployed? Certainly it was, anwered Phillis, and miled, if you were Atreas Brother; for it is the cutom in this Country, when one peaks of a Mitris and Servant, a Shepherd and a Shepherdes is to be undertood.
