Oh Phillis (anwered Diana) amongt the Virgin Druids, the cutome is quite contrary; and you mut know, (added Alexis) that in the Sacrifices of Veta, men are not received.

When the Druide was dret, he took Atrea by the hand, and led her out; and the Flocks of Diana and Phillis being neer the door, Alexis would needs drive them, to hew he was not ahamed of her habit; but to make them believe he was ignorant in that mitery, he ued her Sheephook and talked to the Flock very aukwardly, at which Atrea could not chue but laugh, and Diana would needs undertake to direct and teach her what to do. After they had a while made themelves merry at this exercie, they walked to the Wood, into which they were no ooner entred, but they pied upon their left hand, a great company of Shepherds and Shepherdees, who were walking there in the hade: this encounter did a little trouble the two diguied parties, for being not yet grown confident enough of themelves, they were afraid to be een by any; and therefore they deired Diana and Phillis, to walk towards that company, whilt they, let they hould be known, would take another way: the two good friends according to their deires, went forward and came up to the company; who eeing them, did advance themelves to bid them good morrow. Diana having met with Daphnis amongt them, as her pecial and intimate friend; he went to embrace her, and ask her how he had paed away the night. All complements and alutations being ended, Hylas who was in the company, and Corilas alo, not being able to be together without everal diputes, they continued on the dicoure, which they had begun before thoe two Shepherdees came unto them. Good Hylas, aid Corilas, tell me one thing; when thou didt change Alexis for Stella, at what game didt thou play? Why, (anwered Hylas) do you ask me that quetion? Becaue I think, replied Corilas, that thou daret hardly ay it was the game of the Fairet, as thou wert wont to ay when thou didt leave Phillis for Alexis; for I cannot believe thy eyes o bad, but thou mut needs ee, that he whom thou hat left, is Fairer then he whom thou hat taken: Oh thou ignorant novice, in beauty (cryed out Hylas) what is it that can be called Fair, unles it pleae? I confes (aid Corilas) that beauty does pleae; but I cannot confes, all that pleaeth to be Fair: and o that which a depraved tate thinks good, ought not to be eteemed o therefore. How now friend? (replied Hylas) What, one of Sylvanders diciples? Perhaps thou thinket as he does, that beauty is a right proportion, and a true mixture of colours; Oh how groly thou art mitaken, if thou thinket o? Beauty is nothing but an opinion of her whom we judge to be o: and to demontrate it unto thee; when a woman has a little mouth, a well proportioned noe, a cleer skin, a freh complexion, and buxom plumpnes, dot thou not call this beauty? I do o, anwered Corilas; then tell me (replied Hylas) beauty, and uglines, are they the Mother and the Daughter of one another, or are they contraries? Certainly, aid Corilas, beauty does never engender uglines, and they are o contrary, that the one cannot be without detruction unto the other. Then confes, replied Hylas, that beauty, and uglines are only in opinion: for I will hew thee how that which very oft we eteem Fair, does eem very ugly unto us, according as opinion commands. When a dog has a crooked noe, a wide mouth, large lips, and eares hanging down to the ground, do they not ay, that uch a one is a very fair and a fine dog, and yet all thee are quite contrary unto what you call fair.
All this were right, replied Corilas and miled, if the beauty of a Woman, and the beauty of a Dog were all one and the ame thing. Nay, nay, aid Hylas, this excue will not pas, and if thou wert but as learned as thy mater Sylvander, I would ask thee quetions concerning Ideas of Beauty: But thou my Friend, who art not o high a Flyer, I mut deal with thee by demontrations more eaie and enible: Thou thinket that thou hat given me a ufficient anwer, in aying, That the beauty of a Woman, and the beauty of a Dog are not the ame: But what wilt thou alledge when I hew thee that the beauty of Women has a contrary etimation: The Gauls eteem white to be Beauty, the Moors eteem Black to be the ame: The Tranalpines loves thoe that are high coloured, almot red, they eteem great and fat women to be the prime Beauties, the Gauls are for the lender and lean: The Greeks admire the Black eye, the Gauls the Grey. All Europe eteem a little mouth, red lips, and an even proportioned noe: The Affricans quite contrary, a wide mouth, flapping lips, and a large addle noe: Now my good friend, prithee tell me, wherein does Beauty conit? If thou dot deny it to be in the opinion of him that looks upon it, tell me no more that Alexis is fairer then Stella, ince thou judget by the Genius and Rules of thy Country, and I by mine, which is Camargue; for I will tell thee, that according to the Rules of that place where I was born, there is none o fair as he who pleaeth.

Every one did laugh o much at the dicoure of the Incontant Hylas, that Corilas could not anwer him: and jut as he began, they heard a Shepherd begin to ing, who by his voice was known to be Sylvander. All the company did preently turn their eyes upon Hylas, as if they did advertize him, that now he was like to have a more powerful enemy. Stella who took notice of it: Servant (aid he) all the company looks upon you, to ee whether you begin to look pale at the encounter of this fierce Champion: I amongt the ret do expect to ee what defence you will make of my Beauty, for I hould be very glad for your own honours ake, if you can with honour bring about the enterprize: Not that I care for my own Interet at all, for I do know very well that if Beauty do conit in opinion, there is not a Shepherdes in the world who has more of it then I have. Mitris, anwered he, let this Giant come when he will, I value him not, it is not the firt time we have grapled together. Then aid Corilas, I am confident the victories were never doubtful. No more then thoe I obtained over you, anwered Hylas. I hould confe • , anwered Corilas, if you could perwade me that Stella is fairer then Alexis, you have gotten a mot ignal victory of me. It is very hard, replied Hylas, to perwade a man that is wilful; but I am contented that all who hear us, do judge me to be in the right. If they do, replied Corilas, it may be aid that Right is without Reaon.

In the mean time Sylvander came unto them, with a countenance of contentment more then he had caue for: For Diana, who was not able to diemble her anger, and left her countenance hould dicover it more then he was willing, he went unto Phillis, and whipered in her ear; I beeech you Siter (aid he) do not follow me: for I am contrained to go unto Atrea upon a buines which I forgot, and I would not by any means draw you from this good company. I will do whatoever you command me, anwered Phillis, but I hall be very glad to go with you. Do what you pleae, aid Diana, but if you do come, let it be a little after me: Upon this he went away four or five paces; and then, as if he had remembred omthing which he had once forgotten, he turned hatily back to Phillis, and aid unto her in a low voice; Be ure Siter you remember the Bracelet of my Hair, for I deire you by all means to get it from him; and afterwards I hall be extreamly deirous to hear what dicoure you have had with this Lover of Madonthe. Siter, anwered Phillis, you believe upon too light grounds, but if you will, I hall peak unto Sylvander, and give you an accompt of his anwer. His anwer! aid Diana, No Siter, I deire it not, nor any thing ele from him, but that unfortunate Bracelet which he had of mine; But if you will take o much pains as to oberve his countenance and geture when you ask it of him, you will do me a pleaure if you relate it unto me. I know your mind, anwered Phillis and miled, and therefore trouble your elf no further, but commit the care of it to me. Upon this Diana went away as fat as he could go, and durt hardly look back, let he hould give ome upition of the paion
which he deired to conceal. On the other ide, Alexis and Astrea who were eparated from the company, purpoely to enjoy themelves in freedom of dicoure, they were no ooner alone, but Atrea with contentment, began thus: I cannot tell Mitris what will be the end of my Enterprize, nor how the Detinies will dipoe of me; but this beginning is o infinitely pleaing unto me, that nothing can be added unto my deires, for I am able to ay, that hopes never durt promie unto themelves o much as the kindnes of my weet Mitris hath granted unto me. Servant, aid Alexis, uch is your merit, that you may well aure your elf of all the favours you can deire from me: But if you will oblige me, conider I beeech you how favourable the Heavens are to me in meeting with you: For having uch a bitter remembrance of the change in that woman whom I loved o well, and yet do love her, that bitter memory of her is driven from my heart, by the weetnes which I find in your amity, making it appear that the bet remedy againt a miery, is alwaies the contrary. Give me leave, weet Mitris, replied Atrea with a little mile, to tell you, that by thee extream favours which you do me, you do make me jealous. Is it, replied Alexis, becaue I ay that I do love this Maid till, of whoe change I complain o much? Have I not a little reaon for it, aid Astrea? Servant aid Alexis, You have no reaon for it; for I love you as my Servant, and her as my Mitris. This anwered Atrea, does not remove my jealouie, but rather much more augment it, becaue the love which one bears unto a Mitris, does much urpas the good will which one bears unto a Servant. Well Servant, aid Alexis, to let you ee that I will conform my elf unto any thing you would have me, I will take this coure: To ceae loving this woman of whom we peak, is impoible, as well becaue it hall never be aid that I am uncontant, as becaue it would be an unpardonable error to ee o much merits and not love them: But to cut the thred as even as I can betwixt you, I will love this changeling till, but I will love her only for your ake. Perhaps I hould be atisfied with this promie, if I did undertand it, replied Atrea. My meaning is, replied Alexis, That I will love her only, becaue I am certain that when you do know her, you will love her as well as I do: and if it do not prove o, then I protet that I will not love her: But Servant, I remember you once told me, that you did love a Shepherd, I beeech you let me know who that happy man is; for if our amity continue, as I make no quetion but it will, then it is not reaonable we hould live together, as we are reolved to do, and let any thing be concealed from each other. Though Alexis had a great deire to know the caue of his Banihment, yet this quetion came out before he was well aware, otherwie, her fears of a harp anwer would doubtles have topped her mouth: But the word being out, and pat recal, he expected Atreas anwer, as a entence of either life or death. The Shepherdes on the other ide, or rather the new Druide, he was a little troubled at this quetion, and knew not well what anwer to return; but at lat, after he had tood a while mute, he returned this anwer, with a deep igh: Ah Mitris! you command me to tell you a thing which hath cot me many a bitter tear; and the very memory of it cannot come into my mind without much ad reentment: But ince I am forced unto it by your command, I will hut up my orrows within my oul, and tell you, becaue I have made a vow never to diobey you. Know therefore Mitris, that the name of this Shepherd whom I loved is Celadon, and an enmity that was betwixt our Families, was not able to give any top unto the affection that was between us; but when we were in our highet hopes of a happy concluion, Death did ravih him away from amongt men, and made me a widdow before I was married. This, Mitris, is it that hath cot me a Sea of Tears, and I beeech you pardon me that I make no longer a relation of it unto you: for beides that I think it both out of eaon, and impertinent; alo I deire you to have o much pity upon your Servant, as not to open a wound, which perhaps will never be cured, and which is the mot enible that ever any received. Alexis might well have been contented with this anwer, but his extream deire to know the full caue of his miery, urged him to go further, and ay; I am very orry Servant, I hould be any caue of your ad reentments; but you may think that this my curioity is no mall tetimony of my affection to you; and therefore if this conideration have any influence upon your oul, I beeech you tell me why and how this Shepherd died, when he was at the very top
of all his hopes? Ah Mitris, aid Atrea, you touch the wound where it is mot ore, and yet let the pain be what it will, I cannot diobey you.

When Atrea was ready to atisfie the Druide, they were at the end of the long Walk; and when they turned back, they pied the Shepherdes Diana at the other end, who was coming to them, purpoely to avoid the ight of Sylvander. Atrea was very glad of this encounter, which would erve her for an excue in not atisfying the curioity of Alexis; who deiring to have no witnees, was the firt which entreated her to defer this dicoure until another time.

Preently after, Diana came unto them, with a countenance that poke the dipleaure he had received by meeting with Sylvander: And becaue this alteration was very apparent, Atrea and Alexis perceived it as oon as ever they aw her. This moved Alexis to ask her whether he was not well: to whom he anwered yes, but was on the contrary much delighted at the dicoure of Hylas againt Beauty: But aid he, he found a more eaie Antagonit of Corilas then he will of Sylvander. Sylvander! aid Atrea, is he in the Country? Yes, anwered Diana faintly, he came jut as I came away, and I aw all the company preparing themelves to hear him. Then Atrea miled, and turned towards Alexis; Mitris, aid he unto her, you need not ask Diana whether he be ill, for I know from whence proceeds that alteration which we oberved in her face. The reaon of it is, aid Diana, becaue I made uch hate in coming to you; and indeed I have not found my elf of late o well as I was wont to be. This excue, replied Atrea, cannot hide it from us, nor will our amity permit you hould be thus cloe unto us. Do you not conider (aid Diana) in whoe preence you are? Very well, replied Atrea, both what I ay, and in whoe preence; But my Mitris is pleaed to allow us o much liberty and freedom, that you ought not to ue any uch ditimulations and diguiements, which it eems you would hide your elf withal, both from her and me. Servant, aid Alexis, and miled, unles you will have me accue you of the ame fault for which you blame Diana, you will tell me openly what it is that he diembles. Mitris, anwered Atrea preently, I cannot conceal any thing which you have a deire to know: but let this Shepherdes hould have any reaon to complain againt me, I beeech you command me, and I will tell you. Then I command you, aid Alexis, with all the power that you have given me over you. Atrea offering to peak, Diana put her hand before her mouth, and hindered her: But Atrea putting her hand away, and pulling Alexis betwixt them, Diana, aid he, though it cot me my life, I will obey my Mitris in all her commands. Madam, aid Diana, Do not either hear or believe her, for he cannot tell you any thing either of truth, or worth your hearing: But if you pleae, you may pend your time much better in hearing the diputes between Hylas and Sylvander, which cannot chue but be very pleaant, ince your elf is concerned in it; for the Dipute is betwixt your Beauty and Stellas. We will do o aid Alexis, ince you will have us, though neither Atrea nor I have any great confidence in our new Habits; and as we go, Atrea hall tell us what it is which you are o hye in imparting to us. I would not have her tell you Fancies and Imaginations for truths, replied Diana, epecially uch imaginations as cannot be told without much offence. Then Alexis taking in each hand one, they walked that way from whence Diana came: And Atrea began thus: Siter, aid he, you will be oon offended if what I hall ay will do it: For when I aure my Mitris that the alteration which he oberves in your face proceeds only from your meeting with Sylvander, do I tell any thing but what is truth? Why hould he change her countenance (aid Alexis) at the eeing of one whom he o much loves and honours? Mitris, aid Atrea, I beeech you do but look upon her, and you hall ee her face anwer for me. Diana then held her hands before her eyes, and turning her head the other way, he held it o a long while, and would not be een: But at lat, conidering that her companion would certainly tell what he deired to conceal, he thought it better to tell it her elf, then uffer another to do it. Madam, aid he and miled, What Atrea tells you is a meer Imagination: but ince you have uch a deire to know, I had rather tell it my elf, then uffer her; and when I have told you, then judge what probabilities there is in the matter. You know Madam, that according to the Wager that was betwixt Phillis and Sylvander, this Shepherd eemed
long as if he had really loved me, and ince we have dicovered that he is extreamly in love with Madonthe. Who is that Madonthe? asked Alexis. A tranger, anwered Atrea, who was here a while amongt us, and one whom Diana has an opinion that Sylvander is in love withal. An opinion, replied Diana, Why Siter do you not poitively ay, he is one whom Sylvander loves as much as he can love, for you know it to be true? Did I know it, anwered Atrea, I would ay as you do, but I wear that I think all he does is only out of civility. Civility! cryed out Diana, Do you call it Civility to cry, to pray, to beg, to importune, and to kneel at the feet of Madonthe, to get leave that he may follow her? If this be civility, then I do not know what is Love. Siter, aid Atrea, you believe all that Laonice tells you, and I would have you upend your Belief, until the Shepherd return, that you may have the truth from his own mouth. Fie, fie Friend, replied Diana, I wonder you hould peak thus: Would you have me look for any truth from the mouth of a Man? a man in Love? Or (to peak all in one word) from a Sylvander? from him that thinks he can by the volubility of wit and tongue blind the eyes of our mind, as Juglers do the eyes of our Body? No, no, there is no credit to be given unto any thing he ays. Why hould you think, aid Alexis, that Sylvander loves any but your elf? I never thought he loved me, anwered Diana, nor ever had any intention to uffer him. Surely, aid Atrea, you had an opinion once that he did love you; but if he did not, why hould he take o much pains about you as he did? To pas away his time, anwered Diana, or becaue he had nothing ele to do. Do you think, aid Atrea, that o fine a Wit as Sylvanders can find it elf nothing to do but to trifle away his time about one whom he loves not? You may remember Siter, if you pleae, how that Shepherd lived before he cat any amorous eye upon you, and compare that time with the time of his love unto you, and conider what a difference there was; which of your commands, nay the leat haddow of your will did he not oberve as a Law inviolable? To be brief Siter, Tell me what greater reverence he could render unto any Grandee upon earth, nay unto the Gods themelves, then he hath alwaies done unto you? And whether there be not certain ymptomes, igns, and conequents of a real love, let any hearer judge? Siter, anwered Diana, ince you peak o highly in behalf of Sylvander, I believe you think as you ay; But I who never aw, nor will ee any uch matters, I will believe the reports of Laonice; and if thoe igns which you have oberved in him be any tetimonies of Love, they may be of his love to Madonthe. No replied Atrea, for I have heard him in my preence ay a hundred and an hundred times, that it is you, and you only whom he loves. It is the common quality of men, anwered Diana, thus to delude thoe illy women who hear them: and do you not think he has aid as much in private unto his dear Madonthe? But if I be not much deceived, he never aid as much to me, nor ever hall. I perceive, aid Alexis, you are apt to believe all that is aid againt Sylvander, as confidently as if you had een it your elf. I believe it Madam, anwered Diana, becaue it is true: But I am contented to forgive him with all my heart, and will believe all that Laonice has told me. Me thinks aid Alexis, you are over-apt, and too partial to believe the reports of that woman: you ought to upend your belief and judgement, till you hear him anwer for himelf. Ah Madam, aid Diana, I aure you that I care o little either for his love or hate, as I would not have one word more pent about the matter: For do you think to draw truth from a fale and diembling tongue? For my part, aid Atrea, I cannot believe him in any fault: But if he be in fault, his fault is his love unto Madonthe; now when he is gone, his fault will appear; and if he be in no fault, then he will continue his addrees till unto you. I do not think (aid Diana) that he will continue them. But if he do continue them, aid Atrea, what will you ay then? I will ay, anwered Diana, that he will be ahamed to hew his Incontancy. If he was ahamed of that, replied Atrea, he would not have o freely dicovered it before all thoe who aw him take his leave of Madonthe. Perhaps, anwered Diana, he was not o abolute a mater of himelf, but he was urprized with this udden and unexpected departure; o as though he be his Arts mater in matter of lying, yet he could not chue but upon uch a urprize dicover the truth. But Siter, why hould we pend o much time about a thing which is not worth it? Let
us leave Sylvander to his beloved Madonthe, and have no more memory of him then he has of us; for I believe his oul is capable of no thought but his orrows at this ad eparation.

Whilt thee Shepherdees were thus dicouring, preently after Dianas departure from Phillis, Sylvander came to the place from which Diana went; and he had hardly aluted all the company before Hylas accoted him.

Will you, ay Sylvander (aid he unto him) that Diana is Fairer then Stella? Will you deny Hylas (aid Sylvander) that the Sun is cleerer then Darknes? All the Company began to laugh at the anwer of Sylvander, and the quetion of Hylas: but Hylas without being at all daunted, I will maintain (aid he) that Stella does not only equal, but much excel the beauty of Diana. I do not wonder at what you ay (anwered Sylvander) but yet me thinks thy very ignorance hould have made a better judgment then o; I hould anwer you after another manner (aid Hylas) if I had not right on my ide, and if I did not think to make you confes before we part in the preence of all thee Shepherdees, that Stella is fairer then Diana, at the leat if you will anwer me. Doubt not but I will anwer unto all you hall ask, aid Sylvander and miled, but if you make me confes what you affirm, and which I can never believe, I will ay you can do more then is poible, and makes ue of ome enchantment. The enchantments which I will ue, anwered Hylas, hall be the trength of my reaons, of which, not you, but all the company hall judge: therefore Sylvander, anwer unto this quetion; How Fair do you think Diana to be? As Fair, anwered Sylvander, as any woman can be. And I, aid Hylas, do think Stella to be Fairer then any Woman in the world can be: thus you ee Sylvander how you have poken truth before you were aware; you hold the beauty of Diana, only in the comparative degree, but I Stellas in the uperlative: If opinion, replied Sylvander, were to end the difference, or were that which makes a peron more or les Fair, then I hould confes that in this argument you have in ome ort the advantage of me. But how groly are you deceived if you have that belief; for beauty is the perfection of that which hath it: and can you ay that perfection is only an imagination? But can you deny, replyed Hylas, that beauty, even the beauty of Women, is any thing ele but the opinion of him who ees it? For if it were otherwie, he who eems Fair unto one, would eem Fair unto all eyes, which holds fale in the opinion that you have of the beauty of Diana, and the greater beauty of Stella. The ground you build upon, replied Sylvander, is uch a looe and, that it mut needs fall preently to ruine: for it is not opinion which ets a value upon things, but their own proper quality which is in them; for otherwie a piece of Glas or Alchimy well wrought and counterfeited, were as good as Gold, or a right Diamond, for they are oftentimes thought to be as good as the other: but Hylas, you know from whence this opinion has its rie; even from nothing but ignorance: for if people knew that the Alchimy, and the Glas, were counterfeit; they would never et o much eteem upon them: the very like is of the judgement which you make of Diana and Stella; for did you know what beauty is, you would give a ound judgment, and not rahly at random as you do: for my part, replied Hylas, I cannot think my elf in any error, I have mot men on my ide; and mot ignorants alo, replied Sylvander, yet if you will refer it unto the vote of this company, I am confident you will find very few on your ide: for as there is commonly more ound then ick perons, o there are more ound then imple judgements, otherwie nature was defective in her works, and did not accomplih them according to the right rule, which to think, were a blaphemy both againt her, and the God of Nature.
Silvander having an ample field for his dicoure, would have continued it longer, if Hylas had not interrupted him with another quetion.

I know Sylvander (aid he) that it will be a very dear year when you want words: but anwer me to this; If beauty be not meer opinion, then how comes it to pas that one hould affect the grey eye, another the black, a third the brown, and every one according to their everal fancies; is this from ignorance? whole Provinces we ee of the ame opinion, and contrary unto another; this, anwered Sylvander, is eaily anwered: I know the Gaules are for grey eyes; the Greeks and Latins black,
becaue the women there are commonly black, and the Gaules white: now Hylas, can you fancy that white eyes, and white hair, would hew well upon a black complexion; or black hair or eyes upon a white complexion? But Hylas, all thee anchantments which you menaced, cannot make me confes Stella to • e o Fair as Diana. Upon this, cating his eye upon Phillis, and he making igns unto him that he would peak with him, he would not tay any longer; but <> towards Hylas, content your elf (aid he unto him) that I have lot o much time already; when Diana is preent, I hall read you as long a leon as you pleae: o leaving him, he went to Phillis, and aid unto her, in a low voice; Who, would have thought, Oh my enemy, if I may o call you, that you would have par ••• from that Mitris which you have given unto Sylvander? Shepherd, aid he unto him, all things are o apt to change, that it is no wonder to ee any thing go contrary to cutom: As for the name of enemy which you betow upon me, I kn • w not how I may deerve it; but you mut not give the name of Mitris unto Diana Sylvander was a little atonihed to ee Phillis o erious, and hear her peak o; yet conidering that Phillis was wont to play the wag with him; he miled: but then thinking that he did peronate too well to be in jet, and continued it too long, he eperated from the ret of the company let he hould be heard: but it was more then needed, for all the Shepherds and Shepherdees gathered o about Hylas, and ee • ed him with the victory which he had gotten, that none took notice of his action; but being ditant from all the company, he began th •• ; Your language Phillis, and your geture, does peak you to be my neemy. But as for Diana, there is none but <>
me that he is my Mitris. Whatoever I am, anwered Phillis, it is no matter; <>
as for Diana, I am ure he is none of your Mitris: Oh my mot cruel enemy, aid Sylvander, I beeech you no more of this counterfeit language, let it caue my death. Whatoever occaion you give me to hate you, aid Phillis, yet my hatred hall not reach o far as to wih your death but if you will go a little farther, I will tell you that you are not now upon the ame terms with Diana you were wont to be: and if all reports be true you are to blame. I beeech you Shepherdes, aid Sylvander, if you peak thus only to perplex me, tell me as much, and I hall thank you: Shepherd, Shepherd, aid Phillis, I have no intentions of perplexing of you, but rather deire to bring you out if I can; for believe it Sylvander, I peak in good erious earnet Diana is extreamly angry againt you, and if all be true that is aid, he has good reaon. Oh weet Phillis, aid Sylvander, for Heavens ake tell me what i •
aid of me? I tell you the very truth, replied he, and that you may believe I do not lie; know alo, that aoon as ever he ave you, he went away from the company, and gave me a charge to get a bracelet of her hair from you, which he gave you, for he ayes the time that you were to keep it being expired, there is no reaon uch a tetimony of good will hould remain with one who can make no better ue of it. Sylvander was truck dead with wonder, he tepped a pace or two back from Phillis; folded his arms a cros his bret, and being not able to open his mouth, he fixed his eyes upon the ground, and tood like a Statue without any life or motion. Phillis eeing him tand o long in this ad poture, he had compaion upon him, and pulled him by the arm: he tarted out of his tudy, and looked wildly about him, as if he were affrighted out of his wits, and aid, Oh God, what fault have I committed againt thy power? Doubtles it is ome great one, ince you uffer me to be o unjutly condemned for a fault which I never committed, and which I never will commit. Thee expotulations, aid Phillis, and interrupted him, are all in vain, for you know, the God of Love is Priviledged above all the ret of the Gods, and that Heaven never puniheth his falities. But Shepherdes, aid Sylvander, do you and Diana alo believe that I have no good will unto her? I do not ay that I believe it, replied Phillis, but I ay that if all be true which is told Diana, he has no reaon to Love you: for do you think Sylvander, that he is a Shepherdes that will be contented to be a pretence for your affection unto another? Do you find o little merit in her, as that he is not worthy to be erved any further then as your talking hore, to hide another amity? Tricks and diimulations may perhaps omtimes deceive uch as do not upect any treaon in them; but when notice is taken of them which rubbed a little, it will preently hew its fality. There is nothing comparable
to a free, cleer, and genuine way in all things; ubtilties, tricks, and fetches, are arguments of a vile and bae Spirit. I do confes (aid Sylvander) all that you ay, but I beeech you what have I done? You know, anwered Phillis, better then any: the thing is made publique, and if you will have it from my mouth, I ay Sylvander, that you have made a hew of loving Diana, whilt you have given your whole oul and affection unto Madonthe: this is a truth which you cannot deny, unles you be the mot brazen faced Shepherd in the whole univere; all the Country knows this, and laughs at it; Diana her elf amongt the ret makes it her rallery; if you be orry for any thing, it is, that Diana cares not for your Love: It is a great credit indeed to be courted by an unknown vagabond Shepherd as you are; epecially to her who is to eminent in virtue and merit; but all our orrows proceeds from our being o much mitaken in you: Tell me truly, Sylvander, what deign did you aim at in all your diimulations? How could you imagine you hould continue long undicovered? And when you were dicovered, could you think to avoid a e • ere but jut cenure from all the world? Diana is Fairer at her wort, then Madonthe is at her bet; the very frowns of Diana, are weeter then Madonthes miles: and Dianas anger is more etimable then Madonthes carees and favours: where was your eyes and your wits Sylvander, when you made o bad a choie? Can Diana believe all this? replied Sylvander: Believe it, aid Phillis, why hould he not believe it, when every one ays it? And ince he has een uch apparent effects of it, for ele why hould you he every way o obequious and obervant of that tranger? Why all that eloquence to perwade her not to depart? Why ele hould you cat your elf at her feet? Nay why tears when you bade adieu? and why that uneaonable voyage which you made with her? Now Sylvander, I tell you all this, not that Diana cares a ruh for it, but on the contrary, he thanks God, that he is o well rid of all your importunities and troubles; my aimes are only to let you know, that all your diimulations and tricks are dicovered, and that there is no more hopes of deceiving us by any arts you can ue.

Thus poke Phillis unto Sylvander, not that he had any commiion for it from Diana, whoe modety was uch, and Spirit o great, that he had rather have died then make any hew that the diimulations of Sylvander did dipleae her; but Phillis did it, becaue he was angry with that Shepherd, and reented the injury done unto her Companion, as her own, And well it was they were o far from the ret of the company; for otherwie it would have been impoible but every one would have perceived the diorder which this dicoure had caued in him, and which indeed was greater then Phillis expected. His regret to ee himelf accued of a fault which he never committed; the los of Dianas favour which he hoped that he had obtained, and the harh language of Phillis, which he uppoed came from his Mitris, all thee did o urprie him, that he was not able to utter one word; he was contrained to lean himelf againt a tree, and growing weak, he fell down to the ground, where uch a faintnes of heart eied upon him, that within a little time, he was immoveable, and without any ene. Phillis, who aw him in this condition, did pull him everal times by the arm, and afterwards, eeing him ready to dye, he ran to a little Rivelet which was cloe by, and taking ome water in her hands, he came and threw it in his face: but thee remedies doing no good, he was extreamly affrighted, and ran that way which he aw all the company pas, to call ome to come and help; but mot of the Shepherds were all gone to their everal homes, for it was neer dinner time; o as he had run long in vain, had he not pied a far off Atrea, Diana, and Alexis, who were going in gentle pace to hear the dipute betwixt Sylvander and Hylas, although Alexis and Astrea had no great deire to be een amongt all that company in thoe habits; nor Diana any mind to be in the place where Sylvander was: o as it eems they walked without any deign but taking the air; and as if the good Genius of Sylvander had conducted them thither, to ee him in that condition. When Phillis aw them, he cryed out as loud as ever he could, and made igns unto them with her hand to make hate, though he was o affrighted and out of breath, that he could not be heard at any ditance, Atrea was the firt that heard her, and fearing that ome michance had hapned unto her: I beeech you, aid he unto the ret, let us make all the hate we can to help Phillis;
for I ee her run and make igns, certainly he tands in need of us. Upon this all of them doubled their pace; and Diana, as if ome Demon had inpired her, did feel uch a kind of unaccutomed temper upon her heart, as made her almot divine what the matter was. When Phillis was come nearer, and within ditance of hearing; Oh Diana! Diana! cryed he out, Sylvander is dead! Sylvander is dead! Sylvander! replied Diana, who killed him? You and I, anwered Phillis, you in commanding me, and I in obeying you. At this Diana was eized with o much orrow, that he could not peak a word, nor go one foot further; making it appear, that in her heart he never believed what was reported of Sylvander, and that what he aid againt him, was only words of an offended Love, which was prone to jealouie. Atrea and Alexis on the contrary, who did highly eteem the vertue and merit of that Shepherd, Alas, alas, aid they, is he dead? It is but too true, anwered Phillis, his face is pale, and all tears; do but follow me a little, and you hall find him in the condition I tell you. Then both of them began to run after her as fat as they could, they preently aw him lying all along upon the ground, and in the ame condition Phillis left him. Diana who followed a lower pace after them, let he hould too much dicover that paion which he deired to hide, he no ooner cat her eye upon the Shepherd, but her cheeks were all tears, which he was not able to with hold, and which to tetifie the orrows of her heart, forced their paage through her eye-lids: And becaue the modety of this Shepherdes would not permit her to dicover this paion, he tayed ten or twelve paces from her companions, and turned her elf fromwards them, eeming as if the accident did not trouble her. But Alexis, Atrea, and Phillis, out of abundance of compaion, were very buie about him; one lifted up his arm, another his head, and a third feeling if his heart did beat; but finding no ignes of life in him, they gave over all hopes, and aid unto one another that he was dead. Thee words reaching the ears of Diana, were o many harp words, which wounded her heart with new orrows: and coming unto Phillis, he whipered her in the ear; Good Siter eek about his arm for the Bracelet which you know of, let it hould be found. Phillis to give her companion atisfaction, and thinking that he had good reaon to deire that none hould know of it, he took the Shepherds arm, and pulled off the Bracelet; But as he was untying it, he and her companions alo pied a mark which in all probability he had worn from his Mothers womb; it was a branch of Mileto, o plain, that any might know it to be o; for the leaves, the berries, and the knots of Branches, although they were not green, yet were o perfectly marked, that none could doubt it to be Mileto.

Whilt they were buie in looking upon this Mileto, and untying the Bracelet, and Diana at a good ditance from them, Sylvander revived out of his woon; but o much amazed to ee himelf in this condition, and amongt o many Shepherdees, that he knew not whether he dreamed or waked. All three did not a little rejoyce to ee him alive, after they had lamented his death; for the vertue and merit of that Shepherd, did get the love of all that knew him. When he revived, Phillis had not quite untied the Bracelet; and though he perceived they had unlooed his leeve, yet he did not perceive the theft, but thought that they only untied his leeve to feel his pule. Alexis eeing that he pake not a word, but let them do what they would unto him, he thought it good to begin. Shepherd, aid he unto him, How comes this to pas? What? Does your Courage fail you? Sylvander taking Alexis for a Shepherdes by reaon of her Habit, he thanked her and her companions for the pains they had taken about him, and then told them, that it was rather a igne of want of courage to endure the mieries which he reented, and not die. No, no, aid Atrea, you are deceived, for it is courage to urmount all manner of accidents whatoever: and believe me, your miery is not o great, but being a man you may eaily urmount it. Phillis who feared that this dicoure would renew his grief, Come, come, aid he, Let us talk no longer of mieries and diaters, but let us think how to cure them. Sylvander then anwered Atrea, taking her for a Druide becaue of her Habit; This Shepherdes, Madam aid he, knows the Grand • ur of my dieae better then any other, and therefore, he thinking it to be incurable, has reaon not to have it poke of. But (aid he, and raied himelf up, though with
pain) the good Genius which hitherto hath had a care of my deplorable life, will conduct me ere long unto a place where I hope to find a cure, though that Shepherdes think it impoible. Upon this, thanking them for their help, he offered to go away: But all of them conidering how wildly and ragingly his eyes looked, they were afraid that he would kill himelf. Atrea, as bet experienced in the like accident, he took hold of his arm, and eeing that he took her for a Druide, Know Shepherd, aid he unto him, that the Genius of whom you peak, commanded me to come hither, as well to help you, as to tell you for him, That he would have you live with aurance, that his aid hall never fail you, neither in this occaion, nor any other: Alo that within three days you hall find ome favourable effects of his aitance, unles you want will and courage to wait the time. Remember what I ay, and I take all thee Shepherdees to witnes that I have told you. Upon this Atrea who counterfeited her voice as well as he could let he hould be known, he went away, eeming as if he did not know any of the Shepherdees in the company, and as if her coming thither were only upon that occaion. Now, ee what power an opinion of Divine aitance has over the pirits of men; Atrea had no ooner pronounced thee words, but Sylvander received them as coming from an Oracle: o as beginning to hope again, thoe wilde and raging looks which depair had brought into his eyes, did leave them, and his countenance became more calm and etled: Afterwards with a religious look, he kneeled down upon the ground, lifted his hands and eyes up to heaven, and uncovering his head, he aid: From you, oh omnipotent Tautates and Tharamis, Do I expect that help which from no other I can hope for: You know my punihment to be unjut, and that I am not guilty of that fault for which I am condemned: Help, therefore, Oh great Gods! thoe injured perons who trut in you. Alexis who aw Atrea go away, and who could not endure to be from her, he intended to follow: and becaue he was afraid let the Shepherd hould know her in Astreas clothes, he would tay no longer: upon thee coniderations, they made a igne unto Phillis to tay with him a while, let he hould follow them: At parting, he aid unto him, Remember Shepherd you follow the good advice your good Genius hath given you, and take heed you do not make your elf incapable of that help and aitance which he hath promied. Then not taying for his anwer, he went away towards Astrea, whom he quickly overtook: And it eems that Heaven would have Atrea render the ame Office unto Sylvander, which formerly Celadon had done upon the like occaion unto Vrcaes.

When Phillis was alone with Sylvander, he was much moved to think what harm he had done him, which indeed was much more then ever he intended: Shepherd, aid he unto him, ince heaven has taken care of your conduct, I hope you will find more contentment then ever yet you did: but I beeech you tell me, and tell me ingeniouly and freely, and with an aurance that you tell it unto one of your bet friends, and one that can keep a ecret, and will, if it concern your good: Is it true or no that you love Madonthe? It is not a crime unpardonable to love a fair woman as he is: There is none but does know that it was the wager which was betwixt us did give beginning unto the Love which you bore unto Diana; a thing which cannot oblige you any longer then the time of the wager, and the caue which gave it a being.

Whilt Phillis was peaking to this purpoe unto Sylvander, Diana though he went away before the Shepherd revived, yet he aw him rie up, for he was continually turning and looking back to ee what would become of him: And when he aw he was not dead, as he once thought that he was, for all her anger, he could not chue but be extreamly glad, and reented as much joy, as her apprehenions of his death caued orrow. Her jealouie and anger had o much power, as to make her enible of the offence which he thought was given her, but not to extinguih the affection which really he had unto that Shepherd; and upon this occaion, he gave an apparent proof of it; ince eeing Atrea go away, and preently after Alexis follow, he was welled with an extraordinary curioity to hear what they two (Phillis and Sylvander) aid, and be uneen, auring her elf that their dicoure would be relating unto her: And in order to this deigne, he crept behind a Buh,
and came time enough to hear the quetion which Phillis asked, and the anwer which the Shepherd gave, which was this, Phillis (aid he) if ever the Gods did punih perjury, I beeech them to punih me with the rigour of their fury, if I do not give a true anwer unto your quetion: may the Druides excommunicate me from their acrifices; may they all deny me jutice when I ask it, may men banih me from their Society, may fire and water, and all the ret of the Elements, be my enemies, may I never thrive in any of my hopes or deires, may all thee cures fall upon me at once, if ever I Loved any but Diana. I know that this word Love is too rah, and does not become me, I know this declaration is too bold, conidering the merits of that Shepherdes and my own unworthines: but dicreet Phillis, eeing your compaion upon me and my miery, and knowing your good will unto Diana; I hould think it a crime never to be forgiven, if I hould diemble the truth: auring my elf, that I hall find you as dicreet in this as I have known you upon all other occaions.

Shepherd, anwered Phillis, you have reaon to trut me, epecially in any thing that rela • es unto that Fair and Wie Shepherdes, ince the affection which I bear unto her, is not equalled by any but your own; and knowing her merits, and your judgement, I will believe all you tell me concerning your affection unto her. But Shepherd you mut firt clear your elf unto me, and give me your reaons why yon were o officious and indulgent towards Madonthe. You know Sylvander that Love is like a little child, & is offended at a mall thing, oon angry, & as oon jealous: do you think thoe extraordinary indulgencies which you manifeted unto Madonthe, the tears you hed at her departure, the earnet upplications you made to wait upon her into Aquitain, nay to go with her, almot whether he would or no; do you think I ay, that all thee circumtances coming to the knowledg of Diana, are not ufficient enough to make her offended at you? Ought you not to have conidered, that as Madonthe would not uffer you to follow her any further, let he hould offend Therander whom he loved, o you ought not to have made the motion, for fear of making Diana jealous, whom you loved? Could you hope for any better looks from her at your return then now you have? For my part, I think he has obliged you in treating you thus, and no otherwie: for if he had, you might have thought her to be in a tate of a cold indifferency towards you, which is a mot certain ign of mall good will.

Whilt Phillis talked thus, Diana who lot not a illable of what he aid, did o approve of it, that if any had een her, they might eaily have known her dieae. For when Phillis talked upon thoe points which touched her mot, he made uch actions with her head, her hands, and every part of her body, as plainly hewed what he o much deired to conceal: but when Sylvander began to peak, he was immoveable: her eyes fixed upon him, and her mouth half open, and ready to convince him of a lye upon the firt excue he hould make: Being then thus prepared, he heard him ay thus: Dicreet and Wie Shepherdes, I beeech Heaven to furnih me with a good occaion and opportunity to requite this compaion which you hew upon a poor afflicted and innocent Shepherd; as innocent and as much afflicted as any that lives upon the face of the whole univere: you accue me, Shepherdes of a crime unto which I am o far from being acceary, much les guilty, as I am contrained, mot earnetly to beeech you, that you would be pleaed to tell me more cleerly and plainly, the ault wherewith you charge me, that I may anwer unto it which uch candid ingenuity and truth as becomes me. Diana who heard him, ee the crafty man (aid he to her elf) he knows not what to anwer, and he would have her make a repetition, that he may invent an excue in the mean time; and then he heard Phillis reply unto him thus; Confes freely your fault Sylvander, here is none to hear or oberve your actions; or if they do, none that will tell Diana: I do believe alo, that he who acquainted her with thee things, did not think any harm, for he poke very imply and innocently: I beeech you, aid Sylvander, what did he ay? She aid, anwered Phillis, that you your elf were intrumental to your own hurt, of which, afterwards you could not cure your elf: for meeting Madonthe, you acquainted her with the coming of that tranger, who had ome bad deigns upon her: It is mot true, anwered the Shepherd, I did o: and I
thought my elf obliged unto it by the Laws of Civility. The Laws of Civility did not enjoyn you to accompany her as far as Aquitane, replied Phillis, much les when he denied you, to fall upon your knees, and with a torrent of tears, beg, nay force her to give leave you might wait upon her, at the leat, part of a dayes journey; telling her, after your tears had obtained leave, that he might well permit you the happines of o hort a time, ince you were to endure o long a torment of abence from her. But here comes the miery of it: when he anwered you with a mile, that though her abence did grieve, yet the preence of Diana would comfort you: you anwered again, Diana merits much more then my ervice, but I pay them unto her only upon a wager: I wih he were to go this journey in your room, and you to tay in hers here in this Country. Do you think Shepherd that any Laws of Civility oblige you to ue any uch dicoure unto Madonthe, and to peak with uch corn of Diana? Do you think it trange he hould be offended at you, and reolve to take all occaions from you, of treating her o unworthily? Oh Heavens! Oh Earth! Oh God! Oh Diana! (cri'd Sylvander) What treaon is invented againt me? Treaon, (aid Phillis) why? Can you deny it? How? replied the Shepherd preently, I ay or do any uch things as thee; I had rather my Sheep-hook were run through my heart, then any uch thoughts hould be in it; do you deny (replied Phillis) that you accompanied Madonthe, as far as he would permit you? I mut confes, anwered Sylvander, that it is true, I did accompany her, but it was upon uch reaons, as if I have done otherwie, I had been blamed by all thoe that heard of it; and that you may know the truth, give me leave to make a hort relation of it unto you.

Diana hearing Sylvander prepare himelf to peak; I am confident (aid he to her elf) that if one word of truth be in his dicoure, it is againt his will and deign; but ee with what a brazen face he ets himelf to lie: Then Sylvander began thus; Shepherdes (aid he) it is long ince Paris was telling how that tranger was come into the Country, with a bad deign upon Madonthe, and when I aw him much troubled how he hould acquaint her with it, I took upon me to make it known unto her: he does not tell (replied Diana to her elf) how ready he was to offer himelf in this ervice, let any other hould undertake that charitable office. In the mean time Sylvander went on with his tory. Yeterday morning (aid he) I met her with Therander, and I thought the blame of all the accident might be charged upon me, if I did not acquaint her, I told her therefore as it was told me, and eeing her eyes flow in tears, I mut confes I was much moved unto compaion: nay paion you hould have aid, (replied Diana to her elf) And I to aure her (aid Sylvander) againt the injuries of this unknown peron, I offered my elf to accompany her with ome of my friends, if he pleaed. He is her Champion (aid Diana) and will defend her againt all her enemies. And o I did (aid Sylvander) but it was no further then the place where Paris aw that tranger: It was (aid Diana) becaue he would not uffer him to go any further. Could I do any les (aid Sylvander) unles I trangreed againt the Laws of Civility and Humanity? If I did any more, then what I have told you Shepherdes, may I be denied Heaven, and perih eternally as a punihment of my crime. But, aid Phillis, did you not follow her as far as Aquitane, or would you not if he had permitted you? Had I thought, anwered Sylvander, that he had tood in need of me, I mut confes, I had accompanied her farther, thinking it the duty of man to help any in ditres, Henceforward, aid Diana, we hall have this Shepherd become the Hercules of Gaul, and wander from Province to Province, to fight with Giants and Monters. But, continued he, that I hould be importunate, or pres her, or do any more then civilly deire her, is a thing o fale, as I admire any hould be o impudent as to invent it, or ay it. None more likely then Sylvander (aid Diana) 'Tis true, I did offer my elf (aid Sylvander) to be her convoy, and guard her till he was out of Forrets. But is it true, replied Phillis, that you did not hed any tears, nor kneel down, nor peak of Diana, nor lament her departure? Now, aid Diana, is he pumping, and preparing himelf for a lie. Shepherdes, (anwered Sylvander) if any one illable of all thee be true, let the Jutice of Heaven trike me dead immediately; let the earth wallow me up alive, and never let me ee the face of men again; let the anger
of Gods and men do all their wort againt me, if all that you have aid unto me be not fale, and invented by ome who wih my death, and has ome deigns upon Diana. Now has he hit upon it, aid Diana, for what pretenions or deigns can Laonice have upon me, or his life? Shepherd (aid Phillis) when you know who it is, certainly you will be of another mind: But you mut needs confes a fault in accompanying this Shepherdes without asking leave of your Mitris. Ah Siter, aid Diana, I beeech you give no uch Name unto me, that Shepherd hall be none of my Servant. You know Sylvander, aid Phillis, that one who loves truly, ought never to dipoe of himelf without the Will of the party loved; why then would you go away and never tell her? He is at a non-plus, aid Diana, and knows not what to ay. Certainly anwered Sylvander, if the journey which I was to take had deerved the name of a journey, I had done as you ay; but ince it was not above two or three miles, I thought neither he nor you could take any exceptions: Beides, Madonthe departed o uddenly, as it was impoible for me to have done it, unles I had failed in doing her that civil office. Oberve (aid Diana) that rather then fail Madonthe, he will fail in his duty to us. But it is impoible (aid Sylvander) that the excellent wit of my Mitris (Raze out the words, aid Diana, unles you peak of Madonthe.) It is impoible I ay, (continued he,) that the Judgement of Diana, which is never deceived, (Unles in you, aid Diana) hould o eaily believe uch a fality: But good Shepherdes tell me, If it were true that I were in love with Madonthe, and had taken upon me that office which Paris gave me, to acquaint her and Therander with the coming of this tranger; If I ay, I was o greedy and affectionate to take it upon me, can you think my violent love would have let me tay o long before I acquainted her? Yet if Diana pleae, he may remember I received this Commiion the ame day that we went unto Adamas, and I did not acquaint them before yeterday. Believe it Shepherdes, thoe that are enflamed with Love, are eldom o low in rendring uch ervices, or to ay better, in forgetting them as I did: for I wear that I never thought upon it till I aw them; and had I not een them, I think I hould have never remembred it. But I beeech you conider, that if I were o far in love with this woman, as you eem by your dicoure to believe, why hould I not follow her whitheroever he went? What conideration hould tay me in this Country? unles my love to Diana, I know no occaions I have ele in it, more then any where ele: My mierable Fortune is uch, that I have neither Parents or Etate to tay me, nor do I get any thing here more then my indutry would get me in any other place. If then I do not leave this Country to follow Madonthe, me-thinks it hould be a tronger argument unto my Mitris and you, that I do not love Madonthe, and that nothing tays me here but the love of Diana. But I beeech you Phillis, Did you not ee that I did not love her before our Wager? I know you will confes you never aw the leat inclination in me that way: I mut confes, that naturally I am not prone unto that paion, But then the converation which I have had with Diana, has forced me to erve her; he has ravihed my heart. I cannot tell what you have thought of me ince I have had the honour to live amongt you; yet I think you have had a good opinion of me, and thought me not without ome Wit and Judgement, till this action whereof I am accued, and which is a diater o fatal, that I cannot tell whether the poor Adrates had a greater. What a gros defect in Wit and Judgement were it, to chue Madonthe, and reject Diana? Diana! the fairet, the wiet, and the mot accomplihed woman in the whole Univere; and Madonthe, who only merits to be eteemed in her reemblance of Diana, though in an inferiour degree of perfection. Moreover, were it not madnes in the highet degree, if I knowing that Madonthe does love a Cavalier, and wanders in quet of him, if I hould pretend to divert her: Thee coniderations are o trong that when I reflect upon them, I cannot chue but admire at the opinion which you have conceived of me, and fear, that heaven which from my birth hath condemned me unto o many misfortunes, will have the end of my life like the beginning.

The Shepherd had many other arguments, and was full of uch dicoure as this, unto which Phillis and Diana did hearken with much attention; for though the opinion of Diana was extreamly prejudicated, yet being rational, thee lat coniderations
did work upon her heart, and made her think there was ome truth in them: moreover, commendations which are given without upition of flattery, do get more favour then uch as are given in preence; o that this dicreet Shepherdes began to relent, and champ upon the reaons which Sylvander urged: yet her haughty pirit would hardly permit her to clear him abolutely, but put the quetion whether Laonice or he aid truly: And that he had learned enough for that time, alo fearing he hould be perceived either by that Shepherd or Phillis, he tole away as oftly as he could, and went to eek Alexis and Atrea.

Phillis alo at the ame time, thinking the Shepherd to be well recovered, and that her tay any longer at that time would do him no good; Well Shepherd aid he unto him, I am very glad to hear as much as you have told me; Comfort your elf, and believe that your dicoure hall not be unprofitable to you: for indeed, when I conider your reaons, I believe you to be wrongfully accued; and I promie you, I will not be mute unto Diana, but hope that ere long you hall find the effects of my olicitation: in the interim, do what is fit to be done on your part, and continue loving that Shepherdes, who cannot poibly be excelled in Beauty and merit by any, nor equalled but by very few.

Upon this Phillis left him, and tayed not to hear the thanks which he would have given her for her kind promies, nor the protetations of inviolable and eternal affection which he would ever have unto Diana, what treatment oever he had from her. But when he was alone, and none to divert him, then did his dipleaures preent themelves before his eyes: And though the aurances which he received from that Druide which was unknown unto him, and the promies which Phillis made, did give him ome hopes, yet the conideration of thoe misfortunes which beel him even from his cradle, did put him out of all hopes, for againt them the arms of prudence & reaon were almot of no validity. Being thus preed with extream orrows, he walked gently towards the River Lignon, and ate himelf down upon the Bank •
Then there was not a illable of that cruel meage which Phillis brought him from Diana, but the olitude of that place did frehly bring into his memory; and he lamented the crosnes of his ullen fate, in a thouand various expreions. He had continued longer in this lamenting vein (had not Florice, Cercinea, and Palinice, with that tranger their companion, who were retiring homewards) heard him, Cercinea knew his voice; and becaue the tranger was deirous to know how they hould pas away the ret of the day, Cercinea aid unto her, that if they were in the company of that Shepherd whom they heard talking, it would be impoible to think the time tedious or ill pent, and I am confident, aid he, when you ee him, you will ay as much as I. But tell me I beeech you aid he, if he be a man, how will it pleae Dorinde? who ays, that if he were one, he hould not abide her elf. I do believe, aid Cercinea, and I dare venture a wager, that when you have een Sylvander, if you do continue your hatred of men, yet at the leat you will ay that Shepherd is not a man: What hould he be then asked he? Somthing more anwered Cercinea, and the tryal will but cot you the time that you hall employ in eeing him. He mut indeed be more then a man (aid Dorinde) if he force uch a confeion from my mouth; For if a God (be it poken without blaphemy) hould aume the hape of a man, he would grow near to become ungrateful, and a Traytor, and I could not chue but hate him.

It eems (aid Florice) that you have a very bad opinion of men. Yes, replied Dorinde, and wore then my words can expres; for I do believe that there is none, no not one ingle one that can love. You will alter your opinion aid Palinice when you ee Sylvander with Diana. I cannot tell what I may do, anwered Dorinde, but I never yet met with any woman who truted in them, that was not deceived. When you undertand, replied Florice, how ome do drown themelves, ome banih themelves, and others kill themelves by reaon of too much paion, you will be very hard of Belief if you do not confes that there are men in this Country that can and do love. Thoe reolutions of which you peak, aid Dorinde, are indeed very high, but anger may produce them as well as love, and who knows but that they were tranported with that Paion? for believe it Ladies, Men are of a very bad Nature, they do all by contraries; they are a kind of Beats, which never do any good, but when they think to do ill.

Thus as thee Shepherdees diputed, they came to the place where Sylvander was, whom they found o plunged in his own ad thoughts, that for all the noie which they made, he never heard them: he lay all along, his head leaning upon his hand, his eyes up to Heaven, and upon either cheek a river of tears. Dorinde after he had looked upon him in this condition; Is this the Shepherd (aid he in a low voice), that never deceived any who truted in him? Why do you ask this quetion? anwered Palinice; becaue, replied Dorinde, if he never did deceive any, he weeps becaue he never did: and if he has deceived any, he weeps becaue he has deceived no more. This Shepherd, aid Cercinea, has a better reputation then o; and is held for a very good man: This reputation, anwered Dorinde, is the talking hore, by which men come to deceive us. But dear friends, oberve how a glas hews thoe things which are on the right ide to be of the glas in its left ide, the bet remedy is to do o with them; take all that they do or ay by contraries: and as for the tears of this Shepherd, aure your elves my Companions, they are but the tears of a Crocadile: he can cry and feign, till he has gotten one into a belief of him, and then he will deceive.

Nature to our miery, has given them power to cry or laugh when they pleae, o it be but to deceive a poor woman that puts her trut in them: they are of a mot depraved nature, and are like unto hunters, who make it their delight in taking abundance of paines to catch a poor illy harmlee Woman that flyes before them.

The earnetnes wherewith Dorinde poke, made her raie her voice o high before he was aware, that Sylvander heard her: and turning her face towards them, he was ahamed they hould o urprie him in that condition: for uch was his warie dicretion, that he had rather have dyed, then give them any knowledg of that real affection which he bare unto Diana: therefore to remove all uch upitions, he enforced himelf to hew them a more contented face, then his heart was; o as drying his eyes as well as he could, and eeming to be doing omething ele: Oh Fair Shepherdees, (aid he unto them) how much am I obliged unto you for diverting me From a melancholy mood. There is none of us, anwered Florice, who are not very glad to pleaure Sylvander in any thing, and thinks not our walk well imployed ince we have met which uch a courteous Shepherd: and the rather (added Cercinea) becaue at the firt we were afraid, let we hould be a diturbance unto you: Oh never, anwered Sylvander, it is impoible but the preence of uch Fair and Lovely Shepherdees, hould bring me all manner of happines and contentment: The poture in which we found you, replied Palinice, made us doubt it: for every thing will trouble us, when we are troubled our elf: Sylvander now conceived that they aw thoe tears which he would have concealed; and to drive them from any opinion that they proceeded from any Love: It is very hard (Wie Shepherdees, aid he unto them) to keep dry eyes, when the oul is preed with any tormenting thoughts; for to conider, that I know neither who was my Father nor Mother, no nor the ground upon which I firt breathed, nor to have any etate or fortune, or any hopes but in my own indutry: are not thee thoughts enough to draw tears from the heart of him who is in that mierable condition? Did I not ay, replied Dorinde, that they were not tears of Love? Though all my Companions would needs perwade me to the contrary. Sylvander then looking upon her, and not knowing her, but eeing her to be very Fair, and Lovely: Why Fair tranger, aid he unto her, can you dicern tears of Love from others? Before you ask that quetion, anwered Dorinde, you hould tell me, whether there be any uch things as tears of Love: Nay rather (replied the Shepherd) whether there be any ele but tears of Love. Why? aid Dorinde, do you think one never cryes but for Love? I do not only think it, aid Sylvander, but I am ure you will confes it when I have made you undertand it; That, aid he, can never be, at the leat I am ure, that if one never cry but for Love, Dorinde never cryed; your beauty and your age, anwered the Shepherd, will hardly excue you from paying that tribute, unles Love be contented, which make thoe only cry who do Love you. If ome mut cry, replied he, I had rather the lot hould fall upon any other then my elf: yet to return unto what we poke of before; be aured Sylvander, that if none ever cryed but for Love, then never any man cryed, for never any man neither did, nor will, or can
Love. This opinion, replied Sylvander, is much wore then the firt; and if you pleae to give me leave, it hall be the firt that I will make cleer unto you. I am afraid; anwered Dorinde, you will but loe your labour, becaue I have had mot certain experience of what I ay, againt which no reaons, nor arguments, be they never o well framed, can prevail or work any effect upon me. But perhaps, (anwered Sylvander) when we ha •• examined your reaons and experiences by a true touch-tone, you may be convinced of your errour, Upon which, he was o prepoeed with this opinion, that he would needs turn the dicoure upon ome other ubject: but her Companions did almot force her to hear what Sylvander would ay, and then the Shepherd began thus.

Amongt all the Doctors in the Mailian Schools, I learned this leon, never to dipute with thoe that will deny Principles: Tell me therefore Fair Shepherdes, whither you do believe that there is any uch thing in the world as is called Love. I do believe, anwered he, that there is uch a paion which is called by that name, and which men are not capable of. We will not meddle with that yet, aid Sylvander, but I am contented that you do confes there is uch a paion which is called Love. Then tel me I beeech you, what do you think this Love is? It is, aid he, a certain deire to poes that thing which one judges good and beautifull. There is not a Druide in all Gaul, replied Sylvander, who could have given a better anwer then this Fair Shepherdes. But, continued he, and turned towards her, is there not in the world ome Animals that have reaon, and ome that have none? I have heard ay, anwered Dorinde, that there are uch. And in which of thee two ranks, replied Sylvander, will you place man? You put me to it, (aid he and miled) for I cannot deny but that they are rational in ome things, and not in others, and mot commonly without any reaon at all. Yet is it not true, (added Sylvander) that men do always eek after their delights and contentments? Of this, anwered Dorinde, there is no doubt: for there is not one of them but will loe the bet of their friends, rather then the leat of their delights. I am atisfied, replied Sylvander then, that you confee there is a Love, that this Love is a deire of that which one thinks good or beautifull: and that men are very earnet to accomplih their deires. Now it will be an eaie matter to prove unto you, that men do not only Love, but alo, that they do Love better then women. If what I have aid, anwered Dorinde preently, will help you to prove what you ay, I will unay it again: and I had rather be reproached with it, then uch a fale concluion and conequence hould be drawn from any thing which came from me. All the company began to laugh at this anwer, and deired Sylvander to continue on, which he did in this manner.

There needs not many words, Fair Shepherdes, to decide the buines: for it mut of neceity be concluded, that ince men have uch violent deires of their contentment, and the will having nothing but a good for its object, or at the leat eteemed o, it follows by conequence, that Love being nothing but a deire, as you have confeed, he does Love mot, who has mot objects of good before his eyes; and the woman being much fairer and fuller of goodnes then man, who can deny but that a man Loves better then a woman, who has not o worthy a ubject to imploy her deires upon? I do confes all, aid Dorinde, until you come unto the concluion which you infer: you cannot, replied Sylvander, unles you take away that advantage which women have above men, and therefore it is better for you to confes, that there is none in all the world that knows how to Love o well as man: yet if it happen that any judg the contrary, it is not that the truth is o, but is like a treight taff, which being put into the water, will eem crooked; and all that we ee through a glas, eems to be of the ame colour that the glas is: for the Meduim by which the ight is conveyed, does repreent it fale to the eye: Even o it comes to pas that the actions of a Lover are een and judged otherwie then indeed they are; and all by reaon of ome defect in the Medium, through which they are een. But the truth is, every man does Love, and this aertion is o true, as one may boldly ay, that all thoe who Love not, are not men; for there was never any man that did not Love.

Though Sylvander was in no fit humour for any uch dicoure, yet he could not but mile when Dorinde anwered: and when he began to offer other more olid reaons
he was prevented by the coming of a great company of Shepherds and Shepherdees, who where all returning to their everal homes, as well to dine, as to pas away ome hot hours of the day in the cool hade, and therefore he deired thoe Fair Shepherdees to give him leave to retire himelf for that time. They who were very deirous to hear him talk, and had a deire alo to ret themelves, epecially Dorinde, they invited him to their Cabin; but he excued himelf, upon a promie, that when they pleaed at any other time, he would better explain himelf upon this ubject.

Upon this leaving them, Dorinde after he had conidered well of him; I mut needs confes, aid he, that if all the men of this Country were like unto Sylvander, when I peak of my hatred unto all men in general, I mut except thoe who live about Lignon.

In the mean time, this great company • rew neer, and thee four trangers having no mind to engage with them, they retired themelves to their Cabins; o likewie Sylvander, who deiring to hun all company: he was no ooner out of ight, but he ate himelf down under the firt hedg he came to, & entertained himelf with his own new thoughts But his good Genius, who had the care of his conduct, being not willing he hould gangrene his wounds too much by being alone, did conduct all this great company which he deired to hun, unto the very ame place where he was, and o opportunely, that when he began his complaints, he was prevented by their coming; and ome of them knowing him by ight, did tay all the ret, to ask him whether he knew where the great Druide was, or ele where he was that ued to judg caues in his abence. The great Druide Adamas (anwered Sylvander) is perhaps at his houe, which is a remote ditance from hence, on the other ide of the River Lignon, upon a little hill, which you may ee on your right hand as you go to the great City of Marelles: but the Druide Cloridamantes is not far from hence, dwelling at an ancient Pallace, which is called Julius, after the name of him who conquered Gaul. Then all the company entreated him to conduct them thither, to the end they might have more peedy jutice upon an injury which had been done unto all the Shepherdees of Lignon, and by one whom they had brought along with them. Sylvander hearing this, and cating his eyes upon the Shepherdes that had been wronged, alo being much moved as well by her beauty and modety, as by the general offence, he thought himelf obliged to conduct them, although he had a great deire of taying alone, to complain againt his miery and diater. He quitted therefore his hady buh, and went before them to hew the way; having an opinion that if he did otherwie, the Gods perhaps would punih him for the offence which others had committed, ince they had directed this company unto him.

All the way as they went, this great company oberved a very wary and trict ilence; which was no mall contentment unto Sylvander, for by that means he could both guide them, and entertain his own ad thoughts. When they were come to the houe, and Cloridamantes undertood that they were perons who demanded reparation of ome injury which had been done; he came into the great Hall, where he was wont to do Jutice unto uch as demanded it: and there entred, not only all thoe whom Sylvander brought, but alo many others who followed them, only out of curioity. Cloridamantes was no ooner entred into the Hall, and eated upon his Tribunal, but an old Pator, holding his wife, almot of the ame age, by the hand, began to peak thus unto him:

Mot Reverend and mot Jut Father, you ee here before your Tribunal, a Father and a Mother extreamly grieved and offended by a new way of Proceeding, and by injuries committed againt them and their only Daughter, all who come to demand Jutice of you: we have brought before you, the offences, the offenders, and the witnees, that when the matter is heard, equity and right may be done according to your cutom, and wicked offenders punihed according to their merits.

The Druide then, with uch a gravity as became a Judge, aured them that the Scale of Jutice hould be held even betwixt both parties, offences hould be punihed, and right hould be done unto them all: and to the end, continued he, a more ound and jut judgment may be given, make choice of one amongt you, who is not
intereted in the buines, who may let us undertand your difference, and afterwards let each party alledg what they can for themelves. Then the old Pator turning himelf towards thoe who came with him, to ee who amongt them was without interet, and knew all the particulars of the difference: all the company cat their eyes upon a Shepherdes who came with them: and becaue doubt was made whether being a woman the Druide would admit of her; yes, yes, aid Cloridamantes, truth is as good from the mouth of that woman, as from any other, provided the parties intereted, do acknowledg what he ays: and therefore if you think her able to inform us of the whole matter, we will admit of her: for the innocency of her age and ex, will be a trong argument and tetimony of the truth. By the command therefore of the Druide, and by the election of all parties, this woman began thus.

div.head: The Hitory of Silvanire.
div.p: SInce it hath pleaed you, mot Reverend Father, that I hould relate unto you the caue of our coming before you, I hall do it with as much truth as poibly I can, or you can deire: and ince you think a Peron un-intereted is required to be the Relator, I cannot altogether ay that I am uch a one; for I am a friend unto the parties who are mot offended: and beides, I am concerned in the general injury that is done unto all the Shepherdees of this Country: but withall I mut tell you, that what interet oever I have, my humour is not to lie, epecially in this occaion, wherein is concerned the life and honour of thoe whereof I am to peak; and ince there is not a Shepherd nor a Shepherdes in all the company, but can relate all the particulars better then my elf, I hall faithfully relate all I know: for from my infancy I have been brought up with the young and Fair Silvanire, (aid he and pointed to a young Shepherdes which tood between an old Pator and a Shepherdes of the ame age) and therefore I have been a witnes to all the paages of that Love, from the beginning until now, which is the caue of our now coming before you: o that if you would know every circumtance which relates unto that buines, none can give you o exact account as my elf. After therefore a mot olemn-protetation to peak the truth, I hall tell you, Reverend Father, that neer this place on the other ide of the River of Lignon, at the foot of that high and great Mountain, which is called Mount Luna, is eated that Village where we inhabit, and amongt us is a very venerable Pator, whoe name is Menander, (aid he, and pointed to him) one that is held of the bet rank and reputation, both for his etate, and for his widom: This age Pator being joyned in marriage many years with Lerice, that wie and dicreet Shepherdes whom you ee next unto him, they never had any tetimony of their mutual affection, but only that Fair and young Shepherdes, whom I named before, and who tands now betwixt them. As oon as it pleaed Heaven to betow her upon them, all their care was to ee her educated in all thoe virtues which beget eteem: and nature (whilt her Parents were careful in the cultivating of her mind) did imbellih her body with as many graces and beauties, as he was able to betow: were he not in preence I hould praie her more: but o it is, that in the pring of her age, he grew unto that height of perfections, that he attracted all eyes upon her, and welled them with admiration at her beauty.

One of Menanders next neighbours, and perhaps alo one of his bet friends, was that Reverend old man, whom you ee upon the other ide of him, whoe name is Arion; a Pator without reproach, and whoe Ancetors have long with great integrity, governed the mall buines of our Village. But I mut tell you, and I hope he will not be angry with me for aying it, that his Father was tudious to leave him more honour then etate: o that though he was well to live, yet perhaps not o rich as ome of his neighbours. Some two or three years before Silvanire was born, Arion had that young Shepherd to his Son, who tands next him, and whoe name
is Aglantes, whom he educated in all commendable qualities.
