The friendhip and good correpondency of the Fathers, the neernes of their dwelling, the beauty of Silvanire, and the inclination, or rather the detiny of Aglantes, made it a thing impoible for this young Shepherd to ee her, and not devote himelf wholly unto her; and he courted her with a deign o innocent and harmles, that none could but think very well of it. Silvanire on the other ide, eeing her elf erved with o much ubmiion, not knowing yet what Love was, did entertain this Shepherd with uch a childih incerity, and good will, that neither her Father nor Mother eemed to di-approve of it: when Aglantes attained to the age of twelve or thirteen years, and Silvanire unto nine or ten, they always played in the fields together, and eldom were they een aunder: and when they returned home Menander and Lerice did make o much of the little Aglantes, that he was more at their houe, then at his Fathers. All thoe that oberved their actions and behaviour, did admire them; the extraordinary indulgence, and continual care of this young Shepherd, in courting this Shepherdes, and her weet modety in intertaining him, was very trange: If the Sheep of this young Shepherdes did at any time go atray, he was never at ret till he had brought them back unto Silvanire: If he chanced to lye longer in bed any morning then ordinary, he was o careful in enquiring of her health, and in driving her Sheep with his own unto the pature, that none living could be more officious and careful: And when he came unto him, he would give her an account, not only of what he had done, but alo of every thought, beeeching her to have a care of her health, and leave the care of her flock unto him. One day, when he brought back a trayed Sheep unto her; Sweet Aglantes, (aid he unto him) which way can I requite all this pains you take for me? By permitting me to erve you, anwered the Shepherd. That payment is eaily made, anwered he; but I fear uch coyn is not good enough to atisfie o great a debt: I do eteem that permiion which I ask at o high a rate, aid Aglantes; that if I do but obtain it, I hall think my elf over payed, not only for thoe ervices which I have already rendred, but alo for all thoe which I hall or can render: Why do you eteem that permiion, continued he, at uch a rate? becaue, aid he, my highet contentment, and my greatet ambition, is all my life to be your ervant. I ee, anwered he, that thoe ervants which my Father keeps, do ask other wages then that permiion. Oh Fairet Silvanire (anwered he) they are not ervants, but varlets, drudges, or laves: What difference do you put, aid Silvanire, betwixt them and ervants? They, replied Aglantes, are mercenary, and erve for money or fear; but ervants, ince all they do is out of Affection and Love; are mot commonly, and may rightly be called Lovers, who are fully contented, if their ervices be but acceptable to them unto whom they are rendred. I do much wonder then, anwered the child, why my Father does not rather keep of thee Lovers, then others; Aglantes could not chue but mile at this implicity: and though in reaon, his age hould not make him more knowing in thee things then Silvanire; yet the freedom which is commonly ued in talk of uch things amongt boys, more then amongt wenches, had made him better acquainted with uch things then he was: he miled therefore, and anwered thus: There is, Fairet Silvanire, abundance of difference betwixt laves and Lovers, not only in that which I formerly aid, but alo, in that one may entertain as many mercenary varlets as they pleae, but they mut never entertain above one Lover; and more then that, none but women can have them: So then, replied he, ince you are my Lover, mut I not entertain any other? The truth is, anwered he, that unles you do me wrong, you mut not. I hall never by my good will wrong you, anwered he with a trange innocence, but if it happen o that any other hould meet with one of thee Lovers who is ill favoured, and di-agreeable, can he never have any but him? Sweet-heart, anwered Aglantes, you mut know, that Shepherdees are not contrained to entertain all the Loves which preent themelves; they have liberty to chue: but when they have once made their choie, they cannot quit them without hewing themelves, either incontant or weak in judgement; and both thee reproaches, are hame unto a dicreet and wie woman. Then it eems, replied he, that if any of thoe Lovers do offer themelves unto me, I may refue them, by aying that I have one already.

I do relate thee trivial particulars, Reverend Father, to hew you, at what age Silvanire and Aglantes began to Love one another. For ever ince that time, this plant o grew, that whooever offered to cut it up, was doubtles punihable before the Throne of Love. But when Silvanire was grown a little elder, and old enough to know the truth of thee Queries which he put unto Aglantes, he learned that every wie woman ought to obey thoe unto whom he owed her being, and not to dipoe of her elf according to her own will, farther then as they approved. And becaue this knowledg came a little too late, becaue Love had already owed uch eeds, as had taken deep root in her oul, and could not be pulled up without abundance of orrow; he reolved, ince he could do not better, to feign that he was free in her captivity. And though this diimulation was a hard task, yet he hewed her elf to have a very great power over her actions. Aglantes for four years together, lived in uch incertainty of her good will, that he could not ay he ever received any other tetimonies, then uch as might make him think that he held him in the rank of common indifferency, uch as he hewed unto all: a mot incredible prudence, for a woman of her age, and certainly not to be parallelled.

At that time, I began to be familiar with this Fair and Wie Woman; and I mut confes that her virtue, her dicretion, and her beauty, made me almot in Love with her: and to my great happines, I met with a mutual return; alo I believe, that upon this, he reolved to retire in appearance, from that good will which as a child he had ignified unto that Shepherd: o as by help of this diverion he was able to be abent from him.

The cold uage wherewith he began to entertain Aglantes, went o to his heart, that it almot truck him dead with wonder to ee uch an alteration: and after he had filled all our olitary places, woods, and caves, full of his complaints; an old Pator came unto him when he was in a dark valley, and thinking that none heard him, he broke out into a thouand ad complaints, which might give knowledg unto this old and experienced Shepherd of his miery: this old man, being long ince a friend unto the Father of Aglantes, after he had harkned a while uneen, he went unto him, and gave him a very harp reprehenion, telling him he ought not to pend his pretious time in uch vain thoughts, but rather in comforting his aged Father, and looking to his Flocks and Family. That the Gods would punih him if he thus deceived the hopes which every one had in him; that this enemy which kept him in uch ervitude, was to be overcome by flying; that idlenes was both the Mother, and the Nure of contempt and want; and repentance would be all the fruit he would gather from it. But the young Shepherd being welled with his pleaing paion, Father anwered he, I mut needs confes that thoe who do Love a ubject which does not deerve it, ought to be blamed and reprehended; and thoe again who do not Love that which is amiable, want judgment, and are ignorant: and therefore for my part, I will cherih my affection; and when I ceae, my life hall ceae with it. As for Arion, I hope he will help me to upport my torment; I know what filial duty belongs unto him, and I have ever found his Paternal affection towards me: o as I hope that when he remembers how he himelf has heretofore paed through the ame difficulties, he will conider mine: and as for you Father, who hews o much good will in your apient admonitions, I do beeech and conjure you to ait me with all your aide and power. Aglantes, anwered the good old man, it is true I love you, and knowing how hard a thing it is for a young heart to be rid of that paion which you reent, I wih you were free from it, that you might avoid thoe evils which may fall upon you, and which I ee almot inevitable: but ince you are reolved, hearken unto the counel that I will give. Does he whom you court deerve to be your wife? I know your paion will make you tell me wonders of her merit; but for this time etting aide all partiality, anwer me if you can, like a judicious man, and ingeniouly tell me who he is, that I may out of my Love to Arion, to you, and your Family, give you uch ound counel as may be good for you. Aglantes knowing this old man to be a lover of him, and all his Family, did name Silvanire. The good man, hearing her named, anwered thus; I mut confes Aglantes, that if you have committed a fault in Loving, you are to be pardoned, and your
crime is commendable: I would yet farther know, whether you ever did let that Fair one know that you Love her: I have pent all my time hitherto in erving her, anwered he; and to my miery, when he was not in an age to know Love, he eemed as if he did know it, and Love me: but ince he came to be of age, he eems abolutely inenible: Perhaps, aid the prudent old man, he does it to try your contancy: Four years, anwered Aglantes, is too long for a tryal; Does he not Love ome other? (asked the old man) The quetion may better be asked, aid Aglantes, whether ever he turn her eyes upon her elf: Did you ever give her any caue, asked the Pator, to alter her good will unto you? Never that I know of, anwered Aglantes. Then aid the old man, believe it from me, and aure your elf, that you will not repent it; he Loves you, and to diemble it, according to the humour of mot women, let other hould ee it, he will not make it appear unto you. I aure you, aid Aglantes, that I cannot accue her of diembling it; for he treats all others, as he does me, and behaves her elf towards all alike: So much the better (anwered the old man) for were he engaged unto any other, you would find much more difficulty in your enterprie; but he does diemble it, to make you the more affectionate; knowing that things mot hardly obtained, are mot deired: Oh Father, (aid Aglantes, and interrupted) I fear that in this you are mitaken, for he cannot wih me more affectionate, then he knew I was. Then (aid the old man) it is becaue her Father has commanded her o to do; and he being wie and virtuous, will not diobey him: but be her reaon what it will, I would advie you to make a hew as if you Loved ome other; for by that, you will know what her deign is: he is extream crafty if he diemble it then; and to tell you truly, women are omtimes tyred with being too much loved: as you ee, there is none but loves light, but too much light dazles, and we are oft forced to put our hands before our eyes to eae them: I do believe (aid Aglantes) that this tratagem might be good in them that can act it; but I mut confes, it is impoible for me to do it: I hould be ahamed that any hould think me of o little judgment, or that Silvanire hould any way upect my fidelity. Oh young man (aid the old one and miled) you are a very novice in the mitery of Love; the hame or the glory of him that attempts any thing, is to effect it, or not effect it: and if a Lover can make himelf loved, that is all he deires or aims at. For my part, aid Aglantes, my deign is to Love her: and, aid the old man interrupting him, to be beloved: To be beloved, replied Aglantes, is above all my hopes. Then Shepherd, aid the Pator, if you cannot eem to Love another, I would advie you however, to let it be reported o; for you mut know, that thee young women, though they hew the contrary, are not always affectionate, when they mile upon thoe that court them; but it is more out of vanity, that it may be aid their beauty has gotten uch a number of ervants, and omtimes out of envie at their companions; but be it what it will, it is till very good for him that Loves, to put them into ome doubts: and if you be not o hardy as to undertake this enterprie, leave the paine of it unto me; and I will effect it for you: it will be ufficient for your dicharge, that when it is a fit time to make known your real affection, to ay that you are not acceary unto the tratagem.

The wie old man made it preently be rumoured abroad that Aglantes was changed in his affection; and every one was apt to believe it, becaue Silvanire was o cold towards Aglantes. But though Silina a Fair and Virtuous Shepherdes, and Daughter to this old Pator, was reported to be his Mitris, and that the marriage was ready to be olemnized; yet Silvanire would never believe it. 'Tis true, it did a little trouble her, but not o much as to make her alter her behaviour towards Aglantes: for Menander her Father had a deign to marry her unto Theaner one of the richet Shepherds in all our Village; and though he did care know him whom they would have her to marry, yet was he reolved to follow the will of Menander. One day, I chanced to urprie her, as he was aying aloud unto her elf, that he could not change, though he faigned the contrary. Silvanire was a little atonihed to ee her elf urpried as he was aying o: but eeming as if what he had aid, was not any thing that concerned her, but only a part of ome ong which he had heard ome other ing, he continued talking upon everal other ubjects: but as cunning as he was, I upected that he was troubled at the report of the marriage of
Aglantes: And by fortune, as if that Shepherd came purpoely to anwer for his own innocency, we aw him afar off coming with a heep before him; as oon as Silvanire aw him, he knew the Sheep; Yonder (aid he) is the man that is to be married, who it eems thinks very little upon it; for yonder heep which you ee, is the ame which I lot this morning. It will be very hard for him, anwered I, not to have Silvanire alwaies in his memory: But, continued I, what do you conceive of that marriage? You mut ask him that quetion, anwered he. But replied I, what do you think of it? I believe (aid he) that he never yet thought upon it, and that he is too young to think of it yet this long time. When I would have replied, Aglantes came to us, who preenting the Sheep unto Silvanire, told her where he found it, what michance it had, and what great care he had of it: The Shepherdes thanked him kindly, but yet with uch a modety as might be called coldnes in any but Silvanire: And becaue I aw Aglantes was a little atonihed at it, though he was ufficiently accutomed to uch uage, to let him undertand why my companion ued him o, I aid unto him, Have you any mind Aglantes, or any permiion to erve any other then Silina? Silina? aid he, and tood amazed, why hould he pretend more unto my ervice then any other Shepherdes? Becaue, anwered I, you are ere long to marry her; Do you think to carry it o ecretly that we mut not know of it? No, no, aid he, aure your elf that my wie is yet unborn: Silvanire could not chue but laugh, and ask him why? Becaue, aid he, he whom I would have, my own mall merits makes me receive a denial; and he who perhaps I may have, my heart forbids the Banes. But I hope, aid I, that when he is born we may know her, and tell us in the mean time (I beeech you) what kind of creature mut he be that pleaeth you? If Silvanire do command me, anwered he, I will tell you. I am very willing (aid Silvanire) that you atisfie my friends curioity. Know then Foinde (aid he, and addreed himelf unto me, for that is my name) that he mut reemble Silvanire in all things; and aure your elf, that if he differ from her in any thing, he hall never be mine. Yet Aglantes (aid I unto him) let me tell you that Silina is a very handome woman, but he does not at all reemble her: I confes, replied he, that he is handome, and has no reemblance of Silvanire, and therefore I have nothing to ay unto her: How? aid I, will you not marry Silina? No, no, aid he faintly, Silina deerves better then me, but yet though Silina were Galathea, and would have me, yet I would have none of her: But uppoe he did reemble Silvanire, and were Galathea, aid I, would you refue her? Though he did reemble Silvanire, aid he, yet being Galathea, I wear by the acred Mileto, I would not have her.

Whilt we were thus talking, my companion made a hew as if he minded nothing but the found heep, yet I oberved that he hearkned very attentively unto us, which made me afterwards look a little more narrowly into all her actions; o as within a few days after, I came to know, that though he made it not appear, yet he did love him: And truly I cannot but admire the widom of this young Shepherdes, who at uch a tender age had uch an abolute power over her own will.

At the ame time Tirintes returned into our Village, he is the Shepherd that is brought before you as a Delinquent, and againt whom, age Clorimantes, all this company demands jutice: I ay, he returned into our Town: for though he was from thence originally, yet was he educated and lived upon the confines of Furan: his Father ent for him home, and as we all know, very unluckily. When this Shepherd was amongt us, he no ooner aw Silvanire, but he fell in love with her, and that o paionately, that many thought him in danger to imitate Adrates.

Silvanire on the other ide, whoe reolution was upon exact obedience unto her Father, and had no inclination unto any but Aglantes, though he hewed it not, he did di-intangle her elf from the addrees of Tirintes with as much dicretion as poible he could; and though he carried a very great indifferency both towards him, and towards Aglantes, and all the ret of the Shepherds who courted her, which was no mall number, yet his paion did from day to day o augment, that he reolved, ince he could not live in her favour, not to live at all. That Shepherd, oh age Druide, whom you ee before you, and whoe name is Alciron, he was alwaies a great lover of Tirintes either by reaon of con • nguinity, or rather, as I
believe, out of that drawing ympathy which makes us love or hate one another: He eeing his friend o unprofitably pend his time and labour in the courthip of this fair and wie Shepherdes, he ued the bet arguments his Wit would afford him, to diwade him from it; and at this time finding him in uch a deperate humour, alo ee • ng no hopes of his cure, he reolved upon one of the boldet pieces of wickednes that can be imagined.

Tirintes had that day driven his Flock almot upon the tip of Mount Luna, as well becaue he would be out of ight, as to have the more cool Ayr for his heep; and perhaps this lat reaon made Alciron to go thither a little before; Tirintes not eeing him, its down under a Fir-tree, eemed for a while to be immoveable, his eyes fixed upon ome certain Rocks which were cloe by; and at lat fetching a mot deep igh, Alciron heard him utter many ad complaints againt the obduracy of his Mitris, comparing her unto thoe Rocks, and his eyes flowing with tears.

As oon as he had ended his ad complaints, it was not long before Alciron would needs help him to condole: oh my dear Tirintes (aid he unto him) how long will this mot lamentable life lat? Are you not weary with hedding uch Rivers of Tears, and raiing o many winds of unprofitable ighs? Do you not know how all your labour and pains is unfruitly lot? Is not Hope it elf (which eldom leaves a Lover) quite vanihed? Is it poible that with the los of thy liberty, thou houldt alo loe the ue of thy reaon? If thou hat thy wits, when wilt thou make ue of them? Mut they be alwaies unprofitably idle? Dot thou think any ervice will ever oblige yonder Shepherdes? Will any Tears mollifie her? Will any pains move her? Or will any Affection or faithful obtinacy win her? Oh Tirintes, if thou art in that error, how groly art thou mitaken? She is deaf, and abolutely inenible to all manner of prayers, or ervices, or tears: She is tark blind, Man land cannot ee any of thoe pains and paions which thou dot endure for her; and what cant thou ever expect in any reaon from uch a deaf and blinde oul, but that he hould neither hear, nor ee, nor reent any thing? Oh ye Gods! replied Tirintes, what would ye have me to do? Command me what you pleae, I am here ready to obey you in all, but only in bidding me ceae to love her. In this, I beeech you pardon me if I diobey; for the fault is not mine, but that all-commanding Beauty which I have not power to reit.

He had long continued his complaints, if Alciron, who could not endure to ee his friend in uch torment, had not interrupted him, with intentions to give ome comfort. The Gods Tirintes (aid he unto him) do know our weaknes and imperfections, and out of their infinite goodnes, will excue and pardon them: But they will not endure the crime of thoe who will make them guilty of their own errors: Therefore, dear friend, Do not by any uch blaphemies provoke their jut anger againt thee. Oh my dear friend, replied Tirintes with a deep igh, ince they do know our imbecilities and imperfections, and will pardon them, doubtles they will not impute that crime for which you reprehend me, for it is weaknes only which makes me commit it; proteting, that my intention was not to trangres their commandment, but when I could not obey them. And to make it appear that it is o, good Alciron tell me, who is he that can love uch a mot amiable piece les then I do? And in loving her o paionately, who can blapheme les then I, if it be blaphemy to ay that I cannot chue but love her? Oh Tirintes, replied Alciron, Do not flatter thy elf in thine own fault, for this paion which you ay is o potent in thee, is indeed only thy own Will, which if thou wouldet urmount, thou hat power enough to do it. I do confes (aid Tirintes coldly) that it does depend upon my own will: But do you not ee that I cannot will any thing but what he pleae? So then it eems aid Alciron, you will ceae to be a man, that you may become a Lover. If being a man, aid Tirintes, be not to love Silvanire, I neither am, nor will be a man. Not to make ue of Reaon, replied Alciron, is not to be a man; and can there be any thing more unreaonable then to ceae loving ones elf, to love another? Is not elf preervation the great and principal law of Nature? Oh dear friend, aid Tirintes, let me not ee the greatnes of my wound; I hope it is not incurable: but you take the coure to make it more deperate: But the tone is thrown, it is reolved upon, that I will die in loving Silvanire; and be aured, that I wih for nothing now, but
to end this life quickly; for here I hope for no mitigation of my pain. And I conjure you Alciron to promie, that when I am dead, you write this Epitaph upon my Tomb, Here lies he that was murdred by the Fairet Eyes under Heaven: I hope, that one day this cruel Fair One, will in thee few words read my affection, and her own cruelty, and the Gods to my atisfaction move her unto ome repentance. Oh how happy hould I be, if in the other life I hear one ay that her Fair Eyes was once wet, or that one ingle tear did trickle down her Fair Cheek: Fie, fie, Tirintes, aid Alciron, why this talk of death and Tombs? Love is the God of life, and nothing can ruine his empire but death: Live, live man, though it were for nothing but to preerve a faithful Lover for this Silvanire whom you Love o well: and for my part, I will promie you, that if you will follow my directions, and do as I bid you, I will quickly give this Fair One unto you. Oh Alciron, aid Tirintes, impoible promies never oblige thoe unto whom they are made; this which I do promie, replied Alciron, is no impoibility, provided you will but do as I ay: then he continued thus.

Tirintes (aid he) I deire as much as I do my own life, to ee you rid of this tormenting paion; but ince I ee all perwaions are in vain, I promie to give you this woman, in a very hort time; he hall be o much your own, that it hall be long only of your elf, it you do not dipoe of her according to your own will: do not think it a thing impoible, for you hall preently find it effected, and confes that I never promied, but I performed. In order to this, within a few days after, he came unto him again, and brought him a Mirrour, in which he forbad him to look; and aured him, that if by any artifice he could o contrive it as Silvanire might cat her eye upon it, certainly he were his own, How? aid Tirintes, is it an enchantment? No, anwered Alciron, but it is a natural power, which is in this glas; and what effects will it caue? asked Tirintes. Nay, nay, aid Alciron, be not too inquiitive; be contented he hall be yours. And what? aid Tirintes, will he Love me? Still too much curioity, anwered Alciron, can you not be contented that he hall be yours? But Tirintes, take pecial heed that neither you nor any other whomoever, look into it; for the conequence will be very bad: and if you hould before you are aware, cat your eye upon it, come preently unto me, that I may remedy the fault which you hall commit.

Tirintes took this Mirrour with much contentment and thanks, and to loe no time, went preently unto Silvanire, unto whom he preented the glas with many upplications he would be pleaed to take it. And becaue he made ome quetion whether he hould receive it from him; as thinking it not handome, for any maid to take any thing from a young Shepherd, without the knowledg of her Parents, he preed her with o many humble entreaties, and arguments of perwaion; that at lat, he would give him that atisfaction; but upon condition, that he would keep it no longer then he pleaed. So after he had looked in it, and much commended it, he gave it him preently back: he who aw his deign was attained, he preed her no farther, but was well atisfied that he had done as Alciron appointed him: but his contentment lated but a while; for preently after, Silvanire was taken with uch a giddines in her head, and uch a drowines, that he fell a leep, and they could not awake her, he was troubled above three hours in this manner, and none knew her dieae.

The noie preently ran about the Town, that this Fair One was poioned, and no hopes of life left in her: you may imagine that Aglantes and Tirintes did run with ad hearts to ee what the matter was: but as oon as Tirintes aw her in that condition, he knew it to be an effect of the Mirrour, which made him o extreamly angry againt Alciron, that had he met him, doubtles he had dyed for it. This villain (aid he to himelf) deigned her death, to deliver me from the affection which I bare unto her: but cruel wretch that he is, he never conidered that my life depended upon hers, and that when he dies, it is impoible for me to live: O thou mot inhumane Tiger! Couldt thou find a heart to hurt this Fair One? Who never thought thee the leat hurt? Certainly, the blacket fiend in Hell was thy Nure and gave thee uck: but Barbarian, thou halt receive a death by no other hand but my own: Oh Tirintes, Tirintes! Cant thou know who did this damned act, and live or breath without revenge?

This Shepherd in this mind, went as fat as ever he could to eek Alciron, tranported with o much fury, that had he met him, he had never told who hurt him: In the mean time Silvanire grew wore and wore, and none looked for any thing but death. Amongt thoe that were in the Chamber, and who, adly reented this los, was the ad Aglantes, whoe grief was o great, that he wooned almot as oon as he. Menander alo and Lerice, whoe hopes and comfort was in this Fair Daughter, eeing her in this ad condition, they repented that they had lived o long, and accued the Gods of cruelty, in betowing o many rare endowments upon Silvanire, and depriving them of her o oon; all eyes that aw her in this tate, were turned into tears in uch abundance, that nothing could be heard but ighs, groans, and great lamentations. At the lat, he being in extream agony, and not looking to live, he forced her elf to peak thus unto her Father and Mother, who tood ighing and obbing by her bed ide.

Father, aid he, I am afraid, let the Gods hould be offended at your exceive orrow for my death; you know better then I call tell you, that life is not more natural then death; and thoe who begin to live, begin it with a condition to dye: why then hould you be orry, that I am now ready to pay that debt, which all humanes are obliged to pay unto death? Perhaps you are orry the Fatal Siters have pun the thred of my life no longer, and your good nature makes you deire, that as you preceded me in life, o you might in death: But Oh my dear Father, conider how good and wie the Gods are; who foreeeing the mierable condition of a young woman that is deprived of Father and Mother, they would not leave me in this wicked world without a guide: if you do but conider this favour which they do me, you will acknowledg it to be the greatet they ever gave me. But perhaps you will complain, that having taken o much care, and betowed o much cot in my education, I hould now be taken from you, when I am bet able to render you thoe ervices which I ow. I mut confes, that if any conideration can move me to deire longer life, it is this; for it is a kind of ingratitude not to deire the payment of that debt which I ow: at this word, her pain forced her to top, and recover a little trength, and he gave leiure unto all that heard her, to admire her widom and courage, thinking her to reemble a Candle, which gives greatet light at the lat end: this conideration forced o many ighs and tears, from all that heard and aw her, as they were not able to peak; o as when he had recollected a little trength, he poke again unto Menander and Lerice in this manner.

I have many things to ay, but my end which I perceive approacheth, does hinder me; only I beeech you both, my dear Father and Mother, to conform your elves unto the divine will of God: and aure your elves, that I hould depart from hence more contentedly then ever I lived, were I but eaed of two burthens, which extreamly oppres me. Menander then forcing himelf to peak, dicharge your heart my dearet child (aid he unto her) and aure your elf, that as never Father had a better child then I, o never child had a Father who loved her more then I do you. This permiion (aid Silvanire) is the only thing that can make me leave this life with contentment; which ince you are pleaed to allow, I hall tell you Father and Mother alo, that I was extreamly troubled, having received o many favours and benefits from your goodnes, and having been hitherto o unhappy in my return of that ervice which I ow unto you both, as I hall grieve in my very oul if your good natures does not make it appear, that you accept my good will, and deires, in recompence of o many infinite ervices which I ow. Then Menander kied her, and with flowing eyes aid, your good deires, weet child, are accepted far above the duty or ervice which you ow: great God be praied, aid he, but alas, d •• e I dicharge my elf wholly? Indeed bet Father and Mother, I want courage, and mut ask a new permiion, or ele I cannot. Lerice and Menander alo, and all that heard her, could not forbear their ighs to ee her pain, and their admiration to hear her peak, even when every one judged her to be at the lat gap; all that were about the bed preed Menander to give her a peedy permiion, which he freely did, and then Silvanire fetched a deep igh, and lifting her eyes up to Heaven to hew her extream contentment, and forced her elf to utter thee weak words.

You have both of you o often taught me, that ingratitude is the mot detetable
vice amongt humanes, as I think the Gods would never forgive me, if I preented my elf before them, tained with that horrid in. Therefore I cannot hide the extream contentment which this your permiion brings me; ince by it, I may not only wah away the crime, but alo the thought that I was guilty of it. Then taking a little breath, and triving againt the violence of her dieae, he continued thus: You ee (aid he and pointed at Aglantes) that Shepherd who tands at my beds-feet, and who eems to reent my icknes o adly, be pleaed mot dear Father and Mother, to know, that ever ince the infancy of our days, he has had o great affection to me, that perhaps not any about the River of Lignon, can equal him, and yet all this while, I do protet, I never could oberve in him, the leat action or word that could offend the mot modet maid upon earth; but the great Gods who know my actions, my words, and my mot ecret thoughts, are my witnees and judges, whether in all this time I ever let this Shepherd know that his amity and affection was pleaing unto me. And yet Aglantes do not think that any corn was the caue of it, for I know you deerve better then what you deire: but it was only the duty of a maid, as I am, which contrained me to ue you o.

Upon this word, feeling her elf extreamly in pain; Oh death! (aid he with a deep igh) I beeech thee tay a little longer, and give me leiure to end that dicoure which I began. Then taking a little breath; Oh Aglantes, aid he, though I have been brought up in thee Woods, and amongt wild Rocks, yet am I not o inenible as they: your Virtue, your Love, and your Dicretion, did work that effect in me which you deired; but knowing that my Father had a deign to <> me otherwie then with you, and being reolved never to di-obey my Parents, I reolved alo never to let you know that good will which I wihed unto you and from hence proceeds all thoe incivilities, and dicourteies which you have erceived from me. But now, ince the Gods, who are all goodnes and widom, have by my death untied thoe knots which tyed my tongue, as ince thoe who have the power over me, do give me leave: Know friend, that never was any greater affection conceived in the heart of any human, then the affection which Silvanire does bear unto you. And that I may be cleerly purged from that ingratitude, wherewith I might be charged, give me a little farther leave, Oh my mot dear Parents; which they permitting, and he thanking them; he hated to utter thee words: Alas! (aid he) I can do no more. Then holding out her hand unto the Shepherd, he aid unto him; here Aglantes,
• ake my hand and my heart, in aurance that though I cannot live the Wife of Aglantes, yet I will die the Wife of Aglantes; and as the lat favour I hall ever ask, or you give, O mot honoured Parents, I beeech you conent unto it.

The Father who had another deign, would not have been o forward if he had thought he would have lived; but thinking her even dead, he thought it good to let her die contentedly: and indeed he had no ooner conented, but he turning her head gently towards her Shepherd: Oh Gods! (aid he) I die, but Aglantes I die thine: Upon this word he grew peechles, and lay as dead in the arms of Menander and Lerice. To relate here all the lamentations and cryes of the Father and Mother, and principally of Aglantes, I conceive it not pertinent; for it will eaily be imagined they were extream: but o it was, that they were forced to take them oft her, even by plain force, and carry them away, for grief did enrage Aglantes: & to remove the occaion of o much orrow, they intended to bury her out of hand, without any Pomp or Solemnity; and had according to the cutom embalmed her, had not Alciron prevented them, who told them that it was not humane to bury people, epecially of her quality, before they were quite dead, at the leat quite cold: o as upon this, they left her without pulling off her clothes, in this ad condition.

Tirintes on the other ide, he was in raging quet of Alciron, that he might open his bret, and pull out his heart, and o • e revenged for the wrong he had done him; and afterwards with the ame word, acrifice himelf upon the Tomb of this Fair One. And doubtles if he had met him, he had done o, though he was the greatet friend he had: but the Prudent Alciron, he went to him in bed, becaue he feared the anger which Tirintes might conceive againt him. At the firt when Tirintes aw him enter, he roued out of bed to run upon him; but Alciron holding
the door half open half hut; Tirintes aid he unto him, can you poibly imagine, that he who loves you the bet of all the world, hould ever deprive you of that which you hold mot dear? And yet cruel Tyger, aid Tirintes, and interrupted him, the Fair Silvanire is dead. Silvanire, replied Alciron, is alive, and I will die the mot cruel death your rage can invent, if I do not put her into your hands alive, and well, within this hour, if you will let me go where he is. Tirintes all amazed at this, is not Silvanire dead? aid he, and did not you caue her to be let in the room by her elf? It is true (anwered Alciron and miled) but he is left there for you; Oh good Gods! Alciron (aid Tirintes) Silvanire to be dead, and to be for me are two things that cannot hold together. I confes, replied Alciron, that they cannot; but to be alive, and be yours may: Surely, aid Tirintes, you do deceive me: why hould I deceive you (aid Alciron) or indeed how can I, when I offer, if you will go with me, to put her into your hands alive and well the ame hour? And if it were otherwie, why hould I come unto you? You ee I do not hun you, nor fear meeting with you. Come, come, et your mind at ret; dres your elf, and come with me, and you hall preently ee what I ay punctually performed. But prethee tell me, aid Tirintes, and hrugged his houlders, can you fetch ouls back after they be once wated over the Stigian Lake? Will Charon uffer that? No, no, I cannot (anwered Alciron) but Tirintes know mot auredly that Silvanire is not dead, but by a ecret virtue of nature, which is in that glas which you had of me, he is o tupified, that every one thinks her o. Oh Heavens, cryed out Tirintes, what wonders do you tell me? I tell you nothing but truth (replied Alciron) and to atisfie your wonder, and perplexity, know Tirintes, that the glas is made of a Stone, called the Memphitique Stone, which has a virtue to tupifie the enes o extreamly, that as oon as it is touched by the eye, it preently takes away the undertanding: And unto this Stone is added ome of the bones of a Fih, which is called the Torpedo, extracted by uch art, and concocted together, that as the Torpedo benums the arm of the Fiher, when it touches the hook that is fatned to the line; o alo as oon as the eyes are touched by this glas, they receive a poyon o ubtile, that firt eiing upon the brain, it dilates a general tupifaction all over the body, as every one would think it dead. Now Tirintes, judge whether I have not reaon to complain againt you, who ever found my extream affection flowing towards you; and yet can think I would offer uch a mortal dipleaure: what advantage could you imagine I could draw from the death of this woman? If it be o, aid Tirintes, and went neerer him, you were to blame Shepherd in that you did not acquaint me with it: By that, replied Alciron, you may better know that I do love you; for did I not know Shepherd, that thou neither wouldet nor couldet live after thou wert deprived of Silvanire, and couldet thou hope ever that thy ervices or thy merits could gain her? I know, that having but that only remedy, thou wouldt never have ued it, if I had acquainted thee with all the effects of it: conider eriouly with your elf, and anwer me; hould I have told you, that as oon as ever Silvanire did look in the glas, he would fall into uch extremity of pain, as he would fall down like dead, and being o judged by all that ee her, they will embowel her, and put her into her grave: anwer me I ay Tirintes, durt you have executed uch an enterprie upon her? No, no, I know what power a peron that loves hath, to make any uch attempts upon the party Loved.

Tirintes hearing this, and knowing that Silvanire was not dead, he held out his arms, and went to embrace Alciron, with uch abundance of contentment, that he was almot peechles; but recovering himelf, he asked a hundred pardons for the anger which he had conceived againt him: and dreing himelf as fat as ever he could, he beeeched him to conduct him unto the room where Silvanire reted, to the end that he who was the life of his oul, might not remain any longer in the lodgings of death. But dear friend, continued Tirintes, by the way as they went, when Silvanire is taken out of the vault, (for you mut undertand that they had carried her out of the Town into one) How do you mean he hall be mine? Yours? anwered Alciron, who will take her from you? Does not every one think her dead? And when he is in your hands, who will ask her of you? Oh Tirintes, Tirintes! learn how to make ue of the time preent, as well as I do: and if you do not, blame
not me, but your elf. With uch dicoure as this they came to the place where the Vault was; where the tone being preently taken away, Silvanire was found in the ame condition they left her, at which Tirintes was extreamly at • nihed for all the aurances of life which Alciron gave him. But to ee the wonderful qualities and effects of ome things which Nature doth produce; as oon as ever Alciron threw a little water which he had in a little Bottle, into her face, and rubbed her pule and temples, he hewed ome ignes of Life; he began to breath, and preently after he perfectly waked. Then aid Alciron unto Tirintes; Here Friend, I give you Silvanire, I have performed my promie, and make ue of your Fortune and opportunity: Upon this he left them alone together, as thinking that he had no more to do with them.

But Silvanire opening her eyes, and finding her elf in that place, and at that time, for it was hardly day, he was the mot atonihed woman in the world; for he remembred all that had paed very well: but he could not imagine how he hould come out of the Tombe: o as remaining a while in her atonihment, and eeing none by her but Tirintes; Shepherd (aid he unto him) I pray tell me what miracles are thee? Fairet Silvanire, aid he, I can tell you no more, but that they are the ordinary effects of your Beauty. But Tirintes, replied he, have not I been dead? and, am I not now alive? You are not only alive, replied he, but can give life unto whom you pleae. If I was dead, added Silvanire, how came I to be alive again? who was able to bring me back from the Stygian Lake? One that is o fair as Silvanire, anwered the Shepherd, cannot tay in o foul a place. This is flattery, aid the Shepherdes, but pray Tirintes tell me eriouly, was I not dead? and am I not now alive? Dead you never were I am ure ince I knew you, aid Tirintes, for you were alwaies alive in my heart. The truth is, the affection of Tirintes unto you is uch, that when death was ready to triumph over you, I changed death into leep, and afterwards, that leep into the condition wherein now you are. Your affection replied Silvanire, changed my death into leep, and that leep into the condition I now am in? How could you do it? For my part I mut confes I do not undertand it.

Tirintes who had no mind to tay any longer in that place, let he hould be found by ome who might mar all the plot before him, he thought it bet to deal plainly, and tell her truly the whole paage. Know therefore Silvanire (aid he) that to atisfie your curioity, after I had loved, erved, and adored you with infinite devotion, and found all to be in vain, I had recoure unto Art. Do you remember a Glas which I beeeched you to take from my hand? I do remember it very well anwered he, for I never had my health ince. That Glas, aid Tirintes, was of uch a compoition, that as oon as any did look in it, they were preently urprized with uch a tupifaction and lethargie, that they would eem to be dead: The ame operation it had upon you; and they laid you in this Vault, from whence I now come to take you out. Oh Heavens! cryed out Silvanire, How dangerous all men are? But what was your deigne in o doing? My deign was, anwered he, to do as I did, that is, to make all believe that you were dead, and afterwards to live the ret of our days together in ome place where none might trouble us. Oh Tirintes aid he, and hook her head, could you ever imagine I would conent unto it? I thought (aid he) that an obtinate ervice might urmount your obtinate rigour. Service (anwered he) which is not pleaing, is always in vain. Love, replied he, did put me into that hope. Love, anwered he, is never the Author of uch Treaon; and that you may find the truth of what I ay, Love will o punih your treaon, that you have quite lot all the hopes of my being ever yours; you are much mitaken Shepherd in your deigns, for Silvanire is not her own to dipoe of if he would. How, aid Tirintes, not Silvanire her own, unto whom is he given? She is his, replied the Shepherdes, unto whom you have given her, which is, unto Aglantes. Who I? replied Tirintes, Did I ever give you unto Aglantes? Yes, anwered Silvanire, Tirintes did give me unto Aglantes: Hearken and I will tell you how: Menander and Lerice my parents, did intend to marry me unto the Shepherd Theantes: And the truth is, by my good will I would never marry any but Aglantes; Death is more welcome to me a thouand times, then to be the wife of any other:
yet I was o fully reolved never to fail in my duty to my Parents, that Aglantes, nor any other, hould never make me fail in my obedience to them. Now being in this extremity of pain, your artifice did obtain that for me, which otherwie I never durt ask; The poion in your glas proved my happines: So as when every one did think me dead, Love did inpire me to ask my Parents conent to betow my elf upon Aglantes, in gratitude and reward of his long and faithful ervices: They eeing me in great pain, did give me free leave to dipoe of my elf; upon which I took Aglantes by the hand, and declared my elf to be his wife: Therefore Tirintes, your hopes are all blated, and it is in vain for you to attempt any further. Come, come (aid Tirintes in a great rage) Menander, Lerice, and Aglantes alo are dead unto you, as you are to them. Upon this he offered to take her by the arm, and carry her away: But the Shepherdes with a greater confidence then the place could allow her, did toutly defend her elf againt his violence; omtimes by perwaions, otherwhiles oppoing force againt force, and omtimes flying. But he eeing him pat all repect, and that her flight and reitance was in vain, he was contrained to cry out: As Fortune was, Aglantes came in upon her voice, who (as I undertood ince) was looking for the Tomb of that Shepherdes, that he might there end his days: When he aw her firt, he had an opinion that it was ome deluion of his Fancy; but afterwards, knowing him to be Tirintes, and hearing her voice, he knew that he was alive whom he thought to be dead: and fell into uch an extream paion, that he fell furiouly upon Tirintes; o doubtles one of them had ended his days, (for they were both extreamly incened) had not a great number of Shepherds come in and parted them; and who eizing upon the mierable Tirintes, brought him hither before you, oh age Cloridamantes, to be punihed according to the quality of his offence.

But all thee that came in the company, did not come upon the ame caue; for the joy and contentment of Menander, Lerice, and Aglantes was o great, that they would willingly have forgotten the injury, or at the leat would have didained all revenge. But their coming is to have judgement upon another difference which hath hapned ince.

Be pleaed to know therefore, oh Reverend Father, That this great Tumult being appeaed, and Tirintes in the hands of thoe who have brought him hither, Aglantes full of joy to ee the fair Silvanire rien from the dead, or to ay better, born again, addreing himelf unto Menander and Lerice, he beought them both that they would be pleaed to conummate his happines by a concluion of this o much deired marriage, as thinking that the delay of uch a happy union could not be profitable unto any. Menander at the firt tood a while mute, eeming as if he heard not; but Aglantes econding his firt deire with mot earnet upplications, he took notice that Menander walking about the room with his hands behind him, he muttered o as none could undertand him, or as if he was deaf on that ear; but he went haking his head, as it is uual for one to do that would deny a requet. This ilence and this action did exceedingly urprize Aglantes; for he thought his marriage o ure, that when he aw the old man make a doubt of it, he firt grew pale, and afterwards was taken with an extream trembling. Many of the Shepherds that were in the room wondering at the ilence of Menander, and his way of proceeding, they drew nearer, and eeing Aglantes in that condition, to wit, almot beide himelf, they feared that if Menander did not keep his word, ome fatal accident would befal his houe; therefore gathering about him, they beeeched him not to trouble their great joys, by uch an alteration as appeared to be in him: But Menander not o much as giving them a look, he walked till on, and held his eyes fixed upon the ground. Friends (aid he unto them at lat) New matters, new reolutions. How, replied Aglantes, New matters, new reolutions? What do you mean by that? My menning is, replied Menander, That when I promied my daughter unto yon, I thought her dead, and o I am contented he hould be yours; But now, ince (thanks be to heaven) he is alive, I mean to dipoe of her another way. Menander (anwered Aglantes) you have already given your Daughter unto me, her Mother conents unto it, and Silvanire would have it o: I have accordingly taken her, I conceive her to be mine, and none can take her from me, but they mut take away
my life alo. Your life (replied Menander) is nothing unto me; but my Daughter is my own, and none can take her from me; you cannot pretend unto her by vertue of my promie; for if promies oblige, Theantes may better claim her as his, becaue I made a promie unto him long before any to you: Therefore Aglantes, if you have a mind to marry, you may do well to look for a wie omwhere ele. Oh ye good Gods (cryed out Aglantes, tamping his foot againt the ground, and triking his hands together) Oh heavens! oh Earth! is there any Jutice amongt men? Is it not beyond the bounds of any patience to endure o great a wrong.

All the Shepherds who heard them talk thus, fearing (and with reaon) ome great diater if this dipute went any further, they gathered themelves together, and were of opinion that the bet coure was to preent themelves before you, and receive uch judgement as in your prudence you hould think mot fit in uch a cae. It was not without much ado that they conented unto it; for Menander thought it an undervaluing himelf and his daughter; and Aglantes could not endure a thing o jutly his due, hould be o much as diputed, or put unto the arbitriment of men: yet at lat, by the mediation of friends and kinred, they were perwaded to ubmit unto whatoever hould be ordained by you.

Foinde had no ooner ended, but Menander tranported with rage, and not taying till the Druide gave him permiion to peak; he tood up, and in a loud voice began thus: I do demand Jutice, Oh age Cloridamantes, againt the inolency of this age; which would take away from a Father, that power which nature hath given him over his child: I do conjure you to maintain, that which all Laws ordains, all cutoms oberve, and all the world approves of: I demand no novelties, ince from the beginning of time, Fathers have ued to dipoe of their own children: I require nothing but what is jut, ince nothing is more equitable then for every one to be the Mater and Lord of his own workmanhip: and I require nothing but what is according to natural ence and reaon, ince it is reaonable, that thoe whom a grave experience has preferred above others, hould be believed and obeyed, in what they advie and appoint. The whole dipute rets upon this ingle point, whether a Father may not dipoe of his child as he will: If the negative, then I have lot my caue; but then I would advie all Fathers, never to care for having any children, nor to trouble themelves with giving any education unto them, ince they are not their children, but their companions nay, their Maters; if the Proverb be true, which ays, Have a Companion, and have a Mater. Then will the Father, who is Lord Paramont in his little Republique, be outed of his Dominion by him whom he bred in his own boom; Oh mot depraved age! I have een the time when if a child had in the leat circumtance di-obeyed the command of a Father, he had been hied at in the treet, and pointed at by every finger: but now, it is grown wit to domineer; it is courage and pirit to light commands, and it is duty in a child to uurp authority from the Father. The name of Father, age Cloridamantes, does ignifie abolute Lord and Soveraign Mater of his child. This being o, I am mot confident that you honour the Gods o far, as to maintain my Title and Prerogative over this young Daughter which is mine, and whom I have brought up with uch abundance of care, cot and paines. For my part, I will ue no other argument but this, he is my Daughter; if he be mine, I may dipoe of her as I pleae. If the dipoition of her be taken from me, It mut alo be declared that he is none of mine: and if I may dipoe of her, I do give her unto the Shepherd Theantes, according to my promie long ince made unto him: of this, Aglantes cannot complain, becaue he has no right but what he claims by promie; but if my promie oblige, then that promie which I made firt unto Theantes, has much more trength and validity in it, by reaon of precedency: and therefore I conclude, that, Oh Aglantes, if you have any deire to marry, you mut eek omewhere ele for a wife.

Thus Menander ended, and Aglantes offered to anwer, but becaue Silvanire thought that his paion perhaps would make him over harp in his argument, he pulled him by the arm and interrupted him, beeeching Cloridamantes to appoint ome other to anwer for them, whoe pirit was les poeed with anger and choller; for ele, aid he, Aglantes in the heat of paion, may utter omthing which may dipleae Menander. Cloridamantes admiring the dicretion of this young woman,
man, and impoing ilence upon Aglantes, he looked amongt all the Company for one that hould peak in his behalf; and after he had veiwed them all, he made choie of Sylvander, to anwer Menander, and plead thoe reaons which Aglantes could alledge. The Shepherd would gladly have excued himelf, becaue he was in no good humour: but thinking it a crime to refue any thing the Druide commanded, he undertook it: o after he had required a little time to conider how he hould frame his Arguments, he began thus:

div.head: The anwer of Sylvander, in behalf of Aglantes and Silvanire.
div.p:
THE weight which you lay upon me, Oh wie Cloridamantes, is a little too heavy for my weak houlders to bear: for it is not a light matter to peak in this place, or to undertake the cleering of the duty from a child to the father, or the authority of a father over his child: there are few here who are not intereted, either as a father, or as a child; and to hold the ballance o even, as it hall not lean more on one ide then another, is not a thing o eaie as many may perhaps think it. Do not think Aglantes, that if by the command of this Reverend Druide, I do undertake to anwer Menander, it is any way to maintain, that children are not obliged to obey their parents; God forbid I hould utter uch a word, for all our ervices and all our obedience that we can render unto them, cannot acquit us of that duty which we ow unto them: neither would I have Menander think that if I do declare the exact obedience of children to their Parents, I do infer thereby as you do, that the Father has power to do what he will with his child. 'Tis true, the Gods have named them Fathers, but has not made them abolute Lords of men; but it is rather to hew the love that the Gods do bear unto them, becaue nothing can more reemble it then the love of a Father to his child; and to teach men that they ought to ask all things that are neceary for them, and expect them from their goodnes. For that tyrannical authority which you ugget, is not that which Fathers ought to have over their children; that does too much reemble the authority of a Mater over his lave: there is a vat difference between a child and a lave. 'Tis true, a Father ought to be obeyed in all things; but till with this provio, that the Father do command as he ought, and according to reaon: for a child is more obliged to obey reaon, then any one that can command him; for it is reaon which gives him a oul, and makes him different from irrational animals: and this oul is it which gives him his very being. A man, Menander, is compoed of a oul and a body; the body he has from his Father, but that is common with all brutes: The oul he has from God, and this oul is rational: conider now, whether a man be obliged more to him that gives the body, or to him that gives the oul; I think then you will conclude with me, that a child is not bound to obey the command of the Father, if the command be againt reaon; for in uch a cae, his obedience would be a in: and therefore I ay, Fathers have no uch abolute power as you imagine, nay perhaps they have no power at all, if they go beyond the bounds of reaon: 'Tis true, the child ought not of himelf to judg whether the commands of the Father be jut or unjut, or unreaonable, unles they be o apparently gros that common ence will hew them o, but if the child do at any time doubt, he ought alwayes to incline towards the obeying ide, and that he think his Father more wie and better able to judg then himelf, until thoe who are contituted judges, do determine and declare it otherwie. Now, the cae which is preented before you at this time, Wie Cloridamantes, is of this nature; for here is Menander, who is not willing that Silvanire hould marry Aglantes, but would have her marry another Shepherd; he who is wie, and knows how far the name of daughter does oblige her unto obedience, he preents her elf before you, to know whether the command be reaonable or no: It is you, Wie Druide, that mut et down the Law unto her, for he
is ready to obey it; the reaons of Menander are that abolute power which he pretends unto over his child: that the promie which he made unto Aglantes, does not oblige him for two reaons; the firt, becaue he promied Theantes before: the econd, that though he did promie her unto Aglantes, yet it was when he thought his daughter would dye that ame hour. The reaons of Silvanire and Aglantes (for they are ineparable) are, that the promie which he made unto Theantes, was never conented unto by Silvanire; and her conent unto Aglantes was not only in the preence of Menander and Lerice, but alo by their permiion, conent and approbation: that the eence of marriage conits principally in the will of the two parties who do marry, and therefore reaons tels her that he is more obliged to perform this lat promie, then that which Menander made unto Theantes, unto which he was never privy, though had he been called, he would have conented. As to that point of Menanders, that his intention was not to uffer this marriage, but only becaue he belived his daughter would dye the ame hour; Aglantes anwers, that contracts are never made by thoughts, but by words: for thoughts are not to be dived into.

Sylvander would have proceeded, when Menander tranported with extream impatience, did interrupt him: But upon the firt word he uttered, Cloridamantes commanded him to be ilent, and Sylvander alo, when he offered to continue his dicoure, telling them, that the cae was well enough undertood, and therefore there needed no more time to be pent. At the ame intant Theantes deired audience, and in a loud voice aid, Oh wie Cloridamantes, there is no greater folly under the Sun, then to love without any hopes of ever being loved again; and marriage is a mot mierable torment when it is not tyed with mutual and reciprocal knots, and therefore I conclude and declare, that Silvanire may marry, but never Theantes: Upon this he made an humble reverence to the Druide, and the Aembly, and went his way.

Cloridamantes then roe up to ask the opinion of other Druids, and to give judgement upon the cae; But Tirintes, who could not with any patience endure to hear that Silvanire hould be given unto any other, he aid with a raging voice, and incened eye, Who is he that does accue me? and why am I kept here a prioner? Foinde then began to peak; Wicked Shepherd, aid he unto him, Dare you be o impudent as to ask why you are kept here, or who will accue you? Does not your own concience tell you, that never was a greater malefactor brought before the Tribunal of any Jutice? Does not every thing, every circumtance accue you of Treaon and Infidelity? The Heavens that ee you, the Earth that bears you, Trees, Men, Gods, and all things, oh perfidious and mierable Shepherd, do accue you, and call for vengeance upon your crime.

Every one wondered to hear Foinde give uch tart language; for there was very few in the whole aembly who did not know that he loved Tirintes, and though unfruitfully, yet had done long; o as to ee her now thus exaperated againt him, it eemed much againt the tream of her long continued cutome, and it was trange that her extream affection hould o oon change it elf into uch an implacable hatred, as he would have made him loe his life. But Tirintes tood till, and without any alteration in his countenance, Speak (aid he) unto the Judges if you have any charge againt me, it is they from whom you mut have jutice: Do you think I have not courage enough to abide all your objections? Foinde bluhed at thee words, and turning towards Cloridamantes, he beeeched him to it down again, and hear what he could ay; and then he began thus.

This impudent Shepherd, oh wie Cloridamantes, who is brought before you, is the mot worthy of death of any man that lives; he ays he loves Silvanire, but who believes him? Nay, who can believe him if they conider his actions? Mot certainly he never knew the power of Love, though to excue himelf, he would cat all the fault upon that God. For what are the effects of love? To erve, to honour, nay even to adore the peron that is loved: But what witnees does this wicked Shepherd give of his affection unto Silvanire? In lieu of erving her, he gives her poyon; he caued her to be buried alive, and uffer intollerable torments; in lieu of honouring her, he would have blated her reputation, and made her the mot infamous
Shepherdes that lives: if thee be the effects and conequents of Love, I dare ay that Love has changed its Nature: But haply he will be apt to ay, that thee are meer impotures, and aperions cat upon him, and that he did never commit any uch crimes. Sage Druide, here is the wicked man, he cannot deny it, his concience flies in his face, and ties his tongue: The truth is, his vilany is o great, that it is hard to find words to excue it under the umbrage of a Lover, or with any gloes of affection and fidelity: To give poyon unto a poor innocent woman o ubtilly couched in a glas, what excue under heaven is there for uch a black horrid invention? He cannot glos it over with an excue of ignorance, nor ay that Alciron did not tell him the effects of it; for it is mot infallibly certain, his intention was to make her die, and be revenged upon her for loving another, or at leat, for having no inclination unto him: But eeing his deign frutrated, perhaps by the trong contitution of Silvanire, which reited the poyon, or as it is mot probable, by the Will of God, who would not deprive the world of o fair, o wie and weet a woman, to excue or extenuate his crime, he mut pretend that his intention was only to cat her aleep. But oh age Druide, I beeech you ask the good Menander, Lerice, Aglantes, and all thoe that aw her in the Agony he was, whether in any leeping fits they ue to have uch cruel pain, uch convulions, uch contraction of Nerves, and o many ymptomes of inevitable death; and then judge whether it was not a mot mortal poyon, which the Gods by a miracle made ineffectual to his intentions. But this cruel Barbarian, not being atisfied with her death, but he would alo with the ame cruel eyes ee her in the Tomb, to glut his cruelty; and finding her revived, he never offers to ask a pardon, but would carry her into ome deolate place, God knows where, and certainly, but for the relief of thoe Shepherds which came in upon her cry, he had executed his mot wicked deigne. Judge now, jut Cloridamantes, whether in all this there be the leat hadow of any Love: Conider, that if uch a Treaon as this pas unpunihed, there is no afety for any Shepherdes to live in Forrets; How can we guard our elves againt uch violences? I beeech you therefore let us dwell afely in our houes, and quietly in our fields; and make this man exemplary, by inflicting uch evere punihments, as may be a terror unto others. Thus pake Foinde, who after a low congie unto the Druide and the ret of the Aembly, he fate down in her place. Every one were atonihed to hear this tart accuation, Tirintes only tood un-amazed; for having lot his hopes of Silvanire, he valued not his life: But making a igne that he deired to peak, and the Druide permitting him, he anwered thus.

This Shepherdes, mot wie Cloridamantes, is in the right, when he ays that I have done ill; but he is in the wrong, when he accues me of a crime unto which I never conented, but am as innocent as her elf: No, no Foinde, I refue not one of thoe torments or punihments which are prepared for me, and which I know are my due; I will not excue my elf, for I cannot; and aure your elf, that though I could, I would not: But bitter and malicious Shepherdes, Why hould you add fale crimes unto crimes that are true? You had no reaon in the earth for it; for thoe which I have committed, are ufficient to glut your oul, be it as cruel as it can be. Oh Cloridamantes, the affection which I bear unto the fair Silvanire, is too great to make me think of any uch impieties as Foinde fally charges me: It is true, I did give poion unto the Fair one, but it was becaue I was deceived by the words of him whom I could not upect to have any uch thoughts. Let the fair Silvanire tell you how he found Alciron and me about her, when he awaked, with a Bottle of Water which we cat in her face to awake her. All thoe of Menanders houe can tetifie, that it was Alciron who hindred that Faire One from being embalmed, let it hould have hurt her: Oh Cloridamantes, Could I but be declared innocent of this impoture, I would willingly confes all the other crimes which are charged upon me, I value not the torments of death a ruh, o my love and my fidelity be preerved pure and innocent, for them do I extreamly deire to carry with me unblemihed into the other world.

Thus poke Tirintes, leaving all the Auditory ravihed at his reolute alacrity and pittying his mi-fortune: Alciron who could not endure to ee his friend thus at the take, and himelf the author of the crime: Sage Druide, (aid he) Tirintes is not
only cleer and free from any guilt againt Silvanire, concerning the glas which I gave unto him, but alo from all the conequents of it: for firt, though the glas be broken, yet the pieces are to be een, and eaily tryed whether the compoition be mortal poyon, or only of a tupifying quality. It is compounded of uch ingredients as Foinde hath named: here are the pieces, and tryal of them if you pleae may be made; then he pulled out his handkerchief wherein he lapped them up, when Tirintes in anger againt Foinde broke it. Every one turned away their eyes, let they hould be tainted by the virtue of this Stone, and Cloridamantes himelf commanded him to put it up; no, no, aid he, I cannot believe that either you or Tirintes had any uch abominable intention; becaue it is an act o extreamly horrid, as it cannot be imagined it hould enter into the thoughts of any in this Country: but if you have any thing to ay which will quit Tirintes of the violence which he offered unto this Shepherdes, you may peak it before all this Aembly. Then Alciron offered to peak as to that, when Tirintes interrupted him; Peace, peace, friend, aid he unto him, for I will dye; and happy is he that dyes who cannot live happily. Yet I thank thee hartily for thy good will, and evidencing that it was not my intention to make Silvanire dye, whoe life I beeech the Gods preerve to eternity. But for all this, the affection of Alciron made him begin to peak; yet he had no ooner uttered the firt word, but Tirintes interrupted him again. Oh age Druide, aid he, it is only compaion upon his friend, and not the truth, which makes him trive for ome arguments to defend me, for my part, I diavow what he ays, and beeech you not to believe him, but to do Jutice according to the Law.

Cloridamantes then, after he had impoed ilence upon Alciron and the ret, he aroe from his eat, and went to gather the voices of the other even Druides; for when the life of any one was in quetion, they were to call that number at the leat to ait them. The time which he imployed in taking their votes, was very long, becaue there was ome difference of opinions concerning the judgement. Tirintes being reolved to dye, ince he had no hopes to obtain Silvanire, all delay was tedious unto him: Aglantes and Silvanire, who thought the pain no les then a death to be eparated one from the other, they expected the iue of their enterprie with incredible impatience: at the lat, the Druide after a long dipute and debate of the matter, came and took his eat; then pronounced thee words.

div.head: The Judgement of Cloridamantes.
div.p:
WE Cloridamantes, being etablihed in the abence of Adamas our Arch-Druide, by the Great Tautates, by Amais, and by all the order of Druids and Cavalry, to do Jutice in this Country of the Seguians; after a full hearing of the difference that is betwixt Menander and Lerice of the one part, and Aglantes and Silvanire on the other: and alo of the accuation preferred againt Tirintes for an attempt againt Silvanire, after a long olemn and erious debate, and conideration of the premies, We do Sentence and declare, that a Father and a Mother, have by the Laws of God and Nature, all that power and authority which can be had over free perons; and that their children in this quality cannot diobey them without offence againt Laws both divine and humane: but withal, we Sentence and declare that children are not born laves, but free: for otherwie it were a hame for Fathers to get none but laves; and it would be a mot mierable blemih to the Country, that it of all Gaul hould produce none but people of uch vile quality: for thee caues therefore, and for many other jut and good coniderations us thereunto moving, we do ordain, publih and declare, that marriages be free, and that no contract be but with conent of both parties that are to tye themelves together with that holy knot: and that the rigour and compulion of Fathers in uch caes, be held as tyranny, and be null. Upon thee grounds this contract betwixt Aglantes and Silvanire is declared to be firm and indiolvable, all due circumtances and conditions being oberved. And furthermore, as in Jutice to Tirintes, ince, lights,
ubtilties, and artifices are permitted by the Laws of Love, we do publih and declare him free and abolved from the fault which he is charged with by the artifice of the glas; but in as much as all manner of force and violence is exprely forbidden by the Laws of Love, and ince it is averred that he hath made violent attempts upon the peron of her whom he loved, we do declare him guilty of high Treaon, againt that great God and his Laws, and therefore we do doom and condemn him to be thrown down headlong from the Fatal Rock.

The faces of all the Company were full of great joy, and of great orrow at this Sentence; Aglantes, and Silvanire, and their friends, eeing their marriage was declared according to their wihes, their joyes were tryumphant: on the other ide, abundance of Shepherds and Shepherdees grieved for poor Tirintes; for he was a very kind and courteous Shepherd, and uch an accident had not hapned of a long time.

So as every one was very orry for him, and blamed Foinde for her bitter and malicious accuation. Tirintes himelf was the only one who eemed not to be troubled at it: for he received the Sentence of death with a miling and contented countenance; and turning towards Silvanire, Shepherdes, aid he unto her, I hope that now you are contented, and indeed o hould I be, if I did but go out of this world with a pardon from you: Tirintes (aid he unto him with tears in her eyes) if your life were in my power, as well as a pardon, be aured you hould live many years: for I do not only pardon, but pity you; and hall grieve for you as long as I live. Then Tirintes kneeled down upon the ground, and mot hartily thanked her and aid, that he hould be more happy in his punihments, then ever he was in his ervices.

In the mean time, Foinde eeing her deign did hit according to her wih, he went unto Tirintes; Shepherd, aid he unto him, It joyes my oul to ee you reduced unto this point which I have o long and o much deired: and I, aid Tirintes, am alo very glad my death will give you o much contentment, and I hall leave the world without any rancor or malice in my heart. Oh Tirintes, Tirintes! (aid he unto him) you hall know ere it be long, that I am as free from any malice or rancor as you, and that my own life is not o dear unto me as yours: alas, all that I have done is only out of the excee of my love; then addreing her elf unto Alcas her Father; Father, aid he unto him, you promied that you would very willingly give me leave to chue my Husband; mot true, anwered Alcas, and I will perform it, for I do not approve of the humour in Fathers to be tyrannical towards their children. Then addreing her elf unto Cloridamantes, and the other Druide. Oh age and jut Judges (aid he unto them) you have according to the Law condemned Tirintes to die: and by the ame Law, I do demand him for my Husband, and by that means, free him from that punihment, unto which he was condemned.

Upon this all the Aembly houted, and clapped their hands in ign of joy, and aid with an univeral voice, Thanks, thanks. Then did all the friends of Tirintes run to imbrace him, and rejoyce with him. Every one commended the good act of Foinde: for it was a Law mot religiouly oberved, that if any woman came to demand a condemned peron for her husband, he hould be delivered unto her. Menander and Lerice, only looked but half contented, and could not conent unto the marriage of Silvanire; but eeing the publique joy, and Aglantes upon his knees with Silvanire, at their feet, their anger began to cool, and they imbraced both Aglantes and Silvanire with a joyful countenance, and confirmed the Sentence of the Druides. Then all the Aembly rejoyced: and Cloridamantes, who by the force of the Laws had condemned Tirintes, was very glad of uch an occaion to deliver him; and therefore cauing ome Chaplets of Flowers to be brought; he firt put two upon the heads of Silvanire and Aglantes; and afterwards turning towards Foinde, here Shepherdes (aid he unto her) take this which I put upon your head, and I leave the other in your hands; give it unto Tirintes, for a tetimony that you have given him both his life and Foinde.

The Shepherdes rendred mot humble thanks for the favour, and aid, I do take this which you have given to me, and put it upon the head of Tirintes, and I do
take his, and put it upon my own, in witnes that we will never be eparated. And now, ince uch an univeral joy was unexpectedly fallen upon them all, it was thought fit to go into the Temple, and thank the Gods: And ince the impatience of thee two Lovers were very great, it was reolved upon, that they hould then be married, and the ret of the ceremonies be performed afterwards, when they returned to their homes. But Sylvander who could not endure to be amongt o many joyful and contented perons, after he had received many thanks from Aglantes and Silvanire, he left the company, and went into the Woods to lament his own mierable fortune.

Diana and Phillis who dined that day with Atrea to keep Alexis company, being rien from the Table, and the quetion being put how they hould pend the ret of the day, they were advertized that a certain tranger was come, who was exceedingly deirous to ee Atrea, o as (aid they that did advertize them) unles you make very great hate away, aure your elves he will be before you, which if he be, you mut reolve upon her company all the day. Alexis who was extreamly afraid of any uch diverions; oh God, good Servant, aid he, let us not tay her coming, for we hall not be rid of her all the day; and if I be in o long a contraint, I hall mot infallibly be icker then I was in the morning: Atrea laughed to hear her ay o: Dear Mitris (aid he) command, and be obeyed: I think it bet, anwered Alexis, to take our own habits, and go to meet her: This motion was no ooner made then executed, and the more peedily, becaue Diana who conducted them, did make more hate then uual, becaue he was exceedingly deirous to ee this tranger, who inveighed o much againt men, of whom h • had as bad an eteem, though he knew how to cover it dicreetly.

When Florice aw thee Shepherdees afar off, ee Dorinde, aid he, how courteous the fair Atrea is, who knowing your coming, prevents you in civility, and is coming to meet you. I hould be ahamed, anwered he, that all thoe dicreet Shepherdees hould take o much pains for me, but I mut confes I have an extream deire to ee them. Since it is o (aid Circinea) and if you would not be overloadned with curteie, let us go as fat as we can to meet them, to the end they may know, that if you had known their deigne, you would not have put them to that trouble. Upon this, the four trangers taking hands, they went as fat as they could towards thee fair Shepherdees, who received them with uch free expreions and tetimonies of good will, that Dorinde could not enough admire them, both for their Beauty and their Civility. Alexis alo was not a little in their eteem, who knew how to play the woman o well, that not one of her actions did belye that name: and becaue Dorinde oberved that every one did bear a great repect and honour unto the Druide, he thought it becoming her to do the ame; o as addreing her elf unto her, Madam, aid he, one of my wihes is accomplihed, for I have very long deired to ee Lignon, and all thoe Beauties about it; and I ee heaven is very favourable to my deires, in letting me ee the bet firt. I confes, aid the Druide, that when you ee Atrea, Diana, and Phillis, you have een the glory of Lignon, which heaven hath favoured above all the Rivers in Europe; and there is none precedes thee whom ye ee before your eyes. Thee commendations (aid Atrea) which it pleaes the fair Druide to betow upon us, are tetimonies of that honour which he confers upon us by her love; my companions and I do receive them upon that account, though they be much above our merit: But fair Shepherdes, I would not have you deceived by them; let that belief hould caue you to eteem les of the Shepherdees of Lignon; for do not think, that though thoe you ee here have no great matter of Beauty to boat of, that the ret are the ame, auring my elf, that when you ee them, you will confes that they do not deerve contempt: As for us, we beeech you to love us, not in the quality of fair, but of good, and as thoe that do highly deire the honour of your favour, and are ready to pay thoe duties of Service and Civility unto you, which by the cutome of our Country, and your own merits we are obliged unto. Atrea (aid Dorinde, for I know that is your name by the luter of your Beauty) I ay fair Atrea, I do think the pains of my journey to be highly recompenced by the very ight of you, and I find my elf beyond all meaure atisfied, when I conider your fluent curteie and civility; but let me tell you, that
