I am infinitely ahamed in not being able to requite it. Their complements had continued longer,, if Florice, who was much offended by the too much luter of the Sun which hined full upon them, had not interrupted; wherefore he beeeched the Druide, and the ret of the Shepherdees, to honour her o far as to hade themelves under her Cabine, which was cloe by the River Lignon, and haded with everal leave-preading trees; o as the motion being accepted, they went that way, to pend part of the day under thoe hady trees, till the heat of the day was a little over.

Diana remembring the promie which that tranger made, of telling her the reaon of her hatred unto men, and finding her elf in a good humour, Fair Shepherdes (aid he after they were et) we have a cutome amongt us, that we eteem all promies to be due debts: we do hold the obligations as firm, and reckon upon the payment, as certainly as if it were indented and ealed; and therefore I beeech you, do not think it trange that I hould in the preence of this good company ummon you to the payment of that debt which you owe unto me; and I conceive that beides your promie, the time, and the place, and every thing does invite you to it. Although (anwered Dorinde) I were not obliged by my promie, yet hould I be very ready to pay obedience unto any thing you hall either command or deire; I am orry for nothing, but that what I hall tell you, will not be worth the time that will be pent in hearing: Yet ince it is your command, I had rather fail in obeying you, then in not atisfying your deires. Then after a while of ilence, he began thus.

div.head: The Hitory of DORINDE, of PERIANDER, of MERINDOR, and of BELLIMARTES.
div.p:
IT is with great reaon that learned Phyicians ay, Interior dieaes are mot dangerous, and difficult to be cured, becaue the ight cannot reach them, they know by conjectures only what they are: The heart, and the mot noble parts, are more eaily infected, and ooner eized upon, then thoe that are without us. The dieaes of the oul, are the ame with the dieaes of the body; and thoe which do proceed from things without us, are much les dangerous then thoe which are from within us. I do call thoe things which are without us, Riches, the favour of others, health, icknes, and briefly, all things upon which Fortune has a Soveraign Authority: And I do call thoe things which are within us, every thing that does depend upon our own wills, and within the power of our own ouls: For it is but little hurt that Fortune can do unto one that is reolved, and fully intends to do what they ought in every thing. But on the contrary, when the Will and the Undertanding are infected and corrupted, every trifle is a torment, and he mut look for a cure from the party from whom his malady proceeds. I peak all thee things (mot fair and dicreet Shepherdees) by experience, for I have found them in my elf, and to my cot do know, that a prejudicated undertanding does deceive the Will, which is blind, and miled by every thing which it judges good. But oh God, of all poyons which does mot eaily invenome us, there is none more dangerous nor wore to be avoided, then the treachery of men; for, as if they were our worn mortal enemies, they will attempt any thing in the world to venome our ouls with their poyon: If we have high pirits, they will fall down upon their knees, even upon the bare ground, they will honour, reverence, and adore us, they are our very laves, they will not live but to obey us, and will not change their ervitude for an Empire: If they meet with a more inferiour or humble oul, what ervices will they not offer? Into how many hapes will they transform themelves? What will they not invent to pleae her? How many Balls and Treatments will they give?
how will they pruce up themelves in variety of habits? And how careful will they be to render themelves pleaing in the eyes of thoe whom they have any deigns upon? And why all this art, care and paines to pleae, but only to win upon thoe whom they will afterwards deceive, or rather kill with grief and vexation at their perfidies and treaons? I am ure, the tory which you deire to hear, will make this mot apparent unto you, which I am the more willing to relate, becaue I may make others more prudent and wary by my example, and by the knowledg of all ubtilties and treaons of men. Be pleaed to know therefore, Madam, and all you Fair and Dicreet Shepherdees, that the ancient City of Lyons was the place of my birth, where my Ancetors ever held themelves of the prime Rank: the name of my Father is Arcingentorix, and my Mothers Alcinea; he left me when I was in my Nures arms; but my Father with abundance of care did educate me in all the accomplihments fit for a woman of my quality, as dancing, inging, everal Intruments, and uch Ornaments; by which he did o imbellih my youth, that many of the bet Rank did Court me in the way of marriage: but my Father, who deired to marry me very advantageouly, and aw me yet very young, he waved all motions that were made, to ee if any better match would offer it elf unto me: I mut confes, that omtimes I was angry at it; and at that time blamed the Prudence of my Father, which I now commend; now I ay, ince I know how mierable that woman is who is a ubject unto the ervitude of Tyrants; which are called indeed Husbands by our Fathers, who are in effect the executioners of mens Tyranny.

The firt that cat his eyes upon me, or at leat, whom I took any notice of, was one called Theombres, who ince married Florice. I was then of an age o innocent, as I did believe my elf in no fault if I did believe him. But the clownih behaviour of that man (be it poke without offence unto Florice) together with my young years, which had not made me capable, but inenible of uch addrees, and the hort time he tayed there, did defend me from any wicked deigns he could have upon me; for whether he had already erved this Fair Florice, whom he ince married, or that then he began to love her pree • tly after, I cannot tell; but o it was, that his addree erved to no other purpoe, but to teach me (if I had made ue of it) that all men are deceivers; and that the mot contant amongt them, is like unto a Camelion, which changes colour, according to the objects it looks upon.

Almot at the ame time Periander, a young and lovely Cavalier, and owner of many excellent qualities, free from the vices of cutom, which are in all men, he would make me believe that he was in Love with me. And becaue his Fathers houe was not far ditant from the place where I dwelt, he had all the convenient opportunities of hewing his good will, that he could deire. Indeed I was very young, and knew not at all what it was to Love; yet his contant addrees, the time he pent, and the flattery of dometiques, made me believe he wiht me well; my capacity was able to reach no farther: and ee how much children are obliged unto their Parents; and how thankful they ought to be unto Heaven, when they have uch as are Wie and Prudent. If Arci • gentorix had been too haty in marrying me, as many Fathers are who deire nothing more then to be rid of their daughters, he had certainly betowed me upon Periander; whom now I ee rather then I would have married, I would with my life have pulled my heart out of my bret.

But my Father out of a Prudent deign which he had, was the caue why this marriage was delayed: many thought it a match very utable and advantagious for me, as well in repect of age, as of the noblenes and valour of Periander, but epecial of his etate, which is the main thing mot Fathers conider. This buines being pun out to the length, it hapned preently after that one Hylas, a Cavalier, or a Pator of the Ile of Carmagues in the Province of the Roma • s, came accidentally unto Lyons.

There is none in the company (aid Atrea and interrupted) who does not know him very well. Dorinde then miled; ince you know him o very well, replied he, I hall nor need to relate his tricks which he has put upon me. We do know, aid Diana, of his Love unto you: how he put his picture in a glas, and preented it unto you: and briefly of all his behaviour with you and with Periander until his departure from Lyons. I believe (aid Dorinde) that he has been forward enough
in blazing his Heroick Acts, but I make a quetion whether he was true in his relation. Do not doubt it Coen (aid Florice) for I heard all he aid, and he has not the gift of lying, as he has of incontancy. Let then I hould be tedious, (continued Dorinde) I will wave all dicoure concerning him, only will oberve, that Hylas is the econd peron that deceived me; for Periander who was the econd who loved me, he had not yet compleated his treaon. But I mut needs confes, that of all thoe who ever deceived me, I complain leat of Hylas, for he proteted eriouly unto me, that he would Love me mot faithfully as long as his humour continued; but if that were pat, neither Heaven nor Earth had bonds trong enough to hold him: o as this free and ingenious confeion, keeps me from blaming him; and when I think upon his change, I do only accue the general fault of men, amongt which I reckon Hylas the leat deceiver of all. But ince you know all the paages betwixt him, Periander, Florice, and my elf, I will return to the dicoure where I left. I mut tell you, that Theombres carried Florice out of the Town, and how Cryeide that Fair tranger ecaped out of King Gondebauts prion, auring my elf Madam, that he could tell you no farther; ince then he left the banks of Arar to follow the Fair trans-Alpine, Cryeide, as many ay.

Be pleaed to know then, that Periander eeing himelf alone with me, having lot the Rival whom he always much feared, he did o devote himelf wholly unto me, at leat in hew, that his Love was unknown only unto uch as would not know it. As oon as ever I waked every morning, I was ure of a ervant from him to bid me good morrow, and to bring either ome flowers, or ome rare fruits of the eaon: I no ooner et my foot out of doors towards the Temple, but I found him ready to tender his ervices unto me: after dinner, no garden or publique rendevous of gallantry was about the Town, but he carryed me thither: after upper, bals never failed either at my houe, or ome of my friends, by his procurement: that night was very blutering and tormy, if I had not muick at my window, omtimes voices, omtimes Intruments, omtimes one ort, another time another: all his Dometiques wore no other Livery but mine; himelf never wore any favour but what he begg'd from me. To be brief Madam, all this was not done in a corner, but (as I may ay) upon the houe top: he called and profeed himelf my ervant publiquely. I mut confes that he did o flatter my young unexperienced youth, as I did comply with him: and the rather, becaue my Father conidering the merit of this young Cavalier, and the affection which he expreed unto me, was minded, contrary to his deign, to marry me unto him.

About the ame time, there was two Cavaliers who did both cat their eyes upon me; one was a tranger and called Bellimartes, the other was a neighbour about the banks of Arar, and his name was Merindor: the firt of thee came with King Gondebaut from beyond the Alps, and was a Goth; to hew, that be a man born in any Region whereoever, yet he cannot be exempt from the fault of his ex, I mean from being giddy, uncontant, and a deceiver. This Bellimartes was he who kept Arimant prioner, the ervant, and ince the Husband of the unfortunate, and happy Cryeide, for o I praie the unfortunate and fortunate events, which he reented during the time of their Loves: and were not the tory too long, I would relate it, for I am confident you would be of the ame judgment. You need not take o much pains (aid Atrea) for we know it already, partly from Hylas, and partly from the Fair Florice. 'Tis very well, aid Dorinde, for thereby you will better undertand the equel of my relation.

This Bellimartes then, after he had renounced all his pretenions unto Arimant, as Florice I believe has told you, he addreed himelf particularly unto the King, and put him in memory of all his long ervices which he had done, the dangers he had paed, the wounds he had received, and the blood he had lot, alo hewed many great cars which he had in everal places: then he beeeched him to conider, that for all thee he had got nothing, but the bare honour of pending in his ervice both his dayes and etate: that true it was, he held this honour at a high price, and would not exchange it for any recompence he could give: But though this was honourable for Bellimartes; yet it was not utable with the grandeur and Majety of a great King; that it hould be aid he had o long and o faithfully erved, and erved
a Mater and received no other gratification, but the empty ound of being called his ervant; this would argue that I did not erve a good Mater. Unto thee coniderations, he added many others, which o moved the heart of that generous King, as after he had layed the fault upon himelf in never asking any recompence, to hew ome effects of his good will, he betowed upon him the Regiment of tranger Souldiers, which for the guard of the Town, he entertained in Lyons: an office truly o honourable and o beneficial, as it was a gratification beyond all his hopes, and by which he did thrive o well, that in a hort time he might without preumption apire unto the bet matches in all the Country.

All thee things fell out whilt I was aiduouly courted and erved by Periander. And becaue Bellimartes had a mind to ettle himelf in that Province where he had uch a beneficial office, he intended to match himelf o, that he might rather get friends then money for the portion; upon this ground he cat his eye upon me, and at uch a time that I was o much againt him, as I could never ince endure the memory of him. At the ame time alo Merindor being newly returned from travel, he did unluckily ee me at the marriage of Parthenopea, and from that time began alo to court me: o as Periander found himelf more company then he deired. 'Tis true Merindor did carry the matter much better, and with more dicretion then Bellimartes, who preuming upon the Kings favour, and the authority which he had in the Town, did at the very firt accot me publiquely, as thinking, that though Periander was more in favour with me, yet the advantages of his fortune would prevail with Arcingentorix, to make choie of him before Periander.

This addres did inflame the affection of Periander more then ever, and he expreed more Love unto me then before; he was o netled to think that another hould take from him that prey which he had been o long in chae after, that he thought time to betow himelf. So that he reolved, with my conent, to make the motion of marriage unto my Father. I mut confes that I did conent unto it, becaue I did not like Bellimartes; his age and his rough behaviour reembling a man in armor, did make me almot afraid of him. As for Merindor, I was not yet acquainted with him, for he carried the matter with o much cautious dicretion, as it was hard to know whether he was in earnet or in jet. Periander then, to loe no time, did motion the marriage unto Arcingentorix; and at the firt overture, ubmitted himelf wholly unto him, and deired him to write what conditions he pleaed; my Father firt thanked him for his good will; and told him, that truly he had yet no thoughts of marrying me, ince my age required no great hate: but yet to make it appear how much he eteemed of his alliance, he would promie him within a month to let him know his full reolution. All thee things could not be tranacted o ecretly, but Bellimartes and Merindor were advertied, and therefore they both reolved to cros this treaty as much poibly they could; but believing that Arcingentorix would not marry me againt my will, they thought the bet way was to gain me, and therefore they declared themelves more openly then before.

I remember that Merindor in this reolution meeting me one morning in the Temple, whither Periander conducted me, and went out; he kneeled down cloe by me, and aid; Did you come hither, Fair Dorinde, to pray unto the Gods, or to thank them? I did not know how to anwer him, becaue I knew not what he meant; and therefore after I had looked upon him without giving any anwer, I returned to my prayers again. What means this ilence (aid he again) is it a tetimony of corn? or is it becaue you would be importuned? Neither, aid I unto him, for I do much eteem Merindor, but it is becaue I do not undertand you: for what do you mean by prayers and thanks? I ask you (aid he) whether you came to pray the Gods that you may marry Periander, or give them thanks, becaue they have granted that requet before? Neither the one nor the other, (anwered I, and miled) you are a diembler, aid he, to ay o: you are incredulous, anwered I, if you do not believe me. Why? aid he, can you deny a thing which is known unto all? Why? anwered I, and turned my head the other way, why doe you ask me if you know, and if you will not believe me? I do know that which all knows, aid he, but I do ask you that which you only can tell me: tell me therefore upon what conideration do you take this Husband? As a daughter hould take him (anwered I)
who is given her by her Father. I wih to God (aid he and ighed) that you took him only out of obedience and not will: my will, anwered I, hall be alwayes the will of Arcingentorix: but pray tell me Merintor, what interet have you in all this that hould make you igh for it? Well may I igh, (aid he) for that which I hall never ceae weeping; upon this I aw his eys began to flow with tears: and becaue he would not as I think, let me know any more at that time, he went away and poke not a word, leaving me fully aured that he did Love me, and that this marriage pierced him to the very heart: but all this had no operation upon me, becaue I was already wholly dedicated unto Periander, and thought that his merits and affection did oblige me unto it.

The little account that I made of Merindors dipleaure, when he went away, went o neer his heart, that being almot out of all hopes of getting my Love, as long as Periander lived, he was in two or three minds to fight him, and ee, upon which of the two, the lot would fall. As he was deeply in this thought, a friend of his did meet him, in whom he had great confidence. Euphroias (for that was the name of his dear and wie friend) eeing Merindor walk with his hat pulled over his eyes, looked upon the ground, and his cloke lapped diorderly about him, walking in the treets, and never looking upon any; he knew that omthing troubled his mind: and becaue he knew that youth and courage are often apt unto too violent reolutions, which they may repent of when it is too late, he went unto him, and aluted him: and when he aw that he did not anwer what Merindor (aid he and took him by the arm) will you not peak unto your friends? Merindor hearing this voice, and feeling himelf held by the arm, topped hort, and looked upon Euphroias as if he were newly revived out of an extaie: and after he had tood a while mute; Good Euphroias (aid he) pardon this fault which proceeds from a very bad humour which has eied upon me. I will (anwered his friend) upon condition you will tell me the caue. Though perhaps you would not know it, anwered Merindor, yet I beeech you hear it, for I have need of your counel in a buines which concerns me as neer as my life: but let us go aide let any hould hear us dicoure. Upon this making choie of a private place, he began to tell him the original of his Love, the progres, and the preent condition wherein he was: afterwards he acquainted him with the Love of Bellimartes and Periander: but when he came to the dicoure he had with me in the Temple, and my anwers in favour of Periander, he entred into uch a paion, that the Prudent Euphroias did ee, that the affection which he had unto me, was too great to be diverted either by reaons or entreaties: and therefore to avoid the two evils which he foreaw, he thought it mot neceary to draw him only from the mot dangerous, which was his hatred unto Periander, and as for the cure of his affection, there was no way but to refer it unto time: therefore in lieu of any harp reprehenions, or any four looks, he miled upon him, and anwered thus; Good Merindor (aid he) tell me upon your faith, if this be all the caue of your being thus dicompoed? How? (aid Merindor) is not this enough, ince my affection is uch unto Dorinde, that it is a thing mot impoible for me to help it? And do I not ee before my face, the man that is the great obtructor of my happines? Is there no way, anwered his friend, to find a remedy? None, anwered Merindor, that I know, but to take away the life of him, that takes away from me that happines without which I cannot live. Oh Merindor! cried out Euphroias, you take things at the wort. Tell me, I beeech you; do you think Dorinde Loves Periander? Think it? aid Merindor, nay I were the mot incredulous fool that lives if I were not certain of it. Then (replied his Wie friend) you mut not go the wort way to compae what you deire: for you can never hope to get the good will of Dorinde by murdering that peron whom he Loves bet; your paion does but flatter and deceive you, for by that coure you will make her hate you even to the very death. Certainly, aid Merindor, there is no remedy, if this be not good: Certainly, aid Euphroias, this is neither good, nor a remedy; but I beeech you tell me, why you think it o neceary for Periander to die? Becaue (aid he) the Love that Dorinde bears unto him, is the caue why he does not Love me: If that be it, replied Euphroias, make the ame reaon as well obtruct him, as he obtructs you; I mean, that he hall not Love Periander becaue he Loves Merindor.
Yes, yes, aid Merindor, you are very kind; but here is the difficulty, how hould I make her love me? Do as Periander does, anwered Euphroias, nay, and better; why hould you think heaven will not be as favourable to you, as any other Cavalier of your age? But Euphroias (aid he) he does love Periander. So much the better, anwered Euphroias, it is a igne he is not inenible, nor invulnerable by the blows of Love: Pray why hould you think your ervices hould not work as happy effects as his? You ee Merindor that you do love Dorinde in uch a height, that you cannot retire; reolve with your elf to love her till in uch extremity, that it hall invite her unto Love again, or rather to contrain her unto it. Oh my dear friend, aid Merindor, and ighed; how difficult is it to bring this enterprize to pas! Yet let me tell you, notwithtanding all I told you before concerning Periander, that I do verily believe he does not love him; but all he does, is only in obedience unto her Father. So much the better till (aid Euphroias) for if he does not love him, you will far ooner win her, then if he were engaged unto any. Oh but if he do love Periander, (aid Merindor) what hopes can I have? Why hould not you hope as well as another, replied Euphroias? Will not mot merit oonet obtain? Or ay that Argument have no validity in it, you mut know Merindor, that the love of women is one of thoe things that mut not be ought after by the Rules of Reaon, and of whom one mut never depair; for be mot aured, that there is a certain hour in the day in the which they can deny nothing; And therefore the anwer of the Oracle was good, when a Lover asked what he hould do to overcome the cruelty of his Mitris; The Anwer was, Love, be Bold, and Continue.

With uch dicoure as this Euphroias diverted his friend from his deigne againt Periander, and filled him o full of new hopes, that he began to court Dorinde with uch freh aaults, as Periander and Bellimartes could not chue but be jealous; for until then he did not openly declare himelf, but thought himelf out of hopes, yet now by reaon of the time of my Father's anwer unto Periander, he was the only mote in his eye; and certainly not without reaon, for I eeing my father very inclinable to give me unto him, I thought my elf already o certain to be his wife, that I devoted my elf wholly unto him.

Whilt thee three were thus triving who hould win me, the term which my Father et for Periander's anwer drew on; and he who expected with extream impatience the day whereon he hould be pronounced happy, that very evening he failed not to go unto my Father with three of his neeret kinred; As oon as he came into his preence, he fell down upon his knees, and beeeched him with as much earnetnes as if his life was at take, that he would be pleaed to give him that anwer which he promied. But Sir, aid he, if it be not utable to my deires, make but a igne, and it hall uffice to be rid of me; for I am mot perfectly reolved to throw my elf, and all my deires and deigns, into the bottom of Arar. He accompanied thee words with uch actions of his hands, head, and every part of his body, that every one believed they came from his heart: And my Father, as the ret, being deceived by this opinion, did hold out his hand to take him up from his knees; Son, aid he unto him, for o I will hereafter call you, rie up, and believe, that if I have any thing which is dearer then Dorinde, I will give it unto you and your merit; I do here give her unto you, and pray unto the heavens to make you a mot happy pair. Periander ravihed with joy, did kis the hand of Arcingentorix an hundred times, with o many demontrations of Love, as none doubted but that his Love was extream.

At the ame time my Father called for me, and taking my hand, carried me in to Periander. Daughter (aid he) I would have you love this Cavalier, as him that mut be your husband, and unto whom I now do give you, and within thee eight days, I will prepare for your marriage. Upon this Periander advanced, and came to alute me; and I Sir, aid he, do take you for my Lord and Father, and her for my Wife and Mitris.

Judge, I beeech you Madam, and you wie and fair Shepherdees, whether uch promies as thee o olemnly made, would not make any one believe them indiolvable? But with hame to all humane kind, you hall hear the perfidie of all men in general included in this one particular man. Thee eight days which Arcingentorix prefixed for a concluion of the marriage, were variouly imployed: For my Father's whole care was in providing all things neceary for this marriage: All the Neighborhood to hew how much they loved and honoured our Family, deigned everal diverions of Tilting, Masks, Dancings, and uch like.

Bellimartes on the contrary was perpetually whipering into the Kings ear, and contriving how to break off this marriage. But Merindor, what in ighs and tears, what in careing me and my Father, his time was o pent, that he could hardly leep: He was continually telling everal tales, and foretelling me of Periander's incontancy, diimulation, and perfidie, which ince I have found but too true, and unto which I would not then hearken, thinking it an offence againt the love which he bore unto me, and which I had unto that Deceiver. As for Periander, his whole care was in careing me, and treating me with all the diverions about the Town, and thought upon nothing ele, at leat in hew. For my part, I mut confes I thought my elf o obliged to him, that my tudy was wholly how to pleae him. Now, age Druide, ee how heaven does laugh at all our Deigns, and can change them.

During this while, whether it was with too much dancing, or by eating too much fruit, or rather, as I think, by coming into ome infectious place; or to ay better, whether it was the will of heaven by this mall icknes to prevent a greater miery, I cannot tell; but upon the ixth day, I was taken with an extream pain in my head, and a Fever o violent, as put me all into a flame, and continued everal days, and till with uch a drowines upon me, as I could hardly lift up my eyes: and after it had thus tormented me, one morning when the Phiicians came to ee me, they found me full of red pots, which by little and little growing bigger, did o become bliters, that I was a horrid ight to be een: It was a dieae which children are commonly ubject unto; and many other children and young people of my age in the ame Town were at the ame time infected as I was.

This malady thus falling out, it prevented all deigns and preparations; for I was o exceedingly tormented, that many thought I would die: Periander at the firt came twice or thrice to ee me, and eemed to be extreamly dipleaed that our marriage hould be thus retarded: But as oon as the Smal pox appeared, he would never after o much as et his foot into the houe where I was; he ent indeed omtimes to ee how I did, but he was o afraid of me, and catching the dieae, that he would not o much as come neer the door.

As long as pain was upon me, I mut confes, I did not reent his behaviour, though every one ele did think it very trange; but I was o full of pain, as I never asked what became of him; yet afterwards, when the violence was a little pat, I did enquire what became of Periander; and perceiving the little memory he had of me, I began to think that Merindor poke truth when he foretold me of Periander's incontancy; and yet I could not chue but eek out for ome reaons to excue him: omtimes I did imagine, that perhaps ome buines had carryed him out of Lyons, and that it grieved him as much as it did me that he could not hear how I did; otherwhiles I had an opinion, that my Father had changed his mind, and had forbidden him to ee me: omtimes I thought he was ick, and that none in my houe would acquaint me: Briefly, I turned every tone, and tryed all my wits, and all how to deceive my elf: But my malady continuing long, and this perfidious man alo continuing in his neglect, I was but too well aured that his mind was turned.

What do you think Madam, and you fair Shepherdes, the reentment of this offence might move me unto? At the firt, I wept and was ilent, and hid my tears from the ight of every one; But when I heard it the common talk, and that every one condemned his falenes, it was impoible for me to hide my reentments any longer.

On the contrary, Merindor, as if my icknes had augmented his affection, he was continually at my chamber door, asking how I did, and would gladly have een
me, if they would have permitted him. And as oon as ever he heard all danger was pat, he brought muique of everal orts unto my door, to divert me: and becaue he knew of Perianders change, I remember, he caued a ong to be ung at my chamber door, which intimated the incontancy of a Lover. And becaue he thought that perhaps I did not undertand the words at that ditance, he ent the ong in a paper unto me, by a woman that came into my chamber: yet I was o attentive that I heard and remembred every word. I eemed not to take any notice of all this, though I had a great reentment of it: but when I was alone, the thoughts of Perianders neglect and oblivion, made me even hate his humour: and more, when being out of my bed, and yet durt not go out of my chamber, becaue my face was much changed, as is common in that dieae; he did not o much as end to ee how I did: now I thought it time to forget him, as well as he did me; and I thank Heaven for it, I did o exclude him from my thoughts, that I made him a very tranger unto them: It would be but los of time to tell you what reproaches I laid in his dih; how I reolved my elf againt him; how adly I firt reented this eparation; for the truth is, I had uch confidence in his promied affection, that I thought it impoible to alter: but now, finding my elf deceived, and my dieae to be the caue of his apotacy, I could not complain againt him enough, and indeed againt my elf for believing him: now did I admire his incontancy, and for his ake condemn the ficklenes and perfidy of all men whatoever.

Yet notwithtanding I had worn a hundred times never to care for him again, and that though he hould return, yet never to look upon him; yet for all this, I could not chue but ask him by one that I imployed, what was the caue of this o udden eparation? And he who asked him the quetion, was a woman that waited upon me, and in whom I had great confidence during all the time of his addrees unto me. Periander (aid he unto him) how comes it to pae that you never ee Dorinde, nor ask what becomes of her? How? Dorinde? (anwered he) is he alive till? Alive (aid the woman) why? he is recovered, and ready to come out of her chamber. Ah Sweet-heart, replied Periander, you are much mitaken, or ele does mock me; certainly he is dead: but has left in her room • , a certain ugly woman, whom for the Love of her they call Dorinde: but the Fair Dorinde whom I Loved is certainly dead, and I am o orry for it, as I will not go and ee this Dorinde, let the memory of the other hould give an occaion of tears. Fie, fie, Periander, (replied the woman much amazed at his anwer) is it not enough to eperate your elf from her, but you mut mock at her miery? Dorinde, as I told you before, replied he preently, is not in the world: What? would you have me go and Love her in her grave? And as for her that is in her room; alas Sweet-heart, he is o ugly, that I will leave her to whom that will. As oon as he had aid o, he went away and tayed not for any anwer.

Judge Madam, whether this was to be endured; and yet I mut wallow this bitter pill, and eem, as if I did not tat it. But was it not the height of cruelty, to trike one that was o deeply wounded before? For firt my icknes had poiled my face, which was wound enough, without the addition of another from a peron whom I leat expected it.

A little while after, my Father came to ee me; and not without tears in his eyes to find me o much changed: which I perceiving, Father, aid I unto him, never afflict your elf for the los of that which could not be long kept: but rather, I beeech you to rejoyce with me, ince by the los of a trifle I am recued from an ill fortune. Upon this I told him all that Periander had done and aid, then falling down upon my knees, I beeeched him, that he would not command me to have any more convere with this perfidious man: Dorinde (aid he and took me up) I promie you I will not; and I command you, not o much as to name him unto me, who thinks him the mot unworthy Cavalier that lives.

Upon this, my Father went away, and left me extreamly well atisfied with his promie. And from hence forward I began to think more of Merindor, then formerly I had, as thinking that his behaviour towards me did oblige me to prefer him before any other; for though Bellimartes did end often to viit me, and was very careful in ending all uch remedies as were proper for that dieae; yet his humour and dipoition
was contrary unto mine, o as I could not for my heart Love him.

In the mean time, I recovered very fat; not but that my face was o blated, as I was hardly knowable; and when I looked in a glas, I admired to ee my elf: and therefore I till kept the door of my chamber hut very cloe, to the end none hould enter but uch as waited upon me; hoping till that time might hap • y make ome amendment. But Merindor, whoe affection to me eemed to be greater then before, and who never tirred out of my anti-chamber with everal orts of muick, as I told you before: one day when I was alone with that woman whom I ent unto Periander, and when the door was but ill hut, he entred in upon uch a udden, that he was upon his knees before me ere I could ee him. As fortune was, I had a mask upon my face: but I could no way hide my eyes but with my hands, and they were o blated, that I was ahamed to hew them, for I had not time to put on my gloves. You may imagine me not a little urpried when I aw him; I did my ende • vour to get into my Cloet, but he kneeled o before me, and held my knees, that I was not able to rie from my eat: Oh Merindor (aid I unto him) you are exceeding troubleome unto me, and would do me a great pleaure, if you would think upon me no more then Periander doth. Alas, alas, anwered he, do you think to limit the effects of my affection unto the hallow amity of him whom you named? Ah Madam, pardon me I beeech you, if I think his offence not o great unto me, as it is unto you Unto me? anwered I; I aure you Merindor, if Perianders offences trouble you no more then me, you will never complain againt him: for as for my part, I am o far from any memory of his name, that whatoever he does cannot offend me But let us talk of omthing ele I beeech you, and tell me, what makes you o deirous to ee me in this condition wherein I am; for me thinks you hould rather hun all occaions of it, then deire it: upon this quetion I caued him to rie, and a chair to be et for him, becaue I would not uffer him to kneel. Madam, anwered he, the affection of him who loves, will never let him ret till he have atisfied his curioity, by eeing her whom he loves and adores; and uch is mine to you: do not imagine, I beeech you that I do love you with any reerved thoughts to leave off, though you hould not be o Fair as you was before; uch a love deerves not the name: and I do eteem rather a treaon, and not to be entertained into any heart that loves well: my affection ets no other term but eternity, nor no other condition, but to Love Dorinde, as he is, and as he hall be; for the future, as well as for the preent. Now ee, Wie and Fair Druide, how apt one is to judg others by themelves; a very dog that is burned will fear the fire: yet I, lee wie then thoe animals, after I had been deluded by the upple language of Periander, could not chue but give credit unto the gilded flatteries of Merindor; thinking, that a man well born, and a Cavalier, ought above other men to be jut, and to have his heart in his tongue: but I confes, that I did partly believe that which I hould not have believed at all; I began to fancy that I might live happily with him: but to tell you truly, I did it much out of pite againt Periander, thinking it a full revenge, if I gave my elf unto another, but never thinking that it was a revenge againt my elf: but it was imprudence, which commonly is a conequent of little experience, did give me this imple counel, which ince hath cot me many a tear, and much torment.

The anwer that I gave him was this; Do you think Merindor that any one who has a deign to make themelves loved, will ay les then you? I think (aid he) that thoe who have the ame deires which I have, may make ue of the ame words. But (aid I) if all thoe who have the ame deires, do peak as you do, and all deceive thoe who trut them, what aurance can I have in your words? Periander ued them a thouand times, and even deafned me with his candid language, which was only a gloe upon intended treachery. If my words (replied Merindor) were not accompanied with ome more aured tetimonies, I mut needs confee the treachery of Periander, might make you upect all I ay. But, Oh Dorinde, I hope I am not o unfortunate, but that you have taken notice of my actions, and how, ince the very firt day I ever aw you, I have devoted my elf to be wholly yours. 'Tis true, anwered I, and I hould be very ungrateful if I did not acknowledg that your proceeding and behaviour does much oblige me; but with all let me tell you,
That I think all men make it their glory to deceive thoe who put any trut in them. If o, replied Merindor, then I protet Madam, that henceforward I will not be a man, the very name hall be odious unto me, and I will abominate the title, as much as I do that of Vilain or Traytor. Do you peak this in good earnet, aid I unto him? Madam (anwered he) Do you ask this quetion in good earnet? Is it poible you hould till doubt of Merindors affection? No, no Dorinde, Do not give your eyes, your ears, your judgement the lie; I am ure they all tell you that Merindor loves you: had he been prone to change, he might with more reaon then Periander, who received favours a thouand for one. Merindor (aid I) I do confes it, and having oberved your affection to me ever ince you firt aw me, and continued during all the time of my icknes, I have often aid unto my elf, what would he have done if he had found as much good will from me, as I have hewed unto that Deceiver Periander? But this is not enough to aure me that you will not change; for all men, by the example of one hath taught me, that it is Beauty which they love, and not the peron of her who has it; o as when by any accident this Beauty is gone, their love is immediately gone with it. Oh Dorinde (aid he) you are an unjut Judge, to pronounce entence againt all men in general, for the offence of one particular man: Do you not ee that into what condition oever your icknes hath brought you, yet till I love, nay even adore you? Perhaps (aid I) you may love me yet, becaue you have not een my face, and does not think it o deformed as it is by my icknes. But to cure you of your dieae, I will let you ee it, upon condition you will lament my los, and afterwards leave me at ret to endure my malady alone: Upon this I pulled off my mask, and hewed him my face, which had no reemblance of what it was before, more then the name of a Face: This I did with deign, that he eeing me, might not love me any longer, and o I hould be neither troubled nor deceived: then if he did continue loving me, I might be aured that my uglines would never make him change, it being impoible I hould be wore then I was. I oberved that as oon as he aw me, he tood mute, and was much atonihed, and that tears preently after trickled from his eyes, o as he was not able to peak; but a little after he began thus: I mut confes, Madam, that your dieae ued you more unkindly then any, unles they aw you, can imagine; but this alteration cannot change my affection to you, if you think it does, Madam, you do wrong me: Periander's action is unpardonable; but be aured, I beeech you, that only death, and not any accident of Fortune whatoever, is able to quench thoe flames which your Vertues and your Merits have kindled in the heart of Merindor. I do not deny but • hat it was your-Beauty which firt invited me unto you, which gave me a will to erve you; but ince I have had the honour and happines to be better acquainted with you, oh Dorinde, I find more lating invitations and allurements unto Love, then any Beauty can be: Your Soul, you Soul Dorinde, your noble and weet oul is far fairer then ever was your face; and therefore, as your face firt invited me, your oul will eternally keep me to your ervice.

I hould be too long, Madam, hould I relate all the dicoure which we had upon this Subject; and it is fit I bury them in ilence, as he did preently after in oblivion; But o it was, I thought that I had found a man that was not a Deceiver, and in that belief I contracted amity with him. The way of your behaviour to me (aid I unto him) ever ince you firt aw me, and the aurance you give me that my face does not affright you, nor leen your affection to me, does oblige me to eteem and love you more then I thought I could any, after uch an unworthy falhood as that of Periander; and if you do continue, as hitherto you have, aure your elf Merindor, that I will love and eteem you as your merits do oblige me. Oh Dorinde, replied he, I am not contented with this promie, ince your love is to be proportioned according to my merits, and therefore I am afraid your love will be but a little. No, no, aid I, it may be infinite, and yet but hold proportion with your merits; but to content you, I do promie, that if you do not Perianderize, I will love you as much as you can deire.

Merindor having this aurance, he fell upon his knees, took my hand by force, and though it was covered with marks of my dieae, yet he kied it everal times with uch abundance of thanks, as this action gave me more full aurance of his love,
then my words could him of my good will, and I believe, that if my Father had not come, he would never have ceaed his Demontrations of Affection and Thanks.

My Father at his entrance miled, becaue he either aw him kneeling before me, or ele ome of the Dometiques told him. This invited me to tell him all the paages betwixt us, and to peak very advantagiouly in behalf of Merindor: My dicoure and my free expreions were o agreeable unto my Father, that taking me aide, he asked me whether I did really love that Cavalier, and whether I thought he loved me; and I anwering, that conidering both Perianders behaviour and his, I did both love him, and that he loved me. Since it is o (aid he unto me) I like him better then I do Periander: Sir, aid I unto him, you may dipoe of me as you pleae, for I have no will but yours. We mut not be too haty in any thing (anwered he) nor mut we light them, ince he has behaved himelf o well, let us entertain him with a few handome delays, and reolve upon the matter at more leiure: then turning towards Merindor, he looked upon him with a kind apect, thanked him for the care he had of me in my icknes, and commanded me to bid him welcome, and honour him as I was obliged.

Since this day, the door was never hut againt Merindor; as oon as I was dret, he might enter into my chamber at all times without denial: and he, who let no opportunity lip, was in it from morning till night, with o much hew of affection, that it eemed my deformity did augment it. On the other ide, Bellimartes eeing how this Cavalier had admittance, and thinking the ame might as well be allowed unto him, did end to know whether he might come in or no: And my Father, ince Merindor was permitted, durt not deny him; o as one afternoon he came to ee me; but being advertied of his coming, I put on my Mask and my Gloves, with a protetation, not to pull them off as long as he tayed in my chamber.

The dicoure of Bellimartes melt more of a State-man then a Lover; and though he aw the icknes had much changed me, yet he eemed not to care; but within a few days after, he made uch addrees unto King Gondebaut, that he olicited my Father to marry me. Bellimartes being of another Nation, and never beloved amongt us, my Father deired no alliance with him, but rather with Merindor, whom he thought to be a man of much merit, and whoe etate and parents were not unknown; therefore he beeeched the King to pardon him, if he not conent unto the marriage, becaue I only was the upport and comfort of his age, and to marry me unto a tranger, who had no etled etate in his Dominions, was not any comfort unto him. He told him, that if I did di-obey him, he would deire to punih me no more, then to marry me unto that man; for I hould be as good as banihed from him: Moreover, he aid, that I was at ufficient age to make my own choice, and he would never contradict my Will, ince it was a buines that made me either happy or mierable all my life; and therefore he would not by any means force my Will: and for a concluion, he beeeched the King to remember the faithful ervices which he and his Ancetors had ever done him; and for a recompence of all, that he would do him the favour not to contrain me unto this. The King, who loved Bellimartes, and intended to oblige him further by doing this office for him, did anwer unto all thoe objections which my Father urged, and to every point did give good reaons to cover that Soveraign power which he intended to ue in this buines: And as to that objection, that Bellimartes had no etate in his Dominions, and that he was a tranger, therefore he hould never ee me again; he anwered, That he would confer uch an etate upon him in his Kingdom, as hould take away that exception; and that Bellimartes did intimate as much in his addrees unto me, whoe Beauty now was not uch as could invite him to marry me for any matter of Love, but reaon of State, and to get Alliance in a Country where he was a tranger: That this reolution would make him more tractable unto me, more obedient towards him, and more erviceable towards all our kinred, then any other he could mention unto him. That as to the choice and free liberty of my Will, which he would leave unto me in this buines, that it was great indicretion to do o; becaue youth and widom can never be together; and that being o young as I was, he would commit a great fault, in leaving it to my own choice; which I
could never make but with indicretion: but on the contrary, that he was obliged by the very name of a Father to find out a Husband for me, uch a one as might be advantagious, and not to leave it unto me to chue at random and without judgement. That if they ordained Guardians to uch as are within age; o certainly, marriage which is to lat for life, mut be contracted by the approbation and conent of Wie and Prudent perons, who have the Tuition of any young and unadvied child. That it was generally oberved, few marriages which were made for Love, prove properous in the end; and almot all thoe that were made by advie, the contrary: and that the authority of Wie Parents is commonly econded by all orts of happinee and felicities. And as to the ervices which he and his Ancet • rs had done him, he did make it appear that he had them in memory, by taking o much pains in marrying me unto one whom he eteemed and loved: that had he not remembred them, he would have marryed him unto ome other within his Dominions who was as rich, and as well allyed as I was: but in this action, he thought to acquit himelf of thoe ervices which he had received from him and his houe. To be brief, he deired the marriage might be, and if it was not, he had an occaion to take it unkindly: upon this he left my Father o atonihed, that he neither could nor durt anwer him a word.

The authority of a Soveraign Prince, has uch a troke with it in the mind of loyal ubjects, that it trikes dead what reolutions oever was to the contrary; epecially when it comes with a colour of reaon: for mot certain it is, that ubjects ought naturally to obey their Prince; di-obedience is againt honour, and againt great Tautates: in all other things, good excues may be ued, and cannot be rejected by perons of judgment. But in this, my Father had no will to betow me upon this tranger, and had rather have dyed then to ee me in his hands: one while, he had a mind to tell him that he had already given me unto Merindor, but he was preently off that, becaue when the King poke unto him, he did not tell him o then; other whiles, he reolved to marry us ecretly, auring himelf, that when it was done, Gondebaut could not break it: but upon a udden he foreaw o many mieries, that would befal both him and us, that he altered his opinion; for he knew the Kings anger would never cool till he was revenged upon us: ometimes his thoughts prompted him to admit me amongt the Vetals; but when he fancied that, he aw me o reclus'd and buried before I was dead, he waved that reolution: beides, the Kings anger would have been as high againt him for that, as if he had flatly di-obeyed him. Thus not knowing what coure to take, he continued many dayes o unreolved and uncertain, as it troubled him o much, that he moved pity from all that aw him.

In the mean time Bellimartes whom the King acquainted with all the difficulties which my Father objected, he took counel from a prudent and wie friend, to gain me with a golden hower, as the Poets ay Danae was by Jupiter; I mean, that though his nature was not over liberal, yet upon this occaion he hould overcome himelf, and end rich preents unto me and my Father: for it was the cutom of old people to be covetous, and it was the nature of young women to be deirous of new drees, and hew themelves brave amongt their aociates. Probably the King was of this opinion; for we were ure that Bellimartes was not able of himelf to betow uch delicate curioities as he ent unto me, nor uch great and rich preents as he ent unto my Father every day. Oh how true a aying it is, that tones will trike the Thunderbolt out of the hand of Jupiter, and that gifts does teal away the liberty of them that receive them. After Bellimartes had continued this coure ome twelve or fifteen dayes, his preents had more eloquence in them, and more authority then the King. There was not a woman about me, nor a ervant about my Father, but was o gained, that they talked of nothing but of his merit and of his valour: all others were not worthy to look upon him; and although he was formerly very il-favoured, thoe themelves that were of that judgment, do now cry him up to the clouds; but that which was the greatet wonder unto me, was to ee my Father my degrees to approve of that which he o much diproved before: Daughter (aid he unto me) this man is not uch a Barbarian as we did conceive him; thoe that pend their judgment upon one they know not, are much to blame:
for who would not have been deceived, in this man? Whoe birth was amongt Barbarians; whoe education was in blood and cruelties, and yet his converation and humour is quite otherwie then at firt we thought him. For my part, I think, upon erious conideration, that it were not amis, to give the King contentment in this alliance with him: it mut needs be very advantagious unto us, and he may one day advance us above all our Predeceors: again, it is not good to reit the will of him whom Heaven has commanded us to obey; the ruine of him who commits the crime is impardonable and infallible: for my part, I did reit him when I thought the man to be not o good as he is; but now I know him, I find the King has good reaon to admit him into his favour, I ee my error and my implicity in not obeying him, and in not acknowledging that happinee which he intends towards us.

Oh Heavens! How little reolution there is in a childs judgment? And how eaily are they wayed by the reaons of thoe who know how to argue them with art, they will wallow them like bitter pils which are lapt in hony; I did Love Merindor, and I had no inclination at all unto Bellimartes, and yet my Fathers dicoure turned me which way he pleaed. Truth is, when I was alone, and remembred Merindors affection, and with what contancy he continued his addrees during all the noyomnes of my icknes; I could not chue but pity and be exceedingly orry for him. As oon as this coure was reolved upon, my Father commanded me not to ee him o often as I was accutomed: I mut confes I lamented the los of this Cavalier in whom I found o much affection. But Bellimartes, who by his preents had blinded the eyes of my Father, was the caue of my reolution to obey him who had the power over me. Yet being moved unto compaion, I intended to advertie Merindor, to the end he might betimes decline any further courthip or addrees to me, and divert himelf ome other way.

The next morning therefore when he came to ee me, according to his cutom, as oon as I heard that he was at my chamber-door, I beeeched my Father, he would be pleaed to give way that he might enter, that I might acquaint him with our reolutions, to the end he might be no longer deceived; that his contant courthip, his humble addrees, the hopes which was given him, and his merits and quality deerved all manner of contentment. My Father did much commend my deign, and to give us the better opportunity of talk; after Merindor was entered, my Father retired to his own chamber, and left me to ay what I would. Merindor at firt eeing this new favour, entred into great hopes, thinking that my Father retired purpoely in favour of him: but when he was gone, he oberved uch a hollow kind of behaviour in me, as quite dahed his hopes again; epecially when cauing him to it down, I poke thus unto him

Merindor, your merits, and your good will unto me, does oblige me to honour and eteem you as much as any Cavalier in the Country, and would mot willingly by any good ervice, render ome tetimony of my reentments; which invites me to put you out of ome doubts, which perhaps you have entred into ince you ee me o reerved towards you. Know therefore Merindor, that as long as my Father approved of our marriage, I behaved my elf towards you with all the freedom, that a harmlee liberty would permit: but now ince that hope is quite taken away, I thought it would be a great in, and uch a one as deerved the Title <> Perfidy, if I hould deceive you any longer by uch petty carees, that are apt to delude young perons who do love: do not think. I beeech you, but that if it were in my own choie, I would rather chue Merindor to live with all the dayes of my life, the •
any other whomoever; and have the ame thoughts of Arcingentorix: for were it referred unto him, aure your elf Merindor, that he would never look upon any but you. I have ever found him o dipoed to Love and honour you, and has held you in uch a high eteem, as doubtlee he would have been extreamly well contented, if it had been o deigned by the detinies, that I might have paed away my dayes with one of o much merit as you are. But Heaven has decreed it otherwie, and I am not detined to o much happines; for you mut know (continued I with tears in my eyes) that Gondebaut does force me to marry Bellimartes, Oh Heavens Dorinde, (aid Merindor and clapped his hands together) will Gondebaut marry
you to Bellimartes? Yes, (aid I unto him adly) and I aure you Arcingentorix and I have done all we can to prevent it, but find that there is no way to do it but by death. Since there is that remedy (aid he preently) all hopes are not gone, and without aying any more, or hearing me, he went o uddenly out of my chamber, as made it plain he intended ome violent coure. I called him everal times, and then run after him as far as the gates, fearing left in that fury he hould do himelf ome harm; but all was in vain, for he was gone out of ight upon a udden, as if he had wings. My Father who was not far off, hearing me peak o loud, he came to me, and hearing how this young Cavalier was gone, he feared let he hould make ome attempt upon Bellimartes, and afterwards the King cat all the blame upon us: upon this conideration, he went unto the houe of Bellimartes; he let him undertand in as dicreet a manner as he could, all the paage betwixt Merindor and me, that if any ill hapned we might be dicharged of it. Bellimartes who was a man of courage, and had all the authority and power in his own hands, did anwer, that the buinee did not trouble him at all, and that if Merindor was extravagant, he knew how to tame him.

In the mean time, Merindor tranported with extream paion, did go unto his chamber, where hutting the dore, he began to walk a great pace, o much out of himelf, as he knew not either what he did, or where he was: then after he had walked everal turns, and thinking none could hear, he began to peak with a loud voice in this manner: Mut Dorinde be enjoyed by another, and Merindor it tamely and endure it? Can the authority of a Tyrant prevail above all my ervices, and mot unjutly take that from me which is my due? Is there no remedy againt this wrong, and I with hazard of life and limb not make ue of it? And here making a udden top, he began to ay, mut this depriver of my happines, have it to himelf at any other rate then the price of my blood and life? No, no, if I live, he mut dye; that's poitive: Dorinde was in the right, when he aid there was no remedy but death. But (aid he, as much enraged as at the firt) if it be o, why do I tay any longer? And why do I not put my hand to a work that mut inevitably be done? Do it then Merindor quickly, unlee thou hadt rather turn the word againt thy elf.

Merindor thought he had been alone in his chamber; and that there was none to hear him but wals; but as good luck was, his Wie and mot dear friend Euphroias, being come a little before to eek him, was aid down upon the bed in expectation of him, and falling a leep, did not wake till Merindor began to talk loud; o as eeing him in uch a fury, he was deirous to know the caut, and let him empty his heart by the words which he uttered: knowing very well, that to top the overflowing of our ouls at the firt guh, will make the deluge bigger; and to oppoe fury in the firt, does but inflame it the more. But when he aw him ready to go and execute what he had poken, he tarted up, and took hold of his arm, deiring him to hear him peak: Merindor, not knowing whether it was a man or a pirit, he was truck with uch a fright, that his fury was a little cooled; but recollecting his pirits, and knowing him to be his dear friend; Oh my God! aid he, Euphroias, from whence come you? Come, come, aid his prudent friend, let us walk a turn together • and when you have anwered me to a few quetions, I will atisfie your curioity and wonder Then he continued; Is it poible Merindor that the friendhip which is betwixt us, can uffer you to run into uch extream reolutions without imparting them unto me, and without making ue of me? Do you think I do not Love you? Or do you take me for uch an ueles thing, that in affairs of this importance I neither will nor can erve you? Why? (aid Merindor) hould you ue any uch language? Becaue, aid he, I heard all you aid, and the dangerous reolution which you were going to execute without imparting it unto me. Do you think I know not how the King intends to marry Dorinde unto Bellimartes? And that her Father conents unto it? Why man, it is all the Town talk, and I came hither to acquaint you, if you were not acquainted with it before, to the end you might reolve with your elf, not only unto the Kings will, but alo unto the will of God, againt which there is no reitance: for Merindor, you mut know that marriages are made in Heaven, and accomplihed upon earth. How, how? aid Merindor
hatily, do you ay that marriages are made in Heaven? There is no doubt on it, anwered Euphroias, and thereupon it is, that o many unexpected marriages come to pae. I aure you, if it be o (aid Merindor) it may be aid, that as bad a market may be made in Heaven as in Earth; but from this, I do not conclude that Bellimartes mut enjoy Dorinde, and Merindor live; It mut be concluded, replied Euphroias, that whatoever the Heavens will ordain for you, mut be done: but tell me Merindor, what is your deign? To take away his life (anwered he) that takes away all my contentment. But (aid Euphroias) What will that advantage you? Oh (aid the young Cavalier) revenge is weet. Revenge, replied the Wie friend, is indeed very weet, when it does not make the offence greater; but if you hould kill Bellimartes, the leat punihment you can expect, is banihment from all places where Gondebaut has any power; and if o, what will become of your Love unto Dorinde? Will not then this revenge make your offence which you receive, greater? I do not hold him wie, who to put one of his enemies eyes out, will put out both his own. What then, aid Merindor, mut I it down tamely without reentment, and ee Bellimartes enjoy that which in right ought to be mine? I do not ay o, anwered Euphroias, but on the contrary; but if you will be ruled by me, I hope, we hall obtain for you, this o much deired Dorinde. Do you think that the King is o paionate in behalf of Bellimartes, as that he would do you any harm? No, no, it is only to gratifie Bellimartes in a buines wherein he does not think any has any interet but Arcingentorix, and of him the King makes no account, though he be one of the chief in all the Country, becaue he is old and not able to erve him, and on the contrary, Bellimartes is young, and may: for you mut know, that mot Princes do with their Subjects, as we do with our hores, when they are old and unerviceable, then turn them to the cart; believe it Merindor, Princes put a great difference between thoe that are young and able to erve them, and thoe that are antiquated and cannot. This conideration moves me to think, that if you did acquaint the King with the Interet you have in the buines, he will conider it: and you hall ee, that though this coure hould not do any good, yet i •
will not do you any hurt.

The Wie Euphroias, aid all thee things before him, not that he believed they would do any good, or that the King being engaged by his word, would be taken off it; but his drift only was, to cool a little that angry heat which was kindled in the oul of Merindor; hoping, that if the firt impetuoity were but a little allayed, he might the more eaily afterwards perwade him to reaon. And indeed, it came o to pas, that Merindor conidering upon what he had aid, and finding ome colour of probability in it, he began to hearken a little unto reaon: and in concluion, they did not part until he reolved abolutely to follow whatoever Euphroias did dictate, until uch time as all hopes were lot: and at the ame time they determined amongt themelves, to imploy thoe about the King, whom they thought had mot credit with him: this Wie friend made every thing look with uch a face of facility, as wrought much upon the young mans apprehenions; and he promied unto him everal aitances of great prevalency, though all was only to divert him: for he knew that the bet way to perwade, is to infue great hopes of that which is much deired.

But Madam, I beeech you hear how Heaven is pleaed to play with men, and how fortune does even what he pleaeth; when Merindor made addrees to the King, and humbly beeeched him he would not force Arcingentorix to give his daughter unto Bellimartes, becaue of the interet which he had; King Gondebaut anwered, that he did not know of his Interet, when he firt engaged himelf in the buines: but being now o far engaged, he knew not how to come off, without much prejudice unto his Authority. So, ee how Merindor is blated in all his hopes on that ide; and Bellimartes o aured to be my Husband, that the Articles were drawn; and nothing wanted but going to the Temple. Who would ever think this buines hould be broken off? But ee the black malice, and extream per •• dy of men? When all things were ready, and every one in order to go unto the Temple, a grave Honourable Matron, accompanied with two daughters and four ervants, came to the door of our houe, and with much ado got paage through the croud
of people which flocked thither, he deired to peak with my Father; and after civil aluation, Sir, (aid he unto him, and raied her voice that all might hear) I come to acquaint you, that my daughter whom I hold here in my hand, and whoe name is Alderina, is the Legitimate wife of Bellimartes the Viigot; and that four years have paed ince he publiquely married her in Gergovia, as all the Druides and Nobles of that Province can attet, and as I will make appear before the King, at whoe feet I am now going to protrate my elf, in hopes of Jutice, and that the Common Right of Nations will be maintained and oberved. Upon this, he made a reverence, and went traight to the Palace Royal, not without great houts of the people, when they heard this news.

Whether Arcingentorix was atonihed, judge you; for he was truck into uch an extaie, that he was not able to utter one word: but going into the Hall, where we all were ready to go out, and asking for Bellimartes, Sir, (aid he unto him aloud) do you know a Lady whoe name is Alderina? At the word Alderina, we oberved that he changed colour: why, (aid he) do you ask that quetion? Becaue, (anwered my Father) he and her Mother are at the door, and do let you know, that they are going to the King for Jutice againt you. Againt me, aid he, and why? Becaue, anwered my Father, this Alderina is your wife, and becaue you cannot marry another, as long as he is alive. Upon this, a great noie of atonihment was heard, which was made by all thoe in the Hall: and though Bellimartes made a laughing matter of it, and aid, it was not true, nor ought to retard the marriage, yet none of my kindred were of that opinion, epecially my Father, who told him freely, that he had uch a belief in what the woman aid, as he would never conent his daughter hould marry him, till this impoture was cleered. Bellimartes who was naturally of a proud imperious temper, and thought himelf upported by the Kings favour; let me tell you Arcingentorix, aid he, that I care neither for you nor your daughter, and that I do find my elf much mitaken in the alliance which I intended to make with you. My Father, who was generous, and though age hung heavy upon him, yet could reent the honour of himelf and his Ancetors, Bellimartes, aid he unto him, I had rather you hould deceive your elf then me; and let me tell you, that I value you far les then you can do my daughter or me. As God would have it, Bellimartes never heard thee lat words, for he was gone all in a rage, and left all the company in a trange confuion. But for his part, he was in the greatet confuion of all; becaue his concience, which is a thouand witnees, did convince him of that unworthy act which he would have done. This hour, I believe, was the happiet of all my life: for certainly if this Lady had tayed but this hour longer then he did, I had been married unto him: and mot certain it is, this perfidious wretch had a wife, and as we are informed ince, had quitted her, becaue he was not rich enough: But ee here, what the faith of men is? And how mierable that woman is who truts them; for this Alderina had been long courted by him, and with o many paionate expreions of affection, as it is hardly credible he hould forake her: yet avarice did ince mot hamefully overcome his Love. But o it was Madam, that for this time, I was almot miraculouly delivered from a mi-fortune: for Alderina, having made her addrees to the King, and convinced Bellimartes, who though he denied all, yet he was ordained to take her for his Lawful wife; and charged upon evere penalty, to marry no other, as long as he lived: many did wonder that Alderina being very fair and handom, Bellimartes hould leave her for me, whoe face was enough to affright him: and when anwer was made that he did it out of covetounes, it was hard to be believed, becaue of the many rich preents which he ent unto us, and which ince we ent back: but they did not conider that thoe gifts, which made him thought liberal, they were not given, but only lent, which he knew well enough would return back if he married me, ince then all we had was his: o as this o much eteemed liberality, was mot certainly a bae and unworthy elf ended avarice. Merindor who was going upon his lat, and was fully reolved that when all hope was pat, to kill himelf, but yet to end Bellimartes out of the world before him, he was not the lat man that was advertied of this accident; and as if a new life had been given unto him, he leaped up, clapping his hands together, and bleing the Fates for this happy fortune: then leaving his
chamber, he made all the hate that poibly he could unto mine, where he expreed himelf the mot joyful man alive, and asked an hundred merry quetions: He asked me how I did after my marriage? and whether it was good to be two wives to one Husband; and becaue I knew not well whether I hould laugh or cry, I aid unto him, well, well Merindor, do not mock at me, perhaps when you are married, you may alo find a wife that has two husbands. If I have (aid he) the tronger will drive the other out of the houe; but I fear not any uch accident will ever befal me, unles it be by you. By me? anwered I, Nay, Merindor, the reolution which I have, will free you from that fear; for within thee few days, if my Father will give me leave, I will become of thoe that are to keep in the Sacred Fire. How, how? replied he, will you become a Vetal? Yes certainly (aid I) purpoely to be rid of men, amongt whom I find nothing but deceit and p •• fidie. You do wrong me (aid he) not to put me out of the general number, ince I am ure you never aw any action, or heard any language from me, which was derogatory from my vowed affection, or which in any reaon could induce you to put me into that rank: One indeed, replied I, does make no number; but what do you ay of Theombres, of Hylas, of Periander, and of Bellimartes? I ay (anwered he) that they deerve not only to be razed out of the rank of men, but alo out of the number of the living: But I ay, that all men ought not to be blamed for them, and of all men, epecially Merindor. Oh Madam, give me leave to tell you, it is mot extream injutice to punih a number of innocents for a few culpable; and ince faults are peronal, every peron ought to bear the burthen of his own punihment. I mut confes Merindor, aid I unto him, that you are in the right, but I am not to be blamed; for having found o much falhood and perfidie in all thoe that ever made any addrees unto me, I had good reaon to fear the ame from all others. This Dorinde (aid he) is a econd wrong, not inferiour to the firt; for you rank me in the number of thoe who have deceived you, ince you cannot exclude me from the number of thoe who have made addrees unto you. Hitherto (replied I,) I cannot ay I have been deceived by you; but I cannot tell what you may do upon occaion.

Whilt we were talking thus, my Father came into the chamber, till much moved at the former accident; and eeing this young Cavalier with me, Come Merindor (aid he unto him) are you not much offended againt my Daughter and me, for the fault which the Kings power caued us to commit? Sir (anwered Merindor) I am more your ervant, then to be offended at you; but on the contrary, I thank the Gods for making the vilany of that wicked man known unto you; though let me tell you, that if his vilany had been executed, the Vilain hould not have lived an hour after; for I wear by the great God Ifeus, this word hould have wahed away his crime with his own blood, for not one ingle drop hould have remained: But Sir, thanks be to God that there is no need of uch extremities; and remember I beeech you for the future, that our old Fathers had good reaon to ay, That no man ought to rub an herd which he knows not: And Sir, there are many in this Province whoe Ancetors and Etates are known unto you; and who would think themelves honoured and happy in your Alliance: And if heaven would make me o happy as to obtain that favour, what ervices (aid he, and kneeled down) would I not pay unto you all my life, and what love, what duty and affection hould not Dorinde receive from me? Dorinde I ay, whom you know I ever loved and honoured, what accidents oever hapned. The good old man who knew how affectionate he alwaies appeared, even all the time of my icknes, and eeing him till continue his paionate expreions, he did believe him. But, oh Heavens! who might not as well have been deceived as he? Merindor (aid he unto him) peak freely and ingeniouly, as you are a Cavalier; Are you real, or is it only out of your civility and courthip that you ue thee expreions? Sir, anwered he, I cannot commit an act o unworthy of the name I bear, as to diemble or deceive; and therefore I do protet and wear, that all the words which I have poke, do proceed from the real thoughts of my heart, with all incerity and true meaning, ele may Bellinus root me and my name out from the number of men. If o, replied Arcingentorix, and that it prove o that Bellimartes has another wife, and that your mother do conent unto your deires, I do promie you Dorinde for your wife, and I do call the Gods to
be a witnes unto the promie which now I make unto you. And I (added Merindor) do call all the Gods to witnes, that I do receive this promie as the greatet happines I can deire: for hence forward, I do devote my elf unto you Sir, as my Lord and Father; and unto Dorinde as my Lady and Mitres, and I do vow and wear unto you both, an affection without end, and perpetual obedience. Who would have thought, that heard thee olemn protetations expreed which o much freenes, but that they proceeded from his heart? But alas, o they did: I confes they did proceed from his heart, but it was from the mot wicked, vile, perfidious heart, that ever was in any traiterous and perjured man: certainly it is enough to expree him, to ay that he is a man without any addition of traiterous, or perfidious, or perjured; for I do believe all others that bre • th upon the face of the earth, are o. Now this man, according to the nature and cutom of all others, went from us in appearance full of contentment, as full as man could be, and went unto the Palace to hear more certain news of Alderina and of her marriage: at night he returned again, and told us that the King having een the attetations of the Druids and Nobles of Gergovia, was highly offended againt Bellimartes, and had commanded him to depart his Dominions, and never to come into his preence again; yet ome Grandees about Gondebaut, were in hope to obtain, his Pardon, when the King his choller was a little over: and o it hapned; for a while after, they were reconciled by the mediation of Alderina her elf; who fell down at the feet of Gondebaut, who pardoned her Husbands fault, upon condition he would live with her as he ought:

Whilt thee things hapned, it eems the Gods were pleaed to mock Periander, for the pring coming on, and ome remedies which a Phiitian gave me, did o retore my complexion and features, that it was much better then before; and indeed my companions, aid he unto the three trangers, I believe you will confee it better then ever you aw it before: but o it hapned, that as my deformity did chae away Periander from me o my recovery called him back.

I cannot expres the joy and contentment of Merindor, when from day to day, he aw my complexion return: and not being able (as he aid) to endure any longer delay in our marriage, he entreated my Father to give him conent that he might go unto his Mother for hers, there being nothing ele which could hinder it. Oh Heavens what new protetations did he make to my Father and me when he departed, I have wondred ince a hundred times, that the earth did not open and wallow him alive.

I hould but trouble you, Madam, did I relate the whole eries of his actions: but o it was, that going away, he lot all memory of me, and all his oaths: about three months after his departure, he ent one of his Brothers unto me with a Letter, which I will read unto you, for I keep it till about me, to convince him of his falhood and perjury: then putting her hand into her pocket, he pulled out a paper, and read thee words:

div.head: MERINDORS Letter unto DORINDE:
div.p: I Would to God (Fair Dorinde) that I were out of the World, or ele, that I were not the Son of that Woman who is my Mother; or at leat, that I were my Brother: and al to the end, as your mot humble ervant, that I might obtain that happines which I deire: but being as I am, it is not permitted me: the offer which I make of him, makes it evident unto all, that all marriages are made in Heaven.

Do you not wonder, dicreet and Fair Shepherdees (aid Dorinde) that Merin dor hould write uch a Letter unto me? For if he had quitted me, one would have thought in all reaon, that he hould have done it when I was ugly and deformed, as Periander did: but that he hould with uch aiduity abide the horror of my dieae; that he hould never care for any deformity in my face, but even then to
court me with uch violence and zeal, and then to leave me when my Beauty was retored, and when I thought nothing could eparate us, but his own will, or rathe levity: this eems to be againt the grain of all reaon in the World. And I mut needs confes the truth, this action did go o neer unto my heart, that I vowed never hence-forward to trut any man living; but to flye and hun all uch as bore the name, and never to have any more to do with them. My Father was offended at this as much as I; and therefore without any further conultation, or heeding any applications that Merindor •
Brother would have made unto me, he ent him back with this udden and peremptory anwer, that his Daughter was neither for Merindor nor his Brother: and therefore he intended to dipoe of me another way. And becaue the young man deired an anwer unto his Brothers Letter, with my Fathers leave I returned this:

div.head: DORINDES anwer unto MERINDOR:
