div.p: I Would to God, unfaithful Merindor, that you were not upon the earth, or that I never had had any eyes to ee you; or at the leat that I were a man for a time, and not a woman; and all this to the end, that as your mortal enemy I might take that revenge of your perfidy, which I deire: but ince being as I am, that is not permitted me, The offer which you make unto me of your Brother, which I refue, makes it evident, that the marriage betwixt him and me, is not made in Heaven; at the leat I aure you, hall never be accomplihed on Earth.

Now Madam, (continued he) you may oberve three of the mot horrid infidelities (to omit the ret) that ever were committed againt any woman. Thee that I have told you, are enough to make any that have eyes or their wits, never to trut any that has either the name or the figure of a man: but hear what torments they caued me to endure; and then I am confident you will confes that the hatred which I bear unto this animal, man, is grounded upon mot jut caue.

Dorinde would have continued, had not the noie of men on hore-back, diturbed them: thee Fair Shepherdees being unaccutomed to ee uch aemblies in their Villages, they all ran out of curioity to the door: Dorinde and the other trangers did the ame; then they aw pae along the way, which joyned almot cloe to the door of this Cabin, fifteen or ixteen perons very well mounted, and armed, alter the Burgundian fahion, having head-pieces upon their heads, Suits of Arms for back and bret, a Javelin in their right hands, and a Buckler on their left arm. Thee men marched in order, and in the head of them was him who conducted them, as might be imagined, both by the goodnee of his Hore, which was much fairer then the ret, and by the richnes of his Armor, which was almot all gilt, and a Plume in his Head-piece, which made him remarkable above the ret. This Troop marched very fat, and their Armor and Hores eet made a great noie: as for the men they talked not loud, though they did hold ome dicoure which could not any ditance be undertood. When they came neer unto this Cabin, they cat their eyes upon thee Shepherdees, which out of curioity were come to the door, and eeing them o Fair, they tayed a little, almot ravihed to ee uch Fair Faces in uch rural Cottages. Oh Heavens, cryed he that commanded them, is not yonder Dorinde? She, hearing her elf named, and looking him in the face, he preently remembred that he had een him very often with King Gondebaut: and therefore fearing ome violence, he retired into the Cabin, to try if he could hide her elf: but he, being more aured by this action that it was he, did preently alight, and five or ix of his companions with him: and entring very bluteringly amongt thee women, they came to the place where Dorinde was retired; who trembling for fear, and hiding her face with her hands, he looked as pale as death. Celadon in the dree of Druide, wihed now that he had Arms, to repule the injury which thee trangers eemed to offer unto Dorinde, and not being able to endure any outrage
hould be done unto her in his preence, he firt ued entreaties and fair language; and eeing them lighted, and offers made to carry away that trembling woman out of the Cabin, he could not chue but joyn hands unto his language, and beyond the trength of a woman, like man, reit this violence. The Captain and the Souldiers would quickly have dipatched him, had they believed him to be a man, but thinking him to be a woman Druide, their repect unto that ex, and the reverence they bore unto her habit, made them take it into their conideration. All the ret of the women, eeing this attempt of the Druide, after her example, did their endeavours to ave Dorinde, and perhaps this feeble defence, had held them long in play, had not the Captain being grown into choller, made a ign unto the Souldiers, that without any conideration of thee women, they hould ue force, and carry her away. As Celadon was holding the arms of this man o as he could not tir, Atrea and Diana were on both ides of Dorinde, and held her by the arms; but the Souldiers who had received the ign from their Commander, puhing them both very roughly away, they contrained thee Shepherdees to let their hold go, and with uch violence that Atrea fell to the ground. Who crying out, and the Druide turning about her head, eeing her o unworthily ued, he grew as furious as any raging Lyon, and letting him go whom he held, and ran upon him who did the affront with uch violence, and gave him uch a blow upon the face, as he contrained him to let Dorinde go, who was already pulled out of the door, and after he had reeled two or three paces, he fell amongt the hores feet, which trampled him o, as he was not able to do more harm unto this fair company: the Captain in the mean time being out of the Druids hands, and eeing they had carried Dorinde out of the place, he went out alo, to ee her carried away according to his deign: but when he was out, he aw his companions on foot, and running after her in the fields: for fear made her o wift, as he eemed to have wings at her heels. At the firt, he laughed, for he confidently believed he would be taken again. But whilt he was looking and laughing at this chae, for o may the flight of Dorinde be termed, they aw appear ix Cavaliers, who being very well mounted and armed, came riding the ame way. At the firt, they rid in file, as Travellers ue in a Journey; but when they aw o many men running after one woman, they drew up together, and galloped to oppoe the violence which they thought would be done unto her. Yet they could not come in o oon, but Dorinde was firt taken; and becaue he had no other defence, they aw her fall down upon her knees, hold up her hands, and make lamentable prayers and upplications to them. The Souldiers, on the other ide, without any compaion, took her, and would have carried her away: when thee Cavaliers came up unto them, they out of pity, though they knew not Dorinde, oppoed this violence; but one of them upon a udden cating his eye upon her, did know her: Oh ye crew of villains (aid he unto the Souldiers) and unworthy to bear arms, ince you imploy them o ill; ceae wronging her whom ye all ought to honour and erve, or ele by Heaven (aid he, and drew his word) I will chatie you according to your merits. Sir, (anwered one of them) King Gondebaut commanded us to do what we have done, and none ought or can oppoe his will. Upon this, not caring for the menace of the Cavalier, and eeing him o lenderly accompanied, alo his Captain and company coming to his relief, he continued on his way: at which the Cavalier was o incened, that he gave him uch a blow upon the houlder, that for all his Coat of Male, it gave him a deep wound, and being a little ditant from Dorinde, he rid upon him with his hore, and trod him to the ground. In the mean time, the ret of the Cavaliers advanced againt the Captain, and his Souldiers, who without any expotulations, did aault them very furiouly. The Cavaliers being better armed, and better mounted, and having more courage, though they were interior in number, yet gave them uch a hot alute that the combat did not lat above a quarter of an hour: for the Captain being killed, the ret were quickly routed, and fled ome one way, and ome another, as fat as ever their hores could carry them. This victory was the ooner gotten, by reaon that mot of one party was on foot, and were running after their hores, which were broken looe in the fields. But of thee ix Cavaliers, two of them were killed, and one o wounded that he could hardly it his hore.

p.U: eeing this unlook'd for relief, although he thought he knew the voice of him who poke, yet not being ure, becaue his head-piece covered his face, he retired as fat as he could in a trembling and panting pace unto her companions, though not o much affrighted as when he was firt eized upon: But when he was told of the end of the combate, for he was gotten into the cabbin, and that one of the Cavaliers who defended her was much wounded, he went out of the cabin with watry eyes and cheeks to receive him and help him all that poibly he could: And becaue his three companions took off his helmet to give him Ayr, as oon as he cat her eye upon him, he knew him to be Bellimartes; at which he was o urprized, that he knew not whether he dream'd or waked: But whilt the three Cavaliers were laying him upon the Bed, and one of them tayed with him, the other two pulled off their helmets, and kneeled down before her, hewing all igns of humble obedience; he all the while was o urprized at the ight of them, that he could not utter a word; for the one was Merindor, and the other Periander. Oh heavens! (cryed he out at the lat, when he could peak) Oh heavens! Is it poible I hould be thus much obliged unto three men, who have made me hate all men living for their akes? Merindor then began firt to peak: Oh Dorinde (aid he unto her) do not by your disfavours leen that contentment which heaven has given us, in rendring you a tetimony that we do love you more then you would be loved by us. After this, Periander continued, Heaven (fair Dorinde) has made choice of us, to render you this little ervice; and believe, that the choice could not be made of any others, who have vowed o much affection as we: Receive, we mot humbly beeech you, the willingnes we have to expoe our lives in repuling that violence which was offered unto you. I do protet, aid Bellimartes, and turned his head towards her, I hall leave this world the mot contented man that is in it, ince I have lot my life in your ervice; and if you will have me think my death more welcome then ever was my life, fair Dorinde, Do but only ay, Go in peace Bellimartes.

div.p: Dorinde turning her eyes upon Bellimartes, and eeing a mortal palenes in his face, he only embraced Merindor and Periander, and not having leiure to peak unto them, he ran unto Bellimartes, who expreed uch igns of perfect contentment, as every one oberved an alteration in his eyes and countenance; but epecially when he took his hand, and aid unto him; If heaven hath decreed that you mut end your days in this relief which your Valour has given me, be aured Bellimartes, that it hall never be forgotten; and if it be the pleaure of the Gods, as I hall pray it may, to prolong your life unto my contentment, be confident that I will never be ungrateful unto Bellimartes. Madam (aid he, and forced himelf to peak) to give you my life, which is o much your due, deerves no recompence: but I beeech you accept alo of my oul, which I do mot religiouly devote unto you, and will never take it out of the fair hands of Dorinde: Upon this he would have kied her hand, but he wanted trength; for he grew pale and cold, and immediately died in the arms of that Cavalier who held him in the bed, and whoe tears and lamentations made all beholders pity him.

This lat action of Bellimartes did o mollifie the heart of Dorinde, that forgetting the fault which he had committed againt her, and reviving the memory of that affection which by o many addrees he had expreed unto her, he could not chue but accompany his death with tears of compaion and amity; an office which he continued long in performing, and had continued longer, if the company, moved unto pity, had not removed her by force from the Corps; o eeing her elf contrained to leave him, Adieu Bellimartes (aid he unto his corps) if thou didt think it a happines to have my love, go contented into the Elizian fields, & be aured, that thou art happier in thy death then in thy life. Thee expreions were accompanied with tears, to tetifie they were real, and that he had gotten her love in dying, more then he could have obtained by living.

Whilt all thee things thus paed, a great number of Shepherds in the neighbouring Vilages came running with Pike-taves, and uch Arms as they ued in hunting, and ome brought Bows and Arrows, uch as they ued at their general Aemblies in the Forret of Ioures, and other meetings: o as in a little time there was a
great Army about this little Cabin: Their atonihment was not a little when they heard of the violence which was offered unto that fair tranger by the firt company, and when they heard of the relief which the lat brought her o opportunely; and their wonder was more yet, when they aw thoe marks which the Cavaliers left of their courage and valour. Merindor and Periander eeing Dorinde in the hands of the Druide and Shepherdees, they thought it fit to leave her a little to dry up her tears, whilt in the mean time they went to pay that office unto their dead companions, which the urvivors were obliged unto; and the more, becaue Periander had lot a coin german, and Merindor a brother, whom they exceedingly loved. Leaving therefore the other Cavalier with the corps of Bellimartes, they went out of the cabin, accompanied with many Shepherds, and went afterwards amongt the dead to look for their kinred: They found them both cloe by one another; the one was run through with a Javelin which pierced his heart, and Merindor's brother lay under his hore with a wound given by a word through his breat; but as a note of their valour, four dead enemies did lie about thee two, who held their words till in their hands, with viages which eemed to threaten as well dead as alive.

The griefs and lamentation of Merindor and Periander were indeed very great, and had been greater, if ome Druides had not at the ame time come thither; and this great number of people were ent by their authority to appeae the tumult, as upon uch occaions they ued to do. Thee Druides undertanding the jut and generous defence which thoe Cavaliers had made in relieving this tranger; after that they had highly commended them, and in the name of the Country given them many thanks, they endeavoured by all manner of ways to comfort them, and therefore they deired them to leave their immoderate grief, and alo leave the care of their friends interment unto them; which after many entreaties they permitted, but not without embracing and kiing their dead kinred everal times, and bidding them their lat farewel.

The Druides being advertized that there was yet one of their companions dead in the next cabin? they went and brought him thither, and there wahed their Corps in the River Lignon, afterwards interred them in the place where the combate was; and latly, they raied up monuments of Earth upon their graves, and decked them with all the rural Art that is imaginable. This Funeral ceremony was performed with o much honour and order, that Merindor, Periander, and the Cavalier who was friend unto Bellimartes, had reaon in ome degree to leen their mourning.

Dorinde during all the time of this ceremony, never tirred out of the cabin, becaue he had not yet recollected her elf, nor was rid of her fears; The Shepherdees Atrea, Diana, and Phillis, with the diguied Druide, did keep Florice, Cercinea, and Palinice company; all whom could not ufficiently wonder at this unaccutomed accident: And when Periander and Merindor returned to give an account of that charitable office which they had performed, they, aw a Shepherd coming, who eemed to be in very great hate; when he was a little nearer, he was known to be Hylas: Periander no ooner heard him named, but he cryed out; Oh God, aid he, is it Hylas of the Ile of Camargues, the bet humored man alive, and the mot jolly companion? The very ame, anwered one of the Druides that came with them, he has ojourned in this Country everal moneths; and he found every day o delightful, as I do not think he will ever leave it. Periander then turning towards Merindor, Brother (aid he) I beeech you go you unto Dorinde, and tell her, if he ask for me, that you left me with Hylas, I am confident he will be very glad to hear it, for I mut needs go and meet and embrace him as one of my bet friends: Upon this, he went a great pace towards Hylas, who eeing him coming, did not know him, as well becaue of his Arms, as becaue he little expected to find him in that place: Periander held out his Arms, and embraced him, he not knowing that thee carees came from Periander. But when he aid unto him, Is it poible Hylas that you hould be turned a Shepherd of Forrets, and quite forget your good friends? His voice made him know that face which he had forgotten, and therefore he took him about the neck and kied him, and was o tranported with joy, that he eemed to be almot out of himelf. Then Periander aid unto him, ee Hylas whether I have not good reaon to complain againt your memory, that does not only forget me when
I am abent but alo when I am preent; but I am glad to ee you, and to tetifie how really I love you, I am come to ee you, accompanied with one whom you love the bet of any in the world. Periander (anwered Hylas) I pray ditinguih what kind of one you peak? It is a man or a woman? For if it be a man, none can be more welcom unto me then your elf, ince there is none I love better then I do Periander; and if it be a woman, then, if it be he I love bet, you have met with Stella, for it is he unto whom I have devoted my elf. What? replied Periander, have you forgotten Dorinde? Dorinde anwered Hylas, I perceive my good friend, that you have forgotten the cutom of Hylas; you mut know, that her name has hardly room in my memory: for ince I have een o many Creyides, o many Madonthes, o many Laonices, o many Phillies, o many Alexies, and above all one Stella, who dazles my eyes, I tell you the luter of o many new lights, will not let me ee, the obcurities of your City of Lyons.

I perceive (aid Periander, and miled) that you are till the ame Hylas, upon the banks of Lignon, that you were wont to be upon thoe of Arar. The very ame (aid Hylas) but yet, if Dorinde be here, I hall be glad to ee her, that I may know whether my mouth was not in thoe dayes out of tate: If you deire to ee her, aid Periander, you may go into that Cabin, and find her till frighted, at an accident which hapned: What accident? aid Hylas, it is, anwered Periander, that but for Bellimartes, Merindor, and my elf, ome of King Gondebauts Souldiers would have carried her away: but we finding her jut in the very nick of time, we made them quit their enterprize; but alas the poor Bellimartes is dead, with Merindor's Brother, and I have lot a Coen germane. How? replyed Hylas, have you thus handled King Gondebaut's men? If o, I beeech you, carry me to Dorinde, for I mut of neceity advertie her of ome things which I have heard, and which caued me to come hither in uch hate.

They were then cloe by the Cabin, o as Hylas upon this entred, who eeing all the Shepherdees about the tranger, did judge her to be Dorinde; but faigning not to know her: where is this new Shepherdes, aid he, who at her firt coming has tained the purity of our banks with bloody Sacrifices? Dorinde then knowing Hylas, roe up to alute him, being very glad to meet him in that place, where he thought he hould need all manner of aitance; and going towards him, is it poible Hylas; aid he, that my face hould be o changed, as your eyes hould not know her now, whom your heart did formerly know o well? I believe, anwered Hylas, that if my heart were here, it might anwer the quetions which you ask, but ince it is not, I think there are few here who can tell what to ay unto them. How? aid Dorinde, your heart not here? Who is the thief that tole it? As for any male thieves, replied he, I know how to keep it well enough from them; but I mut confee my bad influences has ubmitted me unto ome certain Female thieves, againt whom I cannot poibly defend my elf: and the wort is, they are of an humour, that the firt thing they eize upon is the heart, o as I can very eldom keep this little piece of houhold tuffe in my houe. I believe, aid Dorinde, that when thee Femal thieves do teal it from you, it is not long before you can furnih your elf with another: You are mitaken (aid Florice and interrupted) for thoe who do teal it, do find it uch a bad piece of tuff, that they preently retore it back again at the next meeting: you are mitaken your elf, aid Hylas, and you had better have aid, that becaue it is impoible two hearts hould dwell together, without the tronger driving out the weaker, thoe who do teal my heart, are contrained to let theirs come unto me, and become mine, and tay with me until ome other thief do teal it from me to give me her own; and therefore Dorinde, if you have any occaion for your heart, which you ent unto me, when you tole mine, ask it of Florice; and you Florice, ask yours of Cryeide when you ee her next: and let Cryeide ask hers of Madonthe; and if Madonthe will have that back, which I had of hers, let her look out Laonice: and whooever has any thing to do with Laonices, they will find it in Phillis: and you Phillis, if you deire to have yours again to betow upon any Shepherd, bid the Fair Druide return it unto you; for as for hers which I had, it is now in the poeion of Stella, who in a happy exchange, did mot courteouly give me hers, which I will keep as long as it pleaeth me; but Dorinde, aid Periander,
and interrupted, I beeech you let us dicoure upon thee hearts another time when we have more leiure: Hylas comes to advertie you, that you are not afe in this place, and therefore it is requiite you hear what he ays: you do very well, aid Hylas, to put me in memory of it; for this new Shepherdes, does o put me in mind of what is pat, that I forget the preent. Let me tell you therefore that not long ince, as I lay cloe in a buh expecting a Shepherdes whom I loved, and was to walk that way with her Flock, I aw four men on hor-back, terribly affrighted, and in great diorder; and one of them had a great cut upon his hand, which bleeding extreamly, contrained them to alight very near the place where I was; and having left one to watch whether any followed, the other held the hores, and the third tore his handkerchief, gathered a little ground-moe, and applied it unto the wound to top the blood; in the mean time I heard one of them ay, that if they made a little more hate, they hould meet with the ret of their company from whom they were parted; & then they would return, and be revenged, by bringing away that woman whom King Gondebaut o much deired to have. As oon as they were gone, I met with ome Shepherds, who told me partly what had hapned in this place, unto which I came purpoely to tell you, that unles you have a mind to fall into their hands, you mut remove from this place. Oh ye Gods! (cryed out Dorinde with tears in her eyes) will not fortune let me remain at ret, even in thee olitary places? Madam, aid Periander, when we came away from Lyons, we heard that you were purued by many of King Gondebauts guard; and therefore if you will take my advice, you hall eek out ome place of trength for your ecurity: as long as Merindor and I do live, we will defend you againt all the world; but we being but three, with this Cavalier that is friend unto Bellimartes, our lives may be taken away by a multitude, and you injured, which is wore then the loe of us. Licydas upon this, who was come unto this place upon the noie, a little before Hylas. Madam, aid he, we will all of us erve you, againt all that hall offer you any injury; but give me leave to tell you, that to avoid a mis-fortune, it were good you were conducted unto Marelles, where your merits would meet with much honour and repect from all: the great Nymph Amais, and Galathea, will bid you welcom, and defend you againt all violence.

Every one did much approve of this advice; And becaue Dorinde was unwilling to put her elf into the hands of thee Cavaliers by her elf alone, Florice, Cercinea, Palinice, and Celidea, offered themelves to accompany her, provided ome Shepherds would go with them, becaue they would not return alone. Hylas, Lycidas, Thamires, Calidon and Corilas, did preent themelves very freely: and therefore without more delay, after thee trangers had bid adieu unto Alexis, Diana, Atrea, and Phillis, and the ret of the Shepherdees, they et forward: the three Cavaliers, mounted and armed as when they came firt, kept at a mall ditance from the company, in a poture to defend them, if any came to aault them: and the ret of the Shepherds, helped the Shepherdees to walk, whilt Thamires helped his dear Celidea.

Now all the company parted; Atrea, Diana, and Phillis, to accompany Alexis, went towards the houe of Phocion, becaue it grew very late; and by the way, admiring the accident that had hapned unto this tranger: I aure you, aid Atrea, Dorinde is lee beholding unto thoe that love her, then to thoe that do not; why? aid Phillis, becaue, anwered he, thoe that do not love her, do not deceive her, and thoe that do, betray her: why good Siter (aid Diana) do you not think that all men are deceivers? Certainly you are deceived if you think otherwie: for believe it for an infallible truth, that falhood and treachery will be in the world as long as there is one man in it. Alexis, who though in the habit of a woman, yet could not hake off thoe reentments of a man which nature had infued; is it poible dicreet and Fair Shepherdes, (aid he) that you hould think as you peak? Is it poible Madam, anwered Diana, that you hould live to this age, and be ignorant of the truth of which we peak? That men hould be o bad as you ay they are, aid Alexis, and yet I not know it, is not trange: for my education amongt Druids has been o retired from all men, that we do hardly know them further then by name: but yet I cannot imagine that the great Tautates, who is all goodnes, would ever give unto
our ex uch a bad companion as you repreent him. I can anwer you no otherwie (aid Diana) but that it is a ecret reerved to himelf: and if it be lawful for me to tell you what I think, I believe it is to make us exercie the virtue of Patience. Oh Siter, aid Atrea, I am not of your opinion, and I believe very few are: Atrea, replied Diana, how were you atisfied with Celadon? for my part anwered Atrea, I had no reaon to be ill atisfied with him you name, no more then you were with Philander: I mut needs confes, aid Diana, I had no reaon to be di-atisfied in him, but I believe if he had lived longer, I might have been, for he was a man: Alexis hearing Celadon named, began to bluh, and not daring to look upon Atrea, he cat her eyes upon the ground; but when he heard her ay that he had no reaon to be more di-atisfied with Celadon, then Diana was with Philander, he was very deirous to know what occaions of di-atisfaction Philander had ever given her, to the end he might know by that, what it was which his Shepherdee complained of: and eeing that Diana, did not anwer any further, he began: But dicreet Shepherdes (aid he unto her) oblige me o far, I beeech you, as to tell me freely, what di-atisfaction you received from that Shepherd of whom you peak. Madam, anwered he, the dicoure would be too long and tedious for your ears, and for me to relate. You may if you pleae, replied Celadon, epitomize it in o hort a method, as will not be a trouble unto either. Phillis upon this replied for her: Madam, aid he, I beeech you, pardon her from that whole dayes work, which I aure you would weary her more then you imagine: I hould mot willingly atisfie your curioity, and tell you what di-atisfaction Diana received from that Shepherd; but that I know the bad fortune of Philander, made uch a wound in the oul of Diana, as cannot be touched with never o delicate a hand, but it is o enible as will grieve her: but Siter, aid he unto Diana, pray tell me, what exceptions have you againt Lycidas? I ay, anwered Diana, that he is not yet dead nor married, and that perhaps before either of thee come to pas, uch things may fall out, as may give you occaion to rank him in the Catalogue of men. Oh Siter, aid Phillis, who do you foretel uch things as cannot chue but infinitely dipleae me? and of which there is no appearance? But I ee, a pallate out of tate, makes all viands eem bitter. Siter, replied Diana, I know your meaning; but conider, that he is a man, and conequently a deceiver: and when Merindor deceived Dorinde, there was no appearance, nor no likelyhood he hould do o: and yet you ee he did. You mut know, that deceipts, are not deceipts, unles they deceive the expectation of thoe againt whom they are done, and therefore they mut be done o, as there may be no appearance or thought of them before hand. For my part, aid Atrea, who has no interet in thee things you peak of, I ought to be believed before either of you, and therefore hearken unto my opinion: I do believe, that men are not uch deceivers as many do think them, nor o faithful, as many have opinion they are. Good Servant (aid Alexis) explain this riddle; Mitris, aid Atrea, my meaning is, that ome men are deceivers, and ome are not; all ought not to be meaured by one and the ame ell; and that the virtues and vices of ome, ought not to be the honour, or di-honour of others: and therefore, thoe who have caue to complain againt the infidelity of men, ought not to ay poitively that they are all deceivers: nor thoe who have full aurance of the fidelity of ome particular man, mut not think, but that another may be unfaithfull.

Their Dicoure had lated longer, had they not heard the voice of a Shepherd inging, whom they preently knew to be Sylvander: and coming a little neerer the hedge where he ate, they heard him repeat ome veres, which intimated that he was not changed: Diana who was the firt that heard him, would have drawn off the company from hearing any further: but for all that, they would needs hear him on: and then they heard him break out into thee expreions.

Mierable Sylvander (aid he with a deep igh) why dot thou drone on this mierable life, and has uch, and o much reaon to die? Is it out of hopes of any better Fortune? Ah fond man, is it not full time to undeceive thy elf, at leat, if thou hat any conideration, any feeling, or any enibility of thy unfortunate life? Thou beginnet now to enter into the fifth luter, ince the mierable day of thy birth; and in o many nights, o many weeks, o many moneths, and o many years, cant thou
name one minute that was not remarkable for ome misfortune or other? I cannot indeed call that hour diatrous in which I firt aw Diana, ince in her I aw all the excellencies and perfection that Nature can give unto mortals: but was not that the time that Fortune took a greater Empire over me then ever he had before? For if he had any power over me before, it was only over my poor heep; and the little tock which I had, but my oul was free, and exempt from blows and changes: But oh ye Gods! ince I aw this fair, this divinely fair Diana, my oul is a lave, and from being inenible, is grown o weak and o ubmis, that the leat Will of this Shepherdes is a Law unto me, her commands are Oracles, and the leat twinkle of her, commands o abolute, that I would rather chue the wort death, then diobey the leat haddow of her Will: and is not this the very height of miery, that all my cares, all my ervices, all my endeavours, and all my extream paions hould be o many offences, and o many injuries unto her? If the Univere, and all that is compried in it, be ruled and governed by reaon, what reaon is there, that I having no deigne but to do her ervice with all manner of affection and fidelity, that he hould make no return but hatred and corn? Then making a top, and taying mute a while, he began again: But oh ye Gods! I do undertand this ecret, or at the leat I think I do; It is to punih me becaue I have loved this divine Diana too much, and have preferred my affection unto her, before that which I owed unto you. But if it be o, give me leave with all reverence to expotulate a little with you; why did you not make her with les perfection? For being as he is, it were a in to love her les then I do: But well (aid he with a profound igh) do your pleaure, and if you think good, double and redouble your punihment, for I cannot leen or diminih one jot.

Whilt Sylvander was talking thus to himelf, Diana had got a good ditance off, and Phillis having no mind to leave her alone, did how her unto Alexis and Atrea, and whipered them in their ears, that if they intended to tay any longer, he would go and tay with her; but the Druide and her companion eeing it was late, they thought it would be to no purpoe to tay any longer in that place, where they could not receive any better atisfaction of this Shepherds innocency then they had; and therefore tealing off unperceived, they went as fat as they could to overtake Diana, unto whom they told all that they could in dicharge of Sylvander. But he, eeming as if he cared not, he anwered in uch a kind of neglective manner, as if he were not Sylvander they talked of, or as if he was not Diana whom they talked to.

Alexis admiring the trength of Dianas pirit, knowing very well by experience how hard a thing it is to reit a domineering paion; I mut confes, fair Shepherdees (aid he) That I could never have met with any women uch abolute Mities of themelves, nor men uch Lovers, as I ee there are about the banks of Lignon. Why do you ay this? aid Atrea. Becaue ervant (anwered Alexis) hearing the dicoure of Sylvander, and the anguih he endures, it mut be acknowledged that he does love infinitely who can endure it. And with what coldnes Diana does light it, I mut needs confes and ay, that in her alone, paion does ceae to be paion, and become eeming reaon. Madam, anwered Diana, I beeech you pardon me, if I tell you, That you are mitaken in both the judgements which you have given: For as to that which relates unto me, believe it to be a very eaie matter to carry it as I do, having no interet at all in the buines, as you think I have: And as to that which relates unto the Shepherd, be aured, That not only about the Banks of Lignon, but every place where the name of Love is known, men do tudy more to diguie and diemble their affections, then to render them real and great: They reemble puft up bladders, which eem to be omthing that's big, whilt they are nothing but empty wind, and the leat prick of a pin dicovers their empty imperfections, Sage Shepherdes, replied the Druide, I do believe that you have more knowledge then I in the humours of thoe you peak of; but give me leave to tell you, that Sylvander does love. I do believe it Madam, anwered Diana, but it is Madonthe. I do believe (aid Alexis) that Sylvander does love, and that he does love none but Diana. Then certainly (replied he) Madonthe has changed her name, and calls her elf Diana; and if you will not believe me, I will refer you unto Laonice.
You will find aid (aid the Druide) in the end, that there is ome ecret mitery in the report of Laonice: for if it were o, that Sylvander did love Madonthe, why hould he eem to love you? What benefit will accrue unto him by diguiing it? To blind the eyes, anwered he, of the jealous Therander: this might be o, replied Alexis, in the time of Therander, and when Madonthe was here: but now they are gone, to what purpoe hould he o do? Oh Madam, aid Diana, did you but know the humours of men, epecially of Sylvander, you would not make uch a wonder at it: you mut know that there is not a man under the cope of Heaven, who deires more to give a good opinion of himelf then he; and this is the reaon that having made a hew of loving me formerly, he is now ahamed his falhood hould be dicovered: all his paionate expreions and behaviour which you ee, and think they proceed from affection, are but tricks and gloes which he ues, out of hame to be thought a diembler, and a man of no faith.

If he were ahamed, as you object, aid Alexis, that hame would produce contrary effects: for if he loved Madonthe, he would with all peed flye from thoe places where his diimulation would be known; and doubtles would follow her whom he loved: for I have heard that he has no relations in this country to tay him in it, or invite him unto it more then any other place; for he is a man meerly of fortune, and has nothing but what he gets by his indutry, which he may do any where ele, as well as about the River Lignon: alo, ince you peak of Sylvander's humour, I mut tell you, that in this hort time I have known him, and oberved his dicoure, I find him to be a Shepherd of o free a Spirit, and of o pure and genuine wit, as I cannot believe any uch abominable vice to be in him, as diimulation is; and indeed intance me one action of all his life which argues him of that humour: I have heard by a general report of all the Country, that he is a very Wie, and Virtuous Shepherd: and is it probable that one ingle man hould deceive o many eyes which oberve his actions? Aure your elf Diana that you are mitaken in your judgement. 'Tis true Madam, aid Diana, and interrupted, that perhaps I was: but now I am not, and if one could foreee the future, I never will be in my judgment of Sylvander, unles my reolution do change very much: Phillis who till then tood ilent to hear the reaons of her companion, eeing now that he replied not; he began to peak; Siter, (aid he unto her, for o he called her) I have no interet in the buines in quetion, farther then in relation to you, and I aure my elf no more has any here: and therefore you ought to receive what we ay, not as coming from perons who are well wihers of Sylvander, but as from your good friends, who had rather be deceived themelves, then be any Intruments that others hould deceive you. When you have this belief in us, as truly you ought to have, you will preently think that when we peak any thing of this Shepherd, it is not to divert you from any good deign you may have, nor to your prejudice to advantage Sylvander, ince he is meerly indifferent unto us; but on the contrary, you know we love you, and would if it were poible deliver you from an opinion which doubtles, (et as good a face upon it as you will) will bring you nothing but dicontent: Conider Siter, that every one is blind in their own cae, and often, that which they mot would have, is wort for them. Siter, aid Diana, I never made the leat quetion or doubt of your affection to me, nor of that age Druids, ince he was pleaed to ay that he loved me, but mut needs give credit unto the words of one whom I think o jut; I receive this favour which you are pleaed to confer upon me, with abundance of repect and thanks; auring you, that both in this and every thing ele, I will always prefer your judgment before my own in all things: but I beeech you give me leave to tell you withall, that thoe who are not concerned in a buines, farther then reentment and compaion caueth, commonly they do not conider nor look into the matter o neerly, as thoe who mut bear all the burthen: and to their advice and their counels, although they do not proceed from any ill will, but perhaps from much affection, yet may they be mitaken and be deficient in many things; becaue the judgment which they give, cannot be good and olid, unles it be grounded upon mot certain knowledg: and therefore we do commonly ay, that every one knows bet where his hooe pinches him, or on which ide the pain is mot troubleome. But Siter, aid Atrea, things that are dubious, and cannot
be well made out, me thinks hould be decided by plurality of voices: for my part, this has been always my rule, that were I ee all are of opinion that uch a thing is of a green colour, which eems red unto me, I do infallibly believe, that my eye is deceived, or ele I hould think the thing to be of the ame colour which all others do: you have an opinion that Sylvander loves Madonthe, and we all ay that there is no uch thing, nor any probability of it; why therefore hould not you conform your opinion unto ours? But Siter, replied Diana, I am not alone; Laonice who has een the truth, does econd me; Laonice, aid Atrea, is ubtile enough to ay it, with a deign of putting you to abundance of pain and trouble. What profit, aid Diana, will accrue unto her by that? The profit, replied Astrea, which uch reap who are delighted in owing editious, it is their patime and pleaure; and hers may be to ee how you will carry it out, and perhaps to dicover, whether it be true that Sylvander does love you, or you him: good Siter, do not give more credit unto that ubtile woman, then you do unto your dearet friends: the judgment of all thoe who do know Sylvander, will be againt you; the whole coure of that Shepherds life has been uch, as his very enemies cannot lay the leat reproach to his charge: Joyn all thee together, and add thereunto the reaons which we have preented unto you, and afterwards ee, whether it be likely, or have any hadow of likelyhood, that the ingle tetimony of Laonice can be true and credible. Furthermore (aid Phillis) I have talked with Sylvander, and he does o peremptorily deny all that Laonice ays, that if Laonice ay truly, he is the mot detetable Shepherd in the world. Yet every one does know (added Alexis) that Sylvander is a man who ears the Gods, and is not ignorant of what is a in againt them; if he be not ignorant, then he knows how great a in perjury is: and if he do fear the Gods, he would never commit it; and therefore I conclude that my judgment was good, when at the firt I affirmed that Sylvander does love you, and that he loves none ele but you. Madam, aid Diana, and interrupted, not being able to endure the continuation of this dicoure, neither Sylvander nor I, do deerve you hould take o much pains in talking of us, epecially upon a ubject which concerns us o little: for as for him, I believe all his demontrations of good will unto me, are only conequents of that wager which is betwixt Phillis and him: and as for me, I aure you that I did never receive them but under the notion of that diimulation, o as the buines is of o mall a weight, and we are both o little intereted in it, that it is not worth talking of any further. Oh Madam, cryed out Phillis, I protet, he diembles, and peaks very far from her thoughts; pardon me Siter, aid he and turned towards Phillis, if I peak the truth, for I cannot endure this diimulation. Nay, nay, never bluh, aid Phillis, nor lay your hand upon your face to cover it, let we hould ee: you know I peak nothing but truth, and that you do really love Sylvander, alo that Sylvander loves you, I am ure you are not ignorant of it: Alexis and Atrea, began to laugh at the manner of Phillis in her expreions; and Diana her elf could not forbear, although he endeavoured to hide it; and therefore recollecting her elf, he anwered thus; I mut confes Siter, that I did bluh to hear you peak thus, epecially before this great Druide, what opinion do you think he will entertain of me, who has not had the honour to be known unto her till of late? But Madam (aid he, and turned towards Alexis) do not believe what this Shepherdee doth ay; for all is but in jet, and he her elf does not think as he peaks.

Alexis would have anwered, and o would Phillis, but they were o near Atreas houe, that they were contrained to change dicoure, let Phocion hould hear, whom they aw at the door, and who conducted them in, where upper was ready upon the table.

During all the time of the repat, nothing was dicoured upon but the accident of the day; a paage o unaccutomed in that Country, that Phocion aid, in all his time he never heard of the like, unlee that of Philander, when a tranger offered to wrong Diana. Alas, alas! (aid he) that indeed was a day the mot diaterous that Lignon had een of a long time; for ince the death of him and Philidas, I am ure that my contentment has been but a little. I aure you, aid Atrea, fortune will play her game out amongt us humanes every where, as well in the Country, as in great Cities, and as well in Cottages, as roo • s of Cedar, and gilded Palaces of
Princes: alas Siter, you oberve the <> day when Philidas died, becaue in hapned upon your occaion: there is ano •
<> that has good caue to remember another accident; I have not forgot that <>
• hen Celadon drowned himelf; for then I lot a Father and Mother, and am able to ay and ay truly, that my eyes were never dry ince, as oft as I remembred that fatal mis-fortune. And I, aid Alexis, may ay as much, and almot about the ame time, at leat if reports make a true calculation. But thee ad remembrances are the mot cruel enemies we have; and therefore for my part, knowing them to be o, I hun them as much as poibly I can: Oh Mitris, aid Atrea, It is an eaie matter for you to expel uch ad remembrances of things which grieve you, for you have a good Father who loves you, and helps you out with upplies of comforts; but were you an orphan, deprived of Father and Mother as I am, I believe you would more deeply reent the remembrance of uch fatal loes: but however, I have mot jut reaon to be thankful unto Heaven, which after o great a los has not left me without ome upport, in giving me a econd Father, unto whom I am obliged in double bonds of gratitude; but for all that, believe it Mitris, it is a mot ad contraint that eparates a child from Father and Mother. Upon this Phocion began to peak; It is mot certain children (aid he) for o my age permits me to call you, that fortune has the ame power in all places alike; and that he is pleaed to make her power known as well in Villages, as in great Monarchies. But it is true alo, that as high and lofty Towers are more expoed to the tearing tempets and blutering winds, then the humble Cottages wherein we live, o alo we do more eldom ee any of thee bloody conequences of fortune amongt us: they are much more frequent in great Empires, and proud Republiques, which the more ret and quiet they have, the fuller they are of motions and inquietudes, and of greater turbulencies then our poor Villages are capable of: o as what we eteem a torm, is with them a calm. This was the main reaon why thoe from whom we are decended, did chue this kind of life, as the mot happy which mortals can make choie of. But for all that, replied Alexis, I do hear as many complaints and griefs amongt you, as amongt the greatet Potents upon earth. So children, anwered Phocion, do ue to cry for the loe of an apple, as if it were the loe of a great Empire: For my part (aid Diana and interrupted) I do not think orrows are greater, for having the greater caues of them; but that is leat which is leat reented. Mot true, replied Phocion, it is o in regard unto the troubled oul, but not o, if it be reented, and meaured according to the right rules of reaon; for then every thing will be reented and eteemed as it is: and oftentimes when the paion is ceaed, we do laugh at that, at which we cryed before; but all our dicoure (aid Phocion, eeing them ready to rie from the Table) does teach us this, that there is no place under the cope of Heaven which is entirely exempted from the blows of fortune, and that we ought alwayes to tand upon our guards againt them, that when they come to aault us, we may not only reit them, but alo without taking the hadow for the ubtance, which is commonly the greater, we may meaure them according to reaon, and not with any partial reentments of thoe blows which we receive, nor with too many tears which eldom do any good, but with prudence, reaon, moderation and patience.
Upon this they aroe from the Table; and after ome other uch Dicoure, bed-time being come, the Druide, and the three Shepherdees, retired themelves to their chamber:

On the other ide, Dorinde and her companions, with thoe that conducted them, went unto Marelles, and endeavoured to beguil the length of the way, and the perplexities of the ad Dorinde, with various and pleaant dicoure. But Hylas, who led her by the arm, and was not much ued to give way unto any melancholy dumps, not being able to endure her ilence (for when others talked, he was mute) I pray good long ince Mitris (aid he unto her) how long mut this imple ilence lat? My long ince Servant (aid he, and miled) I beeech you pardon me, for I am in a very naughty humour, and cannot help it. Thee dumpih humours (replied he) are allowable in any that have not a Hylas by them; but in you who has me o near you, it is a fault unpardonable; and therefore reolve your elf to leave one or the other, for orrow and I cannot be together. I wih, replied he, that I were
in a better mood, and you hould ee <…> I deire it; therefore I pray tell me what you would have me do? Eith •
<>
• and me, aid Hylas, to relate the adventures which have hapned unto me <> aw you, or ele tell me yours; for uch and o many various actions has befallen me, that you cannot hear them but be delighted: I will promie not to make you any adder then you are, and commonly it is more delightful to hear the adventures of others, then to tell their own. No. aid Thamires, and began to peak, it is more expedient that this fair Stranger do relate unto us the caue of her coming into this Country, then for Hylas to relate unto us his contant incontancies, which every one here does know. Oh good Thamires (aid Hylas) indeed you have great reaon to twit me with my incontancies: Pray tell me when ever any of them did o much hurt as your obtinate humour called contancy has done? I do not blame you nor your humour (aid Thamires) nor do I commend them, but leave it to the judgement of thoe that will take the pains to conider them; I only ask you, wherein did my obtinate humour called contancie, do you any harm? It is not to me alone (replied Hylas) that it is obnoxious, but unto all thoe that are about the Banks of Lignon, and to all the whole Country of Forrets, all whom do reent the injury you have done them, in poyling the beauty of this wie woman (pointing at Celidea) who was one of the greatet ornaments of the Country Shepherd (aid Celidea, and interrupted him) I do think my elf infinitely happy in that which you think a los; for by parting with a thing of a poor trivial value, I have in exchange the greatet tranquility of Spirit, and as much contentment of mind, as can poibly be deired. We do not talk of the tranquility of your mind, wie Shepherdes, aid Hylas, nor of your contentments, but of that happines which we have lot by the obtinacie of Thamires; and if uch a chance had hapned unto Hylas, perhaps you hould become as fair as ever you was. Is not Dorinde fairer then he was when firt I began to love her? Look upon Florice, Cercinea, Palinice; and did you ee Cryeide, you would ay that all thoe whom I love, are hugely beholding to me; for I leave them all fairer then I found them: and not like thoe blaters of Beauty (for o may all your Thamyrees, your Tyrcies, your Sylvanders, and uch like be called) who never leave any one of thoe they love, till they have either made them ugly, or brought them to their graves, as two of you have done, and you hall ee what will become of Diana, before the wilful Sylvander and he part; you ee he is now young, and very fair; and I dare venture the affection which I have unto Stella, that before he quit her, either he or he are in their graves; then what will become of thoe fair eyes, and a hundred alluring features: Well, well, God keep you from uch ervants, as will never let thoe they love alone till they be dead; nay, even in their very graves they will be troubling them. Pray ee I beeech you, if any that ever I erved were ued o indicreetly: No, no, when I leave them, I leave them in uch a condition, as others are contented to love them after me. Do not think Hylas (anwered Thamires oberly) that this contancy which we do o religiouly oberve, and which you do o much inveigh againt, is either an humour, or any obtinacy, but only an earnet deire not to fail in thoe duties which we owe both unto our elves and unto thoe we love; Unto our elves, becaue alteration of opinion is to condemn that which we once approved of, and there is nothing more hameful, nor which hews more defects in a man then that; For if it be undertanding which prefers us before the ret of animals, are not thoe who want this undertanding no better then beats without reaon? But of all vices, Incontancy does mot dicover and argue that defect; then Hylas, you mut of neceity confes, that none can commit a greater offence, then by hewing themelves wavering and incontant: For the Will which never conents unto any thing but what the Judgement tells him is good, chuing another object, does undeniably argue, that his judgement was deceived either the firt or the econd time: And therefore, though there were no other reaon but our own particular reputation, we ought never to conent unto incontancy, which renders us mot worthy of all corn and contempt. But further, it a mot unpardonable offence againt the peron whom we do love; For Hylas, does any change but when they think they change for the better? And therefore is it not an injury unto her whom we loved, to leave her for another, ince we do as good as ay that the lat is the better? Hylas not being able
to endure that Thamires hould go any further with this dicoure without interruption, he went nearer him, and looked him in the face, and eeming deirous to look under his clothes, Shepherd (aid he unto him) let me ee, if under the habit of Thamires, Sylvander be not diguied, for me-thinks I hear him peak in his tone. Ah Hylas, anwered Thamires, your having that opinion, is a igne you think my arguments to be good; for there is nothing which comes from o excellent a wit, which ought not to be eteemed o. You are very much mitaken good Thamires, replied Hylas, for hearing your arguments o hallow and ill-grounded, I thought them to be his, or he himelf which uttered them, and not Thamires, who is held for a very prudent and wie Shepherd; and to make good what I ay, I will hew you how fale your reaons are.

You affirm that one ought to continue in his obtinacy of loving one that they once loved, in two coniderations: The one in repect of himelf; and the other in repect of her whom he loves. Ah Thamires! It is an eaie matter to you who are antiquated; for your clothes are not only made after the old mode, but your opinions are as old, and cut out according to the old Gaulih garb: Good friend, is there any thing in a man more depiable then illines and indicretion? And is it not the height of indicretion and illines, to know what is happines, and to court and follow that which will make him mierable? I beeech you fair and dicreet Shepherdees be judges, and tell me whether you would not think that husbandman a very fool, that has divers times found by experience uch a piece of ground is not fit for corn, and will till continue owing it with the ame eed, and only out of a foolih fear, let it hould be aid that he had no judgement at the firt. Ah my good friend Thamires, is it any thing but gain and profit that gets reputation in thee days? And indeed, if one hould enquire of the quality and capacity of any one, be it either as a ervant, or any other ways, Did you ever hear the quetion asked uch a one, whether he be contant or incontant? No, no Thamires, but only whether he can manage well his buines, whether he be rich, whether he have good flocks, and uch things as can encreae and keep them, not by an obtinate reolution never to part with them, but by elling and changing them as oft as occaion hall require. Suppoe friend, you were upon the Sea, you would quickly be hipwrack'd if you kept your Sayl contant to one wind; no, no, wie men will turn their ayl to all winds. The very ame it is in the affairs of the world, and it is overain widom to change according to occaions. And as to your aertion, that changing does offend againt the peron whom one did love; good Thamires, what do you think of me? Or, whom do you think I am? Is there not ome perons who make bread, and others who eat it? Do not ome make clothes, and others wear them? Why hould I not give them the ame counel that I would take my elf? I mean, that as I change them for others, o let them change me for whom they like better, when they have a mind unto it: But in as much as I think it is impoible that thoe whom I once loved hould ever meet with a better, they mut even content themelves as well as they can, and conider, that of all things in the world, ome are detined unto happines, and others unto miery. Amongt hores, ome are for the plow, and ome are for the addle; amongt dogs, ome lie in Ladies laps, and others lick the dripping pan in the kitchin; and o amongt men, ome to be erved, and others to erve: 'Tis true, their fate is hard, but will they complain of Hylas for it? No, it is not in me to command him who ordained them that cruel detiny; but if they will be complaining, it mut be for being born under uch an unlucky contellation: and yet I mut tell you, that this very offence which you preuppoe, is nothing but imagination: For when a Muician changes notes, does he change them becaue he thought thoe he left to be wore then thoe he took? No, no Shepherd, but it was to make his Muique better, and more delightful, which otherwie would be dull and tedious. If a Painter change colours, • ay omtimes the very piece it elf, is it becaue he depied the firt colour? No, but on the contrary, becaue he would more enliven it, and hadow the firt colour o, that he ets it off with greater luter then at the firt: So Thamires, when we do leave a Shepherdes whom we did love, and take another, it is not as you think, becaue we eteem her more then her we left, but only to follow the rules and dictates of Nature, which reacheth us, that it
is nothing but variety which renders the univere delightful. Look upon every thing, even from the lowet to the highet, and you will find, that nature has engraved this intinct and this Law, in uch characters as cannot be defaced. Tell me Thamires, when you lye in your bed, do you never turn from one ide to another? If you do, you are incontant, and hews want of judgement, in chuing the wore ide at the firt: when you walk, or dance; why do you change legs, but rather hop upon the firt you began with, if you will be punctual to your firt beginnings? When you peak, why do you not make ue till of the ame word? Why do Fidlers finger more trings then one? And why do they vary into o many everal tunes? I ee Shepherd that you laugh at what I ay: but believe it, I have greater reaon to laugh at you, when you ay, that one is incontant in loving everal Shepherdees, or that one offends her whom he leaves.

I mut needs confes, aid Thamires, that I do laugh at the arguments which you ue to maintain your fickle humour: I believe there is none in the company but does the like, and perhaps Hylas himelf alo, if not in his face, yet in his heart: for it is a very hard matter to forbear upon uch a ubject: and I wih Sylvander were here to anwer (as it is neceary) unto your Sophitry: I am glad to hear, replied Hylas, that you call for help; it is a ign you think your elf overcome: but never be ahamed of it, for though Sylvander himelf were here, whom you accompt your Oracle, yet I am confident he would confee my victory, and himelf ubmit unto it: Oh Hylas! (aid Thamires) you do mitake the reaon why I deired Sylvanders company; it is not becaue I want any arguments to anwer your aertions, for it is an eaie matter unto any that will take the pains: but it is becaue that Shepherd is able by his plendent fancies, and excellent eloquence, to give this fair company better contentment, then is my dull genius: and yet in his abence, ince he who is ilent unto truth, is culpable of a lye; I will briefly anwer you, but it hall be upon a condition, that you give me leave to laugh at what you have aerted: in the firt place, I confes Hylas, that Husbandman to be very indicreet; who having found by tryal that his ground is not proper for one eed, will not ow it with another, and change his eed: but Hylas, this does not prove what you aert; for love ought not to precede the knowledg of the party loved. The Husbandman had no knowledge at the firt of the quality of his Land, o as he ought not to change his eed till he has found it by experience and knowledg; and therefore all thoe conequent arguments which you ued, to change the ail according to the wind, and that it is prudence to know how to comply with occaions, we do agree with you, that it is indeed high widom to be guided by, and according to the weather; and the reaon is, becaue we cannot command the wind and the weather as we will: o that Hylas, you mut know, that in things which have dependency upon our elves, and which are in our own power, it is a hame to change; but on the contrary, in thoe things which depend upon the power of another, it is high prudence to know how, and when to turn and change according to occaion. Now Love, which does depend upon the will, there is no quetion, but it is in our power, ince God did never give us any thing which is more abolutely ours, then this will; which has no matter of chance or fortune in it, as there is in the Sea, or in the Winds. But truly your intance of Muitians in changing Notes, and Painters in colours, is a very ubtile argument indeed: but good Hylas, do you not know, that their firt deigns are to arrive at the end of their works? The Muitian he deigns to make good Muique, and the Painter to illutrate his work; and by changing Notes, and uing everal colours, they both arrive at their firt deigned end: mot right (aid Hylas, and interrupted) and even o I doe never change, but with a deign to arrive at the end of my deires. But, replied Thamires, Love will not allow of that, whoe perfection does o much conit in unity, as it can never be perfect until it attain unto that one which it aymes at: and hence it is that our Druids ay, two perons that do love, become one and the ame; which is eaily comprehended, ince both parties have one and the ame will, and o conequently are one and the ame peron. As for your arguments of incontancy drawn from turning my elf in my bed, inferring it to proceed from want of judgement in not chuing the bet ide at the firt; you mut know Hylas, that the body, which is heavy and ubject to wearinee, by its own
weight, mut eae it elf by turning, that both ides may bear the weight alike: but the oul, which is all pirit, is not ubject unto uch inconveniences, and therefore ought not to change: but good Hylas, give me leave to laugh a little before I anwer your argument of walking and peaking; aying, that thoe who walk, if they will be contant, mut never go but upon one leg, and hop; or when they peak, never ue but one word: I believe Hylas, if nature had called you to councel, when he appointed to every thing their motions, perhaps you had invented ome other way for men to walk, and had made hopping erve the turn; but ince you were not, you cannot call them incontant, who walk as nature ordained them, ince they can do no otherwie: and as for matter of peaking, know Hylas, that peaking was given unto men, to make thoe who hear them, undertand the ecret conceptions of their ouls: now do but invent one word, that can make to be undertood all that the mind conceives; and then I will ay, we were incontant if we ued any words but that alone: do you ee therefore how hallow all your reaons and arguments are? Certainly you mut needs confee, that they are grounded upon and, which is as looe, and fleeting, as your incontant humour is. But are you not exceedingly pleaant, in aying, that thoe whom you quit for others, ought not to lay the blame upon you, but upon their contellation and their detiny? It is mot true indeed, that they have reaon to complain againt their malignant influence, for I think it a very great mi-fortune unto them that are troubled with your addrees; but are not you extreamly to blame in being the intrument of this malignant influence? Tell me, I beeech you, is not the gallows upon which a malefactor is hanged, a horror unto every one, and corned? Ah my friend, what are you unto thoe poor women that are detined unto your incontancies, but the gallows where they receive their punihments?

At this all the company laughed a long while, and Hylas alo, though it was againt himelf; and when he began to reply, he was prevented by Adrates, who having met with Doris, did o hang upon her, that he could not be rid of him; at the firt he ran unto her, and kneeled before her; he would have kied her feet, and with all humble reverence touched the hem of her garment: but eeing he went till on, he would not go out of thoe limits, unto which he was by a kind of witchcraft confined; he was o bold as to tay her by her gown, and would have taken her by her arm, which caued her to cry out: and Palemon being not far off, ran in to help her; but do what Palemon could, Adrates would not let his hold go: when he pulled one hand off, Adrates took hold with the other: and Adrates being a big trong man, Palemon would hardly have matered him, but for the coming of this company, who advancing towards them, the Shepherds took hold of Adrates, and gave Doris time to ecape out of his hands. The tate and mierable condition of this poor Shepherd, moved Dorinde to pity him: and the beauty of Doris made her very deirous to know how the diention did arie: Palemon as a very civil and courteous Shepherd, aid unto her, be pleaed to know, fair tranger (for o he thought her by her habit) that this Shepherd and I were both in love with this Shepherdes, & he being adjudged unto me, he received the entence o adly, that he fell mad, and lot the ue of reaon. A thouand pities, aid Dorinde, for he eems to be a Shepherd of excellent qualities: were he in the Town where I was born, I believe, there might be found a remedy for him; for I have een one cured of the ame dieae; and o may he, epecially if it be not long ince the mi-fortune did befal him. It was not above two months ince (aid Palemon) and I am o exceedingly orry for him, that I would do any thing which might be conducing to his cure doubtles (aid Dorinde) this will; I have had the experience of it, and the remedy is very eaie, is there not a Temple of Jupiter in this Country? And is there not another near unto it, dedicated unto the Goddee Minerva? There is many of them, anwered Thamires, which they ay, the Romans built; but, as for us, we do never frequent them; becaue our Druids teach us, that the Majety of the Great Tautates is o incomprehenible, that the whole Univere is only a Temple worthy of his grandeur, which he himelf did build; for uch as are built by the impotent hands of men, are too mean for uch a Divinity: and this is the reaon why all our Sacrifices are offered in Sacred Groves, and under no other roof, but
the glorious Arch of Heaven. But that people whom I mentioned, had Sacrificers which erved in Temples, and I think that I have een uch a one in the great City of Marelles: for the Founder did not only give it his own name, but alo planted his Religion there, and I remember very well, there is alo another dedicated unto Minerva, which as I think joyns unto that of Jupiter. If o, aid Dorinde, and that you deire the cure of this poor Shepherd, carry him thither, and I am confident of his cure: for there needs no more then to drive a nail which hath touched his Pemples into the wall of Jupiters Temple, which is on that ide towards the Temple of Minerva. If that be all (aid Palemon) I wear that to morrow I will neither eat nor drink until I have driven one o far, as it hall hardly be pulled out, but by breaking the wall. It is not you, replied Dorinde, that ought to do that ceremony, but it mut be the principal peron of the place. If o, (aid Palemon) I will fall upon my knees before Amais, I will beeech her to do that charitable Act, and I will make a vow, that if this poor Shepherd recover, I will not deny the firt thing that hall be asked of me, be it made by whom it will. And becaue Adrates till followed the company, and the place which he ued to haunt very near, Palemon entreated Doris, that he would either by prayers, or any other way, to make him follow them unto Marelles, whither he undertood all this good company was going. Doris, to pleae him, though much againt the grain of her mind, went to that poor Shepherd when he aw him ready to leave them. Adrates (aid he unto him) will you not go with me unto my houe? He went nearer to her, and after he had looked well upon her, he anwered, to my houe do you ay, Adrates and Doris? Yes, replied Doris, will not Adrates go with Doris? To which he anwered not a word but Doris: and turning himelf about, offered to go away. Doris then calling him by his name, and he turning towards her, he offered her hand and aid unto him; come, come, Adrates, do not you love Doris? He looked eriouly upon her, and aid not a word; and it would have pitied any one, to ee how tears trickled from his eyes, though he miled. Doris then made him a econd offer of her hand; what Adrates (aid he) do you not know Doris? Then he anwered, Doris; yes, aid he, I am Doris, who entreats Adrates to go with her unto Marelles. Then going to her, and taking her under the arm, he aid, Marelles, Doris, Adrates, Palemon, and never left aying o all the way long: but ometimes did weep, and ometimes at the very ame intant laugh, and would never anwer unto any quetion, but only the lat word of it.

They had already paed over the River Lignon, and left the houe of Adamas on the right hand, when they began to dicover Marelles; and becaue Hylas was very orry that he could not know the caue of Dorindes coming into Forrets; it is a hard cae (aid he) that ome foolih accident or other does always prevent me in my deires; what foolih accident do you complain of, aid Dorinde, which has prevented you in your deires? Two things, anwered Hylas, I do complain of, and they are very different; the one is, that Thamires and I have talked o long: & the other is, that Adrastes hath made us loe that time which I deired hould be pent in hearing what has hapned unto you ince lat I aw you. If that be al, anwered Dorinde, to content you, we hal remedy it when you pleae: thee promies are eaily made, aid Hylas, but often fail in performance; hold me for a peron very uncivil, aid Dorinde, if I do not give you atisfaction in a thing which I may with o much eae perform; I believe you to be civil enough, replied Hylas, but I cannot tell whether your leiure and your will can permit it: as for matter of will, anwered Dorinde, it hall not tick upon that; and as for leiure, I believe, that at night when we have nothing ele to do, we may have as good an opportunity as can be deired. But pray, why have you not as great a deire to know the adventures of Florice, of Palinice, and Cercinea, as well as mine? Is it becaue you already know them? There is a hidden mitery in that, anwered Hylas, and the truth is, I do not know them; but I do very much wonder, now I think on it, that I hould never have that deire; then turning towards them, but good (in the dayes of old) Mitries, tell me, why you did not pay that tribute which was due unto my curioity and deire? We do anwer, aid Florice, that neither you nor we had any will thereunto; but yet there is a reaon which is better, and which proceeds from a caue more high; for Heaven did forbid us:
How, how? aid Hylas, have you uch familiar converation with Heaven? I do not wonder now I hould o retire my elf from you, ince you are o celetial: you mut not now be loved, but adored as heavenly beauties. Hylas, aid Cercinea, you now peak like unto your elf, who being one of thoe Gallo-Ligurians, which retain nothing of the ancient Gaulih Religion, but the •
•• ry name, having received the Graecian fables for truths: but we, who adore nothing but one only Tautates, we do not deire to be adored. Oh Cercinea (aid Hylas) I perceive your celetial converation with Heaven; and your intimate familiarity with Angels, has made you o divine, that now there is no coming near you: you do not talk now like Cercinea, but like a Sarronide, an Eubages, a Prophetes, a celetial Druide. God keep me from loving you, ince you are learned; for when I begin to talk unto you of my affection, in lieu of anwering, you will reprove me for not peaking well: and God knows how extreamly ahamed hould I be to receive correction at this age. Then turning towards Florice, but pray tell me in good earnet (aid he) how comes it to pae I hould never know the caue of your coming into this Country? Becaue (anwered Florice) we would not tell it unto any, being o enjoyned by the Oracle, which did forbid us to peak of it, until a thing come to pas which is not yet hapned. Now I do ee (aid Hylas) that heaven is better to me then I deerve, ince I am not afflicted with any deires of a thing that would have been long before the effect would be obtained. But, aid Dorinde, why might not I have atisfied this deire, for I do know all their adventures, almot as well as themelves, and heaven has not forbidden me to tell them? Were we not o neer the place unto which we go, aid Lycidas, I hould humbly entreat that you would be pleaed to take o much pains; for I believe there is not a tranger upon the Banks of Lignon, who hath o long concealed the caue of their journey, as thee three fair ones have: It eems aid Hylas, that they have extreamly offended the Gods. Why? aid Cercinea. Becaue (anwered Hylas) the greatet punihment that heaven can lay upon a woman, is to be ilent. If it be o (anwered he) heaven has been very favourable to us, in giving us occaion to hew our elves more then women.

Such dicoure as this beguiled the length of the way; and when they were come to the gates of Marelles, Periander, Merindor, and their companions asked Dorinde if he intended to do her obeyance unto Amais that ame night; and where he intended to lodge if he did not. To whom Dorinde anwered, that it was very late, and that all the company was too weary to go o high as the Catle, which tood upon the top of a teep hill; but yet he knew not where to lodge ele-where, having no acquaintance in the place: Lycidas upon this be-thinking himelf; I beeech you (aid he) give me leave to go before you into the Town, and if he whom I hope to find in it be there, I am confident your reception will not be bad. Dorinde thanked him; and itting down under a hade neer the High-way, he told him, that he and the company would expect his return in that place. Upon this Lycidas with the company of Corilas, went into the Town, and went as fat as they could unto the houe of Clindor, the dear friend of Alcippes, the father of Celadon and Lycidas, This Clindor has till in memory the affection which he bore unto their father, and ince the death of Alcippes and Celadon, all his good will was placed upon Lycidas, as all that was left unto him of his dear friend; and therefore as oon as ever he aw him, he held out his arms of love to embrace him, and hewed as much entire affection, as if he had been his own on. Father, aid Lycidas unto him, for o he called him; if I have been backward in rendring that duty which I owe unto you, I beeech you lay the blame upon the rural woods, which will hardly permit their inhabitants to frequent great Cities, without offence unto the Laws of their olitary lives. Son, aid Clindor, I do both excue and envie you: I excue you, becaue Alcippes did all his life mot religiouly oberve the vow of his ancetors: and I do envie the happy lives you lead, when I conider the turbulency and inquietude of ours: But Son, continued he, and embraced him, you are very heartily welcome, and your companion alo; auring your elf, that I cannot receive any greater contentment, then to ee the on of my dear friend Alcippes well and with me. This aurance Sir, aid Lycidas, made me o bold as to offer your houe to a great number of my friends who accompanied me hither, though I did not know whether it would be thought too
great a trouble: Son, aid Clindor with a miling countenance, thoe who do come unto my houe, epecially under o good a conductor as Lycidas, hall have as much power in it as my elf; the trouble that will be, will be only unto them, but much honour and contentment unto me: and then hearing who thoe were whom he brought with him; I am very orry aid he, that I had no ooner notice: but ince they have urprized me, I hope t •• y will excue the inconveniences of my houe, and the they are mot heartily welcome: Then calling for his on, Leontidas (aid he, for that was his name) go along with your brother, offer this houe unto thoe trangers to whom he will conduct you, and tell them, that if my age would permit me, I would have waited upon them my elf.

Thus Lycidas with Leontidas went unto the company which expected him, who after many complements of civility, Leontidas took Dorinde by one arm, and Hylas took her by the other; when they came to the gates, the guards asked them who they were, and from whence they came? The three Cavaliers told them their names, and atisfied their demands; and Leontidas added, that they were going to the houe of Clindor. The guards then cryed them mercy, and asked pardon for their trictnes, becaue it was but according to their duty and commands received from their uperiour Officers. Thus they entred, and were conducted unto the houe of Clindor, who received them with o kind a countenance, and treated them o nobly, as every one admired he hould have et his houe in uch excellent order as they found it.

In the mean time the ad Sylvander, who after he had left Dorinde and her company, was retired into the thicket woods, where he could leat be een, and there pat away the ret of the day with his own melancholy and mortal thoughts, till at night he came to the place where Diana, Alexis, Atrea, and Phillis found him retired: He did o avoid the ight of every one, that he knew not what had hapned unto Dorinde; for as oon as he aw any, he hunned them like a avage peron. His ad melancholy retained him in this place until it was night; but when he aw the canopy of heaven pangled with glitering tars, and thought that none was abroad, he went out; not with any deigne of diverting himelf, but only to reent his orrows more apprehenively, and that his orrows might the ooner do that which his hand durt not againt his life, let heaven hould be offended if he gave himelf a violent death.

This thought did inenibly conduct him unto the place where Phillis delivered the cruel meage from Diana unto him: Oh mot fatal place (aid he) and mot infamous for the highet piece of injutice that ever was committed upon the Banks of Lignon: Oh thou mot abominable and and odious piece of ground! I do wonder Heaven does not caue the earth to open, and wallow thee in her deep Abys, and never uffer thee to be ooting for any innocent Shepherd to tread upon again.

Then folding his arms one within another, he continued; But if heaven will needs purue me with a perpetual hatred, as it hath done ever ince that cured day on which I was born, why does it not execute and compleat its cruel detinies upon me? Should I wih all places where I have reented the unjut malignity of its influence to be Abyes; Alas, then all places where-ever I did et my foot, mut be wallowed up into the profundity of the earth. Then coming to the place where he fell into a woon, he topped hort, and looked long ilently upon it; at lat he began again, 'Twas here (aid he) where my diaterous cogitations did muter themelves to overwhelm me; but how comes it to pas I did endure them and not die? And is not heaven ahamed to ee it elf urmounted by the contancy of a mortal? It is not more trange, to ee how obtinate the Detinies are in rendring me mierable, then it is to ee the inenibility of my oul, in upporting their blows. But upon good conideration I needs mut ay, that heaven will either try what power it has in tormenting, or what courage I have in uffering. But fairet Diana, mut you needs be the intrument of o many cruelties? Can your beauty ever conent unto the ruine of him that adores you? What excue can you alledge for your elf?
