You are either the partner in this fault, or at leat the caue and the original; for it is as impoible I hould love any but Diana, as it is for Diana to live, and not be the fairet in the whole world; and as long as I live, the mot loved Shepherdes upon earth.
But alas, alas, you look for no excue where you cannot repent of the fault: or to ay better, where repentance would be a thouand times greater atisfaction, then the wrong.

Then tanding a while ilent, and the moon hining very clear, he went looking and taring upon every thing about him, like a man that was ditracted, and hardly knew what it was that he did look upon: at lat, the cruel dicoure of Phillis, and the opinion which Diana had of his change, coming into his mind, he could not chue but cry out: Oh God! Oh Heavens! Is it poible that the judgment of Diana, which is o sound and quick in all other things, hould to my miery, be thus mitaken? Can he think Madonthe has any power to divert me from her, and her ervice? Could that Wie, Prudent, and Solid Shepherdes believe, that thoe eyes which have her can look upon any other eyes but hers? Have I; Oh Fairet Shepherdes, by any of my actions, given any tetimony that I become a Hylas or an Adrates? For before I commit uch a in, I mut needs be either one, or both; and I could not be o incontant unles I were a fool, or a mad man.

This thought entertained him a long time, and would not let him depart from that place, he thought to have found that contentment which he had loft: but on the contrary, he met till with freh caues of grief; for wandering inenibly from one thought to another, he began to think upon the weet beginnings of his affection, and with what dicretion Diana received the firt buds of his love, under the notion of a wager; with what kindnes he uffered that plant to take root, and how prudently he aw it grow up to that grandeur which now is arrived at. And as concomitants of this thought, he et before his eyes the pleaant jars of Phillis, the favourable anwers of his Shepherdes; and briefly, all thoe reaons which he had to hope, that his affection would thrive, and grow fruitfull. Then did he bethink himelf of that Bracelet of hair, which was intended for Phillis, and which he had obtained of Diana, as an extraordinary favour. He guided his hand to the place where he was wont to wear it, thinking to have the contentment of a kis from it: but not finding it, he looked upon the other arm: but not finding it on either, he was urprized with o much grief, as not being able to endure the blow of that diater, he fell to the ground, and o lay a long time without either motion or peech; but at lat he revived, and concluded that now all hope was gone.

Sylvander had no ooner ceaed his complaints, but (as he thought) he heard ome coming towards him; and to know who they were, and alo out of fear to be een, let by that means he hould be interrupted in his olitary thoughts, he kept till cloe, and ilent; then did he plainly hear ome coming and talking very loud, but not o as he could undertand them at that ditance yet till keeping ilence, and they drawing neerer, he perceived by the help of the Moon, that they were two men talking together: and when they were cloe by the place where Sylvander tood, they topt a little; then did he hear one of them begin to ing, and the effect of his ong was, That he had more love, then he had cruelty. He had no ooner done, but the other began; and the ubtance of his ong was, That he ought to love her for no other end but to love her. Ah Brother, (aid the firt, and interrupted the other) you are in the right; for whooever does love for any other end but loving only, he does abue the name of love, and mot unworthily pro • ane that pure and Sacred Divinity. But give me leave to tell you that in what you alledged before, concerning the torments which you and I do uffer, you have as little reaon, as I have much, to ay, that there is no torment in the world that is equal unto mine. Brother, (anwered the other with a deep igh) that love which every one doth bear unto himelf, is the caue of that judgment: for when you ee me uffer any pain, do you not reent it more then any tranger would? Doubtles I do (anwered the firt) Then Alcander, replied the other, the ame reaon which makes you reent my pain more then another, does make you reent your own more then mine: for as it is natural to love a brother more then a tranger, o it is as natural to love ones elf more then any ele: it is love which gives the weight unto all things which fall under opinion. I do not know Amilcar (aid he) how you intend this? It is true that I am partly in the ame belief, and partly not; I mean, that it is love which doth caue reentment of orrows and joyes, and that it is by it, and its ell, we do meaure
the greatnes or the littlenes of all things: but that every one does love themelves more then ome others: Indeed brother, I mut confes, that if this be an effect of nature, then nature has failed in me: for I do protet and vow, that I do love Circinca, a thouand times better then I do my elf; and it is an eaie matter to make this evident, ince I do find in my elf towards her, all the effects which a mot extream love can produce: for firt, I had rather any evil hould fall upon my elf, then the leat upon her: and I deire her contentment infinitely above my own; there is nothing, be it never o full of difficulty, but I would attempt it, if there was any hopes it would conduce thereunto: If any thing that pleaed me, dipleaed her, believe it, Amilcar, I had rather dye then receive it: and if thee be not infallible arguments, that I do love another better then my elf, I know not what are. Brother, replied Amilcar, I do reent the very ame effects of affection unto Palinice, which you do unto Circinea: but oh Alcander, you are much mitaken if you do conclude thereby, that you do love Circinea better then your elf, or that I do love Palinice, more then I do my elf. For if we will but ingeniouly confes, it is the love of our elves that makes us love them: and as the mier does expoe his life for the preervation of that Gold which he loves; o do we Sacrifice our elves to the pleaure of thoe fair ones whom we adore: Fie, fie Brother, replied Alcander, will you offer uch a wrong unto our loves, as to compare them unto a miers love of Gold? Aure your elf brother (aid Amilcar oberly) there is no difference betwixt them, only the love that we do give unto thee fair ones, is for a thing of greater value and merit, and therefore it is more noble and reaonable: but the very truth is, the original of all loves, is elf love: does not the miers care to preerve his dearly beloved Gold, proceed from the love of himelf, and not his Gold? Doubtles it does; for what cares the gold into whoe hands it fals, ince whereoever it is, it is till Gold as well as in his hands. Then let us apply this reaon unto our elves, and you will find that it is the love which you hear unto your elf, which makes you have all thoe cares of Circinea, and all thoe earnet deires of her contentment: would you wih her o much happinee, and endeavour to procure it unto her, upon condition he hould extreamly love Clorian, and devote her elf wholly unto him, without ever caring for you? But did he love Clorian, replied Alcander, he would not be o happy as you uppoe her. But uppoe he hould be as happy (aid Amiliar) would you wih her the enjoyment of all thoe contentments with Clorian? I ee you will not anwer, nor have you any reaon; but I will anwer for you: it is mot certain, that you and I had rather ee the grim face of death, then to ee your Circinea happy with Clorian; and I to ee my Palinice, the happy wife of Sileines: and therefore let us both ingeniouly confee, that all the happinee which we do wih unto them, is but like the love of a Mier to his Gold; that is, for our own particular interet: though the excee of our paions makes us think the contrary.

Upon this, thee trangers continued on their walk, and for a while were ilent. Sylvander who heard them, and thought them to be perons of merit and undertanding had a good mind to be talking with them, had it not been for the curvy humour, into which the jealouie of Diana had put him: but conidering this vexing humour, he thought it better to be as he was, then interrupt them: and therefore, he deigned to go away: but as he was going, he aw thee trangers turn back, as men that knew not which way to go; but having found that walk, would pae away the ret of the night in it. His fears to be een, caued him to keep cloe till they were pat, and afterwards to fall into the thick of the Wood. But whether he made ome noie, as he couched down, or whether the Moon hined clearer then it did when they paed by before, I know not: but Alcander pied him, and hewed him to his brother, who tepping nearer, certainly (aid he) it is a Shepherd who is a leep. Sylvander, who eeing himelf dicovered, and who thought that they would not go away before they made him peak; he thought alo that it was better to prevent them: and therefore, he anwered, if I do leep, then it may be aid, that a man may leep and not ret; for the mierable condition wherein I am, will not let me enjoy any: do not think Amilcar (continued he, and roe up) that it is any love which I bear unto my elf, makes me judge my miery unequalled; for hould
I judge by paion upon that which relates unto me, it would be rather by hatred then love, ince I am able to ay, and ay truly, that I never wihed any o much harm as I do unto my elf. And though the miery which I endure, be as much as any mortal man can endure, yet am I o much my own enemy, that my hatred cannot be atisfied, unles by wihing my mieries multiplied above the number of all the leaves in this Wood. I mut confes, aid Amilcar, that if your condition be as bad as you peak it, all orrows mut ubmit unto yours. Oh Amilcar, aid Sylvander, it is but too true, and did you but know my wounds, you would confes it alo; but becaue it would be ome kind of comfort to tell it, I will not give my elf o much contentment. It eems (aid Alcander) that the greatnes of your miery hath driven you into depair, and you know depair argues but little knowledge, and little courage: I mut confes, aid the Shepherd, that my miery is changed into depair, but I do deny that depair, is alwaies from want of knowledge or courage; for were it not a trange ignorance to have uch extream misfortunes as I have, and not to know them? And would it not argue a great defect of courage, and reentment, to tand in uch fear of death, as to wih, living in uch miery? This may pas amongt petty and trivial michances and mieries, uch as are common and ordinary; but amongt uch as are grown to that height, as there is no remedy, nor no cure, it is a folly, a madnes, an argument of a poor low courage, to endure the hame which cannot be avoided by any way but by being no more, However replied Alcander, it is an argument of a faint and poor courage, to want a heart that will endure the blows of an enemy. Mot true, replied the Shepherd, but there is no reaon to hope for a thing which there is no hopes to obtain, and thereupon I ay it is, that my miery is deperate; not that I do conclude thereby, that I will run a word into my breat to kill my elf, or throw my elf head long down a precipice: uch an act would argue a defect in courage; nay wore, it is a great impiety and in committed againt the great Tautates; for man being the workmanhip of his hands, it were a mot horrid in to detroy what he hath made; He, as the Potter with his pot, may do what he will with us: and we were made to be as he will have us, and not to dipoe of our elves according to our own will; if it be his pleaure we hould endure pain and abundance of miery, we mut endure, and not endeavour to cros his will by any udden death: but I begin to reent ome mittigation of my adnes by this dicoure which I have had, and therefore, becaue I will not do my mieries o much wrong, I do conjure you Amilcar, by your love unto Palinice, and you Alcander, by yours unto Circinea, that you let me go and retire my elf into the mot olitary parts of this wood; and in requital I will tell you (that if you eek for thoe two fair Shepherdees) where you may find them; and that is, where I have often een them upon the banks of Lignon in the company of the fair Diana, Astrea, and their companions: upon this, he aluted them, and went into the Wood as fat as he could, let he hould be followed by thee trangers.

They on the other ide ravihed to hear uch dicoure come from a Shepherd, they were o atonihed, as they could not tir a foot after him; But having held their eyes a while upon the place where he entred into the Wood; Alcander broke ilence firt: Brother, aid he, did you ever hear uch a hepherd? His habit indeed, aid Amilcar does peak him Shepherd, but not his tongue: for my part aid Alcander, I think him to be the good Genius of Lignon who preented himelf unto us in that habit, to hew us, that there are ome who are in greater miery then we are. Perhaps, replied Amilcar, I hould have been of the ame opinion, if we had been in any Country but Forrets, where I have heard there are o many dicreet and well accomplihed Shepherds, as the encounter eems not o trange unto me. If he be a Shepherd, continued Alcander, and the ret like him, it mut needs be confeed that Cities have reaon to envie thee Woods and olitary places; but aid he, and pointed at a paper which lay in the place where they firt found Sylvander, I do ee a thing like a letter, and perhaps the Moon will give us light to read it. Amilcar upon this took up a paper which Sylvander accidentally dropt, in which were writ a copie of veres, importing, That he, he only is worthy of her elf. It is certain, aid Alcander, that he is a Shepherd, and not the Genius of this place; but it mut needs be acknowledged that thee Woods are extreamly happy in having uch guets.

But Alexis in the mean time who lay according to her cutome in Atreas chamber, where Diana and Phillis alo lay, he was up as early as the Sun, and taking the clothes of the fair Atrea, he dret her elf as oon, and with as little noie as poibly he could: Then he opened the windows, and et a chair cloe by the bed, that he might the better contemplate thoe Beauties which he adored. Atreas body was half turned towards her bed-fellows, and the weather being very hot, part of her breat was open, and her right arm hung carelely naked over Diana. Alexis having a while contemplated, Alas (aid he in a low voice, let he hould be heard) Ah Alexis! why art not thou metamorphoed into Diana, or Diana into Alexis? But mierable wretch that thou art, why uch a wih, ince Celadon then is to have no hare in it? For oh Alexis! what greater favours cant thou receive then thou hat: but all will not do thee any good, becaue thou dot not call Celadon to take a hare, which it eems thou dot envy him. But till it cannot be envy, for Alexis, cant thou have any felicity with him, or any happines without her? No, no, certainly thou cant not: but yet his preence is both terrible, and deirable unto me? deirable, in that without Celadon I cannot have any perfect happines; and terrible in that he would make me loe all my hopes: when I do re-enter into my elf, I do find that I am a micellanie of Alexis and Celadon: and as Celadon I deire to recover that happines which is ravi • hed from me, and as Alexis, I fear to loe that which I poee. I am then both Alexis and Celadon mingled together: but now I know who I am; how hould we do to find out a way to content Celadon, and to atisfie Alexis? Oh there is the work, there is all the difficulty: this is a place o lippery, that the leat treading awry, is to fall into the horrid abye of depair. But why hould we think that Atrea wihes ill unto that faithfull Celadon, ince every time he peaks of him, he eems to lament the loe of him? But on the other ide, why hould we not fear that he does wih him ill, ince having commanded him not to ee her till he command, he does not command him, though hee ee him every hour?

This lat conideration touched o to the quick, that tears dropt from his eyes, and uch ighs econded thoe tears, that Phillis waked at the wind of them, who eeing it light day, after he had aluted Alexis, he roe out of bed in her mock, and went to dree her elf by the Druide. Diana all this while lept o oundly, as the noie which her bed-fellow made in riing did not awake her; but had lept on, if Phillis had not called her luggard everal times: and peaking very loud, it eems Atrea was in a dream, and waked upon it; for turning towards Alexis, Ah Celadon (aid he with a deep igh) and aying no more, he fell aleep again. Diana and Phillis, hearing her name Celadon, they were very attentive to hear what he would ay farther: Alexis, though urpried at the hearing of himelf named, yet he et as good a face upon the matter as he could poible; and laying his finger upon his mouth, peak low, (aid he) that we may hear what he will ay of that Shepherd: but though they were all ilent a long while, and very attentive, yet he poke no more; but perceiving that Diana kied her, he waked, in an opinion that it was Alexis: Mitris, aid he, you are very early, and her eyes being yet not well open, he kied her again in that belief: but when he aw it was Diana, ah Siter, aid he, you have deceived me, for I took you for my dear Mitris, Servant, aid the Druide then, I am not o far off, but you may eaily repair that mitake if you pleae: then leaning towards her, Atrea kied her, with as much affection as poibly he could expres. Well, well, (aid Phillis, who was dreing her elf, and who aw how didainfully he had repuled Diana) you reject the kies of thoe lips, which ome other perhaps would ooner chue then yours. Certainly, aid Diana, they are out of their wits who makes o bad a choie. You may ay what you pleae, replied Phillis, but I believe there are ome that are of my opinion, and that is Sylvander, whom I believe you do not think to be out of his wits, unles it be in one thing; what is that? aid Diana, in loving too much, anwered Phillis, for in that indeed he is in the excee. What Siter, aid Diana, all in one ong? Will you peak of nothing but Sylvander, Sylvander till? Are you not weary with naming him o oft? Siter, aid Phillis, reolve upon one thing; that I will never let you ret, until you be reconciled unto him, and he in your favour as formerly he was wont to be: and
I believe it is the part of all your friends to do the like: for if you hould loe that kind Shepherd, I do not think Lignon will ever have his like: good Siter (aid Diana) what you do think of Lycidas, is not he above him? Lycidas, (replied Phillis, after her accutomed jollity) is good for nothing but for me; and I hould be very orry any hould envy me: but Sylvander is uch a one, as not only you and we, who are ordinarily with him, but alo all this Country, nay perhaps all the Gaules, have an interet in him. Good Siter, aid Diana, hall I be payed out of the publique exchequer, for having a care of him, in whom o many have a hare? You ought (anwered Phillis) ince you have all the power; and if he micarry, every one will blame you; and though he be all yours, yet ought you not to envy, that every one hould receive contentment from that which you have. I am o far from any envy, anwered Diana, that if he be mine, I will give him unto you with all my heart; and with a promie never to ask him again. Oh mot cruel woman, (cryed out Phillis) the Gods will punih you for this ingratitude, and as they uually do, in the ame manner that you offend. And remember this that I now foretel you, with as much truth as if it came from the mouth of an Oracle. Good Siter, replied Diana, what is it that you do tell me? that the Gods will punih me for that which I intend to do? Is it a in to give you that which is mine? Though I had not given him unto you, yet till he had been yours; for all that I had, was long ince o. Fie, fie, Diana, replied Phillis, thee cruelties that are covered with a cloak of kindnee, are not unknown to the Gods: you cannot o gild them over, but they will find them to be counterfet tuf, and conider that I hall ee you weep for it; and when that time comes, I will laugh at you, for not believing me when I was in the right. Indeed Siter, anwered Diana, very eriouly, you are extreamly unkind; you hould rather provide for me good tore of handkerchiefs before hand, to dry up the tears which I hall hed.

Thus thee two Shepherdees dicoured whilt they were dreing themelves; and in the mean time Alexis and Atrea were talking, omtimes giving aurances of their mutual good will, and otherwhiles kiing each other; omtimes as women, and otherwhiles as lovers: and therefore Diana eeing Atrea made no offers of riing out of bed, he turned to Phillis, and aid unto her, me thinks Siter that though you have been omthing out of charity with me this morning, yet we may go together and look to our flocks, and return again before this luggard rie out of bed. Do not think, anwered Phillis, that my anger is o great as to make me fail in that repect and affection which I do ow unto her that was my Mitris, and ever hall be o as long as I live. And you Siter luggard, aid he unto Astrea, ince we will not command you any things that are either impoible or grievous, I pray let us find you in the ame place at our return, where we leave you at our going away, and in the mean time, that you may have no excue for your abence, we will take care of your flock: o bidding them good morrow, they went out of the chamber, and went talking upon everal ubjects: and Diana being in a little better opinion of Sylvander, then he was, he began to be in her good humour again.

Being then going out of Atreas houe, Phillis who was ilent a while, did make a top upon a udden; and looking upon Diana, Siter, aid he unto her, dare I tell you, what I am thinking upon? Why do you make it a quetion? anwered Diana, you know our familiarity does not allow us to conceal the leat motion of our ouls from each other: I was thinking, aid Phillis, upon the extream and udden amity betwixt Atrea and Alexis; and what hould be the caue of it? I have known Atrea long, but I never aw her o apt and forward to contract amity upon a puh, with a tranger, and leave her old, for new affections: and yet he no ooner aw this Druide, but he loved her extreamly, and in loving her does a little light the company of Diana and Phillis, who were wont to be o dear unto her. To which Diana anwered, I have had the ame conceptions, Siter, aid he; but then conidering that Astrea did extreamly love Celadon, and Alexis having o great a reemblance of him, he was quickly moved to love her, as fancying her to be her dearly beloved Shepherd; you know he never loved any but only him: as this being her firt and only affection, it is no wonder he hould keep it alive in this woman; well (aid Phillis) this reaon may pas, as relating unto Atrea, but what do you alledge as in relation
to the Druide, who at the very firt ight, was o wholly devoted unto a Shepherdes, that he forgets and forakes her very Father and kindred, to be with this Shepherdes, and to wear her clothes; and eems as if he had quite forgot both Carnutes and all her companions. Unto this, aid Diana, no anwer can be made, but that as Alexis has the face of Celadon, o alo he has his heart: and for my part, I believe he has, when I do ee her Idolize, after the ame manner that Shepherds ue. I aure you, anwered Phillis, you phrae it right, in aying that he does Idolize her, as if he were a Shepherd: have you oberved her actions and behaviour when he is with her? I aure you Siter, that were he trimmed up in mans clothes, I would ay, here is a Shepherd. Siter, replied Diana, you know that Atrea has rare attracts to move love, and having an affection unto this woman, he renders her all the tetimonies of her good will that he can, we ought not to think it trange that her natural perfections hould become inchantments; we have found it our elves by experience, and I dare wear that never any loved better, then we loved Atrea; and I do believe that I cannot love any more then her. But (aid Phillis) what hall we ay of Adamas and Leonide, who have left her here upon o light a caue, and eem as if they had forgotten her? When Adamas went, anwered Diana, we know he was not well; and when Leonide left her, he went away in hate, becaue the Nymph Amais did end for her, o as he had not leiure to conduct her unto the houe of Adamas: and why, aid Phillis, did he not carry her with her unto Marell • s, where her Father was? I cannot well anwer you unto that point, aid Diana: but I do believe that Adamas would not have her, he being a Druide, go amongt great companies, but deired rather he hould pae the time away amongt us, and recover of that icknee which o long tormented her, which was the reaon of her coming from Carnutes, whither as I hear ay he is preently to return.

Thus Diana anwered unto all the objections in the dicoure of Phillis, as he did in real incerity think of Alexis; and ued uch good arguments to clear her doubts, that he quite removed them. Afterwards, they walked unto the Wood, where they thought to find no Shepherds tirring, becaue it was very early; but when they came into a long walk, they aw at the other end a Shepherd and a Shepherdee, but they could not know whom they were, by reaon of the ditance of the place, and hade of trees. Thee two Shepherdees deiring no other company but themelves, their deign was to hide themelves in the Wood, until the other couple was walked pat them, and then to continue on their own intended walk; and therefore finding a thick Buh by the walk ide, they at themelves down in it with a reerve of ilence till they were pat; and therefore they heard them coming when they were at a good ditance off, and becaue they were omthing loud in their dicoure, they knew by their voices the one of them to be Ti • ces, and the other Laonice. Yonder is (aid Phillis, in a whiper) the good friend of Sylvander: and rather mine (anwered Diana) for he has acquainted me with that which of all things in the world was mot neceary for me to know. Well Siter, replied Phillis, I hope to ee the day when you will ee your errour, and then you will take me under the notion of your good friend: Diana durt not anwer, let they hould be heard, becaue they were very near: and as they paed, they heard Tircis ay, I protet L • onice, you are the mot piteful woman in the world: Phillis and Sylvander are not to be blamed, for they were obliged unto all they did, and not by their own choice, but by the will of the Gods. Tirces, anwered he, do you not know that thoe who have been beaten with a rod, and cannot be revenged upon them that beat them, yet they receive ome contentment, in throwing the rod into the fire and burning it? Tircis, by fortune, topped jut at the place where the two Shepherdees were hid in a Buh: and admiring at the wickednes of Laonice; what (aid he unto her) do you infer from that? I infer, replied Laonice, that though I cannot be revenged of the Gods, from whom I have received this injutice, yet I will be revenged upon the rod wherewith they have beaten me, which is upon yonder Mitris Minks Phillis. and Mitris Orator Sylvander: What? do you think I have ojourned o long upon thee banks, and have found out no wayes of revenge? You mut know, that ever ince the day, that judgment was pronounced, by which I lot all my hopes of you,
I have been pretily well revenged upon Phillis; for I owed uch eeds of edition betwixt her and Licidas, as have brought forth the fruits of many a diquiet • ight unto them both. What hurt had poor Licidas done, aid he, that you hould do him o much dipleaure? Since I could not otherwie be revenged upon Phillis, anwered he, he mut accue his own misfortune for it; and you mut know, that rather then want my revenge upon one enemy, I will loe an hundred friends. Oh Laonice, aid Tircis, are you not afraid left the Gods hould command the earth to open, and wallow you up alive? All's one for that, replied he, and miled, there is nothing o weet as revenge: And as for the Gods, they do not meddle in uch matters as thee. 'Tis true, aid Tircis, unles to punih them. Come, come, replied Laonice, The Gods have reerved the heavens for themelves, and have left the Earth unto us: Had I gone without this revenge, I had lived without ret; but now I am a li •• le contented, ince I am revenged upon Judge Phillis, and Orator Sylvander, whoe ruine I have wrought as well as he mine.

Tircis went back two or three paces, and folding his arms, tood looking upon her with admiration, and poke not a word. At lat, he asked her what he had done unto Sylvander? What have I done? anwered he; why I have given him uch a blow, that a Chirurgion will hardly alve up his ore; for I ee, as good a face as Diana ets upon it, the pain of it does reach his heart. But, aid Tircis, what do you tell me of pains of heart, or of Diana? I ask you what you have done unto Sylvander? You are very inquiitive, replied Laonice, and to atisfie you this is enough, That I am o well atisfied in my revenge, that I will not now tay a minute longer in this Country where I have received thee two contentments: The one is, the jealouie of Lycidas againt Phillis; and the other, of Diana againt Sylvander. But replied Tircis, How can Diana be jealous of Sylvander, if he do not care for him; and if Sylvander did never look upon any in the way of Love? Oh Tircis, replied Laonice, if their love or their hatred would have been advantagious unto you, as they are unto me, you would have oberved them better then you have. You think (aid Tircis) that all their dicoures of Love did proceed from affection: But do you not know them to be only in jet, and caued by a wager betwixt Phillis and him? Ah Shepherd, aid Laonice and miled, I perceive that you are one of thoe that believe all that is reported. But my good friend Tircis, if you had loved me, as well as he loves her, aure your elf he had never been my Judge; and believe it, Diana loves him as well, as Phillis her Lycidas, nay better, until I did her the good office of putting her into a little doubt. Content your elf with this I have told you, and that I tell you no more, though I could very much, let you hould know how to remedie it. The perons who are able to verifie the contrary, are all abent, and will not return of a long time to tell them the truth: But trut me, I have not omitted any circumtance that might conduce unto my full revenge, either in the manner, or in the time, or in the perons that I have alledged. Tircis did let her talk on a long time, and did uffer her to vomit up all her malice, to the end he might gather omthing that might be a remedy againt it: But eeing that he would not out with any thing more, he lot all patience. Go, go you damned witch, aid he unto her in a fury, you fiend of hell, ent hither upon earth to torment humanes; thou dot not retain any thing of a woman but only thy habit, and thy name; having under that hape the pirit of a Divel: Hence, hence thou horrid Hag, get thee out of this happy Country, where uch malignant monters mut not inhabite: Let thy venomous and impure heart know, that though thou mayet ecape the jutice of men, yet thou cant not of the Gods, whom I mot heartily beeech to deliver me out of thy wretched hands, and from all thy wicked, malicious, and damned devices.

Upon this he turned from her, and went a great pace, the ame way he came, and left Laonice o atonihed at his reproofs, which her guilty concience told her were true, that he all confuion, tood a while immoveable, looking after him, and peaking not a word; at lat, when he was gone out of ight, he went the other way into the thick of the wood, and would not hew her elf unto any in the Country, but went away unto the place from whence he came, being able to ay, that he left none behind her that was orry for her departure.

Diana and Phillis who were very attentive to the words of Laonice and Tircis, and who durt hardly brea • h for fear of dicovery, when they aw them gone, they tayed a while looking upon one another, and aying not a word, but were both of them amazed at this far fetcht revenge; Diana joyned her hands together, miled, and looked at Phillis; who after three or four times biting her lips, and haking her head, he clapped both her hands upon Dianas, Siter, aid he unto her, do you ee how true all your jealouies and upitions are? What do you now think of the poor Shepherds innocency? Where is all that confidence and belief which you had of this malicious woman? I mut confes (aid Diana, and roe up) that without any wrong unto her I may ay, never was wickednes and ubtilty equal unto her • . But Siter, (continued he, and entring into the walk) could any ever imagine this woman hould ever take uch great and long pains to be revenged upon poor innocents? For truly Sylvander and you are both innocent of her dipleaure, ince you were choen unto that office which you did her, by lot and hazard. But uppoe that you were culpable; what have Lycidas and I done, that could give her o great offence? Did you not hear her ay, replied Phillis, that rather then want her revenge upon one enemy, he would ruine a hundred friends? Good God, aid Diana, keep us from any uch friends. Now Diana, replied Phillis, learn from hence, that all which is aid, is not always true, though never o probable: Mot true, anwered Diana, for who could avoid believing this piece of wickednee? Conider, I beeech you, how cunningly he made her relation, and upon what likely probabilities he grounded it? How ubtilely did he take her time when Madonthe went away, and Sylvander accompanied her? So as every circumtance was a confirmation of what he had related: Oh Siter, aid Phillis, thoe that live with uch turbulent pirits as thee, had need be well advied, I mut confee, aid Diana, that I was deceived; but the falhood was o contrived as I was not to blame, but on the contrary, had been blamable if I had not been deceived by it; for I did thereby make it appear that my pure and innocent oul was free from any uch wickednee, o as I could not imagine any uch thoughts could enter into any other. But Diana (aid Phillis) what hall we do to poor Sylvander, whoe orrows may be his death, and who perhaps is looking for ome way to finih his diaterous life? I hould be very orry, anwered Diana, that Sylvander hould receive any harm, for I plainly ee he is not culpable, and the firt time that I ee him, that ame hand which gave the wound, hall cure it.

I pray God, replied Phillis, that depair do not drive him into ome deperate coure: No, no, aid Diana, Sylvander is not in any uch danger; depair will not eaily work upon uch a pirit as his. Yet let me tell you, replied Phillis, that perons of uch a cold contitution, as his, when griefs eies upon them, are apt for trange reolutions. Siter, aid Diana, as trong contitutions when a Fever eies upon them, have fits more violent then thoe that are weak, o alo can they reit them better, and endure them longer. It is the ame with uch trong pirits as that of Sylvander; it is certain, they are more enible of pain, but then they are more able to endure and reit it: However Siter, aid Phillis, let not this confidence make him endure any longer pain: I am confident, aid Diana, that we hall ee him ometime this day, and then, he hall not depart without a good remedy, if he be in any uch neceity of it, as you think he is. But in the interim I conceive it bet to take our way towards Atrea and Alexis, and acquaint them with the mornings adventures. Upon this they made their coure towards the houe of Atrea, whom they found till in bed.

For as oon as thee two companions were gone out of the chamber, in lieu of dreing her elf, he was talking with Alexis, and hewing her uch abundance of good will, that the diguied Druide was hardly able to reit o many expreions of favour; and the truth is, never was any lover o near delights without a tate, as Celadon was under the guie of a woman, which he durt not throw off. This contraint went o againt the grain of this diguied Druide, that he bluhed everal times, which Atrea perceiving; Mitris, aid he, I am afraid, that you are not well; for I have oberved your colour to change everal times, I beeech you, ue no contraint, for you cannot be in any place of the world, where you have more power
then in this houe. Servant, anwered Alexis, I value not the pain, as I do the favour which you do me, in oberving the colour in my face: 'Tis true indeed, I am not well, but it does not much trouble me, for it is only a dreg of my lat great icknes, which I am often troubled with, but it will be pat immediately, and I am orry that you took any notice of it. Ah Mitris, replied Atrea, you uffer no pain which is little unto me, and you do me wrong in concealing it from me, ince I might as your ervant have ought out for ome remedy. Servant, replied the Druide, I perceive that you do love Alexis, more then he deerves, but never trouble your elf at her pain, for my body is not in o much diorder as my mind. Your mind, aid Atrea, I beeech you Mitris, what is it that can be a trouble to it? Does not all things comply even to your very wihes? Have you not a Father that loves and cherihes you above all his children? Are you not upplied with every thing your heart can deire? Moreover, are you not eteemed and honoured by all that ee you? What then is it that can poibly trouble your mind? You have forgot one thing, aid Alexis, which would be a greater contentment unto me then all the world, and which I deire to poee before it, which is, that Atrea will love Alexis: Oh God, anwered Atrea, and embraced and kied Alexis, it is a in impardonable, if Mitris you do not think I love you: Yes, yes, Mitris, I do love you, and love you o, that I wih Heaven may never love me if I do not, and punih me with eternal torments, when I have the leat thought of any ceaing to love and honour you. Do not ay that you do love me, anwered the Druide, but that you do love Alexis. I do not undertand (aid Atrea) what you mean by that; but I am ure that if I do love Alexis, it is not the name; for if you had any other, my love to you will be till the ame; and if you will know what it is that I do love, it is your peron, your pirit, and your merit. Suppoe I were not a Druide, replied Alexis, would you love me then? I would to God. anwered Atrea, that without any prejudice to your elf, you were for my contentments ake a Shepherdes of Lignon, for then I hould hope that the equallity which would be betwixt us, would more invite you to accept of my affection. Suppoe alo, aid Alexis, that I were a Shepherd, would you till continue the ame good will unto me? Unto that (replied Atrea very oberly) I will anwer very freely, that it is abolutely impoible for me to love you any otherwie then I doe. And truly it would not well become me to love a man o well as I do you; and though it were permitted me, yet I think that I could not; it is enough that I did love one, and therefore will love no more men. Alexis was orry her curioity had gone o far; but ince the Ice was broke, he would tep a little farther. I knew ervant (aid he unto her) that it was only Alexis whom you loved, and not her peron; for otherwie, if the Gods hould make me become a Shepherd, why hould you then ceae to love me? If the Gods hould do o, anwered Atrea, I hould have an occaion to complain againt them for depriving me of all the happines that I hoped ever to receive: and from that time, I would bid adieu unto all delights and contentment. But why hould you not till love me, aid Alexis, ince my body would be till my body, and my mind and oul, till the ame? Alas Mitris, anwered the Shepherdes, what would you have me ay? This is all I am able to ay, that it hall never be aid, Atrea did love two Shepherds. I beeech you, dear Mitris. no more of this dicoure; for though I know that uch a change cannot be, yet the very imagination of uch a thing does freeze my blood to Ice; and indeed he did begin to look very pale in the face: Which Alexis eeing, and thinking it not good to drive the nail to the head, he aid thus unto her: Well ervant, aid he, I will not talk any longer upon this ubject, upon condition you will tell me, what you dreamed this morning when you waked: with all my heart, anwered Astrea, if I can but remember it: but Mitris, continued he, why do you deire it? Becaue, anwered the Druide, as you were betwixt leep and waking, I heard you ay, as you turned towards me, in a pitifully complaining voice, ah Celadon: Mitris, aid Atrea, by that word you put me in memory of part of my dream, which otherwie I hould have forgotten; I dream't that I was in a grove o thick with trees, bryers, and ruhes, that I tore all my clothes; and the obcurity of the place did hinder me from eeing which way I hould pae; at lat after much trugling and long labour in vain to get out of this place, me thought I aw one, whom I
did not know by reaon of the darknes; coming towards me, and aid, holding her hand before her face, that if I would follow her, he would help me out of that thorny Labyrinth wherein I was: After I was helped out, me thought I thanked her for her aitance, and went following her; and followed her, until both of us were o wildered, that neither of us could get out of the Wood: At lat me-thought that ome one coming betwixt my guide and me to part us, he graped my hand o cloe, and I clung o cloe unto her, that the other was forced to ue all the trength he had to part us; and at lat, he pulled off the hand of her that guided me. At the ame time me-thought I aw a little light, and therefore deiring to look upon the hand which remained in mine, I found it to be a heart which panted, until he who had evered me from my guide, returned with a great knife in his hand, and do what I could, did give the heart uch a blow, that it made me all bloody: The horrour of this did make me throw it away upon the ground; which I had no ooner done, but I aw that the heart was turned into Celadon; which put me into uch a fright, that it caued me to cry out as you heard me, and then I waked.

This dream, replied Alexis, does certainly ignifie omthing; for though mot of them be fale, and only impreions of things precedent, which we have either een or heard; and omtimes are only vapours ariing from a urcharged tomack or ele from the complexion, and according to the good or bad contitution of the Body: yet this has none of thoe qualities which dreams ue to have; for they are full of non-ene, and have neither head nor feet: but this is a compoed tory, and holds a correpondency in all parts, alo it was in the morning, when vapours from the tomack could work no effects: o as if you pleae, I can give you the interpretation of it. I hould think my elf much obliged (aid Atrea) if you would be pleaed to take the pains.

This Wood o full of thorns and obcurity (aid Alexis) wherein you were, and out of which you were o out of all hopes to get out, is the troubles and perplexities wherein you are; he who appeared and offered her elf as a guide through this labyrinth, repreents my elf; He which would ever us, is, that I hall be contrained to return unto Carnutes by Adamas; we mut both reit as much as we can, at the lat they will part us, but I hall leave my heart with you, which you hall take in lieu of Celadons; and in the knowledge of this you hall live more contentedly then ever you did.

Ah Mitris (aid Astrea) I like well the interpretation of my dream, but for that ad eparation; and that indeed I cannot uffer, nor me thinks hould you Does it not grieve you to part from uch a ervant as loves you with o much paionate affection, as he thinks the time of parting to be the time of her death? As he uttered thee words, tears trickled down her fair checks; and becaue Alexis looked upon her, and pake not, he continued: Ah Mitris, Mitris, will you not afford me one word of comfort? Is it poible you hould ever conent unto any eparation? Judge you, replied Alexis, whether I conent unto it or no, ince your dream tells me, that I am to leave my heart with you; and do you think I would not be where it is? Oh Mitris, replied the Shepherdes, this is not enough to give me atisfaction; but wear unto me you will not, by that thing which will mot inviolably oblige you unto it. Then it hall be (replied Alexis) by the affection which I do bear unto the fair Atrea: Be it by what it will (aid Atrea) o it be by an oath inviolable. Swear unto me, dearet Mitris, that you will never forake me, and in retaliation, I will wear unto you by the oul of that peron whom I loved mot, and by my affection unto you, and alo by all that is acred, that neither any oppoition of parents, conideration of etate, or any other repect whatoever that can be imagined, hall ever be able to eparate me from my dearet Mitris, whom I do embrace (aid he, and took her in her arms) and will never let her go out of my arms, until he has made this oath. Alexis then embracing her alo, Servant (aid he) I do wear unto you by the affection which I bear unto you, which is all I have; I wear unto you by Ifeas, Bellinus, Tharamis, the great Tautates, and I wear by your elf Atrea, without whom I pray heaven I may never be happy, That neither the authority of a Father, nor the obedience I owe unto my Superiours, nor any thing under the cope of heaven, hall ever eparate me from fair Atrea. Upon this kiing each other, to
the extream contentment of Alexis, and incredible atisfaction of Atrea, they parted nor, till they heard one open the door of the chamber: and then, let they hould be een, Alexis ate down in her eat, and Atrea continued in bed. Then Diana and Phillis entred; and Phillis in a joyful manner cryed victory, victory, we have got the victory: here is this incened woman (pointing at Diana) here he is, that confeeth all he aid, and all he did was wrong: Siter, aid Diana, oft and fair; you go a little too fat and far: for I do not confee that I was in the wrong, but indeed I ay that I was deceived, and the opinion which I had of that Shepherd was fale: but that I did it in believing what was told me, I am o far from confeing, that I think I had done ill, if I had done otherwie. But I beeech you Siters (aid Atrea) exp • nd your words, that this fair Druide and I may rejoyce with you: Ah luggard, aid Phillis, as deep in bed yet as when we left you? Had we two been in bed till as you are, we had never undertood what we do, which you deire to know: may I not ee him to day that I Love bet if I do tell you. Then tell it to me, aid Alexis; yes to you I will, aid Phillis, becaue you were the caue of our riing o oon, and conequently of the encounter which we met withall, and which only could drive that angry Shepherdes out of that opinion which he entertained; had we mied this occaion, we had never recovered it, becaue he who hatched and brought forth all thee traiterous devies, went away as oon as ever he had (unknown to her elf) done this good office unto Sylvander. Hereupon he related the whole dicoure betwixt Laonice and Tircis, and forgot not a illable of thoe things which Laonice poke, either againt her, or againt poor Sylvander.

Here is now, aid he, that cholerick Diana convinced; he that would not give credit unto any but Laonice; who thought that he only could peak the truth, and that poor illy we were all lyers: I thank God, aid Atrea, for conducting both you and Diana o opportunely to hear her, and all her trechery; for had you been eperated, I verily believe Diana would not have believed your reports: nay, though he her elf had heard it without a witnes, it would have been a long time before he would have confeed her knowledge. 'Tis true, anwered Diana, and I thank the goodnee of Heaven that has o happily directed me to the only means that could clear all my doubts. From hence may be oberved (aid the Druide) that innocency is never left without a helper, ince the poor and innocent Sylvander has found it when his hopes were mot remote. And ee, aid Atrea, how good Heaven is, and how omtimes to our conolation it caueth future things to be foretold by perons who peak them in jet, I my elf have found this to be o in this accident; for when I was honoured in the habit of my Mitris; I told Sylvander that within three dayes he hould ee an end of the pain wherein he was, I poke it only to keep him alive by infuing this hope, and not that I thought it would come to pae: yet you ee, I foretold the event as truly as if I had received it from the mouth of a God. To make your predictions true, aid Phillis, it is very requiite and full time you rie out of your bed, that we may go unto the place where Sylvander ues to be, unles you will carry your bed with you into the wood, where we will go and deire that Shepherd to bring you your mock. Neither you nor he need to take that pains, anwered Astrea, pray go you unto him, and bring him hither into this chamber, where he never yet was whilt I was in my bed: Is it poible? aid Alexis, no I aure you, aid Astrea, neither he nor any other Shepherd, and of this I dare take an oath. Never wear, replied Alexis, unlee you be mot certainly aured: I believe you do think o, but perhaps you may be deceived, and what do you know but that there may at this time be one concealed and hid? You are pleaed to jear me; replied Atrea, but believe it Mitris, we do keep a more reerved ditance with the Shepherds of Lignon, then you do think we do. Siter, aid Diana, the time was when I durt have taken uch an oath as that, which if I had, you know I had been forworn. However, aid Atrea, if you will pleae to give me a little leiure, I will dree my elf to ave Sylvander a labour of coming hither.

Upon this, Alexis roe up and fetched her own cloaths unto her dear Shepherdes, Servant, aid he, I would have you take my cloaths; be you my Mitris and call me ervant; and when I take them, then I will be the Mitris, and you the Servant. What will people ay, anwered Astrea, when they hear me call you o? They
will ay, replied Alexis, that it were trange if you hould call me otherwie, I being in the habit of a Shepherdee, and you in a Druides, and o of me, if I hould call you by any other name then Mitris: for my part, aid Astrea, I had rather fail, by obeying you, then not to do as you command; and to hew my obedience: Servant, aid he, if you do not help me to put on this Gown, I aure you I am o ignorant, that I know not where to begin. Alexis then took Atrea by one hand, did put that into one arm of the Gown; and then getting upon the bed, did put her other arm into the leeve of the Gown, and with o much contentment, or rather rapture, that he knew not what he did: for this new Druide did o confidently believe her to be a woman, that he did not hide any thing from her. At the lat, he was dreed: and becaue it was omthing late, they left the houe, and went all together to bid Phocion good morrow, who eeing them diguied in this manner, did at the firt, mitake them; but afterwards taking better notice of them, he was extreamly delighted at it. But thee fair Shepherdees had uch a deire to put Sylvander out of his pain, that without entertaining any motions of dinner from Phocion, they all took their leaves of him, and went unto the place where they hoped to meet Sylvander.

Sylvander, after he had got into the wood to avoid the company of Alcander and his Brother, went walking and wandering up and down all the night, until it was break of day; and he by fortune found himelf upon the banks of Lignon, where reting himelf, leep o eied upon his eyes, that the Sun was a good height, when ome dogs of the neighbouring Towns running at wolves, did awake him. Before his mind was thus tormented with thee turbulent perplexities, if he had heard the barking of a dog, he would have been the firt of all the Shepherds in running to preerve either his own or his friends flocks: but now, he tirred no more then if he had no interet in any flocks; which hews that the tronger paion makes the oul contemn the weaker. By fortune at the ame time an Officer who ued to wait at the Oracle of Mount-Verdune, and who knew Sylvander, paing by him, and eeing him not tir at the coure of the dogs, he did much wonder at it; and had an opinion that he was not well, becaue it was not his cutom to it till upon uch an occaion. But coming to him, and eeing no igns of any icknee in his face, becaue he diembled the anguih of his looks and mind, when he aw him approach: how now Sylvander, aid he unto him, who would have thought you o backward in puruance of the common enemy to our flocks? I know not of what enemies you peak, anwered Sylvander oberly, for there are o many orts of them, that he who undertakes to purue them all, has work enough; truly, aid the Officer, I know that the Gods do intend ome great and mierable mi-fortune towards us; and there is not any more certain ign of a Countries ruine, then when Tautates takes from it great and eminent perons, by whoe counels and valour it was preerved: and when the ret are carelee of its welfare and defence. And why, aid Sylvander, do you peak thee words? Becaue, anwered the Officer, all the victimes which we Sacrifice, are found o defective, that they do atonih all the Sacrificers; uch mifortunes never hapned in my dayes; I ay mi-fortunes, becaue it is a preage of the wort mi-fortunes that can befal us: and now, at this time, I ee that Sylvander, who was wont to be the mot careful man in all the Country, in the preervation of his etate and flock, is now grown careles, and eems as if the publique los did no more concern him, then if he had no hare in it. You ought not, replied Sylvander then, to conclude of an augure from my actions: for firt, Heaven would not have them take notice of a peron o mierable as I am: and next, I am worth o little, that it ought not to be coniderable. The Officer then anwered; there is an exces, as well in too much depiing, as in too much eteeming ones elf: and omtimes as much vanity and pride in the one as the other; as the Philoopher told him who to hew how much he depied rich and cotly habits, did wear an old rotten cloak full of holes; take heed, aid the Philoopher, that your pride do not appear through the holes of your cloak: and o Sylvander, take heed let in peaking lee advantagiouly of your elf then you deerve, you be not chargeable with the ame fault: all that knows Sylvander, knows alo his merit, and his capacity, and what eteem he is in this Country; and therefore to peak againt the opinion of every one, is either,
that he would declare himelf his own enemy, or ele would give occaion to be commended more: upon this, without any tay for the Shepherds anwer, he went on his way, leaving Sylvander in ome ort ahamed of the eteem which he had of him.

This thought tayed him a while in that place; at lat returning unto that which mot touched him to the quick: and conidering the inevitable accident which was faln upon him that was o innocent, he thought that Heaven was certainly incened againt him: and that by this correction it would make him re-enter into the conideration of himelf; to the end that ubmitting himelf unto him from whom all true conolations can come, he might receive that remedy which he ought to expect only from him. This thought caued him to fall down preently upon his knees, and holding up his hand to Heaven, he implored aide: and at the ame time reolved to conult with the Oracle of Cleontine; in order to this deign, he paed over the River Lignon, went to Mount-Verdu •• , conulted with the Oracle, and received this anwer:

lg.head: THE ORACLE.
lg.l: THy preent grief hall quickly ceae;
But he who only doth thee pleae,
Paris mut marry her: N'ere pretend
To compae thy deired end,
As long as thou hat any breath,
But only by Sylvander's death.

div.p: When the ad Shepherd received this cruel anwer, he tood as immoveable, but not o inenible as a rock; for uch was his reentment, that after he had folded his arms, he fell down, and for a very long time gave no ign of life, unles by the tears that flowed from his eyes: o that the Vacies and Eubages there preent, were exceedingly moved to compaion; but he anwered them all with ilence, turning his eyes only upon him that poke, but in uch a pitiful manner, that he forced tears from the eyes of all the company. At lat, a good part of the day being pat, he went from Mount-Verdune without peaking a word, and o retired himelf into the great wood next the long walk, not with any other deign but to be in that place, where Phillis delivered that cruel meage unto him, thinking that the ight of this place would augment his grief, and o much the ooner end his mierable life, in which he hoped for no manner of content.

But by fortune, Alexis, Astrea, Diana, and Phillis, came thither at the ame time, to pae away the heat of the day, according to their cutom. Phillis was the firt who pied the Shepherd, and hewed him preently unto her companions: he would have called unto him, but Diana did prevent her, aying, I would not have him think that I have been jealous, for uch a pirit as his would draw no mall conequences from uch a thought. What then, aid Phillis, would you have us do? We mut and o mut you, have compaion upon his pain. True, anwered the Shepherdes, but you mut alo have compaion upon me; and me thinks it is not a matter of uch mal concernment unto me, but it deerves very great conideration: upon this, he turned towards Atrea and Alexis, who were a little retired, and propounded unto them the difficulty which he found in the buines. It is a hard cae, aid Alexis, that one hould take o much pains to conceal truth. What truth Madam, replied Diana, do you peak of? You would not have Sylvander know that you love him, anwered Alexis; and to hide this truth from him, you are pumping for ome tricks and artifices to delude him: is it not much better to live freely with him, as you ee this fair Shepherdes and I do? Madam, aid Diana, you and Atrea are both of one ex, and therefore allowed. But, aid Atrea, what do you think then of Phillis and Lycidas? I do think Siter, aid Diana, that if Belinde my Mother would approve of Sylvanders marriage and mine, as Artemis does
of that between Phillis and Lycidas, perhaps then I hould make no difficulty to do as Phillis does: but knowing that this a thing impoible, why hould I make my good will appear unto this Shepherd? It would not perhaps avail him any thing at all, but perhaps bring much harm unto me; for I know that I will never chue a Husband without Belindes conent, and I am mot confident that he will never conent unto a marriage betwixt Sylvander and me.

Alexis then began to peak; I do not know, aid he, of what mind and humour Belinde is, having never een her; but I do find Sylvander to be a man o very well qualified, as I cannot think but if Belinde knew him, he would approve of this alliance. For a man is to be preferred before etate, I mean uch a man as Sylvander, whoe qualities are o highly etimable, as uch another is not to be found in all Gaul. Oh Madam, aid Diana, virtue now a dayes does get but little credit, if it be not et off with riches: beides this, my Parents will never conent that I hould give my elf unto a peron that is unknown: one whoe fate is o diaterous, that he himelf does not know who was either his Father, or his Mother, or his Country. This circumtance, replied Atrea, is very coniderable; but as we conclude that a Roe grows upon a Roe-tree, o may we the ame of Sylvander; eeing him o full of excellent perfections, who can doubt but that he is decended from Excellent and Virtuous Parents? Thee conjectures, replied Diana, are very good; but it belongs not unto me, neither to urge them any farther, nor to deny them: but for my part, I will lay all the fault upon Phillis. Upon me, replied he, I beeech you wherein am I culpable? Was is not you, aid Diana, and miled, which did him all the harm in telling him? This is an excellent good reaon indeed, anwered Phillis, it was I that did him all the harm in telling him: pray who did all the harm in putting me upon it, and giving me a commiion for it, nay preing me unto it? I ee, anwered Diana, that it is an eaie matter to give a commiion, but a very hard matter to give prudence and dicretion to execute it. And good my Lady Embaador, who gave you any intructions, to run and tell Sylvander every word which paion did hake from my tongue? You whoe paions were calm, and judgment free and ound, why did you not tay a little, and give me leave to conider in cool blood, till the heat of paion was over? Had it not been time enough now to have delivered him uch a meage as might have cot him his life? But you were o haty, and all upon the pur, to tell him that which hould have been eriouly pondered, and conidered upon with grave and erious deliberation, and after you had been many times prayed, entreated, deired olicited, nay preed unto: I beeech you tell me, Suppoe Sylvander had dyed upon it; did you think it would have pleaed me? Nay, could you think I would not have hated you all the dayes of my life? Oh with what prudence and olidity thee offices are to be performed? For could you imagine that you would not be culpable of all the inconveniences that hould enue upon it? And were not you worthy to bear all the blame? Atrea and Alexis could not chue but laugh to hear Phillis thus charged, and to ee that he could not anwer unto it, and therefore they condemned her to do whatoever Diana deired of her. I do aure you, aid Phillis, a very fine Sentence; which yet, in repect of my Judges, I will obey; but unto what punihment, I beeech you, mut I be condemned? Not o great as your crime, anwered Diana, I will only, that when you ee Sylvander next, you hall aure him, that all which you told unto him was only out of • allary, and that I did never know any thing concerning it: o that he may think all proceeded from your mouth, and that when I do peak next unto him, I may treat him as I was wont to do, before the trechery of Laonice. I do aure you Siter, aid Phillis, I did alwayes think you to be very ubtle, but never o ubtle as I find you now. No, no, aid Alexis, this is no ubtilty, but prudence; for Diana has reaon to deire it, and though you had not committed the fault whereof you are convicted, yet you ought to do as he ays. Madam, anwered Phillis, I hould be more willing to do it, were I not obliged unto it; for I am of uch an humour, that I had rather give twenty gifts, then pay one debt.

Whilt they were thus talking, Sylvander all orrow, and hanging down his head, came through the wood, till he was jut upon the place where thee Shepherdees were: and by fortune o near, that when he aw them, and would have turned
back, Phillis in obedience to the command upon her did peak unto him; Sylvander, Sylvander, aid he unto him, do you remember the time when you put me out of all patience againt Lycidas, and made it your delight to make him jealous? And becaue he anwered not, he continued; If you do remember, let it be a warning to you for the future, not to offend a woman, for it will not be long before he be revenged: and if you will not believe it, let me erve you for an example. I do not know (anwered Sylvander very dejectedly) what you mean: I do mean, replied Phillis, that all the tories which I told you concerning Diana, and her anger, were things only invented by my elf, to be revenged of you for making Lycidas jealous of me, when he oberved the familiarity which was then betwixt you and me. How (aid Sylvander) Diana not know any thing of all that which you told unto me? Not at all, I aure you, anwered Phillis. Diana hearing her elf named, and faigning to be ignorant what the matter was, he went unto them, and addreing her elf unto the Shepherd, I heard you name me, (aid he unto him) I beeech you, what hare have I in your dicoure? I am o confounded (aid Sylvander) to hear and to ee what I do, as I do think my elf to be in a dream. Phillis then breaking out into a loud laughter, Siter, (aid he unto her) you mut know from me, what this Shepherd does know but in part; upon this, he began to relate the jealouie of Lycidas, the pains he put upon him, and how Sylvander behaved himelf towards her. To be brief, aid he, I thought that if I were not revenged, I hould never enjoy any contentment in my life. I knew how Sylvander
• ccompanied Madonthe, and never acquainted you with it: I thought this to be a fit opportunity for my revenge; and indeed, ask him how he likes it, and whether he will take o much pains again to vex me any more. But I beeech you, aid Diana, what hare have I in all this buines? You have had what hare I pleaed, anwered Phillis: For I made you peak, even what I would, Truly Siter, aid Diana, I am very much obliged to you, for making me to peak when I never thought upon you. I beeech you Siter, aid Phillis, to pardon me, for I mut needs be revenged. Oh Heavens! (cryed out Sylvander, recoyling a pace or two, and folding his arms one within another) Oh ye Gods, is it poible that Diana hould have no hand or knowledg of that meage which you told me from her? No, replied Phillis; he knows not one illable of it; and that you may ee I ay truly, here Sylvander, continued he, and gave him the bracelet which he took from him, take this again, for I am contented with thoe tears which my theft did cot you. Sylvander kneeling down upon the ground, he took it and kied it a hundred times: and Diana the better to colour her eeming ignorance: Siter (aid he unto her) what is that which you give him? and what theft do you peak of? Content your elf, anwered Phillis, that ince you had no hand in the taking it away, there is no reaon you hould have any in the retitution. Sylvander was o extreamly joyed in receiving the dear bracelet, as • rgetting all his ad thoughts, his countenance began to change upon a udden: <> turning unto Phillis I cannot tell, oh my enemy, aid he unto her, whether I hould complain againt you, for the harm you have done me in tealing a thing which I eteemed o infinitely dear; or whether I hould think my elf obliged unto you for the favour you have done me in retoring it: For I cannot ay which is the greater, the dipleaure I received, or the contentment which now I have. Atrea then began to peak; Truly Phillis, aid he, I cannot chue but admire at the cunning piece of revenge which you have taken upon this Shepherd; and I mut confes, that I never thought you had a pirit o reolved upon any ill. Good Siter, aid Phillis, why hould I not prevent this Shepherd from putting any future dipleaures upon me? Do you not conider that impunity gives boldnes to commit new offences? Alexis who admired the wit of this Shepherdes, as well in diguiing the buines, as inventing the way of it o uddenly, he concluded that the wit of any man could not poibly be o quick at invention, nor o lie in disimulation as the wit of this woman: and from thence drawing conequences which eemed unto her to be unquetionable. Alas, alas! (aid he in her elf) unto what a mierable fate is that lover detined, who falls into uch hands: but Mitris, aid Sylvander in the mean time, and addreed himelf unto Diana, will not you be pleaed to help me in taking revenge, ince he was very near ridding you of the mot faithful ervant
that ever lived? Shepherd, anwered he, if you will be advied by me, you hall not have any longer thoughts upon revenge, but rather to make her a friend, ince you ee how well he can remember offences: if her memory be as good at courteies, as it is at offences, anwered Sylvander, he may remember that it was I who compoed all differences betwixt Lycidas and her: and you alo may remember that I have done the like for you, anwered Phillis: pray conider that I could have kept you a long time in this torment; whereas I contented my elf only with two or three dayes: and you are beholding unto me for no les then your life. 'Tis true, (anwered Sylvander faintly) for I cannot term that a life which I hould have lived: but cruel enemy, did you but conider what mieries you have caued upon me, I cannot think you would have thought upon any revenge, but rather have pitied the poor unfortunate Sylvander, who had no hopes of any contentment, but in his grave. Shepherd, anwered Phillis, you may believe, that for all my revenge, I hould have been very orry that any ill accident hould have hapned unto you, epecially upon my occaion. Alas, oh my enemy, replied Sylvander adly, you are the occaion of my greatet miery, which is of uch a nature that no remedy can cure. Certainly your miery mut be very great, anwered Diana, if it be beyond all cure; and yet I will condemn Phillis to contribute all her endeavours towards it, as thinking her obliged thereunto; and not only he, but all us, nay all the Country, who certainly are all very much concerned in the dipleaures of o kind a Shepherd. Phillis then interrupting Sylvander, who would have anwered unto thee obliging expreions of Diana. No, no Shepherd, aid he, hold your peace; all you can ay will do more hurt then good unto your dieae: but Diana, ince you think me obliged to cure the mieries of this Shepherd, be they of what quality they will, I will promie to cure them, provided alwayes, that you, on your part, will contribute your endeavours alo. Diana miled, and anwered; you mut be a very good Phyitian, if you cure uch deperate dieaes. Let it atisfie you, replied Phillis, that I will do it, o he will tell me his dieae. My dieae (anwered the Shepherd with tears in his eyes) is incurable by any thing but death. Without your death, anwered Phillis, I will cure you, if you have but the courage to tell your dieae, and Diana a will to apply the remedy. When you ee the greatnes of it, (replied the Shepherd) you will be out of all hopes. Is it poible (aid Atrea) that uch a man as Sylvander hould have les courage then uch a woman as Phillis? The courage which he has, anwered he, proceeds from her ignorance of that which I do but know to well. Let the proof, bear witnee, aid Phillis, only tell me your dieae, for both the Phyitian, and the Phyick are ready, Alas, alas! cryed he out, there is no reiting Heaven. This morning being plunged in the abye of orrows, which your diimulation caued, I went to conult with the Oracle at Mount-Verdune, which gave me an anwer o deperate, as makes me wih the Mountains may fall upon me, ince I mut not hope for any contentment amongt the living • What is the Oracle? (aid Alexis) If you deire to hear it, anwered Sylvander, I hall tell it; and when you have heard it, I am confident, you will pity the diaterous fate of this unfortunate Shepherd. It is this:

lg.head: THE ORACLE.
lg.l: THy preent grief hall quickly ceae;
But he who only doth thee pleae,
Paris mut marry her: N'ere pretend
To compae thy deired end,
As long as thou hat any breath,
But only by Sylvander's death.

div.p:
Oh ye Gods, continued the Shepherd, what hopes for me, ince Paris mut enjoy all my deires? And what hould I deire, ince in my death only, all my detres
are to be accomplihed? Oh Diana! (aid he and cat himelf at her feet) give me leave to tell you, ince you are to be anothers, that before this fatal day do dawn, I will pervent it by my death, let living, I hould endure every hour a thouand torments wore then death. Diana who did love this Shepherd, as dicreet as he was, he could not chue but hew her dipleaure at this Oracle, by ome tears, which her heart did ent into her eyes, which Phillis and Atrea oberved very well; but he being very wie, did recollect her elf as well as he could. And becaue this Oracle truck all the company with ilence except Sylvander, who never ceaed his complaints, but till continued them, and went the hand of Diana with his tears, Phillis began to peak: This Oracle, aid he, is indeed very trange; but if it pleae Diana, it is abolutely to your advantage. To his advantage? aid Diana, yes, aid Sylvander, to my advantage, o far as by my death to take me out of this miery: No, no, aid Phillis, it is clearly in favour of Sylvander if Diana will. Either I do not undertand the words of this Oracle, aid Diana, or ele the words of it, do not at all relate unto my will. But (aid Phillis) if they do relate and depend upon your will, will you let this will conent unto his cure? Diana made a top at this, and did not anwer, which gave occaion unto Alexis and Atrea to peak; and addreing themelves unto Diana, they told her, that if this Oracle had any relation, or dependency upon her will, it was an argument and will that the Gods did command her to conent: If the Gods (aid Diana) do command me, and Alexis and Atrea deire me, I cannot in all reon refue. Will you conent, aid Phillis, unto whatoever the Oracle would have you? I will, anwered Diana, Nay, aid Phillis, I will not trut you, without an Oath; wear therefore, by the God of Lignon, and by the Mileto of the New-year, that you will conent unto any thing that hall be neceary for the rendring this Oracle advantagious unto Sylvander I do, aid he, provided that I may not contribute any thing but my will. Then Sylvander, aid Phillis, rie up; thank Diana for the favour he has done you; and henceforward, eteem your elf the happiet Shepherd of all Lignon: and hearken how the Gods have pronounced unto you all manner of contentment by this Oracle. As for the firt vere, which tells you that your preent pain hall quickly ceae, there needs no better interpretation, then the event which you have already found. As to the econd which eems uch a fatal aying unto you, it is delivered in an ambigious manner, as mot Oracles are; the ambiguity rets in this word, Marry, which has a double ence, and may be taken two wayes: firt, we uually ay, that a husband does marry his wife: and econdly, we ay that the Druide does marry the husband and the wife; and it is in this lat ence it is to be undertood, that Paris mut marry Diana: he hall become a Druide like unto his Father Adamas, and it hall be he who hall marry you together. But (aid Sylvander, and ighed) I mut not expect the accomplihment of my deires, but in Sylvander's death. Ah thou ignorant Shepherd, replied Phillis •
have you not told us a hundred times, that he does dye in himelf, who does perfectly love another? And therefore the Oracle does advertie you, that you mut not expect the accomplihment of your deires but by the death of Sylvander; that is, by loving Diana o, as thou halt dye in thy elf and become her: Atrea and Alexis hearing this, doubtlee, aid they, the Oracle is to be thus undertood, and there wants nothing to make good her promie, but adding her will. Diana, who perhaps was as well pleaed with this interpretation, as Sylvander could be, though he made it lee appear: do you not ee (aid he) that I am not concerned at all in the buinee? Nay, nay, aid Phillis, never deny it, for it is plain that the Oracle refers wholly unto you: do • u not ee that Sylvander can live in you, and dye in himelf, if you will? Love (Siter) is one of thoe miteries which cannot be in a ingle peron: moreover, do you think that Paris can marry you unto Sylvander unles; you will? Unles you will give the Gods the lie, and unles you break your Oath, you mut make good all that the Oracle would have you; which is, that you do not only let Sylvander love you, but alo that you love him, o as he may live in you, and you in him. Ah Siter! (aid Diana, and turned a little the other way) no, no, aid Phillis, and took her by the arm, let me hear no more of your ah Siters, there is no middle way to be taken; you mut either be perjured, or do as I ay; otherwie there is no recovery of this Shepherd. Siter (aid Diana, with a becoming bluh,
and holding down her eyes) what would you have me do? I would have you oberve the Oath, anwered Phillis, which you have worn, and promied: what did I promie (aid Diana, and miled) you did wear, anwered Phillis, to do all that was neceary, to make this Oracle advantagious unto Sylvander. 'Tis true, aid Diana, and what ought I now to do? You mut, as I told you before (replied Phillis) love Sylvander in uch a manner, that he may live in you, and you in him. That (anwered he) is above my Oath. No, aid Phillis for amity conits in nothing but the will: Diana, aid Alexis, and Atrea, you mut needs give your conent; Well, aid Diana, after much importunity, ince you command me, I will: this will, aid Phillis, mut be a little better explained; and ay, that I will love Sylvander o, that hereafter as he lives in me, I will live in him. Oh Heavens! aid Diana, is not that too much? Yes, aid Sylvander, too much for my merit; not for his merit of affection, replied Phillis, nor to atisfie the Oracle. Well, aid Diana, I will do all that Alexis, Atrea, and Phillis, would have me; but if it be a fault, let it be yours, and upon the counel which you give me; o be it, aid Phillis, but furthermore, I do ordain, that for aurance of your words, Sylvander by your conent, do kis your hand, with a protetation never to depart from your obedience. Sylvander fell down upon his knees, ravihed with too much joy, and was o urpried at this unexpected happines, that taking Dianas hand and kiing it, it was a long time before he could peak one illable; and looked as if his eyes were dazled with too much light: this inexceive joy did almot take away from him the ue of reaon; but his ilence and his raptures had more eloquence in them then he had, and better-poke the grandeur of his affection then his tongue could: and had it not been for Alexis and the Shepherdees who helped him up, he had continued long in this amorous extaie, not knowing o much as what he did. Diana her elf was no les moved, though he et a better glos upon it: but Phillis, who oberved all this; and helped him to recover: come Sylvander, aid hee unto him, mut I be till your enemy? Do you ee how fully I can revenge thoe wrongs that are done unto me? The Shepherd being a little returned to himelf, I mut needs confes Phillis, aid he unto her, that you are the weetet enemy that ever was; and confee alo, aid he, that I have as much power as the greatet Gods: for wherein is their power more een, then in the good and bad fortune which they give? And have not I, when it pleaed me, made you the mot mierable, and then when it pleaed me, the mot happy man upon earth? What is it that fortune can do more then I? Good fortune and bad fortune, happinee and miery, have their dependency upon my will. I mut confes, oh puiant Shepherdes, aid Sylvander, that if your power do extend it elf over others as it has over me, Altars will be erected to you. However, repl •• d he, you cannot deny but that Sylvander ought to adore me. If it were permitted amongt us (anwered the Shepherd and miled) to adore many Gods, Phillis hould certainly be an adored Deity unto me: but ince it is not lawful, and that we mut acknowledg but one God, I hope I hall be excued, if I do not render that devoir. I am very well contented (aid Phillis then) that you do adore but one Deity in Heaven, and another upon earth: o I hall, replied the Shepherd, Tautates in Heaven, and Diana upon Earth. Oh mot ungrateful wretch, aid Phillis, are you not more beholding unto me, then to Diana? Is not all the contentments you receive from my hand? I hould be mot ungrateful indeed, replied Sylvander, if I did not acknowledg what is due unto you; but I hould be much more ungrateful, did I equal my obligations I ow unto Diana, with thoe I ow unto you: for thoe I do ow unto you, are but conequents of my love to her; and thoe which I <> ow unto her, are no conequents, nor upon any conideration but love it elf, without any relation to you. And therefore Phillis, undeceive your elf in this: all the benefits which you have done me, I take as coming from her; for otherwie I would not eteem them benefits.
