I perceive, replied Phliis, and miled, that all my labour in obliging you is but lot, ince all my benefits are et upon the core of that Shepherdes. What would you have me do? aid Sylvander; for uch is my affection unto Diana, that I give Heaven no thanks for the life it hath given me, unlee I may erve and adore this Divine Diana, unto whom all humane hearts ought to render homage.

Thus did Diana let Sylvander know that he loved him; and ever ince this day he was not hie, nor made any difficulty to live with him, as Atrea was wont to do with Celadon, and Phillis with Lycidas: o as Sylvander has ince oftentimes aid, that he had never been happy, if he had not been firt mierable.

The joy and contentment which might be een in the eyes and actions of Sylvander was uch, that Atrea and Phillis did extreamly admire at it: and the changing of his complexion and countenance in o hort a time, was an infallible argument unto them of his real affection. As for the diguied Druide, he meaured the grandeur of Sylvanders joy by her own, which he hould have received if under the notion of Celadon, and not of Alexis, Astrea had been o kind as he was unto her. But when Sylvander oberved the change of habits between Alexis and Atrea; I mut confes, aid he with wonder, that Phillis has o infatuated my undertanding, as till now I never found my mitake. Oh Sylvander, aid Phillis, aure your elf that a woman can deceive a man a hundred wayes when he has a mind unto it, and therefore it concerns you to keep my friendhip very carefully. All the company did fall to laughing, and they walked along the River Lignon, till they came to the place where Celadon did cat himelf into the water; which Atrea eeing, let us flye, aid he, let us flye away from this fatal place, from which me-thinks nothing can come but diaters.

The Druide knew very well that it was the place where he received thoe cruel commands, which contrained her to turn her elf from Celadon into Alexis: and it was impoible for her, not to give knowledge of ome reentment. But not being able to imagine that this Shepherdes hould call the place fatal for that caue: and why my dear Servant (aid he unto her) do you term this place of Lignon fatal? Astrea did not anwer, but looked upon her, changed colour, and could not chue but igh. Which Diana perceiving, Madam (aid he unto her) Atrea has good caue to call this place fatall, becaue he was very near being drowned there: for he fell into the River, and but for ome happy help which came in opportunely, this Country had for ever lot the fairet Shepherdes that ever lived in it. I pray tell me (aid Alexis) how chanced that accident? Phillis, who was unwilling Sylvander hould take any notice of Atreas diquiet; Mis-fortunes (aid he) and diaters are not to be talked on in a time o full of joy as this: but yet, they ay, aid Sylvander, that the memory of pat mieries does bring contentment, and are pleaing: yes, replied Astrea, when the mieries which are related, do not make mierable again: but that for which I give the phrae of fatal unto this place, does never come into my memory without infinite grief: and ee Sylvander whether I have not good reaon for it; for when I fell from that fatal place into the water, poor Celadon deiring to help me, was drown'd: and ome cured reporter carrying the fale news of my death unto my Father and my Mother, they both dyed preently after, o as I had no ooner bewailed the one, but tears began to overwel my eyes for the other. Atreas eyes could no longer refrain from tears, and certainly they had flowed into a torrent, had they not heard a Shepherd inging, which diverted Astrea, and caued all the company to look that way: As oon as Diana had turned her elf, I am, aid he, very much mitaken, if yonder Shepherd whom we ee, and the company which is with him, are not coming hither to look for me: what moves you unto that thought? aid Alexis, I will tell you (anwered he) but let us hear what he ings; and they being very near, alo he inging very loud, they heard him ing, That whereoever he came, he found the repreentation of him and his Mitris. I am not mitaken, aid Diana, as oon as the Shepherd had ung that vere, for the Gods have choen me to Judge a difference which is amongt them; yeterday they deired me to undertake the office, and I promied them to meet them here at this place this hour; happy I am that we light o opportunely both of the place and the time, for I wear unto you that I had quite forgot it. By that, Mitris (aid Sylvander) you may draw aurance that it is the will of the Gods you hould take that office upon you, ince they have o opportunely conducted you.

Upon this, the trangers were o near, that Diana out of civility went to alute them; a little after, Alexis, Atrea, and Phillis, did the ame: you may ee, aid Diana, that I am a peron of my word, and have brought all this good Company
with me, not only out of curioity to know the caue of your coming to me, but to help me in the judgement which I am to give unto you. We are much ahamed, fair and dicreet Shepherdes, replied Delphire, that we have made you tay o long; and we do find our obligations doubled, ince we have greater hopes that our caue will receive a more equitable judgment, by the aitance of your company of which do not doubt, for all our ret and tranquility depends upon what you hall pleae to ordain amongt us. But, oh jut Judge, aid Thomantes, and interrupted, what hall be done unto thoe that are condemned, and will not oberve the Sentence which you hall doom? This quetion is not moved without reaon; for I have een this fair one (pointing at Delphire) o negligent in the obervance of thoe Laws, which all other humans hold inviolable, as I have good caue to fear he will not oberve what you hall ordain, if it be againt her mind. Oh Thomantes! (aid Delphire) this reproach is inupportable; and were I not in hopes that ere long our jut Judge will revenge all the wrongs which I have received from you, I would demand Jutice upon this injury in particular. You are o accutomed (replied Thomantes) to complain without a caue, as I do not think it trange you hould now do the like; nor think it a lee wonder to hear me peak o openly and freely, having all my life behaved my elf towards you, under the Laws of uch a grand repect, that any complaints were not permitted me in my greatet pain: but now we are here before our Judge, and it is fit he hould know both your cruelties, and my torments, that he may the better give judgment upon them. I will not enter or hold any Dicoure with you (aid Delphire) but will only hint unto our Judge to oberve from your language, that it is the highet injutice to blind Jutice. Only beeech her not to loe any more time in hearing you, but imploy it upon that which he is ordained unto by the Gods.

Whilt Delphire and Thomantes were talking thus, Diana eated her elf upon the ground, and Alexis, Atrea, Phillis, and the ret of the Shepherdees, eated themelves in uch places where they might bet hear this difference argued: Filintes, and Aphales, with Sylvander, did the ame: Now (aid Diana) fair Shepherdee, and you courteous Shepherd, if you deire any thing from me, let me undertand your demands and difference; and in bet order thereunto, it is very fit you make choie of one which knows all the paages betwixt you, to relate them unto us, and afterwards both parties to peak for themelves. Fair and Wie Shepherdee, aid Aphale then, we are four Shepherds and two Shepherdees that are intereted in the judgment which you are to give, and therefore if you think it good, Androgenes, aid he, and pointed to him, or I, will relate unto you what concerns Thomantes, Filintes, and Delphire; and afterwards, either Filintes or Thomantes will relate the difference of Doriea, Androgenes, and my elf: I conceive, anwered Diana, that for brevities ake, it is better that the Shepherdees make the firt relation, and not the Shepherds, who know too well to anwer their reaons: and therefore Doriea, I do appoint you unto the office, not only to relate what concerns Delphire, but alo what concerns your elf, not quetioning but o direct a Shepherdee will give us true information. Hereupon Doriea, after a low reverence, took her place, and after a little time of conideration, he began thus.

div.head: The Hitory of DELPHIRE and DORISSEA.
div.p: IF thoe who have heard tell of jealouie, had but the experience of it as we have, Oh Wie, and Prudent Shepherdes, doubtles they would all ay that it is a great enemy unto love: and as cold is contrary to heat, o is it directly contrary to that paion which caueth love: for fear i • the Mother of it, and conequently it mut be cold, but love is always burning, and in a flame. Some on the contrary do eteem it to be the daughter of Love, and o neceary to its preervation, that as the water which the Smith throws upon the fire to make it burn more violent and ardently, o likewie jealouie augments and makes the flame of love more violent in the ouls of Lovers. Had you not commanded me mot Wie Shepherdes, to relate unto you the differences betwixt Delphire, Thomantes, Aphales, Androgenes, and my elf, I would have intanced ome examples to prove what I ay, but I aure my elf, that in the Dicoure which I hall make unto you, there will appear o many proofs of it, as will force you to confes with me, that if love can hardly be without jealouie, jealouie can never be without effacing love.

Be pleaed to know then, fair and Wie Shepherdee, that Thomantes being the only on of his Parents, was brought up with abundance of tender care, by the Wie Shepherdes Ericanthe his Mother, and by Eleaman his Father: o tender was their care over him, that they would never uffer him to be out of their preence, as thinking that as oon as they lot the ight of him, he was lot for ever. And becaue Eleaman and Ericanthe were the wealthiet in all our Town, as well in the great abundance of flocks and patures, as in the great number of Shepherds and Shepherdees, unto whoe charge he committed the care of them, the young Thomantes was brought up in all the qualities and exercies fit for a Shepherd of his rank, in which for his age, he did o profit himelf, that none in all our coats could equal him. Being got out of the hands of his Nure, an ancient and Wie Pator was et over him as his Governour; not that he was thereby excluded from the company of thoe women, who waited upon his Mother; for on the contrary he was amongt them till the age of ten or twelve years, o beloved and careed by all, as well were they that could love him mot, for beides his being very amiable, and had all the good qualities that one of his age could have, he was looked upon as the darling and delight of the Pator Eleaman, and of the age Ericanthe their Mitris. But as it commonly happens at that age, rather by intinct then by election, to love one above another, the young Thomantes no ooner aw ten years of age, but he hewed a great inclination to love Delphire, who was then brought up with Ericanthe, and and not above eight or nine years old at that time. Their innocent age, and their deign without deign, not being yet intructed in the art of diimulation, every one took notice of the particular affection of Thomantes unto Delphire; whereof Ericanthe was very glad, as well becaue that Shepherdee was indeed very handom, and worthy of love and ervice; as becaue many do think that there is nothing does more awake and enliven youth, nor roue it up unto noble deigns, then love: doing in this the office of Steel, which makes a flint to parkle, that is of it elf cold, and without light. One may eaily imagine what kind of infantine affection this was, which they bore one to the other, for I am confident none can think it above matter of play for pins, or making preents of cheries, and telling old tales, that their Nures taught them in the Univerity of the Nurerie: but o it was, that thee trifling beginnings did omtimes produce great effects, and love was pleaed to raie by degrees thee childih inclinations unto great affections: the Shepherd when he was arrived at his fourteenth year, was able to call himelf old Lover, it being now five
or ix yeares ince he began the profeion; and yet all this while he was not o good a proficient as to know that it was love: but afterwards, both of them growing every day more learned then other, they came to undertand the Mitery; and then confirming by their wills what they had done before by hazard, or at leat by a blind inclination, they began to lay the foundation of a real affection.

The c • res of Thomantes were great, how to tetifie unto Delphire the good will which he wihed unto her: and the modety of Delphire was no les in a dicreet receiving of it, according to the duty which he owed unto the on of Ericanthe: o as every one did ee the love of this Shepherd, and every one did commend and eteem the widom of the Shepherdes, in carrying her elf o even, and learning no more to one ide then to another: I mean, he walked even betwixt love, and repect, o as one could not know whether her actions proceeded from affection or from duty: the love of Thomantes was now known unto all thoe in the houe of Ericanthe: Delphire her elf could not doubt it, before ever the Shepherd did let her undertand it by his words: and all his actions did peak that, which out of a puiant repect, his tongue durt not: but at lat, his affection from day to day growing tronger, it broke thoe trings of repect which tyed his tongue.
The firt time he took the boldnes was the day of his birth, which Ericanthe in thanks to the Gods did every year celebrate upon the day that he was born.

Not far from the oure of our delightful Lignon, Bleaman and Ericanthe had a houe, which nature had imbellihed with all the ornaments that could make it delightful; it was eated upon a Hill, whoe propect, though a little limited, by reaon of ome petty Mountains; yet it was o pleaant, as thoe that would take a landskip of delight, might make that their pattern for a cituation. Lignon ran below it with its lovely meanders, as far as the ight could extend; mead • ws made a mot agreable object to the eye: all one ide of the Hill was covered with a hade of trees quartered in walks, where one might walk and defie the cortching heat of the day, till they came to the River Lignon: flowers at all times, and of all colours, do grow in great abundance; Nightingals making choie of it for their contant habitation, do people it in uch ort, and warble it in their anwers of each other, like a world of Muitians, as if they had foraken all other places of the Country, to come and chant it there; to be brief, the place was the delight of all the neighbouring Towns, and commonly had a great concoure of people in it, epecially upon dayes of olemnity, as this birth day of Thomantes was.

It eems Heaven would let this young Shepherd know, that he had not been born, but only to live in the ervice of this fair one; for though he had opportunity enough to peak unto her, and to let her undertand his affection, yet he tayed till the day of his birth before he would declare it by word, as if he had aid, that the day whereon he received him for her ervant, hould be the firt day that he did rightly begin to live. It fortun'd o, that a little before, an Uncle unto Delphire dyed, which caued her, according to cutom, to be in a mourning habit. Delphire having an excellent grace in decking and dreing her elf more handomly then any of the young Shepherdees in the Town, he appeared o fair and handom in that habit of orrow, as there was no eye which looked upon her without ravihment and admiration, as well at her beauty as her weet civilities: and Thomantes was not o much an admirer as an adorer, but indeed both; and took uch delight in contemplating her actions, as his eyes had no other objects: he could not atisfie himelf with commending her; omtimes he doted upon her complexion; omtimes upon the ymetry and features of her face; omtimes upon the vivacity of her eyes; omtimes the coral of her lip; omtimes upon the ivory of her teeth; otherwhiles, he was wholly taken up, with her tature, garb, and mind: otherwiles with the delicacy and whitenee of her hand: otherwhiles in the advantage he had above all her Companions in her dree: o as he concluded that there was nothing under Heaven, o fair, nor o lovely as Delphire. You make me a relation of hitory o new, (anwered he and miled) and o incredible, that for my part, I can give no credit unto it. I do know very well (replied he) from whence this incredulity comes; it is becaue you cannot ee your elf: for if Heaven had done you that favour, I do not think you uch an enemy to truth, as to ay I am not in the right. I have een
my elf everal times in fountains of water, replied he, and in everall glaes: but I could never find what you out of flattery are pleaed to tell me. Oh Delphire, anwered he, how imperfect are thoe repreentations, and what infinite wrong they do unto your beauty? Do you think thoe dead and enlee things are able to repreent you? You I ay, who are the very life and joy of all thoe that have the happines to ee you: if you have a mind to ee your elf as you are, be pleaed to take a living mirrour of my preenting unto you; and I aure myelf, that if you will daign to cat your eye upon it, you will there find in your elf more beauties then any tongue can tell: what is that, aid the Shepherdes, which you call a living mirrour? My heart, anwered he. Oh Thomantes (aid he) how fale and deceitful are all uch mirrours? For as one cannot ee in them what one would, but onely what thoe deluding mirrours pleae to repreent; o there is no aurance or credit to be given to their repreentations, becaue they are only uch as the paion of the oul does bid them. I do believe (anwered he) that the heart does repreent nothing but what is in the oul, and therefore you may ee in mine, Delphire in her perfect beauty, becaue you are o imprinted in my oul, as nothing can be more perfectly repreented. Thomantes (aid he) what a lyer you are, and how you jear me, and would laugh at me, if I had o little wit as to believe you? There is nothing o hameful to a peron of honour, anwered he, as to be urpried in a lie: you need not fear that hame (replied he) for you know that none can look into your heart to convince you. Actions (anwered he) are they that open the doors of a heart; and you ee that all mine do tetifie unto you, how Thomantes does love Delphire, and that he does never look with the eyes of love upon any other beauty but hers; and I do make this declaration unto you upon my birthday, to tetifie that I believe Heaven gave me life only to imploy it in loving and erving you; which I do vow to do, with o much affection and fidelity, that I am forced to call my elf your mot devoted ervant.

Thomantes added unto thee many other expreions, which (for brevities ake) I omit, and which Delphire did not interrupt; becaue, though he had a quick wit, and ound judgment, yet was he o urpried, that he could not anwer: for the repect which he bore unto him as the Son of Ericanthe, the good will which he already had unto him as Thomantes, the virtues and affections which he found in him, and her fears to fail in her duty, did hold her in a upene of reolution, and therefore Thomantes, after a while of ilence in expectation of her anwer, and when he aw he remained till mute, he continued thus: I perceive, fairet Delphire, that your ilence does menace me; and that thoe hopes which the weetnee of your eye does promie me, are not very certain: but on the contrary the augure which I might take from that black habit which you wear, does but too truly portend my ruine. Upon this, he changed colour, and his words did die in his mouth; and though he did offer everal times to fall again into his dicoure, yet he was o confued at her returning no anwer, that he could not peak.

Delphire then, to eae him from any longer pain, he aid unto him: The words Thomantes which I heard you utter, are very like unto thoe which mot Shepherds do commonly ue unto Shepherdees; and I will believe they were poken more out of cutom, then with any deign: yet the repect which I do ow unto you, and the honour which you do me in dicouring with me, does oblige me to eteem them, as coming from o kind a Shepherd, whom I will alwayes eteem and honour as I ought, and as he deerves: and becaue he would not have this dicoure continue any longer, or go any further at this time, he went away unto her Companions.

Be, oh age Shepherdee, pleaed to know, that a long time before, Filintes who is that Shepherd whom you ee next unto Delphire, and who is a near kinman unto Thomantes, was become a ervant unto that ame Shepherdes, and being older then he, he had alo more boldnes to declare himelf o. But ome urgent affairs contraining him to leave our Town, and to take a long voyage; it eems Heaven would favour the deign of Thomantes, in taking from him this rival, who was no mal mote in his eye.

Filintes then departed, full of love and full of orrow, and about twelve or thirteen months after, returned with the ame love he carried away, unles perhaps encreaed
and grown bigger as his body was. But at his departure he had an opinion that he had ome advantage of Thomantes, yet found at his return, what a mortal enemy abence is unto Love: for he found the deign of his rival o thriven, and his own o blated, as any but himelf, would have lot all hopes. Yet his generous courage would not hrink at any difficulties, and therefore reolved a econd defeat: at his return then, he renewed his addrees; added new upplications to his old prayers; and econded his old ervices with new ones. Briefly, he was o aiduous, and did o importune her, that though he could not win any thing upon the reolved mind of Delphire, yet he raied mot extream upitions and trong jealouies in the oul of Thomantes. For though Delphire did prefer Thomantes, yet the true love of that Shepherd, would not let him be in ret, knowing very well, that love works wonders, and does miracles. And from hence did proceed o many diquiets, and o many torments, which thee two Shepherds have caued unto each other.

And yet, although their loves were very great, and the violence of their affections did daily increae; yet for all this, the friendhip and amity that was betwixt them did not alter: a quality which was highly etimable in Filintes, who was leat loved; and whoe humour was naturally plenetique: and yet who could ubmit himelf unto the laws of reaon. The advantage of Thomantes was great, having the authority of Eleaman, and principally of Ericanthe, to back him: and yet the encouragement of Filintes was not a little, having a iter, brought up alo with Ericanthe, who had a very great prevalency with Delphire: and indeed, it was unto her, to whom Filintes did commonly make his complaints. At lat it fell out, that this Shepherd, after he had oberved upon everal occaions how this Shepherdee preferred Thomantes before him, and after he had made all the complaints he could, eeing that he received nothing but freh tetimonies of his being not loved, and being out of all hope and patience, he reolved to make a retreat, and draw off from a iege which would digrace him if continued. So eeking for an opportunity of peaking to her; at lat finding her in a place where none could hear, he gave her this language: You know Delphire how I have loved you; and I ay you know it, for your excellent and pregnant wit cannot chue but clearly ee it in all my actions, ever ince you can remember me: you know alo, that coldnee, nor your didains, nor my too long abence, could ever divert my affection, nor in the leat degree diminih it. But now being preed, or rather oppreed by thoe corns and injuries which I daily receive from you, I come to tell you, that finding them inupportable, I mut quit the name of ervant unto Delphire, and that which neither any time nor abence, nor your rigours could do, your corn, which is inupportable to my pirit, does move me unto a jut pleen. Delphire without the leat diquiet, and almot glad of this his reolution, did anwer him extream carelely; I never thought, nor deired, Filintes, that you had any mind unto that Title which now you quit; and it is a thing o very indifferent unto me, that if you think there is any one amongt my Companions, that deerves it, I hall advie you to love and erve her.

This cold anwer, and the carelee manner of giving it, did till more offend the courage of Filintes, and this was the reaon why he went away with a lowring brow, which ufficiently hewed his ill atisfaction. But pleen, being a paion which blinds the judgement, he thought that no way was better to be revenged upon Delphire, then to divert the affection of Thomantes from her. And as ome do hope to accomplih all they deire, and imagine all things eaible will come to pas, o he had a conceipt, that he could perwade him to withdraw. In order to this deign he went unto him; and after he had taken him aide, Brother, (aid he unto him, for o Eleaman would have them call each other, though they were only Coens) I come to entreat a favour from you, you ought not to deny me, becaue I ask it out of the abundance of my affection, and becaue it is as much to your advantage as mine. Brother, anwered Thomantes, you may well think that any thing which will give you contentment, I will certainly do with as good a will as you can deire it. Then promie me, aid Filintes, that you will do it; for unles you be obliged by your promie, you will at the firt tart back, and make ome difficulty. I will not promie any thing, replied Thomantes, till I know what it is; and you need not fear that any difficulties
can make me tart from doing all I can to give you contentment. A long dipute being betwixt them hereupon; at lat, Filintes, eeing he could not oblige him by his promie, he reolved to tell him what the buinee was; Brother, aid he unto him, I deire you, as the greatet obligation you can put upon me, that you would quit Delphire, or at leat eem as if you did for a time; pride has huffed her into o much inolence, as if he continue a little longer, he will render her elf inupportable; he thinks all men in the world were made only for her: does he not pretend that all thoe repects and devoirs, which you and I out of our free wills do render unto her, are due by obligation? And does he not demand them as a tribute, to draw all thoe he ees, after our example, into her poeion? She tryumps, and is become all corn, both towards you and towards me: yet would I gladly know upon what ground he does it. But Brother, aure your elf, the more he ees we withdraw from her, the neerer he will draw to us; it is good to love, but not to be laves: I have heard ay, that women do alwayes make much of men, till they be aured they love them; but then they treat them no better then laves: come, come, Brother, oblige me o far as to retire, as I am reolved to do; and you hall ee her with all her corn, and indifferency, brought a loop lower. Thomantes in a miling manner, Brother, aid he unto him, I am orry you hould ask me a thing which is impoible. For I do deire as much as I do my own life, to give you all full contentment; but aure your elf Filintes, that let Delphire treat me which way he pleaeth, I can do no other but endure it without murmur: I have no power to withdraw my elf from that ervitude in which he holds me: and for my part, I do think, all that ee her, are in reaon obliged to erve and adore her: for judging others by my elf, I think it to be a great deffect in judgment, not to end their dayes in uch a weet ervitude. Fie, fie, Thomantes, aid Filintes, are you not ahamed of uch an unworthy reolution? Good Brother; anwered Thomantes, the tone is already thrown, there is no recalling it, I am o reolved upon it, that if I hould find in my elf the leat will to the contrary, I hould die with hame: but Filintes, aid he, pray tell me, what is your deign? To live, aid he, like a man of pirit and courage, and not a lave: I can endure any thing but corn; but that, I mut confes, is intollerable unto me. Perhaps, aid Thomantes, when I am more wie, I hall take up the ame reolution; but as I am, there is no hopes of it.

Thus ended the dicours betwixt thee two Shepherds; but the event will make you laugh: Filintes, eeing he could not divert Thomantes from his reolution, as if he had quite forgot all that he had aid unto him, or unto Delphire, he ran as fat as ever he could unto her, and beeeched her with all manner of prayers and upplications to forget and forgive all that he had aid; and then he addreed himelf unto his Siter to intercide for him and make his peace: Delphire could not chue but mile; well, aid he, Filintes I am contented; upon condition that you will not believe, you have obliged me more by your return, then by your going away.

Delphire had no ooner aid o, but Thomantes entred, who eeing this reconcilement, and hearing what Filintes aid, was o amazed that he asked Delphire and Filintes, whether what he aw was not a dream: no, no, aid Filintes, it is real; but imagine that I do as laves ue, who endeavour to break their chains but cannot. But when Thomantes did relate unto Delphire in private, the requet which Filintes made unto him, you may imagine whether that Shepherdee was not ravihed at two uch uddain, and uch different motions.

During the time that thee two Shepherds lived thus, I returned from the banks of Argent, a little Rivolet, which runs into the great River of Loire: and at the ame time Aphales, (the Shepherd whom you ee with Filintes, and his younger Brother) took up an humour of courting me, rather I believe, becaue it hould not be aid, that he was the only one in all our Town who did not love, then for any other end. Now Aphales being almot alwayes in the company of his Brother Filintes, as his friend, or perhaps as well wiher unto Delphire; we were almot alwayes together. I oberved that Aphales was long before he could bring himelf to any certainty, and knew not upon which of my Companions he hould betow himelf, imitating a Bee which flyes upon everal flowers before he fixes upon any: for
omtimes he would be for Delphire, another time upon Filie, one while upon Eritrea, and another upon me: But at lat, after he had turned and returned, omtimes to one, and omtimes to another, he fixed upon me, or at leat eemed o.

I mut confes, that if I had been in a mind to entertain any, Aphales had not been diagreeable to me; for though he be preent, yet I mut needs ay, that it was hard to meet with a Shepherd of more taking qualities then he was owner of; agile in all manner of exercies, handome in his habit, quick and nimble in his dicoure, kind towards Shepherdees, civil towards Shepherds, affable with his familiars, and o complaiant towards all, as it was impoible to be weary of his company: and withal (interrupted he) one that of all the company Doriea loves leat. Doriea (anwered he and miled) is not reolved to love all that are amiable. Then continuing her dicoure; Now this Shepherd (aid he) though I told him freely my mind, and that he ought not to pend his time about a buines from which he could expect no contentment, yet he till continued obtinate, and hoped, that time perhaps which overcomes all things, might in the end melt my reolution, and alter my Will; He neglected no opportunities of tetifying his extream affection unto me: and becaue I was at all hours in Ericanthes houe, out of my amity to Delphire, he was at all hours alo talking to me: for being Nephew unto the age Pator Eleaman, he never tirred out of the houe, but was continually there, in as much freedom as in his own; o as I had been deaf, if I had not heard him ay an hundred times in a day that he loved me; and that he deired no greater happines in the world, then that I would love him: his contant continuance of this, made me think that indeed he did love me: And this opinion obtained o much from him againt my reolution, to permit his continuance; but till after uch a reerved manner, as he could not be contented with it: He aid, that this permitting him to love me, did as good as ignifie nothing, and would never oblige me to love him again: I told him, that this was all I could permit; only that he hould keep his affection to me o ecret, and epecially this permiion which I gave him, that if any came to know it, I would hold it for revoked: That he hould never deire any thing from me, which might in the leat manner offend my honour; and above all, that I hould not be troubled with any letters from him; and many other uch like articles, unto which he conented, knowing, (as I think) that the refual of them would rather prejudice then advantage him. But of all thee, none went o much againt the grain as the lat, which exempted me from receiving any letters; for (aid he) if it hould be my misfortune to be at a ditance from you, how hould I know how to let you know how I do, or you me? Very well, anwered I; for uppoe I hould receive your letters, can you hope or think that would end you mine? So that as to that point, the Letters which I receive will not avail you any thing, and as for hearing from you, truly I am o little inquiitive, that the labour would be but lot in ending them to me.

But replied he, do you not value the contentment that I hould receive in holding correpondency with you in this manner? and in rendring you an accompt of my life? I hall know all this, aid I, at your return. But in the mean time, aid he; in the mean time, anwered I, I will be contented to know you love me till, as you have promied: for have you not told me that your life hould be alwayes uch as I pleaed? What then, replied he, mut I never hope that you will write unto me? No, aid I, and more then that, never hope that I will receive any Letters from you. This everity, replied he, is too great, and I protet, aid he, half angry, that do what you can, I will end you ome Letters: and I protet, aid I, that I will never look in them.

The reaon why he was o earnet in this, was becaue he knew that ere long he was to be abent from me: for his Father was to end him upon ome important buines into the Province of the Romans. And indeed within a few dayes after, he came unto me the addet foul that ever was een, and looked like a prioner going to be hanged. Doriea, (aid he unto me, as oon as he could peak unheard by any) ah Doriea! this is the lat day I have to live, unlee you have ome pity upon Aphales: I eeing his face o changed, and his colour quite gone, I mut confee, I had ome apprehenions of ome harm he would do himelf, and was o kind as to reent his adnes: but when I asked him, why he poke o? and undertood that it was only
the journey which he was to take, I could not chue but mile. Do you laugh, aid he, at that which my heart weeps? Oh mot cruel woman! if Heaven do not revenge me upon you, I hall not think it jut. I do not laugh at your journey, aid I unto him, for ince it dipleaeth you, it hall not be pleaing unto me; but I laugh at the dipute which we had ome few dayes ince, becaue it eems you foreaw your departure: could I hope, anwered he, that you would never be pleaed at any thing which dipleaeth me, I hould depart the mot happy man, that ever was contrained to be abent from her whom he adores. If you undertand my words aright (aid I) you may go with aurance that what dipleaeth you, hall not be pleaing unto me; and how, aid he, would you have me undertand them? My meaning is, replied I, that whatoever dipleaeth you, o I have no interet in it, but only for the love of you, hall never pleae me. Then, continued he, becaue you have no interet in my departure, and becaue it dipleaeth me, you are alo orry for it: would you Aphales, aid I unto him, and miled, that I hould conclude as you do? I cannot tell what I would have, anwered he dejectedly, unles it be death, ince you will not uffer me to write unto you in my abence.

At the leat I am ure, replied I, that I will not receive any of your Letters. Are you till in that obtinate humour? (aid he half angry) and making a ign unto him by nodding my head, that it was o. Then I wear, aid he, by the affection which I bear unto you, that you hall receive them in pite of your teeth; and becaue I aured him, no, we laid a wager of it, which he aid he was ure to win.

Our dicoure had continued long upon this ubject, and had continued longer, if his Father, who intended he hould depart the next morning betimes, had not ent two or three times for him: he went then to his Father, from whom he received all intructions neceary for his voyage: and when he was ready to depart, he called to him an old Shepherd, who had erved him from his infancy: the Shepherds name was Alindre, a dicreet and ubtle man, and one who loved Aphales exceedingly: Aphales took him into his chamber, and the door being hut, he acquainted him with his affection unto me, with his orrows to depart from me, and the extream contentment it would be to write unto me; and becaue it was a buines which he deired hould be kept ecret, he had made choie of him amongt all the ret of his friends, to do him the office of delivering his Letters. Alindre who deired nothing more then to pleae Aphale in all things, did tell him that in this and all other his commands, neither his affection nor fidelity hould fail: Aphale upon this embracing him; dear friend, aid he unto him, I ever had that belief in you; and therefore, as the thing, which of all the world is mot dear unto me; I put this into your hands, conjuring you to find a way as oon as I am gone, that he may ee this letter: and be ure, you ue all your ingenuity and care in the delivery of it. The difficulty (anwered Alindre) will not be great; for being o familiar with Eleaman as I am, I can watch my time when he goes to ee Delphire, whom they ay he loves extreamly, and ten to one but once in a day I hall find a fit opportunity to give it unto her: Oh friend (aid Aphales) do you think he will receive it o? No, no, friend, I would have her take it and read it, before he knows that it comes from me, otherwie he is of o croe a humour, that he will not take it; for he has proteted and worn that he would not: and becaue I do infinitely deire to hew her that my affection has more indutry and ingenuity to arrive at my deires, then he has cruelty to hinder me; I do conjure you, my dear friend Alindres, to ue all the wit and ingenuity you have in this buines; I know you have wit enough, and I know you love me, o as if you will but make it your tudied buinee, he is not able to defend her elf againt your tratagems.

To be brief, fair Shepherdes, Alindres took upon him the charge of two Letters, and promied that ince it was a buines which he deired with o much paion, auredly either one or both of them hould be read by that cruel hearted woman.

Aphales departed with this aurance; and Alindres in the interim more deirous to keep his promie then perhaps Aphales was; after he had long conulted with himelf upon the matter, he reolved upon this light.

Eritrea, who was a very wie and dicreet Shepherdes, and in ome ort my kinwoman, did make it her particular profeion to love me above all others in the
Town; Alindres who knew very well what good wil this woman bore unto me, and that though he had a very good wit, yet he never imployed it in uch trifles as are commonly ued upon uch occaions, he cat his eye upon her, and deigned to make her give me the firt Letter; and the rather, becaue he had a great familiarity with her long before. He went to ee her therefore, everal times, and talked with her upon every thing, but only that ubject which chiefly brought him to her houe: at lat, he turned and winded his anwers and quetions o, that he made her elf to enquire and ask of Aphales: Ah me (aid he, and eemed as if he had forgot to tell her omthing) my memory it eems is admirable good, for I came hither purpoely upon a buinee which I had quite forgotten, if you had not put me into remembrance of it by naming Aphales. Then he preing him to tel her what it was, he began to whiper as if it were a buinee of confidence and trut, and aid thus unto her; you know Eritrea that I am a ervant unto Aphales, and hould be very orry either to do or ay any thing that might dipleae him: but in this which I would have you to know, I think I do not any thing againt his ervice; nay on the contrary, I am confident that when his Spirit is free from that paion which now poees him, he will thank me as for the bet piece of ervice I could do him: and therefore I beeech you, and conjure you to keep it extreamly ecret, until he be grown wier then now he is. And Eritrea having promied, and worn that he would, I believe (continued the ubtle Alindres) you are not ignorant of the extream affection which he bears unto Doriea, for it is o apparent, that any who have eyes may ee it. Eritrea upon this hrugged her houlders, and eemed to be very orry for it; and then he, continued, God only knows what Lectures I have read unto him about it, and how often I have hinted unto him the inconveniences and orrows that would enue upon it, as wel in relation to Doriea, whom if he love as he ayes he does, he ought to have ome care of her honour and reputation; as alo in relation to the offence it would be unto Dorieas kindred, in which Aphales own Father wil have a hare in repect of the ancient amity that has been betwixt their two Families: but all thee arguments and remontrances were light, and erved to no ue but to make him more cloe and retired from me ever ince, then from any other: and I to content him eem to take no notice of it, but keeps my elf out of his way as much as poibly I can. Now at his departure, he was not contented to peak his mind unto Doriea, for I know he was with her two hours together, before he went; but alo hath writ Letters unto her, and left them in the hands of a Shepherd whom I know very wel, who promied to give them unto her; but this careles and ill advied Shepherd, in lieu of performing his promie. I mean giving them unto Doriea, or burning them, or at the leat keeping them ecret, he left them looly lying upon his table; and yeterday as I went to ee him, upon buines which I had with him, I aw them lying upon the back of his chimney, where trivial Letters ue to be thrown, and God knows who aw them as well as I: Now knowing what affection you had unto Doriea, what relation of kindred there was betwixt you, I thought good to acquaint you, to the end you might ue ome means to get them out of his hands and burn them: for I am confident the dicretion wherewith they were writ was no more then that wherewith they were kept: and I believe that if they could be een, there would be omething found which concerns the reputation of this wie woman who is in no fault.

Eritrea who hearkned very attentively unto this Shepherd, who was more ubtle then her elf: Oh Alindres, (aid he and hoak him by the hand) I am exceedingly obliged unto you for your care of Doriea: he is indeed the bet friend I have, and I dare wear he is innocent in this buines: but all this is nothing unles you tell me more, and help me to get thee Letters out of that Shepherds hands; The Shepherd, aid he, you know very well, his name is Atis, he who has the whole management of Aphales affairs; but I dare not venture to take them: for if ever this lover hould come to know it, he would never pardon the theft. Then pauing a while, he continued: yet I have a Son who has wit enough, and may do it if he will; for being but a boy, les notice will be taken of him then of me; and though he hould be een when he takes them, they would not upect it out of any deign: and if you will, I will et him a work: Eritrea who longed extreamly to have it done,
Oh good Alindres, aid he, let it be done withal expepedition, let ome hould be before you; and I aure you Doriea and I will not be ungrateful: How, aid the crafty Alindres, I beeech you Eritrea, let not me be o much as named in the buines; for if Aphales hould ever come to know it, he would never look upon me again with a good eye: Wel, replied he, I wil not tel her, but wil atisfie the debt my elf. Alindres who had already intructed his Son in the buines, who though young, yet was his Fathers own Son in ubtilty; he ent for him immediately, and in the preence of Eritrea asked him, whether he had o much courage as to take the Letters which lay in the chimney of Atis, o lily as none hould perceive him. Yes, aid he, or any thing you command me: go then, aid the Father, and if you be taken in the fact, be ure you do not ay that I commanded you. Upon this the boy offered to go, but Eritrea called him back, to promie him omething in cae he brought them, purpoely to encourage him the more; but he anwered, no Eritrea, I had rather die then play the theft upon any conideration then the command of my Father: then he eemed to go about his buinee; but his Father having given him one of the Letters before; it was not long before he returned, but yet meaured his time jut according to the ditance of places: Father (aid he, and gave him the Letter) if there had been a dozen more I could have brought them al, but I found only this: and what is become of the other? aid the Father, I know not, anwered the boy, perhaps ome took it away: tel me truly, aid the Father, did you not want courage to take it? If you wil pardon me, aid the boy, I wil tel you truly; and when the promie was made, when I came firt into the chamber, aid he, I found none in it, but as oon as I had taken one Letter, I put it in my hat, and was reaching at the other, one came into the room, took it from me, and threw it into the fire. Eritrea then to excue him, It is no matter my little friend, aid he, ince it is burned, I am as well contented as if you had brought it. Oh Shepherd, aid he, I am infinitely joyed the buines has thriven thus well, and that none has een thee Letters. And becaue Alindres aw he was impatient til he was alone, he bad her adieu, gave her the Letter, and conjured ilence.

Alindres was no ooner out of her houe, but he came to mine; as fortune was, the houe was ful of trangers, who came to ee my Father, and therefore he knew not how to give me this Letter, nor acquaint me with the good office which he had done for me; but I oberved that omthing did diquiet her mind, though could not imagine what it was: at lat, I went to her, and took my opportunity to ask her if he had any news to tell me? I am infinitely deirous, aid he, to talk with you, and it concerns you, that it be as oon as conveniently you can. You may well think (age Shepherdee) that this was enough to well me with curioity. I rid my elf therefore as oon as I could conveniently from all the Company, and carried her into a cloet; and I had no ooner hut the door, but he aid unto me, ah my dear Coen, how careful have I been to recover this paper, out of a place where it could not be any advantage to you; upon this, he gave me the Letter, and aid unto me, here dear Coen, read it, and when you have done, I will tell you the whole tory. I who had never een the hand of Aphales, could not know the character, nor ever had the leat thought of the wager which I had laid with him; and to tell you truly, I never believed that this young Spirit would ever have thought upon it: I opened it therefore, not imagining what it was, and found in it thee words.

div.head: ASPHALES Letter unto DORISSEA.
div.p: IT is Love which made me find out this way, to continue unto you the asurances of my fidelity: you ee it is in vain to trive againt him, ince there is nothing o difficult, but he can urmount it. Be contented then, Fair Doriea, that as by his means I have won our Wager, o by my extream affection, I may change that courage, which makes you inenible of my paions.

I am not able to expree (oh Fair and Wie Shepherdee) my amazement at the reading of this Letter, which by mentioning the Wager, made me know from whence it came. Believe it, my atonihment was extream, and I believe Eritreas was no lee, when imbracing her I cryed out, oh my Coen! what have you done? He who gave this Letter unto you was too ubtle and crafty for us: How? How? (aid he and went back a pace) what ubtilty and craft do you mean? for I protet Coen, I never took more care nor pains in my life, then in getting them out of the hands of thoe who had them; and then not giving me leiure to peak: nay, nay, aid he, I am in very good earnet; aure your elf there was need of craft and ubtilty to get it out of the place where it was; and continuing her Dicoure, he told all the whole tory of what he had done, o freely and innocently, that I could not chue but laugh heartily: at which he began to be half angry, thinking I did her abundance of wrong in not believing her; and becaue I knew that it was out of her good will unto me, Coen (aid I unto her) I am much obliged unto you for the pains which you have taken: but aure your elf, that if I have offended you, Aphales ought to make you atisfaction: for you have helped him to win a Wager which he had laid with me; and then I told her the whole paage, and conequently made her undertand the ubtilty of Alindres; at which he was o urpried, that the poor woman could not ufficiently admire the treachery.

I have told you thee things, Fair and Wie Shepherdee, to let you undertand how Aphales, Thomantes, and Filintes, behaved themelves towards Delphire and me; and upon what grounds we might pretend that they ought not to engage themelves any where ele, and yet, be pleaed to hear what hapned afterwards.

Thomantes, had ingratiated himelf o far into my Companions favour, that his rival had good reaon to think him better looked then upon himelf Yet Delphire, who could not any way approve of thee plenatique paions in Filintes, he would omtimes be jeting and laughing with him. During which time, the ixth day of the month came on; a day as you know, dedicated to the gathering of the Mileto: and by fortune thoe that went to eek it in our Sacred Groves, did find it in that part which was nearet our Town: this was the reaon, that not only we, but all our neighbours came to rejoyce with us, and to congratulate our good fortune: for into what place oever Heaven ent this Sacred Mileto, it brought with it alwayes abundance of properity.

Every one therefore prepared themelves, according to the cutom, to honour the day; and to perform thoe exercies which were intended; as running, wretling, throwing the bar, and hooting: the young Shepherds pruced up themelves in all their gaiety and gallantry: Filintes deiring to be very fine, he begged a favour of Delphire, which he denied with the bet excues he could find: but he, who was bold enough, and thought that the greatet pleaure in love was, as in hunting, to take what one purues by force, he put his hand about the Shepherdees neck, and took out of her head a flower made of ilk, which the Siter of that Shepherd had pinned there. Delphire, who thought it better to let him take it thus before all the company, then in private, after two or three times asking: well, aid he, what the iter gave me, the Brother takes from me, but Filintes went away unto his Siter to get it fatned to his hat; it chanced that Thomantes was there; who knowing the flower, and thinking that Delphire had betowed it upon him with her free conent, he fell into uch a jealouie, that a fever eied upon him, and that in o violent a degree, that it contrained him to keep his bed.

This udden icknee et the age Shepherdee Ericanthe off the humour of any rejoycing, o as the bravery of Filintes was poiled for this time: for Eleaman having the whole authority of the Town, deferred the olemnity: and becaue Ericanthe was deirous that we hould go and viit Thomantes, epecially Delphire, he deired me to go with her: and when we came to his chamber door, we heard him talking very loud: o as being told that he was all alone by himelf, we went as oftly as we could to hear what he aid; and being very near, we heard him make extream complaints, as if he had received ome trange injury, offered unto the fidelity of his Love; and perhaps he had continued longer in his lamentations, if Delphire had
<> (purpoely as I think) made a noie; being unwilling I hould hear any more:
but he kept a great butle at the door, and as if it had been againt her will, oh what a noie do I make (aid he) It is no matter, aid I, eeming to take no notice of it; upon this, opening the door, we entred into the chamber, We found him indeed, in a very bad condition: for beides the violence of his fever, which much perplexed him, we aw his face all tears, which his jealous fancy had fetched from his heart. This ight, though he wiped his eyes as well as he could, might very well move my companion: for I protet it moved me to much pity, not knowing what the matter was, yet doubting that it was againt her that he complained; o as looking upon her, my very eyes invited her to give the Shepherd ome comfort. And he with abundance of modety and dicretion, went to his bed-ide: Alas Thomantes! (aid he unto him) how long mut our orrows lat, in grieving at your icknes? The Shepherd then raiing himelf up, as deirous to thank us for the favour which we did him in the viit. I am but too well in being ick, anwered he, ince uch fair Shepherdees daign to have a care of me. But Thomantes (aid I unto him) if your icknes continue, you will caue mall joy for the Sacred Mileto. Such an unfortunate Shepherd as Thomantes, anwered he, can never hinder the joyes of o many fair Shepherdees, epecially uch as are o free, in their favours, as they care not if all the the world do ee them. Delphire till now never thought that the complaints and icknee of this Shepherd proceeded from the flower which Filintes took from her, and was very glad that he had found it out, to the end he might undeceive him: but not being willing that I hould undertand any thing of this difference, he eemed as if he did not apprehend it, but turned her Dicoure into expreions of Ericanthes orrows for his icknes, and how much all the houe was troubled at it: and afterwards told him, how every one were preparing themelves for the exercies and patimes of the day, and wanted aitants: briefly he told him all that he could to cheer him up, and to undeceive him in the opinion which he was in that he favoured Filintes more then him; yet o cautiouly, that I could not judge that he had any interet in thoe favours he poke of. And becaue I was not ignorant that this Shepherd did love her, and knew how Lovers loved privacy, I walked up and, down the chamber, looking upon every thing in it, and eemed very buie in my own thoughts, and all purpoely to give them the better opportunities of private talk. Delphire, who was very deirous to undeceive him, and to loe no time, let any hould come in to interrupt, he bowed her elf nearer him: Is it poible Thomantes (aid he unto him in a low voice, and with a miling eye) that you hould be jealous? Is it poible Delphire (anwered he) that you hould be o kind unto Filintes as you are? and that I loving you as I do, hould not be as much in your favour as he? Upon this, the Shepherdes could not hold from laughing: Oh Heavens Shepherdee, aid he, do you laugh at my miery? What hopes can I have ever to be happy? Truly (aid he) I do laugh at a thing which you your elf would laugh at with me, if you knew the truth: How? replied he, do you think I can laugh to ee one whom I would have to love me, love another? and that I hould ee Filintes with my own eyes trimm'd up in your favours, and not die with depair? Oh Delphire, if you think o of me, you do more offend me by that thought then by the favour which you have given him: for in your favouring of him more then me, you do only intimate that I hould yeild unto him in happines; but by this thought you do as good as tell me that you have an ill opinion of my love, which is an offence o unjut, as is not to be endured, Thomantes, Thomantes, aid he unto him, never let it trouble you, but et your heart at ret, and be aured that in this I have not offended either againt you, or your love unto me: that which you call a Favour, was a theft, a violent robbery, againt which I could not defend my elf; o many everal witnees are of it, that I need not init upon any farther clearing of my elf; for my chamber was full of Shepherds and Shepherdees; from whom, if you will not believe me, you may know the truth.

Now ince it is thus, as mot truly it is, have I not good reaon to laugh: No, no, Thomantes, as long as you behave your elf towards me as you do, I hall have more regard of your atisfaction then you imagine: and if this were a place fit to chide in, I hould chide you for having o bad an opinion of that good will which I bore unto you: but ince I believe your dipleaure proceeded only from your affection,
I will take it as an argument of that amity which you have promied unto me. Oh Heavens (aid the Shepherd and kied her hand) how near are extream contentments in love, and extream dicontents, unto one another? This Declaration retores that life, which my opinion would have ravihed from me. But dearet Delphire, may I without offence beg one favour from you, whith would compleat my happinee? Tell me what it is, anwered the Shepherdes, and if it be a thing which depends upon me, you hall ee how much I deire your atisfaction. I mot heartily beeech you, aid he, nay I conjure you, even by your elf, which is the dearet thing in the world unto me, that you would get back this flower, for I am not able to ee it in the hands of this raviher, without a mot trange alteration, I promie you Thomantes, anwered he, that as well for your atisfaction as my own, I will do all I can, and you hall know it.

She left him with this aurance, for many Shepherds and Shepherdees came in and hindred them from farther Dicoure. This viit had a better operation upon this Lover, then all the Phyick which hould have been given unto him: for the next morning, he left his icknes in his bed, and found himelf in perfect health.

But Delphire not forgetting the Shepherds requet, he no ooner aw Filintes, but he ued her bet rethorique to procure the flower, pretending that he would keep it for her ake who gave it: Filintes, who did not repent of the robbery which he had committed, Do you think Delphire (aid he) that I value this which I have got by lawful war, no more, then to part from it without a ranom; what ranom aid he, do you require? Some of thoe knots, anwered he, or thoe ribands which you wear. I have none to give you, anwered he; nor I any to retore, anwered he, but am very orry that I rob'd you of no more: what more, aid he, would you have taken? Your heart, anwered he: as for that piece of thievery, anwered he, I hould never have required retitution; but the flower which you have is much better, and I wonder you hould have any atisfaction in retaining any thing againt ones will. What? (aid Filintes) is it againt your will that I wear it? Me thinks, anwered he, my deires of having it again hould intimate as much; Then he deired me to lend him a pair of Siers; which I did, not knowing what he would do with them; and then he took off his hat, and cut the flower in a hundred pieces, and threw them into the fire: then (aid he unto me) Here take your Siers, and I thank you, for they have helped to revenge me againt the dipleaure which was conceived againt me: then he roe up in an angry mood, and it was a long time before he would peak unto her; but it was excellent port to ee them together: for he could not forbear from being where he was, and often twit her in a plenatique way, till addreing his peech to a third peron; and Delphire paid him back again in the ame coyn, with o much delight to all that heard them; that whenoever they two were together, every one flocked unto them to hear the quirks which they put upon each other.

This divorce lated until the day when the Mileto was to be gathered: and that day he came unto her very early, Delphire (aid he unto her) is the heat of your choler now pat? My choler, anwered he, never began againt you, but perhaps you mean your own. It may be o, replied he and miled, for ince I have nothing but what is yours, my anger is yours. If you mean it o, aid Delphire, I fear you do mi-reckon your elf, for I know not who can make any thing mine, unlee I will. Delphire, replied he, there are ome things which we have by force: Is it not commonly aid, uch a one has a fever; uch a one has the hatred of every one; and uch a one has abundance of miery, and yet I am confident they would not have them: would you have me, replied Delphire, to have your anger in that way? Not only my anger, aid he, but alo my oul, my heart, my affection, and my all: but Filintes, anwered Delphire, take heed you do not draw a concluion from hence, which will put you into your plenatique mood again. What can you alledge, aid he, which can give me any uch occaion? God defend me, replied the Shepherdee from the thought of it; but if you will give me leave, I will tell you, that uch things as are forced upon one, do alo make one trive with all their power to be rid of them; o as if that which I have of yours be of this quality, conider with your elf what concluion may be drawn from thence. Oh mot cruel and didainful
Shepherdes, aid he, can you vent nothing but arguments of your corn and ill affection of me? I was in hopes this morning to have obtained a favour from you, that I might have flourihed in it under the notion of your Shepherd, but now I find my hopes are all blated, and that you corn and light me more then ever. You are mitaken Shepherd, aid Delphire, I never corned any thing that had relation unto you; no, I do honour both you and your family: but I was forced to anwer unto your aertions which you ued unto me. I hall quickly know, replied he, whether you peak truth; for if you do not corn, I hould be known this day as your Shepherd; pray give me that knot which is upon your head, in tetimony of your good will. I am afraid, aid he, let you hould cut it in pieces, as you did the flower which you took from me. Perhaps it might run the ame fortune (aid he) if you would take it away from me. You need not doubt, replied he, but if you hould ravih it from me, as you did the flower, I hould do the ame. What would you think, replied Filintes, if I hould not let you ret all this day, until I have that knot? Upon this, he put forth his hand to take it; but the Shepherdes being aware of him, recoyled, and went unto Ericanthe; but till he followed her, and importun'd her for this knot. No, no, Filintes, (aid Delphire) you hall not have it, unles Ericanthe command me. I will not receive it, replied he, upon Ericanthes command: no, no, ungrateful Delphire, deceive not your elf, I deire no favours from you, but uch as proceed from your free and good will: I would have them to be gifts of Love, and not tributes of obedience; upon this, he went away in a fretting fume. And fortune was o avere unto him all that day, as he received no contentment from any thing he took in hand.

On the contrary, Thomantes, continuing his courthip of this Shepherdes, without the leat complaint or murmure; every action about this proud Beauty, made Filintes jealous, who eeing him o patient, and judging of things according to his own humour, he could not imagine any one hould endure the cruelties of her whom he loved with o much ilence, unles he was tyed unto it by ome great obligation; o as he concluded very advantagiouly for his rival. This opinion did torment him o extreamly, that one day when he was almot out of his wits, he went unto the Shepherdes; and though it was long ince he had poke unto her, yet at the very firt ight he accoted her with this language: reolve with your elf to ee one of thee three things come preently to pae. For either I mut change, or you mut change, or I mut die. The Shepherdes returned him this faint anwer: for me to change, is a thing impoible; that you hould die, would grieve me; and for you to change, is of les importance unto me, and depends wholly upon your own will. Oh Heavens (cryed he out) is all this cruelty to be endured? and yet I mut love this inenible woman. Upon this, he pulled his hat over his eyes, and went away, more tranported with choller then ever he was: But as his Spirit was quickly hot, o it was quickly cool for when he was in his greatet fury, if Delphire did but peak one word unto him, he was appeaed, and eemed as if he had no memory of thoe offences and wrongs at which he was angry.

All things thus far went well with Thomantes, o as he might well think himelf one of the happiet Shepherds about Lignon; and I believe Aphales might have aid as much, had he not been abent, for he could not have een any Shepherd o much in my favour as himelf: but ince that jealouies, and by conequence inquietudes have o ravelled their ouls, as I believe they enjoy but a little ret, and we but a little more: Thus, Wie Shepherdes, this is the caue which has brought us hither before you, according to the anwer of the Oracle.

Aphales, as I told you, before was abent; and Thomantes was contrained almot by the ame detiny to be abent from Delphire, and alo to go into the ame Province of the Romans, where Aphales was already. Perhaps I hould be too tedious in relating all the Dicoure of this Shepherd, and all his laments a little before his departure: but o it was, that he gave unto this Shepherdes of poible aurances of a contant, and lating affection; his expreions came from him with uch an emphais, as if his heart had been in his tongue, and thoe that would not believe them, had been as incredulous, as that fale Shepherd who uttered them was perfidious, and who afterwards was quite wafted away with incontancy.

He departed with the prayers and orrows of all that he left behind him. And becaue Eleaman the Wie Pator would needs out of his affection ee him take hore, and was not ignorant of the good will which his Son bore unto this Shepherdee, when he aw him a little gone, he turned towards her, and in a jeting manner aid, he is gone, and none of thee fair Maids lament him: and becaue as he poke thoe words, he had his eyes upon Delphire, he miled; which was oberved by many, and afterwards when Filintes returned, for he accompanied Thomantes a little way, and was told of this: Oh mot cruel, hard-harted, and inenible woman, aid he, can Heaven uffer o much injutice? Does all the ervices which Thomantes has rendred unto you, merit no more then to laugh at him when he goes away, and when he goes away with o much orrow to part from you? But the bet conceipt was, he was really offended at the injury which he thought he had done unto his rival. And to ee the humour of this young Shepherd: as long as Thomantes was abent, there was not a day wherein he did not put Delphire in memory of him. And at any time when he did her any trivial ervice; I wih, aid he, that this were put upon the core of Thomantes. But that which is hardly credible, is, when Thomantes was preent, Filintes vexed himelf, and fainted at every illable which Delphire uttered: but when he was abent, he took all well, and was as patient, as if nothing could move him.

Thomantes who was abent, and longed to hear how Delphire did, was preently acquainted how Filintes was changed in his humour. This news began to gripe him a little at the heart: and as fortune would have it, he and Aphales meeting in a trange Country, they contracted (as it is uual) a more intimate familiarity then ever they had before: o as always one of them was receiving news how quares went at home. As ill luck was, thoe who writ unto Aphales did end him omtimes uch news concerning Delphire, as they fancied: and thoe who gave intelligence unto Thomantes, did write of me according to their opinions, not knowing what great familiarity there was betwixt them. They who took all for truths, and did believe what was written. Unto Aphales was written, that Filintes had o gained the heart of Delphire, as now there was no room for Thomantes. And unto Thomantes they ent word, that ince his departure, Androgenes was o in love with me, as that I had no eyes but to look upon him; o as thee two poor Shepherds, when perhaps they had mot caue to be contented, they thought they had mot caue to complain againt us. They counelled and conulted together; and I am ure not without omtimes talking of our changing humours. In concluion, both of them having hated, or rather hudled up their buines, that they might the ooner look homeward, we heard of their return: Ericanthe expected her Son with uch impatiency, that he went as far as the Town of Boen to meet him: Delphire that day was not well, and therefore intended not to tir out of her chamber. Filintes not being able to endure that Thomantes hould receive uch a dipleaure, he came to pray and beeech her by all means, that he would keep Ericanthe company upon this occaion, which he aured her would be very well taken, and that for his part he would take it for a very particular obligation; and was o very importunate in his deires, and upplications, as at lat, he obtained that which none ele could: But when Thomantes heard from Delphire her elf, that the favour which he received was by the interceion of Filintes, he grew extreamly jealous at it: and upon this reaon, he et himelf ever ince to oberve and watch the actions of Filintes and Delphire more narrowly. And o much the rather, becaue his rival was grown very familiar with all the Shepherdees, which tung Thomantes to the heart; for he could not imagine that this familiarity could proceed from any thing but Love, and not out of habitude: yet at the firt he eemed to take no notice, but diembled his paion as dicreetly as poibly he could.

Aphales alo, whoe head was full of that news which was written unto Thomantes, concerning the affection between Androgenes and me, he alo made a fair hew, and et himelf to be a py over our actions, out of which he drew no conequences to my advantage. I know not how it came to pas: but I being at that time in Ericanthes chamber, where there was a great number of Shepherds and Shepherdees, Androgenes deired to talk with me, as it is uual at uch aemblies, for every one to
addres themelves unto uch as they have familiarity withall, rather then unto trangers: but becaue I took notice that Aphales oberved us, being unwilling to give him any occaion of dicontent, I turned another way, and would not peak unto him; and ee how one is omtimes deceived in their deign: this action being oberved by Aphales, it made him upect all that he aw not, and think that all was true which had been written concerning Androgenes and me: and the wort was; Androgenes oberving how I declined peaking unto him in conideration of Aphales, he never ought for any opportunity of peaking unto me during all that Aembly; but there being a great Looking-glae upon the table, which was fixed to the wall, this dicreet Shepherd did cat his eyes into it; and as fortune was, I looked into it at the ame time: Androgenes hrugged his houlders, as if he complained of my behaviour to him, and I not utterly to dioblige him, did wink upon him with one eye, which perhaps was ome contentment to him: but I protet, it was only out of deire to hide the odd humour of Aphales: but as ill uck would have it; he took notice of all thee igns, and uppoing thereby that there was ome cloe correpondency betwixt us, he was o netled, that he went out of the houe, and was not een all night.

Perhaps you will think it trange, dicreet Shepherdes, that Thomantes and Aphales, who at their departures had uch mall hares in our good will, hould at their returns pretend o abolutely unto them: but you mut know, that they obtained our affections during their abence, more then whilt they were continually with us; for when they were amongt us, and erved us, we uppoed they did it becaue they aw no greater beauties then our elves: but when we heard that after they had een the world, and in it many beauties uperior unto ours, and yet kept themelves contant unto us, we eteemed their affections at a higher rate, o as by our Letters to them, they knew that their abence obtained that which their preence had denied them.

This was the reaon that the leat favour which we hewed unto others, eeming unto them a taking away their dues, they could not endure we hould o much as look upon any but them. If we chanced to cat the leat glance of an eye upon any one, then thee Shepherds; or rather thee Tyrants, were ready to flye in our faces, and would oblige us to uch a contraint as was intollerable: but becaue Delphire and I did not like to be banihed from all the world, we continued our converation, not only with Filintes and Androgenes, but alo with any others that addreed themelves unto us; the number of which was not mall; and behaved our elves towards them as was fitting, let we hould give occaion unto any of peaking ill of us; which they did take o ill, that after they had called a counel amongt them two, as if they were to govern and direct us, they reolved to put a face of coldnes, and afterwards to eem as if they loved ome others. But not knowing whom to chue for uch a buines, they would only eem to tand as Neuters and be indifferent; and for a concluion, they came at lat unto down right incivility, for o may their behaviours unto us be termed, ince they did not only leave off addrees and courting us as they were wont; but when they met us at any time in Ericanthes chamber, or any where ele, they would not o much as look upon us. If at any time we found them in a place where it was impoible for them to turn away their eyes from us, it was with o much corn, and they rendred their alutes in uch a didainful manner, as was not civil.

This trange way of behaviour and proceeding, caued every one to take notice of it, and almot all that heard of it, did tax them with incontancy and levity: but they on the contrary, maintained that they were the ame they were always wont to be, that they had not changed, but loved us and honoured us, as much as ever they did; that it was buines which they were contrained to follow, concerning the etate which belonged to their family, which did divert them, and hinder them from imploying all their time in thoe trivial ervices which they were wont to render. Delphire and I mut confes, oh age Diana, that after we had everal times talked together, (for our fortunes were the ame, and required the ame remedies) we reolved, to take all manner of excues from thee two wavering minds, by retiring our elves from all thoe who might give them the leat umbrage; and to do it the more handomly, we took this occaion.

Eleaman and Ericanthe took great delight in eeing Comedies acted by thoe in their own houe: and Delphire, as he that had the bet wit, had commonly one of the bet parts: It hapned that Delphire in the play was to tell a Shepherd that he was never to hope for any thing in her affection: by chance he pied Filintes very near the Theater harkning and admiring her action; and conceiving him to be the greatet caue of jealouie in Thomantes, when he was to peak unto the Shepherd in the Comedy, he turned her elf directly to Filintes, and as if he had hore a part in the play, and aid thus unto him; I do wear unto thee Shepherd, that I can and will ooner die a hundred deaths, then love thee: ceae all thy hopes, trouble me no more with thy love, for Shepherd I do hate thee.

The face of Delphire being turned towards Filintes, and her eyes and getures addreed unto him, was a caue, that not only the poor Shepherd knew her meaning, but alo Thomantes, and almot all the Spectators, which caued all eyes to be cat upon him, who durt not before all that company let his anger appear.

A few dayes after, when we were upon the banks of the Chrital River of Lignon, and as we were paing away the time upon the Sands by the River ide; Aphales, Androgenes, and many other Shepherds and Shepherdees, were all about me: and I writ upon the Sand, I LOVE: Androgenes looking over my houlder, and eeing what I had writ upon the Sand, is it I (aid he, and miled) for whom you writ that word? Yes, anwered I, and I oberved that Aphales blushed when I poke that word: but do you undertand, continued I, what it ignifies? I do undertand the word, anwered he, perhaps not the meaning of the writer, anwered I, for I mean that the Love which I bear unto you, is like the writing which you ee, (and trod upon it with my foot) and which you hall never ee again. Aphales, and all that heard me, fell into uch extream laughter, which perhaps urpried Androgenes, as much as what I aid unto him.

One would think, age Shepherdees, that thee two actions of Delphire and me, hould have contented thee two tubborn Lovers, if at the leat, this term Lovers, be not too good for them; but on the contrary, they till continued their high humours, and whenoever they came into company, they preently began to ing their invective ongs againt us, upbraiding us with incontancy.

Now, age Shepherdes, we both of us reolved to have no more to do with them, but become as very trangers, as if we had never een them; & to the end none hould think we cat them off by reaon of any new affections, we retired our elves at the ame time from all manner of converation, not upon a udden, let it hould be thought trange: but ee, fair and Wie Shepherdes, how thoe who upbraided us with incontancy, are incontant themelves; we had not lived above two months in this cold retraint, but as if our Ice, by a contrary operation had re-kindled fire in their ouls, they come and cat themelves at our feet with all manner of ubmiion and prayers; but I know not whether I hould ay, with the ame importunities they ued before. Filintes, and Androgenes, were the firt who oppoed them at their return; aying, that their incontancy was too great and gros, ever to be entertained or endured; and that if uch Weather-cock minds were not punihed by ome eminent corrections, there would be no faith or loyalty amongt Shepherds. We whoe humours were well enough dipoed never to entertain them again, did eaily conent unto the opinion of Filintes, and Androgenes. And in this reolution, as oft as Aphales and Thomantes came to us, we laid their incontancy before them; and they on the contrary, to hew that no caue is o bad but will find ome maintainers, they ued all the arguments and reaons they could, to jutifie themelves, affirming that they were not incontant, and asked what incontancy was, and within what terms and limits it was confined, when it was made a rule, or rather a Law, and then maintained that they did never break that Law. This dipute went o far, that in the end, being wearied with their importunate prayers, we all reolved together to addree our elf unto the Oracle for a deciion of the controverie; by whoe anwer we were ent unto you, fair and Wie Shepherdes; from whom we wait for a jut judgment, to deliver us all from burthens, that are too heavy to be endured.

Doriea thus ended her Dicoure, and after an humble reverence, he returned unto her place, to vvait for vvhat the Shepherdes Diana vvould ordain; vvho after
he had asked the opinion of Alexis, Atrea, Phillis, Sylvander, and ome others, he ordained, that Thomantes and Aphales hould deliver their reaons, by vvhich they vvould maintain, that they vvere not incontant, and Thomantes poke thus, in behalf of them both.

div.head: The Speech of THOMANTES.
