div.p: WE do ee, and know very vvell, oh mot jut Judge! that it vvas upon great reaon you ordained Aphales and me to deliver unto you thoe reaons by which we may clear our innocency, and wipe off thoe aperions, which the malice of our accuers had cat upon us; for otherwie it is impoible any humane undertanding hould come to the knowledge of the truth, which is now put into doubt: the artifice of thoe who have done the wrong is great, and they have o gilded over rotten reaons with flourihing arguments of eloquence, as it is a very hard matter to ee the imple and pure face of truth, but by the oppoitions and anwers of thoe that are oppreed.

We do ee, and know alo very well, that we who have hitherto made it our whole buines, profeion, and tudy, to love well, and not to peak well, are by the rigour of thoe whom we have erved, driven to defend our elves by words. It is a very hard matter for us to peak well, that which we have o perfectly and o religiouly oberved; in as much as none ought to meddle in that mitery and trade which they have not learned, and of which they have not made profeion: and, oh our jut Judge, is it not very hard, that we who have made it our whole profeion to love well, and not to peak well, hould now be driven to that which is not our profeion, and to ue words to verifie our actions, to which we referred all our eloquence and rethorique. This conideration makes us extreamly doubt the iue of this enterprie, knowing very well, that we have to do with perons, who quite contrary unto us, have more tudied to peak well without loving, then love well without peaking: now all the arms which we are to ue, are only words, which being their own, and in which they are exercied and skilful, mot certainly they know better how to ue them then we; and therefore have a very great advantage of us, unles our jut Judge by her prudence, and oundnes of judgment, do balance the incerity of our naked reaons, againt the gilded gloes, and well peaking of our adveraries: and upon this confidence, we take the boldnes to preent our reaons plainly unto you, and as briefly as poibly we can.

But when all is well conidered, what kind of accuations, (oh my friend Aphales) are thoe which they charge upon us? Had they blamed us for loving too much; had they accued us of being tranported with too much violent affection: had they aid that, we go beyond the limits of Love; had they complained that the excee of our paion makes us troubleome, or inupportable in our continual addrees, thee accuations, might perhaps have had ome hadow of likelyhood; and we hould have found a hard task to dicharge our elves of uch objections. But that they hould accue us that we hould not Love thoe whom none can look upon, without adoration! Is not this, to mock us, and thoe (if I may ay o) that hear them? Can they ay Aphales does not love, whoe affection urmounted o long an abence? If abence be called the Death of Love, what hould one ay of that Love which is not dead after o long an abence, but that certainly it is immortal? Immortal then is the love of Aphales unto Doriea; Immortal is that of Thomantes unto the fair Delphire, who have not only reited abence, but alo the rigours of that fair one, which perhaps had been inupportable unto any other: length of time, which they ay ruins and rots the mot lating thing, never hook his contancy; no nor any monters of difficulties which he met with, nay even impoibilities, were not able to top him in his deigned coure: Oh Gods! who does not know that Thomantes hath loved the fair Delphire even in her Cradle? at an age when he was not capable (if I may ay o) of knowing either to love, or caue love? And can it be imagined that Thomantes hould now fall off, and not love her, when her eyes enflames all that they daign to look upon, and cat their rayes on? Who can have een
this Thomantes overcome all the rigours and corns of Delphire; abide the length of time; urmount all difficulties, and believe that the ame Thomantes hould not love her, when this fair Monter of Beauty eemed pliable to his will and deires? Truly thee accuations are as far from any common ence, as they are from reaon and truth; and there is no other anwer to be given unto them, but this, that there is no diputing againt thoe that will deny principles: and no more ought I againt thoe perons who make thee oppoitions, who yet do fill Heaven and Earth with their complaints againt us, and will by force have us confes that we do not love them.

They will needs take upon them to know what we do, better then we our elves: Love is an act of the will; and is there any o clear ighted, as can ee my will better then my elf? But as humane nature is more apt to believe the bad then the good, o hould we but once tell Delphire and Doriea, that we do not love them, oh how preently would they believe us? But if we hould tell them, and tell them again, a thouand and a thouand times that we do infinitely love them, they would preently ay it was not true. Why hould you not believe us in the one as well as in the other? But we (and it is no mall argument of that love which you deny to be in us) if you once tell us that you do love us, we preently believe it, and never make the leat doubt of the truth; and from whence proceeds this eaie faith and belief? Even from love; from love I ay, which makes us believe, that truth as well as all other virtues is in the peron loved, o conequently in you. But thee fair ones would never confes that we loved them, but alwayes denied it, and now they tax us with incontancy. This lat injury (my dear Aphales) is an argument for us, for from their own opinion mut be concluded, that we do love them now; for they confes that we did not love them heretofore, and by aying that we are incontant, they ay, that we do love now: in this ence, fair Shepherdees, we hould agree with you, were it not that Love (who forced this truth from your own mouths againt your wills) will not let us confes, that we did not love you before: but on the contrary, we do ay, and maintain, that we did love you, and do love you, and ever hall love you: and that never was affection more perfect then the affection of Aphales and Thomantes.

Now the main argument they have againt our affection, is, that our actions have not given ufficient tetimonies, that we love them: Conider, (oh mot jut Judge) conider I beeech you, upon what a andy foundation this charge is built, and how quickly it will fall to the ground: when our actions and behaviours to them were all fire, and full of impatiencies, then they charged us that we did not love them; when we aw this way would not prevail, nor perwade them to believe the truth of our affections, we had recoure unto the contrary: we put on a garb of coldnes, and became all patience; but they forgetting the judgment they had before given, do now accue us of want of love more harply then before. What hould we do, if to our mi-fortune two contraries do work the ame effect upon their unjut ouls: if neither heat nor cold will tetifie our Love, what can we do? Yet thee coniderations, or rather contradictions, do put us unto abundance of pains: not that they who do ee and weigh every thing with a ound judgment, can ever enter into any doubt of us: but ince there are more of thoe who are inclined to judge ill of others, then of thoe who hold an even cale of judgment, it mut enue, that the greater part of men will blame us: and which is wort of all, or which is indeed inupportable, thee fair ones may nourih a tiniter opinion of us in their ouls, although we never courted any thing with more deires, then to perwade them of the contrary: and therefore though we know very well that we ought in all other things to yeild unto them; yet in this, we are contrained to contradict them, and bring the matter unto the judgment of another; which we would not have to be taken as any defect of love or repect, but rather for exces, and height of affection, which tranports us beyond all rules of duty. In this excee, we have everal times deired, that ince they do charge us with incontancy, they would firt agree that heretofore we did love them, and afterwards that they would precribe unto us thoe limits in which a Lover ought to keep himelf within compas of this contancy, to the end one may judge, as by a traight rule, whether the line be right, and come no neerer one ide then another; and o, oh our jut Judge, it may appear whether we be incontant or no. The Gods
are they who have ent us unto you; and the Gods are they will inpire you with a pirit of right judgment. But in the mean time we do require and conjure the God of Love, to take away all incredulity out of the ouls of thee fair ones, which makes them condemn our actions, which truly if they were different from what they were wont to be, it was not out of any alteration of will, but urgent affairs which was the caue, and which hindred us from paying the tribute of thoe trivial ervices we were wont to render, and in which we could not imploy our time without much prejudice unto our etates. Has not all eaons their proper actions; does not nature teach us, that flowers are proper for the pring, and fruits for ummer; if trees hould bloom all the year, they would bloom in vain; and why hould not the ame be aid of us? If we hould be alwayes bearing thoe little flowers, which are proper and natural at the beginning of Love, we hould not produce o much fruit in the ummer of Love, but hould in a manner derogate from the Law of Nature. But perhaps, that which induceth them to this opinion, is the more familiar converation which we have with others, then we were wont to have; and that this converation proceeds from ome Love we bear unto thoe we are familiar with all: truly if a Lover ought to be a alvage peron, and without communication, I mut confes, they have reaon; but ince the name of Lover does not ignifie any Wilde Man, or Wolf, or Tyger, or Barbarian, we ee no reaon or ground they have for their opinions.

All thee doubts, and all thee judgements which they have conceived of our affections, mut receive a deciion from you, age Shepherdes; we mean thoe doubts and judgments which they have in di-advantage of our affection: for of all other things whereof they blame and accue us, as we are Aphales and Thomantes, we dare not o much as whiper the leat complaint againt them; but will with all reverence and repect uffer what they pleae: but when they accue us as we are Lovers, then we are forced to open our mouths, not to accue or complain againt them, but to igh, as thoe do whom exceive pain torments above their trength: otherwie we could ay; that when they charge us with incontancy, they themelves are the caue of our change, and hould eek out for ome reaons to excue it: and hould urge that o many ervices paid and received, did not deerve, that Filintes, during the abence of Thomantes, hould be entertained in his place; nor Androgenes in the room of Aphales: that the favours which both thoe received during our abence, would afford us ample matter and caue to accue them: that the news which was writ unto us from all ides, was enough to make us believe it. And becaue they ay that a woman neither can nor ought to hinder any from loving them; o it be with all requiite dicretion, repect and honour: we ask your judgment, oh our mot jut Judge, upon thee four quetions; firt, whether he who permits many to love and erve her, do keep her elf within compas of the Laws of Contancy? Secondly, if this plurality of Lovers be allowed unto women, whether may it not be as well allowed unto men? Thirdly, whether the Laws of Contancy do ordain that a Lover hould flye the ight of all other Shepherdees? And latly, what are the terms and limits of this Contancy, o much talked of by all, and o little known unto any: and all this, to the end that thee fair Shepherdees may know whether or no we be true and faithful Lovers, and not be offended, if our affections cannot endure uch injuries hould be offered unto them. In all thee things, oh mot jut Judge, we deire and expect your judgement.
Thus ended Thomantes; and after he had made an humble reverence, Diana appointed Delphire to anwer unto what Thomantes had aid, if he had any exceptions againt it; then Delphire began thus.

div.head: The anwer of Delphire unto Thomantes.
div.p:
WE think it not trange (fair and dicreet Shepherdes) to hear uch abundance of windy words, from the mouth of Thomantes, as vvell in his own behalf, as in that of Aphales: for he that does love truly, cannot peak vvhat he reents; and it eems by the rule of contraries, that he vvho loves
but a little, will never be weary of talking: doe but oberve with what a torrent of words he argues, not with reaons, but with di-reaons, if I may coyn the word. And though upon the ame conideration (I mean, becaue Doriea, and I, do not love) I could with the ame fluency of tongue make a long oppoition of their arguments, yet I will not, as well becaue that were to abue the patience of our Judg, and all that hear me; as becaue all their arguments are grounded upon uch imple foundations, and gloed over with uch thin covers, as the fality of them are eaily een: and truly een o clearly, that I hould not think them worth an anwer, were it not in obedience unto the command of our jut Judge.

To begin then, What do you mean Thomantes, by all this talk of your affection? You who ayes you are accutomed to Love without peaking, as we are to peaking without love? What do you mean, I ay, ince you do confes that if Doriea and I do but ay once that we love you, you will believe us for ever? Ah Shepherd, ince we have been o accutomed to peaking, what do you complain of? Why are you not both atisfied? To what purpoe did you make addrees to the Oracle, and trouble this Aembly with o many words, ince we have been o accutomed to peaking it? But, oh jut Judge, I perceive the trength and ubtilty of his argument; he dares not directly ay, that we are accutomed to peaking it; but only, that we are accutomed, as much to ay that we love, and yet do not love, as they are to love, and yet not peaking it; and becaue that they have not been accutomed to love, it conequently follows that neither have we been accutomed to peaking it: and in this ence they are in the right; for it is very hard to peak of a thing which they do not know, witnes all the dicoure of Thomantes, in which there are not more words then contradictions. But to give them ome atisfaction, let us confee that they cannot peak well upon this ubject, becaue if they loved heretofore, as they ay they did, they loved without peaking it, and that now they do not love, they are yet contrained to peak: well, we will allow this; and now Thomantes and Aphales, are you contented? You may be, at leat ince you are allowed what you ask; but what's all this to our difference? Nothing at all; nor is it any proof that they do love us: for it might perhaps be available, if men, I mean men of their age, did guide themelves by reaon, then one might infer from hence omthing of what they ay: but for them, who do all things at hazard, out of humours, and nothing according to the right rules of reaon, what can one infer from hence, but that then their humour was uch and now is quite different? But, ay they, why hould they then take o much paines? To which we anwer, who can find the reaon of that which has no reaon? I ay, it was either out of obtinacy, or to deceive, or out of ambition of the name of a Lover without any effects, or out of ome wore, or more pernitious deigne. What reaon can be expected from perons that are unreaonable? But (ay they) we do know, that we do love: is there any that knows our own wills and minds better then our elves? Oh mot, jut Judge, there is no quetion but others may know them better; can any judge aright whoe Spirits are prepoeed with paion? What likelyhood is there that thee Shepherds can give any ound judgement upon a thing that concerns themelves. But we who are without paion, and are unconcerned in any thing which concerns them, we judge oundly. As for example; cannot thoe that ee Adrates, better judge of his madnes then himelf? And to hew that they <> know what they would have, nor what they do; do they not wih and unw ••• the very ame things, in one minute? O Gods! (cry they out) that humane nature hould be apter to believe the bad ooner then the good: certainly they mean, the natures of men, and particularly of Thomantes and Aphales: as for our parts, we neither believe nor unbelieve, but what is fit o to be; and to hew that it is o, we do confee unto you, that if you tell us you do not love us, we do believe it; for commonly every one believes what they deire. Moreover we do know by experience, that you cannot love: when you tell us that you do love us, we do not believe it, becaue we know all men are lyers, which is a mitery in Love which we are ignorant in, and cannot do it. But all your actions do belie your words. And when you tell us any thing to your own advantage, we give no credit thereunto, for we know that you ue to flatter your elves: when it is to your diadvantage, we do believe it, knowing very well that then it is true: and therefore you may ee that
our belief is grounded upon reaon, and that which you ay of u • is untrue.

But, oh jut Judge, here is a fine piece of otentation: the Love, ay they, which is in us, does make us believe, that you peak true: and Thomantes, if you believe o, why are you not aured that I do not love Filintes, nor Doriea, Androgenes, ince we have o often told you o? But to relate all their contradictions would be too tedious; I will briefly anwer unto thoe objections which have weight in them; it mut needs be (aid they) that if we did not love you heretofore, and now you call us incontant, you do as much as ay, that we do love you: Shepherds, without etting our thoughts, either of love or hatred, we called you incontants; as much to ay that you had changed your lives; and in that your incontancy is indubitable: and that which we do charge you withal, you do not deny before all this Aembly, o as we are not obliged to prove a thing which is not put in doubt; and you never needed to excue the change with that hallow argument which you alledged, that having ued all actions of fire, and finding we did not believe them to be parks of Love, you had recoure unto actions of Ice; for beides that this argument is mot ridiculous, there is no neceity of alledging it, ince you do know very well in your own ouls, that all thee flames and fires whereof you peak, are meerly imaginary, and only to glos over your Dicoure. And it is no wonder at all that we hould not believe them, ince they are but only flourihes, and eeming as if you did love us. And is there any doubt of it, ince for all your Ice and cold fits, you have made addrees, and courted others before our faces. Is not the voice of the people, the voice of God? Would you have us give our own eyes, and our own ears, the lye, and not believe when every one ayes it, and when we ee it by your actions? We never courted any (ay they) but only out of a deire to perwade them: ah Shepherd, you have confeed the truth without a rack; it is very true Shepherd, you did never court any, but to perwade us that you did love us; but it was to perwade only, and not to love us: Alas we knew this ambition in you long ince, and if we did not, yet now we do; and it is better to be late wie then never.

But what a mot delicate excue they have to cover their changing? If our actions and behaviours (ay they) were different from what they were wont to be, it was becaue multitude of buines and urgent occaions did divert us: Then Thomantes, if you any time came unto me, it eems it was only becaue you had nothing ele to do, and know not how to trifle away your time any where ele: oh how much am I beholding to you? Am I not infinitely indebted, and can never come off without ome great recompence? But, mot jut Judge, I beeech you look upon thee Fathers of great families, who have the whole charge of all the etate and houe upon their houlders? How? their houe? Nay of all the communaltie, or rather of the whole Republique of the Gaules: oh Heavens! how great are their imployments? And what a in it were againt the publique good to diturb them, or make them loe one minute of time? Indeed, you Fathers of families without children, and Senators without any buines, we do agree with you, that you could not imploy the time which you pent in thoe trivial courthips, as you call them ince thoe munits were o pretious, and ueful to the publique, better then you did; but did you not imploy that time with us which you pent in the particular converations, and familiarities which you had with other Shepherdees? Why did you come to us when you had nothing ele to do? Why hould we receive you when all other company excluded you? For had it not been o, we hould never have een you. If you be o full of buines, let Love alone: for Love is a Deity o great, that it is an injury unto him to offer that time unto him which remains after the ervice of the other Gods: he requires the firt offerings and the bet of things, and if any remain, then offer unto the other Dieties: do you think he will be contented with the refue and dregs of devotion? And out of this Dicoure you may gather Thomantes, that it is true, as to others, every eaon has its proper actions, but not to Love; for in Loves Garden, Trees do Bloom and bear fruit all at once. Do you not ee, that Love makes the young, as wie as the old; and old ones as very fools as the young? You may ee that there is no ditinction of ages with him, but all of an age; did you never oberve that the mot tender Flowers of Love, are mot weet fruits? For what are hopes but flowers, and hopes excel all other contentments, which one can have out of Loves
Garden. Oh Thomantes! ignorant in Love Thomantes; know that the Fruits of Love are Flowers, and his Flowers, Fruits: for there is alwayes contentment in hopes, and hopes are renewed by contentments; and therefore it is that the Orange-tree is given for an Embleme of Love, becaue it bears his fruit and his flower together.

You ee mot jut Judge, how little thee prtended Lovers do know what Love is; and they have good reaon to deire you would let them undertand what contancy is; for being o ignorant in Love, it is no wonder they hould be alo ignorant in it; andyet, as ignorant as they are, they will maintain that they forooth, have oberved all the Laws of Contancy to a tittle, though if they be contant, it is by chance and hazard, not out of any reolution or deign. But if they were convented before the evere Throne of Love, and were asked who gave them permiion to call themelves Lovers, and aume unto themelves a title o honourable, not knowing the leat duties of a right Lover, what could they expect but a mot evere punihment for uurping a name o much above their merit?

Now as it is ordinary for thoe that are guilty of any vice, to deire that all others may be of the ame die, to the end they themelves may not be upbraided, they propound four doubts, ayming by the firt, to tax us; by the econd to excue themelves; and by the two lat, to be intructed in what they are very ignorant. We hould return them uch an anwer, as they deerve, were it not unto you, our Judg, that they addres their queries, and in which we beeech you, to inform them; not out of any hopes to amend them for the future, but to let every one ee, how far they are out of the right way. And in as much as a great blunder is made about ome letters which were written unto them, we beeech you, oh our Judge, to command that thoe Letters may be produced; for by their own confeion they were written only upon common fame, and not as known truths: what then? mut every thing, that is taken up in the treets be believed as true? Oh Thomantes! if uch reports may pas for truths, I could tell you trange tales of your new affections, unto everal other Shepherdees; but being only common fame, I let them pas without belief; and was not this example ufficient for you to do the like. And whereas you ay that one ought to think nothing but virtue to be in the peron loved; can I think that you do love me, ince you do thus upbraid me with levity and incontancy?

Thus mot jut Judge, you have heard the Requets which thee two Shepherds have made unto you: and to the end it may not be aid, that there was ever upon the banks of Lignon any Shepherds o ignorant in Love as thee; we do add our Requet alo, that they may be forbidden to uurp unto themelves the honourable name of Lover, of which they are o much unworthy; and for a punihment of their crimes which they have committed againt us, that they may b • forbidden ever to have the names of Doriea or Delphire in their memories: and that contenting themelves with having o long abued us, they may hereafter make their addrees ome other way, and practice upon others thoe apient intructions, which you in your wiedom hall give unto them.

Thus Delphire ended, and after a low congie to the Judge, he eated her elf in her place, in expectation of Dianas judgment. An univeral humming was heard amongt all that heard her: ome approved, and others di-approved of her reaons; but all in generall admired the excellency of her wit, and the modety wherewith he poke: and becaue Diana thought that none had any thing ele to ay, he began to ask the opinion of the Shepherds and Shepherdees in private, when Filintes and Androgenes tood up, beeeching that before judgment they might be heard, becaue they were as much intereted in the buines as any. Diana then itting down again in her place, commanded Filintes to peak for them both; and when the murmure was ceaed, he began thus.

div.head: The Speech of FILINTES.
div.p:
JF the greater Lovers be the wort peakers, as that fair Shepherdes aures us they are, then think it not trange, mot Wie Judge, if according to that maxime, Filintes ay but little of his love unto Delphire, nor of Androgentes unto Doriea; let not defect of language redound unto our diadvantage, ince from the parties themelves you hear, that we have loved Delphire and Doriea with o much affection and fidelity, as that they never found any failer in us, nor any remarkable fault. For my part, I began to love Delphire before Thomantes had any eyes to look upon her: and Androgenes erved Doriea, when Aphales by his incontancy hewed himelf weary of that glorious ervice. This firt affection like to the eldet on, deerves the greatet portion: and this lat of Androgenes, as a urvivor and a worthy ucceor deerves the etate; and though one of us was the firt, and the other the lat, yet both of us have ever ince we began lived in uch great obervance and repect, that we have patiently born all thoe favours, which before our eyes were done unto thee two incontant weather-cocks. I mut needs confes that pleen has omtimes made me conceive ome impreions of anger, and made me murmure againt thoe hard rigours, which that fair one made me uffer: but let her elf ay if he can, whether in my greatet fury, I expreed any action which was not all love? As oon as ever he cat her eye upon me, I returned immediately unto my duty; and what can this ignifie, but that my affection was tronger then her rigour? And Androgenes eeing Doriea prefer Aphales before him, he continued till with o much dicretion and fidelity, as is a mot trong argument that nothing could divert him from this love and faithful ervice. They ay that the dropping of water by continuance of time will wear the hardet marble, and will not a mot contantly continued ervice have as great an influence upon the marble of an inenible heart? Mut we be they who mut continually erve without any recompence? Mut we ow the ground, and reap no Corn? Will love be ungrateful only unto us? And can they be niggardly unto us alone who have erved with mot fidelity? Judge, what reaon or what Jutice is in this? Androgenes and I have oftentimes comforted our elves with thought, when without reaon we aw thee two Weather-cocks obtain recompences in lieu of thoe punihments which they deerved, that we mut think to fight and trive before we mut look to overcome, and groan a long time under pain and travel before we tryumph: but now we mut confes that two things do extreamly atonih us; the one is to ee thee two incontants, tryumph before they travelled: and the other is, that we cannot overcome the rigour of thee cruel ones, after o much travail, and o long a combate: and nothing does trike us into o much admiration, as the pretenions (not to ay preumptions) that Thomantes and Aphales have to hope, nay ask as their dues, to be loved by thee two fair ones; for if ever love had any caue to revenge the wrongs which are done unto him, it is againt them they ought to let drive all the arrows of his jutice, and make them exemplary unto all uch as abue the name of Lovers. I am atonihed Thomantes, that after you had o many favours from Delphire, the leat of which was enough to fix the heart of Mercury; that yet, as if they had never been done unto you, you hould be full of mitruts, full of reproches, and never atisfied: I cannot chue but admire Aphales, that when you went away, you went and was not loved; and that when you returned, you hould be in full poeion of Dorieas favour: was it not trange, that meeting her eyes, and Androgenes in a glas, you hould forget o many favours received, which could not be merited by you, nor any peron in the world? But the greatet wonder of all is, that after you both had committed uch high crimes, crimes which in Love are impardonable, you hould till dare to ask and pretend unto the ame favours, and the ame graces which you had o ungratefully didained. I am even ravihed with admiration to ee you dipute with them, and quetion who is in the wrong; but the wonder of all wonders is, that you durt be o impudently bold as to enquire of the Oracle, and to ee with what confidence you preent your elves
before a Judge to demand jutice. For if jutice be done unto you, what lee can you expect, then to be banihed from all places within the Dominions of Love; or rather condemned unto all punihments that ungrateful wretches do deerve. Thee, oh jut Judge, are the faithful Lovers, who after they were even loadned with favours and graces, did not only ungratefully fall off from thoe ervices, in which they ought to have continued until death; but have even corned thoe whom they ought to have adored; nay more, they came unto that height of ingratitude as to candal them, and contrive infamous Libels and Songs againt them: can you ever think that thee fair ones will ever endure to look upon you again without bluhes! O ye good Gods, in what an age do we live? Mut thoe that in and wrong innocents not only ecape punihments, but pretend unto recompences, and rewards? Fie, fie, unfaithful Lovers; leave it unto Androgenes and Filintes, to ask for recompences and rewards, for it is only we, that by the Laws of Love deerve them: and we do protet here before all this Company, that if Thomantes and Aphales be not punihed for their ingratitudes and infidelities; and if on the contrary Filintes and Androgenes do not receive recompence and wages for their affection and fidelity, then there is no hope that within the Dominions of Love, any wrong or crime will ever be punihed, or any benefit or virtue rewarded, ince thee highet degrees of inners do pae unpunihed: and we without recompence or reward.

When Filintes had done, and et down, Aphales and Doriea would have anwered for themelves; but Diana anwered, That ufficient information had been given already on all ides: and therefore, he took Alexis, Astrea, Phillis, and Sylvander a part, and asked their opinions concerning the difference betwixt thee Shepherds and Shepherdees: at lat, he returned again to her place, and pronounced this judgment.

div.head: The Judgement of DIANA.
div.p: LOve, as all things in the univere are, is preerved and perfected by motion and contrariety: and in as much as this motion cannot work upon things that are in themelves olide and table without ome exterior Agent, the motion and agitation which can preerve and perfect Love, which is of it elf firm and table, and requires another mover, and it is often times moved by jealouie; the daughter indeed of Love: but a batard, not legitimate, and yet almot ineperable. We do ee alo that it is from jealouie all thee trivial quarrels and petty dientions do arie; which by the ages are called Renewings of Love: but yet it is to be undertood, it ought to be the Mother, but no long the Nure: for if he uffer them to uck of her milk too long in lieu of trivial quarrels, and petty dientions, they will be changed into great divorces, and dangerous hatreds, which in the end will mot undoubtedly mother Love.

Now this difference before us, betwixt Delphire and Doriea on the one part; Thomantes and Aphales on another; and Filintes and Androgenes on another part, does demontrate thee everal orts of dientions and divorces. For betwixt Filintes and Delphire, appears only thoe petty and indeed amorous dientions, from which Loves takes a pleaing and acceptable trength and increae. Betwixt Thomantes and Aphales, towards Delphire and Doriea, appears nothing but thee diunions and dientions, too long nourihed by the milk of an obtinate jealouie, by which, if Love be not quite mothered, yet it is in the agonies of death, and gapes for breath: On the contrary, one may ee in Androgenes a patient ufferance, which may be upected of a little Love, without his pereverance, and continuing to love her.

Thee things being long debated, and eriouly conidered by us, unto whom the charge is committed by the voice of the Oracle, We do declare that Thomantes and Aphales have trangreed againt the Laws of Love, and againt that duty which they owed unto the name of Lovers, in nourihing o long thee dientions by their inconiderate jealouies. That Filintes and Androgenes on the contrary, have in all
their actions hewed a mot exact obervance of all thoe duties requiite in real Lovers. And in as much as impunity of crimes, and good actions unrewarded, are caues of ruine in all Etates and Republiques; We do ordain, by virtue of the power which is given unto us, that all thoe ervices which unto this day Thomantes and Aphales have rendred under the notion of Lovers and Servants, unto Delphire and Doriea, and that all the pains and inquietudes, which they have uffered in loving them, be taken as nul, and as if they had never been; not pretending unto any recompence or gratification for the future. And on the contrary, we do ordain, that the ervices which Filintis and Androgenes have rendred unto Delphire and Doriea, and all the pains, patience, and inquietudes, which they have uffered in loving and courting them, hall remain in force and validity, and erve them for the future, as of right they ought. Yet notwithtanding, ince repentance does almot by force exact a pardon, We do ordain, that if Thomantes and Aphales, do really repent of their crimes, and would love and erve Delphire and Doriea a new, they hall be obliged to receive and entertain them as new Servants and Lovers, who from this day forward do begin to erve them, and to hew their merits. And as to the four queries, which were put by Thomantes and Aphales, we do ay by way of anwer unto the firt, That a Shepherdes may without any offence unto contancy, uffer and permit, but not eek nor deire, to be erved and courted by many. Unto the econd. That this plurality of ervants not ought to nor deired, but uffered only, does not allow a Lover to have many Mitries, unles (which is not likely) they be uch as are only uffered, and not deired nor courted. Unto the third, That both the he and the he Lover, ought to live amongt all, but unto one only; imitating in this fair fruit upon a tree, which is looked upon and admired by many, but tated only by one mouth. As to the lat, that he does go beyond the limits of contancy, that does any thing which may offend the peron loved.

And to the end that for the future, uch an ignominious ignorance amongt Shepherds, may not be upon the banks of the River Lignon. We do will and ordain, that the aforeaid quetions and reolutions be written by Sylvander, under the Table of the Laws of Love, to the end they may be een in the Temple of the Goddee Atrea.
